reviews.review: Eye opening must visit when in Cape Town. My wife and I were in Cape Town recently and one of the things recommended to us by family who have visited is Robben Island.We booked for a 11am departure a couple of days in advance online via the official website (we booked via our phones and took a screenshot of the barcode tickets which were scanned on the day).The booking advises you must be at the departure point in the V&A Waterfront area a minimum of 30 minutes earlier than the ticket time but in reality due to the queuing process you could be later. After having tickets scanned you proceed through an airport style security check before going to the boat(s) to go across to Robben Island.On the way to Robben Island we were on the Jester boat which I believe is the larger of the two boats on the trip which is boarded first and is also by far slower at making the crossing taking over 45 minutes. There is downstairs enclosed seating but most people go upstairs up to the limit of capacity especially as it can be a bit choppy out at sea! On the way back we deliberately held back to get on the faster boat which though leaving a few minutes later than Jester made it back to Cape Town quite a few minutes earlier and it definitely felt a smoother ride.On arrival on the island you either go first for a bus ride around parts of the island and then have a guided walking tour of the prison or do the walking tour first then the bus ride.The bus ride is quite interesting and there is an opportunity for picture taking and a shop area to buy drinks and snacks though the highlight is of course the prison tour.The prison tour is with a past political prisoner on the island, this brings the whole experience to life hearing first hand experiences as well as seeing cell areas including Nelson Mandelas.It is a sad experience visiting the island with all the history it has but I do think a visit to Cape Town must include a trip here especially at the reasonable cost.

Fascinating place. Robben Island cannot be missed on a visit to Cape Town. It's important that we never forget what happened to our fellow human beings during the Apartheid years. To see the lime quarry and Mandela's cell bring out strong emotions. Being guided around the former maximum security prison by an ex political prisoner is also a memorable moment.

"Excellent in every way!". A former political prison did the tour and he gave great insight into the life on the Island. It's a must visit if your into the history of the Aparthied movement in South Africa.

The history of Mandella's incarceration is a sad time for South Africa.. A must see place to go to understand apartheid. Unfortunately going around the island on a crowded bus & visiting the prison with a very large group was not the best way to see it.

Ferry, Penguins, History. We went to Robben Island on the second week of October. It's cold so bring a jacket. You take a ferry which is called the "Jester". Be prepared because it's slow and not the smoothest ride but it is safe! Once we arrived at Robben Island we got into a bus which took us to the prison where Nelson Mandela was kept. We were guided buy an ex prisoner who explained the history of the jail. It was great. However the jail was newly painted and did not give the historical feel I imagined. We saw Nelson Mandelas prison cell and it was cool, not exactly what I expected. After the tour of the prison we got back into the bus and our guides took us around Robben Island and provided us with a brief history surrounding different architecture. We made a stop at a gift shop which was right beside a little beach that had penguins, you can't approach them as they are not friendly. Overall it was a good trip!

Fabulous afternoon ... Initially I was unsure I wanted to do this tour as my husband & and I are not great on conducted tours .How ever this was an inspiration and we were so glad we took the tour .The guides we had were both well informed knowledgeable and passionate and we felt they portrayed the events leading up to South Africa's struggle relayed in a nutshell .Alan our first guide was great and Kgotso Dede Ntselengoe our second guide was inspirational having been a political prisoner himself he enabled us to have a glimpse first hand as to how it was for him and the internees ..I would highly recommend doing this tour especially if you are lucky enough to have these two guides..

ALIVE WITH HISTORY OF STRUGGLE. Now guys this is where the gr8 Mandela was kept and many many more prisoners.....the movies which they show in the Robben Island Museum at the ferry site is so touching...u cud feel their pain...This place is must for those who love history and guide through the corridors of past life...an insight over the sacrifice of past which has been the fore-bringer of present happiness...Loved this journey and yes for not so History buffs...there the ferry ride...u could chance an encounter with a whale or a dolphin and definitely a penguin or a seal....Recommend take the 3 PM ferry..U will get to see a beautiful sunset...

True reflection of the apartheid times in South Africa. Great way to understand what the political prisoners of the time went through and how they experienced life in the prison. The queuing system at the beginning is a bit of a nightmare and be prepared to stand for over an hour.

Sobering history. Two pre requisites if you're visiting Cape town----Table mountain and here.Expect huge queues on the jetty pre boarding and re embarking for the ferry which takes about 40 minutes to reach the island.It's a shame you're not given much time or scope to wander round at will with your own thoughts as you take in the surroundings of the inhumanity of the prison.Frankly you don't need to be told everything the guide tells you on board the tour bus---it speaks for itself.Having said that, the former inmate who gives his spiel is endearing and informative as he shows you round the prison.A bit more organisation on the boarding proceedure and queueing and a bit less formal herding on the island would improve the whole experience no end.That said, it's not to be missed, the views alone across the bay to Table mountain are worth the trip, as is the rest of the island which,apart from the prison, idyllic.

Somber Moment - Great Visit. I am so happy I visited. The boat ride and from the prison were ok. It was a little rough at one point. The tour guide is an ex political prisoner. It was humbling to listen to the stories and realize how much these families lost during that time in history. We visited the prison cell of Nelson Mandela, the yard, the rooms for the general population. We also walked around the grounds of the prison then went over to the church.

A fantastic place to visit.. What a fantastic trip. So organised from boat, to bus, to "the long walk to freedom". Having a tour guide that was an ex prisoner makes it even more real about what the prison was like. So educational and interesting. It's a must go place.

Interesting Tour. We learnt so much from this tour, I am South African and I didn't know about the history of Robben island, all I knew was that Nelson Mandela was a prisoner there. The tour starts at V & A Waterfront where you board a ferry which takes you to the island. We were so lucky, we saw some whales on the way! Once you get off the ferry you board a bus with a tour guide, our guide was Mpho, he was very friendly and knowledgeable. The bus takes you all around the island to see the churches, the cemetery, the quarry's, the village (where ex-prisoners and ex-prison wardens now live because the work at Robben island) there is also a stop along the way if you should want to use a toilet or buy some snakes. The bus stops at the prison where an ex-prisoner takes you through the prison and tells you stories of how it use to be. The last stop is Nelson Mandela's old cell. On the way back to the ferry there is shops for souvenirs and snacks. A ferry then takes you back to V & A. Booking is essential, we thought you could just buy tickets on the day, but they were sold out, the only tickets available were for the following day.
Must go. When having a trip to Cape Town you have to see it's historic part, and there isn't better place to do so than Robben Island.

Actually a beautiful island to have been a prison. I was very shocked to see what a beautiful island this was to be used as a prison. The tour was great and was given by a former inmate. What is that for true to life experiences explained? It really helps you to understand all about apartheid and what really happened to people's lives.

Interesting place, but lack of organization. An important part of history of the country is closely linked to Roben Island. So it's a place that you simply must see! Even if it gets a whiff of pilgrimage. The guides are former political prisoners on the island. It makes their story touching and authentic. We lacked time for self reflection and to go around the field on our own. There is room for improvement regarding the organization to bus tours and guided tours.

A living piece of history, not to be missed. I visited Robben Island with my 6 year-old daughter in October 2016. We bought the tickets online a few days before, and the process worked smoothly. Before you embark on the boat you can view a series of very informative exhibits on the history of colonialism and apartheid in South Africa. The sea was a bit rough, so the boat trip was not great, but the visit to the island and the prisons were moving. I particularly liked the fact that it is a former prisoner who guides you through the prisons. It really gives you the feeling of experiencing a living piece of history.

Living history and heritage site. . President Nelson Mandela spend more than 18 years of his 27 years behind bars, it's emotional electric and takes one down memory lane. I recommend this place to everyone who want to know about the history and heritage of South Africa. You take a boat from the Victoria and Alfred Water Front in no time you reach this rich heritage spot. Memorable, emotional and tranquil.

Very Emotional and Inspiring!. Enjoyed the 1-2 hr ferry ride, look out for seals in the water, carry a hat on a hot day and lots of water. Cant believe Nelson Mandela endured cruelty and great inhumanity, but from it we can learn to never, ever treat others different because of their skin complexion.Sad but amazing experience.

A lot of Potential that is wasted. We had a family visit in October 2016.After the tedious process of ordering tickets in advance and waiting in line to pick them up, we waited again in line to board the boat (about 45 minute wait).The process of getting people to the island needs to be streamlined - there is no reason to be waiting in long lines when everything is so computerized.As to the experience.While waiting in these lines the time could have been used to give a much better tale and story of the history of the Island and the people who were imprisoned. There is a lot of work to be done.After a 45 minute trip - which is in very basic ships that you feel every wave (I recommend taking motion sickness medication), you arrive at the Island. Again, they could have used these 45 minutes to enhance the visit by explaining a bit about the Cape Town Port or other facts associated with the trip.On the Island you get on a very old bus. When the motor is running you cannot hear a thing. The so called tour guide was very poor with explanations that fit a kindergarten class at most. You make two stops, one at the coffee shop and one at the prison where Mandela's cell was. Here we were greeted by a former inmate - as a tour guide. With all due respect to the authenticity of having an inmate a tour guide the experience was clearly missed. Very basic facts and figures - no emotions or personal experiences what a missed opportunity.

School trip and historic background. It feels like your basic school excursion. It is amazing for first timers as you actually get to go into the cells and get a tour of the island. However, some little kids may get bored as there are no activities for them. There is a shop with trinkets but no restaurant for luxury dining. I'd just go there for educational and information purposes. Not a place to "hang out"

Worth the Visit. This is a very interesting tour topped off by the guide actually having spent time there as a political prisoner. However there is more to this island including its history prior to the political prison, its use as a sanctuary for a variety of migratory birds, and the island also has its own colony of the endangered African Penguin. The boat ride over can get a little rough in strong swells, however you might be lucky to see dolphins or even a whale or two. If the seas are too rough the trips will be cancelled. Book well in advance, this is not a trip you can book for in the day due to it always being sold out. Well worth it though.

Bad day to go. We were really looking forward to this trip. Unfortunately the previous day's trips had been cancelled due to the weather, so there was twice the normal amount of people on our trip. This really ruined to experience, as over 100 people tried to cram into the small rooms. The guide - an ex-inmate - had to shout very loudly so that everyone could hear him, and this made him very hard to understand. We left feeling very disappointed and cheated. Not the atmospheric trip we had hoped for at all. It felt very rushed and disorganised.

Robben Island. We were very disappointed with this experience. Hard to get tickets. Disappointing when we got there. Not very informative. Rushed. Tourist trap. If you want to learn more about the prison read a book.

An experience not to Miss. We travelled to and from Robbin island using the ferry. This is a good service and we saw whales and seals on both the outward and inward journeys.The coach ride around the island was guided by a really helpful and interesting young man. He clearly knew his stuff and was really engaging with the people on the coach who were of a variety of nationalities.We were guided around the prison by a former political prisoner of Robben Island. He shared his experience and gave witness to the time he spent there and the struggle for freedom. Nelson Mandela's prison cell is an experience that humbles in terms of the human spirit in adverse conditions.It is an unforgettable experience and it should not be missed if visiting Cape Town. It was also a surprise to me that the village on the island still has families living there and they have everything any other community has, except no longer a school, which I think is sad as the children have to travel by boat each day to Cape Town. The penguins are delightful as were the tortoises and we were lucky to see the Sacred Ibex that had migrated there for the season. So if you like nature this is also a good trip for you.

Important place to visit. We took the boat (not quite sea.. that day... very wavy)... about 40 min.. visit the main prison include Mandela cell and all the history there. the guide was one of the prison who arrested there for 7 tears... followed buy bus tour of the island and a boat back to mainland. all together about 4 hours.

BOOK WELL IN ADVANCE. A once in a life time must do..An experience i will never forget from the boat trip to the island.The guided bus tours to the lime quarry ,church,mosque,Nelson Mandela's prison cell.This tour is history of the struggle of people under the apartheid government.

Impressive and very moving!. The highlight of our time in Cape Town. We were much impressed and felt humbled by this experience. The guides working at the prison museum are mostly ex prisoners, which makes their story even more moving. Incredibly moving to see Nelson Mendela's cell. The boat trip to and from the island was fairly hair raising as there was a lot of wind, but even that turned into a special experience as a group of Nigerian people on the boat burst into a communal gospel singing session!

Just Okay. The ferry is very crowded. If you want to sit outside up top be sure to get there early! The bus ride around the island was the best part of the tour. When you get off the ferry you are directed to waiting buses. Our bus guide was wonderful. He gave us lots of information and was very knowledgeable. The prison tour was not so great. Unfortunately our prison guide was extremely hard to understand so after awhile we just stopped listening. In fairness, I guess some people were able to understand him but our ears were not used to the accent. It was humbling, though, to see where Nelson Mandela had to spend 18 years!
Overall. Definitely a must do...But a very sad sight...& you will leave the place affected emotional somehow...

Robben Island. Robben Island is where Nalson Mandela, and others were held as prisoners. It is impossibl to escape it as the waters are very cold with strong currents. The tour takes a couple of hours, and our guide was a previous prisoner.

Bring kleenex. A profoundly moving experience! A must do! Attended by adults and children of all ages. A testimony to the undying spirit of Mandela and many others. Tour groups are led by former "political prisoners" -- didn't take much to be a political prisoner -- and are very informative.
Humbling. It's such a historic place. The bus tour is informative and the prisoner that showed us around was just inspirational.

This should be on your bucket list!. Visited twice already - Only brave the rough winter seas if you are up for a bit of ectra adventure. Take a warm jacket as it can get quite chilly, even if it is a beautiful day in Cape Town. Very informative and you get to speak to actual inmates

Heart Breaking but worth the visit. I think that everyone who visits SA should take a trip out to Robben Island so that everyone can understand the brutality and sacrifices that were made in order to procure a democratic SA where all people are treated equally. Learning the history of apartheid in SA is pertinent so that evil of this magnitude is never perpetuated again and the current post apartheid challenges are not minimized.

Well worth a visit. Not as distressing as I thought it would be. A beautiful location.. We enjoyed our boat trip and even saw a spouting whale quite close to the boat on our return journey. We were shown around by an ex- prisoner which was quite a moving experience. Most of the visit was spent on a bus whereas we would have much preferred to have done more walking.

Awful. Will never go there again. Boat trip to Island was better then then the tour. The mandela jail walk just a few seconds of view. The guides stories was so misleading and very uncomfortable. Allot of overseas travellers did not like some of the guides comments. Sorry my kids will not go yo this island for any history lessons
Nice Day Trip (except for the hoardes). Great trip by catamaran to see Robben Island, but didn't like being hoarded with 40+ people. Also, hard to hear the tour guide with so many people on the tour.

Wow!!. We did the walk to freedom tour as well as the Robben Island tour.We loved the whole experience. It was a little uncomfortable on the walk to freedom tour when we were brought into a hostel with 2 young men cramped into a small room while 12 tourists stand over them listening to their daily life.. I did not like that part.We went to Robben Island shortly after lunch. Our bus tour guide was named 'Toyer' and bus driver was 'Andre'.Toyer was a fascinating and passionate bus tour guide who had been doing his 8th tour that day due to sickness on the team. He was fantastic and it was really interesting to see the history of the island not just the prison. Once completed we were given a tour of the prison by an ex prisoner. I really wish I caught his name. He was a fascinating, well spoken individual that had most people hanging on his every word.One social commentary that is nothing to do with the tour but what summed up parts of society today was when we were standing in the court yard where Mandela had his garden, a couple who must have been late 40's were strolling around the yard which I took to being exploring the history. On closer inspection it turns out these individuals were simply playing Pokemon Go as this fascinating ex prisoner gave real insight into Nelson Mandela and himself. It bugged me for the remainder of the tour. Either way well worth a visit.

Amazing Story. We visit Robben Island as part of a tour group. It was eye-opening and jaw dropping. We were taken on a tour of the facility (old prison) by a former prisoner. He was imprisoned there as a political subversive during the same time as Mandela. He was so knowledgeable. It was well-worth the ferry ride back and forth to see this place first hand.

An very educational experience.. Opens one eyes to the very special persons Nelson Mandella and his colleagues were, to so stoically endure 26 years of very harsh imprisonment there, and emerge all the stronger for it, and become South Africa's President. A person like him would be impossible to find from the present generations.
An interesting place to visit.. The boat trip to Robben Island is a good way to spend an afternoon if the weather is good. Trips may be cancelled if the sea is too rough.

A moving tour of the island and prison. The tour of Robben Island features a tour of the island and a tour of the prison where Nelson Mandela spent 18 years in prison. It was very moving to take the tour of the prison with a past inmate who was the guide. Very interesting half- day tour.

Sad part of the history. After 40 minutes of travelling by ferry, you will be for the first part transport by bus to different locations of the island. The guide will explain the role of the different building and the story of the island. They are few stoppage for pictures and taking fresh sea breeze. For the Robben Islands next to the pinguin there is a nice view of the table mountain. The second part of the tour is conducted by a former prisoners from the Robben Islands. He explains his story and the evolution of live in the prison.

The birth place of the new South Africa. Robben Island left me in tears and with an appreciation of what the human spirit can triumph over when tested with adversity. You really cannot appreciate the significance of this place in terms of influence over the history of South Africa and its journey to freedom until you visit and hear the stories of what happened from the people who lived it and this is what you get when you visit Robben Island. You start with a bumpy ferry ride to the island then jump on to a bus (which can be crowded) and you are driven around the island whilst your guide introduces you to the interesting history of the island, also the flora and fauna etc. Once you have done the bus tour you then visit the maximum security facility that held Mandela and other political prisoners. Your tour guide for this leg is an ex-prisoner which adds so much more intimacy and meaning to the tour. We had Sparks, a lovely and very genuine man who spoke simply and plainly about his time on the island. Remember that none of these guides are professionals - they speak from the heart and without training. The tours are quite full and there can be a lot of people but that doesn't detract from the quality of the experience. I would recommend everyone visiting Robben Island.
real life. wonderful 4 hour trip total includes ferry ride and taken around on bus , guide a ex prisoner for 12 years and so interesting . a must do

Historical. The trip to the island can be interesting. The day we went over, the swells were around 3-4 meters and the boat was rolling quite a lot. The tour starts on the wharf at the island with a drive around to show and tell the history of the island. On the driving tour, you get to see the town where the wardens lived, the quarry where the prisoners worked, the graveyard from the leper colony and other points from the islands history. Then, we were dropped at the prison itself. Our tour guide was a former prisoner from the F Block. He showed us the F Block where he was held, the A Block and cell where Nelson Mandela was held, the garden where Mandela had a plot and other areas within the prison compound. Very enlightening about the apartheid period.

What a Colourful History. We went over to Robben Island for the 3 hour tour. We were firstly shown through the prison by one of the ex political prisoners. What an emotional experience! Our tour guide described his experience of living in this hell hole and the terrible conditions he had to endure for so many years.We also had a look at Nelson Mandela's cell and the exercise yard in which he had hidden his famous book - Long Walk to Freedom.We then went on a bus tour of the rest of the island viewing the limestone and bluestone quarries.It was fascinating to listen to the colourful and mostly horrific history of the island from the early days when slavers used to call in to gather supplies to the time when the island was a leper colony and then a defence base during WW2.While having a coffee stop at a café we were lucky enough to spot a Southern Right Whale just off the shore.

A Must Do When in Cape Town. Robben Island is where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for eighteen years and is now a museum. A ferry leaves from the V&A Waterfront several times a day for those who have purchased tour tickets. We purchased our tickets in advance on the Internet to ensure we wouldn't miss out. If you are prone to sea sickness be warned that the older ferries can be quite rough, especially if you are on the lower, enclosed deck. Once on the island, the tour takes you by bus to see various buildings and the quarry where forced labour took place. There is a stop at a lookout with beautiful views back to Cape Town. The last stop is the cell blocks where you are greeted by a new tour guide, who is an ex political prisoner. He explains the living conditions, the reasons for imprisonment and a little about Nelson Mandela. It is very touching to hear the personal stories and see the sparse living conditions .Then it is back on the ferry to Cape Town..

Good trip. The trip is by booking and going to the island on a large yacht, and arriving after half an hour, it's a good trip to see the history of the country and the suffering of the prisoners and see some of them who are alive and storytelling and describe events, movement was by bus across the island and stop at important stations to explaining
A MUST SEE. I loved the boat ride over to the island. The guide was very knowledgeable and entertaining. Very sad and thought provoking stories. Makes it all real and puts history into perspective

Must see history. I think this is an important part of history to experience. You take a bus tour around the island, which is much bigger than I thought. At the end, a former prisoner joins you to give you a tour of one of the cells. Lots of great information and perspective. Even on a rainy day it was worth the trip.

Rubbish. Never even got to see it.The problem is it is such a popular attraction it gets booked up quite a way in advance.Herein lies the problem,we were booked to go on a Saturday,we got a text on the morning of the visit to say it was cancelled due to technical reasons.They can also cancel at a moments notice due to adverse weather.When this happens you have to re book.We tried calling the number supplied in the text but after 8 attempts with no answer we had to go to the booking office.We tried to re book for the following Monday or Tuesday as we were flying back on the Wednesday.The first available booking we were offered was the following Sunday.Now what they should do is when cancelling a trip those booked have until 1pm to have priority booking.Logical,but not to them.We were offered a refund but because we paid by bank card the credit would take 3 working days,meaning we had to fly home and hope the refund occurred.All this plus the staff were disinterested,unapologetic and not at all professional compared to Cape Town staff in general.
Informative trip. This is a great trip to understand the struggles during apartheid. An ex-political prisoner gave the tour.

Great tour. I'd read some negative reviews on this but we loved it. Cool ferry ride spotting seals, penguins and whales on the way over, crammed in a bus for the bus portion was ok, some I guess expect first class service but it was perfectly fine. Jama, our political prisoner guide was great, very humble and informative. Pretty cool seeing the big mans cell, but looks like all the rest in there. Definitely worth it.

Just okay. I was expecting more on my visit especially since our guide was a former inmate. I was hoping to get an inside feel about what it was like to be an inmate, the trials and tribulations he went through, etc. However, the guide mainly focused on the fact that the country is going through reconciliation and he was making jokes. This was at the jail itself. I will say that I enjoyed the first part of the tour when we were on the bus. The guide was very knowledgeable and gave a great overview and history of the island as we drove around and was great at answering questions.

Robbed island visit. If you like your history this is a must when visiting Cape Town,great little museum to look around whilst waiting for the ferry to take you across to the island very informative and the guide doing the talk was a ex prisoner sad but worth it.

Not worth it. The boat ride over was nice, but once you got there they put you on buses and drove you around the island. All they did was point out stuff and you could not get off - they did have one stop to use the bathrooms. Then when you get off the bus they show you the jail cell - there was a guy who spoke to us before hand and we all had a really hard time understanding him. Then after you walk through the jail, you get right back on the boat. The boat ride back was long - almost double the amount of time it took us to get there.

A must when in Cape Town. We were not really sure what to expect from this trip. But both my daughter and I really enjoyed the history behind Robben Island. We had an ex prisoner who showed us around and told us about the history and what happened to the men who were imprisoned here. The boat ride over was great and we saw penguins and seals. The only thing I would have liked was for it to have been a little bit longer on the island. By the end of the tour you felt the guide had to rush things because we all had to get back to the boat. Other than that well worth a trip

A Taste of S.African History. Again as in most attractions in or around Capetown , it is wise to pre-book your tickets. The journey from the Harbourfront by ferry took about 45 mins. where we boarded buses that had a guide give a strictly scheduled tour. Then at the maximum security block, where Nelson Mandela's cell was located we were then shown around by an ex-inmate of Robben Isl. The tour gave an interesting insight to the trials and hardships suffered by the detainees, but I felt the tour on the buses were too rushed and the ex-inmate was to emotionally affected to be able to conduct a more informative tour.

HISTORIC and BEAUTIFUL. It was a good trip. learning about the prison where Nelson Mandela was incarcerated. Aside from the history side of it, it is also a great place to see Cape Town and Table Mountain from afar.

Boat ride, penguins, springboks, great views of table mountain. Great half day out with boat ride, harbor and mountain views views. Saw African penguins, springboks, and enjoyed the bus tour with amusing and informative commentary but respectful of the story being told. The walking tour of the prison was a little tricky to follow and a tiny bit tedious for my attention span but seeing the cells was very cool. Had a fleeing look at the gift shop which looked pretty good but not much time for shopping before the boat returned. Would recommend this tour, BUT book in advance online other wise you are likely to be disappointed if you just rock up and they are sold out for a week.

If you do any trip in Cape Town so this one. My husband & I did the Long Walk To Freedom tour while in Cape Town for 4 nights. It involves a visit to the Apartheid Museum in District 6, a visit to a township and then a trip over to Robben Island. The bus tour around the island first had a very infomative guide. We then had a tour of the prison by an ex-prisoner Zozo (sorry don't know the correct spelling). Most of the stories he told were awful but it gave you a real understanding of what happened during Mandela's imprisonment there. Would thoroughly recommend it but you do need to book as it's very busy plus there is a chance if it's windy that the ferry will be cancelled. We were booked on the 1pm ferry and we were delayed by almost an hour, we discovered later that it was because they weren't sure it could run. We heard that the day before the 1pm ferry was cancelled and they couldn't offer our friends a new date until 3 days later and by then they'd left Cape Town.

An emotional must see. Departing from the V&A waterfront the boat tour is 30 to 45 minutes depending on the boat - you're then given a bus tour of the island with a stop for the view - then a tour of the prison with a former inmate. I found the last part had the potential to be very moving and informative but rushed and cramped with a large busload of people - would have liked time to read the information boards. Nevertheless well worth my time

A very humbling experience. Wow - this place is an absolute must to visit. The ferry ride out gives you the chance to whale spot, the views and tour of the island are excellently organised. Your tour of the prison is with an ex political prisoner and really makes the experience stand out. It was a pleasure to be in the presence of Sparks our guide and to learn of his experience and that of the other inmatesThe bus tour is a great way to see everything and our guide was again superbIt's hard to describe this place and what feelings you experience and are left with - you need to experience it as words are not sufficient in my opinion

Historically importance . We were lucky with our guides both for the bus and prison tours so had a highly insightful and meaningful visit, however, did overhear some other guides that seemed to be less informative. I think it's just your luck who you get, but would encourage everyone to make the trip to the island for its historical importance and of course the views.

Interesting tour - but could do with more info. This was a really interesting tour that was split into a bus trip round the island and a tour through the prison with a former prisoner of the island. I felt the only drawback was that there was an assumed knowledge about the island and the reasons people were put in prison. They could do with going back to basics and telling you a bit more about why people were imprisoned there. Perhaps some bitesize facts on the boat across would be a good way of doing this?It was excellent being shown round by a former prisoner though it must be incredibly difficult for them to return there. Definitely worth doing if in Cape Town.

Too rushed. The views of Table Mountain and Cape Town are excellent and it is definitely worth visiting Robben Island but we found the compulsory tour quite rushed and would have liked more time on our own to explore the prison and island.

Amazing experience . To get to the island you have to catch a ferry to the island, it takes about 50 minutes. Be mindful the sea can get very rough. When arriving at the island, you board a coach and go around the island with a guide. You are then dropped of outside the prison where a former prisoner will walk you through the prison and and share they're experience. You will then walk the long road to freedom back to the ferry where the experience finishes.

Apartheid history in an emotional setting. After a somewhat rough boat ride, our visit to Robben Island proved to be a historically important and emotional experience. Visiting Nelson Mandela's tiny cell, where he spent many years as a political prisoner, was eye opening, and best explains the horrible history of apartheid in South Africa in a practical way. The guides (including actual former political prisoners) were excellent.

Get to ferry early!. The ferry left 10 minutes before scheduled departure. Tour was interesting, but unfortunately, the former prisoner who took us through the prison was very difficult to understand. Our tour guide told us that people had similar experiences when taking this tour.

My Heritage. It was an emotional experience for us as we learnt more about our history. We never got the opportunity to meet Tata Nelson Mandela and other heroes but going to Robben Island taught us a lot about the experience they went through.

Rushed History. While I liked Robben Island for its historical significance, there simply was not enough time to appreciate it. The ferry ride was longer than anticipated and then you take a bus tour of the island. This was all well and good but left no time to read the information on the large signs. The presentation by the former prisoners was very enlightening. Then after visiting the penguin colony it was back to the boat. Tickets were hard to get on short notice.

Unmissable . Make sure your Cape Town trip includes a trip to Robben Island. Part of the tour includes a presentation by a former political prisoner. I'm sorry I didn't catch the guide's name but he wax fantastically charismatic and candid. My tip would be: take a picnic.

Great Visit... . We booked our tickets in the reception of the Jetty in the V&A the day before our visit.On the day we took the boat crossing wonderful views of Table mountain and Cape Town. On the island we were taken to the bus which takes you of the tour of the Island the guide was very knowledgeable we stopped at the quarry where the prisoners worked as saw the pile of rocks started by Nelson Mandela even saw some penquins. We then were took to the prison and met by a political prisoner who was at Robben Island for a few years.He gave us alot of information how life was in the prison and took us to Nelson Mandela prison cell. The crossing back was really nice and pleasant this is a must if you are staying in Cape Town.

Authentic tour from an ex-prisoner . The ex-prisoner, as tour guide, gave really authenticity to the tour- he was charming ;his personal stories and descriptions of prisons life and the long fight against apartheid kept your attention and you couldn't feel anything but sadness and admiration for the freedom fighters! I was a bit disappointed to not actually go inside any jail cell, just to get the feel of what Mandela and each prisoner must of felt. Footprints would be a nice addition to walk in their footsteps. The tour around the island and scenic views were great. Options for bicycling would be better! Guide on bus was also very knowledgable and entertaining. The stop at the quarry no longer allow you to get off the bus:(

We could not get tickets! So disappointing! . We had 6 days in Cape Town. On day 2 we tried to book tickets - but there were NO tickets available for 6 days! So we missed out! So disappointing! Book before you arrive .

Tour group of 108 people and one guide!. Having had high hopes for this supposedly must-see activity, we were left disappointed. Rather than the group of 10-20 people I was expecting, two tour buses of 54 people were assigned one guide for the "interior" part of the tour. Sure, it's a great idea for ex-prisoners to give the tours, but our guide had to shout - and with a strong accent, it was very difficult to understand what he was saying. With so many people, we had to rush around, wait for people to catch up and jostle (or rather, be jostled) for position to see anything. It would really have helped to have a short film or audio guides (on the ferry ride perhaps) to really understand what we were looking at. The information on the walls while waiting in the queue cannot be digested in time. Being such an important living monument to something of huge historical importance, it is a shame the tour does not educate people in the way it could.

Plettenberg Bay 'Robs' Robben Island Rating. Probably, this UNESCO World Heritage Site and South African Heritage Site deserves an 'Excellent' rating But after the 'Ocean Safaris' in Plettenberg Bay, we kinda thought that the ferry to Robben (Dutch for Seal) Island was simply Okay. Of course, you pay a lot more to Ocean Safaris as few hours of excursion also includes Whale / Hump Back Whale and Dolphin Watching together with watching more Seals than one could have seen (or Imagined Seeing) at Robben Island. Definitely worth if it's difficult to include Plettenberg Bay's Ocean safari into your intinerary.

Interesting history in a pretty locale. Robben Island is actually quite pretty and a pleasant place to visit, despite its long history as a prison. The guides were good, providing a tour that included the entire history of the island, both good and bad. It is obvious the current caretakers care about the wildlife, the land, and the history of the island. Well worth visiting.

Incredible experience travveling in history . It was super interesting to have staff on the bus tour of the island + having time to visit the prison and I even had the chance yo meet of the prisonner of the time Mr.Nelson Mandela was there.It was really and amazing experience for me. A big THanks to the staff who was really good.

A living museum of the apartheid days.... Famous as the place where Mandela was imprisoned for years, it is a bleak reminder of a bygone time, and a man who could have emerged bitter but became a healer and national leader. Interesting tour by former inmates who knew because they were there.

Good historical day for the kids. The long walk to freedom can be fully understood if you take this tour of a life time. My two kids aged 13 and 9 wanted to learn about Nelson Mandela and this is a good place to start. We learnt a lot from our tour guide Jama and left with the message of forgiveness.

Average. We had to take a ferry to Robben Island. As soon as you reach the boarding area you are rushed into the queue as the tickets are pre-booked and they get edgy about the timings. You hardly get anytime to look around and read history.The ferry was fully booked and the seas were rocky resulting in sea-sickness for many. It was quite hot outside and we had to board a bus which took us to the prison where Nelson Mandela was held for years. We were taken around by an "ex-prisoner". Later on we heard all the guides claim to be ex-prisoners. He had heavy accent and if someone asked him to repeat he would get cranky. Some people from our group commented about prisons on Andaman Islands in India and the severity the prisoners faced there was extreme, the guide was offended and I wonder if he showed us everything he was supposed to. The place was packed with tourists and somehow the boisterous behaviour of few robbed the place of the sanctity.Rest of the island tour was by the bus with a stop at a cafe. You can click good photographs here. If you have2-3 days in Cape Town, you need not waste time here. Go to Apartheid Museum/City tour.

Do not miss this historical tour - it will help you learn the history if you do not already understand it. It does help if you know the history of the struggle against apartheid, but you can catch up during the tour. I found it obscene that people were taking selfies outside Mandela's cell rather than contemplating the significance of the place they were visiting. You are taken on a bus tour before visiting the prison - there is no food on the island but one place where you can gets drinks. There are great views and photo opportunities at this stop, including Cape penguins and Table Mountain. At the prison you are taken around by a former inmate. Previous reviews have listed the tour details - it is rushed and shorter than you might like. I was told there are plans to improve the tourist experience and give tourists more freedom to walk around. There are displays at the jetty but no time to read them all. The organisation of the tour prior to embarkation was chaotic, but ignoring that, it is well worth the effort. If you are on a full day tour of the townships and Robben Island, it is a good idea to take a packed lunch in case your guide leaves you at the quay at the last minute - our group was lucky to grab a sandwich in the quayside cafe before embarking.

Very commercial, but an impressive tour guide. Robben island was not what I expected of it. Not sure what to expect either, since it is a place of great history, not one of SA's finest to say the least. Although the first part is very commercial - everyone hops on a bus and drives around looking through the windows of the bus to see the several historic land marks of the island. Bit disappointing since I was looking forward to take in more of the heritage in open air instead of sitting in a bus with 49 other people. The second part of the tour felt more real since our guide was an ex-prisoner who made a very strong, proud and positive impression. The way he talked about his past, SA's past and where we are at now, amazing. How such a man can stand in front of so many people everyday and talk with such pride. Amazing! I feel very privileged to have witnessed just a small part of his story at Robben island.

Disappointing and could be so much better. Like most visitors, we were organised when arriving at Cape Town with our tickets already purchased and were eagerly anticipating this to be one of the highlights. We had visited the Apartheid Museum in Johannesburg - which was fantastic, including the permanent exhibition on Mandela - and so felt we had a great overview of both the history of Apartheid and the man. It was a beautiful crisp early Spring morning which augured well for our ferry trip and the views back to Table Mountain were superb. What we didn't like was that immediately on entry we were herded onto the ferry like cattle. There was no time to read the information on boards before showing our ticket. On arrival we were shunted onto buses where our guide gave us a history of the island. This was clear and concise and if we hadn't had him for the first part, I would have felt decidedly ripped off. When we arrived at the prison block, we were rushed through - the guide - a former prisoner - spoke very quickly and was difficult to understand and was not a sympathiser of Mandela. (Was this because he had to run back to find a key to open the cells- don't know.) Had no idea what was Mandela's cell because the group was so large and by the time we got them, the guide and half the tour group had already been and gone. I guess we were lucky that the weather was good and we didn't get sea sick as well. Unlike the Apartheid Museum where I came out with empathy and emotion, this all left me cold and my recommendation? if you only have 3 days in Cape Town as we did, I would not spend 4 hours doing this tour. Highly recommend the Free Walking Tour of Bo Kaap or District Six instead.

See it Only if You Understand the Political Conflict. Its well organized with the ferries out the island. It will take around 30 to 40 minutes. Once you arrive you will get on a bus. Each bus will have a guide and drive around the island, explaining its history for about 45 minutes. After your drive is over another guide will walk you through the prison explaining how the prisoners lived. This will take about a half a day for the entire tour.

A must see!!. This is an island that is well worth the visit. You not only get a beautiful view looking back at Table Bay (especially if it's a clear day) but, you get an inside look at the place where Nelson Mandela spent many, many year.

Will make you realize value of Freedom!. You realize the value of freedom the moment you land at this place. It's a prison converted into a museum, and the place where Mr. Mandela was kept for 36 long years! The guides are all ex prisoners and have tales to tell about each section and cell. A must visit place if you are in South Africa. It's recommend that you pre-book tickets as the place is accessible through ferry and they have limited number of tickets each day. You will need about an hour to reach there, about a couple of hours touring the place and about an hour to come back, so be prepared to block half a day for this. I would recommend going their early morning else the place becomes quite hot as you will have to walk quite a lot in open and will be taken from ferry jetty to the prison in a non AC bus!
a must in cape town. it was very interesting to listen to the background information and stories told us by an ex inmates.

Go while you can still get the authentic experience. The total round trip tour to Robben Island takes about 4 hours including the crossing (up to 45 minutes each way on the slower boat). You are met at the island by a tour guide who shows you the sights of the island that is now only inhabited by museum staff and their families. A key part of this tour is the limestone quarry where prisoners worked in all weathers with no eye protection from the sun's reflection on the stone. There is a pile of stones that was started by Nelson Mandela and his fellow ex-prisoners when they returned to the island for a poignant reunion. But the real tour starts when you are met at the prison gates by an ex political prisoner who will show you the prison but also give you his own personal story. What these men went through for their cause to right the injustice of apartheid is humbling and should not be forgotten. But go while you can hear it from their own lips and not from a tour guide.

Unique Experience. It took about 45 minutes on the boat to get there and almost everyone was incredibly sea sick by the time we arrived. The actual tour of the island was great and a very unique experience. It was very surreal.

Fascinating history, but a little depressing as well. It was fascinating to hear all of the history on the island. Your guide is a former political prisoner, which makes it even more interesting. Take the cataraman over from the V&A waterfront...it's faster, smoother, and nicer.
Great wholistic tour. Great tour that provides context on the history of the island and the history of the prison. The tours sell out fast so buy your tickets in advance online.

Rushed tour could have been better. Torrential rains shortened our tour, which was unfortunate but also provided a weirdly appropriate backdrop for such a depressing place. While our travel agent bought our tickets several weeks in advance, you can get them a few days before by dropping in at the museum at the Victoria and Albert Wharf. I wish we had spent more time at the museum, there appeared to be a lot to view. The tour of Robben Island felt very rushed (no doubt due to the weather; our group was the first and only one before inclement weather canceled the rest of the day) and our tour guide - a former prisoner - didn't seem very comfortable talking in front of people.

Moving Experience. Visiting Robben Island far exceeded my expectations. It is like visiting history and the stories of the life of Mandela and other political prisoners in the island are fascinating and very moving especially when the tour is given to you by a former political prisoner. We need to learn from history and I hope history never repeats itself with such a monstrous system of injustice against a group of people discriminated just for their skin color. Love Trumps Hate
Very interesting. An interesting experience but as there were so many people there we felt we were herded from place to place with no time to actually look at anything.Good boat ride to the island

A must see for anyone interested in social history. This trip is to a living museum. The island still houses the original jail facilities where both criminal and political prisoners were held. You are firstly taken on a bus tour of the relevant parts of the island with commentary by very well informed guides. You are then left in the hands of an ex prisoner from the jail who explains first hand what the whole experience was like. You need to visit whilst these guys are still alive totell their stories. There are also ex guards who work there and the thing that really hits home is the lack of blame and resentment between the two groups. The final stage of the trip takes you past the cell where Mandela spent 18 years of his life which really drives home the reality of what he and others went through

Lots of history but lost on the organization of the tour.. We were excited about the opportunity to take the ferry over to Robben Island and learn more about the history there. The ferry was packed and we were packed on to buses when we arrived. It was difficult to hear any of the guides providing either history or processes. The bus stopped at one point and we were given 10 min to get off and look around; although for those of us sitting at the back of the bus we really only had about 5 minutes; therefore did not get to see what we stopped for. Once we were off the bus and at the prison we were excited to hear that our tour would be given by a former political prisoner; yet due to the very large number of people in our group we could rarely hear him or the stories he was sharing. It was so unfortunate as the concept of learning more of the history of Robben Island was at the top of our list of to do's in Cape Town. I would still recommend going over, but be prepared to be moved through like cattle. Overall, disappointed in this tour.
2nd time. My second time doing the tour and I still enjoyed it an learned more history from the different tour guide. Highly recommend!!! Mandela was one of a kind!!

Good but parts of tour a bit hurried. We enjoyed the ferry ride over to the island and back. Once there we walked to the prison with a guide as the bus was already full. The prison tour guided by a former prisoner was very moving, but felt more time could have been spent in areas other than Mandela's cell. After the prison tour, we then got on the bus for what would normally be the first part of the tour around the island. The bus was pretty cramped and it was difficult to hear the guide even though we were in the 4th row. I understand that many people would not want a longer tour with more information, but I think that would be a nice option to offer.

When the Cons Outweigh the Pros…. When I say cons, I’m not talking ex-convicts. I’m referring to the negative aspects of this tour. There are really only a few, but they are significant and impacted the entire experience:1. While in concept, the opportunity to have a former inmate give a tour of the prison is a good one. What better guide than one that can share his personal experience? Unfortunately, that’s where the brilliance stops – at the concept. Who you get as a prison guide is random. When you get off the short bus ride over to the prison from the boat, the former inmate who is now your guide gets not half the bus to tour, but the entire bus. Already, the size of the group is a problem because the guide’s voice must carry loud enough for all of us to hear. However, even if your guide could project loud enough, it wouldn’t matter when the guide’s English is difficult to understand. Our guide’s English was heavy with an accent. He also spoke in broken sentences, talked in circles, and often repeated himself. While I don’t know if it’s a cultural thing or not, but his attitude also came across as pompous. It was off putting. It became immediately apparent that tourists whose first language was not English were giving up on trying to understand our guide. They were breaking off from our group and sitting down wherever and whenever they could. This infuriated our guide. The tour felt long and drawn out because our guide also talked incredibly slow. Nelson Mandela’s cell was saved almost for the last part of the tour. Our guide spoke little of Mandela and by the time we got there, we couldn’t wait to catch the next boat out. How incredibly unfortunate. We spoke to our other friends who visited the island on a different day and had a different guide (we checked) and their experience was the same. They could not understand their guide. 2. The boat ride over and the boat ride back. If you are prone to motion sickness, be prepared. There are two boats that are used. The older boat is one of the original boats used to transport the prisoners. While we appreciate the historic significance of the boat, I don’t need to actually experience what they did. It was a rough ride. While none in our group got sick, many of us were in a cold sweat and close to it. What’s annoying is on the ride back, we got a newer, faster boat. The waters were still rough, but it was a much more tolerable ride. Nonetheless the motion sickness had set in and ruined the rest of the day for us. 3. There are large billboards throughout the prison of prisoners in organized group photos. Other than listing the names of the people in the photo, few billboards explained the significance and purpose of the photo. Now the pros….and I’m stretching here, just to balance it out:- The website is well laid out and has helpful information. - The ticket purchase process was extremely easy. - The option to save the ticket on our smart phone for scanning purposes is convenient. - The building to which you catch the boat ride over is large and easily accessible, located in a great area. - The bathrooms on the island are clean.- The bus ride over to the prison was the BEST part of the whole excursion because the guide on the bus was articulate, funny, engaging, and informative. (The lime quarries, wow!) - The second best part was the quick rest break before the prison to grab a quick coffee or snack and take pictures across the waters to see Cape Town. There are a few penguins along the shore as well. Dear Tourism Board, if you’re paying attention, I know there’s contention to keep the former inmates as the guides. I completely understand and I still think to have them as part of the tour is valuable. Take note that even places like Choeng Ek Genocidal Centre (The Killing Fields of Cambodia), provide audio headset tours. What a better option to provide English and non-English speaking visitors a chance to learn the island’s great history. The tales of former inmates can be included in the audio narrative and it would also be great to have former inmates available after the tour for an optional meet and greet and Q and A. That’s my 2 cents/27 R.

Well worth it. Really knowledgable guides on this tour, both the main guide and the ex political prisoner. It gives you a really good insight into the conditions on the island for the prisoners and the comradery between a number of the inmates.Definitely worth a visit to learn about that period. If you suffer sea sickness take some pills for the ferry, it can be choppy!

A must do in Cape Town!. The island is located about 30-40mins by boat. This was a great tour done by a bus when you arrived at Robben Island. After the bus drive you are dropped off where the main jail was where a former prisoner of Robben Island walked you through parts of the prison where they were kept, showered, slept and spend their days. It was an such an insight to the hardships all these men had to ensure back in those days and is a must do for anyone visiting. Highly recommended.

Moving experience. The tour of Robbins Island was very interesting and moving. Make sure you take the more modern boat over if you get easily sea sick. One boat was very smooth but the other very, very bumpy....people getting sick!

Tours led by former inmates. This was a very unique experience as I knew before we went a little about the history but never expected to learn from a personal perspective of someone that was held there. Our guide was exceptional, he used a delicate approach to teach us about the horrible experiences of the inmates but somehow made it an overall enriching and not so depressing experience. We were glad to hear his personal experience and he answered many questions from our group. On a side note the island is covered with rabbits and penguins....the former was brought in as a food source and multiplied out of control.

Visit with the ex-prisoner brings it all to life.. A must do experience and you really get a feel for what it must have been like up to 1991. The tour of the island could be better with more stops / free time but the prison tour with an ex prisoner is inspirational. Do it.

Good tour . One of the places you shouldn't miss out on when in Cape Town, to see the place where Nelson Mandela had been incarcerated for 18 years. The boats depart about three times a day and an approximate 35 minutes ride will take you to the island. For people who are prone to sea sickness, I would advise to take pills beforehand as the sea can get quite rough. Once on the island, you will be asked to proceed to the busses quickly. You will be given a live narrated tour of the island which is more than just the actual prison. After about 15/20 minutes, there will be a break with the opportunity to use the bathroom or buy some refreshments (hot and cold drinks, sandwiches, candy bars, crisps). After the break, the bus tour continues until you get out at the prison. Here another guide takes over who will show you the interiors and especially Nelson Mandela's cell. He will also tell you more about life in those days as the guide himself is an ex prisoner of Robben Island. I learned a lot from this tour and liked the way it was conducted. The whole activity takes 4 hours including the return ferry ride.

A must see when visiting Cape Town.. Well organised tour, no time to wonder around by yourself. Tour was packed and very crowded, couldn't sit next to my better half on the bus part of the tour. Take along your own water and snack before you board the boat. I have full understanding and immense sympathy for the unjustly jailed political prisoners, however, I thought the conditions, diet and work were laid on a bit too much. Prison is prison after all
Beautiful island. Island win political prisoners were held. Peaceful clean island. The prison has been restored. Somewhat disappointing

Designed for tourists - not impressed. As a South African, I was frankly disappointed and felt the trip rather exploitative. I realise and witnessed that for many visitors this is an essential visit but let's say that I have my doubts about a number of things mentioned. I actually went to the Island when it was a functioning prison.

Absolute Must Visit. I so enjoyed my visit. I wished there was more time to walk around. You are pretty much limited to the time allowed by the guides.As soon as you arrive on the island, you go to the buses and they take you around to various sites and you finish up at the prison, where you are shown around by a former prisoner. Of course, Mandela's cell is the highlight.A tip is to get your ticket in advance. Some friends did not and could not get tickets on the day as they were sold out. You get your money back if the ferry is cancelled.A real highlight of my visit to Cape Town.

Thought provoking.... Wonderful bright sunny day to take the ferry over to Robben Island. Breathtaking scenery including sightings of seals and whales. The guides on the island were very interesting and informative. Sobering to see the conditions black and coloured political prisoners (the different treatment of both groups) endured and gain a glimpse of their lives. In awe of the fact many ex-prisoners and guards now work together on the island. Definitely a must do trip if visiting Cape Town!

You have to go ..... The trip over to Robben Island takes 45 minutes so be sure to take sea sickness tablets if you tend to get queasy. The trip itself is quite fun - we saw seals and lots of sea birds. Once you get there you are put on a coach and taken around the island which was far larger than I'd expected. You are then taken on a tour of the prison guided by one of the ex-prisoners. My only criticism of the whole day was that we found our guide's accent very difficult to understand; I think the other visitors whose mother tongue was not English found it totally incomprehensible. This was a shame as we didn't really hear the history of the place. Nevertheless, the effect of the prison is quite sobering when you see the conditions in which prisoners were kept for so many years. A place you have to go if you're in Cape Town.

A Must Visit. Along with Table Mountain, I cannot imagine a visit to Cape Town without a visit to Robben Island. The tour is conducted by a former prisoner who offers a very unique insight into what it was like to be imprisoned on Robben Island. A fun ferry ride as well!

very organised and felt authentic. Several buses tour you around the island which means the group size is very good and you get to see everything without getting worn out, making it accessible to all ages. Inside the prison we were met by a former resident of the prison itself! He was a lovely gentleman who did well to provide an unbiased view of what it was like, but at the same time offering his insight. It wasn't heavy like I expected until you see for yourself the cell that Mandela stayed in, and see the lime quarry the prisoners were forced to dig - we were not allowed to take flash photography of the former prisoner as the lime work had affected his tear ducts! The buses stopped at a nice viewpoint where we could buy refreshments too.

Highly recommended. My experience to Ruben Island was emotional and very historic my tour guide was very knowledgable with the museum as he was a serving prisoner many years ago. Very highly recommended place to visit if you visit South Africa Cape Town
Must see. Must see attraction and brings you to reflect on all of the things human beings do to each other. However, surprisingly less moving than many other similar examples that I have visited.

An interesting morning. Boat trip to the island takes up to an hour, then you are taken on a bus tour to key places and guided round the prison by a former prisoner. He was very interesting, though it wasn't always easy to understand all he was saying. Views back to Cape town were good. It was definitely worth going. It would be good if there was more freedom to explore yourself - perhaps they will get round to offering bikes for hire and a self-guided tour

Average trip!. If you are limited to only a couple of days in Cape Town than I wouldnt waste the 4 hours to do this again. Yes it was an experience seeing where an icon of the modern era lived for so long, but apart from seeing the cell, finding out a few facts, I cant say it was that great! Alot more exciting things to do in Cape Town!!

Mother/ daughter. Unbelievable, and gut wrenching. Very humbling place to go. Our tour guide was once a prisoner on this Island. The tour guide on the bus was great, and to see where Nelson Mandela spent so many years and his cell takes your breath away. Everyone from all Nationalities should see this.

Powerful history. We followed the suggestion of the travel guides and booked our tickets approx 3 months in advance. I think this is more important for travel in the South African summer. Allow yourself some time to review the exhibitions at the building at the Nelson Mandela pier. While there is some information on the walls of the room to access the pier (and the Robben Island ferry), it's hard to read them when the room is full of people waiting to travel out. The tour is split between tour of the island (given by a resident) and a tour of the prison, given by a former political prisoner. Very moving.
Mindblowing. 3 hours very well spent. We found Robben island to be fascinating and very educating - a must visit for anyone visiting Capetown.

Interesting but Not Top 3. First, tickets are hard to get. I had limited time in CT and didnt know this tour sells out fast. I could not get tickets on line so I just went down to the dock. They also said tickets were not available. But then I made a discreet announcement inquiring if anyone in line had extra tickets and 5 people raised their hands. So if you really want to go and are not shy, there will be space for you. It a bit of a cattle like experience, but I wanted to go to get a deeper understanding of the culture and history. From that perspective it was excellent.

Emotional trip. A really rough trip over to the island which we really enjoyed. The history of the island was very interesting but the emotional part came when one of the prisoners of conscience showed us around the prisoner's quarters. Surprised and a little disturbed at how many people were laughing and taking selfies.

If history is your thing this is for you.. I found this to be a totally enthralling experience. The boat ride across was picturesque, and on the day we went, quite pleasant in terms of the sea. I have heard however it is sometimes not for the feint hearted. Once your on the island the tour is in 2 parts. The first on a bus with a very knowledgeable guide who shows you the pertinent spots on the island and gives a good insight into the overall goings on there and where things happened. The next part is even more interesting as you are shown around by an ex-inmate who tells not only the story of Nelson Mandela and some other high profile inmates, but is in the position to give you the benefit of his own personal experience. A great half day trip for the history buff. Don't be fooled into thinking you may miss the boat back as they run all day and you can apparently get any one back. It is apparently best to go early as more often than not if the sea or the weather gets bad it is later in the day.

Must visit this place. We took the ferry to Robben island on a drizzly day. The water was choppy but we made it safely. When we got off the ferry we took a 45 min tour around the island before being dropped off at the max prison where Nelson Mandela spent 18 of his 27 year sentence. The tour of the max prison was done by a gentleman who actually served in that prison for 5 years. He explained what they went through and how they lived. It was very well done. We then walked down to the ferry and took it back to the waterfront

Rushed tour with no time to take in the atmosphere. Pre booked the boat ride out to Robben Island, luckily it was a good morning on the water, but very foggy. 45 Minute slow boat ride, that would be shocking on a bad day. Herded off the boat as soon as it docked, shoved onto 45 seater busses, the bus doesnt stop anywhere, you are expected to take pictures from inside the bus and the seating is 3 wide at the back, so no good views. Drive around for an hour, only place you stop is a little cafe and told to take a 10 minute break which turns into 1/2 hr because so many of you on the bus. Then dropped at the jail, rushed through a tour packed with other tour groups, then have to quickly walk back to the boat as the horn is blowing to say its leaving for the day. Not worth the trip over to get 10 seconds of a view of Mandella's cell.

Very interesting. Went here with 8 people for the day. The boat trip was pleasant but can get a bit rough some days. The tour of the island was first by bus and then a guided walking tour of where Nelson Mandela's cell. Was very interesting.

Must visit. We went there and great info from ex prisoner who explain his suffer at the prison.we Saw Nilsson Mandela cell.we took the boat 30 minutes when we r going and the ferry while returning (50 minutes).

Book in advance!. A somber place. A must see stop on any trip to South Africa. It is both awe inspiring and disturbing to truly comprehend what the place represents and the importance of the people interned here.

A great learning experience. The trip starts with a que at the ferry terminal, but this is well managed. The ferry is clean, quiet and fairly quick. There is a video of the island's history running to keep you entertained. The tour around the island is by bus with a knowledgeable guide. What could have been a highlight is the tour of the gaol with an ex inmate, unfortunately we had trouble understanding our guide and he was more focused on a political story than his experiences.

Go.. Just go. The island and the prison are more important than the pretty stuff in central Cape Town. Tour guides are very informative. The whole tour takes about 3.5 hours, with the boat rides taking about 45 minutes each way. This location is essential for understanding recent South African history.

This is a must do activity whilst in Cape Town!!. Me and my sister visited Cape Town for 2 weeks inc a 3 night safari stay. Out of all the trips we went on, this was the best trip ever! The whole day is really well organised and you forget that you are visiting an actual real prison due to the way the day is planned. You will get a ferry boat across to the island and join a coach which drives you around the island with stop offs to take photos. The best part is that the tour guide is a real prisoner who used to be inside the prison and is now working for the island - how fantastic is that! This trip is so well priced for you get out of the day. Truly wonderful!! You even see Nelson Mandela's prison cell and get close enough to take a picture and touch the cell railings!

Very Emotional. What a great experience. Full of history and emotion. The bus trip around the island and the goal tour were very special. The two hours on the island was not nearly enough time to take it all in.

A step into History. This is the most amazing experience as it is very tactile. You get to walk through the cells that held political prisoners and for a few minutes experience a part of what they had to endure for a long time. Hear the stories that kept them alive and not despondent. Experience the cell that Mandela occupied. A worthy trip.
Sobering. This is a sobering experience to visit the place Mandela was imprisoned. I felt I learned more about prison than Mandela.

Have to go - Simple. You cannot visit South Africa and not visit Robben Island. The trips are well organised, good value for money, educational and the prison section of the tour is given by an ex-prisoner. Great experience and very though provoking for the kids - be prepared for questions from them afterwards.

A must to do to experience the trials & tribulations of political prisoners such as Nelson Mandela. This trip gave me an insight as to the hardships of being a political prisoner during the apartheid era. Seeing Nelson Mandela's tiny cell gave me a sense of nostalgia and gratitude to man who spent so much of his life in captivity just to be released & forgive his enemy, going on to be a world renowned leader & Nobel winner.The guided tour is sentimental & authentic as it's done by ex prisoners.Suggest choice get a day with calm seas as one can book rather easily.

Slightly disappointed . This was a highly anticipated part of our trip but I have to say I was slightly disappointed. The tour starts with a 40 minute bus ride of the island itself which in doesn't really add anything. The later part of the tour involves a walk-through of the prison itself. This was obviously the highlight of the tour as you're guided by an ex-prisoner. It was a bit of a shame as this part of the tour was a bit rushed and our guide spoke so quickly with such a large group in the tour that we missed large parts of what he was saying. It clearly depends on who your tour guide is but I have to say I felt the tour of the prison was rushed and not as informative as I would have liked. Our guide spoke so quickly that I didn't even know which cell belonged to Mandela! Still worth a visit however!

not worth all the fuss. 45 minutes on a rough sea with lots of people trowing up just to visit Nelson Mandela's prison cell, for me not worth going through all the trouble of getting there.i visited Museum of distrikt 6 in cape town, there you can find everything there is to know about apartheid

Robben Island. We were fortunate and had a smooth ferry trip across and back. The bus trip around the island was interesting, but it was the tour of the prison itself with a former political prisoner that I found enthralling, confronting and thought provoking. If you are interested in history (and this is recent history) my recommendation is go and see for yourself what people can do to each other and tell a country it's the right thing to do.

A trip into Apartheid. Tour provided good background for prison that held Nelson Mandela for most of his years. Use of ex prisoners as tour guides excellent. Tour was educational and good value for money.

Well organised visit. On the first boat to the island which took longer than expected. Once on the island the tour was at good pace with a rest place for food and drinks. The prison tour was fairly quick but there was time for questions. Quick boat back to the mainland.

Best experience ever. Came to Cape Town and had to visit robben island. Best experience in SA I have to say. Thoroughly enjoyed it! Well worth money and day. The boat there is a bit cold so ensure you bring a jacket. The tour itself was well planned and we had true ex prisoners and people who had been through the experiences taking us round which was great! We got to ask them questions and take in the island. Overall a great day. Would recommend

Excellent morning. Time well spent to learn about apartied.. The trip to Robben Island can get a little choppy if the wind is in the wrong direction - take a waterproof jacket!The actual trip around the island was very informative and the ex-inmate made it all very real.I would recommend anyone visiting Cape Town to make the effort to visit Robben Island as you will regret it later if you don't.

Good piece of history, with intense and informative tour.. The trip to the island is 45 minutes each way, with choppy waves. The bus tour and prison tour are well worth it though. The focus is on Mandela of course but you learn about other inmates and general knowledge too though. Also has a great view of Cape Town from here, good photo opp.

Cape Town High Point. Our recent visit to Robben Island was one of the highlights of our visit to Cape Town. Apparently there are some boats to the island that are faster than others. Our cruise over and back took an hour each way with the entire experience totaling four hours but it was worth half a day.The start of the island tour focuses on the general history and it ends with a conversation with a former prisoner. Know that there are cancellations if the water is deemed too choppy.

A needed reminder . Lest we forget the journey this country has been through, Robben Island makes for a great refresher course. It was a very educational experience; the beautiful views bring a blalance to the sombre mood. A must see for tourists.
One of the must Visits. One of the must visits while in Cape Town. The place makes one feel how racism affected people in Africa.

Meaningfull but little value . As South African the tour helped me empathise even more with the prisoners . as a tourism destination the communication from departing to return was poor . The crew on the boat were unfriendly and not helpful . For a 50 minute Susan Kruger ride without snax or drinks, for me was unacceptable.
