In comparison with free ferry from Manhatan to Staton island with all amenities ! No ATM available , or card puchases at halfway stop - why not warn us ? My kids were starving !! Then we driving in a buss with broken door . Why not develop a kids prgramm and play activities and a restaurant ? Table mountain has ? I would not recommend this other than the historic value - otherwise you waststi your money .

Must-see. Our visit to Robben Island felt like an important pilgrimage to my 8 year old daughter and I - we were still reeling from an outbreak of racist attacks across the UK in the wake of the Brexit result. It felt so important for my 8 year old daughter and I as Brits to visit Robben Island in August 2016 and remind ourselves of how far racism can go and how hard people have fought, how much people were willing to suffer to break the Apartheid system. The subject of Apartheid is covered at school in Year 5 (Age 9-10) on the UK National Curriculum - the children read Journey to Jo'burg by Beverley Naidoo. We read that book and also watched the Mandela film starring Idris Elba the morning before we set off. The journey out to the island on the Ferry was haunting - we left a Cape Town with blue skies and temperatures of 24'C, but found Robben Island in a bank of damp bitterly cold mist. It is a miracle that with this perishing wintry microclimate the inmates, sleeping on thin mattresses on the stone floor equipped with one thin blanket each didn't die of pneumonia within a couple of weeks. It was a privilege to be guided by a political prisoner who was a contemporary of Mandela in the 70s - we will never forget meeting him and hearing him speak of his experiences.

Excellent day out. We spent 2 weeks close to Cape Town and did much on the "must do" tourist list but the Robben Island trip was easily a highlight. You purchase the boat trip and tour as a package - (it doesn't appear you can wander around the island independently.) It's wise to arrive in plenty of time for your allocated boat (sailings in August were at 9.00, 11.00 and 13.00) because the boats are very full and so choice of seating limited. Also the tours are so popular that if your time in Cape Town is limited it would be wise to book well in advance ( can be booked on the net). After landing on the island we were asked to join buses parked 100yds or so from the quayside and were taken on a short tour round the island guided by an amusing commentator. At the maximum security prison, where Mandela was held, we were treated for over half an hour to a fascinating talk and tour by an ex prisoner. His clear explanation of what life was like for political prisoners such as Mandela and himself was delivered with such calm reflection and with not a shred of bitterness. It was very moving and an experience I shall never forget. The cost was around £18 per person and having left on the 11.00 boat we were back on the Cape Town Waterfront just after 15.00. The views of Table Mountain on the return journey are outstanding!!

Worth the visit. The tour in Robben Island starts in a bus, where a guide tells us some curious facts about the island and its prisioners. Quite hard to understand the english, the accent is very strong, although i am assuming the guide was an native english speaker.The highlight of the tour is the guided visit to the prision where Mandela stayed. Our guide is a former prisioner and it makes the diference.The boat that takes us to and back from island is big, which is good for those who suffer with sea sick. Anyways, for those people it is always better to take the first boat in the morning (9 am), as the ocean is calmer.Tip: online the tickets are very limited, but if you go to the office at Waferfront the day before you intend to do the tour, it is very likely you can get tickets for anytime!

Very Interesting viist. Two main attractions at Robben Island, the prison and the African penguins. THe prison isof ourse a historic siite with many stories. Yu lear about Nelson Mandela and you can visit the different areas of the prison incuding the celll where he stayed. Vistng the areas where the Endangered African penguins breed is another big attraction.

Invaluable History Lesson. We bought our tickets in advance on line. Easy, cost effective. Ferry departure is easy to find and well organized.Robben Island is an excorted tour. You are bused around the island then given a tour of the prison. Emotional.Important if you want to get to know South Africa.

Bridge to the past. On the boat ride to the island; I couldn't help but think about how Nelson Mandela must have felt traveling to prison. While it really made me think about the sacrifice that Nelson Mandela made for South Africa; I was left longing for more. It was great having a former inmate as a tour guide but I felt they could have done more to enhance the experience. My visit there may not have been all that I expected it did indeed spur me to learn more about South African history and the part that the prisioners of Robben Island played in that. It is worth the visit but keep your expectations in check!

Fascinating experience. This was a thoroughly fascinating tour. I found it different from any other tour I've ever been on because we had the benefit of hearing from a former prisoner. He gave us a unique and open account of the harsh and harrowing realities of his time on Robben Island. One negative comment is that the tour felt a little rushed and I would've like to spend more time on the island to read the historical information on display.

A Must Visit. A UN World Heritage Site, one recognizes South Africa's past and the courage of its African peoples in their struggle for human rights by visiting this former prison. A very moving experience, especially if one has taken part in demonstrations in one's own country when Nelson Mandela was imprisoned there to demand justice and freedom for Black South Africans. The struggle continues, not only in South Africa but in all countries shaped by the forces of colonialism and contempt for Indigenous peoples.

Forever in my Heart!. This was a very emotional experience for me. To learn of the history from the locals was very meaningful. Sometimes the news media will not give a correct description of what has happened. The tour was guided by a former prisoner of Robben Island! I thoroughly enjoyed the knowledge shared and to have the ability to walk the grounds of the prison and see the actual cell that housed Nelson Mandela.

Immersion into humans best and worst. This is a must do tour to get a better understanding of the Apartheid and human nature. Nelson Mandela and many over political prisoners were in this Robben Island for over 20 years for fighting racism and abuse of power. In the end they won. Guiding the visit to the prison was an ex political prisoner who shared his experience and what landed him there. It was really impressive to hear him tell his story. I couldn't help but think that every day when he leaves the gates behind he must breath a bit easier!It's a good trip to do with kids as they can enjoy the boat, the occasional penguin and running in the court yard.

Inspirational A must....... If you visit Cape Town this is a MUST! I have visited this island twice. It is a central part of world history with it's inspirational call for freedom and human understanding. The guides are very expressive in their deep knowledge of the history, due to their personal involvement. This provides a deep understanding of the immense sacrifices that were borne, especially in the lime quarry. Each part of the island has its own story, so the trip provides a deep perceptive of life under apartheid.

See the prison where Nelson Mandela spent 18 years. A sobering experience to see the inhumanity that the political prisoners suffered under Apartheid. The boat ride to the island can be rough for those prone to sea sickness.

Thought-provoking tour of Robben Island. I'm glad we took the time to travel out to Robben Island during our recent stay in Cape Town. It was thought-provoking, interesting, educational, and at times a bit sad. We particularly appreciated the final part of the tour with one of the former inmates, who really brought to life the terrible reality of being imprisoned there during apartheid. I asked him why he'd want to return to the island after that experience, and he said essentially to bear witness to what went down, so that people would always remember, and perhaps try to prevent something like this in the future.

Memorable visit to Robben Island. The tour of Robben Island was very moving to say the least. Some of the previously held political activists that were jailed during the Apartheid share their experiences of their time under Apartheid and their many years in prison. Our guide of the prison really made this trip personal hearing of his personal struggles to achieve freedom for all South Africans. A definite must to visit while in Cape Town.

Robben Island (offshore from Cape Town) definitely worth the visit. Boarding the boat to Robben Island is somewhat chaotic, but we all got onboard safely and the boat itself seemed very safe - even with several hundred people on board. The boat trip to Robben Island takes about an hour (each way), and then our tour around the island and through the prison areas took about 75 minutes. On the boat trips, we saw whales, many THOUSANDS of seabirds of maybe 6 species, and hundreds of seals on the island itself. That was just about worth the price alone. The tour on the island, and through the prison areas, was very moving and an eye-opener. We had one of the former political prisoner inmates as our tour guide, and his matter-of-fact description of what went on there last century was a graphic eye-witness account. It was both very disturbing and also a privilege to listen to what he had to say.My tip would be - be sure to be self-sufficient in water and food for the round trip.Overall - just excellent. I thought it was worth every dollar.

Guides were great! . The tour itself could be done so much better as its a place that deserves to have people understand and appreciate what went on! The two guides we had were great, really knowledgable, passionate and enthusiastic! The overall your was unorganised and almost thrown together with most tourists having no idea where to go between the boat and the tour! Also at the end no one had time to look at the gift shop (not my thing so wasn't worried) but they have obviously made an effort have the shop but not allowed for time at the end of the tour for people to visit!

Do this first when you visit Cape Town.. So you might be wondering why I have suggested you visit Robben Island first when you visit Cape Town. And this is not because of it great historical significance, which it is, but because you will get the best views of Cape Town and Table Mountain when you're on the boat going and coming from Robben Island.Even in the winter months this is a popular trip so I would suggest you book your tickets online in advance, You print your tickets out at home and present them at the entrance. I was asked if I had tickets to sell when we arrived so you can see how busy this tour is.You catch the boat at the Waterfront (the building is well marked on maps). Go a little early as there is an interesting exhibition to see.There are appear 2 different types of boats, one larger and slower (45 minute trip) and a smaller faster one (30 minute trip). You may see some seals as you depart but the highlight are the fantastic views and photo opportunities you get on the boat trips. The smaller boat had an open upper deck so lots of viewing ares and the larger boat has great views from the rear as you leave Cape Town.When you off load on the island we were divided into groups of about 20 and met by our guide who was a ex-inmate of the prison. Undoubtedly this is the best part of this tour in that you hear real life experiences.Its a short walk to the dormitories and then onto the individual cells which held the more important prisoners including Nelson Mandela. There is no plaque outside his cell as we were told he didn't want any special recognition for his cell, but there is a bucket in it which differentiates it from the others. Some people do complain that it has become a bit sanitised but it is a tourist attraction now and the highlight is actually the stories your guide will tell.(in our case it included is arrest, torture and incarceration here fro 5 years).There is plenty of opportunity to ask your guide questions.After the prison tour you board a bus with a different guide and are then given a tour of the rest of the island, which has a long and colourful history well before it was used as a prison for political prisoners. (e.g.whaling station, leper colony, naval base). You also get to stop at the quarry but are not allowed to disembark here.The bus will stop at a viewing point at the north side of the island and there is a great photo opportunity of views towards Cape Town and Table Mountain. They have one of those Instagram frames as well. There is a small shop here for drinks and snacks.At the harbour there is a shop for some souvenir shopping and if you don't get a chance here then there is a shop in the main building at the waterfront.In all like I said, if you can do this trip first before you do the rest of Cape Town.

Humbling exeprience. Amazing exploration of South Africa's dark period. Humbling to see the prison where the heroic ANC freedom fighters were held and brought to life by our guide himself an ex political prisoner. The capacity of the people to forgive was what amazed me most. I felt privileged to have visited this place and walked where Nelson Mandela and his comrades had been!

Very moving experience. After a bus tour of the island we were taken to the high security prison complex and met by an ex innate who's name I am sad to say I don't recall. He was imprisoned for 5 years at the age of 24 as a Uni student for demonstrating against apartheid. Our guide toured us around the complex giving us insights into his time there and the cruelty inflicted.It is a terrible reality that the apartheid regime ended less than 30 years ago!!!!

Can't avoid the sense of history, but could be done so much better!. Went to Robben Island in June and it's fair to say you cannot avoid the phenomenal history it offers up and it is still worth a visit for that reason alone. There are some fascinating artifacts and some compelling images on the island and it's a very grounding experience. Worth knowing though that you are very much shepherded around the island with little room for exploration. I can understand why they do this but it does feel like you're rushed from place to place, without even a mention of a toilet break. The organisation of the tours could certainly be improved to provide a better experience. Obviously extremely touristy so be prepared for crowds.

It's ok. The total time needed for a visit is about 3.5 hours including the boat trip and very few museums are worth that investment, including this one. You are guided around throughout so there is little option to go at your own pace. So, it's "ok" if you have time free and don't mind being guided.

Eye Opener. Robben Island is a must for all who visit Cape Town. Its hard to put it into words, but its definitely worth psending the money (for South Africans its quite expensive). The tour guides are all very interesting and smiley, and to think that you meet an actual ex prisoner at the end of the trip is mind blowing! We were lucky to get a very sunny day. The boat ride is quite comfortable and I didnt get seasick which was a bonus.

incredible. our trip was delayed due to bad weather but when we did reach the island it was incredible. having a bus tour of the island and a guided tour around the prison it was a moving trip. Seeing how the prisoners live was amazing a great day out. On the way out we even saw some seals!

You have to go here. Over whelming, so glad I went there, did this on my last day in Cape town. You must reserve your boat ride/ tour at least 3 days ahead of time. this bit of information is important, especially if you plan to go with the flow, and not book things. I almost missed this, did it on my last day and flight left that night. this tour made my trip to south Africa, you will learn so much and it left me speechless. this tour is a must!!!!!!!

Does not honour the legacy. A real disappointment. So much history to inspire respect from us visitors yet completely spoiled by shambolic organisation. To start, the boat transfer was awful. The bots are not well presented as to see the crew completely disinterested in seasick children leaning over the back of the boat without any restraint in a choppy sea was nothing short of gross negligence. Then, on a rival, being rushed on to coaches - no time for a toilet break - and families being split up set the tone for the visit. The experience at the prison and the tour of the island were truly memorable but such a pity that the organisation ruined it.

For people who want to understand South African politics and sacrifice. This tour gave a really good insight in political history and how the ANC leaders lived during apartheid. The first guide was passionate and gave us good stories. The old ANC inmate gave me the impression that he had done this lecture too many times. Anyway you must visit Robben Island to understand the history of South Africa. Just do not go home with the last ferry from Robben Island - it does not leave until every tourist has been found and is on the boat!

The time flew by . We were a bit concerned when we discovered this was a 3.5 to 4 hour trip. Would we find it a drag? But we needn't have worried - the time flew by. The boat trip was about 50 minutes each way, the bus tour another 45/60 minutes and the guided tour of the maximum security prison about another hour. Breaking it into chunks like that maintained our attention easily. As with others, the real highlight for us was hearing from a political prisoner also held at Robben Island during (some of) Nelson Mandela's incarceration there. That really brought things to life. I still can't get my head around how anyone retains his sanity having spent so long in a 10' by 8' cell, though...
John. Greatest experience learnt a lot about S A history and the S A way great changes well done S A to a new experience

A must if you visit Cape Town. This is one of the main reasons we came to Cape Town. In all honesty it wasn't on a par with our visit last year to Auschwitz, which was more moving, but it was still well worth going to learn about the history of Robben Island and how we continue to make each other suffer.

You must go. You will need to book in advance but this is easy on line. This was the most poignantmoment of our holiday. The guides give you a wonderful perspective on the struggle against apartheid and an ex political prisoner will take you around the prison complex where Mandela and the other prisoners were kept. An experience not to be missed.

An absolute MUST if you`re in Cape Town.. Haunting experience of man`s incredible inhumanity towards his fellow beings. Hear about the prison from former inmates who tell everything, warts and all. The beauty of the island and the boat ride is overshadowed by the histories of the men who survived the brutality meted out to them by the apartheid regime.

A door into Soth African history. Take the boat fronm the V&A waterfront. The sea is always a bit rough and it may have to wait for a few days for the weather conditions to be good enough as the weather is changing all the time in Cape Town. Beautiful pictures to be taken of Cape Town from the island. very emotional when you go stand in Mandela's cell. I really liked the facts taht we are given some time to ask questions and all the guides on the island are previous inmates.

Needs some work. Ferries are dirty. One was very slow. 11 o'clock departure means 11:30. Ferry ride is not 10 min it is over 30. The bus ride to the prison was informative. The prison tour guide was difficult to understand. There needs to be some overhaul done. It could be so much more given the history there.

Thought Provoking Experience. A short ferry ride from Cape Town waterfront and you arrive at Robben Island. Once on the island you are bussed around the island with a local guide describing its long history before and including the Apartheid period. The bus terminates at the prison where a former inmate takes you on a walking tour through the prison sharing his experiences, most of which are confronting to say the least. Nelson Mandela's cell is viewed during the tour. Following the tour a 5 minute walk takes you back to the ferry for ride back to Cape Town.
Mr Farouk Khan . Very organized, very friendly, very informative, a must visit for anyone who has that chance, I was overwhelmed.In that short visit I learned som much , unbelievable.
Poignant tour. A must-do trip when in Cape Town. Gives a great sense of how much Capetonians have endured and yet shows their unbelievable hope and courage to heal the country. Bravo!
Nice. This is great place wth great history too bt very emotional. Almost burst into tears seeing how the people lived on that island

Absolute "Must Do" in Cape Town. The visit to Robben Island is a must do for visitors. First class departure facilities and ferry. Top staff. The island visit experience is really interesting, informative helps gain a better understanding of the complexity of South Afrixa and frankly quite emotional, The part of the tour guided by a former prisoner is very moving.

Piece of History. Visiting Robben Island is a must for any history lover or anyone interested in human/civil rights. The island tour (be sure to book online early as tickets do sell out and ferries are cancelled due to weather often) takes you around the island by bus with a stop at the prison. While Mandela was held at this prison, the tour does not focus on him and his life but does show you the cell. As long as you do not go in with the expectations of learning about him, you should find the tour of the prison very interesting as it is performed by former inmates. Overall a great lesson in history.PSA: If you are visiting the prison, please be respectful in terms of not eating or smoking on the premises, not letting your children run around unaccompanied while the guide is talking, and not taking a million smiling selfies in a place that should be treated with respect and reflected upon.
robben island. This is an amazing attraction. The view is unbelievable. You must go when it is clear. So plan on in the morning, and if not, go in the afternoon. Amazing pictures.

Robben Island. Historic place to visit. Nelson Mandela used to be in jail on this island. Tour is interesting and informative. There is also the Penguins to visit and the view from the island looking back to Cape Town is absolutely spectacular !

Amazing history . To be shown a prison by someone who was incarcerated in it is amazing, the insights the stories, etc, make the visit incredibly insightful
A must visit when in cape town and the boat ride was fun

The sad truth of segregation. Poignant tour of the island that hosted among many Nelson Mandela for 27 years.
The guides who accompany you in the path are former prisoners, who know very well the history of the places that hosted them.
Listen to the voices, sounds, heartbreaking stories of those who lost everything to follow the freedom of his people.
Really strong experience.

well worth a visit. the whole trip took 3-4 hours and it was really interesting. We took our teenage Sons who also really enjoyed it. You have a tour of the island and a talk by one of the prisoners that was there with Mandela. You also get to see his cell. Amazing views of Table Mountain as we had great weather too

Not what I was expecting. The tour involved a drive around the island which was very interesting but there was no chance of getting off and exploring. The tour of the prison was great as it was conducted by an ex-prisoner. This way you could feel the emotion the prison caused within the prisoners and made you appreciate it in a different light. The experience was brilliant but I think you need to know a little bit before going and the tour was not long enough, it felt like you were herded around the area as quickly as possible.
Historic and eye opening!. This should be a mandatory stop for all visitors to Cape Town. A fantastic experience with learning opportunities and connection to recent historical events.

Awesome place to visit - a must-do experience. We booked on-line well in advance based on other reviews. Make sure to get in the line early if you want an outside seat - our vessel was limited to just 23 on deck. All others had to sit inside. We were met by coaches on arrival which took us on a well-narrated 45 minute tour if the island. We then had an eye-opening tour of the jail given by an ex-inmate. His tales of what went on gave us a hint of what it must have been like. The reality must have been many times worse. I don't know if we were lucky but both our guides were very clear and graphic in their accounts. All in all it was the highlight of our visit to Cape Town.

Emotional. Obviously, there's a traffic jam at Mandela's prison cell! But the highlight of this experience is the guided tour by a former inmate and his talk about forgiveness. It's an emotional experience. Especially looking over the water and knowing there could never be, had never been, an escape from this prison once an inmate is committed. Parental advisory - the stories [on the wall] include accounts of rape and other acts of cruelty.

Worth a trip. Still worth a trip. Takes a whole day, the boat ride was alright, not much of a comfort. It is worth hearing the first hand experience of history from guys who were jailed and tortured at this place. They bus you around the island, you can see some penguins and seals by the beach too.

Emotional.... Difficult to review purely as a leisure activity due to the content of the tour being that of the recent and painful history of the nation. However...Ferry crossing from V&A Waterfront takes between 35 mins to an hour each way. On arrival at the island the tour commences with a guided bus tour where the history of the island was outlined with a quick stop for pictures of the view of Cape town. The second part of the tour is a walking tour, where you are shown around the prison by a former political prisoner who is able to provide a human face and personal perspective of the history of the prison. Its emotional but well worth a visit when in Cape Town.

Fantastic Day Trip. A very well organised and moving tour of Robben Island. Our tour of the prison was with an ex in mate, in prisoned as a teenager for protesting while at university. We visited in July when the weather can be changeable and the boats over to the island were cancelled the day , so if this is a must trip for you and you are visiting during the African winter dont leave the trip to your last da just incase of bad weather.

Interesting but a little rehearsed. The tour includes a drive around the island and then a walk within the prison, led by an ex political prisoner, with a quick toilet and refreshment stop between the two. Both the bus guide and the walking guide were knowledgeable, friendly and happy to ask questions. However, some sections do feel a little scripted as they have told the same story many times. The ferry over is short and comfortable enough. The end of the tour was a little delayed so people were basically chased back to the boat which probably wasn't everyone's idea of fun!Overall it was definitely worth a visit and good use of half a day

A Must Visit. Very enjoyable ferry ride to Robben Island with great views leaving Cape Town harbour. Trip around the island by coach with good narrator. Then off the coach to meet with ex-political prisoner who gave informative & moving talk and then a viewing of Nelson Mandela's cell. A visit to Robben Island is a journey to recent history that cannot be allowed to ever happen again.

Informative. This tour was both informative, well run and done with dignity. Would recommended it to anyone visiting Cape Town. The guided tour by an ex political prisoner gave really meaning and insight to the tour.

A unique and unforgettable experience.. This can be an uncomfortable place to visit -- not the tour bus or the potentially choppy crossing. But because this unique former leper colony and prison is so irrevocably connected with the history of the nation. There was so much suffering and exploitation here. Yet out of the incarceration of political prisoners came the emerging first step of democracy. The guides are former prisoners who speak with humility and are dedicated to the evolving nation. Book your trip in advance to avoid the queues. That, at least, is luxury. But you will be unsettled yet uplifted by the whole experience. Thi is one of th most significant visits you can make.

Pleasant island and interesting history. Surprised by how beautiful island was with penguins, steenbok, tortoises and other wildlife. Interesting bus tour guide. Ex-prisoner talk valuable as has experience of being there but quite strong accent quite difficult to understand - may be best to give less information and talk slower so can follow more?

Mixed feelings. The trip over to the island and back in a large, fast catamaran with ample seating is very good. A commentary would have been appreciated even if it was just pointing out the obvious points of interest. The organisation on the island is a bit confusing, no proper instructions given. The tour of some of the prison cells is amazing. The tour guides are ex-prisoners and that added an amazing dimension to the visit. Based on the above I would be tempted to rate the experience a 5/5 but for the bus trip tour of the island. It was terrible. The bus is far too crowded and you are not allowed off to look at the sights so you see very little. The buses are old, dirty, smelly and billowing diesel fumes.The commentary was mostly unintelligible. The tour guide seemed to be having a good time but the visitors were bored. I couldn't wait for it to be over and it is far too long. Overall I would not recommend this trip because of the bus tour and the excessive time taken where you stand around doing nothing or just sit and wait on the bus.

So Glad I went.. When my travel agent scheduled this trip, I argued that I really did not think I needed to go here. She said "yes you do" and pushed to keep it in the itinerary. She was right. We learned so much and had a tour guide who was actually a former prisoner with Nelson Mandela on that very island. Wonderful educational experience and I am glad I went.

Inspirational. You must visit Robben Island if time permits, but make sure you book your ferry crossing slot in advance. We travelled in S. African winter but still needed to book 6 days in advance for the time we wanted.You get there by ferry, and you need to remember that the sea is not predictable. We were okay as we are well used to travel on water, but there was a fair swell on the return crossing which some found uncomfortable. Also, you cannot miss the very strong fishy smell as you arrive, probably a combination of the nesting sea-birds and the seals.Once you get off your ferry you will have a bus tour of the island. We had a really good guide called Kent (or Kennet or similar) who was compulsive listening. He explained the life and time on the island of Robert Sobukwe (read 'How can Man Die Better') as well as Nelson Mandela. We were told the history of the island from first colonisation and subsequent use as a leper colony, as well as its more well-known use as a prison.The second part of the tour is a walking tour, where you are shown around by a former inmate. Ours was good, again, but the group was a little bit on the large side and you couldn't always hear what he was saying (so don't hang back).The gift shop is good, but the food and drink supplies are limited at best, so plan to eat before or after your visit. We didn't have time to walk and see the penguins, which was a shame.Overall, a day not to be missed, but probably not for young children who will require a little more stimulation, and it would be a shame for them to spoil it for others (and that's not their fault - they are kids after all!).

Interesting and emotional tour. this is a must do for anyone interested in South Africa's history. The best part of the tour is being shown around the prison by a former inmate and listening to the stories of a survivor. It's emotional, thought provoking and I opening and well worth making some time for.

Very moving and informational. I had visited Robben Island in 2003 when in Cape Town on business. Wanted to return with my spouse, and the experience was even more impressive the second time. Visiting the prison with a guide who was actually a prisoner adds a dimension that increases the impact on the message of forgiveness! God bless Nelson Mandela and all who suffered to bring justice and freedom to all South African people!Don't miss this experience if you visit Cape Town. Be sure to buy your tickets 2 weeks in advance to assure your visit.

Great tour with loads of information. We took a ferry out to Robben Island where we had a bus tour of the island, saw how people used to live there etc. Then we were greeted by an ex-prisoner which was our tour guide for the prison. He told us the details of his imprisonment, his day to day life and answered questions of his time there. It was fascinating to hear his experience first hand. I highly recommend this.

Interesting and thought provoking place. Large boat takes you over. You then get split into groups on buses to tour the island, you then meet an ex inmate who shows you round the prison. Our guide was a sweet guy but unfortunately we could understand very little of what he said and he seemed unwilling to talk about himself. I guess we were a little unlucky. Boat ride can be rough!

A moment of truth. We had a team building visit at Robben Island. Our tickets were bought on line 3days before. When we got there everything went smooth, we were then directed to the check point leading to the boat to the Island. We were all excited. The reception by personnel at the Island was so professional and warm. The tour began from the cells, by the time we got to the hall, it was clear that everybody was shocked with the first hand information we got. We were then taken on a bus tour . The few minutes we spent there, was a true eye opener, Hence I say that was a moment of truth. I wish every South African can have an opportunity to visit Robben Island, especially the younger generation. Given a second chance, I will not hesitate to visit the Island again.To the staff, keep it up. You are a brave team.
Worth A Visit. We had limited time in Cape Town and were going to skip this but friends told us not to miss it--they were right. It's very moving. Takes a full afternoon there and back.

Not for young kids. Even though the history of this place is worth knowing, it's not for young kids, once you arrive at the island you have to get into a bus, they drive around he island while a guide tour gives you a detailed explanation, it takes around fifty minutes which seemed like an eternity with a six year old that wasn't interested at all. Visiting Mandela's cell was moving and the ex-prisoner testimony was humbling but I wouldn't recommend it for kids younger than 12.

Humbling but incredible!. I highly recommend this but make sure that you book in advance by at least two or three days. We went on the 13.00 boat so that we could let the mist burn off in the sunshine. There are also boats at 09.00 and 11.00. The boat trip takes 25 minutes each way and the entire thing lasts four hours. When you get to the other end you are taken on buses and shown around the Island then you are taken into the jail to be shown round by a ex-inmate who has chosen to work on the island. Truly humbling and saddening to think what awful conditions they had to live in.

Too Short - Needs Age Restrictions. First - this is NOT a tour for children younger than the age of 6 (imho). There is lots of time on boats, busses and in very small rooms and tight quarters not made for antsy, loud kids. Please, I beg of you - don't bring them and ruin it for everyone else. With all the languages/accents and echoing hallways I had 3 children under the age of 2 or 3 that screamed, cried, ran etc. Parents trying to "shush" them, chase them or worse - parents that do nothing made for a frustrating 3+ hours. Tangent over. As others note - book the first boat of the day. Waters are supposedly smoother then and you have less of a chance of cancellation. Our trip over to the island at 9 am was somewhat rough, with more than one person running to the bath and using barf bags. They ended up canceling the afternoon boats today as the swells were just too high.The ride takes about 30-45 mins. You then board busses for a tour around the island prior to going into the prison. My bus was perfectly filled (everyone had a seat), but some others were really jammed full. We had a fantastic guide in Tabo, he was very patient while tour members on our bus talked loudly while he was educating us on buildings, stops or were late returning from scheduled breaks. He was very well spoken and clear. I felt for him with some of the folks on our bus, they challenged all of us with their lack of self awareness.The prison tour was good - I had a hard time hearing the guide at all times, I'm guessing who you get as your guide matters here.All and all it's a worthwhile trip but I wish we were given the opportunity to walk around at our own pace or in smaller groups. Obviously this is driven by the boat limitations but I would have really enjoyed more interaction and Q&A with less people in a group. This is a peaceful place, and one that deserves respect. I felt as if a good number of people that come here don't view it as such which is a shame.

Historical . The Island of the freedom .Nelson Mandela was person there for more 27 years.you should booked before two or three days some time more than week .The boat will take 30 minutes three big buss will wait for you each buss with different guide.

Not to miss, history of human suffering. World Heritage Site. Nelson Mandela and many other political prisoners were imprisoned here during the Apartheid era. Many attempts were made to break their spirit. Some of the guides are ex- prisoners and we met a former guard who befriended Mandela and was invited to attend the ceremony when Mandela became president. After getting off the ferry, we went on an hour's tour around the island with a guide telling us many interesting things about the actual island which had one times housed people with Leprosy and about Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners. We saw the quarry where Mandela worked. You then visit the actual prison and see the various blocks and the cell and compound where Mandela spent his time and given an overview of prison life.On the negative side, we felt the groups were too big and the guide started to speak before we were all in the room so we missed a lot of what he said. The full bus load was left as a group but this should have been split into two groups inside the jail so we could all hear. We also felt that we were rushed too much so didn't have the time to read the signs with many interesting facts and explanations. Despite this, it is definitely worth a visit and the on the ferry ride back from the island,if the day is clear, there are great views of the port and Table Mountain.

A long day. I feel badly giving this important historical venue an average review of 3 stars but here are my thoughts. When we came here I had already done the Soweto tour, apartheid museum and constitutional hill tours in Johannesburg (all three are excellent and highly recommended tours). If you don't get to Johannesburg for these tours then this tour is an important one to attend but be warned that it is a long one so bring drinks and a snack with you. They do stop at one point and you can buy a snack and drink but when we were there the store was pretty picked over. It was important to see this attraction as it does hold incredible significance to South Africa's apartheid history but after being at the other attractions in Johannesburg this one felt less informative and quite long. In my mind the tour could have been 1/2 as long and provided more information. We did enjoy the boat ride out to the island but did not enjoy being stuck on the boat at the end of the day waiting for stragglers and island staff as we were the last boat out that day. I would take an earlier tour to avoid that wait.
Must do. A visit to a place with such history is something you will never regret doing. Emotional, educational and amazing. History and nature wrapped into one small island.

Good historical experience. My whole life I've loved Nelson Mandela; every biography project I ever had to do was on him. I expected this trip to Robben Island to be the highlight of my trip. The boat ride was beautiful, as was the island. I liked seeing all the structures and learning the history. Being led by a former political prisoner was very unique, although at times he was difficult to understand. I did feel like the focus on Mandela was minimal, and maybe that's how it should be as he wasn't the only political prisoner fighting for the rights of the people who was held there, but I guess I was expecting more spotlight on him.

Mrs Cheryl Amos. If u haven't been to Aquarium I will encourage u to go especially with little children just to watch them interact with sea creatures is amazing the expressions on u kids face & an adult telling them more about sea world as kids are curious & like learning new things

History so close in time. Make your booking well in advance since the three daily tours may be fully booked for a week in advance. After a 30 minutes boat ride you are welcomed by former prisoners who now work as the guides on the island. You are transported around the island in busses and are also taken around in some of the prison buildings. The cell of Nelson Mandela was on of the main attractions and history comes very close when told by a person who has experienced it. The gate to the camp reminded me of the one at the concentration camp in Dachau, Germany.

Business . I spent the turn of the millennium on the Island with Nelson Mandela, not in jail I hasten to add. The service on the island and to and from it was awful. This time it was excellent, well ordered and organized, good guides, reasonable timing. Our bus guide was brilliant and funny, the guide through the prison not so, he was indecipherable at times and seemed a little touched in the head from the many years he had been imprisoned after the 1976 Soweto riots. But overall a moving and worthwhile experience from boarding to disembarkation four hours later.

A walk through history. I purchased my ticket for the ferry to Robben Island and the tour several weeks before my trip. This turned out well since the Saturday 9:00 tour was sold out for same day tickets. So buy ahead if possible. We loaded onto buses for a tour of the island with a great guide. He told us about people, history, buildings, the quarries, the plants, and the animals of the island. He handed us off at the prison to a guide who was a political prisoner there for 5 years. He was charged with treason in 1976 for participating in a peaceful resistance protest in Soweto. This is a must visit for Cape Town. It’s our world history up front and personal and part of our future.

Visit to Robben Island. The visit was informative but I have to say the experience was not as awe inspiring. Our guide on the bus tour was very informative and you could tell the story of Robben Island and the hope that it gave many meant a lot to him. We then had a former prisoner for the second part of our tour. He was on a schedule and we felt rushed through there were a lot of stories on the walls of the cells that were interesting and sometimes inspiring to read but time was so limited that we probably only had time to read a quarter of them. We also had an incident of a group of over 30 who did not all speak English and the method that they were using to translate was initially very disruptive. both tour guides caught on quickly and made arrangements to accommodate this group in a less disruptive manner. It's unfortunate that the guides weren't advised of this issue in advance. Maybe the museum should look into headphones with some sort of translation capability for those that don't speak English. It was a very tight schedule to get back to the ferry at the assigned departure time. It would have been nice to be able to spend the time to finish reading some of those essays by former prisoners.

Robbed island. A remarkable and learning tour to Robben island. Tutorials and observations during the tour were like history classes. Prison atmosphere was observable and learnt lessons regarding patience, tolerance and struggle against oppressors

Must-see. This should be at the top of your to-do list when visiting the Cape Town area. Really interesting and great to hear the story of a former inmate there. The whole things is very professionally done and can easily be done in a morning or afternoon visit.

Very moving.. A great thing to see, what a moving piece of history. Lovely ex prisoner showed us around the chain, still very emotional for him. A lovely tour, but if you get seasick, the boat trip out to the island may not be a good idea.

Could have been better. I heard your experience depends on your tour guide and that's absolutely true. We had someone who was a prisoner yet told us no stories. We did a lot of research and reading on our own. It's important for people to go here and understand what happened but it could have been so much better if we had a good guide who told us stories and helped us to understand what happened to him. Get there early- the line piles up early!

A mixed bag. The boat trip out and back on the Catamaran launch was very good. Very professional staff. Fast trip and great view of Cape Town. Left on time and good seats. Quick to load and unload. No refreshments for sale.The guided tour of the prison cells by an ex-prisoner was excellent. It made the experience very real and thought provoking.The guided bus trip tour of the island was terrible. The buses are very old and so over crowded and cramped it was really uncomfortable. You are not allowed to exit the bus and you can't see what they are talking about. The commentary was almost impossible to hear because of volume, other noise and very broken English. The bus trip was a shocker, really bad. I heard some others say 'you know what would make this bus trip worse? Nothing, it couldn't get any worse'. I'd have to agree.Even the exhaust fumes were coming back into the bus.On the whole I regretted going because of the bus trip and bus commentary. NOT RECOMMENDED.

Interesting and worth a visit. A very enriching and interesting visit. A guided tour through the prison with one of the (ex)prisoners! Wow, talk about an insight into prison-life! It ended with a your around the island and you get to se the other side of Robben Island. It is, after all, so much more than a prison.

Worth the visit but..... Really interesting and best part was the stories of ex prisoners plus bus guide. Lovely boat ride over as well. Only negative was it All felt a bit rushed, no time to spend on your own exploring - just processed from one element to next.

Interesting place but.... Luckly I booked in advance (9am departure) insofar a lot of people stayed at the museum because it was fully booked.The boat trip to reach Robber Island was fine (30 minutes of journey) and it will give you terrific views over Cape Town and Table Mountain.When you will arrive on Robben Island you will take a bus and BIG SURPRISE you can not walk over the island yourself and this is a hige pity.Infact I was disappointed about this policy.This was the first part of the tour, the second part of the tour was we at the prison and the meeting with an ex-inmate who will tell you about his story and takes you through the cells. In my opinion the visit could be more interactive, allow walks around the island and to go inside the jails.The price for the visit is 320R. Quite expensive for my point of view.

A piece of history. If you want to learn more about the south african history, as apartheid, and Nelson Mandela, you'll soon realized about the horrible things happened there. Take the tour, learn and enjoy the view. i recommend you to book the tickets in advance cause there's lot of people interested in Robben Island.

Amazing if you love history. the guides here are the ex prisoners who take you around the island. To hear the stories from them is amazing. the visit is worth it and if you are lucky you can also spot dolphins and whales on your way

Didn't get there!!!. We were incorrectly informed that if your trip is cancelled you can just turn up and take a slot. NOT true, if it is cancelled they refund and you have to rebook. This is not a review, just advice.

Fascinating experience guided by ex-politician prisoners. A visit to Robben Island is a must. The island is accessed by a number of boats. On arrival you benefit from a coach tour of the island with excellent commentary and several photo stops.Afterwards you are shown around the prison and here first hand from a former political prison on the life in jail. There's plenty of focus on Nelson Mandella. We struggled to undertand our host and only understood about 50% of his what he was saying so that took the edge off a little.

Robben Island tour. we went there for a team building, it is nice to go in a group, the nice part is that the people that give the tour stayed there, they were prisonars so they have firts hand experience, to me that was very good.

Very moving SA History. A very moving experience, I felt a little choked up even before getting on the boat - standing in the hall with the pictures of some of the horrendous things that black South Africans had to deal with - seeing it all together like that, really made me feel the enormity of it.Boat trip across was fine - massive ferry with two decks of seats inside and a small open deck on top - estimate it takes around 300 people. The return trip was very choppy (don't forget your motion sickness tablets like I did!) - the rest of the days trips were cancelled due to the weather so we were very fortunate to go at all.Upon arriving we got on buses that took us on a tour around the island, seeing some of the memorable places and buildings that dot the island - our guide Thabo was very friendly and knowledgeable. After a short stop for coffee, snacks and a few pics, we then returned to the Prison where we got a tour of the cells.The prison tours are all guided by ex-prisoners, our group was guided by Jama Mbatyoti - who spent 5 years in the prison. We visited the group cells were Jama gave us a little insight into what life was like, from the food they were given, to the bedding and routine of a normal day.We then went to the single cells, and passed Nelson Mandela's cell. At the end of the tour there is a short walk back to the boat for the trip back to the mainland.Very moving, informative and a must do on your list of activities - for international and South African tourists! Book in advance, but be prepared that your tour may be cancelled due to weather, so you may need to change your date.

Educational and hearty experience . We visited Robben Island in May and enjoyed the experience. Whilst the boat trip was a little long to and from the island, it gave us an opportunity to enjoy Cape Town from a different view. The bus tour on the island was great and our guide was very knowledgeable, informative and interactive making the tour enjoyable and very educational. The time spent with the ex-inmate was an awesome touch and hearing from someone who experienced the island first hand really brought the overall experience to life. Our only disappointment was not being able to jump off at the quarry (only a bus stop and view) and walk around the island freely whilst there.

Historically fascinating. The whole day "walk to freedom" tour followed by the Robben Island trip is an absolute must-do for any Cape Town visitor. It's a humbling experience but one that is steeped in history.When arriving on the island you are taken on a bus tour round the island where you find out the island is so much more than just "Mandela." You then go into the actual prison where you are guided by a former political prisoner. My only criticism would be the nature of this guide wasn't the best and whilst he was evidently passionate about the island he conveyed it in a very muddled manner. There were also too many people in the group making photo opportunities rushed.However this did not deter from a fascinating experience and one I would thoroughly recommend.

Really worth it. I really enjoyed the tour, although you really must book in advance. Also, when planning your trip to Cape Town, make sure you book your visit to Robben Island for the very first days. I did that and fortunately when my visit was canceled because of weather conditions, I still had days free to rebook. If you don't, they will reimburse you and you will miss one of the most relevant attractions in Cape Town.

Moving. I highly recommend this tour of Robben Island. Regardless where you are from, most countries have had race relations. The tour covers the spectrum of disparity and triumph. The ticketing was easy on the web and the boat ride was good. The tours are giving by ex cons and very informative. If this does not move you, then nothing will.

Very impressive but we were a little disappointed. We booked in advance (11.00AM departure) and the boat trip was fine and gives you beautiful views over Cape Town and the Table Mountain. Once you arrive on Robben Island you are transported in a bus and unfortunately you cannot walk over the island yourself. We felt the bustour was too long. When we arrived at the prison and ex-inmate tells his story and takes you through the cells. That was very impressive. Because we waited almost an hour before the boat took us back to Cape Town the visit lasted for 5 hours! In our opinion the visit could be shorter and more interactive.

Very informative and educative. We had a guided tour around parts of the Island before an interactive and informative tour around the prison by a former political prisoner. It's an amazing experience. Book early to avoid disappointments.

Life Changing Experience . This is highly recommended for all visitors to Cape Town. The tour is very well organized. The bus tour of the island, the guide through the prison with an ex-prisoner, and time to explore various pivotal spots along the tour. There are so many stories and facts learned during this tour. You will be in awe after you realize the prisoners journey in that prison.

Brilliant. Although really horrid to hear of the worst cases of us humans treating other humans appallingly, it is very well-done 'museum' and very educational and enjoyable. The boat trip is great both ways and the prison tour by an ex political prisoner fantastic. Not to be missed. Be aware that white South African tourists seem to have a habit of leaning over into your close personal space to get photos and the word for 'excuse me' seems unlikely to be heard. Sorry but that was my honest experience. Only happened on the Robben Island trip to be fair and not at any other times on our 14 days in SA.

Moving insight to apartheid history. A must-do trip, whilst in Cape Town. The ferry gives great views back to Cape Town and Table Mountain ... weather permitting. Arriving at Robben Island you are herded into waiting buses, with an ex-inmate acting as tour guide. The guide we had was very good: very personable and informative. The bus only stops twice: once for a view back to the mainland, and once at the end so you can see the main prison block; everything else is viewed from the bus, and it is disappointing that most of the visit is sitting in a bus looking through a window ... would have been better to have stopped at a couple more locations and been able to walk around.
So much history. Our tour was done by a former Robben island prisoner. The visit was very informative despite being a little crowded....
The tour was too long and information overload.. It is very educational if you are into the history. Maybe too much information for some and it is about four hours long.

A must see in Capetown. A short water trip to the island is worth the time. You will be given a tour by a former inmate of the island prison. To see and feel what Nelson Mandella lived is inspirational and humbling.

Very educational. Our family visited last week. Bought tickets a week in advance. 20-30 minute boat ride to the island and then started our walking tour. Tour led by previous prisoner. Very emotional and educational. Our two teenagers thought it was definitely worth doing. In total took 3-4 hours.

Robben Island - mixed experience. (RI). Hopefully the ferries will be working when you plan to visit RI. There have been lots of issues related to the ferries. RI is a bland place with a large history. Most people only know it as a destination where the Great Leader was incarcerated. However, before this it had a huge history in penitentionary, medical and isolation terms. Having been there many times we could say that it is worth a visit for historical reasons. Do your own research. It is a terribly underutilized place. It could be one of the top draw cards in Africa if politics were discarded. It has its own vote in local electoral terms. You need to book your place on the ferry in advance. Not sure that we will go back. Hugely overrated. Visitors to SA love visiting the place. Many locals avoid RI.

A fascinating trip into history. This island is famous for prisoner 466/64, Nelson Mandela, but has so much more to it. From the history starting in Dutch times through its role as a leper colony to its more recent history as a prison this was worth the half hour ferry ride. As well as the man-made attractions there were a number of opportunities to spot both wildlife and shipwrecks. A particular highlight were the penguins.

Must Book In Advance. I wish I could write a review. We went to the ticket counter on a Sunday morning to find that all space was booked until Thursday, Unfortunately that was our departure day so we never got to Robben Island. My rating is pure speculation and we regret we missed going. Hopefully this will help others be able to take the tour.

Humbling experience - you have to visit if you are in Cape Town. I found this experience very humbling. Part of the tour was conducted by an ex-detainee on the island and what stood out for me was his lack of anger or bitterness. We saw Mandela's cell and heard stories about his detention (he was incarcerated here for 18 years). This was a well organised tour that left plenty of food for thought

Lots of talking. My husband and I joined the tour to Robben Island while we were visiting Cape Town. Our ticket included the ferry trip to the island and back, a bus tour around the island, and a tour of the maximum security prison where Nelson Mandela was held. The bus tour was very enlightening. We had a very knowledgeable tour guide who pointed out all the significant landmarks as we went around the island. However, we found the maximum security prison part of the tour somewhat disappointing. The great thing was having an ex-political prisoner talk about his experiences and what happened to the people held there. The problem is the talk went on for such a very long time! They need to sit down with these tour guides and give them some guidelines regarding what they should say. Make it concise. After 30 mins our ability to take in info was just done. After all that, we only had minutes walking past Mandela's cell. Maybe the part of the talk about conditions of prisoners should be in the hallway where these cells are. I'm afraid my husband and I found all the talking really dry.

A Must in Cape Town. Robben Island is famous for being the prison where Nelson Mandela spent 18 of his 27 years of imprisonment. You MUST book AT LEAST 2-3 days in advance as it gets filled up pretty quick. Don't even think about booking at the ticket office. Due to the unstable and windy weather in Cape Town, the chances of having the trip cancelled are high. Our first booking was cancelled due to high winds but we were refunded automatically. Fortunately, our second booking was on a sunny day. There are two trips per day, at 11:00 and 13:00 and the whole trip takes around 4 hours (including the boat rides from/to the island). The boat trip to the island is around 30 min (make sure to bring some medication with you if you're prone to sea sick).We were taking on a guided bus tour around the island and a small village where the employees live, which was pretty interesting. We then got to enter the prison and tour the cells (including Mandela's). The best part is that all the tour guides were ex-prisoners themselves, so you will get an inside story of what it was really like to live there as they will share their personal experiences.

Informative tour, highly recommended. Having lived in south Africa for 6 years,this was the first time I have managed to do the robben island tour. We booked tickets in advance as friends had told me it can book up quick. The bout ride over was a bit choppy due to large swells but the crew were on hand to aid people who turned green! There was a little confusion once we got off the boat due to the bus drivers, who take half the tour around the island,were awol but things then smoothed out once the tour divided. We did the prison section first and were guided by an ex- prisoner. He was serious but held the audience well as he explained how the inmates lived day to day. The second part of the tour takes you by bus around the island. All very informative and interesting.

A little disappointing. We visited here for the second time after 16 yrs. it was not as good especially for the kids. We felt the talk went on for way too long and people got bored. It used to be much more interactive, not so now!! We had no time to visit the gift shop after the tour. The older tours were much better.

A Must See. I'm not sure why this is not higher on the list of things to do in Cape Town, but it should be number 1. This was a very enlightening tour of the prison where Nelson Mandela and many others were held. The ferry ride over was nice and we got to see seals swimming in the water. The tour of the prison is really good and the guides who have all served time at Robben Island are eager and willing to answer all questions. There are also penguins on Robben Island so it was a treat to see them walking around. This is a must see for anyone who visits Cape Town. If I ever go back to Cape Town I will visit Robben Island again. My only suggestion is to buy tickets in advance to ensure you get to experience it.

Must visit. Get your tickets early to avoid being left out. The bus guide was great, he let us know about the history, answered questions. The former prisoner guide though wasn't as good. He recited from a memorized script and was unable to answer questions from guests. He is to be commended for serving as a guide in the same place he used to be imprisoned but I wish there had been someone else to answer questions.

Very good guides, slightly rushed.. The tour is a slick operation, considering a few hundred people are there you are not tripping over other groups. Very Knowledgeable guides but somewhat crowded buses.Our tour ran over so we had to rush for the bus, a shame as we didnt get a look in the shop.Good day out, stark reminder of past 'ideals'

Must see , fascinating tour but needed more time. This was a much anticipated visit which did disappoint. The guides were excellent and the island beautiful. It was bizarre to be greeted by instructions over a loud speaker both on arrival and on departure and we weren't sure if this was intentional to help us feel how the prisoners did. We would have appreciated more time after the prison visit to go to the penguin boardwalk and read the fascinating photos and information and regret that this wasn't possible; maybe because our guides were so informative. Well up to expectations .

A must learning experience . For some (like me) this was a remembrance. I remember watching Mandella freed on TV as a young adult in the US.To walk in the same place was an awe inspiring event.The boat ride over can be interesting. On our day the water was choppy and the fog heavy. Our guide was absolutely awesome and provided insights that made the day even more inspirational.A must see for any visitor to Cape Town.

Would have liked the freedom to walk!. After not being able to get tickets in June 2015 to go to Robben Island, I was very excited to have the opportunity to go again this year. We had to book a few days before we wanted to go (pre-booking is essential).What a disappointment. It felt like a waste of money and time, although I can now tick it off my list. The main issues we had were:- we felt herded from one place to another (from the ferry, to the bus, to a guided walking tour and then back to the ferry).- we were not aware that you cannot walk anywhere independently (a guide is with you all the time)- the guides provided limited information and we did not feel that we learnt anything by visiting- although the prison guide was an ex-inmate he gave no real insight into what it was like to be there, what crimes they had been found guilty of, how it affected them etc. - although I understand that it should have some focus on Nelson Mandela, it would have been nice to have had some information on other inmates- we felt rushed - there was no time to read any other the information boards/displays- you couldn't see the penguins (if you are not allowed to go anywhere near them, don't advertise them on your website!)I would not recommend this tour to others. Your time and money can be better spent elsewhere. You would be better off buying a book; you will see and learn more!!!!!!!

Beautiful and thought provoking. We took a trip to Robben Island expecting to see the prison where political prisoners of the Apartheid government were held. Not only did we see this but also infrastructure built by Irish immigrants for an old leper colony, old houses in which prison guards used to stay (now occupied by the museum staff). We saw penguins, sacred ibis and tortoises. There is also a military history at the island and we saw huge naval canons that were installed during the Second World War. The prison tour was given by a previous detainee which was interesting. Don't plan to see a lot at Mandela's prison cell. We were is a big group and had a few seconds to snap a picture before moving on so others could do the same. Well worthwhile a visit but beware that it will take 4 hours. You should also arrive early at the dock to transfer to the island. We had booked for 11am and started boarding at 10:30. Travel to the island is about 45 minutes, some boats do go faster.

Tour could use a review of time division. Boat ride takes about an hour, reaching Robben Island's interesting pier sculptures. There is a bus tour of the island, followed by conversation with your tour guide - an former inmate or officer at the prison. This is followed by a visit to the building where Mandela was kept. Unfortunately, there is very little time to take in everything available in the last part of the visit. All of the cells have information in them, but we weren't able to read everything due to time constraints.

Enlightening and educational. This is a MUST DO in Cape Town. The stories (told by former inmate) and the history are enlightening. It was a prison and prior to that a leper colony - so got educated on history of the island - and more importantly history of cape town.

Don't ever forget. Maybe it has lost a bit of the "glory" it used to have but it remains an absolute must to visit. Especially with youngsters it can give them some perspective of the madness of human kind

It's a prison. This tour is about the prison and life there in the 1960s and 1970s. Toward the end you get to see Nelson Mandela’s cell. This seems to be why many people are on the tour. I found visiting the other cells with brief comments and sometime mementos from one of the prisoners to be more meaningful. Although the tour is very popular, if you are pressed for time, this would be something that could be eliminated unless you are really interested in prisons.

Amazing experience. Robben Island is a pilgrimage that must be made. The tour guides were outstanding--many ex-prisoners who shared their knowledge and experience of the place. The juxtaposition of the natural beauty of Table Mountain in the background, the penguins and beautiful sea, upon this place of incredible oppression was moving beyond words.

Best palce to understand apartheid. You must catch a ferry which leaves clock tower and it´s recommended book as early as you can because tickets are sold out quickly. It costs R320 and all tours are guided and included ferry transfer. Inside the island, you go through all point in a bus and you stop for walks at important points. There´s a small café with bathroons in the island.In the final point of the tour, is a walking tour inside robben island with former prisioners which can explain better than anyone what happened there. It´s definitly a mandatoy place to go when visiting Cape Town

A must see when in Cape Town. Robben Island is accessed via the V & A Waterfront. We were advised to pre-book. Not terribly hard, but that regimented our trip to a tight schedule. Our ferry boat was full. The island is viewed almost entirely by bus. No foot wandering allowed. They then drop you off at a prison barracks where a former prisoner explains prison life and shows you some isolations cells and group cells. Then , back to the ferry. No wandering allowed,, your boat is leaving. It is clean and sanitary now, but it is pretty easy to imagine the suffering, beatings and cruelty imposed when the prison housed Mandela, and other prisoners. It is good to see something like this because we are capable of repeating the past when we don't examine it

The Robben Island experience. I've done this about 5 years ago. We managed to get tickets on the same day which is generally difficult as it's always busy. A huge ferry took us across and it took approx 20 min. We were then met by our tour guide who was an inmate during the time of apartheid. He explained every detail of what exactly went on at that time. We got to see where Mandela slept and worked. A very emotional time spent on Robben Island. I was truly inspired by his courage and faith. We also toured all of the island and learned about many other politicians from the past. A definite must do for tourists.
History Revisited!. A must if you are traveling in South Africa. Helpful in understanding the horrors of apartheid and the success of Mandala in conquering it.

Not to be missed. When I was in CT 40 years ago, no one "visited" Robben Is so this was a real thrill to be able to see it. From the start as you leave the harbor, you get great views of CT and begin to feel the isolation of Robben. As you approach the island, you think, "this doesn't look so bad" but once you actually start the tours and hear the talks, you realize what a terrible place this was. The tour is by bus first, with commentary by the driver, and then you are led thru the buildings. In our case, our guide had been a prisoner there with Mandela. It was an amazing tour and should not be missed.

Such a wonderful experience! . This Robben island tour is a must to see and experience when in Cape Town! The trip on the boat to the island was a bit choppy. However coming back, we managed to get into a newer boat and the trip was much better than the initial one. The tour guides were informative and were able to convey their stories and information with genuine passion! Despite being South African and knowing the famous stories and characters of Robben Island, there were many additional jewels unearthed.

Wow what a new understanding!we all know Nelsin Mandela!. Be there to hear first hand from a former political prisoner what exactly went on and of the inmate treatment! How did he survive 18 years in that environment. Question we all need to ask ourselves when you can re-merge with unity in your soul! Great half day, but allow the time, and if you have pre-booked be there about 20 minutes before you board to go through security! Large crowds in summer so precook tickets on the net saves the quese's!

an interesting and informative afternoon!. Robben Island should be recommended to anyone interested in South Africa's history.The tour involves a ferry ride to get to the island and you are there for about 4 hours [the time there and the ferry rides going and coming back] The highlight of the tour is that you get to meet former prisoners who share their experiences of what it was like to be incarcerated on the island under apartheid. It is very emotional when they tell their stories. They will also take you to the cell where Nelson Mandela spent most of his time. it is imperative to get tickets for Robben Island either in advance or as soon as you arrive in Capetown. We arrived on a Monday and wanted to go the next day and they were sold out. We were fortunate enough to be in Capetown for 4 days otherwise we would have missed Robben Island. Do not miss this!

Sobering!!. One must go to Robben Island to get a deeper understanding of the history of South Africa. The guide we had was an ex-inmate from the island. His perspective was sobering, humbling, and inspiring. I highly recommend this tour.

Very Interesting Trip. A very informative tour of Robben Island made even more so as we were guided round the prison itself by an ex inmate. The only drawback we had was that on the bus part of the tour there was a mix up waiting for the guide which meant we were very rushed for this part as we had to get back for the ferry

Low key, but interesting.. Worth a trip out, if only for the sea voyage. Very interesting to talk to ex inmates, and rather harrowing to think of the mistakes that led the country to think it could repress democracy by such means. One hopes that future governments will remember the lessons.

A must go to destination in Cape Town. Views differed in our group about the quality of the experience. Some thought it a little disappointing, thinking more could have been done to bring the prisoners' time there alive. The tour is certainly downbeat and low key. This for me added to the authenticity of an ex prisoner's personal story and made it more compelling. Robben Island is about 7 miles from the V&A Waterfront and the waters can be choppy so it is important to recognise this if you suffer from mal de mer. We went out of season so it was not very busy. In summer it can get busy so it is worthwhile booking online in advance.

Robben Island. You need to book two days in advance and you are given a set time. 9,11 or1 o'clock. The journey across was fine, but you need to check which ferry you are on as there are fast ferries and slow. We took 50mins on the outward journey and 30mins on the inward. Once we arrived we were greeted by an ex inmate and transported around the island on a bus. We stopped to look at a several places but we're only aloud off the bus at the coffee shop for photos. We were taken to look at the quarry where the prisoners had been made to work. We saw a pile of stones which had been placed by ex prisoners, but again we were only aloud to photo these from the bus. It was a shame that there was no opportunity to walk around the quarry and experience the place. Our tour guide on the bus was engaging and informative and easy for all to understand. We then arrived at the prison and were escorted around by an ex inmate. We were taken to a large room where the gentleman talked about his own views. An opportunity missed to engage all about the prison life. He was hard to comprehend at times. I feel this is not really a child friendly trip as it was not inspirational or uplifting.I would liked to have heard more about daily life, read information and seen artefacts etc.Sadly a disappointing experience which could have been so much more.

Wow-- Unreal Site. We booked on Tuesday and could not get the ferry to Robben Island until Friday- and this was their off season. They have ferries running three times a day..9am- 1pm and 3 pm. This tour is one, if not the leading attraction in Cape Town and I can see why. Tours are given by people who were jailed there, and the gentleman running the store was Mandela's guard. Would be very wise if you read the book Long Walk to Freedom before you visit. As well, bring a copy of the book--Nelson Mandela- My Prisoner My Friend with you as the author is running the store-- would be a great autograph to have! I would STRONGLY recommend booking this attraction online. Many who were there for only a day or two went away disappointed. On of this best tour we completed in our five week stay. You will not be disappointed.

A bit of history, very informative but not to heavy!. Make sure you get to the ferry 30 mins before it is due to leave, it gets very busy. once on the island you travel in large coaches with a guide followed by a former prisoner leading you through the prison. extremely informative and makes you appreciate how far South Africa has come in the last few years. Don't expect any real breaks although there is a café part way round the coach tour
Tour. Awesome tour boat trip then bus tour then jail tour . Just a pity they don't maintain the gardens and general vegetation . Lots of weeds etc.

A Must. My daughter insisted that we take this tour. She was right, it was very insightful and of course sad. I suggest you go to the Watershed at the Waterfront and get a bag lunch. There is time to eat while on the island. Also, we got our tickets a month or two before the departure.

A Must!. We are so glad we committed a half a day for this. It was educational and so important. Both of our tour guides, on the bus and the former political prisoner, were very knowledgeable and interesting. The views of Cape Town from the top of the ferry are great too (We toured with the Robben Island Museum). Once is probably enough, but so glad we did it.

A must, but a little dissapointing. The history of Robben island, especially of the political prisoners, at the apartheid period, is very impressive. A visit to Robben island a tribute to those incredible heroes as Nelson Mandela and Walter Sisulu. Despite this the tour to the island is disappointing. The boat tour takes about 30 minutes. Be one of the first to board, so you can sit on the upper deck. When full you have to sit at the closed lower deck. Especially when you get seasick easily this is not the best place to be. Arriving on the island you are crammed in a bus and hurried along the different places on the island.
