I would gladly walked the limestone quarry, but we were not allowed to leave the bus at other places than the shore with beautiful sights on Cape Town and Table Mountain.At the end of the tour you are guided through the prison were the political prisoners were imprisoned, by an ex-political prisoner. The mere fact that an actual (ex)prisoner tells the story is special and makes the trip worthwhile. On the other hand, if you want to get information on the regime on Robben island, the prisoners and the apartheid regime, you better check wikipedia.

worth the trip. boat ride with rough see. The guide was prisoner himself in Robben Island and was very authentic, allowed private discussion. The island tour was excellent as well and prsented a lot of history of the island so far unkown to us.

Very sobering. Like any visit to a prison it is a very sobering experience. Fantastic that this very important part of SA history has been well preserved and that the buildings are now used for more productive purposes than incarceration. Very crowded with tourists when we went, either side of this day high winds closed the ferry. Even so it was well organised and efficient on the island. Having an ex-political prisoner talk to us about his own experiences was fantastic and seems at least in his case to be providing a purpose and employment in a city where jobs are scarce. Well done to the organisers. Take food and drink if you think you will need it, supplies in the small cafe are meagre.

The Most Heartfelt Experience. The Robben Island Tour spoke to my spirit and heart like no other. From the intensely turbulent boat ride, to the island to the stories shared by a former prisoner at Robben Island, there's no way you won't be impacted by this experience. I was moved by every small detail such as the size of the cells and the redacted mail that the inmates received. There's so much history in this excursion. I owed it to myself and those who sacrificed for my freedom and democracy to tour Robben Island.

Wonderful wonderful wonderful!! . We caught the 9am ferry to Robben Island and arrived on the island about 30 minutes later. The crossing was beautiful and we had amazing views back over Cape Town from the boat. When we got to island, we were taken to awaiting buses and began a tour of the island. Our tour guide was brilliant giving us loads of interesting information about the island and answering everyone's questions. We stopped off half way around the island at a cafe, toilet and beautiful view point. Afterwards, the bus took us to the prison where we were greeted by another tour guide, an ex- prisoner. He was absolutely fantastic and told us about his time on Robben Island. He bought the stories to life and it was very emotional at times. He took us around the prison showing us the cells (including Nelson Mandela's cell) and common areas. We then went back to the boat and crossed back to Cape Town. The tour lasted about 3 hours. It was absolutely brilliant and I would recommend it to everyone! Make sure you book in advance though as it is so popular!
Astounding. We got a fascinating guide on the bus. Safe trip to the island. The former prisoner did a good job when answering our questions

A must do tour. This was really fascinating. I thought that I was reasonably well informed about the history of apartheid in South Africa, but I learned a lot. You get to find out about what it was like for those on Robben Island, both the prisoners and the guards and you hear this from both ex prisoners and ex guards. We were also pleased to discover that it doesn't focus solely on Nelson Mandela, as that would belittle the struggle of all the other inmates.It really is a lesson in the strength of the human spirit.

A must tour to understand the culture and history. this tour was a beautiful way to see the mountains and enjoy the waterfront. The tour itself was very interesting and engaging. You were lead by someone who was imprisoned there as your guide. The stories and detail made it so real.

History at it's finest. I visited Robben Island with a group of females. The island is huge. We took a ferry over to the island. Once you arrive there's an opportunity to take pics of the items on the walls. You then enter the prison area where you wait to be separated into groups. The tour guides are actual inmates that were imprisoned in Robben Island so they are able to give you stories from their experiences. We walk through the prison and even see where Mandela was imprisoned. After that, we take a tour of the island on a bus with another tour guide. It was a great experience and I recommend that anyone do it when visiting Cape Town.

Visit to be both saddened and inspired. This was a special visit for me having followed the apartheid issues from a young man. This is a must do and for everyone to remember just what injustices were perpetrated just 25 years ago.The tour is well organized and your time passes very quickly before having to catch the ferry back to the mainland.

Not the best tour. The boat trip was quite bad and made a lot of guests sea sick. The bus trip felt rushed and like being sheep herded along a route. The jail visit was ok, but we were late because of the bus trip so it also felt rushed. It is a good educational trip if you want to learn more about apartheid, but having already visited Joburg and the apartheid museum this did not give us much.

Big history time. It is simple: you have to go there when being in Cape Town. The history makes it a must see!Having ex-prisoners as tour guides is a good idea, hopefully for them not too painful being there again.Only I thought it would be mote about Nelson Mandela and specific stories about the life at Robben Island. The tour was interesting but not emotional enough.I guess they have done the tour too often - it seems like it is only business now.. a pity.

Special visit. What a moving experience the only problem was if its a hot day there is no shade so be prepared with a hat.a veteran prisoner will take you round and show you all the horrible things nelson Mandela suffered and the other prisoners as well.A very interesting and sad trip but one not to miss it is definitely a must.

Fantastic display of Apartheid history in South Africa. A " Not to miss" tour when you are in Capetown. A beautiful thirty minutes ferry takes you to the Robben Island which hosted Nelson Mandela as its most famous prisoner. The bus tour takes you on a tour of the facilities of the prisoners and the guards. Of course the most emotional part of the tour was the prison cell in which Nelson Mandela was imprisoned. The guides are former inmates of the prison and speak of the difficult times they endured. Apparently Mandela was a good tennis player, is what we learnt. Do yourself a favour - go for this.

Take Your Seasick Pills! Touching Tour. I"m not sure why some are not impressed with this, it was one of the most personal experiences we had in Cape Town. A former political prisoner shows you around and tells you their story and then you take a short bus tour of the island itself. It was really moving. I took my dramamine the night before and then again the morning of and I'm so glad I did. The boat ride to the island is about 40 minutes and there were many people getting sick each way. They have two ferries, one quite small the other large. We were told to sit in the back if you get sea sick, which worked well on the small one, until all of the actively sick riders came to the back to lean over.

Great trip!. I was very excited about going on this tour and I wasn't disappointed! The ferry over to the island was nice and short, don't worry about sea sickness. After the boat we got on a bus and brought on a little tour around the island before the prison. Our tour guide was excellent, can't remember his name tho. He was funny and his knowledge was fantastic. He even stopped off at the Irish graveyard just because the four of us came from Ireland(he said he doesn't usually drive that way). The tour of the prison was lead by a former prisoner. He was very good and we thought that really added to the tour. The one and only criticism id have of the tour was nelson mandelas cell was the exact same as all the rest. Probably because they wanted to show he was one of many prisoners and they were all equal but I thought maybe if they opened it or at very least have the number of his cell 46664 on the door or something like that. We were at the back of the group and we didn't hear our guide saying this was his cell. Should really be some small plaque or sign to say this was his cell.
A must-see place if you are in Cape Town. Most of the tour guides are former inmates on the island. If you are in Cape Town don't miss out on this historical place

Interesting but..... We were very lucky to do this tour. This was booked for our 2nd day ig I is a lovely ferry ride over to the island but apparently the next day's ferries were not running due to high winds. The island tour was very interesting and the tour guide was very informative. Once the bus tour was over we were handed over to an ex inmate for a tour of the prison. Again very interesting anx informative but it just went on far too long. A quick 15 minute tour and then a chance to walk round would have been so much better than the approx 45 min tour of a booming voice often repeating info.Great views back to Table Mountain

Emotional and moving. as part of a three week trip to South Africa we took a trip to Robben Island.Our guide an ex prisoner was friendly informative and spoke from the heart It was emotional standing in Mandela's small cell and quite grounding.Well worth a visit

Must See. Part of the tour is led by former prisoners on Robben Island. A thorough and heartfelt presentation. Nelson Mandela spent 18 years in confinement here. A bit overly long but still very worthwhile.

Very Bad Service. I wanted to purchase my tickets online as I was advised that this is a very popular tour and the best way to ensure I could experience it on my visit to Cape Town, would be to get my tickets online. When attempting to do so, after entering all relevant info it kept taking me back to the initial screen where I need to enter my credit card details, there is no notification that your website is not up and running or that it's undergoing maintenance. Then I decided to call the ticket office when I arrived, the staff was not able to assist me either, I stood in a queue for over 2hours trying to get a ticket and then just decided not to waste my time and left. I was so disappointed not to have visited the island. You need to get your act sorted, or this will not be the last bad review you guys get. Good luck.

Remarkable site with huge potential, but not very well organized. it's a 4 hours door to door tour, the highlight is were you get to meet an ex-political prisoner that share his own experience and you understand from a first hand experience the life under apartheid.Before you board, there are very little explanations of what you are going to experience, the well over one hour ferry time and the long wait time can be used in a much better way to share with the visitors of the country and the island history.

Emotional. The countries troubled history starts here at this sacred ground . You will take a 30 minute boat rise to the island. When you visit this site , there is a mix of emotions you will feel. The island is also home to many wonderfull fauna and flora , a great photo opportunity for you to photograph the wild life. Beware its a world heritage site and everything on the habitat is protected.Sme highlights are the penguins, tortoises birds seals etc.

Don't believe the experts! You DO need to pre book.. Just posting this as a "lesson learned"We were told not to bother pre booking this. Got to C Town and the whole thing was booked out for over a week in advance. We missed out on this as well as cable car as it was apparently broken.Do some homework/planning and secure a spot. We are so disappointed to have missed out.

Very informative and interesting day out . I visited Robben Island for the second time yesterday. I would definitely recommend it to anyone interested in South Africa's history. The tour is variable with a ferry ride and a walking tour and bus tour on the island. We were really lucky with the weather and the ferry ride was lovely. The prison tour was done by an ex prisoner which gives the tour a very genuine feel. It was however, at times, quite difficult to hear our guide. He has quite a strong accent so was sometimes a bit difficult to understand (especially, I would imagine, for those not from South Africa). I think if the groups were smaller on the prison tour section of the tour it mean more people could hear and take in more of what was being said. Although cost wise this may of course not be feasible. Perhaps more literature around the island would have been helpful for those not that familiar with the history of the island.The bus tour was very informative and overall I think the whole day was well managed and well delivered.My only complaint about the experience would be the ticket office. I'd booked over the phone and just had to collect the tickets. We waited in the ticket sales queue for ages (the collection queue was unmanned).

Truly a "Can't Miss". I can't imagine visiting Cape Town and not spending the couple hours to visit Robben Island. The boat ride out takes almost 30 minutes and the programs on the island are about 90 minutes. We had an excellent walking tour from Jama, a former political prisoner. We then had the bus tour of the island. It is a much bigger island with a more complex history than we realized.Make sure you make reservations ahead of time. Most likely you will have to book a tour a day or two ahead.

A walkthrough on how Mandela lived!. Robben Island is a very emotional place. Getting to know how Madiba spent most of his days is very touching. Seeing his prison cell first hand and hearing how prisoners were discriminated against can make you understand how far we come as a country.

Great SA history and insight. I thoroughly enjoyed a trip back in time where our South African political heroes beared the brunt of apartheid. Thr tour guides were ex robben island inmates which added a bit of contextual realism to the tour.

Special day out . What a wonderful day at this historic island. A lovely boat trip out takes you to the island that has gone through 400 years of interesting history. On arriving at the island after a 30 minute you climb onto buses for your driven tour, finishing at the maximum security prison that housed many political prisoners , most notably Nelson Mandela, the reason of course that many travelers come to the island. Our guide who was a political prisoner himself on the island from 1984 to 1992 was wonderful, getting first hand accounts of life during the 1980's on the island was very interesting. What a humble, down to earth man. If there is anything to criticize about the trip is it was sad to note that when we waited for our boat to return 100's of travelers where unable to buy anything from the curio shop on the island as it closes before the last tour is fen done. The other concern was that some of the information about life on the island from our first guy on the bus did not match info from our guide who himself was an inmate. Maybe a bit of fact checking is in order.

Interesting historical experience. The jail where Nelson Mandela spent most of his days...definitely worth a visit. Tour guides are former inmates and one can hear interesting accounts of interaction with Mr. Mandela.

Interesting but wish we could have understood guide. Robben Island is an important part of South African history and very thought-provoking. We visited with our teenagers. The tour starts with a bus ride around the island, and our guide for that was great and very informative. Then a former prisoner gives a walking tour of the prison building where Nelson Mandela's cell is. Unfortunately our guide was very hard to understand. Even the South Africans on the tour couldn't understand him. It was disappointing because he clearly was very passionate and we would have loved to know what he was saying or to have been able to ask him questions.

You have to visit a Robben Island. Robben Island ferry is very safe and comfortable. The tour guides in Robben Island are very knowledgeable and friendly. The ex-prisoners tell the Robben Island Story as is since they have experienced it.

A long day if political science is not your focus. Since Apartheid or lack of it was not the impetus for our trip to South Africa, I considered skipping this boat ride and bus tour-- but I did not, and therefore I learned a lot about history and injustice and the human spirit. Robbin Island is really a depressing if educational place. But there is sooooooo much to see and absorb about South Africa that the time might have been better spent elsewhere. Know you are committing a full day to this history lesson and the weight of all the injustice might wear you out.

So interesting . It is such an historical place you have to go! The fact that ex-political prisoners are your guides during the visit gives an extra touch of human feelings and helps you connect. We had great luck and we met the guard at the cafe stop that was responsible for Mandela's care for more than 10 years. It was really meeting "history"!

Powerful story, This is highly recommended. I would recommend this as a MUST visit for ANY person from ANY race, background and conviction. Nelson Mandela (or Madiba as he was called) is an international icon of peace and reconciliation. Robben Island is where Nelson Mandela spent 25 years in captivity during the Apartheid era. The prison is on Robben Island (approx 5km offshore) and can be reached via Ferry boat tour. Now a museum where you can go on tour and get all the info and history
I now know the true meaning of Apartheid. My tour of Robben island was surreal, the moment I saw Mandela's cell a sadness overcame me. As if I could feel the anguish.

#mustseetheisland. Can't visit this part of South Africa without going to the island, where the great man, Nelson Mandela was incarcerated. Such an experience and one of the guides, was an inmate at the same time.

A must visit with a powerful story. This has to be done a really interesting morning and a very useful history lesson from the 1500 to today. The guides are amazing and so interesting. A quick 25 min ferry ride over. If we had more time would have considered staying in the first house on the island for one night.

Interesting and thought provoking. Visited the island by ferry and the tour was led by an ex prisoner. The personal story and impact really brought home the hardship, being separated from families etc. The trip included communal cells, seeing Nelson Mandela's cell, the quarry, the warders village. Interesting to see the Irish graveyard, celtic cross and leper graveyard.

An interesting attraction that gives cause for reflection...... Robbin island really is a must if visiting Cape Town. The visit is hosted by those who actually served as prisoners in the establishment and they give an excellent insight into the life inside the prison including that of Nelson Mandela. It is one of those attractions that really causes self reflection and depth of thought after hearing of the experience of those who were incarcerated here.

A fascinating trip. I had expected a boat across and a wander around, but this is a very structured and well delivered tour. I learnt a lot, not just about Mandela but about the island in general. I never dreamt people live on the island today. Not to be missed.

A lovely spot with a terrible history. We were fortunate enough to have as our guide one of the former political prisoners who was held at Robben Island back in the day, so his history and commentary were both compelling and rich with information. The more you learn about the prison, the more tainted the views of the lovely little island become. A powerful monument to a very troubled era.

It's not Robben Island but the guides that make this great!. The prison is quite basic with little ambience. The island tour is interesting (has a basic cafe for a cup of tea and a surprisingly good sandwich - all a bit pricey but I needed that tea!) and good. The best part was definitely hearing the ex-political prisoner's stories and experience. That made an average experience really, really excellent. Bring water.

Humbling experience. I'm glad to have made this trip, it was a humbling experience. Our bus tour guide was very knowledgeable. Our prison guide, an ex political prisoner, was amazing. I definitely enjoyed every minute

Beautiful, but depressing from it's history. Robben Island is where Nelson Mandela and many other political prisoners were held prior to the end of apartheid. The prison and the stories of the prison are very oppressive, but at the same time the physical environment is beautiful. The island has been used for many things over history, from a ship docking place to a leper colony, to a political prison, to now a major tourist exhibit. Our guide for the tour had been held at their as a political prisoner so he had much to tell us about the conditions for the prisoners. It was amazing to me that he had a relatively upbeat outlook considering all that he had been through. We toured the prison and the island seeing the remains from the church built by the people in the leper colony to the prison cells, one of which had contained Nelson Mandela. The dining room had a poster that showed what each group was fed based on skin color. It was appauling. The boat ride out to the island lets you see the physical beauty of the island. There are many sea birds living there and there are some beautiful seascapes to be seen along the coast. Of course, the fact that the water is so rough there is what made it so effective as a prison.It is definitely worth seeing if you have any interest in the history of South Africa.

Educational experience. It was an educational experience visiting the island and learning more about South African history. It's an experience I will vary with me the testy of my life. It's definitely worth your while to take the ferry over and hear first hand for yourself.

Not to be missed. Essential for anyone who appreciates learning about history, this tour complements the movie about Nelson Mandela, allowing you to see some of the places depicted in the film, some of which were filmed on the island itself. But seeing the actual island, the prison, the lime quarry, the yard and Mandela's cell brings home the feeling of confinement, even claustrophobia, prisoners must have felt. Our tour guide, a former inmate who was arrested at 19 or so for his political activism and spent years in the prison not only gave us insight in an intellectual sense, but also an emotional one. And he's still an advocate for social issues (better education etc) - such an inspiration.

REAL PENGUINS!. Love this place. Real Penguins in their natural habitat! You get to see how Penguins swim and feed their young in their natural habitat! LOVE THIS PLACE! very cold, a must to visit for animal lovers! Lots of penguins to see!
Vacation in South Africa. Wonderful monument of South African history. If you are interested in history and stories of the struggle of the freedom fighters, this is the place

Disappointing and not recommended. The best part of this is the boat trip over! You arrive at Robbin Island and on to a large 40 seater type bus. You are then driven around with opportunities to take photos and dropped at a shop to purchase drinks etc. There was very little food available and we were fortunate enough to buy the last two ice blocks! At this stop you can take a photo with the the Robbin Island sign. Wow. About 30 minutes there - once you have the photo then what - oh nothing till you get back on the bus. Then we were dropped at the prison. The guide for the prison was an ex inmate who I found overly zealous and incomprehensible. We couldn't understand a word he said and everything was so melodramatic. While I appreciate that he was providing his view and his claim to fame was that he had been incarcerated there, as a tour guide which is now - he should be able to be understood by those he is taking on tour. The whole point of the tour was to view the Nelson Mandela's cell - so for an hour we endured this tour until you get to the cell. The whole thing was really unprofessional and we were so disappointed in the waste of money!

A must see in Cape Town. Informative and moving tour, led by former inmate. Cant imaging going to Cape Town and not experiencing it. Must book ahead to get choice of times. We did the 9am and the water was calm for ride over. It was all well-organized. Highly recommend to all.

An absolute must-visit. The tour of Robben Island was a thoroughly worthwhile and enjoyable afternoon experience. It began with a 20-minute catamaran ride to the island followed by a bus tour of the important parts of the island with an experienced guide. The best part though was the tour of the prison where Nelson Mandela was held for 18 years. The guide was a former political prisoner inmate who really brought the story of the prison alive. We returned by boat. The whole experience lasted about 3.5 hours. You can post mail from the island if you are interested in a Robben Island postmark.

A step back in time. A well organised informative tour of the history of Robben Island. Part of the tour is conducted by a former prisoner.Book early to avoid disappointment. We found that the return trip was much longer and was transported on an old dining boat.

An eye opener for sure. What a place, our guide on the first part of the tour (bus trip around the island) was very entertaining and knowledgeable. Our guide at the prison was an actual political prisoner who was incarcerated there for 8 years and his story and anecdotes were amazing to hear first hand. Not to be missed when coming to Cape Town. Make sure you book early as it is very popular.

My visit to Robben island . Have you read a lot or watched several documentaries or even studied the stories of South Africa during the apartheid regime, this is a must do. Travel by yatch to the island and then take a bus and in foot tour. The tour guide is an ex-prisoner with first hand experience of the type of treatment in the cell. You will also see the cells of Nelson Mandela, Walter Sisulu etc.....Be sure to book three days in advance as they sell out....it was a life changing experience
High peak: the view. I expected to hear more about the history, to see the reality, but really? Nothing like that. It's nice to see the penguins and the view of the shore.

Loved It!. This is definitely one of Cape Town’s must do experiences. While not cheap, it is very good value … not just because of the island tour, but also the enjoyable ferry experience and unsurpassed views of Cape Town and Table Mountain. To book, you must go to the ferry office on the Victoria & Alfred waterfront next to the clock tower and select your ticket from the tours available at the time. It is strongly advisable to do this as soon as you get to Cape Town, as you often have to wait a few days. Also, fairly regularly the ocean is too rough to cross, so you might need to re-schedule. I met various people who missed out because they either waited too long or due to Cape Town’s unpredictable weather. The tours are conducted by a former prison inmate and encompass more of the island than I’d expected, and of course include a stop at the jail cell where Nelson Mandela spent 18 years. We spotted a whale breaching a few times on the ferry ride back to Cape Town, which was an unexpected thrill.

17 year old got bored. My girlfriend and i truly loved this visit, great history, great scenery aye yes boy. Lost ourselves in the atmosphere of the past, reflecting on the iconic figure Mandela was aye, seemed like a good bloke yes. It was beautiful enough just to gaze upon the mighty table mountain, the quality of the tour just added to what was a wonderful day.Such a shame my girlfriends son Alex JR didn't find it very exciting! He spends all his time playing minecraft and watching strange videos on the Internet!Keep it between you and me, but i'm not taking that little greasy rat on holiday again!

Experience the true Africans history of the apartheid . Given by an ex prisoner who will tell his story and experiences of staying on the island for numerous years separated from other political leaders of that generation - showed where nelson mandela would sleep at night and where he worked - its a must see to gain an understanding of what the poor Africans had to sacrifice to gain their independence
Interesting but quite expencive. A short part of the tour is done by ex-prisoners. That was the best and most impressive part of the tour.
Eh not great. I went here with some friends and while the history is amazing there is so much more they could do. It's nothing like what Alcatraz offers. Could be so much better!

Excellent tour, but more factual info would have been appreciated. Living in Australia, I have visited many gaol museums! Our convicts had it ever so much more worse. Still, the conditions were not exactly fantastic and the labour required of the inmates was pretty cruel. I don't think that the guides should hide the fact that nelson Mandela was not incarcerated here for as long as they make you believe.

Disappointinf. Having heard so much about Robben Island from guide books and friends we booked tickets as soon as we arrived so as not to miss out. Whilst the ferry trip was enjoyable, it went downhill from the moment we arrived on the island. The tour is split between a bus tour around the island and a tour of the prison done by an ex prisoner. The bus tour was interesting but seemed to be based around a stop at a gift shop. The prison tour took us around the cells and whilst interesting we felt rushed and didn't have enough time to read a lot of the information on display boards before we were moved along. The tour also didn't seem to have much order which made it harder to understand the history of the place. We were also in a very big group and the tour guide was hard to hear. The museum has a lot of potential and could become a really interesting place to visit with a bit of an organisational revamp.

Great History and presentation. The tour included a boat ride, bus tour around the island and a previous prisoner showed us around the prison. A Lot to take in and we felt the tour was a bit rushed, especially at the prison where they had audio from previous inmates throughout the cells.

An Amazing Experience. Such an eye opening experience to see first hand what the prisoners of Robben Island lived with during their stays. Having a tour guide that was a former prisoner was just amazing.

Walk in the Past. There is a love/hate relationship that Capetonians have with Robben Island. For one, it is a distant island that most of us gaze upon from our shores, but with the tragic history associated with it. It will always be our own Alcatraz. When stepping onto the Island for the first time, I got an eerie sense of the past, which was of course unsettling. On the one hand, it is our duty to experience the tour, but on the other it has a haunting feeling knowing what transpired here. Tourists will thrive on the magic of Madiba that still echoes on the island, while locals may have a different sense altogether having felt the Madiba magic in our every day lives. Regardless of your reasons for visiting the troubling yet iconic island, it will leave you filled with emotion that may not leave you for a long time, or at all. It was surreal, that you can be sure of.
Historical site. First hand view of apartheid's results- very interesting- part of the tour conducted by former prisoners-a must see if in Cape Town-- allow 4 hours

VERY GOOD. It was a very interesting experience. The guides are all former inmates of the prison. Our guide's recounting of the ways he was tortured brought tears to my eyes. I loved seeing the seals cavorting in the water from the ferry.

Memorable journey and seal sighting.. Trip to Robben Island by steamer is a memorable experience. The island has large population of Atlantic seal and their antiques are worth watching. The bay also is really beautiful and the trip is really memorable one.
Educational. One of the best places to learn the history of South Africa. Learned some things I didn't know especially about Robert Sobukwe - I'm glad I went there.

A must do in cape town. A very well presented tour. Ferries run to robbed island three times a day 9,11,13) weather dependent. Try and get to the harbour at least 30mins ahead. The journey is 30mins. You then get an intro to the island, talk from an ex political prisoner, you'll see mandalas cell. Finally there is a bus tour of Robben island with a very informed guide who will tell you all about the history of SA and also of the islands fauna. Excellent tour

Must see while in Cape Town. Robben Island is an absolute must see for anyone who visits Cape Town. It is an incredible experience and a testament of the human spirit. Getting there is easy and once you have your ticket everything is taken care of, from your bus tour to the actual tour of the island with a former political prisoner. The island isn't just about Nelson Mandela, but about all of those who fought in captivity for a better South Africa. Beautiful experience.

Daunting but very important experience in understanding the Apartheid era. After a 30 minute boat ride on somewhat rough seas (those prone to seasickness -- be warned) on a large ferry, we arrived and were in a group that was taken directly to the prison (vs. taking the bus ride around the island). Our guide was a former political prisoner who shared his gosh-awful experiences (interrogation under the worse conditions imaginable and the most inhumane form of torture) --- everyone in our group could have heard the proverbial pin drop. Of course we were all curious about Nelson Mandela's cell and experience and in-prison leadership of the others. It would be a shame to visit Cape Town and not see/experience Robben Island!

Very educational. Take you sea sickness tablets as ride can be choppyReally informed bus ride around the island and great to have an ex prisoner take you round the prison and tell you all about it and his personal experiences It was a humbling experience especially when you see what they experience compared to modern times in prison You may also be lucky to spot a penguin or too and the shop is great for memorabilia

Not for everyone.. This 30' ferry ride to Robben Island is an eye opener. It is not just about Nelson Mandela but all of the men and boys who took part in protesting apartheid in South Africa. Our guide was a former prisoner who was rounded up for protesting when he was in high school. He spent 5 years in prison. As an American, I had no idea how oppressive the South African government was before the 1990s. When Le Clerq ( spelling? ) handed over the government to the black majority it was without a civil war that you see in so many countries today. It is still an evolutionary progress but so much better for blacks than before. South Africa is essentially a three pronged society. Whites, nonwhites and blacks. It is a beautiful country finding its way peacefully into the future. I wish them the best and credit Mandela for the road of non hate.

Great history tour. We did the ferry trip to Robben Island and toured the island and then the prison. It was very interesting listening to a former political prisoner however it would have been nice to learn a bit more about e island and its other history as well as the Mandela period.
Jetty museum in the Waterfront. I never realised there is the Robben Island Jetty Museum in the V&A Waterfront until we saw it on the programme of the Museum Night. What an interesting little museum!

Well presented tour.. Very sobering part of the countries history , but well conducted on both the little bus tour before you enter the prison and listening to one of the former prisoners describe conditions experienced when the prison was open.

A historical visit. The ferry ride to Robben Island is a "must" for anyone interested in South African history. A guided tour is provided by former inmates providing insight to their experience and those of the anti-Apartheit leaders. To view Nelson Mandela's cell is to appreciate his commitment to his cause.

A must. Robben Island, along with the Apartheid Museum in Johannesburg are essential stops for any visitor to S. Africa. The ferry ride is delightful, but the main point is to experience this aspect of S. Africa's history. Touring the island by bus is fascinating; walking through the prison, guided by a former inmate is overwhelmingly moving. Do NOT miss this.
Could not do,this trip. We understand that this is well worth doing, but unfortunately we were too late to book tickets. So either book your tickets before you go or as soon as you get there

How much is your time worth?. I had very mixed feelings about Robben Island. I went because I read Alan Paton's Cry the Beloved Country sometime in the 1960s, participated in civil rights things traveling to Mississippi, USA stuff in the 1960s, and 3) Had also become interested in South African issues when I heard Bishop Tutu speak at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco in the 1980s. But the truth is that for the most part the trip to Robben Island is slow and boring except for the brief period hearing a former prisoner describe life there. And it takes a long time. And it doesn't help that I don't have much faith in what Mandela's political party, the ANC, has done for the African people since his death.
Well organized . Well organized tours. On time, with great facilities.Enjoyed the talks and overall attitude of the staff.Great to see the effort to tackle littering.Recommended.

Highly recommended historical adventure. A definite must visit for all South Africans. So glad I had the opportunity to share this experience with my girls. Such an important part of our history which helps one understand why some can forgive but perhaps never forget the struggles of the past.A very well organized outing. My only criticism is that they don't allow enough time to read the many writings that express the feelings of those who experienced life as prisoners on Robben Island. Felt a little rushed and would have appreciated an extra hour or 2 on the island.

Great informative tour and views. Boat ride aside, this was a great insightful, educational and visually pleasing experience. The guide was funny and informative, and there are great views to be had. The tour of the political wing of the prison was given by a former prisoner which was a great touch, for us to try to understand the conditions.

Interesting. As this was the jail that not only housed Mandela and his freedom fighters it is worth the visit....but don't think you will be able to look around freely.Once landing on the island you are put in a bus and driven around but really not allowed to disembark anywhere.You are than taken through the jail cells told very brief stories are shown mandela's cell and than put back on the ferry to mainland.For the money of the tickets, the boat ride is worth the trip.
A must visit. This place has enthralled, inspired and humbled me, if you come to Cape Town you must come here. All negative reviews should be disregarded.

Boat tour to and around Robben Island. I was a little let down from the visit to the Island. We had a nice boat trip across the harbour and were met by a ex inmate who guided us around the island and the prison area itself. He explained how he was arrested and the hardships he was put through. He also showed us where Nelson Mandela's cell was. I feel I would have benefited much better if I have been able to walk around on our own and read rather than being spoken to. Very one sided opinions and he seemed as if he was totally bored with his job.

Essential. The 45 minute ferry ride doesn't go out on blustery days. Even with advane tickets, prepare to stand in line a while before boarding--she boat was late coming in. The ferry is scenic in and of itself with beautiul views back to Cape Town. Tour begins with a bus tour of the homes for lepers etc, then a walking tour which includes a visit to the dorm like prison rooms for political prisoners who weren't leaders. Then off to the individual cells, including Mandela's. In addition to the leaders of the anti-apartheid movement it is interesting to learn about other political prisoners, especially, about the Namibians.

Maybe. Important to visit because Robben Island as it is a World Heritage Site & also because this is where the plan for theNew South Africa was formulated by Nelson Mandela. Unfortunately, the operation lacks professionalism & the ferries often run late. Allow yourself extra time with this tour. Tour guides on the walking part of the tour are sometimes hard to hear. Stay close to your guide to hear his story.

A Must-See if you are in Capetown. The boat ride over to Robben Island is worth the price of the ticket alone. You are whisked away on buses to tour the island before you walk through the prison. Make sure you bee-line straight to the bus after disembarking so you get a seat with those you are traveling with!!!

The first thing we did in Cape Town. This tour was probably the reason we decided to come to Cape Town. The tour seemed to define such a momentous transition in South Africa's history. But as a UK citizen, our historical relationship with slavery is regrettable. It was important to us that our teenagers were able to have an insight into the torture, torment and injustice of the Apartheid regime. We were careful to emphasise to them that all slavery including modern forms were just as appalling.However the tour was up beat. It focuses on the message of forgiveness and tolerance. There was real pride that SA had managed the transition without dissolving into Civil War. Our guide at the prison was an ex-political prisoner. His description of his experiences was graphic but very real and completely believable. He brought the empty buildings to life with his descriptions.We did feel a bit rushed at the end- as you only have until your ferry leaves. The tour buses are also a bit dated- I wouldn't really care about that but the guide's microphone was unreliable- so those at the back of the coach could not decipher why he was saying.
Nice trip. A well organised trip. The tour guide was very friendly. Just make sure to go in a nice sunny day. You need to book in advance.

Good history lesson. Robben island is one of those places that you hear a lot about and just need to visit. The first part of the tour in the bus was a good way to start the tour. You get a good impression of the island. Our guide spoke understandable english and was able to answer questions.Buses are perhaps ready for an upgrade? Buses also stop at a location with a beautiful view over cape town.The second part inside the prison was the best part, we again had a good guide (former prisoner) which explained everything in detail. Perhaps expectations are increased by all the stories/reviews of Robben island but the main conclusion for me would be that to understand the history of South Africa, one has to visit it themselves.

Sad to see how run down the island has become!. The tour on Robben Island was disorganised, not very interactive and the island has become dilapidated as zero maintenance has been done on any of the grounds and buildings. The tour guide who was one of the original prisoners gave a very interesting account of his incarceration, but the tour was rushed and there has been no effort made to facilitate any audio visual experiences. The cells are almost barren and after being hustled through the tour we had to wait 30 minutes on the quayside for our boat, time which we would have loved to have spent looking closer at the prison museum

Very enlightening tour, a window into South Africa's history. The tour guides were excellent in knowledge of the Island and humor, it was great being able to walk through the cells, read the personal struggles and victories of the prisoner, see the actual cell where Nelson Mandela was held.

An experience not to be missed. This is one of the few historical sites which are still from a time we lived through. The guides are all ex-prisoners with a depth of insight that is unparalleled. The issue I have is that because of the strict timetable of the tour there is not enough time to really appreciate all the individual stories available I needed at least 1-2 hours more in the prison

A Worthwhile Half Day Excursion. The boat ride alone is worth going to Robbin Island. Such a beautiful perspective of Cape Town and Table Mountain from the water. Having said that, the tour itself has changed a lot from our experience 12 years ago. In 2004 Apartheid was only a decade out and the emotions of the revolution were still raw and powerful. Nelson Mandela was still alive and the respect and awe of what he accomplished was fresh and real. Our tour this time felt like a canned speech written by Disney. Informative? Yes, but unfortunate to have lost the genuine spirit of reconciliation in such a short time.

Disappointing . With all the respect I have for this place and the people, I thought it was very disappointing. It is one of the to do activities in Cape Town because of its history.It takes about 30min by boat from the Waterfront to Robben Islamd. As soon as you get on the island, you are placed into busses. You drive around the island together with a tour guide. The Tour guide I had, could barely answer any questions. Even I believe often asked questions such as "How old was Nelson Mandela when he left the Island?". Once the drive was over we went into actual prison and met with a former prisoner. That meeting is very special as you can the emotions when he is talking about it.The prison has been completely repainted and looks brand new... It made me feel like I was in hospital instead of a prison. All the drawings or writings the prisoners could have done disappeared under that bright new grey and white wall... If you are only staying for a short period in Cape Town I wouldn't say it is a must.

A Must when in Capetown. My hotel took me in their minicab to the V&A waterfront to catch the boat, boat trip over lasts about 30-40 minutes. Everyone off the boats gets into buses once they arrive on the island. Our guide was very good, so good that we were late getting back to the boat, so it was late going back over to Capetown! Really interesting tour, walked past where mandela and other political prisoners were held. Also where families came to visit etc. It must have been realy hard for the prisoners as they could only see their family for a very short time each day. The guide who took us around the prison was an ex-prisoner which was good.

Interesting and well worth it. Interesting trip that is informative and educational. As an added bonus you get spectacular views of Table Mountain.The bus tour of approx 45 mins gave us all the information about the island and its history that you need. The tour of the prison is by an ex inmate and he gives you plenty of background and interesting facts.

Soul Stirring Excursion. The boat trip took about 45 minutes from V&A Waterfront to this world historic site where President Nelson Mandela was held captive along with other African citizens fighting against apartheid. This is a must see and will surely stir your soul. Well preserved and the docents provide excellent narratives as you walk the grounds and facilities of history.

Educational and Inspirational. The entire tour is between 3 to 4 hours including a half hour ferry ride to and from the island.The tour is very educational, but more than that, because the prison guide was an ex-prisoner there, sense you get when he shares his stories is like history brought to live. The personal "stories" by some of the prisoners, printed and displayed in the actual cells they stayed in, helps you to imagine what the conditions must have been like during their prison days.A "must go" even for those disinterested in history, because one cannot help but become interested once actually there.The tour comprise 2 parts, a visit to the prison complex, and a tour of the island on a bus with stops at several places of interest on the island (like the quarry where the prisoner worked while serving time).

Can't miss. This was a truly amazing experience that can't be missed by anyone visiting Cape Town. To see the island was in itself amazing, but what I found most incredible was the tour of the maximum security prison led by a former political prisoner - hearing his experiences firsthand is something I will never forget.

An island full of history . If you're in Cape Town, Robben Island is a must. It was an emotional experience visiting the prison where brave men made history. The best part of the tour is that the guide is a precious political prisoner!

Emotionally Powerful Experience. I have never been as moved by a travel experience as this. The guides, including a former prisoner, provide so much historical information and context, and seeing some of the iconic places from the life of President Mandela was incredible. Their logo represents the Triumph of the Human Spirit, and that is palpable in meeting a former prisoner, seeing so many pictures, and hearing so many stories. I left less angry with the brutal suppression and racism of the captors, and more in awe of the strength and will, and humanity, of the prisoners.

It has to be done. . I had read some bad reviews on here about the experience not being worthwhile and people feeling like they were being herded around the island. I didn't find that true. We catamaraned to Robben island and then had a very informative guided tour by a guide and an ex prisoner. Time was managed, but of course it was, there was a boat to catch back, but there was plenty of time to take pictures, ask questions and see Mandelas garden and cell, along with other areas of the island. Definitely worth a visit.

Interesting piece of SA history. I really enjoyed this trip. It was so great to see the history of Mandela. There were some discrepancies between the cell you see on the video coming over in the boat compared to the actual cell at the jail
definatley a must see very educational. Staff are very clued up and ready to answer questions with confidence.very well planned trip and good for the young ones to learn

Interesting day out. I still can't understand how hate can dominate and cage people who just want to be free. The more I travel the less any of this ever made any sense. It's amazing Nelson Mandela was able to break away from the hatred cycle and lead his Country to a path to peace. I am not sure I could have done the same. A don't miss real history lesson for us all to see. I do see things have been slow to change here but I have hope with Mandela's encouragement as well as the kind people we have met here during our travels.

Worth a visit, but perhaps without the touristy bus trip. A visit to Robben Island is a must for mist people, and it is a very interesting and thought provoking trip. The prison tour guides are all ex prisoners which makes it even more poignant. When you arrive you are ushered onto tour buses and taken round the island, which is quite interesting but is longer than necessary - perhaps just walking round the island alone would be preferable. A long stop at the only cafe for some mediocre expensive coffee.The ferry crossing takes 30 to 45 minutes and they run very regularly - book ahead though.

Robben Island Trip. Robben Island Museum invokes much emotion with its history. A twenty minute boat ride from Cape Town. The waters can be very choppy so be sure to take some motion sickness tablets if you are a sufferer like me. The tour includes a foot tour into the maximum prison where political prisoners where detained and a bus tour around the rest of the island. Child friendly with a fifteen minute stop for toilets, coffee, sandwiches, cookies, books and photos along the way. Definitely worth your time if you are in Cape Town.

Extremely humbling, well worth a visit. A boat trip starts your journey to Robben Island and if you are lucky there may be some Dolphins. At the island you transfer to a bus for a tour of the island and then on foot into the prison. What an amazing story...as place not to miss.

Dr Nelson Mandela Cell for 27 years.. The journey by boat from the V & A Water Front was awesome, in the island a tour guard take you around the prison, the touching moment is when you are shown the cell where Nelson Mandela spent the most of his 27 years in prison, the quarry where they were forced to dig lime by hand, a very touchy moment indeed.

A must visit site - superbly preserved.... NB: A ferry journey is required for your trip to Robben Island - if the weather isn't favourable the ferry doesn't run - check the website..On arrival at Robben Island our bus embarked on an island tour of approx 45mins to 1hr. The story of the island on this trip is told by friendly & informative guides who explain that Robben Island wasn't just a prison in years gone by, indeed now it's home to not only families & staff but wildlife too.On your bus tour you do stop at a little type of club house allowing you to meet (in our case) an ex-guard at the prison, grab a drink & snack & make use of the bathrooms. It's not a restaurant.On arrival at the prison itself our visit was conducted by an ex-prisoner. He bought into parts of the tour his memories & experience of life at Robben. His story alone was incredible but all in all we found it an educational & fascinating visit. For those wishing to know timings our trip in total took about 4hrs including the ferry journey, the bus trip around the island the visit to the museum/prison itself & a portion of time before your return ferry journey to visit the islands shop. We thought well worth the visit.Facilities wise: The shop by the Clock Tower before you depart is quite small, for those going to the island the shop their is bigger & stocks a wider selection of items.There is not a restaurant as such that you stop at on the island - their is the small club house on your bus trip where you can get snacks, tea, coffee etc.

A must see for all visitors to Cape Town. Its a shirt boat ride away, a journey that could be bad on your tummy if the sea is choppy. But its totally worth it once there. The whole trip is guided and if you have a good guide, like we di, then its absolutely amazing to hear the story of horror that unfolded there in Robben Island.
A must see. A very historical site and worth every minute. The guides are walking history books, which even made our children listen. The process is very well run and they keep you to schedule.

Interesting tour. Very interesting to see how Nelson Mandela was in prison.. Great tour guide on the bus, very well presented and informative about the history of the island... Bit expensive but worth the money. Bit more freedom to explore would be nice... But the tour is worth it at the end of the day... Trip back allows for amazing photos of Capetown.

Should be better. Educational of course but not much else apart from a nice boat trip. Didn't get the emotional or interested buy in you usually get from places like this. Perhaps just the guides we had on the day?

Very worthwhile. Some friends had said not to bother with Robben island as it"is tired" but they're wrong. Go. This was uplifting, walking in the steps of Mandela. There prison tour was by an ex inmate, so hearing about life there first hand was emotional. If you aren't interested in this then the views of Cape Town across the bay are worth it.

A life on the ocean wave.. A Tourist attraction and quite pricey to go across on the boat - providing the boat doesn't break down which quite often happens !!! Takes about half hour or so each way and there's a gift shop on the island as well as a tour bus which takes one around the island which is quite interesting. A tour around the old prison is also interesting but not something that would keep children occupied. You would need good weather also & wrap up, the ride across can be quite chilly.

Sobering view of South African History. Although the sea was pretty rough the boat trip (4km) did not make me feel sea sick which I sometimes suffer from. The tour included a bus trip round a portion of the island and a tour of some of the cell blocks. Both the guides were very knowledgeable and provided fascinating information. I know most people are interested in the political prisoners but I would have liked to hear more about the leper colony and local chiefs the British banished to the island during colonization. I booked my ticket online but missed my tour as public transport took a lot longer than expected. Robben Island does not give refunds or reschedule.
Well recommended . Ensure you book this trip when visiting Capetown. The staff and volunteers were knowledgeable and jovial so made our trip so interesting.Good value for money.

Not enough time. I would have given this an "excellent" except groups are shuffled in and out far too quickly, and there is no freedom to explore, think about what you are seeing and hearing (or have heard), or read any of the large picture posters along the dock. One of the television monitors on the ferry was not working, so we were unable to see the documentary that was being shown on the way out.

Lessons learned from former prison inmate - history and grace. There are 3 parts of the tour.(1) The ferry ride to/from Robben Island - this is beautiful on a clear day. The peacefulness is very welcome on the return.(2) The bus tour of the island. You will be ushered onto a bus and they will fill every seat before starting on the next bus. There will be a guide that gives general information about the island. This was of some interest but the guide talked rapidly and was prone to trying to punch up the talk with humor and shout-outs.(3) The tour of the prison by former inmates. On our tour it was a little confusing on which of these guides to follow and it didn't seem to sync up with the ferry departure. Get that settled in your mind because the lessons to learn from these former prisoners are well work it. Our guide was captured with 5 of his friends as political prisoners. After 6 months of torture, 4 of them were released to Robben Island to serve their time. One of their group did not survive the torture to elicit names of other protesters. With all of that as his background, he spoke calmly of what happened and expressed gratitude for those that helped them. He spoke of how important the news was and how they spread that information. Weeks after my return, I still find myself thinking of things he said and wondering how we can do things like this to each other.

Eye opening visit to Robben Island. It is best to book online a day or two in advance. There are currently 3 ferry timings to choose from: 9am, 11am and 1pm. The ferry crossing takes about 45 minutes each way. The entire trip lasts approximately 4 hours from start to finish. So if you depart on the 9am ferry, you should return to port about 1 to 1:15pm.Obviously you're going to visit a prison and learn about some of the history of South Africa and the apartheid regime. So don't be surprised if you shed a tear or two. It's eye opening information but definitely worth the visit.The ticket costs approximately 20 euro and included the return ferry crossing plus a bus tour and a walking tour with one of the former prisoners.

Must do. Very interesting and thought provoking.. We weren't planning to do Robben Island but I am so pleased we did! It seems to be bestter if you pre book your tickets so as to ensure you can turn up and get onto the ferry you want. The ferry across affords great views of Table Mountain, and then once on the island you get some great views back.Our guide was a former inmate who gave us an excellent tour of the site, most notably the prison cells. There was a bonus; the penguins in one of the bays were a lovely sight too.Well worth the visit...with a great feey trip and views of the mountain.
History. Visiting the historic place gave lot of insights on the struggle of the people in South Africa. Stories narrated by the ex-inmates gave us the virtual tour of the historic place.

Essential visit when in Cape Town. Learn about the history of the island, although naturally focuses on the apartheid years. You not only get the boat trip across to the island, but a coach tour around it, plus a tour of parts of the prison by an ex-political prisoner. Thought provoking.

Meaningful to understand more about apartheid . This is one of those attractions that is not entertaining but is important to experience as a UNESCO site. We purchased tickets online in advance to avoid a sell-out but they can be purchased on the wharf if available. You cannot park or be dropped at the terminal entrance, so do be prepared to walk a short distance. There is an exhibit about apartheid at the ferry terminal - although we did not view it because boarding starts early on busy days. The ferry ride is about an hour, and may be rough for those with motion sickness. It is also important to note the ferry sometimes cancels due to weather so be prepared to reschedule if you can.Once on the island itself, the focus is on detention and prison life. The first half is a tour of the island itself conducted on a bus, and photo opportunities are limited to the side on which you are seated. The second part is a walking tour of the facility guided by a former political prisoner. I appreciated that previous reviews set appropriate expectations about the content: the presentation covers all prisoners' experiences and is not focused solely on Nelson Mandela. Obviously he was not the only prisoner, although he is the most famous and there is an opportunity to view his cell.Depending on the group size, it can sometimes be difficult to hear. Our group was very polite but it helps to be close to the front.Overall the tour takes about 3 hours, and is a moving and educational experience about a tragic period in recent history.

A sobering experience. Maybe it was just the overcast day and choppy grey sea, but the trip to Robben Island was bleak and somber for me. There were plenty of chatty happy people around but to watch the mainland disappear and the flat ominous island waiting to receive guests gave me the chills. The guides are ex-prisoners and tell of what happened to them while inmates. Everyone should visit Robben Island as it both informs and warns.

Listen to the thoughts and stories of an ex Robben Island imate. The ferry trip to the island and the view back to Cape town and Table Mountain was worth the $320 R ticket price, add to that the opportunity to listen to an ex inmate on his experience and then to see the cell where Nelson Mandela spent 18 years of his life priceless.

Extraordinary Tour. Do Not Believe SMARTour LocalGuide Trying to Get You to Not Go!. May-June 2016 travel dates with SMARTours. Robben Island is not part of their Africa tour; however, SMARTours lists Robben Island Tour as an optional tour to take during your free time in Cape Town, South Africa. This optional tour suggestion was a highlight of our time in Cape Town and recommend you not pass up the opportunity. Unfortunately the ground tour operator in Cape Town did everything in his power to persuade us to abandon our plans and spend our free time paying him for a high priced tour of his own. What a disservice to a world traveler! Please do not pass up a trip to Robben Island.Robben Island is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It has been a military base, a leper colony, a mental institution, prison for criminals, and most famously the prison for Anti apartheid Political Prisoners, including Nelson Mandela. This has been such an important part of late 20th Century history. Furthermore, the tour is extremely well done. The Ferry is clean, spacious, and comfortable. The introductory video that is played en route and back to the mainland is very well done. The initial motor coach “windshield” tour around the area is magnificent. Our motor coach guide and driver were will informed, engaging, interesting, asked questions of us to make sure we understood, and these men were very professional. A former political prisoner inmate inside the prison was fascinating. He deftly fielded questions and could frame the experiences of prisoners in such a manner as to give you a very genuine experience by way of his first-hand account. Without exception everyone in our SMARTour Group that ignored SMARTour guide Ron and went to Robben Island were so happy they did not listen to him and participated in the Robben Island Tour.Nominal cost of about $20 US Dollars.Very educational.Location is Victoria and Alfred Waterfront, which has many delightful shops, photography opportunities, and places to enjoy a meal. Easy access by cab from our hotel was approximately 100 Rand ($6.75).

Must go. An amazing experience just on the ferry ride over getting the view of cape town from the water. Once there the island tour and jail tour was very informative. The jail tours are done by past political prisoners which is a special treat since they won't always be with us. My husband and I were able to have a great side convo with our guide. I will forever cherish this moment b/c not everyone will have it. Thank you mr Mcongo!
could be 2 hrs shorter. My teenagers were very interested in going, but after 3 hrs, its MORE than enough. IF you go at Christmas, buy your tickets in advance!
What to say.... A must see. What else to say? Definitely sobering, interesting to hear from previous prisoners themselves.

Heartbreaking but a piece of history worth visiting. The bus tour with the guide explaining the history of the place and the prisoners who lived here, some in isolation for years, how they were referred to by numbers, the Robben Island university where most like Mandela worked in the mines; was a little heartbreaking but I was glad to walk in their footsteps. We also met and got a tour with a former prisoner.

Enlightening, heartbreaking and well worth the visit!. The tour was fantastic, it was really sad to see the conditions that were placed on prisoners and especially the harsher treatment of 'political prisoners'. I found the trip extremely educational and everybody should go. The ferry ride takes a little while (I think it was about 25 mins each way) and you can buy snacks on it or at the island. The whole ferry ride and tour takes about 3 hours and it goes pretty fast once you are on the island to get you back to ferry in time.

Interesting but could be better. The tour was by bus on the island and provide only limited opportunity to experience the place. Our tour of the prison complex and cell where Mandela was imprisoned was interesting but was a bit sterile with very few objects on display from the period. This we felt detracted from the experience in that you didn't get a feel for what it would have been like to be imprisoned there.

Must Visit for Historic Reasons. We visited Robben Island on a beautiful day in March 2016. The ferry ride was scenic and enjoyable. Once on the island we had a private tour and our guide was very informative. When she finished her part of our tour she introduced us to our next guide, a former prisoner at the time Mandela was at Robben Island. This was the best part of the tour. We talked to him about his time there and why he was imprisoned.... for peacefully protesting during the Apartheid. Unbelievable. He showed us Mandela's cell and also the cell he was in. We are very glad we visited Robben Island.
Wonderful Place!. I loved hearing the stories about the political prisoners who fought to end the apartheid in South Africa.

Must do in South Africa. A very interesting part of anyones trip to South Africa. The boat out is great, we saw whales and dolphins. Our tour was completed by an ex-prisoner from Robben Island which makes it that much more personal and special. Of course you see Nelson Mandela's cell and get to understand the history and conditions of the prisoners themselves.
History with aftertaste. Unless you are very much in history there far better things to do in Cape Town than to visit this Island.

We learned so much at Robben Island about Nelson Mandela. Our tour guide at Robben Island was unbelievable. He was a former prisoner at Robben Island while Mandela was there. Everything he was relating to us was 1st hand information. You almost felt like you were there when he was describing the living conditions in the prison. We went into most of the blocks and saw where Mandela spent 18 of his 27 years in prison. It was something that will be with me forever. I'm so happy that Tauck Tours has Robben Island in their itinerary!
Very poignant trip.. This is an interesting trip with informative guides and gives something of an insight into the events of Robben Island.

Part of the Dark History of Apartheid. Robben Island was the site of the prison where Nelson Mandella was taken as well as many other political activists during the apartheid era. It has been compared to Alcatraz and rightfully so. The tour is conducted from a bus with a couple of stops for photos. The prison tour is a walking tour and the guide is one of the former inmates. Worth the time and effort to get there.

Very impressive Experience!. Our tour was led by a former prisoner (later we met a former guard). The personal nature of the tour, the background information on the island, the prisoners and their history made it into a very special experience. Although I thought I know something about Robben Island and it's most famous prisoner, I heard many new details. My advice: when visiting Cape Town, you cannot leave without visiting Robben Island!

it was a pilgrimage. the journey by catamaran was quite pleasant. the fact that it housed Mr Mandela and shaped his thoughts turned it into a place of worship for humanity. You see where he stayed for 17 years , suffered it and then survived it and then realise what a great person he was. He came back to talk peace, talk forgiveness and talk cooperation . Its only who has gone through it can come a full circle. Its a hair raising experience to go through the tour and more so when an ex political prisoner show you around. It becomes so real!

Amazing and Chilling. This is a must if you are in the Cape Town area. The experience is one that cannot be matched. It is unique and very educational. You cannot leave this tour without a new appreciation of how far along the country has come.

Apartheid Continued. We took the ferry from the V&A Waterfront on a Sunday afternoon. We walked to the waiting tour buses for a narrated overview of the history of Robben Island from a very entertaining bus driver. Seeing Robben Island a couple of days before from the top of Table Mountain underscored the isolation of the prisoners on the island which sits off-shore but well within sight of the city of Cape Town. After a tour by bus around the island, including a ride by the quarry where prisoners worked at hard labor and a stop at a small museum with a view of Cape Town from its shores, we were dropped off at the prison. Our guide, as is the case with all of the prison guides, was a former inmate. All Robben Island prisoners were black and primarily political prisoners. He took us through the cell blocks-solitary confinement, including a look at Nelson Mandela's cell, and the dormitory-style rooms which held several prisoners- and explained what life was like for them. We would have spent more time but ours was the last tour of the day before the final ferry and we had been somewhat delayed on the bus tour. All in all, it was very interesting and well worth the time.
Great Experience. It was a great experience. Saw the maximum prison, had a good tour round the island, and it was educative. Was privileged to take a picture of Nelson Mandela's prison room.

A must see. As many other reviewers have mentioned , a visit to Robben Island is a must if you are in cape town. It has an important role in shaping the history of South Africa. Its recommended that you book the tickets a day in advance. They only have three trips per day. The boat ride was very bouncy due to rough sea. After a 30 min boat ride, you then board a bus which takes you around the main parts of the island. Our guide was very good and we could feel the pain in his voice when he talked about the prisoners. We were then taken around the prison area by a former political prisoner. You are not allowed to explore the island on your own. Overall a very informative trip which gives you a glimpse of the prison life and the hardships endured by the people to get back their freedom.

a must for capetown historic tour, but a bit boring. even i love history, the tour is a bit boring.not much to show and not properly arranged. with so much to offer robben island tour can be much more interesting.

Well preserved historic site with excellent tours. Tickets can be bought on the Internet. Some days tours are cancelled due to weather. It's worth the price. Nice boat ride to the island. Tours given by folks who were actually in prison on the island during apartheid times. That's really awesome---though the way they were treated by the Afrikaaners is sad. Got to check out all the prison rooms with pictures and quotes by the imprisoned. Boat trip back was bouncy. Highly recommend this tour if you visit Cape Town.

Very interesting, but needs better care. The weather was great for the boat trip to the island. The guide was helpful and informed. The toilets needed better cleaning and there was a fair amount of deferred maintenance. There was a colony of rare penguins on the island, but we weren't allowed to get close enough to enjoy them.

Great tour!. We had heard horror stories about this tour, but totally enjoyed it. We went over on the Jester boat. It's slow and old, but has a fully licensed bar if that tickles your fancy. It also has an open top deck for those who need fresh air when out on a boat like me.The tour itself was good. Our guide on the island for the bus tour was lovely. If it's a hot day, the bus could be rather yucky I would imagine. Our day was chilly and overcast so the bus was comfortable temp wise. The seats are tiny so be prepared to be cramped in. Either side of the bus is fine for pictures. I didn't think the bus needed to stop for such a long break to take pics of Cape Town, but it did.Our guide at the prison (former prisoner) was also wonderful. His information and views were wonderful and informative. Touring the place where Mandela was housed was rushed I felt. You were prodded along and didn't have time to linger. Because our boat was slow getting there we got less time on the island. Overall a good tour. Wish we had more time to linger and explore though.

a must see. Roben Island is an interesting place for its footprint in the SA history. As a place of reclusion many people had the bad luck to spend there many years under harsh conditions. One of them was Nelson Mandela. What I found more interesting for me at least, is the fact Mandela and his colleagues who had been at school managed to train their fellow with no education. Everyone teach one - that was their motto. This is what I liked. The resilience of the human spirit. Otherwise, it is a good spot to observe the table mountain and the beauty of Cape Town

Learning History . Fantastic and humbling experience, a former prisoner took us through the prison and the tour guide took us through the island and told us stories .I was humbled when I heard how some people gave up their freedom to fight for their country.

Should have been better and more moving experience. Glad that I went. Could have been much better organized. Ferry took an hour each way and the weather was clear skies and calm waters. We had two guides. Our first guide was a young guy who had not been a political prisoner and spent too much time telling jokes and not enough time focused on the history of Robben Island. Had been lead to believe that we would have one guide who was ex political prisoner. We were 45 minutes late to the part where the ex political prisoner guides us. He was upset that we were so late and he had to significantly condense and rush us through his experiences as a prisoner on Robben Island and a tour of the barracks where he was a prisoner and the cell Mandela was in. He was excellent. Wanted more time with him and not time with the jokester first tour guide. He had so much to share and the we all wanted to spend more time with him. So it seems like sometimes you can get the ex political prisoner for the entire tour -- so when you get off the ferry and the buses are waiting ask for the bus where the ex political prisoner is on.

Modern history worth seeing. I went with a limited knowledge of the Apartheid and left feeling like I'd definitely learned a bit more about it. A nice 30 min boat trip to the island and a bus with multilingual guide to take you around the island. This was followed by a tour of the different cell blocks from a former inmate of the prison. Allow 4 hours for this trip and booking in advance is a must.

Humbling and Inspiring . Made my first visit to Robben Island - humbling and yet inspiring visit - hard to believe the inhumanity and yet wonderful to see these men emerge from this experience to make such an incredible difference to SA Boat trip is 25 mins but beware those who do not travel well by sea - choose a very calm day My third trip to CT but first to the island - recommend this is a must not miss first time

Much more to the island than I had reslised. Fantastic tour. There are two boats providing transport to the island. One being the old prisoner boat. It is much slower than the other, newer boat, but great that we got to experience it.The island tour was guided by a former political prisoner who was very knowledgable and informative and it made the experience all the more interesting being delivered by someone with personal knowledge.A thoroughly insightful tour and well worth a visit.

Historical, Powerful, Unforgettable. To come to South Africa and not visit this sight, you would be missing a major part of it's history.Taking the tour and being guided by one of the former inmates is priceless in the education of Apartheid and the impact it had on this nation.This was a must do tour for me and hard to take in as you hear the story first hand.It's hard to put into words really, as we cannot imagine a life of internment these prisoners experienced. But they changed a society for there suffering and undying efforts.Go there, look and listen.
