not informative and rushed. we were really looking forward to this trip, but unfortunately didn't live up to expectations, its run by ex-cons, which is fine, but its very badly organised, we barely had time to look around and just got a quick photo of Nelson Mandelas cell before we were rushed on, the guides information was very basic and didn't go into a lot of detail regarding their daily routine etc. very little information about Nelson Mandela. we had litterly to run to our ferry immediately when guide finished talking, no time for questions and way too many people on tour. have been to Alcatraz and its a superior tour. disappointed :(

Historic Island. nobody should visit Capetown without a visit to Robben Island. There is so much history there. Our guide was an exprisoner and gave an excellent Account of life there during his incarceration. It being winter the boat trip was rough and one person in our group was sea sick, but generally it was no bother.

Glad we went but.... I'm glad we made the journey to Robben Island, which is still home to 146 people. However, I was a bit disappointed with how it was done. Admittedly it is nothing like Alcatraz, for example, but I do think with a bit of thought and investment in new buses and perhaps multilingual commentary it would be a better experience. The highlight was when a former political prisoner (Sparky) told us his story from his time in maximum security where he spent 7 years.

You have to go, but do be aware.... You can't decently give this very worthy, very moving experience less than a five star review. It is sad, informative, and grave. But you know that already. A few things though are worth bearing in mind when you go. Permit a good half a day to visit - it will take at least that long, and you won't get very much else done in the same day. If it's winter time, don't sit on the upper level of the boat unless you are very well wrapped up. If you get sea-sick, maybe check out the weather a few days in advance before you go - that boat rolls around a lot! And be prepared for how affecting the whole thing is. Not much in this world feels more solemn than having maximum-security lore explained to you by one of its victims. It takes a moment to get over it all. And quite right too. That's just the way it should be. But I'm just warning you...

Nice . Was interesting to learn about the prison and where Nelson Mandela was held. The buses were too full and not enough seats and waited over half hour for boat to leave. Tour was good but took long just to get there.

helpful historical insights: very informative!. i never imagined that robben island was harbored by other people other than prisoners. after the tour am more informed. The other related stories about other freedom fighters or apartheid resistance was so enlightening,.....apart from the common knowledge of Mandela,..... one apartheid fighter caught caught my attention.".. sibukwe.."... ..... the narrator's are so good. very well informed. i was so impressed. ....although there are so many people on these tours.
Bonding. We went there for the first time even though we are South Africans, this is part of our history even South African must visit the island.

Important Part of History. South Africa's colonial segregationist history and the role of the antiapartheid movement is important to understanding the current status of this country in the context of the global economy and world affairs. South Africa is much more than fabulous wildlife and luxury safaris, diamond and gold mines, sophisticated cities such as Cape Town, and beautiful scenery and wine. A visit to Robben Island is only a snapshot of how black political prisoners (and criminals) were treated by the white apartheid government. [the Apartheid Museum in Johannesburg is a must do!] As a tourist attraction, it's not that interesting to just see a bunch of buildings, penguins, and birds -- and Nelson Mandela's cell. The most interesting is the story told by the former prisoner. However, given the size of the group and the acoutistics in the room, it was difficult to hear his voice. They should put a microphone on him, or he should have stood in the middle of the room. The story boards were also amateurish, and could be easily overlooked but told graphic stories of the treatment of the prisoners. This museum could be so much more improved with adequate funding and could really stand as the symbol of the end of the apartheid government. Visitors should spend the half day to visit this former prison, if only to acknowledge that South Africa's political history is a crucial part of the visitor experience of this country.

Significant History, So-So Guides. My wife and I visited Robben Island on a cloudy day in June. We were able to book the tickets online the night before. The boat is simple - adequate seating inside or outside and plenty of room to move around. There is a small bar area that serves chips/crisps and a few drinks. (There is also a small store with snacks upon arrival at Robben Island.) Not that it is at all controllable, but we found the water to be a bit choppy and my wife found that she needed to be outside in the fresh air to calm her stomach. The boat ride was about 45 minutes.Upon arrival to the island, everyone is ushered to large buses to tour the island. The buses will pass by the hospital, the school, the cemetery and stop at an area for photographs. If the sky is clear, you can get some great shots of Table Mountain. Eventually the bus will stop at the prison where you will be escorted by a former (political) prisoner around some of the prison. The former prisoner gives you an idea of the day-to-day life at the prison and helps one gain a better understanding of the past political climate of South Africa.It seems unfair to give an attraction of this much historical significance a low mark on the review, but we found that the tour guides didn't provide enough background and context for non-South-Africans to really grasp everything here. We're educated, travel internationally often, and aware of politics and history, but this just wasn't a great tour.
History. This tour depends on your interest ,for me it was amazing the tour guide was an X political prisoner a wonderful man . He really touched my heart.

Not quite what we expected. It was fantastic to meet an individual who had experienced the horrifying realities of Robben Island, however it wasn't a long tour & did not provide as much information as other similar visits we have done

Needs organization . This is a must do in Cape Town due to the historical, political and social significance of the place. However, there is only one tour option. Half of the tour is spent driving around the island in a bus getting familiar with the landscape. The second half you meet a guide (all of whom are previous political prisoners) who takes you through the prison. While our guide's story was incredibly powerful to hear, it might have been helpful to have paired him with a trained tour guide who could have been prepared to answer more detailed questions about the history of the movement. Book your tickets early, or have your hotel do it, because the number of visitors is limited each day!!
Worth a visit. It is definitely worth a visit, wasn't the best thing that we did but was something that had to be done.

Robben Island the Historical Beacon/landmark in South Africa. hen you get on the Boat to Robben island, you can really get the feeling of the old "Apartheids Years" and how the people were treated before the 1994 elections when Nelson Mandele were elected as the President of South Africe. The whole South Africe move into a new direction, and all the people stand together to make it work for shuch a beatiful country. This experience on Robben island is one of my most Hisorical moments of my live. To see the places where the people had to plan their way out of jail, was just an unbelieveble experience. This is a must see if you visit Cape Town, and if you are interest in the history of South Africa, this is money well spend

Very interesting . After a 40 minute ferry ride, there was a bus ride around the island and to the different prisons and living quarters on there. Had a very informative tour by an ex-political prisoner of the maximum security prison where Nelson Mandela was held. The tour was about 1 hour and a half. Overall the trip took about 3 hours. All for 300 rand. (Around £15)

Must see! But don't compare it to Alcatraz. We went to Alcatraz in May and then went to Robben Island in June. It is a very informative tour and overall a great experience. I recommend the morning tour and then return and hang out at the waterfront for the rest of the day. The boat ride there (30 mins) was pleasant and the tour consisted of a 40 mins bus ride around the island and a 40 mins walking tour in the prison. your tour guide was a former political prisoner and it was neat.

Outstanding Historical Site. We had planned to tour Robben Island where Nelson Mandela had been unjustly incarcerated for quite a long time, wow this tour was outstanding.First, you are taken on a ferry from Cape Town to the Island so during the trip you get majestic views of the city. You basically see Cape Town from a very different perspective. When you arrive to the Island, you are given a tour guide who narrates and discusses the significance of different areas of the island.Our guide was a former inmate who had been unjustly incarcerated with Nelson Mandela. He spoke about their living conditions, their psychological and emotional state as we sat in one of the cells. We also toured to group cells as well as the isolated cell that Mr. Mandela occupied for 17 years before he was moved to another jail. What a historical place.After the tour you are given time to shop - of course. We purchased some books but they have t-shirts etc.Then you get back on the ferry and have another majestic ride back to Cape Town. This is a must-do when in Cape Town.

An OK experience. While it was a must-do on my list, and I suspect most visitors will still go despite any reviews, it was a little underwhelming. This is mostly due to how the visit is structured. You are taken on a ferry and then transferred to a bus. The tour then takes place as a bus tour with a guide talking on the microphone. It ends with a walk through the prison section with a former prisoner as a guide. The whole thing is over in about 90 minutes. The regimented nature makes it feel more like a classroom lecture than a visit to a museum.
Emotional & Educational Tour. I't an old historical place that one has to visit during your lifetime. I't a very well organized, informative and emotional tour & worth all your time.

Go now while former prisoners still lead tours. Very special place. I could have spent another hour here but the ferry leaves pretty soon after the tour. Former detainees lead tours, which is the best part.

a history lesson. This is a must do if you go to Cape Town, its best if you prebook online as they sell out fast for each tour. You go on a ferry first over to the island which tajes about 45 minutes, you are then taken on a coach with a guide who explains a little about the island. Then you are guided around the prison by an ex political prisoner who give you an insite to what it was like to be locked up here. You then take the ferry back, it all takes about 3 hours.

We would not have missed it, but an average experience. Maybe we have seen too many documentaries about the great Nelson Mandela and Robben Island, but it didn't quite work for us.No real time to interact and explore yourself - bus tour followed by a monologue from a former inmate (lots of people nodding off on a warm day) and then rushed past Nelson Mandela's cell.We would not have missed it, but think that a different approach would definitely improve the visitor experience.

Terrific!. Definitely worth doing while you are in Cape Town.Allow a few hours, as the boat trip there and back is an event in itself with the views of the city from another angle.The tour guide on the island being an ex inmate makes it a very personal visit, and of course to actually see the cell where Nelson Mandela lived was incredible.Plenty of time for questions and answers, so go prepared.Best to read up about it before you go so you are more familiar with what to expect when you get there.You can't really come to Cape Town for any length of time and not go to Robben Island!

Educational Experience. As a South African, it was a real eye opener to see the living conditions of political prisoners in the 1960's, such as Nelson Mandela and his fellow comrades, who eventually shaped our current democracy. A heart warming experience. Will highly recommend this historic journey.

An educational trip full of South African History. About a half hour boat trip from the marina in Cape Town. We landed at Robben Island and walked to several buses. There was an excellent guide who gave plenty of information about the island and the prison. Nelson Mandela was held for 17 years and then transferred elsewhere. Robert Sobutkwe was also held under house arrest on the island. Once the bus trip was over we stopped at the dangerous block of the prison where we were taken around by a former political prisoner. He told us about life in the prison and showed us Nelson Mandela's cell.

Structured Tour of Robben Island. Everyone who goes to Cape Town should go to Robben Island. The tour was well thought out and the tour guides are excellent. The tour was somewhat structured with a drive around the island with a tour guide and then a tour around the prison with a former prisoner. Hearing the prisoner's experience was especially powerful. I would have liked to have more of an opportunity to walk around and see more of the prison and I may take another trip to do that.

Steeped in history. A place and a person that leave you in awe- a prison where nelson Mandela was tortured and spent terrible days and still came out with only forgiveness for his captors, not only tells you of the morass of apartheid and what the blacks had to endure but leaves an indelible Impression of the greatness of the man!

Up close and personal with history . My visit to Robben Island was emotional. All of the tour guides on the island including ours were former political prisoners at the prison. I is very eye opening to see and hear about the treatment and conditions the prisoners had to endure.

A must-visit on your Cape Town trip. A very moving and humbling experience, well worth the visit. Former inmates of Robben Island will take you around the island and through the prison, including a walk past Nelson Mandela's cell.The tour is one of the most popular CPT activities so it is best to book online a day or two ahead if there is a particular departure time you want. We visited the museum at the Waterfront on the day and could only get tickets for the 3pm departure, which wasn't a problem for us, but a number of others in the line were from a cruise ship and needed a specific departure time.

The ride to freedom. This was quite a moving experience for everyone who visits Cape town. The history and the story is unforgettable and the ferry ride, as well as the tour is wonderful. You won't regret going!

Gives a very moving understanding.. The boat ride was a bit rough. The bus tour was informative. The best part is the tour guide of the prison was an actual inmate of the apartheid period. Great learning experience.
Nelson. My late dad was born on Robben island. My late grandmother was a matron. History!!! Nelson Mandela spent 27yrs imprisonment.
History!. This is a must when visiting Cape Town! It really gives you the history of Nelson Mandella! Do0nt miss this island!

Don't Miss Out on This. This was a “Must Do” as we prepared to for our trip touring South Africa. I am so glad that we had the foresight. The trip to the island was fantastic and gave ample opportunity to take some superb photos of Cape Town and Table mountain from out at sea. Once at Robben Island we had what proved to be a humbling experience. The tour guide was an ex-convict from Robben Island. He told some of his life story, about his arrest and imprisonment at the age of 19 and kept confined on the island for 18 years thereafter at a time when Nelson Mandela was also there. It was told in a very matter of fact way, without bitterness or anger. It was truly a fantastic tour and one that I would thoroughly recommend.It is not that expensive but you should book in advance and cross your fingers that the trip is not cancelled because of bad weather.

An important part of history. Tour the prison where Nelson Mandela and other political opponents of apartheid were held in tiny cells for years. The tours are conducted by former political prisoners who served time in the prison. The tour also includes a bus tour of the island, which has a small village and also was formerly a leper colony. By tickets online in advance - they sell out quickly. And get to the boat early - it holds about 300 people and loading takes some time as they use metal detectors and X-ray to screen all passengers and their belongings.

Emotional Tour. We were given the tour by a guide who was once a political prisoner, you have to really be emotionally prepared for a tour like this. Pictures of prisoners in each cell, persons of different race and nationality who fought for the rights of the people of South Africa. We got a glimpse into the daily life of the prisoners, went to the cell where Nelson Mandela spent 18 years of his life and was given a tour of the Island. Lots of history, highly recommend this tour.
Amazing Africa Tours. If you are interested in history, it is a must to do the excursion to Robben Island. The tour is handled very well with lots of information. Book at your hotel reception.

This atrraction is a closed down prision that was filled with Apartheid prisioners including Nelson Mendela. This is includes a beautiful Ferry boat ride from Cape Town Ferry Terminal to Robben Island. This is a very popular attraction that includes many tour groups I would suggest that you get your tickets for first sailing, as our boat was about 45 minutes delayed. The guided tour is great. This is historic place that is very sobering and does not seem to hold the interest of many school children which can be nerve racking if you are trying to hear the guide. It would be a huge improvement if the tour guides had microphones. It is a depressing tour to believe this happened not to long ago.

We learned so much. This is an important visit to Cape Town. The history and the significance was integral to our visit to South Africa. Be sure to purchase tickets in advance to avoid long lines. Our guide on the island was a former prisoner who shared his personal stories and insights to give us a clearer understanding of the history. The bus trip around the island was worth the time. Be sure to allow for the boat trip and the tour. We highly recommend spending a half day at Robbin Island.

Tour Guide was an ex-prisoner!. My tour was running very late. Because of that, I felt the 30 min of the tour (which ended up being the most interesting part) was very rushed. The boat ride to the island was about 25 min but it was very nice and relaxing. My bu tour guide was informative and funny. I enjoyed the walking tour the most. Despite it being haunting and rather sad, it was definitely the most interesting. Having an ex-prisoner as the guide was crazy. He was telling us his personal experience at the prison and man... it was rough to say the least. I just brought a fanny pack filled with my essentials and I was set. You have a chance to buy snacks/food/drinks on the boat and on the island. Overall it was a cool experience. I just wish I could've spent a little more time on the walking part of the tour.

Great Boat Trip Out. Too much like having and audio earpiece even though we got a guided tour from a former inmate. All too rehearsed and no real genuine discourse from guide. No opportunity to amble and explore at leisure and guide's obvious avarice for a substantial tip a bit demeaning to the Great One who had actually really changed things utterly for a while. Mandela would turn in his grave I suspect with how he is now being exploited here as a mere of interest commodity with no depth to the experience save for a wonderful African elderly women's group who were on a day out and who sang, chanted and danced for all of the boat trip to the island).

Mandatory visit for all visitors to Capetown. The trip to Robben Island offers a great view of the Capetown skyline. The tour conducted by a former political prisoner and allows the visitor to better appreciate the continuing conflict of South African society. One gains a deeper appreciation of the Nelsons Mandelas gift of forgiveness . A truly moving experience.

Step back in time whilst visiting Cape Town. Visiting Robben Island is a humbling experience and well worth giving up your morning or afternoon to make the visit. The attraction is well established and easy to find at the V&A waterfront. Boat ride took about 20-25 minutes to cross and when you arrive everyone boards buses which take different routes around the island to split the crowd up. Our guide was extremely knowledgable and was able to relate a piece of the islands history back to any of the audiences home country...even Wales.

Truly amazing. It was a very touching tour, and it was good to know how Nelson Mandela and other prisoners lived their lives on the island.
The tour guide was the last prisoner to leave, I was amazed that he did the tour.
It's a must, so don't miss it

Interested . Tooked very long time. You was only allowed too walk around by your self in they end. They ship is full of people, try to take a seat on over deck. It can be windy. When you arrives you get too jump into a bus... tight and hard too take pictures.

A MUST FOR ALL SOUTH AFRICANS. Awesome total experience.Professional and very informative.Great photo opportunities with awesome new angles of Table Mountain.Most memorable and touching was the injustice in menu`s served to the different races in confinement.Eye opener for our group.

Must visit for the history lesson. We booked the tour online beforehand, so there is no hassle. We went straight to the ferry pier at our scheduled time. Only complaint is the direction to car parking. As overseas visitor, there is no enough information online to suggest to visitors where to park. Boat ride takes 45 minutes. Depends on weather, the ride can be rough. The tour lasts around 4 hours. I highly recommend a visit to learn about forgiveness and reconciliation.

Sobering. Yes, worth the time to understand more about South Africa's Apartheid past and the character of Mandela and others who suffered their with him. History is not always pleasant, but it is poignant and should not be missed.

Interesting. this is a must for firsttime Capetown visitors. Prebuy tickets on the web or at the Robben Island Museum in the Waterfront. the tour took about 4 hours in alles (boattrip about an hour an a half roundtrip). On the Island the visit is diveded into 2 parts. A guided bustrip around the island and a prisonvisitd guided by an ex-prisoner.
Important site of modern political history. Visiting the actual spot of the major part of Mandela's imprisonment gives a hard reality to facts in a guidebook.

Worth the Wait and the Cost. Book way in advance and be prepared for a long queue but I promise it is worth it (unless you are heartless and racist and uninterested in the history of SA). You travel in groups from your boat and are met by a guide. Ours had been incarcerated there himself and his story and experiences had most of us in tears. We sat in his cell and we heard his personal story of violence, torture, fear, struggle and release. Most of the moving round the island is in a bus but it still requires a great deal of walking. VERY memorable experience!

A must see. It is humbling to see this place with such a dark history. The most memorable part of the experience is having a former inmate as a guide and he recalls his story. I was last in Cape Town when Robben Island housed political prisoners so the trip was all the more poignant.Don't miss this experience if you are in Cape Town.

Words can not describe this place. You have to take a ferry over from V&A. It takes about 45 minutes to get there. Once there, you feel like you are walking on holy ground. The tour is run by former inmates. you hear the brutual truth of what they experienced. My heart was breaking hearing the stories but also pleased to see that they had overcome. The stories are powerful. You get to see Mandela's cell which was very tiny. If you get to Cape Town, you have to go to Robben Island.

Interesting trip, but could be improved. I really enjoyed the trip to robben island but it felt very rushed. We arrived and got straight on a bus to tour around the island. You are then dropped at the max security unit and have a talk from a former prisoner. There's not much time left after that to walk around and look at the prison. Would recommend booking in advance and going as early as possible to ensure you have as much time there as possible. It's a great trip so I still would recommend it.

A Humbling Experience. It starts with a queue to board the boat that takes you to this island visible from the mainland,,,i have been here on two separate occasions and in each i learnt something new and felt different emotions...the boat ride takes about half an hour to 40 minutes depending on the weather....met by bus and driven to the prison for your tour...what is incredibly emotive about the place is its silence.....former prisoners are your guides so their perspective is hugely personal...I found them charming but matter of fact and devoid of any anger......walking along the corridor to Mandela's cell was a sobering experience....it is so small....simple , but so very small....a wonderful and hugely humbling experience....please take the time to visit.

A must do. previous reviews cover the experience in great detail so there is little point in repeating , we visited on 10th May 2016 arriving at the dock 15mins before departure as specified on the ticket. We waited as a tour group was fast tracked ahead of us only for the guy in charge of loading to announce that everyone should have been there 30 mins before departure and the boat was full. As a large number of people started to express their displeasure he quickly added that another boat was on its way. Either a weird power trip or his attempt at humour I am not sure which. Tour was great and imformative after this strange start.

Really wanted to see.... As South African's you must go to Robin Island and this is what we did, the history is very interesting but what is shocking is that it is a "bus tour" on the island you cant get off and see anything until the last stop when you see Nelson Mandela's prison cell but what is also disappointing are the facilities available.... toilets could do with a good clean and the shop to buy a cold drink or coffee could really do with an upgrade, it is a pity when the world's tourists just want to go to Robin Island... it could be so much more.

Bussiness outing. The place us not interresting like I taught it would be. The only attraction is Mandelas cell. But other ppl crowd so around and cant stand in line so I missed the cell. The island us dry and looks deserted. Little to non is done to the plants everything is dying. No thanks never again r me. A nasty experiance.

Important part of local history. This is a well run tour that takes about four hours. The opputunity to interact with former prisoners made it all the more interesting. A must visit site for anyone who is interested in South African history.

Bucket list tick. Have always wanted to go and so glad I did. Smooth ride to the island and informative bus guide. The island itself has changed little and glad it hasn't, you really get to see how things were. Highlight was an ex political prisoner talk about his experience and of course seeing Nelson's cell. Go and see history.

Don't leave Cape Town Without a Visit to Robben Island!. This is a must do while you are in Cape Town. All tours are given by former political prisoners. Our guide knew Nelson Mandela, gave a wonderful talk about apartheid and what it was like to be a prisoner on Robben Island. You are given a walking tour, as well as a bus tour of the island. It's a short ferry ride from the waterfront, but reservations well in advance are necessary.

Not to Be Missed. You cant go to Cape Town and not visit Robben's Island. Being toured the facility by a former prisoner is profound. Between the Apartheid Museum and this facility you will have a much deeper understanding of some of the history of this country

Robben Island gives you insight into the history of South Africa. I was on a volunteer trip in Cape Town and had the opportunity to visit Robben Island during one of my off days. While I had a busy schedule I made it a point to fit the time to go to Robben Island. I am so glad that I did. It is somewhat of a commitment if you are pressed for time. Depending on the ferry ride, the tour itself can be as short as 3.5 hours. The tour comprises of three parts. The first part is a tour bus around the island. The tour guide is very informative and gives you an explanation behind the history of the island. I particularly like informative tours and my gold standard is the architectural tour in Chicago. I found this very comparable. The second part of the tour is in the political prison itself. You are paired with a former inmate and you have a chance to see what life was like for these political prisoners. The final part of the tour is to look around Cell Block A where you read the intimate stories of some of the inmates. All in all, I highly recommend making the time to visit this former penal colony. The history and its significance can't be captured in this review, but I guarantee once you visit you'll be happy that you did.

Do not miss out on this - buy your ticket in advance. So much worth a visit. The sailing trip there is amazing and takes 40-45 min. - you have a stunning view of cape own center, table mountain, signal hills and lions head. When you arrive you will be guided to the buses, that will take you on a 45 min trip around the islands. In the bus a local guide will tell you the history of the islands - brilliant and very knowledgeable guide. After the bus tour you will be taken to the highest secured part of the prison, which is the place where the political prisoners were placed (including Mandela). The guides here are former prisoners. We had Vusumsi Mcongo, who was a brilliant guide - tear-pressuring stories he was telling of his life in the prison.Book your ticket in advance, since it is sold out very quickly.

Powerful . Robben Island isn't just about Mandela. There's a long and sad history of slaves, lepers, and criminal and political prisoners (as well as military) . It's likely larger than you'd expect (12km circumference) and you'll be taken around in a bus with a guide who explains all about the buildings, history, etc. Powerful stuff - and that's before you're shown around building interiors by a former prisoner. It's all a bit disorganized and low-tech, but totally worth a visit. You shouldn't visit Cape Town without going to Robben Island for context.

Enriching Visit. Because of its association with the Great Statesman Nelson Mandela, the island is a must-do place in S Africa. Prior booking of ticket is highly recommended though in the winter months, if lucky, one might be able to get tickets on the spot. Try to take the first ferry there so that the rest of the day can be used for other activities. Upon arrival on the island, one is taken on a bus tour of the island. This is where & when the historical landmarks are pointed out.More interesting and enlightening is the prison cell tour. Former prisoners played guide and it was history come to life as the narration was a personal one. Here, one would also learn of the discrimination in the treatment of the prisoners based on the colours of their skin...somewhat an extension of what one learned from the Apartheid Museum in Johannesburg.

Dreary day, dreary place. We took the tour boat to Robben Island with some friends. Upon arriving, we were jammed into a bus for a 45 min driving tour of the island and then "released" for a 45 min walking tour with a docent, who we think had once been a prisoner. He was very passionate, but difficult for us to understand in the echoing rooms with his booming voice. All that said, it pointed out what a supreme struggle it was to live under Apartheid if one wasn't "european."

Not quite what I expected, but still a must do. I'm not sure what I thought the visit to Robben Island would be like, but I still felt a little disappointed at the end of ours. It is a lot of effort to get there and I felt the tour was very short. Once you arrive by boat (can be rocky... on our visit, the way back was WAY worse) you will be split into groups and find a bus that will take you around the island for about an hour. They will show you some notable things, including, the quarry where Nelson Mandela and others were sentenced to hard labor. After that, you are taken by an ex - prisoner (which I did actually think was cool) around the cells, and then you will walk through Mandela's cell. I think it's a Cape Town must do, but I think I wanted more history behind it.

Mandela's Prison. The trip to Robben Island was a must on my too do list for my trip to South Africa. The trip begins with a boat ride over to the island. beware there is a huge difference in the boats. The first one I took was very nice and provided a smooth ride over. The one I took back was a nightmare and I started to feel sick to my stomach. I could just look at some of the other passengers faces and see they felt the same way. Luckily I had my motion pills with me so I made it back without throwing up. After getting off the boat you walk and board a bus where the tour guide gives a brief history of the island. Then an ex political prisoner takes you on the tour. It was a long tour almost four hours for me but just being able to see where Mandela was imprisoned for all those years and hear the first hand experiences from our guide made it so worth it. I would definitely recommend making time in your itinerary to do the tour.

Interesting morning. This trip gives an insight into the lives of the people held there. Pre booking is reccommended, we visited in the winter months but there was still 3 boats full of visitors. You have a 40 minute bus ride with commentry before going inside the prison. A good morning out.

Worth a visit. Learning about Robben Island at school and actually being there are two completely different experiences. The tour is so well organised from nice well maintained boats to the whole tour experience.Listening to stories of a prisoner from first hand was really amazing and it has an amazing impact on a person to realise what the freedom fighters had to go through for us to experience the freedom we have today.Definitely worth the visit and it is a pretty little island

History. It starts off with a very nice boat trip. The guides were excellent though the program is rigid and does not allow you anytime to wonder off independently. But it is obviously a must-do when in Cape Town.

Good if you like history. The 11km ferry trip to the island is nice, the visit to the jail cells is interesting. This is where Nelson Mandela and many other political prisoners were held. The scenery is average, the service was below standard when we went.

A moving experience. We felt we should go see Robben Island because of Nelson Mandela. What we got was so very much more, it is a place not to be missed. What makes it so moving is that the guides are former political prisoners from the Island. So not only do you get to see it, which is interesting, but the personal experiences that the guide shares are incredibly moving. The way the men communicated, organized, kept each other going, is a story all should hear! Don't miss it!!!

Much better if the crowds were smaller. I wish I could give this 5 stars and I still recommend this tour. But one of the downsides was the large group you have to be with. It was unfortunate that we had a large group of teenagers with us who were laughing and singing songs as we approached the island. This took away from the experience trying to absorb the surrounding and a little bit of the atmosphere. The bus tour had a superb guide, but the bus was very full and hard to see outside if you don't have a window seat. The visit was a bit rushed and could have had a bigger impact otherwise. The boat ride to and from the Island could be very nice if you are lucky enough to share it with more mature visitors.

SottoK. This island prison could be so much more interesting. The tour appears to be still politically influenced. The ex political prisoner who took us through was interesting enough but it would have been a better experience if he talked about general prison life rather than himself. I felt that a great opportunity to explain the harm of apartheid was lost

Life changing experience. I took my son on a half day tour of Robben Island when he was 11 years old. I truly think the experience had an impact on his life. We visited Nelson Mandela's actual cell. Our tour guide was a former prisoner who had been imprisoned at age 15 because he wanted an education. He walked with a limp from the torture he had endured. I will never forget the things he said, or his dignity and strength. It was a powerful experience. I wish everyone could experience this tour, especially teens and pre-teens. Tour was actually in October 2006.

Superb Place. Very interesting area, especially if you want to know abt Nelson Mandela. Our tour guide was an old prisoner, so it made it very interesting, as we could hear his personal relations to the experience.

Must go for tourists to learn more. Robben island is a great place to go for tourists as its located in a tourist destination (V&A). You can get to walk around the wharf before or after Robben Island. Robben island itself is very educational and teaches you about the history of South Africa and the prisoners who were there during the apartheid. An ex-political prisoner will personally guide you through which makes it very authentic. The boat ride is quite long at 30 mins but you will also learn stories of who managed to escape and who didnt during the tour. On a good day, the boat ride lends you a beautiful view of the table mountain. So I will highly recommend this.

Educational but Kind of Boring. It was interesting to see and hear the stories of everything on the island but after three hours it gets pretty long. Maybe it was because I went on such a hot day but just be prepared to be there for a long time.

A must for anyone interested in the history of S. Africa. Robben Island was a highlight of our tour - it brings the history of apartheid alive. There we 'met' Mandela through the memories of our guide, a former prisoner.
Memorable & Moving. So pleased that we visited Robben Island. It was a great history lesson & opened our eyes to the challenging history that SA has faced. Parts were very moving

Very interesting side trip from Cape Town. Go down to the Waterfront, take a quick (30 minutes) boat ride out to an impressive attraction. Whole trip is about a half day. Actually seeing the cell puts it into perspective. Incredibly small and cramped. Having an old prisoner guide us through was a neat touch, even though he seemed a bit reticent about talking about his experiences. Overall a must see if you are in Cape Town

TRIP DOWN MEMORY LANE. Having lived on Robben Island in the early 50's it was a very special experience to return there some 55 years later. The staff, both on the boat and on the island, were very friendly and informative. The whole experience was sad but very interesting
AMAZING. This is a unique opportunity to visit the island that was home to Nelson Mandela. The tour is given by an ex prisoner and is very moving.

An important part of South Africa's history. I've been to Robben Island three times and am always humbled by the story. It's well worth a visit. I do find it has been a bit sanitised and feels a bit like a boarding school rather than the dreadful prison it once was. But you still get the feeling of what it must have been like and the story telling is really good.

Preserving the lessons learnt from history . We've made many grave mistakes as a human race. And this place is just one of those that bears witness to not only such crimes and cruelty but also hope, love, justice and light.The entire trip was well planned and well guided. It ended with a tour by an ex inmate who also shared first hand experience of his time there. Very emotional. Must visit.

Nelson Mandela fan. I have always admired the man for what he suffered for his country so therefor Robin Island was top of my must list to visit and it didn't disappoint. So touching and sad,at the same time so very interesting Again it was a humbling experience.

A must visit to fully understand the birth of democracy in South Africa.. An important part of South Africa's march to democracy. Former "political prisoners" incarcerated by the Apartheid Government lead tours of the prison and recount the struggle black South Africans undertook to achieve social justice. You can see Mandela's cell. Most of all you get a sense for the great lengths the Apartheid Government went to in order to silence the advocates of equality and justice.

rich in history. it was a lifetime experience to see and be inside the prison where our greatest leader of all times Nelson Mandela spend time in prison for 27 years. This is a real holiday destination

A must see!. The whole trip was great. The boat over was a bit cramped with not many seats, but the one on the way back had great seating.The tour around the prison was very good and our guide, an ex-prisoner, was very informative.There is a lot more to Robben Island than just the prison. It is really interesting and has a lot of history. After the prison, you are brought around the island by bus. Our guide, Thabo, was full of information and good fun. Highly recommended.
Decent Place to visit. Its a decent place to visit. Those having interest in Historical Monuments would love to visit this place. The experience of Ferry is very good.

The best are the views from the boat in the way to the island and also from Robben Island.. The best are the views from the boat in the way to the island and also from Robben Island.You need to book at least two days in advance befor there are only 3 trips every days with a limit of visitors so it gets a Little bit crowded.Views of Cape Town and Table Mounten from there are a must.The visit to the prison is just OK. The former prisoners talk much more about their own personal experiences rather than the general history of this place.Bus is not punctual. We stayed 55 minutes waiting the bus to the tour on the island after visiting the prison.It is a very interesting visit eventhough it is sad as all those kind of places are. Of course it's a must in Cape Town.

A Great History Lesson. It is a great lesson on how human sprit can transcend the most adverse condition . The small cells, the inhuman conditions under which the prisoners lived are all on display. We had an amazing guide (an ex prisoner) who described the ordeal that they had to endure. To think that Madiba was able to rise above the cruelty of his jailers and forgive them is almost unimaginable.The boat ride to the island is nice if the weather is good. One tip: get to the dock early as there is a long line.

Informative and Enlightening. An organised tour of an important insight in the life journey of hope and dreams. A well represented bus tour seeing sights and buildings on Robben Island, as well as island wildlife and magnificent sea views. The jail cells of important political prisoners, information about their stories all delivered by a past political prisoner. A visit is Important to have further insight to a part of South African history.

Humbling experience. This trip was a must for our trip to South Africa. We learned a lot, and found the experience very humbling. The guide was an ex political prisoner and he spoke very well and was very informative (without being bitter) It was fascinating to see, with our own eyes, the conditions and the struggles the prisoners at Robben Island endured. A truly humbling visit and I will never forget it. The boat trip to and from the Island was a nice bonus, but the real attraction was the prison itself. Thank you for teaching us.

Interesting . This was an interesting informative experience BUT the boat trip out there was awful - very old boat on really rough seas the day we went out and a lot of people were seasick. Also it is very cold and windy on both the boat and island so you need warm clothes -we were in shorts and short-sleeved tops do were really cold

History lesson. A real eye opener for this Brit with regards to the conditions here. Learnt a fair bit but also felt rushed on the prison tour and FAR too many people in one group. Felt a bit like a group of lemmings following the leader ...Mixed feelings about this place. However, the songs that my SA husband plays by Johnny Clegg now make A LOT of sense to me.

A humbling experience. One has to set foot on Robben Island to really understand the struggles that these great man had to go through to eliminate discrimination. Coming from a multi ethnic city like Singapore, it was hard for us to really comprehend what apartheid was all about until we came to Robben Island. We were given new insights and newfound respect to all these great heroes. The only flip side, our journey back was on choppy water, and it took us almost an "eternity" to reach shore. Resulting in us missing our preplanned itinerary on that day. Otherwise, a must-do experience for all travellers to CPT

Hauntingly interesting. This attraction obviously has some very sad tones to it, but I feel that it's important to realise humanity's history to better ourselves. First off, book WELL IN ADVANCE, the queue for buy tickets on site for the day is long, often with limited tickets available and you'll probably never get them. When you get on the boat to the island, note that it's a 50minute ride to the island, if you get sea-sick, bring medication as the sea can be rather choppy. There are no bathrooms, food or drinks onboard. When you get to the Island, it's a guided tour first on a bus with a ride around the island and then to the prison with a guide who is a former inmate of the prison. Our guide was incarcerated for political reasons during the apartheid uprising.The tours are about an hour each with a stop on the bus part at a cafe for refreshments, food and drink available as well as a bathroom stop. The only problem we encountered on our trip was that some people didn't seem to care if their children shouted and screamed over the guide. I found this rude and inconsiderate. I struggled to hear the guide telling us the history of this landmark while parents let their children scream at the top of their voices. This isn't the staff's fault hence not penalising on trip Advisor points, it's a great attraction and I really recommend it to anyone.

Great lesson learned . With a 30 min boat ride from Cape Town...it's one attraction you can't slip by...Great tours around the island.... I myself as a local felt the tour was a bit to rushed.We also saw dolphins swimming along our yacht....Bedankt sure time book early morning trips as once the wind starts the tours shut down to rough seas.. thus timing is crucial...

Enjoyed the boat trip. Dont ask questions of the guide.. The boat trip was excellent. Great views of Cape Town.Saw a whale.The tour is unnecessarily long and the guide repeated the same information over and over (and over) again. It was as if he had been told the exact words to say.He dismissed a number of perfectly valid polite questions from other people on our tour so we felt we could not ask questions.We were left abandoned on a bus at the end of the prison tour as the driver had gone for lunch. This was ok as it was not too hot but I hope they do not treat guests like this in summer.
Sad but True. It was amazing to see how human nature prevailed in such appalling conditions given that these were purely political prisoners.

Very interesting. Was here also 7 years ago still have a great memory of this place. Been taking around from a former inmate who was there, to hear some incredible stories. Seeing where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned, where he had his exercise and working at the lime pit. Also seeing the church, hospital and small village on the island was great. The journey to the island was ok.

Enjoyed this outing. This will take up a good chunk of your day.The boat across is large and very fast but still takes a half an hour.We had a fabulous tour person who was our guide for the tour of the island on the bus. He was passionate, interesting and funny. Then you are taken to the museum and a former inmate takes you on your tour. We had a guy who no one could understand. He was full of himself and really boring. This was unfortunate, but it was still worth going to Robben Island.

dissapointing visit. We were so looking forward to this visit to Robben Island and to explore the history of this island, we were taken around very quickly and were not allowed to explore on our own. Hardly any mention of the Great Mr Mandela as the guide was talking about his time spent there and the other thing that we were looking forward to was to visit the cave where the prisoners broke limestone but we had to view it from the bus with no comentary from the driver so didnt really know anything of what went on there so we brought a book. Very upset with this trip. Tip book in advance you cannot go on same day.

So worth every second of trip! . From the quick ferry trip return to Cape Town, every second of the trip and lesson to Robben Island is worth it. Your guide will be a former political prisoner, he was an innocent student and now a resident of the island along with a very happy, healthy community of former ill faithed guests and their families. Truely an amazing place in every way!!!
Interesting tour of prison. Surprisingly little information about Nelson Mandela - more about the history of the island and prison. The staff were unhelpful, which is most unusual in Cape Town.

A visit that hits your heart and makes you revisit history. Visiting this island leaves nobody indifferent. Ther island is beautiful and the views towards Cape Town stunning; views which must have been aching and maybe also consoling to the interns who once spent their years here. The final part of the tour - a visit to the high security prison which always is led by one former inmate telling his personal story is compelling and leaves no way out but to understand what this really was about. You do not leave amidst laughter - but humbled and impressed.

An interesting day out.. It was the guides that made this trip interesting. The two guides that showed us around were very knowledgable and sometimes very amusing as well. With their description you could imagine what life was like a political prisoner on this island.Of course you always have the great man, President Mandela in the back of your mind as well.The island is a 40 minute boat ride and needs to be booked well in advance.It's a bleak environment so take water and sun block or something warm in the winter.

A walk back in history . One can take a yatch from V&A waterfront to Robben Island. Prior booking is advisable. The name is derived from Dutch for seal island. This was the place where prisoners were kept during the apartheid movement. A guided bus tour of the island is provided. They take you through the history of the movement and the struggles of the prisoner. The highlight of the tour is that an ex prisoner takes you through the prison and share anecdotes of the tough time spent there. We also got to see the cell where Nelson Mandela spent 18 years of his life. The island also offers a view of the table mountain.

Disappointed big time!. We were so looking forward to our visit to Robben eiland, but in the end the boattrip to the Island was the best part of it. Groups are to big and our guide wasn't realy very informative. We didn't experience the prison and history the way we expected. We were rushed to finished and our guide spend to much time talkingabout himself.

harrowing but a must see. It was interesting to learn that Robben (Afrikans word for Seals) Island has been a Prison for centuries. But the impact of the surviving political prisoners when released was such that they pressured the govt to make it a Museum. As the world came to admire Nelson Mandella it was appropriately named after him.Mans inhumanity is vividly demonstrated by the talk of the guide

Thought provoking. Not to be missed. Boat from V & A Waterfront and ex-prisoners on hand to give tour and information. An eye-opener to how badly men can treat other men who don't share their views! Bit crowded on bus round island but nothing like the prisoners had to endure! Small shop for refreshments so best to take your own.

Moving!. This was such an organised trip! A great boat trip where we saw seals, whale and dolphin. As we arrived at the port of Robben Island I really was thinking this whole trip would just be about the prison. How wrong I was! We had a tour of the prison which was informative and very moving followed by a guided tour of the island where the history was explained. A fantastic trip and we were so glad to have had the opportunity.

An example of how mass tourism can ruin history. Hugely overpriced in comparison to other attractions, we were not initially perturbed given the significance of the journey to Robben Island. However on arrival you are herded on coaches, given a short tour of an initial part of the prison and then seated in a room with someone who experienced life as a prisoner. Sadly the dialogue felt scripted. For someone who was imprisoned for what they believed in, it felt unjust that he didn't wish to or wasn't able to speak his mind.Many of the others on our tour were only interested in Nelson Mandela. It was embarrassing to listen to others ignoring this gentleman's individual experiences to ask if he knew Mandela personally. We were taken to Mandela's cell, the only one with furniture in. Be prepared for a struggle as people stand there taking endless photos without letting others see in. Hang back wherever possible. In fact why not look into the other cells and give consideration to all of the other people held on that island for standing up for what they believe in.

See Mandela's cell!. The trip to Robben Island should only be done on a day that the sea is calm. Its quite a nice experience going across to the Island but NOT if the sea is rough. The Island is very sparse and the tour is interesting ONLY if your guide is good. Unfortunately one has no choice of a guide so its just the luck of the drawer. Nothing much to see in MR. Mandela's cell except a VERY SMALL cell. Gosh to spend 25 years there its amazing that he came out sane.

Robbin island. Pre book your trip, as these get fully booked rather quickly. Should you embark on the "prisoner" boat suggest you go below deck.. Will save you from choppy waters and getting wet. At the island, it is what you make of it and how you engage with your guide. You need to embrace the challenge of Mandela and try and visualize the struggle.. Then only can you understand 1% of what they went through. The bus ride on the island is a good way to get a full view of the island.

Full of promise...but so disappointing! The Island has much, much more to offer.. Robben Island is of course a must-see in Cape Town, approached with much anticipation. Sadly, the reality is so different. The highlights:  - the 60 or 30 minute boat ride (depends on the boat) to the island has great views back to Cape Town. - the tour of the prison, including a (10 second) viewing of Mandela's cell, with a former inmate telling his personal story. - that's it!The lowlights: - the prison tour was too crowded and rushed, with the guide's commentary continuing with his group still racing to catch up. Poor photo opportunities because of the speed of the tour. No time for reflection in a space that really warrants it.  - the bus tour was a waste! We waited in the bus for about 20 minutes for our guide to arrive, time clearly to be made up during the trip. A bored, disinterested, scarcely audible guide reciting snippets of information. 15 second stops at key spots e.g. the lime quarry, but not allowed to alight for photos or proper viewing, being curtly instructed to take our photos through the (grimy) windows. But we were allowed a coffee stop! - no time at the harbour to read the many interesting information boards on the history as an apartheid era prison.Of course Robben Island's role as Mr Mandela's prison of 18 years is of National importance, and we visitors are touched by this piece of history. However I do wonder without the Mandela involvement would there be these tours to the Island today? There certainly should be.Why? Because the Island is so much more, and thus has so much more to offer visitors. For example it's periods as a 17th century prison, a whaling station, a leper colony, a naval base, a sacred Muslim site; it's marine and bird life, the village, the lighthouse etc, etc.And no mention of it being a Unesco World Heritage Site!?While extremely disappointed with my tour, I'm not sorry to have visited having since dug a little deeper into the broader story of Robben Island and now believing the Cape has a largely unexploited tourist jewel on it's doorstep. One day I hope I can return and enjoy it more fully.

Visit Now. This was a moving experience. Currently tours of the prison are given by former inmates who live on the island. As time passes, this will not continue to be an option. I still have chills when I think of the experience. It is an amazing lesson in human nature and the ability to forgive. Worth every single dollar spent to attend.

Undervalued. Enjoyed the boat ride over on smooth seas under a sunny sky. Saw whales which was a bonus. Took the bus tour and although the lady guide was warm and welcoming her accent was so strong that even as a native English speaker it was almost impossible to understand. The island is clean and tidy but I feel so much more could be done to present this significant historical landmark to the public. Ensure you do your research beforehand as sites and buildings are pointed out you will have a better idea than us what their significance was

Very powerful experience!. My husband, my daughter and I visit this place, we never imagined this was going to be so powerful...it shocked us, how can a man live for so many years in a space so little, and not to give up in his believes! on the contrary to teach to all of us with his life. Thats why Nelson Mandela won the Nobel peace prize. Our guide was an ex-prisoner who lived with Mandela, he talked to us about the life in the prison those days. We recommend this visit very much.

Powerful message. You will all know the history of Robben Island if you are thinking of going there. I will say that I found it an extraordinary experience to visit it for myself. It made me ashamed to be human being who was alive during apartheid. The message of reconciliation and rising above, is inspiring. The tour from one of the inmates was the highlight. Lots of lessons here for the current world leaders. About the particulars. The busses have very little leg room, but you are not on them for very long, and its the only way to accommodate all the visitors. There are two ferries going to the island...try to get on the newer/faster one. It literally takes half the time. There was a large chop on the day that we visited, and the slow boat, with all the pitching around made for a lot of vomiting customers (they have barf bags). If you get sea sick...for heavens sake take something! You will enjoy your day so much more. We booked online, it was simple and painless. Be aware that the weather in cape town is very fickle, you may have to re-schedule.

Unmissable. One of the real highlights of my time in Cape Town was my trip to Robben Island. For just R300, the boat trip in itself was worth it to see the breathtaking city from the sea. On the island we were taken on a bus tour - stumbling across springboks grazing and penguins on the shore - before having a guided tour of the infamous prison by an ex-political prisoner. It added so much depth to my understanding of the apartheid era. Please support this remarkable attraction.
Very interesting. This was a wonderful trip. It was very interesting and informative having an ex prisoner for a guide. It is a must visit for anybody going to Cape Town

Give it is skip if you want to see more of Cape Town. If you want to visit Robben Island to tick the box or for the emotional experience, by all means make the effort to take the trip to the Island. Opinions about a visit to this World Heritage site vary greatly and there are people who either love it or hate it. If you have other attractions that you wish to still wish to visit in Cape Town, especially if you have limited time, I would rather attend to those and spend quality time on the many other attractions that the beautiful Cape has to offer. The whole experience takes a good part of 60% of a day which in effect takes away a big chunk of a day’s sightseeing, for the sake of seeing a jail cell. Scenery and view of Cape Town whilst on the ferry cannot be beaten (if the weather is good) and it could be a spiritual experience walking in the steps of history.However, the ferry service is extremely unreliable and often break down even while at the island. Sometimes are replacement ferry needs to be sent to collect passengers, causing further delays. Personal experience as a tourist guide was that the stories which were told by the local site guides were not completely objective. Visitors were also not always treated in a respectful and professional manner.

A must !!. We set off at 9am. The sea was pretty rough, but I'd taken my sea sickness tablets (thank goodness)All the guides were knowledgeable and friendly - one on the boat, one on the bus & an ex-inmate.It was a fascinating excursion - a most for all who visit Cape Town.

Great Information. Well, obviously this is a must see attraction if one is the least bit interested in the dark history of South Africa. The tours focus on the political prisoners who were kept at the island...most importantly, Nelson Mandela. The tour leaders are former prisoners. However, there is a lot of 'padding' to make visitors feel they have gotten their money's worth. Truthfully, there is not much to see. The tour guide tells personal stories and, although I value his struggle, he spoke a lot...really a lot!!!! Be forewarned that if one has any mobility issues think twice about taking this tour. There is a lot of walking to see the same gray walls over and over. They say the last walk from the prison to the boat is supposed to signify the 'Walk to Freedom', if you are not a walker, it is just really long. We were there when it was quite warm, too, so standing and listening for almost an hour BEFORE the walk to the ferry almost did me in.

Sardine packed boat and bus! What a way to waste a day!. I love history and in particular modern history. I have done museums such as Check point Charley in Berlin, Aparvati ghats in Mauritius and Flanders Fields Museum in Ieper, Belgium. I had such expectations of this tour and this was for me the reason to come to Cape Town. When I travel in South Africa I find that many things are well organised and compared to other countries in the world, you find world standards. For example the Two Oceans Aquarium is world class. Therefore, I expected that Robben Island would be of the same level as it is also an expensive attraction.This is my two cents worth.-It is very popular and online tickets are often sold out and today was in the off season!-They tell you to arrive at 12:30 for 1 pm ride. But you have to wait till about 1.15pm in a very crowded setting where you cannot even find the space to look at the posters on the wall describing the history.-You are marched into a boat and in our case 'Sea princess' which is already full upstairs. You have to sit in a dark indoor area. The life jackets for the children are dirty. And windows are very dirty and have not been cleaned at least in one year. When you try to come out to the back deck, an aggressive man called John stops you and say it is not allowed. When you ask why he says 'its dangerous.' Some other people manage to sit on the back deck and then you try to go and sit. He allows you to stay after you have a big fight. The voyage is about 30 minutes and every one inside the boat are feeling stuffy, hot and cannot see any thing. Each time you want to take a picture, they treat you like a criminal and there is absolutely no customer service. This is a private company and not former prisoners. -You arrive at the Robben Island and you have to find your way to a bus. The buses are stuffy, again dirty windows and you barely can sit in a group with your family. We sat on the right hand side. The tour starts with a lady guide who introduced herself. She is actually like a tape recorder and some times she forgets what she told and repeats the same sentence. After a few minutes we realise that half of the tour is going to be in this crampy bus. And most important buildings are on the right hand side. So if you are sit on the left hand side, you cannot take pictures. They don't stop for you to get out. The stop is about 15 seconds if you are lucky and she barely explains. For the mosque in the island she said that was for some Muslim who was buried there. Later we find out that it was for an Indonesian Prince who had been a prisoner of the Dutch. What a lack of interest in history from the Guide.-When we drove past the living quarters of the staff, which is the warden's quarters, no explanation was given. Normally if you want to explain a system of oppression you must also explain how the oppressor lived as it is one of the most important part of the museum.-The bus tour stops at a snack place and you can go to the toilets. Make sure you do, as the Prison area have no public toilets. Especially if you have children. -Here you can take a picture of the table mountain or selfies on a wooden frame.- Then the bus drives through the rest of the island without much explanation and you are dropped off at the second part.-An ex prisoner comes now and takes you around. The whole thing is rushed. You get to see the Mandela cell. And in the next part where there are many cells with stories of each political prisoner, you get less than ten minutes. And you are pushed off as another group of tourists are coming.-There is not time to observe, to read, to reflect nor even to take pictures. -At the end you have to walk to the boat and you have not even time to read the big sign boats. We left at 1315 and the boats were already waiting at 1600.It all feels like a tourist trap to make money and organised without interest in history and it is such an insult to the historical significance of the place. It could have been an educational and fascinating tour if done in an interesting way with time and space for reflection.For us, it felt like a sardine packed boat, sardine packed bus and the tour with the ex prisoner was the best part out of the experience.I have pain in my heart when I think about this experience because it killed every thing I wanted to feel during that experience.

Wonderful day. This 3.5 hour trip was well worth it. To see the conditions and here about the torture was very mind blowing. You are taken round by an ex prisoner and the one we had was excellent. How he keeps so passionate about the experience all the time is amazing as he must do the tour a number of times each day. The short ferry crossing is also a nice experience. Remember to book in advance as it is often booked up many days ahead

A very long tour, yet so very rushed. As this was the last morning of my trip to South Africa, I was hoping for a great ending to a great trip. It was, however, quite disappointing. The boat ride was terribly wobbly, and if you didn't get sick from the waves, you would from the unbearable petrol fumes. I was not expecting a complete busride on the island, and it was really not something for me. The guide was very good, and his story was impressive. But still you have the feeling of being rushed through the island, stopping at the strategic locations so everyone can make the exact same picture. If you are unlucky, you have a seat in the bus from which you cannot see any of these sights. After this tour comes a second, given by a former prisoner of the island. It is impressive to hear his story, and a great way to see the prison. Yet he was performing a monologue for about an hour, while the whole group sat and listened with just three actual sights on the route. Again we were rushed past everything, although the tours in total took us 2,5 hours. So in retrospect I should have just gone to the beach.
Improvements needed. Very interesting to see around the island but the explanations given by ex-residents of the prison were not clear or loud enough to understand...... great shame!
Mandela remembered. Robben Island is where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for 27 years. A must see on any visit to Capetown. A twenty minute boat ride and then a bus tour of the island.

Holiday . We had taken some friends to Robben island because we had been previously quite a few years back and found it inspiring then. This time we had a tour guide called Tom Moses who took our tour he spoke with so much passion and determination, because he had experienced what had happened in Robben island and could explain first hand because it happened to him. Everyone listened so intently even our our seven and nine year olds. We then went on a 45 min bus journey where the guide explained to us about the history of Robben island this was very informative and eye opening, this was an excellent tour and we were then dropped back to the quay side to catch the ferry back. I would recommend this to anyone to do.
Average. The experience overall was good and I am glad I made the trip.My complaints are similar to other reviewers; the guide was difficult to understand and we spent a lot of time on the bus.

Long Live Mandela. Probably the most important attraction in Cape Town (maybe in South Africa). It is essential to understand the cruelty of the apartheid and to honor a great leader such as Nelson Mandela. The tour is presented by an ex-prisioner and this is a great opportunity to face how were those days. The imprisonment of Mandela is a shame of our society and this attraction help us to understand and to face how cruel humanity can be.

Very good. Took my teenage daughter there for her 13th birthday. Best birthday present ever. Really informative. The guide's are really good and go about their day with passion. Well worth a visit and will definitely return.

Nice walk down memory lane.... This was a very interesting visit to the very famous Robben Island. A very funny yet interesting tour guide combined with the stories from an former fighter against the apartheid.

Interesting . It was an interesting visit, but fairly chaotic on the ferry. The first guide was easy to understand, but the second one's accent was more difficult for me. It was definitely very powerful to be where Mandela was held. And the roaming penguins were a treat.

Not a great experience. I'll just say first of all that it's mind blowing that this was ever a thing, and the awareness we now have is thanks to tours like this.Crammed into tiny hot buses, with tiny seats and fat tourists does not make for the best learning experience! Our tour guide was late and so we sat in the car park for an extra 20 minutes. And here's some penguins. The tour by the ex prisoner was interesting, but didn't really tell us very much. It was a little like they were just pushing us to get to Mr Mandela's cell and that was it. There's so much more history that could be told in such a better way. I'm surprised there isn't a talk on the boat as well. Even just five minutes.

A must visit. A really interesting day out - lots of history and the fact that they have a former political prisoner guiding you round the former prison is great - interesting stories and makes it that much more personal.

A must see. As a family we visited Robben Island and were provided with a treasure trove of history.The trip on the boat was little dicey due to the weather however once we arrived we were shuffled in and met by a former prisoner who couldn't have been more engaging.Our only complaint is that the tour is time limited, it would be wonderful if visitors could be given a little more free rein and explore at their leisure however I understand this is probably due to security.This is a must see for everyone, especially those with children.

If you really need to. It's wonderful . Almost impossible to buy tickets on site. Book online ahead of time. Boat trip will make you queasy if you are like me. R300 PP. Takes 4 hours from boarding to returning to the waterfront. Once you are on the island it becomes one of the most intense and emotional experiences. Only chips chocolates and coffee to be bought on island.

BOOK YOUR TOUR IN ADVANCE. Popular tour with limited space, so make sure you book online or make a booking at the Robben Island museum on the waterfront. The tour takes around 4 hours, beginning with a cat ride across the 11.5kms to Robben Island. The island is small, only about 5.5kms long and 1.5 kms wide. Good photo opportunity looking back to Cape Town. Very well run tour from start to finish, we learned so much about the history and conditions of this now Unesco Heritage listed place.

Thought provoking trip. Boat over only takes 20 minutes. You are met by a guide and taken on a bus around the island, our guide was fantastic we learned so much in that short time, he is clearly passionate about its history. We then met another guide for the prison itself , ours was called Sparks, he had been an actual prisoner. He was amazing , listening to his experiences and his history of the prison was an unforgettable emotional experience. We went back to the boat with very different minds to when we got on ...

Memorable visit. A must visit because of its remarkable history and location.It was made even better by a superb tour from a former prisoner. First he offered the tour in a choice of five languages, not your usual beginning! Even without the ghostly presence of the great Madiba, this prison tour ranks with the best anywhere in the world.Warning, bring a jacket. It can be cool on the boat trip in autumn/winter.

A bit over-rated. There are better things to do around Cape Town. I am not discounting the history of apartheid or Nelson Mandela; one does not need to make the trip to the island to appreciate the history. The boat trip can be deceivingly rough, and the first half of the tour is spent inside a crowded bus. The second half of the tour is lead by a former prisoner and was longer than necessary. I booked the tour on the recommendation of others who were much more moved by the experience than I was.

One for the itinerary when visiting Cape Town. A good trip departing from the harbour. Unfortunately due to bad weather our initial trip was cancelled so we had to rebook - an email advising of this would have been more useful, but we were in good time to arrive and so were able to rearrange for the following day. The boat departed promptly and the tour guides during the trip were very good. Not much free time to explore but our guide mentioned they are looking at walking tours in the future so this may be better.

Wish the Tour Was Longer. 40 minutes one way by ferry. Get your tickets in advance online so you can make sure to get in. When you land you get on to a bus and go on a short drive around with the bus driver who gives some interesting and funny commentary. Then you get off and go in to the prison with your tour guide who is a previous prison inmate. I was surprised that with all that he had been through, that he would want to work on the island for a system that kept him locked up and tortured unfairly for years. I was also surprised about the tone of the tour because you can tell the guide didn't want to step on any toes and keep up the impression that forgiveness is key when you see how little things have changed since Apartheid in terms of racism and income inequality for a loft of black South Afrikaans. Segregation only ended 22 years ago and you can really tell in Cape Town. I wish the tour guide was able to feel like he could give more detailed info without feeling like he might offend the white Afrikaans in the group.

Interesting and enjoyable day out. I must admit I wasn't sure about taking this trip as im never much of fan of history/museum trips but this is a completely different experience. The boat trip over to the island has brilliant views back of Cape Town and table mountain then when you arrive a bus takes you aid the island with a really friendly happy knowledgeable guide. This really helps understand the island and it's history, then I learnt so much I didn't expect, yes this was where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for many years but I learnt so much more about the other political prisoners held there over the years and what was absolutely unbelievable to me was that the guide in the prison area was a prisoner here at one time and now lives in the island with a whole community of people with varying connections to the islands past. If you have the time during your stay in Cape Town then save a day to do this it really was a huge part to understanding the underlying history of this area.

Something that should be on your itinerary when visiting Cape Town. As part of our 30th Anniversary celebrations my wife and I made a great choice in having a trip to South Africa, taking in Cape Town, Stellenbosch (Winelands) and Kariega Lodge Game Reserve. It proved to be a truly memorable and enjoyable trip from beginning to end with many highlights.We had been advised by friends who visited South Africa last year that they had missed the opportunity to include a trip to Robben Island as part of their visit to Cape Town. They had assumed that it would be an excursion they could book during their time in the area, but discovered that both of the daily trips were fully booked for all three days of their stay. With that pre-warning we had booked on-line before leaving home using the official website for Robben Island, and we were very pleased that we did.We booked an afternoon sailing (3pm) and the boat “Dias” takes around 45 minutes to get to the island. The ticket includes an informative guided bus tour of the island and then a tour of the prison complex with a former inmate. The evening catamaran (at around 6:30pm) makes a slightly quicker return journey to the V&A quayside.
