The overall excursion takes around 3 ½ to 4 hours.The guide on the bus tour was a very personable chap who explained much of the history and layout of the island, including the lime quarry where the prisoners (including of course Nelson Mandela) worked breaking rock, the hospital and leper colony and graveyard and the house where Robert Sobukwe lived in solitary confinement for nine years. The tour also included a brief stop to see some of the resident African penguins. Robben Island is in fact named from the 17th century Dutch settlers as they named it “Seal Island”. The tour of the prison itself was thought provoking and poignant as our guide was Peter, a former political prisoner himself. He explained about the regime and conditions in the prison and showed us around the various buildings with his own personal insights, including of course the block and actual cell inhabited by Nelson Mandela for his 18 years of incarceration on the Island. To date, three of the former inmates of Robben Island have gone on to become President of South Africa: Nelson Mandela, Kgalema Motlanthe and the current president Jacob Zuma. Robben Island was used as a prison for political prisoners and convicted criminals from 1961. It was a maximum security prison for political prisoners until 1991. The medium security prison for criminal prisoners was closed in 1996. In the South African general election in 2009 the Democratic Alliance “won” the island.For anyone interested in such an important part of recent history we would definitely recommend that you include a trip to this intriguing world heritage site as part of your itinerary.

Impressive. Visiting Robben Island is such an impressive experience! At first I had no idea the island was so big, so when we went by bus was necessary to see the most of it. The guide was a really good storyteller with stories from obviously Robben Island, Nelson Mandela and his experience as well on the island as well. All in all, very impressive!

A great learning experience. You cannot miss a trip to Robben Island while in South Africa. The tour guides are wonderful and so knowledgeable about what went on on the island (because they were the prisoners) yet they don't hold any grudges about their mistreatment. Besides Nelson Mandela, there were so many more involved in the apartheid movement. You will get to hear their voices if you go to Robben Island.

Glad I went but would've liked to hear more history. First-I recommend booking your tickets in advance because there are a limited amount of tours per day. Now that we got that out of the way-here is the deal:I took the 11:00am tour but was told to go to the marina a half hour before. I went through a security check similar to the airport, which was no big deal. Took a jammed packed ferry ride over (there are seats available). We arrive to the island and without instruction, just start walking down the street where there are buses lined up. I got on one of the buses and there was a guide and while she was friendly, I wished her speech was a little bit clearer. The guide gave a history of the island but it was not as informative, as I would've liked. Robben Island is an important part of history and felt like we did not hear as much as we could about something so significant. You ride around the island, the guide shows a few landmarks, and then they let you out at a cafe to buy a drink, bathroom break, and to take photos of the ocean and Cape Town in the distance. Finally, they drop you off at one of the prison buildings and another guide greets you, whom is a former prisoner. I enjoyed what this guide had to say. They let you roam about the jail for a bit and you can go into the cells and read about the history of political prisoners and their experience. Finally, they take you to Nelson Mandela's prison and you can view his cell. There is no fanfare, you are told where his cell is located and can take a photo. Really not a lot of information about Mandela, as I think it was assumed you should already know about his life prior to visiting Robben Island. After this moment, the guide says goodbye and you are left to walk on your own to the ferry (not a far walk). This whole excursion will takes a half day, so plan ahead.

Robben Island. The tour is worth taking just for the historical and social significance. There is a kind of herd mentality on the tour to get you through the tour. The tour groups are too big and do not leave time to just think about where you are and what happened there.

Fascinating. This museum is testimony to the strength of the human spirit, as well as to the triumph of good over evil. Our tour guide was a former political prisoner, who first came to Robben Island at the age of 18. Just amazing, but somewhat depressing that these things ever happened.

The Prison Island. For the history lovers, if you are interested to see the place where the iconic and the only one Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for almost 18 years, this is the place to visit. There is a tour guide that will take you to the cells and explain everything about the prison and Mandela and you will also get the chance to be in the cell was jailed and take some photos of everything. There is also a bus ride through the Island to see the rest of the infrastructures of the prison. During the bus ride you will also find some good places to take some photos. Attention, the place is very windy and a bit cold, so don't forget to take some protective clothes even during some...

rushed in... rushed out.... Such a fascinating place would have enjoyed a little more time to read the plagues and information panels at the harbour and around the prison. I understand there is a great deal of information to fit into the visit but some self exploring time would have been enjoyed.

Great History~. We really enjoyed this. Being from Canada we knew some of the history around Apartheid, Robben Island, and Mandela, but we love to take the time to as much information as possible about the places that we visit. Robben Island did not disappoint. The guide we had was imprisoned on Robben Island, so it was a really neat perspective as we toured the prison and the island. It's about a 30 minute trip out there so if you get sea sick be prepared, but it's definitely worth the time and money to get out there.

a MUST. this was a very moving experience - allocate about 4 hours from start of lining up for the boat across and back. Ensure you book as you book for flights....you do not want to not go! You will kick yourself to go so far and not do this tour. A must if you are interested in South Africa

A Valuable Historical Perspective. Among all the fun, exciting things to do around South Africa and the Cape in particular, Robben Island is definitely a somber choice--however, if you are visiting a country with such an important past and a developing future, it only makes sense to learn more about its history.Our excursion to Robben Island, while certainly the most subdued activity we did, was enlightening and valuable.The whole process is pretty well organized; you can buy tickets in the Visitor center located on the V&A Waterfront. The ferries leave every half hour or so, so you may have to wait a bit if you get there just after one has departed.The ferry ride itself is nice and refreshing--you get to see lots of beauty around you (as with everywhere in Cape Town). Because the boat is pretty fast, I did not get motion sick, so if you have a tendency for that, it may not be an issue. What was an issue was that it was so windy that your hair basically ends up looking like a bird's nest; obviously this isn't your top concern when going to Robben Island, but just something to keep in mind if you have plans afterward.Once we got to the island we were transported all around by bus. Our guide was one of the past prisoners from the apartheid era (as are all the guides!) and he did a great job of pointing out important landmarks, telling personal and intimate stories of his own incarceration and also giving an overview of the island's history. We definitely learned a lot over the course of the couple of hours we spent there.It was pretty moving to walk through the prison cells and actually see where Nelson Mandela made his mark on his fellow prisoners. Additionally, we got to wander around a bit and see a shipwreck as well as the millions of bunnies that now inhabit the island.Overall, this was a great experience, especially for a history buff or a socially conscious individual interested in learning more about a very painful period in this amazing country.

Spiritual place. Thoroughly enjoyed boat trip there and back with amazing views.Great tour around prison with ex convicted political prisoner - very humbling.Bus trip afterwards was a bit unnecessary , but penguins were a treat!

A must visit whether you're interested in Nelson Mandela, history or how the island is used today. To understand what the remarkable Nelson Mandela endured during his incarceration you must visit Robben Island and hear what the tour guides have to say. They are most informed with the history and how the island is being used today. An ex prisoner gave a talk on his own experiences during his 12 years spent there as a prisoner. It's very easy to get to, a very pleasant ferry ride over, you may even see whales breaching as we did. There are tortoises on the island.

Disappointing . I had such high hopes for this excursion as I thought it would be very interesting. However it was very unorganised from the get go. We were on the first boat of the day and there is security before getting on the boat. No problem with that but they need to have people arrive earlier in order to complete checks and ensure the boats can leave on time. There were lots of staff just stood around not really doing anything. Once we got off the boat it was unclear where we were to go but we eventually got steered towards a bus. The tour guide was more concerned about the jazz concert he went to the night before than telling us about the island. This tour could be so much more. We were told conflicting things about the history and nothing was really explained well. Really disappointed about this and hope that they make some improvements.

Sobering Tour / Fascinating History. The tour of Robben Island is a sobering reminder of man's inhumanity to man. A prison whose inmates did hard labor with a breathtaking view of Table Mountain In the background.Robben Island (Robbeneiland in Afrikaans) means “seal island”. The island's lighthouse is the only one in South Africa that uses a flashing instead of revolving signal light. Dutch settlers used the island as a prison before the British colonists. In 1845 lepers from the Western Cape formed a colony there. During World War II the island was fortified with guns and became part of Cape Town's defense system.Robben Island is surrounded by shallow, treacherous waters from the Atlantic Ocean that have caused many shipwrecks by forcing unlucky vessels onto reefs. In the late 17th century a Dutch ship carrying gold coins to pay Dutch East India Company employees ran amok a short distance off Robben Island. The gold that went down in that shipwreck was worth millions of dollars. Over the years some gold coins have washed ashore but the treasure remains buried in the ocean protected by the violent surf.The ferry ride from Victoria & Albert Waterfront to Robben Island is unforgettable and there is a calm and comfortable sense of camaraderie among the eclectic group of visitors. Many of the guides were former political prisoner who lived on the island for 10 years or more.

Robben Island. Nice place, good history. The staff are great storytellers, letting us know of their experiences they had as prisoners so you get a good understanding of the struggle. Took a tour of the whole Island in a bus, only thing I wish we could have done was also stop at some more sites and walk around inside instead of just stopping and talking about it. But definetly something you should do in Cape Town. It is a good expierence and the boat ride there is pretty cool too (you get to see the Bay between the Island and the city)

Choppy travel. We took the ferry on a windy day and the sea was very rough. Frighteningly so. It took an hour to get there and many people were sick on the boat, so try and choose a calm weather day. I am glad we made the effort but its not much fun for young children.

Robben Island. I found this a very worthwhile trip to see where Nelson Mandela spent so much of his life imprisoned, how he lived and worked there for so many years. If you don't want to visit the prison and the quarry there is an option to see the penguin colony on the island.

Amazing Experience. This is a Super Day Out but BEST to BOOK ONLINEWe could not get tickets on last 2 trips to Cape Town but this time we did and it was a Super Trip.So Iterating to hear the history and actually visit all the Locations.Not Bad or Scary but More Meaningful and Informative.

Very interesting. This was far more interesting than I thought it would be. This was not just about Nelson Mandela. We were taken on a bus tour around the prison, with a guide who gave us a very good potted history with interesting facts and humour. When we left the bus were were guided by an ex prisoner who showed us the cells and told us about day to day life as an inmate. The only criticism was that there was not much time to read all of the information that was around the exhibition.

Visit to Robben Island. An interesting an informative tour into the history of a new era of democracy for our country. The somber, soulless atmosphere serves its purpose in identifying daily life for the political prisoners that called this home. I was humbled by the ex political prisoners' willingness to return to the island to assist in the facilitation of the guided tours. A great sightseeing experience, with a bit of added humor in true Capetonian style from the security officials at the ferry docking point. Note to self - always sit near the center back of the ferry where there is less rolling movement - for those that are a bit susceptible to seasickness.

Nelson Mandela's jail term where he spent 17 years.. Try to take the ferry across to the island when it is not rough waters. The guide we had on the Island was so interesting and as being mature had a long time history to share with us tourists.

Raw. I had read "Long walk to freedom" and I felt it important to visit Robben Island and find out more about the Apartheid era and the political struggles.Let me start off with the logistics first: We had a 1.00 pm sailing. We queued for 30 minutes and got going half an hour late. The crossing was very rough and quiet scary for some people. It took around 45 minutes.We got off the ferry and boarded a bus once on the island. Our tour guide was funny and informative. We drove around the island, getting off at certain points for a walk around. We saw a few birds and animals too which was an unexpected bonus.We then were handed over to a former inmate of Robben Island. This gentleman had been a political prisoner for 15 years. He was a serious man and was not a guy to be trifled with. He delivered a talk on what life was like on the Island as a group of 20 or so tourists sat on the floor listening. He then asked if there were any questions and at this point things got embarrassing. He had just delivered a very powerful, passionate and informative speech about the struggle to power and the various heroes / martyrs of the cause. To be asked questions about the quality of food or the comfort of the bedding seemed to be disrespectful. He was clearly getting a little frustrated and then when a young woman who was South African and of mixed heritage showed her complete lack of knowledge about historical facts he just blew up. He berated her in front of everyone for her lack of knowledge and then we she tried to argue back he berated her again for being disrespectful to her elders. Was he a little out of line? Probably "yes", but were the stupid questions and complete ignorance disrespectful? Absolutely "yes".Anyway, she left the tour, the former prisoner composed himself and we continued the tour. We saw Nelson Mandela's cell; (just like all the other ones).We then got a slightly smoother crossing backwards.I would recommend this tour if you are legitimately interested in the wider topic. Read up a bit beforehand and I think you will get a lot more out of it,

a MUST TO UNDERSTAND WHERE SOUTH AFRICA HAS COME FROM. A humbling experience, and somewhat weird that an ex prisoner is your guide, but does give you a great perspective on the conditions and the challenges for the everyday people during Apartheid.

Moving Experience. Round trip, this experience was 3 1/2 hours, but totally worth it. How often would you be able to meet and interact with a political prisoner from the apartheid era? You can feel the presence of Nelson Mandela. After your ferry arrives at the island, you board a bus for a trip around the perimeter. A guide provides history along the way. You will stop on the "natural side" of the island where we saw penguins and even a whale! You are then dropped off at the prison cells for a tour with the political prisoner guide. He answered our questions and provided a real flavor of what that time was like. It was moving and interesting. Well worth it!

A must do. Get to the ferry terminal at least half an hour before departure. If the weather is good then try to get outside for the views.Busses will take you around the island on arrival. There is a short stop for snacks etc halfway round and is a good viewpoint of the penguins.The prison visit is quite emotional but the depth of knowledge by the guide depends on the way it is conveyed. Mandela's cell and the courtyard where he had his vegetable plot was especially interesting.The views of Cape Town must have been so poignant for these political prisoners. It may be worth reading a book such as Mandela, my prisoner, my friend.. This was written by a guard who helped Mandela as much as he could. No previous knowledge is required but it may make the experience more interesting.
Rugby Tour. Visited Robben Island for the morning. Found the tour guide fascinating as he was a former guest of this establishment. Well worth taking the time to visit.
Elders . A very moving place to visit. We had one of the original prisoners as guide and was an excellent tour. Highly recommend. Must do.....

Can't miss Robben Island if you are in Cape Town. It's one of those places that is a must visit especially if you are in Cape Town. A short boat ride takes you to Robben Island where the very knowledgeable guides will take you through the life of the apartheid prisoners including Nelson Mandela.

Very educational visit. I loved Robben Island though is tough going there knowing the history. The guided tour of the prison was interesting and we did a bus tour of the entire island. It is better to purchase your ticket ahead. There are amazing views of the Table Mountain from Robben Istand, we even saw a whale. Overall I liked the whole experience.

Historic homage. Robben Island, the place that is so significant in the history of South Africa and in the formation of what it is today.As soon as one steos into the musuem and the gateway to the jetting of Robben Island you are fascinated and humbled by the history and the bravery of the many who struggled to make South Africa what it is today.The scenic fifty minute ferry ride gives you time to reflect and as you approach the island you have a feeling of going back in time and walking in the footsteps of legends, one cannot fathom the experiences of those that were imprisoned here.It is a shrine to Nelson Mandela who was in this prison for 18 of his 27 years in prison not to mention the great freedom fighters of the time A must do for all ages a travel back in history one is whisked off on busses with learned guides who highlight relevant spots and stop off at a tuck shop for refreshments and a pit stop so one can take selfies of Table Mountain and Capetown from Robben Island. Then a short walking tour by an ex political prisoner highlighted home life was on the island.Daily tours arevat 9, 11, 1 and 4 and are a total cof four hours.This wil be at a cost of 300 Rand per adult.

Historic .... but functional !!. Well worth a visit with undoubtedly the biggest attraction being the relaying of the first hand experience by the ex-inmate who accompanies your group - not forgetting the opportunity to view Nelson Mandela's cell.

Fantastic Tour but very difficult to understand both the guide on the bus as well as the guide who did our prison tour. Always a heart-wrenching yet soul satisfying place to visit. It was my 5th time. This time though hardly anyone in our group could understand the guides.

Great African history! Bucket list worthy.. This is an island not only for tourists from overseas, but also for South Africans! It was amazing to learn about our history and to "relive" almost what you thought you understood, but couldn't really until you actually go there! A bucket list worthy

Impactful experience!. I almost didn't go to Robbin Island while in SA, but I am glad that I did! It was a moving experience and it gives you some Insight to life during apartheid. This is a must do during any visit to South Africa.

Thought provoking and moving. I have to say that I was surprised when I arrived at Robben Island after a 20 minute boat ride. I expected a deserted complex but there are houses , tennis courts and shops there. The set up is that you are met at Robben by a guide on a coach. He takes you to key places then you are transferred into the hands if an ex inmate. The time allocated is not sufficient. Prisoner manuscripts are unable to be read as you are hurried along and the opportunity to chat with the ex inmate is limited as you are told to be back at the boat two hours later which actually doesn't leave until two and a half hours later. People queue up to see nelson mandelas cell but everyone who was incarcerated here has a story to tell. Take the time to read the prisoner stories and remember that this isn't some disneyesque theme park. Real people sacrificed so much of their lives for the good of others.

A must see.. Listening to the former prisoners describe their years of confinement, the degradation they suffered through and the primitive conditions the endured makes you grateful that they stood by their beliefs and changed the world.

Fascinating insight of the South African penal system towards the end of the last century.. We disagreed with other reviewers about our visit,we found it very interesting and informative. Fairly well organised,a half hour boat trip each way,followed by a tour of the prison,ending up with a coach tour of the island,( not a long coach trip,the islands not very big!) Our guide's English was however not the easiest to understand. Recommended for adults,but I think the average child would get bored quite quickly.

Puts it all into perspective. Although the transport to and from and on the Island is both packed,tired and basic, the overall experience was very worthwhile, it put the struggle for human rights against apartheid completely into perspective and brought home how much of a contribution Nelson Mendella brought to the process of peace not just for South Africa but to the whole of Mankind
What a place. Stark yet beautiful, a sobering reminder of the struggle South Africa has had to overcome apartheid. What a man Nelson Mandela was! Totally recommend

A must see if you have any interest in SA politics . We booked a couple of days before our trip. The transfer was smooth both ways and we even saw a whale on our return. The island guides were informative, and the ex convict that gave us an insight to life on the island was sincere and I suspect, underplayed some of the hardships they suffered. I understand that there is a drive to develop the island with hotels etc, I think having cycle and walking tours would be a good thing too.

Guiding lights. The crossing to the Island was smooth and took about 40 minutes, we left Cape Town in fabulous sunshine and arrived at Robben Island to grey skies and a definite chill. Coaches were on hand to tour the island and the guide on our coach was both informative, knowledgeable and funny. At the end of the coach tour we were given a tour of the prison itself, our guide for this part of the trip was Jama, himself a prisoner for 5 years on the island, his crime! organising youth boycotts ......it is hard to imagine a culture which allows incarceration for such actions. He is doing a great job now in educating future generations and older ignorant generations about the way things were. We saw some of the local fauna including a springbok, the jetty on our arrival and departure was awash with black cormorants in their thousands, an amazing sight.

A beautiful place popularly known for"Apartheid". Robben Island is a beautiful small Island right in the middle of the sea, located 11km away from Waterfront. A boat is available to take people there. Such a beautiful scene.It is popularly known for its history about Apartheid in South Africa. Tour buses are available to take you around Robben Island.The place has now become a resort place visited by many people from all over the world. Of interest is the church where most couples visit to get married every 14th February every year. Just outside the prison premises you can find a habitant for lots of penguins, a number of birds too as well as wild animals like bucks.

Very humbling. Visited Robben Island as part of a 10 day holiday. Pre booked tickets prior to our arrival and used web tickets, which were then stored on our phones and scanned from there on arrival for our tour. Around £6 per head. Fabulous value. The Jetty is located on the V & A waterfront in Cape Town. Various two hourly slots available and the visit is around 4 hours in total. Short boat trip to the island (30-40 mins). Then transported by a bus to the beginning of the tour (5min). A prior inmate of the prison took us on the tour, which was supervised at all times and meant we were under pressure to stay with the group to get around. The tour incorporated some talk and some time to see the cells and the surrounding exercise areas. Not enough time to absorb and contemplate what life was like in my opinion. A small tip for the tour guide is gratefully received at the end of the walking and bus part of the tour. Once that part was over, you are taken on a bus ride around the rest of the island and given a historical overview of the island and what it's used for now. There is a small church, where you can marry after a special application but only on Valentine's Day! A lovely tour, which no visit to Cape Town should be without. The love the people have for Nelson Mandela is plain to see.

Unfortunately boring.. I found this tour really boring. There is nothing special about that prison, except for the fact that Nelson Mandela spent many years there. I also thought that the harsh conditions of the prisoners were overdramatised. If anyone had a chance to learn anything about Gulag, Auschwitz or many other horror places would understand what I mean. The prison actually reminded me the summer camp on the Black Sea my parents used to send me)

A humbling experience. Left for Robben Island by boat from V & A waterfront, if you are going to make this trip book it yourself from the V &A and not through tour operator. On the trip out to the island fortunate enough to see pods of dolphins and whales, on arrival board buses for trip around island with commentaries in several different languages, so make sure you get on the right one. our guide was very informative and made the tour interesting.After the bus tour we went inside the prison ant the guides there are former political prisoners who tell you about their experiences, living conditions and journey during their internship / imprisonment, I found it to be a very informative, moving and eye opening experience. Make sure you take plenty of water with you as depending on time of year it can be very hot.

Extremely interesting and though provoking.. The tours operate at convenient times of the day and, on a clear day, the journey across Table Bay provides stunning views from the back of the boat. It was a bit of a free for all and fairly chaotic once we arrived in the harbour at Robben Island with no staff there to shepherd people to the coaches for the island tour, or to walk with you to the prison entrance. However, the former inmate who will be your guide was spellbinding and there are beautiful views back over the water to Cape Town from the viewpoint on the coach tour. If it's hot when you go, bear in mind there is very little shade but don't miss this as part of your Cape Town experience.

Informative & Inspirational. I had arranged that my mother (Aged 52) visits the Island for the first time. My mother was moved and revisited memories of the Apartheid years informing curious tourists of the days where she was not allowed to go to Muizenburg beach...she had provided them with a first hand account of the struggle and restrictions.This was my second trip to the Island and I will continue to revisit, at times, our generation not directly affected by Apartheid need to ground ourselves once more to see how far we have come, not only as people but as a nation.Forever inspiring!

For anyone who has slight interest in history. Amazing place to visit for another worldly experience. An insight into the history. Especially the part where you go for a bus tour, how the wardens chose to stay on the island. The life of the villagers. And of course the experience of the prisoners. I would recommend take the last ferry back for some amazing sunset view of the island as well as the rest of the town.

Amazing. Loved this trip taking in history.The island is around a 40 minute boat trip to the island. There is a bar on board the boat.Upon arriving at the island you are taken on a bus to the prison, however we felt you could walk this as it is a short distance. The guide sorry forgot your name was actually a prisoner there with Nelson Mandela so you had a first hand account of what the prison was actually like.You are taken on a bus ride of the island. however one of the last stops you are given five minutes to go to the shop and take pictures, i feel this could be a bit longer.Overall an exceptional trip and well worth the money. Thank you

I think a must do... This is an interesting tour - made more interesting by the fact our group had someone who was able to give us a first hand account. I think each tour is conducted by or includes this and it really adds a great perspective to the tour. Well worth making the trip to gain a greater appreciation of the history it holds.

A very moving experience but .... We were on the first ferry of the day when we visited and the sky was clear blue . The ferry out was very good with professional staff with full safety info and we very much enjoyed our sail over.It was a little chaotic moving from the ferry to the bus , ours was ridiculously full yet the one next to us was half empty, bad organisation here. We found the tour fascinating and the ex inmate who accompanied us made it a very emotional event . Due to our bus being over full we did feel like we weren't given time to fully absorb the experience at times.Overall we enjoyed this and it's definitely worth the visit but please be aware - the ferry which brought us back was no way like what we traveled out on, it was not a purposely built newish boat but looked like an ancient, poorly maintained ex fishing with cobbled together seats below deck with no windows . No safety instructions on life jackets etc. My husband works offshore and even he felt some anxiety at this sail, I think if we had been traveling with young children I would have refused to go onboard this vessel it definitely did not feel safe .

Fascinating place, but the tour could be better. I did the tour out to Robben Island recently. The boat ride there and back was pleasant, there were spectacular views of Cape Town and Table Mountain.The tour was broken into two parts, a bus tour of the island by a local; and a walking tour of the maximum security prison by an ex-inmate.The bus tour didn't give any opportunities to get off and really look at the sites we passed, though the guide was very friendly and informative.The walking tour was fascinating and it was great to have the insight from a former inmate.While the tour was interesting and informative, I felt that it was lacking in something.Regardless, I would still recommend a visit for its historical significance.

Good boat trip.. Enjoyable catamaran ride to and from the island. If you want the top deck view, get there very early! The walk along the quayside is quite atmospheric and there are some information boards along the way. The tour groups are too big and if you get stuck at the back you can't hear much. The guides do a good job but who will guide you when they've gone? Headphones? The trip could benefit with a few more information points and maybe some inter-active areas. Room for improvement.
Trip to Robben Island. Had a fascinating trip to Robben Island where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for many years. Very interesting tour and history in the Island.
Badly executed gem. Great idea; great location. Lovely boat trip there and back. Planning and organising of tours are bad!! Tour guides were good. Hardly any facilities. Transport old.
History . Great day out and learn a bid of Robben Island history. Nice tour guide a former political prisoner. Nice 20min boat ride.

Inspiring. The Robben island tour was a highlight of our trip to Cape Town, the guide was a person who had spent time as a prisoner on the Island so therefore the picture he painted was real. Thought provoking as you read about apartheid and that era but to feel and see and understand how humans were treated the way they were because of the colour of their skin and how they rose above this to complete there harsh sentences was awe inspiring.

Historical - but depends on your guide. I know many people who would rate this activity higher -- but unfortunately, we had a poor guide for the bus portion of the tour on Robben Island (he didn't give clear information), and the former inmate who gave us a tour of the prison had such a thick accent, we couldn't understand anything he said. So, we left Robben Island without learning anything :( We did see some of the resident African penguins, so that was at least neat.

A rich experience. If you are interested in the history of South Africa, this is a must see attraction. What makes it memorable is the fact that former political prisoners are giving the tour. The nice boat ride from Cape Town is a nice plus, especially in summer time.

Informative and interesting trip. Easily one of the highlights of our trip - we were very lucky that the weather held and we could take the ferry to do the trip. We left at 9am and were back by 1am. The tour comprised two parts - the first was a guided bus ride around the island and the second was a trip around the prison itself with an ex-political prisoner. The first part was entertaining and informative. The second was fascinating and brought the historical context to life.Highly recommend to anyone visiting Cape Town as an important means to learning more about SA's recent history

Wonderful Historical Learning experience. Boat ride out there gave a real feeling of the impossibility of escape from the prison. Wonderful guided tour and learning about Nelson Mandela and others prison experiences on Robben Island. It was very moving and I learned a lot.

Eye opening. This was an amazing trip very inspiring my children learned such a lot and had many questions which showed their interest .the tour guide was an ex prisoner who new nelson Mandela personally . I found out about all the other types of prisoners too The island is still inhabited which I didn't know It has some great wildlife too .

interesting and insightful. beware of the queue,several ferries take the 30 min journey to robbin island, including the Dias , which took Mandela to Prison, a great photo opportunity and the best view of table mountain can be taken from this boat,On arrival you take a coach and guide on the tour, all of these tour guides were former prisoners and my heart was in my mouth by the tales he told us,i Found the whole tour utterly gripping and i shall never forget it,This tour is unmissable,

thought provoking place. pre book your tickets as they sell out so quickly. This was a wonderful place to visit and really made you think how things have changed in ZA. A must for all travellers to Cape Town

Well worth a visit. We booked this trip on line before travelling so didn't have to queue for tickets. Boat trip across to the island gave beautiful views of Cape Town and Table Mountain, we even saw a whale in the distance. The guides were very informative and the one who took us round the buildings was once a political prisoner there and he brought the conditions they lived in to life, quite heart rending at times. The only problem we had was that we were put on a bus with a French tour so everything had to be translated into French consequently the tour took too long so when we got back to the dock we had to get straight on the boat so didn't have time to go in the museum and shop which was a shame.

Humbling experience. Visiting Robben Island makes you think of the horrible suffer human beings are capable of inflicting to others. Hearing the former prisoners narrate the treatment they received from the wardens chills your blood. Made me appreciate even more the figure of Nelson Mandela, who advocated for forgiveness and peace instead of looking for revenge.
Mandela's home for 18 years. A worthwhile trip to see the conditions and hear of the deprivations that the prisoners endured. Visit Nelson Mandela's cell and see the dorms where other prisoners lived

An afternoon on Robben Island. This was one touching experience as we were taken through the Island and told of the history of South Africa and those who were held on the Island inclusive of Nelson Mandela. This historic place brought about an appreciation to the struggles of those who fought for equality in South Africa. Especially touching was that former prisoners still remained to take tourists and those visiting around the Island and share with them to stories of life in prison.

3rd time visitor to educate our kids our history!. My second visit to Robben Island was with my In-laws and they were blown away by how the island and keep this rich history and captured the past but in factual but positive narrative. For this last visit our kids had an eye opening tour of our history very educational!

Robben Island. We did online booking. This is the easiest since you then just get onto the boat at the V&A waterfront area at your time slot. The boat trip is about 45 minutes from Cape Town to Robben Island. An ex-political prisoner provides a comprehensive history lesson including his own experiences. You get to visit the prison and then also have a bus ride to major historical sites on the island.You then return by boat from the island to Cape Town.

Historical must; tips for booking and going. Going to Robben Island is a must to get an appreciation for the history of S. Africa. While you'll learn that it has had other functions, such as a leper colony, the tour mostly focuses on what it was like during the apartheid era. The first part of the tour is by bus as the island is quite large; the second part takes you into the prison buildings. The latter part is led by a former inmate, which adds a lot to the information you get and the whole experience. Both guides were engaging and extremely informative. There are several breaks for restroom stops and one stop where you can buy snacks and water.  I was there right after Easter. During Easter and also Christmas the tours can fill up very quickly. Book ahead as soon as you know what day and time you want to go. The ferry trip to the island takes about 45 minutes and the seas can be choppy. We used windguru.cz to decide on the days with the least wind and the lowest swells. I recommend this if you have flexibility when you go, especially if you are prone to seasickness. The sooner you get there, the sooner you can stand in line to get on a ferry. Everyone goes through a metal detector, then you board a ferry. As soon as it is full, it takes off. We were one of the last ferries for the 9am sailing, so we didn't board until 9:30, and that limited our time on the island so we didn't quite get to see everything. Be sure to have layers; it can be chilly on the ferry. Sunscreen and a hat are a must if you are there in summer. If you need a wheelchair or a scooter you need to tell them ahead of time and they will make accommodations for you on the ferry. The tour bus had a wheelchair lift and there were lifts or ramps wherever we went.

Educative and emotional. Must do for all. We had excellent guides (Indian origin gentleman in the bus and ex prisoner - making the experience informative, educative and truly interesting - for adults and kids. Important place to visit in order to understand the history.

Moving history lesson. Twelve of us went over to Robben Island. We had a ferry ride and then a bus ride to the prison. We were greeted by a former prisoner and he eloquently explained what it was like to live in this awful place. No beds just mats. No protection from the cold or heat. Virtually no medical care, torture , cruelty and very little contact with the outside world. An occasional heavily redacted letter or an occasional short visit from family a few times a year. Starvation portions of food and filthy water. Hard to believe these men survived their ordeal . Some did not. The inspiring part was how they never gave up their dignity or belief in what was right and finally overcame it all and were released after a prolonged hunger strike. This place tells us so much about South African history ... And the importance of freedom! Do not miss it!

Good visit and tour, slightly underwhelming.. Overall, an excellent day out. Very interesting to see the side of the island beyond the apartheid ears with the 400 or so year history being talked about having got off the ferry and onto buses. The first tour took an hour with a refreshment stop and was very insightful as a tour.The second part of the tour was the prison which was taken by a former prisoner. This obviously has benefits with regards to having a tour from someone who's been there, but you did (perhaps understandably) get the (in our case) 5 year snapshot of their time there more than the overall 50 or so years of the apartheid imprisonment. Overall the prison tour was a good experience, but I left feeling slightly underwhelmed. Having said that, as I walked through the gate that freed prisoners did I did think about what it would mean for me to go through what the political prisoners did.

Thought Provoking Experience. For your money, you get a boat ride, a bus ride around the island with a tour guide explaining the history and wildlife of the island and then an hour or so tour through the prison, led by an ex-political prisoner.Toyer, the bus tour guide, was great fun. He had the whole bus (~30 people) engaged at all times with tales of Robert Sobukwe, WW2 and, of course, Nelson Mandela. He bus tour gave you an insight into life on the island, both past and present and how it was more than just a prison. Our political prisoner tour guide was arrested for five years and obviously experienced a lot during his time. Although a less polished speaker than Toyer, he shared an awful lot of his stories with everyone within his group and gave a real insight into what the political prisoners must have been going through. We walked through the solitary confinement cells, seeing Mandela's cell and onto the dormitories; all the time learning about how the prisoners fought the prison rules with the help of the Red Cross (no beds, no warm water for showers etc)

The spirit of the Rainbow Nation lives on..... In all of South Africa there is one place left where the pure spirit of a Rainbow Nation still lives, and that is so unexpected here that I was moved to tears by it. Those who explain to the visitors do so factually, without a hint of rancor, without any taint of color. No racism exists on Robben Island - thereby honoring those inmates that sacrificed their lives here so that the rainbow nation may come about.

Very interesting on the history of the Island. This was a great tour but the tour guide who was a former inmate was impossible to understand. The guide on the bus over to the prison was great and we understood everything he said. I wish the same could be said for the other. Best to read up on the history before you arrive.

A Walk to Freedom. We visited here as part of an organised tour travelling by boat across to the island from a pier in the Waterfront. Excellent views looking back towards the city we were luck enough to see the tail of a small whale, dolphins and seals. On arriving on the island we boarded buses and with a guide were given a full tour of the island stopping off at several interesting points, the quarry, and prison blocks. The facilities were very sparse as was the food that the prisoners were given to cook, different for each ethnic group. The guide at the block where Mandela was resident was a former prisoner himself and and holds no grudge against the time he was imprisoned, he was only 16 and a student when he organised a protest and was sent to Robben Island for 5 years, I felt very privileged to meet this man and shake his hand, some one who had stood up against the powers for something he believed in and knew was wrong and to take the consequences. Mandela was not the only activist serving time on the island as information boards tell you and they were all heroes in my estimation.

Was a bit disappointed.. We were really looking forward to this trip but ended up a bit disappointed. The ferry across was fine and we were ushered onto buses where the guide started the pantomine act of "good morning"..."I can't hear you" nonsense. As soon as the bus started, we were unable to hear any commentary and the only photo stop was at the refreshment shop at the far side of the island. The clearest part of the commentary was that tips were welcomed.. They need to invest in updateded busses with plug in commentary like the open top tour bus. Let's face it, we all want to hear about Nelson Mandela so it was disappointing that the guide, sadly a former prisoner, had to draw out the tour by repeatedly asking if there were any other questions. We were then ushered quickly past Mandela 's cell as so many stupid questions had taken up such extra time. It certainly is a must do in Cape Town but they could invest and make the experience so much more enjoyable but do they have to when so many people want to go, they have to put on extra ferry? Still glad we did it. Such a reminder of a terrible part of modern history.

A Lesson In Forgiveness. We went to Robben Island in 2002. Coming from Northern Ireland it was a lesson in forgiveness and how to move forward from a divided past. This was a humbling experience. Our tour was led by ex-prisoners of the apartheid regime. As a result we learned about the true brutality of life on Robben Island for the prisoners. What was remarkable was that they were presenting their previous gaol alongside some of their previous gaolers. When asked how he felt about this, our guide said that, in order for the country to move forward, he has had to learn to forgive his captors and seek a way of working with them.The tour presents the visitor with the reality of life for the inmates. We learned about the history of the island and of those who never left it despite having served their time.This is a must for any visitor to Cape Town.

Visit to Robben Island. An absolute must when visiting Cape Town. First a bus ride around the island and then a visit in the prison. An earlier political prisoner talked about how it was. Very inspiring and educational.

Try to get the earlier ticket. This was very interesting but due to the fact that we could only go at 3pm our experience was a bit rushed. We were bussed around the island with one quick stop at a shop and the lime quarry, but it was obvious there was a rush on. The visit to the high security prison and the talk with the ex prisoner was fascinating.I can't blame the staff for being in a hurry, after all if you miss the last boat you're stuck, so my advice is to book the earliest time you can so you have time to have a proper look around this place.

Inspiring. After a pleasant boat ride you board buses for a 45 minute guided tour of the island with a very educational and interesting history. After the bus ride you are directed into the maximum security prison where Mandela was for 18 years with an hour long discussion by someone who was a political prisoner for many tears. This is an experience you will long remember

A must visit place in Cape Town. Real history was made here. History based on real suffering. The bus tour showing the infamous hard labour quarry, the pile of stones made by Mandela after his release and the cramped quarters where Robert Sobukwe suffered house arrest are all sights to stir the consciousness as well as snap some pictures. However, the tour of the prison by a genuine political prisoner which speaks to the heart and the mind. Insightful and delivered without any bitterness, we were taken aback by the grace of our guide. To understand the challenges facing the Rainbow Nation, you need to understand its past. This trip was essential for that understanding. Excellent and essential.

Powerful. Such an interesting, sad and important part of S African history. Guided tour by bus around island with a couple of stops, then a tour of max security prison by A FORMER PRISONER! A full 3-3 1/2 hour experience. Plan accordingly.
Humbling. Being shown around by a former political prisoner and to be told he holds no grudges - puts so much into perspective.This place is a must on any visit to Cape Town- book in advance though.

Robben Island. After travelling over to the island on the boat, we were assigned to a coach with a guide. He explained the history of Robben Island and showed us, among other things, where the inmates used to work in the stone quarries. You then are passed over to a guide in the prison. Our guide was a previous inmate himself - he gave us a very moving description of what life was like in the prison. You get a really good picture of what some people went through because of apartheid.

Definitely worth going to, and do spend some time before you go in the museum to get a fuller understanding. The ferry out can be a bit rough, but the trip is so worth it. The guides are ex prisoners from the island and have a lot to say about torture, inspiration, revolution and boredom. Empty, it is hard to picture the feeling of the place when it was full, and sadly photos of that time with overcrowded rooms / isolation / meals etc are rare, but still you can get a sense of the horror of the place. The bus tour of the island itself was also well guided and the politics explained carefully to us. We went the day before to really read all the stuff in the room you leave from where the tickets are sold and I would really recommend this. We knew a lot before we went, but we still learned a lot. I think the placard with the different amounts of food for the different races, and the length of trousers for blacks/coloured/whites hit home hardest for me. Definitely worth a visit.
A must do. . Lived up to expectations. Talk by political detainee was insightful and informative. It might be good if an ex warden gave their perspective.

Heavy and important lesson . The Robben Island tour is well organized and informative experience. Departing by ferry from the V&A waterfront, the 20min trip to the island offered some of the best views of Cape Town. Once in the islands, the tour is divided into two parts: i) a walking tour in the prison lead by a former political prisoner, and ii) a bus tour around the island. The tour led by the former political prisoner was the highlight of the experience. It was very personal and heavy, but a great honour to us that our guide would share such an emotional and harrowing story of his time as a prisoner.

reality check. second time i have been to Robben island in 10 years. coincidentally, i had the same guide, mr tolani. The tour of the jail and listening to the guides who were prisoners in the island, is a good way to appreciate the struggle that some leaders went through before apartheid was abolished.

So-So. I was really looking forward to this tour and read much of Mandela's autobiography but was fairly disappointed. The inmate portion of the tour was very hard to understand. They seem to downplay Mandela except for showing his cell. The bus tour was a little better. The ferry ride back on a small ferry was pretty miserable and anyone with seasickness issues should be on guard. I'm glad I went to Robben Island, on principle, but if you are short on time, don't spend half a day here.

A must for every visitor to Cape Town. After going across on the ferry we were met by our first guide who took us round the island in coach. The guide describe what the island had been before the incarceration of Nelson Mandela. It was very interesting and when he handed over to a former inmate it became even more so. The first guide had excellent English where as the former inmate did speak in a broad Bantu accent making him difficult to understand but one got the gist.

Disappointingly mundane. We had high hopes for the Robben Island experience. Visiting Mandela's cell, interacting with former political prisoners. You know - stuff that all sounds good on paper.Sadly, the reality was disappointing. The ferry departed 25 minutes late from the Waterfront, for reasons unknown. Once we docked at Robben Island, we were shuttled into a number of tour busses, each with it's own (non-political prisoner) guide. The first part of the tour entailed us being driven around in the bus, looking at the Kramat, the lime quarry, the leper graveyard from the bus itself. No opportunity to get out and spend time in the quarry, to add a rock to the pile that Nelson Mandela started. No opportunity to browse the tombstones and get a sense of the poor souls who died there.We were allowed out of the bus at Robert Sobukwe house, given about 10-15 minutes to explore his prison house. Original letters between Robert and his wife made for touching reading. The next stop was a comfort stop for a snack and a toilet break with the opportunity to take photos at the Robben Island "photo frame". From here it was back into the bus and off to the prison where we were introduced to a former political prisoner. It was all very rote and almost scripted. We sat in F block and were shown the food that the various colours of prisoners were allocated, and shown the prison card system.We then shuttled past Mandela's cell, very much on a take one photo and move on quickly basis. And that was pretty much it - back to the ferry where we waited about 40 mins before leaving. We were back at the Waterfront at 5:30 instead of 4:30pm and it just really was a disappointing waste of 5 hours. It has so much potential, but is very poorly thought out.

Come and see where the world changed.. I will start the review with an observation that anyone coming to visit should be aware of. Especially if you are used to well organised escorted trips, clear instructions and "queues". DO NOT EXPECT TO BE WELL MANAGED BY TANNOYS AND DISNEY STYLE BARRIER QUEUES!!!!!!!Just relax and understand that it works. And works really well!!Once you get off the boat, we seemed to just wander aimlessly along the dockside and then without realising it, we had splintered into a number of smaller groups and suddenly there was a guide there talking to us and taking us through the chilling Robben Island Prison experience.Our guide was a former inmate of the prison, something that we were not previously aware to expect (I understand all the guides in the prison are). This made the experience more chilling, more real and so much better for it. The horror that he was able to put across was a "hairs on the back of the neck" moment that I will not forget any time soon.He was able to make the tour come to life, especially when he took us into the communal cells where the inmates were allowed to associate at the end of their terrible working days.Yes, of course, we saw Nelson Mandela's cell. But that really was only a small part of the whole experience.The second part of the tour is a coach tour around the rest of the island. Be ready to be surprised with all of the other aspects of the island - in addition to the prison / Mandela aspect.Such a great trip.You MUST experience this and see where the world changed, if you come to Cape Town.
Hard to believe. Our guide was a prisoner at Robben Island. We saw many parts of the island including Mandela's cell. So moving. Hard to believe this occurred in my lifetime.

Worth visiting but a bit sloppy. Compared to 10 years ago they extended the tours. The prison walk with an ex convict was really good and informative. But English only. The 2nd phase island bus trip was a royal cock up !! Busses were late, cafes had run out of food midday, everything rushed to get back to prom on time. So best take water and food!! Prepare for 4 hour tour.

A Moving Experience............ The booking section is a bit hap-hazard as the tours are listed as 9am,11am, 1pm and 3pm.We phoned and booked and were told to be at 10-30 am for the 11am ferry.However the ferry left at 10-30 so be aware that the times can only be guidelines and tours tend to overlap at times so it is best to set aside a day for the V and A Waterfront and connect with the tours which depart from the Clocktower Nelson Mandela Gateway.The ferry ride is quite pleasant and the trip is about 30mins.The weather can play a big factor and if the wind is howling or the waves are crashing, the tours may not operate so it is not advisable to book too early as tickets are valid for day of departure only and cancelled tours may be validated with a bit of arm-twisting perhaps?Once you disembark there are busses that move tour groups around in short stops and at each stop the tour guide will give a brief or detailed description of the events that occurred.We had a female tour guide with a lovely voice and she was impeccable with her narrations.There was also a female bus driver so the fairer sex is in the mix although I don't think that there were female prisoners on Robben Island!The visit to the main prison and the cells can be very touching and emotional and can have one picturing what those brave men like Nelson Mandela, Walter Sisulu, Ahmed Kathrada, Jacob Zuma , Mac Maharaj and many others went through on a day to day basis when imprisoned on this desolate barren island which has no resemblance with any island paradise whether in the Caribbean, the Bahamas or Ile Maurice!The one little house where the leader of the PAC was imprisoned solo and was not allowed to speak to anyone even the wardens was too traumatizing to contemplate entering and exploring because of the inhumane sentence that was handed out to the poor man.Other places of interest were the leper graveyard and the limestone quarries which was responsible for damaging the eyes of the inmates as they were made to break stones as part of the punishment.The tour guides in the prison section are ex-inmates and they do a very good narration of what went on in the life of an inmate on the island. The tennis ball episode was masterful!There is a tomb or Kramat of an exiled Prince of Madura, Sayed Abdurrahman Moturu who was sent to exile from his country in the East possibly Java or Indonesia in the 17th century by the Dutch and he eventually died on the island.This noble hero was one of the 1st Imams in the Cape and political prisoners always paid homage to the saint when leaving the island.It is recommended to visit the shrine, enter through the gate and remove shoes when entering the door. Once inside pray with a dua or supplicate any prayer or just meditate in the peaceful solitude of the tomb.There is a shop which sells memorabilia and other tourist items and also food and drink snack items and cards were also accepted.Stop at the entrance gate to Robben island when walking back to the jetty for selfies and photos.A definite experience not to be missed is the Robben Island tour and the only reason we could not do it in the Cape visit of 1981 and 1985 was that it was still inhabited by political prisoners and only visits were of family and more prisoners to the island.

Robbed island. Difficult to realize that Robben island was a jail until you get there and you visit it. Nelson Mandela spent more than 17 years there with many other prisoners. The testimony of former prisoners as well as evidences of their life such as letters sent to their family or photos provoke lots of emotion.
Always a humbling experience . Been to Robbin Island several times now and to be honest, it's amazing everytime and it has made better improvements each time. Great tour guides!

A one off essential to do in Cape Town. We saw loads of whales on the way to the island and back-worth the trip before we even arrived at Robben!!! We were shocked at what we saw and at the treatment of the prisoners- our guide in the prison had spend six years there as a prisoner and made the trip by being factual but with a good injection of humour. The Nelson Mandela cell was a shock as it really is small. The Penguins were great to see too.

A necessary, and sobering, experience. Robben Island is the locale where Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners were incarcerated for decades due to their resistance to apartheid. The tour is comprehensive and full of information, and the sight of Mandela's cell--alongside many similar cells--brings home the long tragedy that was the apartheid regime. And the focus post-apartheid on reconciliation rather than revenge speaks to the greatness of character of the anti-apartheid leadership.
Tie-in with District 6 Museum. Learning about the history of apartheid and Mandela is mandatory. We did this trip on the same day as visiting the District 6 Museum and a township.

Informative. Tour can last up to 3.5 hours. Get tickets in advance. Boat ride approx 30 min to island where you board a bus which drives you around the Island. Some interesting facts were provided. After bus tour, there is a walking tour inside the prison by a former prisoner who also tells you there own story. You have opportunity to take as many photos as you wish as well as ask questions. Very rough ride back on ferry as it was very windy. Sometimes it was difficult to understand the tour guides due to their strong accents. Very worthwhile to learn some history.

Everyone should come here. The trip to Robben Island involves lots of queues in hot sun, so take sun screen, water and a hat/cover up. Don't be on a strict timetable to get back to the mainland, as you may just miss a boat and have to wait for the next. However, it is somewhere that everyone should visit, to learn about the history of South Africa. The prison guides are all former prisoners, who are getting older, but the plan is to teach their children to be guides too. Our guide was very embittered that his struggles had not resulted in the changes that were promised, and so many of his people were still living in unacceptable conditions in the country of their birth. Change is happening, but much more slowly than was anticipated when I was in South Africa 8 years ago. Then, there was a sense of optimism, now there is more a sense of frustration. This is why it is important to go to Robben Island and learn about he history.

Remembered. As you would expect - thought provoking and humbling. One bit of advice - don't travel to the island on Jasper as it takes 50 minutes and is very bumpy and lots of people were sick, the other boat is much faster and smoother
Heart rendering and thought provoking.. Defo not one to miss. The whole trip lasts 2 to 3 hours. On arrival it's very well organised but do book in advance.

HISTORICAL TRIP. One very important visit this one ... The presentation by guides and former political prisoners gives one a chance to reflect on the challenges faced by inmates. Ultimately the trip provides you a platform to appreciate how far the country has come and how far it still needs to go! Besides the historical elements one also enjoys the ferry ride with the table mountain and the waterfront in the background.

Needs a revamp before I'd recommend it.. We were excited to visit Robben Island to gain some insight about the history of the region but it was a bit disappointing because it was very disorganized and seemed to miss the mark.We bought a ferry ticket and went over with the Robben Island tour; however, I think you can do the tour with other companies who may be better? Our tickets only cost about $30AUD each so we were fine paying that just for the ferry ride but the rest of it felt like a bit of a waste of time and perhaps we could have found a better activity to satisfy our curiosity about the history of the region. I hear the District tour is good.Pros- Ferry ride to and from the island was beautiful- Really interesting stories on the walls of the ferry terminal- Former Robben Island prisoners now host the tours so it offers an added element of emotion to the tourCons- Confusion from passengers moving from the ferry to the buses- It was challenging to understand the guide and there isn't any catering for those who don't speak English (our entire tour was French speaking people except for us and they all struggled)- Minimal signage or explanation about different areas - Lack of opportunities to use restrooms (a boy actually peed in his pants because there were no toilets for +4 hours)Give it a shot to tick it off the list and support the former prisoners - but don't expect much from the tour or you will be disappointed.

Very interesting visit to Robben Island. We just returned from a trip to South Africa with Smartours. On our 3rd afternoon, we took the free shuttle from our hotel to the V&A Waterfront area, to take the Robben island tour. The tour begins on the mainland with some historical information and pictures that you can read/view while waiting for the ferry to the island. You then board a ferry to take you to the island. The tour consists of 2 parts -- part 1 is on a bus, which drives around the island, stopping at the various buildings to provide the history; part 2 takes you into the building containing Nelson Mandela's cell (set up as it would have been when he was there) -- the tour guides are former prisoners, and their personal stories really do make for an informative visit.NOTE: Would strongly recommend booking a ticket on-line for the date/time that you want to take the tour -- there is limited capacity, and it sold out quickly (several people in our tour group were not able to get tickets when they arrived) ALSO, allow enough time -- the ferry ride to & from the island takes approximately 45 minutes each way, depending on how rough the seas are, and you need 1-2 hours for the tour on the island. If you get sea-sick, definitely remember to take some anti-nausea tablets (it was a very rough ride over & back on the day that we visited)

Sadly a poorly organized experience. I thought the trip to Robben Island would be one of the highlights of our trip. Unfortunately the entire experience is poorly organized. Once you reach the island (often by a very rough 30 min ferry ride--bring your vomit bags), you're herded on a tightly packed coach to drive around the island for 50 minutes. Depending on your seats it can be very hard to see the landmarks being discussed. You are then given a tour by an ex prisoner of the cells. This was very interesting, but our guide's English was very poor and it was difficult to understand what he was saying. The experience would have been better if visitors had more time to explore the island and contemplate its history. Other guides we met in other parts of Cape Town said our experience was very common.

A wonderful learning opportunity! . Really well organized tour made extra special by ex political prisoners taking you around. Very well presented and excellently spoken! They also provide you with a tour of the island itself and all the other history too. Only downside is that you don't have much time to explore the cells and stories written by the prisoners. They also have artifacts supplied by some of the ex prisoners on show in the single cells. Everyone also fights to get a picture in front of Madiba's cell. Overall a definite must! Well priced and a great way to learn a little more about our history.

Dignifying . Forgive but not to forget. Tom Moses an ex-political prisoner guided us around the Robben Island Prison. He's story and he's presence in the room both strong and touching. We left Cape Town with the 11.00 boat, a big and fast vessel. It was plenty of space onboard. Seats outdoors is however limited to ca 30 on the top deck. It is worth to be early to grab one of those seats on a sunny day. We made it on the return trip and turning back to Cape Town was amazing. I found the whole experience very good. The guides was great and the timing of this he whole trip was very good. No stress and no waiting. Our children 9 and 13 got a lot out of the trip even not English speaking.

Interesting but would only do once. The life of Mandela was truly inspirational. The tour was good but is is very long day and you are, ironically, a captive audience for most of the day.The boats are crowded and take an age to get there. The tour itself was brilliant. The guides make it special.It needs to be done once but only once.

This is a "must go" in Cape Town. Robben Island is really impressive and worth the visit.When I went there (march 2013), the guides were former prisoners from Robben Island, and it made the visit much more interesting.

Interesting place to visit. . Our tour guides were great and we thoroughly enjoyed the tour. The 2 hours was perfect time wise so our younger guest (7) didn't get bored and there was plenty information to keep the 11 and 13 year old interested. If you battle with motion sickness, you might want to take something before you get on the ferry. It does, of course, depend very much on what the sea is like on any given day, but I wasn't expecting the ferry rides to be quite so up and down today. The swell was bigger than I thought it would be.

Steeped in history. Well,worth the 45 minute boat trip from Cape Town. Tickets must be booked in advance. A most interesting and informative tour of the prison given by a former inmate. He spoke from the heart - he had experienced the harshness and the regime

Cannot miss!. The Robben Island tour was amazing! We learned so much history and to see the actual cell Nelson Mandela spent 18 years in as a political prisoner is just something you can't miss when visiting Cape Town. Our guide was actually a former political prisoner himself. We learned about quite a few of the political prisoners and how they were kept separate to minimize their influence on other prisoners. The tour takes up quite a bit of your day, but can't be missed in my opinion.

Really insightful visit, great bus guide and tour by ex inmate.. We visited here in the afternoon and was concerned that our 1-6 year olds would play up, but couldn't visit Cape Town and not visit,We really appreciated the historical significance and the kids were well behaved, the bus driver guide was humorous and knowledgable. We were then dropped at the prison and got a taste of prison life. Cold bleak and massive but well worth it.The tour desk and queues to get on and off the island were a joke. Considering they will take millions of rand each year here should allow them to provide a service that merits the ticket cost,

A must when you're in Cape Town. This is a don't miss for sure. Other than the potential rocking of the boat (you're really on the open seas) a trip to Robben Island is fascinating. You board a bus upon landing on the island and head to the prison building. There you're met by a guide who is a former inmate (and who likely still lives on the island in the little village). Speaking from experience, the guides are able to answer any question and have a unique perspective on life during their own incarceration. In addition to seeing Nelson Mandela's cell, you'll see remnants of the island's history as a leper colony, incredible wildlife, and a community where many of the current employees live today. Our guide had been an inmate for 16 years, taken there in his teens. Pretty amazing. There were children on our ferry who were returning home from school in Cape Town - they make the trip every day.

Missed opportunity to do so much more. Having visited Robben Island 10 years ago, I was looking forward to seeing the place once again. I was disappointed. The boarding process was completely chaotic. We left Cape Town 30 minutes late and arrived 45 minutes late, as a result of which the remainder of the tour was extremely rushed with little or no time to read the various information materials in the prison and home of Robert Sobukwe. The account of life in the prison from an ex prisoner could have been enlivened with some more personal anecdotes. Generally, it would be good if there was some time to wander around the prison and the island by oneself.

Very Moving Experience. We were lucky to have ex prisoner Tom Moses as a guide. An unforgettable visit due to his description of his personal experience as a prisoner and to his dignity and strength of character.

As said already - a must do!. Similar to others' comments, this is a must do in Cape Town (similar to some other attractions as well).I saw some slightly negative comments on here, including the rough journey across. Really? Maybe they should smooth the water for the travel across!Once on the Island there are two tours. One on the bus around the island, and then (or before) a tour around the prison. The prison tour is carried out by an ex-prisoner and this does add to the experience.Whilst I've given the overall rating a 5 star, I do think it could be improved. I think both tours (bus around the island and prison tour) are slightly off-script and therefore I'm sure somethings are missed out. I could be wrong. Making it more scripted would work for these types of tours. Especially the prison tour which no doubt includes some personal experience of the the guide, which though important to them is probably not the most important stories of the prison. A lot of visitors will want stories of more high profile political prisoners and I think they could be added into the tour in a better way.Nevertheless still an excellent tour and I would highly recommend.

Important trip to take. This was really the only serious part of our trip to Cape Town, and one that a few in our group were a bit reluctant. It is about 4 hours from when you get on the boat to when you return, but in retrospect, we were glad we took the time to learn the political history. It could have been a slightly shorter tour, spending a bit less on the bus trip on the island or in the prison. It may seem like I was trying to speed up the trip, but there is no way that you can only go to the prison or only do the island tour, you have to do the whole thing. There was a little snack shop in between with drinks and snacks, which was good to have, and the rest rooms were OK also.

Sombering experience. Before going, I wasn't so keen, but it definitely isn't something to be missed if in Cape Town. The prison was essentially a political prison. You see a small amount of the prison, including Nelson Mandela's small cell and you learn about the conditions and history by the guide, who was also a former prisoner on the island. You don't get to freely move on the island as much as we hoped, you get shuttled by bus from the prison, to the rock quarry and past several important buildings while a guide explains the historyGo pick up tickets early, as tickets sell out quickly. We got there around 10am and the next available ferry was at 1pm. There are a limited amount trips that the ferries make. There were three ferry boats per session, so we weren't all cramped onto one ferry which was good because it is at least 20 minutes by ferry from the port to the island

A visit that will stay with you forever. Robben Island is best known as the place where Nelson Mandela and many other political prisoners were incarcerated during the Apartheid years. It is located in Table Bay about 12 kilometers (7.5 miles) off the coast of Cape Town. The island is now a museum and a World Heritage Site and it can visited as part of a tour that starts with a boat ride from the Nelson Mandela Gateway at the V&A Waterfront. Robben Island played an important part in South African history and it's in my opinion an essential visit when in Cape Town.During the boat ride, which for us lasted about 40 minutes, you get to enjoy wonderful views of Cape Town and Table Mountain. Once you arrive on Robben Island, you embark on a guided bus tour around the island. During the tour you are told about the island long history as a prison and as a leper colony. The island served as a jail since the mid-17th century when it was used to held political leaders from various Dutch colonies. Two very moving stops on this tour are the house where Pan African Congress leader Robert Sobukwe was kept in solitary confinement and the limestone quarry where Mandela and other political prisoners did hard work during their imprisonment. After the bus tour, which lasts about an hour, you are dropped at the gate of the prison where you are met by a different guide, usually one of the former inmates who will show you around the prison. The guide will talk about the daily life of the prisoners on Robben Island. The fact that our guide was a witness to what happened made the tour very moving and personal. At the end of the tour we were shown Mandela's cell. Nelson Mandela spent 18 of his 27 years of imprisonment on the island. In order to visit Robben Island you need to book a ticket. We visited in February and they were fully booked for a week in advance. I was lucky to find tickets for the last day before our departure. So if you're visiting in summer my advice is to book early.Robben Island's harbor also has a colony of African penguins which we didn't get to see. My kids were tired after having to keep quiet and still for 3 hours :) so we headed back to Cape Town.

Getting the balance right. Everyone has to visit the island but this trip left me with mixed feelings. Seeing the quarry and the minute cells was not something you can experience from books and the coach trip round the island was well presented and hugely informative. As so many want the experience volume is an issue and the hydrofoil carries a few hundred at a time who have to be dispersed in a small island and eventually come coach load by coach load into a narrow prison corridor.
