It is hard not to feel herded. The ex prisoner enriched the event but you wanted to ask him questions and one was all that time would permit. Organisation was good although our 300 boarding left at 345. There was good information at the departure and finding out more about the history of the island was a bonus and the trip was good value for money at 300 rand for a full half day.

You can't miss it . This tour is amazing, we had a guide in the prison who was prisoners there when he was 20s and listen to his story was so emotional.. You can Also see Mandela 's room .After the Prison tour there is nice bus tour and you can see the island and Also Penguins !! Choose the tour at 3:00 so while you are coming back you can enjoy the sunset from the boat!

Could be better. It can be a bit of a scramble to get tickets. The ferry ride out is an experience with good views of Table Mt and Cape Town, but be prepared for a bit of boat movement.Once on the Island you are driven around on a bus to see some parts of the island, and then dropped off at the prison. The group sizes are very big so 50 people will be huddled around the guide trying to listen.The tour only takes in a few of the blocks and doesn't really give a sense of the place.The guides, who are ex political prisoners do an excellent job and tell stories of their time on Robben Island.Its something that has to be seen, but the experience won't blow you away.

A must see . You probably know or heard stories about South Africa, Nelson Mandela, and the apartheid, well get to robben Irland and it will all sink in and you will realize how sickening the old oppressive regime was, and understand the grandeur of Mandala love for all people.

Very informative reflective trip. Our visit to Robben Island was well organized and very informative. The process of booking online went well and we were able to get a Ferry at 1 pm. One thing that I would suggest to travelers is to have their credit card or form of identification as this is required for you to collect your tickets on site (we had not been informed of this when making the booking). Our tour guide (for the first part of the tour was very knowledgeable and funny at the same time - lightening the mood in a somber place). So was the tour guide a former prisoner who took us to the tour of the former cells. From a personal perspective, this tour reminded me of the strength of the human spirit and the sad history of apartheid.
A must visit...... Learn about S.Africa modern history and the Apartied. More time could be spend in the jail and there was so much more to Lear about the inmates.
Very interesting trip. To get to know more about SA history and darksides, I suggest to take time and visit Robben Island.Even for 9 year old child was exiting.

Excellent attraction but plan early and have a plan B. During our visit to CapeTown we were very fortunate that the ferry we booked, on the time and day we booked it, actually ran, as during autumn and winter months, the schedule for this trip is very uncertain due to weather, and when the wind is high, or the mist is down, ferries get cancelled. During the week we were there this happened a lot, so we very lucky. The visit is really very good. It is in two parts, the first a bus tour round the island showing areas such as the limestone quarries where prisoners had to do hard labour, and then a tour of the cells including the cell Nelson Mandela was incarcerated in for years. The cell tour is conducted by ex prisoners which brings the whole thing to life in a very graphic but incredibly engaging way. The ferry takes around 30/35 minute each way. In total this is a 3/4 hour trip.

Lifetime Experience. It is indeed a lifetime experience. The approach was by boat and once you are at the island the buses took you around. The cost was very much worth it. I was awe struck by the Guide and his manner of excellent presentation. He is South African educated in a local university. His English was excellent. Once you are inside the prison the guide changed to an one time inmate who had been in prison with Mandela.it is a treat to listen to him, first hand from him.

Robben Island Pilgrmiage. It is a must for every human to see and hear what trials and finally tribulations people went through to have the freedom we have today. If not for anything to just respect those that sacrificed their lives for others. I could not help but shed tears on hearing the story. It indeed a lesson for all of humanity!

not just a prison. This island is famous for being where political prisoners, including nelson Mandela were locked up. Former political prisoners guide you through that part of the visit. A coach then takes you round the island which still has a small village. Views ove rto Cape Town are great

Good experience . It's advisable to buy your tickets on line to avoid the rush.Its a 20 min boat ride to the island.Once you get to island you are taken in a bus fir the rest of the tour. Not much walking around to do. They stop at all the important places so yiu can get down and see.Recommended for all people who are interested in history and apartheid.
History. Yes, its one of those tours where you learn about history but a very important part. I think it would be a waste to not learn about the place you're visiting.

Robben Island. Robben Island is an island 12 km off the coast of Cape Town. The island has been used to insulate people from the outside world, primarily as a prison. The first prisoners were political leaders from Dutch colonies in Africa and Asia. Between 1836 and 1931 the island was used as a tuberculosis sanatorium, and later prison for political prisoners from South Africa. One of the most notable prisoners was Nelson Mandela. The place is a UNESCO World Heritage site. A very popular tourist attraction which I absolutely recommend to everyone while visitng Cape Town.

Reflective Robben island. The island tour lives up to its expectations easily, a point ant reflective trip and highlight in tourist itinerary easily.the ferry was over an hour late for us, as its busy in March but a pleasant trip in boat, lacked audio description that could have enhanced experience. The bus ride was really informative an unexpectedly humour ours.the prison trip was superbly led by ex prisoners and this made it all the more meaningful and as it should be...we should never forget human injustices and autrocities. The timings where all good apart from late ferries. The exhibition at the ferry terminals also excellent curation, really educational and set the tone.easily a highlight trip from my visit
An unforgettable experience!. I loved every minute of the experience. Very interesting..informative..and emotional. Going back in time...a must visit!!!!

An uplifting experience. As soon as we decided to visit South Africa, this was a must-do trip. We had a great morning - saw dolphins and whales from the boat to the island, and the iconic views of Cape Town and Table Mountain. The bus tour of the island was interesting and educational, but the walking tour of the prison block guided by a former prisoner was really moving. Our guide was fantastic with the children on the trip.

Awe inspiring!!!. Wasn't sure what to expect on this tour, but from the minute we joined a very short queue we were treated very well. The boat trip was quite rocky but well worth it as the weather was warm. Saw the water spouts of whales which added to the boat trip. When we got to the island we were put on a bus and shown around the island which was a great way to see the whole island sights. We were bused back to the prison and were escorted around it by Thomas Moses. He was the most inspiring man, what he went through and still so solid. He made the prison visit for us all Well with a visit to see how they were treated just for being born the wrong colour

A must see. We were quite lucky cause we had an amazing guide who talked us through the history of each corner of the island and of the prisoners. If the weather is nice you can even combine the tour with seeing Cape Town from a distance and penguins!

Can't help to be moved. Pleas and and interesting boat ride out, saw a couple of whales. As soon as you step onto the island it is a moving experience. Very interesting to experience the place the location and the narrated tour was well worth the tip
Must Visit. Very humbling experience, well worth a visit. Try and chose a calm day to make the trip if you are not a good sea farer.

Nelson Mandela & Others. I am at awe what the human spirit can deal with. Nelson Mandela and so many other people fought hard to rid the injustices of what governments imposed on its own people. The tour guide was extremely knowledgeable and I will bring some of our friends with and will recommend this! Thank you!

Must see sight but need to suffer through guided tours. This is a must see sight if in Cape Town due to the historic significance. Tour is half walking half bus. Our walking guide was a former prisoner, and he gave great insight but the group was too large for a detailed tour. The guided bus tour was really boring. We did not get off the bus to see things in more detail so we missed a lot. Get tickets in advance, the lines get long and the ferries are not speedy.

Makes you think..... Well worth while if you have an interest in the history of the country. Well organised and bookable in advance, which is advisable. Clever idea to use ex-political prisoners as guides to the actual prison. Makes what they tell you more authentic. Need to set aside the morning or afternoon as it takes all that time. I visited Alcatraz and was struck by the fact that the cells at Robben Island were larger but the 'bed' was appalling. At least they had bunks in Alcatraz. It amazes me how Nelson Mandela came out of it without extreme bitterness about his treatment.

Great historical experience. This is a must do in Cape Town to experience more of the history and culture of the country. The tour guide was extremely knowledgeable. A former prisoner gave the tour inside the maximum security prison- it was a bit hard at times to hear because of room acoustics. Overall great tour and would recommend!

Poor management, poor guides, grotty buses. No flair or imagination for what should have been a memorable day.. We traveled on the ferry form the V&A waterfront and that part of the day was OK. The rest of it was so poor in the way it was managed, organised and presented. The presenters were ex convicts and it was impossible to understand them with their poor language skills and lack of audio back up. The trip did not do justice to the memory and history of Nelson Mandela - which is a very great shame. If ever there is an opportunity for a good PR presentation this is it.
A moving day. I have done this trip twice. It was very moving. I missed so much information the first time. How great was the man?

Emotional and well worth visiting. Its hard to compare the emotional and impactful stories told to you by an ex prisoner on Robben island with the luxury of the V&A waterfront in Cape Town you will have left an hour earlier. Robben island is one of those 'rewarding pilgrimage' places that you really feel was worth the effort but it does also bring to home the harsh realities of prison life during the apartheid era in a very direct way. The stories and conditions are hard to believe especially when told by a passionate ex prisoner who went through it all and survived. Many of the people on our tour were visibly moved and as the wind picked up and the clouds came over it gave a good impression of what life was like. Overall this is highly recommended if you want to experience one of the key places for the struggle for freedom.

A real sense of history in the making. Great visit to get a real sense of what Nelson Mandela went through while in captivity as a political prisoner. Guides are ex inmates and give a brilliant insight into day to day life in the prison. Access is by boat so watch for days where the sea is rough!!

Moving Experience. You will learn about the history of the island, including the most recent history at the end of the apartheid regime. A good reminder of how history judges those who use threats or acts of violence to maintain their positions of privilege.

A historic venue that must be visited. An excellent trip, even though the sea was slightly choppy. to be taken round the island by bus with excellent explanations of the various sites on the island , only to be followed by a tour of the prison with explanations from a former prison inmate

MUST VISIT to hear first hand experience from ex-prisoners of Robben Island. This is one trip that you must plan in your itinerary for Cape Town. As there is a limited number of visitors that each tour can take, you should prebook your tickets in advance. That is the only sure way to guarantee you will not miss out this tour.As you queue for the ferry to take you to Robben Island, take some time to look at the exhibits hang around the queueing area. We were lucky that during our ferry ride to Robben Island, a whale was sighted. The ferry even stopped for a while for the sighting. A pleasant bonus for the whale sighting.Upon reaching Robben Island, we were instructed to get up on the buses. The guide on the bus who was giving the explanation of the various point of "attractions" was an ex-prisoner. I was quite surprised that we were not allowed to get off the bus to see the various points of "attractions" at a close range. But I guess, the previous generosity of allowing visitors to get close to these sites were abused, hence, the drastic measure of such is taken. So depending on where you are seated on the bus, you might not even be able to take a decent photo of the sites. Before the bus went back to the prison building, a short stop was made for toilet stop, shop and also some exhibits. I feel that the time for this stop can be shortened so that the rest of the tour for the prison facilities is not so rushed. Another ex-prisoner took over the guiding when we reached the prison facilities. Of course, the highlight is to see Nelson Mandela's prison cell. On the whole, I really enjoyed the history lesson that I had hearing from our guides, who had first hand experience, as they shared their experience with us. However, the whole tour felt very rushed even though the tour, including ferry rides is about 3 hours. We did not even have time to see penguin on robben island or to walk around the place on our own. Maybe the management or the tour operator can review the whole tour and see how to improve the experience of the visitors.

Amazing walk through history. Absolutely awsome experience,from the boat ride,bus tour of the island and ofcourse the inner sanctum of the prison with Mandela's cell. Truly an unforgettable experience.
Interest. Good trip over on ferry. Guide interesting giving various facts slightly biased but informative. Island ok. Place to see history where Mandela had been kept.

Not the most family friendly attraction. We were travelling with a small baby and as we had to hang at the back of the rather large tour group we couldn't hear any of the commentary. The boat on the way over wasn't at all stroller friendly and you should take snacks and drinks with you as the only shop on the island is at the end of the trip and isn't well stocked.

Thought provoking visit. A 40 minute ferry ride from the Waterfront to Robben Island (you may need to consider a seasickness remedy as the journey was across quite choppy waters). Once on the island buses take you on a tour, a guide travels on the bus to describe the various areas and buildings. We were particularly fortunate to be on the same bus as an elderly ex-political prisoner, although he was there as a guide for one particular couple he spoke to the whole bus whilst alongside the stone quarry- his testimony was incredibly moving. The prison complex was as barren as could be imagined. Walking along the corridor past Nelson Mandela's cell was a sobering experience, at least for the majority of the group- not the young SA couple who held up the group whilst posing and taking selfies in front of the cell!

at the heart of the history of modern S Africa. This was both depressing and inspiring. To see and hear first hand of the conditions of the political prisoners , including Nelson Mandela, was a revelation. Their ability to rise above this was incredible.
Moving experience. We learned a lot about Mandela and the island and those that were kept there in prison. The short hope from the coast may be choppy but ours was fine

Great insight into the history of South Africa. Fascinating tour of Robbin Island by an ex prisoner. While I know of Robbin Island's history during the latter part of Aparthied, I was unaware of how long it had been used as a prison and who had been kept there. Highly recommended.

Blew my mind. Visiting Robben Island right before Human Rights Day was the best experience. The tour guides were all prisoners on the island, and made the tour ever so personal. It really was the best experience, even the boat trip to the island was eventful :)

Great experience. A must do trip when in Cape Town. A trip back in history. Amazing human beings could treat others like this. How Nelson Mandela and the others survived is incredible.
The boat trip across is really nice . Seals swimming alongside the boat . A real bargain trip. I really recommend this

An okay visit. If you are in Cape town and have spare time, i recommend you to go this place. You will see there the jail that Nelson Mandela was in and the way of life they had. It was an okay visit.

Somber experience. Former inmates lead you around the jail after a short bus ride.
Didn't see the penguins this time around. Just sad to hear how people were (still?) Treated. The 45 minute ferry ride over offers great views of the city and opportunity to see the seals and depending on the season whales.

Words cannot describe this trip. When I was told to book the Robben Island ferry before our trip to Cape Town, I had an idea of what to expect on our visit there. I expected a museum like tour of cells and possibly a few anecdotes about experiences on the island during apartheid.However on arrival, we were greeted by Tom Moses, our tour guide and former political prisoner for over 12 years. He told us his story of his time there and the political conflict during the time. He shared his thoughts on Mandela and what has been achieved since the end of apartheid. I can't explain in words how incredibly privileged I felt to be in his presence, but what I will say is that this is an experience I will take with me in whatever I do in life.Thank youPS Book in advance!
Beautiful Memories. We had a wonderful experience in Robben Island, beautiful History about that Place, everyone must visit the Place.

Must go to Robben Island. About an hour ferry ride to the island. It's very windy so better take warm clothes. You will see lots of seals on the way. Once you arrive, you will get on a bus with a friendly guide. Bus ride is about an hour including a short break at a little shop where basic food such as cookies, chips and sandwiches. Not much choice really so better take your own lunch if your trip departs at 11am. After the bus tour, a x prisoner will take you to the inside of the block. After the tour people were giving him some tip which I loved to do because I really enjoyed the tour. Sadly we didn't have any cash left after buying snacks so you might prepare some cash.

So much potential . We really enjoyed our visit to Robben Island, and you cannot fail to be moved by the significance of the events which took place there. Friends had told us that it was very dull and I completely disagree. The tour was conducted by a ex political prisoner who served five years there, and there is also a bus tour of the island. However, having visited Alcatraz about five months ago, the comparison is compelling and there could be so much more made of the prison, the history and the struggle faced by the prisoners there. One final point: the sea crossing to the island can be rough with a number of passengers being seasick, so take tablets if you use them. Also book a couple of weeks before you travel. The phone app worked well.

Needs work. I understand the personal seriousness of the tour guides. Most if not all spent time here.The bus tour around the island was informative and interesting. But the "tour" of the prison consisted of walking in to a large communal cell where you sit classroom style for 45 min listening to little known fact after fact after fact. It was like being back in grade school listening to someone just talk about the event. We're here! Take us around the prison, give us a couple of facts at each locale and let us be here and experience it with you.It feels like an us vs. them mentality instead of an experience to see what happened, to step in and live for a moment the lives of those so important to change in South Africa.I'm sure over time this will improve, but for now, they take everything they have to offer and hide it behind classroom lectures. I wouldn't take children under 13 to the current rendition.It would actually be a truly amazing experience if they did one of those auto tours in the prision, where you go from section to section and get a basic rundown of the importance or purpose/relevance to the cause for each.You are there... you should experience it first-hand, not have it lectured to you as it could be from any classroom in the world.

Essential.. You have to go don’t you? The boat trip out is nice complete with dolphins. The tour is very well organised but with slight and pleasant rough edges. It is not a slick Disney trip. Our guide for the cells had tremendous presence and knowing that he was held here for some years added essential authenticy. I lived in SA between 1970 and 1974 and don’t think I read or heard about Robben Island or its famous inhabitant, let alone the others. And to be there now, knowing all that has gone on since 1990, and gradually discovering what happened in the years from the Rivonia Trial to Mandela’s release in 1990 – well it’s a significant series of thoughts. Reflecting on the efficacy and secrecy of the pre 1990 years – and my own memories of living in SA for 4 years. And all that changed so completely and quickly between 1990 and 1994. Leading to now; some of the visitors weren’t alive in 1990. How different it is now. That’s a statement and a question. Better – that’s for sure, but as in the apartheid years – the future is full of uncertainty.

Don't miss this!. Robben Island is a must for all travelers to Cape Town. In its bleak landscape, it's wonder that all prisoners didn't choose to give up. Our indoor tour of the prison was led by a former prisoner who really brought the reality of the prison to life. Be prepared to be moved by the stories told by your guide. The bus tour was good as well, but the real treasure are the political prisoner guides. Don't miss going to Robben Island!

Highly Recommended. For what it is (a prison) and despite its history, Robben Island is an incredibly beautiful place. While there I was constantly battling between being sad and angry about the things that went on there, and admiring the incredible views. I just ask that anyone who goes takes the time to understand the history of the island and what it represented for so many years. I was honored that our tour guide was someone who had unfortunately spent time there as a prisoner. Hearing first hand accounts made the experience even more powerful than it would have been without it. As a side note, the ferry ride to get there was super rough. I don't ever get sea sick but I definitely did this time around.

Must See. I don't think this should be missed on a trip to CapeTown however, there are some notes. 1) you must have an advanced purchased ticked as they do sell out. Only the official boats go over to the island 4 or 5x/day with a no option guided, structured tour. The wait to get on the boat could take up to 45mins. 2) I don't get affected by rough seas but, some of the passengers got VERY sea sick (and threw up) on the 40min passage. I would recommend taking an anti sea sickness prophylactic if needed. Possibly the passage is not always rough but, it was rather rough the day we went. 3) the tour is given by a former political prisoner which makes the experience very impactful. 5) When you get to the Island and get off the boat, make your way as soon as you can to the busses so you can get a seat that you want. 4) this is only a partial (if you will) of the apartheid suffrage. I VERY strongly recommend to take a trip to the district six museum (also in Capetown) and if headed to Johannesburg, a trip to the apartheid museum (phenomenal) and Soweto (Mandela's house) will put it all together.

Amazing, once in a lifetime experience. It is impossible to put in to words how profound our trip to Robben Island was. Not only do you get to see and hear the history of the prison island but they are given first hand from ex-political prisoners. It was hard to contain our emotion throughout our tour. It was educational and inspiring to hear from the tour guides and see where Nelson Mandela was held prisoner for so many years. This is an absolutely must do when you visit Cape Town.

Historical Robben Island. It was a great place to be, the tour was nice and i totally enjoyed it. I was able to transcend through time and space and perceived happenings on the island years before i set foot through the vivid recounts of ex inmates who served as tour guides.

Not a great experience.. As a disabled person, I found the staff unfriendly and unhelpful as they constantly shouted at me to hurray up even though they could see that I walked with 2 sticks. I would not advise any one with walking difficulties to go there unless they take their own wheel chair or similar.

A must. You just cannot lave Cape Town without visiting the island. Advance booking is required as these tickets are hot property.There is a 30 minute boat ride to to the island followed by a bus tour around it lasting 45 minutes. You are then walked around the prison by a former political prisoner. His stories are harrowing. It's an incredible experience and one not to be missed.

100% Must. You can't come to this city without a visit to Robben Island. Sobering and educational, you get a real sense of the not so distance past which is all too familiar for most people. Of course visiting Nelson Mandellas cell is the whole reason for going but you mustn't forget the other political prisoners who have served time for the fight for freedom.
Interesting. It was an interesting place to visit. The guided tour was well organised. The staffs are friendly. We had the chance to meet an ex prisoner there.

Wow!. The historical magnitude of this tour is like no other. The tour is provided by former political prisoners and gives an in depth, emotional point of view. We got to see Mandela's prison cell and toured the whole island.

bored. I expected a prison island to be more interesting. It was only filled with political prisoners. It's only famous because of Nelson Mandela. My friend and I found it a waste of our money. You only get to go inside one building, and look at Nelson Mandela cell. I did find it neat that in the other cells there was a profile of a prisoner.

Outstanding. This was a brilliant trip.It includes a boat trip, a guided bus tour of the island and a tour of the prison by an ex-prisoner.The sea trip is very picturesque, however, it was extremely rough on the day we travelled. The bus tour and prison tour were interesting and thought provoking. You also get an opportunity to see some of the wildlife on. The island.I would definitely recommend this trip.

A must see for every visitor to Amazing Cape Town. We bought our tickets on line before we went to SA.It is a good idea to take the first ferry at 9 am.Once at the ferry port there was a half an hour wait to board one of the two ferries.We were not able to get on the new ,more modern ferry and ended up on the old and bit slow ferry.There weren't enough seats for everyone and almost half the passengers had to stand during the 45 min crossing which is not really ideal.However,the journey is pleasant with great views and we were lucky enough to see hump back whales.Once there, you are put on coaches and taken to meet your guide who is an ex prisoner and who escorts the group round the IslandWe were taken to see Nelson Mandela's cell which was tiny and during the early years prisoners slept on cold concrete floors on a thin mat and blanket.The details of prison life were harrowing and very upsetting.At the end of the walking tour,coaches took visitors on a tour round the Island.Our guide on this part of the trip was also very interesting.The return journey we were again on the slow ,old ferry!Overall very interesting morning.

Informative Tour. It is advisable to pre-book your tickets. The ferry took approximately 40 minutes and if you are lucky like us you may see some whales!We enjoyed the bus tour round the island and the guide was very informative. There is a stop for photos across to Table Mountain and there is a small cafe for refreshments. The cell tour by our guide and ex prisoner was very moving as he gave us a description of what his life had been like for the 11 years he was imprisoned on the island.

Educational. I booked the Robbens Island and Township tour through Viator and was not disappointed. This tour is very educational. The township tour was enlightening and gave me hope that things will get better even though it's going to take a very long time. I took people's advice and took Dramamine to combat potential seasickness on the ferry to Robbens Island. The ride coming from the island was rocky. The tour of the island gave us knowledge of what it was like during those times. The guides took their time, so we weren't rushed. The views of Cape Town from Robbens Island are spectacular. Viator provided an excellent guide for the township which made the overall experience worth the price. This tour is a must-do if visiting South Africa.

Its an island with a prison on it.. There's not a lot more you can say about the place itself. The tour guide himself was interesting to talk to and the trip across the water to the island itself was interesting because of the whales we spotted, but at the end of the day, its not Alcatraz. Its interesting from a historical perspective given the terrible political regime which ran the place, but there isnt a lot there to actually see.You should do it so as not to forget the ills of the Apartheid regime, but its an island with a view, that all.

This place brings you down to earth. You cannot visit Capetown and not visit Robben Island. The tour guides on the bus are excellent, at least the one that we were having. Explaining all about what there is to see, without you getting the idea they are just hammering out words. Meeting an ex-prisoner makes you feel humble. I am not adding any spoilers here, go and see it for yourself

Fascinating and though provoking experience!. A place to get in touch with history, with the resilience of the human spirit and to really appreciate the long walk to freedom. I highly recommend it for every freedom loving human being

Amazing history . The tour was amazing...great history yet sad one but its amazing to see what these amazing people went through to get their freedom. Our guide was an ex-prisoner with Nelsom mandela. He explained everything they went through, how they used to punish them etc
Must not miss this tour.

Living history. The trip to Robben Island helps to put into perspective the sadly too recent history of SA. The use of former inmates as "guides" to life in the prison brings to life the brutality of the apartheid regime as well as the small victories made by the inmates in their long struggle. You also may get to see some whales on your crossing to the island and you will have wonderful views of the Bay and Table Mountain.

Family holiday. The boat trip across to robben island is about 15-20minutes. The ferry is quite crowded but gets you across quickly. Once your over on the island they split everyone into about 4 groups of about 50(depending on how many people are there) and you go around in those groups for a incredible tour of the island. Near to the end you visit Nelson Mandela's prison cell which is incredible to see and hear facts. At the end you get the ferry back and you can walk around the museum on the Victoria and Albert waterfront.

Thought provoking.... Informative tour on the island by bus, with a guide, followed by tour of the prison with an ex-prisoner as the guide. Fascinating, stories told about the conditions of the prison as well as the history of the island. A must do visit.

A great day out - a very interesting tour, but felt a little rushed. The entire island is a heritage site, and as well as visiting the prison you also have a quick tour of the island.Our guide around the prison was an ex-inmate, so was able to add personal anecdotes to the experience - fascinating. Many of the cells have names, photos and little stories from the prisoners - often harrowing/poignant but sometimes quite humorous. You also see a small cell where Nelson Mandela was incarcerated for some time.Then it's back on the bus to see the rest of the island, with a couple of short stops, before returning to Cape Town on the ferry.

Sadness. I do not know whether we expect luxury treatment or a walk in a park. Somehow the simplicity of it all does ring a bell to the sad conditions the prisoners lived under. After all they were not criminals just people fighting for a cause. I really felt for Nelson Mandela and all the other folk who were imprisoned on Robben Island. So perhaps the prompt service etc we expect is actually not required. Though it would be great if the busses and boats are well taken care of and on time as tourists and folk have many other things on their itinerary to get through and deadlines to meet.

shameful place. Best combined with a District 6 and township visit. Great views of Table Mountain and a whale on the way over. Prison very sanitised and visit satisfaction depends upon the nature of your guide who will have been a previous inmate. It's not all about Nelson Mandela although that's the reason most of us go. Sea can be rough so twin hulled boat more stable than traditional.

Hard hitting historical tour. It's not a feel good tour but it's informative and a must-see for the history buff travellers. It requires a lengthy boat trip and a short bus tour and culminates in a walk around what was once Nelson Mandela's garden where he hid his manuscript of "a long walk to freedom" and his cell where he spent many years writing it. It's not an aesthetically pleasing tour but certainly an emotionally stirring one.

Important testimony to freedom. You cannot go to Cape Town without going to see the fomer prison on Robben Island. We were even brought there by the same fishing boat that transported prisoners up to 1990. An excellent guide took us on a bus trip around the island before we were taken to the prison by a man who was a former prisoner himself. Going here you never forget what racism may lead to, what apartheid was, how they treated political opponents.
book in advance.... ...we didn't unfortunately...so didn't go to one of the key things we wanted to do...next time we'll know better.

Good, but very drawn out. Lots of repetition. You need at least 4 hours for this iconic island. 2 hours are used travelling there and back in a packed boat on choppy seas (one of our party was very sick) and 2 hours for the tour of the island. Snag is that all of the tour guides actually served time in this prison, and each different guide basically told us the same story over again. Whilst very interesting the first time, most people become noticeably bored near the end. We were pleased to have visited the island, but glad to get back to Cape Town by the end.

Fascinating and authentic trip. The boat trip is interesting. We saw a whale on the way over. Return trip on on of the boats used to. Ferry prisoners so not comfortable - but surely that us the whole point. Being sent to Robben island was never comfortable from being a leper colony to being a prison for political prisoners. The tour gives a flavour of the history and you see the natural history. The prison tour us humbling to see how Nelson Mandela and others were held. Remarkable.

Guides indoctrinate a dramatic Mandela story. Tourist trap: Informative but annoying tour guides indoctrinate you only on the positives from Mandela's life. Tour guides try to be inclusive of all nationalities on the tour which becomes annoying. After the ferry ride you hop onto a bus which tours the island; you can't explore the island by yourself except for the jail which Mandela was held in.

Book your ferry EARLY!. I suggest, to book the earliest ferry, at 9am a day before you embark on this historic journey! Remember to come before its closing time which is at 5pm! The main reason is because by the time its around 1pm, it gets pretty hot, and the crowd just makes you feel very irritable. Remember to bring your caps, sun tan lotion and lots of water! The ferry ride was amazing! We caught whales along the way! And we heard stories of the prisoners first hand from their very own prisoners! COOL stuff!

Peaceful. On our way to the island we saw whales, dolphins and seals, all beautiful sights. The tour guide was once imprisoned on the island, he was very informative and answered all questions honestly even personal one's. It is a must do.

Everything done in a rush. I have now visited the place for the fifth time in January since 2012 but I have not yet received the quality tour in the museum. We were kept in a communal cell for longer time given a lot of information but did not see the museum as expected. We were then taken to the late Mr Mandela's cell. We spent less than ten minutes there to take pictures and were told to leave and our tour ended there. Every time I visited the museum the tours were not the same. The tours at the museum were not standard and we missed some valuable information. I consoled myself that the money I paid was for the sea cruise not for the museum, which defeated the purpose of visiting the museum.

You cannot fail to be moved. The travel agent was very insistent: you must go, she said. I wasn't so sure, but am I glad I went. The trip out is like a seaside holiday: blue skies, blue waters, we even saw some whales and dolphins. Then the reality of the place hits you - hot, dusty, desolate. You are shown round by a former prisoner who details just ow dreadful conditions were, even after the International Red Cross had been and insisted that inmates have a t least a blanket to sleep on. The harshness of the regime is brought home by the regulations about food - not much for anyone, less for blacks than for Cape Coloured (Indina, Malayan and mixed race), and the unrelenting heat at the quarry were people laboured for nine hours a day.Yes, it is famous because Nelson Mndela was there, but in the block where he was held and scores of similar cells and each one has a picture of a man held there and something about his life and the way he endured his imprisonment.It's impossible not to be moved by this experience and for people of a certain age (like me) who remember the anti-apartheid movement - the protests, the marches, the Wembley concert, the exhibition at the ferry terminal brings it all back very vividly.

Great tour for history lovers. Great tour for history lovers, we were honoured to be show around by actual ex-prisoners of the Robben Island - it made if even more of an emotional visit.If you're in Cape Town, it would be bad if you didn't visit it!

Well worth the trip. Robben island is an interesting trip if your here as a tourist you should make it if not just for the views going in and out of the harbour.For taking pics try to avoid the hovercraft.

Tour was long and drawn out. Beautiful boat ride to a worthwhile historic site - however our tour guide (ex prisoner) wasn't as informative as I had hoped and didn't share as many stories regarding his experience in the prison. He kept repeating that nelson mandela was an amazing man, which is obviously true - but I wouldn't have liked to gain more out of the trip. The tour should provide visitors with more information. Would go again for the beautiful view of cape town from the boat. Would skip the bus tour.

such a bizarre place to go where mandella was imprisoned. what an expierance going to robben island where mandella was imprisoned and have a tour guide who also was imprisoned there a bleak place but what a story

History relived. Robben island holds much of South Africa's history. First hand insight on the lives that South Africa's freedom fighters lived... apart from the jetty to and from the island making me a bit nauseous, it was a once in a life time Kind of experience...

An interesting place . A very friendly guide guided us through the interesting secrets of the island. After the bus guided tour, a former prisoner took over and revealed the darkest sides of Robben Island to us. Very fascinating but also very sad and depressing. May things like that never happen again!
Memorable. Chilling, emotional, educational and very worth it. We loved it! Definitely recommend the trip. Our guide on the bus was amazing and so was the prison guide who was a former prisoner.

Less informative . Here we bought our tickets on line so it was easy when we got to take our late ferry. I would not advised to take late ferry 15h00 as everybody will be rushing to finish the shift from the bus drivers to the tour guides which are believed to be once prisoners themselves,If you know quite the history of robben island and the strangle of blacks in SA you will be disappointed with the tour guides they just tell you what everybody knows.About Robert Sobukwe there was minimal information about him and the house he lived in, this I first head in the local radio station and was feathere cornfimed by our uninformative guide. I added up buying a book on Robert Sobukwe to make up for my loss.Overall I was disappointed about the experience but for tourist who do not know much the information might be sufficient.

Robben Island in Cape Town. I didn't have many information about Nelson Mandela until visit Robben Island in Cape Town.just for your information, this is the prison where Mandela stayed for long time due your fight against apartheid. If you are going to South Africa, you should go to Robben Island because it is a mark in the history of the world.

A must do in Capetown. We prebooked this tour to be sure not to miss out. A good thing too as we avoided the long queues for tickets on the day. Once off the ferry, you are placed onto waiting buses to be transported around the island. The bus stops at various points of interest around the island and for taking photos. There is even a chance to get off for a short break which offers a picturesque view back to Table Mountain. The second part of the tour is walking through the prison and being guided by an ex prisoner around the buildings. His stories were fascinating and then we were shown Nelson Mandela's garden and then his cell for 18 years. It was haunting but at the same time very moving. We came away feeling sad about the injustice of it all but inspired by what he achieved.

An island we should never forget . One of the main reason we are traveling to this part of the world. To see and appreciate what humans can to inspire love and happiness with forgiveness to move forward with our humanity.Going there was easy. We bought our ticket online but when we were there the ticket booth was not really busy. I guess everyone had bought their tickets online as well.Boat ride was around half an hour with the most gorgeous view of Cape Town and the magnificent Table Mountain. WOW.On the island itself, you will be guided with 2 tours, the bus and the prison cells. Both guides were former political prisoners so I could imagine how emotional these for them.I could write a book...We ended up seeing penguins but unfortunately not allowed near them as it is mating season and they can be very aggressive.This journey is a must to all of humanity.
Family trip. In spite of the historical interest, pretty boring and long.45 minutes trip in a bus with one single 5 min stop (good speaker in the bus)Jail visit with a former prisoner : super boring.

Visit of Robben Island. My second visit there. Always something different we had the chance to listen to one prisoner . Though he could shorten his presentation so that we have more time to tour the island. The tour guide was very good and funny.

A moving experience.. A great trip pre booked via Audley Travel. Once on the island we had a bus tour of the island with a very experienced and amusing guide. Back at the prison block a former inmate gave an insight into life while we sat in one of the communal cells and then went to the tiny cells of B section where Nelson Mandela spent many of his 27 years in prison. A very worthwhile experience.

Beautiful spot with great historical significance. We really enjoyed our afternoon on Robben Island. The ferry ride was interesting and seeing Nelson Mandela's prison cell was certainly worth the trip. The bus tour could have been better - but there are not a lot of other options to see the island. Penguins on the beach was a nice bonus as well.

Heartbreaking & yet Beautiful . This place moves you. Our ex prisoner Tom Moses your guided us through cells, experiences, history, struggle and triumph through Apartheid.If you are a lover of history, this is a place that will make you feel proud of the people who fought for freedom. This is a tour that can make you teary eyed, and finally leave you with a smile.The struggles and the calm dignified fight of Nelson Mandela, the visit to his cell and his story of 27 years in jail is a story that must be heard and absorbed.

One of Cape Town's 'must see' attractions. We pre-booked our visit to Robben Island before we travelled and arrived in good time for the boat. In fact there were several boats all going at once and they were all busy! Our boat took about 40mins to reach the island and we all disembarked onto a fleet of coaches, each with a guide, taking us on a tour of the island. After various stops you end up at the prison itself where the bus guide hands your group over to an ex prisoner. Our prisoner guide told us what it was like to be incarcerated there and also to leave again! When asked why he became a guide, he explained he felt their story had to be told to the world. The guide spoke at length and with a fairly strong local accent which some people might find hard to follow so you might want to read up about the visit in advance so you are familiar with the history. On the way back we travelled on a catamaran which was faster and you have the most amazing views of Cape Town as you sail back into the harbour. The whole visit takes 3 to 4 hours depending on how long you spend there. Take a jacket for the boat as it's breezy and leave time to explore the harbour area which is packed with shops, restaurants and hotels.
Thought provoking. The visit to Robben Island, including talks by former political prisoners, is very thought provoking and excellent value for money. A 'must do' for all visitors to Cape Town.

Thought provoking.. This has to be done when visiting Cape Town.Book online before you go, saves a lot of queuing.The boat ride over to the island can be choppy.The coach trip around the island is very interesting, we had a well informed guide who explained everything we needed to know. The visit to the prison was guided by an ex detainee, sometimes difficult to understand what was being said. You get to see most of the prison particularly the cells.

A must do- our former prisoner/guide was exceptional. Nice boat ride, weird and frustrating bus tour, but the prison block tour was both heartbreaking and inspiring. Our guide, imprisoned for 5 years (which he assured us was "nothing"), was wonderful. The prisoners' stories inside many cells brought tears to my eyes. Our guide's ability to communicate their daily lives, the incredible leadership they received from Mandala and the others, their commitment to the cause and to each other and his total lack of animosity (in fact, his generous and caring spirit) was awe inspiring.

Very informative. We went on the Robben island trip which was very well organised. We went expecting just to see the prison and have a tour but got much more from this with a tour of the island which is steeped in history. Well worth a visit. We were lucky to see whale and dolphin on the crossing.

Well worth a visit.. Do book in advance as the boats only go at set times and are very busy. We had an enjoyable boat ride and even saw a whale on the way back. The coach and walking tours were very informative. It was moving to read the stories of the prisoners in the cells. Would have liked more time there, but had to get the last boat back.

Emotional. this trip gets booked up fast but they do have a couple of sailings each day, saying that we booked on the day and struck lucky.the cruise out was wonderful as we saw whales on the way and got some great pics .when you get off you are then transferred to a bus and a local guy will tell you all about the surrounding area, once you get to the prison an ex prison convict then does the talk which is quite humbling...as soon as we got outside i was in tears.

A sobering and eye opening experience! A Must when visiting Cape Town.. We visited in December 2015. The ex-detainee explained the harsh conditions for most and also the preferences given to some in the COLD and bare premises.All was done to break the spirit of the detainees, some for minor reasons. It must have been a gruelling experience, with no fresh water, some shoeless, hard floors to sleep on, poor food and censorship all around. Hardship, illness, loneliness and death as daily companions. The guards had a better time but it seems it was still hard even for them.However, the prisoners, in spite of controls, the prisoners and Nelson Mandela as guide wrote up the Draft Constitution for a new more integrated and egalitarian South Africa in those conditions!!It makes you re-examine your sense of values, humanity and compassion.When we asked what was the most important lesson he learnt from Robben Island, the answer was "Forgiveness, forgiveness unto those who had done the deeds.'Book early to know more

Thought provoking trip. One of the must do trips whilst in Cape Town.Very enjoyable boat trip out to the island in great weather.The fact that the person showing us around had been a political prisoner was quite interesting.Very thought provoking.

Interesting visit. We booked this the day before and opted for the 9am sailing as the later sailing don't appear to run to time. I paid by c/card as they do not give cash refunds if they don't sail due to weather, usually high winds. You are requested to be there 30 minutes before sailing. We were on the first boat out, but there was another boat filling up behind us. We had a tour of the prison (1 hour) followed by a bus tour and cafe stop (1hour). it was an interesting and thought provoking tour. We travelled back on a smaller boat arriving back at 1pm. Take a drink with you and a jumper for the boat trip, Toilets available at the cafe and the end of the prison tour. Convenient parking available at the clock tower section of the waterfront

See where Nelson Mandela was held and more. One of the places I really want to see while in Cape Town was Robben Island. It is the location of the infamous prison where Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners where held during the apartheid years in South Africa. As you would expect, it is a place of great significance for South Africans. It has been accorded World Heritage status by UNESCO. The people at the hostel recommended that I book ahead to get a ticket. My tour started at 1.00 p.m. The boat to the island was not what I expected. It appeared to be a ‘working’ boat, with limited places for the passengers to sit. Prison Ship The trip out to the island took about 50 minutes. There was quite a large swell. As we drew into the harbour on the island we could see a number of other boats. They all looked like your typical harbour cruise boats.Once on the island we were directed to a line of buses. Once on board we were greeted by our Guide. He looked like a young Nelson Mandela. He asked which boat brought us to island. Someone old him it was the “Dias”. He explained that the Dias was one of the original “prison boats” that were used to transport supplies to the island. It was also used to transport the prisoners to the island. Tour of the Island by BusThe bus took us past the prison and to an area which the guide explained was the site of a leper colony. The island housed the colony up until the 1930’s. It must have been dreadful to suffer from leprosy in those days. I note that it has been determined that leprosy has been determined to not be very contagious. I guess that leper colonies were a bit of an overkill. Robert SobukweThe bus then stopped at a house. The guide explained that house was where a political dissident by the name of Robert Sobukwe was held in solitary confinement. He was famous for leading the resistance to the ‘pass laws’. This was system under apartheid wherein the Blacks were issued with identity passes that were used to restrict where they could live and travel within the country. The guide told us that as part of his solitary confinement Sobukwe was not allowed to talk to anyone, including the Warders that were guarding him. Towards that end of his incarceration he was visited by the anti-Apartheid activist, Helen Suzman. The guide said that he met Suzman when she visited the island shortly before her death. She told him that Sobukwe told her that he was “forgetting how to speak”. What an extraordinary form of torture solitary confinement is. Lime quarryThe tour took past the Lime Quarry, where the political prisoners were forced to work. The Guide explained that the educated prisoners used the “relative freedom” while working in the quarry to teach the illiterate prisoners to read and write. He also explained that the dust and glare at the quarry caused eye damage to the prisoners. Penguins and Great View We stopped for a short break the northern end of the island. From this point there is a great view of Table Mountain. You can also see some of the local penguins. Apparently their numbers are declining and no one is sure why this is occurring. Large gunsHeading back to the prison we passed a large gun, one of three that were placed on the island during WWII. Of course these guns never fired a shot in anger. PrisonThe bus dropped us off at the prison. We were met by our next Guide. This gentleman was really interesting he was a former political prisoner. The Guide explained that the prison had several blocks. The prisoners of different categories were held in separate blocks. There was a block for the ‘Coloureds’ (mix race) and the Indians. The ‘Blacks’ were held in separate blocks. The ‘Leaders’ like Nelson Mandela were held in a separate.The first block that we entered was where the guide was kept. The ‘cells’ were large. Up to 20 men were held in the cell. The prisoners slept on blankets placed on the floor. There were no beds. This practice ceased under pressure from the Red Cross and it was causing the prisoners to contract TB. The next block was where more ‘dangerous’ prisoners were held. This block has single cells. On the walls of the cells are cards will short stories written by the inmates. They are all harrowing. Guide tells of his Personal Experiences While we were in this block, the Guide fielded questions from the group. This was very interesting. He told us about the controls that the Warders placed over their communications will the outside. The sending and receiving of mail was very restricted and all mail was read and censored. He told us about one particular Warden with whom he become friendly. This Warden took the Guide’s letters and smuggled them off the island and personally sent them to the Guide’s family. He also encouraged the family to send him letters that he passed to the Guide. The Guide told us the “the Warden is still alive and is one of his best friends”. The last part of the tour of the prison was where Nelson Mandela was held. There is a quadrangle next to the block. The Guide explained that in the corner of the quadrangle was one of the spots where Mandela hid the manuscripts for his book ‘The Long March to Freedom’. Where the original fence was being replaced will a stone wall, the manuscript was discovered. Mandela had to re-write that part of the book. Clever use of a Tennis Ball The Guide also told us about the tricky thing that the ‘Leaders’ used to communicate with the other prisoners in the adjoining Block.They used to play tennis in the quadrangle. They cleverly placed written messages inside one of the tennis balls. During the course of the game they would hit the ball over the wall into the next block. The prisoners in the next block would reply to the message and throw that ball back over the wall. Apparently this went on for years. Notwithstanding the Warders saw the ball going over the wall and being returned, they never twigged that it was being used for communication. Mandela’s Cell The final stop on the tour was Nelson Mandela’s cell. I always find it a bit eerie to visit a famous place in history. This is one of those places.

Very moving, don't miss it.. Make sure you make your reservation before you leave on your trip. Also book it early in your time in Cape Town. Our first reservation was canceled due to weather. But with a reservation they gave us another time. Former prisoners were the tour guides and really gave you a rich history.
Cape Town highlight. Tremendous experience, great value and very well conducted tour. From the ferry ride across to the island and the bus tour around the island the whole experience was excellent.

Worth the time and money. This was a great experience! We saw whales, seals, and penguins on the boat ride out, and the portion of the tour led by former political prisoners of Robben Island was powerful and worth the price of admission to her their experiences alone.

The home (or at least prison) of Nelson Manadela. Typical South African timing on this trip, hurry up and wait! Our tour boat was supposed to leave at 1200 and we were still queuing in the sun an hour later waiting to board. However a very nice 45min or so journey across the sea to Robben Island. When we got there we had coach tour of the island followed by a tour of the prisons. All very good and interesting although like I say timing was an issue. Make sure you book half a day out of your diary for this one and don't book anything afterwards in case you don't make it back in time!

A 'Must See' visit but had it's drawbacks. It's a shame I didn't have the option of 'good' for the review as 'average' is a bit mean but I'd struggle to rate it 'very good'. You definitely need to book in advance as it is very busy, and therein lies the problem. The boat trip isn't too much of a squash and there's a breeze from the speed, but once we arrived we were packed so tight onto a bus it was horrible, really squashed and claustrophobic. It was a very hot day, there is no air conditioning and our guide, who was a lovely man, was very talkative. At one point I was next to the window in full sun for a stop of over 15 minutes and it was unbearable. He was also very quietly spoken so I missed much of what he said. The visit round the cells was also very rushed. That said, I would still say that any visitor to CapeTown should go to Robben Island. It's not suitable for small children.
Mandela's prison. Very emotional tour. As the tour guides are all old prisoners. They tell you their story and how it was during the time they were there.

A 'must do' visit. If you are in Cape Town then this has to be a 'must do' visit. The tour gives a fascinating and moving insight into a divining moment of South African and world history. The tour starts with a 45 minute boat trip to the island, on which we were fortunate enough to spot a whale. You then get a guided bus tour around the island, and a guided tour of the prison in the company of a former prison inmate. You get to see the tiny cell in which Nelson Mandela spent 18 years imprisond on the island and the lime quarry in which prisoners did their daily hard labour, many going blind from the sun's glare in the process. A very moving and at times disturbing experience but not one to be missed.

A four point experience. Going to visit Robben Island is a must as a human being. This trip contained four seperate parts all making one great experience.First, a beautiful boatride out to the island. Taking in CT from the water is great.Secondly, a guided bustour of the island and the history of the island, a lot of new knowledge came to me.Third, a guided tour by an ex-inmate at the maximum security prison. Interesting perspective as it was first-hand. Genuine! Nelson Mandelas cell could have any old cell, they all really look the same...Fourth, the boatride back in the afternoon. The sea as woken up and as my 6 year old said, "Dad, this is like a rollercoaster on the water!!!" It was rough but well worth the 45 minutes.Go visit!

Unesco heritage site. This is an important part of South African history, and hence very much worth a visit. You can only see the island as part of a tour, which is more or less well organised. The trip over was rather slow, but this was more than compensated for as we saw a whale. Swimming and blowing through it's spout just in the harbour area in late February. Amazing! The tour starts with a drive around the island on a bus, followed by a tour inside the gaol by an ex prisoner. This was fascinating, although our guide got a little too repetitive and lecturing towards the end. Still, given his experiences you had to give it to him. The trip back was a bit of a mess. We got on one boat, got herded off and had to wait in the full beating sun for 2 more boats. Not sure why the trip back didn't work the same as the trip out, but we made it.

A visit I will never forget as long as I live. I have always had a love of Nelson Mandela and have read just about everything I can about him, so no trip to Cape Town would have been complete without a trip to Robben Island. I was very nearly disappointed and I would stress the need to book in advance. We were visiting between Christmas and New Year which is a popular holiday time in South Africa, we didn't realise you could book online and we very nearly didn't get a ferry as these were all showing as fully booked. In the end we had to contact a tour operator and take a bigger tour which included the Robben Island visit. To be honest the Rand is so weak against the British Pound that it really wasn't that much more to do it this way.The trip over on the boat is spectacular with Table Mountain in the background, dophins and whales swimming in the bay. We even saw a couple of sea lions.Initially I thought this was just going to be another tacky attraction but I am so pleased they haven't ruined the authenticity of the island. It pretty much remains as it always has been and the tourist shop and cafe is well hidden away from the main part of the island. The atmosphere is calm and peaceful which was not something I expected.It is sobering to think that our guide was actually imprisoned for 18 years on the island. He had no bitterness or antagonism towards his captors and you felt his pride in the role he was now fulfilling. I found the whole trip extremely emotional and I will never forget the experience.Advice: Don't take small children. We had the misfortune to be in a tour with a few families with pushchairs, the children pretty much screamed the whole way around and eventually were asked to leave. It is very disrespectful when your guide is trying to give you the history and the stories related to his time and you can't concentrate due to the screams and cries of tiny children. Please have more respect.Overall the time for the tour including the ferry is 4 hours and it is well worth the time. Take lots of sunscreen as it gets very hot in the Summer and there is little shade.

Not to be missed. A visit to Robben Island is a must for anyone visiting Cape Town. The tour around the island on a bus with a guide is included as is the walk inside the prison with an ex prisoner who gives a graphic description of what life was like.The journey out to the island can be pretty choppy so be prepared for the 45 minute boat trip both ways

An informative way to learn about South Africa's recent history. Taking the ferry to Robben Island and then the bus and walking tour round the former prison is a worthwhile educational experience to learn about the country's troubled recent past. Being shown round by a former political prisoner made the visit all the more vivid and meaningful. The ferry trip can be bumpy but well worth it!

Interesting experience. We really enjoyed the tour of Robben Island a lot. It was more neutral than we had gone in expecting, but that was likely dependent on the tour guide.Our tour was at 3PM, and although it says we must arrive a half hour early as the gates closed 10 minutes before departure time, we ended up leaving nearly a half hour later than scheduled due to the number of visitors.Make sure to bring a jacket with you because the boat ride can be very cold! The men who took us over on the boat though were very friendly and kept us entertained. They even started offering to take photos of couples, and we ended up getting some lovely shots from that bumpy and freezing ride over the island =)Upon arriving, there are bathrooms, a small snack shop, and a curios shop before you get on the bus. We were under the assumption that we would be doing a lot of walking around, but instead, you get a tour guide who takes you around on the bus to all the important buildings and sights.Unfortunately, I cannot remember our guide's name, but he was fantastic. Very informative and knowledgeable, but also entertaining; clearly, he's been doing this for a while...! He was a member of the PAC, and through his job as a tour guide, has had the privilege of taking the likes of Barack Obama, Hillary Clinton and even Nelson Mandela himself (when Mandela returned) around the island. With our diverse tour group, he was able to tell us how each our countries was connected to Robben Island, which was very interesting as the information reigned from the the Axis powers military base during WWII to Australia's Eucalyptus trees that have taken over the island. Overall, I appreciated his take and information on the island. The only downside to the bus tour is that we only got off the bus once for just a few minutes for a washroom and snack break. The second part of the tour focused on the political prisoners led by a former prisoner. He showed us around the group cells and isolation cells where Mandela stayed and shared with us his story of how he ended up on Robben Island, as well as the day-to-day life of a political prisoner. It was very interesting to see the conditions in which they had to live and work in.(The only thing that put a slight damper on this whole experience was the parents who didn't watch over their young daughter. She sang and hummed for a good portion of the bus tour until even the tour guide had to shoot her a look, as well as sang and danced around the group cell while everyone else was listening to the guide speak about his experience. The parents did nothing to move her aside or keep her quiet.)Overall, a great tour and highly recommended.

Everyone should experience this. A large group of us attended Robben Island and had a private tour by a man once imprisoned here.Our guides stories were captivating and the level of detail he could offer through personal experience truly makes it even better whilst ever more harrowing. Visiting this facility and experiencing the history is an absolute must. It cannot disappoint and the tour guides absolutely make it even better than you could imagine.

Touching history. It is sobering to think that the man who is your guide in the prison tour was locked up there. Luckily it has not been turned into a Nelson Mandela theme park. Advice: must book in advance, overall time for the tour including the ferry is 4 hours. If you are lucky you may see an occasional penguin or tortoise wandering about when you are on the bus. The bus around Robben Island is not comfortable.
full of history. This is one place everyone needs to visit when visiting Cape Town. It is a wonder how anybody could have survived as the living conditions would have been horrible.

a must see, but dependant on your tour guide to get the best out of it. Has to be a must see because of the time Nelson Mandela spent there and the conditions he endured. Our tour guide was particularly good at ensuring we got the best out of the visit - half is a bus trip, it is better to get a local guide who lives on the island, rather than one who was in prison there; the second half takes you inside the prison and Mandela's cell - much more emotionally charged. The trip over to the island can be quite rocky - preference is to try and get on one of the more modern vessels which are quicker and smoother.

Looong Tour. This is a must do for its historical value and for making tourists aware that political prisoners during the apartheid era were treated worse than those imprisoned for other crimes. However, the boat ride each way takes a long time and too much time is spent on the bus tour around the island and on the walking tour of the prison itself. We would have appreciated a "lite" option that doesn't take up the better part of a day. Asking everyone to arrive 1/2 hour prior to departure is also ridiculous as we just stood in line for that time and did not board until departure time.

Interesting tour. Great to do the tour with an ex inmate as a guide to provide an insight of the history of apartheid and the battle against it, Mandela's cell included. Go on a day with little or no wind as its a 40 minute trip on a boat that will move a great deal on choppy seas which will result if the Cape Doctor is blowing.

Lots of space for improvements. Depending on the sea the tour will start or be cancelled, therefore book your ticket on the day or if you watching the weather forecast the day before.We were booked on the first trip and waited for over three hours to get on a boat, I say on a boat, as the first boat had a problem with the engine and could not get started. The trip to the island was the best part because:On the island it is mass production! People are packed in a bus and driven around the various places. If you are lucky to sit next to the window, you might see out but our windows were so scratched that we could not make a picture through it.One stop at a curios shop and then in the bus again and to the next “Highlight”.The groups attributed to one guide are much too big. If you are next or just behind the guide you’ll experience a lot, but should you be one of the last one in the group, then you can just run and try to keep up; there is no time to feel and see. They will definitely have to improve a few things if they want to keep tourists coming to the Robben Island.I did enjoy a few things but overall I missed a lack of information and communication, the long waiting time without been informed what is happening, the feeling of battery chicken that is certainly efficient for never proactive and a time will come when people will longer be interested. Most important, no one tells anything about that beautiful island with its flora, bird and animal life and history before the jail period.

An Historical Must Do. The boat ride out to the island can be rough so take precautions but it's worth the trip. When you arrive you board a bus for a tour of the island then go inside the prison to see Mandella's cell. Our guide was a former prisoner and added much color to the story.

Can you go without the bus trip?. The boat trip was awesome. But my overseas guests were disappointed by the political indoctrination we received on the bus and by the ex prisoner. Political prisoners are NOT the only history or the island. Leper colony, world war 2 and prisoners etc is the history. More about the ENTIRE history would have been more informative than a political stand point and an ex prisoners libido and sanity was forced upon us for what felt like hours. We have visited other prisons and the conditions today are far worse with overcrowding, sanitation and violence. Please make robben island a more enjoyable trip. I object to paying to hear political indoctrination.

Catch a history lesson. Note, book early and be there on time as the boats leave punctually. I agree a calm day would be most enjoyable. A great way to get a ride on the water as well as see an historic site. More importantly, it is my understanding that currently all of the guides at the prison were once prisoners with Mandela. Now who wouldn't want to meet them? There is very little walking to do once on island so don't worry about that. I don't think young children would be interested in this.

Amazing piece of history!!. Taking the time to learn about the history of South Africa and the imprisonment of Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners was an important part of this vacation. Our tour was given by a political prisoner previously confined to Robben Island, it was humbling!

A 'must do' visit. This was our last visit in a 16 day visit to South Africa. After visiting Soweto and the Apartheid museum at the start of our tour, the trip to Robben island completed our understanding of the journey this country has made in the past three decades. It is not comfortable to confront man's inhumanity to his fellow man, but to meet an ex-prisoner now working as a guide is humbling. The boat trip over was quite an experience, partly because of the sea state, but also the sighting of whales. Overall this rounded off a fantastic visit to South Africa, a country of such stark contrasts.

Eerily thought provoking. What a fantastic trip from the boat across to the guided bus tour to the waking tour with genuine ex political prisoners - I found the whole experience both thought provoking and uplifting culminating in Mandela''s sparse , tiny cell with no bed but home for 18 years - humbling in so many ways

Emotionally and politically not to be missed. Apartheid is one way of expressing that one human being is superior to an other. We easily forget our mistakes and do not learn from history. A visit to Robben Island is a journey back in time, when different colours meant different value. We need to be reminded of this on a daily basis and not take it for granted. There is still much injustice in SA, but a giant step has been taken forwards. The information and guides were fantastic.

Could be so much better. The boat ride out is around 45 minutes and the water can get a bit choppy. My advice is don't sit underneath at the front, it was making me feel a bit queasy, up top was amazing with beautiful views. A little cold coming home around 6:30pm in Feb so take a jumper.The actual tour is in two halves, the first half on a bus looking at the more famous sites. The second half was through the jail was an ex-prisoner giving a talk and acting as the tour guide. We really couldn't understand much of what the guide was saying and there was no printed material so it was hard to really get caught up in the stories of the place. I've been on quite a few tours of places like Sachsenhausen where you really get caught up in the history and stories. Robben island could be so much more and have so much more of an impact if it was done in a better way.

Thought provoking. Very well organised. 45 min boat ride to the island. Tour includes various buildings on the island the mine where the prisoners did not need to break up rock. Second part of tour is by an ex prisoner who was v humble spoke of not being against the white man but against a political system which was not fair.

Wanted more. I wanted to feel things when I went to Robben Island. As much as I am aware of that I would never ever be able to experience something like Robben Island was and meant, this was still a dissapontment. The info you get from your guide is pretty dry and boring and then you're not even aloud to go around on the island or around the prison.

A little mixed. Check the weather the day you choose to go. On a beautiful calm day there was a considerable swell midway between mainland and island...take motion sickness pills! An hour there, 45 mins back, this was quite a long trip. Herded on to tour buses and taken around island, no opportunity to really wander at your own speed. Guides, ex prisoners, very informative and knowledgeable and visit to prison block very sobering. There is so much history, our guide seemed determined to include every aspect quite slowly which did add a certain frustration whilst sitting on a hot, uncomfortable bus, 3 to a seat. But it to be missed and a fascinating experience and I shook the hand of the man who had shaken Mandela's hand......

Not to be missed.. Fantastic boat ride over to Robben Island,where we saw penguins,a whale,dolphins and seals,combined with a fantastic tour. The guide on the bus tour was funny,knowledgeable, and extremely interesting,in fact for me he made the tour.

Robben Island made me understand a lot more about the apartheid and South Africa.. The visit to the prison was thought provoking in so many ways. Listening to the experience of a former inmate and the treatment he received was harrowing.A walk past Nelson Mandelas cell, and then a bus tour of the island with a guide showing various houses and their uses over the years. A stop at the limestone quarry where Nelson Mandela and other political and criminal prisoners toiled under the blazing sun. So glad I did this trip as I am really interested in South Africa's story.

A must go if in Cape Town.. A brilliant history. Not too pricey and told by ex-political prisoners. It was about $25 AUD to catch a ferry to the island and be taken around on a bus tour and then a walking tour through a cell block. Very interesting and sad. We got to see Mandela's cell along with many other influential figures.
A must see for history geeks!. A must see for history geeks! So many important things have happened here. Most interesting: Guides are former political prisoners!

Prison of incarceration for slaves. Robben Island has become synonymous with the name Nelson Mandela,having spent 27 years of his life in prison here. But very little is noted of many other prisoners that have spent their better part of their lives here for the same reason of seeking justice,peace & equality for people.In fact many a prisoner had died on the island & is buried there today.One such man is the foremost pioneer of Islam at the Cape,Tuan Matarah/Sayed Abduragman Motura.A Sultan,well learned muslim teacher,leader and resistance fighter who was turned into a political prisoner in the late 1700.
