He resisted the colonization by the Dutch in Indonesia & was banished to the Cape of Good Hope.Today his shrine on the island is a symbol of the pain and suffering convicts & slaves had to endure at the Cape.The shrine was build by the Apartheid government in the 1960 & reminds any modern day Cape muslim of their identity/heritage that has lasted for 300 years (Islam rejects the claim/does not allow the building over any grave)

Vital glimpse at history . This is very popular, so pre book as early as possible.Boat journey over was about 40 minutes. If you are lucky you will see dolphins, seals (at the V&A) and even penguins swimming alongside you. The boats even on a calm day, which we had, does rock about a bit. When you arrive you go in a big group on a bus tour of the island. If you are well read on the area the info is a bit less than you may need. However it is still of interest. Halfway through you get off at a view point for Cape Town, and what a great one it is. We were lucky and saw a whale, at a distance, that day.The second part of the tour for me was what it was all about. To see where Mandela, and the other political prisoners were held was deeply moving. Tour is taken by a former political prisoner. The merchandise shop at the end was tacky though.In the grand scheme the shop is a small gripe. Robben Island to understand where South Africa has come from and is going is a must see.

Must-do when in CPT. At first I was a bit sceptical when I booked the tour but didn't regret it all afterwards. The tour is extremely interesting. First you get shown around the island in a bus with a guide onboard telling you all interesting facts. Then you go on a tour with a former prisoner who shows you around the camp, cell's and tells you his own experience and about Nelson Mandela.This is a must-do when you are in Capetown.

History, not entertainment. Robben Island offers a great perspective on South Africa and its time during apartheid. The visit, though, is about history. There is not a great deal to see (the prison itself is a sterile, institutional building and the grounds offer little), but the stories are compelling. And there's the challenge some people encounter. The visit includes a bus tour of the island with a guide offering an overview of the various uses over the many years. There is a stop at the infamous limestone quarry where Nelson Mandela and other political and criminal prisoners were put to work and at a refreshment stand (great pictures of Table Mountain and the Cape Town waterfront. The second half of the trip is spent in a large prison cell listening to the experiences of a former Robben Island inmate, a walk to the exercise yard and more stories from the former inmate and, finally, a quick walk past Mandela's cell.The groups often are large so experiences often depend on the ability of the bus guide and former prisoner to be understood, engaging and interesting. We had a great visit. We enjoy history, we are fascinated by South Africa's story and we had very good guides. Other visitors haven't been so fortunate.This is a visit that likely will bore young children and those who aren't keenly interested in history. It is a good investment of time, including a 30 minute ferry ride to and from the island and a 2 hour stay.

This feels like a missed opportunity. It goes without saying that Robben Island holds an important place in South African and world history. Mandela spent 18 of his 27 years in prison on the island, the prison's prisoners were at the forefront of the fight against the abominable apartheid regime. Thus, the island has rightly been designated a UNESCO world heritage site. It should form part of any trip to Cape Town. At the moment, however, the Robben Island experience feels like a missed opportunity. From the woefully outdated and seemingly dangerous ferry transportation, to the rushed and inadequate tour around the island, (which failed to explain the context of apartheid or bring to life the stories of the many prisoners who were kept there.) This tour should be about education, the tour guide did his best, but if you knew little about apartheid before you arrived, you left none-the-wiser. The bus journey around the island felt tagged-on and slightly bizarre. Little information was given about the history of the island, but for example, we were informed about the state of the local school and other stories about residents who currently live there. The bus tour concludes at the limestone quarry pit where Mandela and other ANC leaders were forced to perform back-breaking labour. It was a place where they defied their oppressors and discussed politics and ideas. As visitors to the island we were shown the pit from our bus, we couldn't enter or take pictures, it felt rushed and pointless and it did a disservice to those brave men were imprisoned there. Further to this, the ferry back to Cape Town seemed a little dangerous, many passengers were choked by diesel fumes, and we seemed to speed into choppy and dangerous waves at every opportunity. It was not a comfortable journey (nor was it for my girlfriend who was very green by the end of it.) To be honest I am less worried about the intricacies of the transport or the queuing, but by failing to properly educate, explain and bring to life the horrors that took place on Robben Island those responsible are failing Madiba and those who were imprisoned there.
Tour of Cape Town. Reasonably well conducted tour by ex inmates . Interesting stories but not sure if blowing get up a post office is a good thing to put on your cv for tour guide !

Oh my word - you have to visit if in Cape Town. Book your visit before going to Cape Town, get an early morning slot. It's an incredible place to visit. I am so glad we went, our children (aged 13, 16) found it sobering and fascinating in equal measures, as did my husband and I. You are shown around by an ex political prisoner.

Robben Island, great history lesson but too rushed. Our guide was fantastic. I think his name was Ntando?? He took us through the prison and told lots of very informative stories. The whole tour was great but I felt really rushed. We never had time to get out and actually read some of the signs posted in various places. I would have liked to do more walking instead of bussed around and craning my neck to see out the windows. The girl on the bus (can't remember her name) was also excellent.

Informative and Emotional. Our trip began at the Waterfront Mandela Robbin Island destination center, which is in the middle of a ton of shops, cafes and attractons. It is a safe area during the day with lots of security to help guide you around. They ask you to arrive 45 minutes before your scheduled time, and there isn't anywhere to sit...they line you up on stairs. After walking all morning, we just plopped down on the steps along with everyone else. Finally, we were boarded onto the ferry. I must say, the ferry we had to take us to the island (there are several) was awful. No seating and it was quite packed. A little scary by American standards, as there weren't any flotation devices that we could see and many people felt uncomfortable with no where to sit or really stand except on ropes. The staff were not helpful and a little rude to passengers. It is a rather long ride, at least 45 minutes, but the views are awesome. You might get lucky like us and see the seals playing around, or a great white attack a seal (not pretty, but it is a sight watching nature do its thing) and we even saw several whales, even though they were off season. Dolphins also put on a show. Once you arrive on the island, you then are boarded onto buses. As the driver navigates the island, a former Robbin Island apartheid prisoner will tell you about the history of the island and it is quite emotional listening to his stories. After a brief break to get a cold drink or snack on the waterfront (great pics at that stop), you ride the bus again to finish the island tour. Then they take you to jail. Literally. It is a dingy, bad vibe feeling place. As you look around, you can enter cells and read about their former occupants. So many stories of respectable men, locked up because of their color and desire for equality. It is easy to put yourself there and think about what it must have been like for them. It's hot and horrible. After meeting with another former prisoner and hearing his tales, they take you past Mandela's cell, which you can't enter, but can take a picture. The whole tour from wait time on shore to the return trip takes about 4-5 hours, so eat before, bring a shawl for the boat, but dress cool if you are there in summer. It is damn hot and sticky. Some people felt it was way too long, and I think I agree because people started losing interest late in the day. Thankfully, the return ferry was great, complete with lots of benches and two bars. Just hope for that ferry. Worth the trip and time. And there is a plentiful gift shop at the end of the tour, of course, where you can buy anything Mandela related, including books and videos.

Guests on a tour. Tour guide on bus was okay but needs to be taught people skills when talking to guests. Your tone of voice needs to change. The guy doing the prison tour spoke really bad English and I could Beauly understand what he said. I was the only South African on that tour hence I could make out what was said. My guests kept on asking what did he just say. Really! !!! Guy doing safety on boat OMG needs to be fired asap. That boat will sink and everyone will not know what to do as he cannot explain to safe his own life

An essential to add to your Cape Town Itinerary. A well worth while trip. Booking essential after checking the weather forecast! The ferry crossing can be quite choppy and lasts an hour. The tour of the island is well organised with knowledgable guides on the coach.An ex prison inmate will take you around the prison and give you a wonderful insight into the hardships endured by Nelson Mandella and other politicians fighting for freedom.

Fantastic.. The coach guide was very personable, funny and very informative. There was plenty of time at each stop, no rush breaks built into the schedule. A member of the group was in a wheelchair and some parts of the pathways made it a struggle to get round.

Real insight. In you want to do this trip book a couple of days in advance as it gets very busy. The boat trip takes around 40 minutes, you then go on a bus around the island with a guy on board giving commentary and stops. You then end up at the Maximum Security Prison, and see Nelson Mandela's cell, this part of the tour was given by an ex political prisoner. It was a great trip very information, great value for length of the trip which was around 4 hours. Would recommend.

An essential visit to pay homage.... ...To Dr. Mandela and all of the political prisoners who were sent there. Loved how so many South Africans were on my tour but hated the uncomfortable buses that drive you around the island. They just pack you in. The actual prison is quite striking with its rough green hued stone exterior...very neat and tidy. Horrified at the labour outdoor area and how many of the prisoners experienced health problems from the stone dust. The best part was how they have actual former prisoners as your guides...really adds depth and emotion to the entire experience. Go...it's so worth it.

Marvelous. We were really inspired to get to know more about Nelson Mandela's history and the rich lessons about the Robben Island Prison. It was worth every penny (paid 600 rands for both of us), and the island tour guides were amazing!
nelson mandela - incarceration. An interesting island to visit not just to see where nelson mandela was imprisoned but also the history of the island aswell.

A must visit. What an awesome way to see and learn so much about what so many different people in our country struggled through. It inspired me to want to learn more about Madiba and our country as a whole Definitely going to take my kids there as they will learn too

Important history to experience. This is a must visit while in Cape Town. The boat trip to/from the island offers great views. The tour of the prison guided by former political prisoners is an important part of recent history that must be experienced.

Very Moving. Boat trip over was nice and smooth, straight onto the buses for the tour of the island stopping at relevant points and then being shown round by an ex inmate explaining what life was like on the island.Can not imagine anyone feeling unmoved by this experience.If you take the time to watch and listen this is an excellent experience.

Important place to go to. I took a cruize over to Robben Island from the harbor. I really enjoyed the tour where former prisoners worked as guides. I say that please read any pamflet or book about apartheid before going over - that way you will get more out of the experience. It is strong social experience but visually not as great as I expected. I recommend the tour, and the cruize over to the island was very nice, we saw dolphins. The message is powerful and should be heard.

To prison for two hours!. Very informative and atmospheric visit. Passionately presented by former inmates. "Must do" to get better understanding of the experiences of those struggling to end apartheid. Only drawback: very slow moving wait without shade to get aboard ferry even though already had tickets.

Terrible Experience . It was terrible right from the start - imagine standing for 30 minutes just to go through airport-like security and to get your tickets scanned. The boat ride to the Island was extremely choppy - so beware if you are prone to sea sickness. After we got off the boats with hundreds of other tourists there were no staff to provide any explanation or directions. We followed a group and got on an old bus (without air conditioning) and were stuck being driven around the compound with long stops while a guide shouted commentary and the sun beat down on us. The best part was the walk-through of the prison with an ex-political prisoner as our guide. But that part felt very rushed and restless little kids and rude adults distracted us from the guide. Overall this was a waste of our precious vacation time.

A Once in a Lifetime Experience. As in, once you've been, you won't want to go again. That said, Robben Island is a must do activity in Cape Town due to the historical importance. The boat ride is nice, but long (45 mins each way) and may leave you a little sea sick. The experience on the island is worth the wait. My tour guides were both individuals who spent time imprisoned on Robben Island. The prison itself, as you can imagine, empty and nothing special to look at. Read up on Nelson Mandela and the anti-apartheid revolution if you want this experience to be more meaningful to you. Also, plan to do this activity early in your trip so you have time to reschedule if weather becomes an issue.
SOMBER VISIT. Must see if you go to Cape Town. Sad part of history but have to see it . The island is maintained very well.

Come To Robben Island and be part of our history. From the Robben Island Nature reserve, to whale viewing. The beauty of this former isolated community to one of the hardest prisons on earth. Robben Island got a lot to offer with friendly tour guides. The prison tour is conducted by former political prisoners who are very informative. Walk in the foot steps of the world icon like Nelson Mandela.

Must see. A depressing but mandatory visit. Depending on the tour selected, you may be travelling with @100 other tourists taking the pilgrimage.Check the water conditions with the company. Those subject to seasickness will be challenged during the 45 minute crossing. Large swells are normal but the boats are sturdy and have been performing this service for many years.The island tour covers the many phases of the island since the late 1400s. Not only a prison, it has been a leper colony, ship provisioning point, harbour defensive position, and wildlife refuge (mainly for formerly domestic cats.)Make this activity a priority on your visit.

Scope for improvement. Open top Boat crossing was highlight of visit. Although the guides were interesting and informative about life in the prison, you are couped up in non air conditioned bus for long periods of the trip and had no time to visit the penguin colony.

Great experience - but it is a bit erratic. It is a really great experience to go there and see the whole island (surprisingly large) and see the lime quarry and then the actual prison and Mandela's cell. It is disorganised and you need to get there early because there are 3 boats per trip and the queues are long. The coach trip around the island was good to see but the guide was poor. Rambled on about his family rather than telling us about what was where. We then had a tour round the prison with a former prisoner. Ours was very good but I have heard others are not so good. It takes around 4 to 4 1/2 hours.

Well Worth A Visit. Good to see Cape Town and Table Mountain from the sea on the journeys. Thought provoking and good that ex-political-prisoners acted as our guides. Our trip went about 30 mins early and arrived back 30 mins late so don't cut things too fine. Probably not for young children.

AMAZING. I have no words to describe how I feel about Robben Island. I was taken away by the beauty and amazing stories. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND ROBBEN ISLAND to ANYONE! My 6 year old daughter enjoyed it as well as myself and my husband. I was so impressed by the stories and sights I saw at Robben Island, that I bought Nelson Mandela's book later that day.

A must-see. Our visit would have been incomplete without spending a half day at Robben Island. This was, by far, the most educational part of our experience and helped us to understand the politics of South Africa. Buying tickets beforehand is a must. The jetty actually takes a substantial amount of time but it has beautiful views on the ride to the island and back. The tour itself was a few hours. There's a bus portion where you are driven around the island to see the parts that you are not allowed to walk through and a walking portion where you see Nelson Mandela's cell and a group room. This part is led by an ex- political prisoner, so you get to be told about the experience by someone who lived it. Great views of Cape Town from the island.

Great afternoon .. Enjoyed the boat trip out to the island. Met by buses to transport us around various interesting places , and then to th prison , where we were met by an ex prisoner , who now works as a guide.. He was very keen to keep the afternoon visit on a tranquil keel and cautioned children to keep quiet so we could "feel" the experience. A thorough tour of the prison did indeed give us our experience -especially as he had first hand knowledge of the events that took place there. A very humbling time!

A humbling experience. Having read Long Walk to Freedom this was a must and it did not disappoint. I must admit that I was not aware of the full history of the island and our guide on the coach was very informative and had a great sense of humour.

History Lesson. After an easy ferry crossing we boarded a bus to go around the island. Our guide Yasien Mohamed was a great orator. His stories were so well explained and delivered with substance and style. At the prison itself we were handed over to a former political prisoner who gave us a real insight as to what life was really like on the island. Of course we got to see Mandela`s cell but the great man is not the whole story.A fascinating day out and well worth the money!

Great experience . The guides are ex prisoners and it's really interesting hearing their stories. I don't have much knowledge of South African history or politics so some of it went over my head but what I understood was interesting. The boat ride over was good, choppy on the way back.Good value for money and great views back to Cape Town and of Table mountain.

Excellent guide and visit. We did the whole day which included a township tour and Section 6 Museum.All the guides were local and very informative. Getting an ex- political prisoner to do the tour was brilliant

Absolute must see - but not brilliantly run. When in Cape Town you have to visit the stunning Robben Island. Its an amazing place even without all the history (bit like Rottnest in Perth). The tour is good - but it could be a lot better compared to many 'world' attractions. Depending on which bus & guide you get allocated your experiences will differ greatly. We spent a long time on the island tour, not so much in the prison as the timing was off which was a shame. I wanted to look around more and talk to our guide but at the end we had to run for the boat and missed it which meant we waited on a follow up vessel (which actually was a bonus as we had plenty of space and were able to enjoy the bonkers swell and headwind on the return leg).It is a museum and should be preserved but could do more for visitors (timing needs improving, more chance to look at exhibits and soak up the history, better signage etc). But it is a must see if you have any interest in recent history.

Must-do attraction. Highly interesting tour. Ferry ride, takes about an hour, then bus-ride with a splendid guide to see the different parts of the island and a guided tour of the main prison where the guide is actually a former prisoner. We were able to ask him anything at all which really enhanced the experience, hearing his story and how he feels now was amazing. Top value for the money spent. Buy your tickets in advance and bring pills for seasickness if you're sensitive.

Excellent ..!!. Well worth the visit ! Well organised crossing and coach trip around the island. Our guide (on the coach trip) was brilliant - and funny ! He seemed to know everything about the islands dark history and its famous inmates .....For us the trip highlight was an unexpected guest on the coach who had served a seven year sentence there in the 60/70s. As a political prisoner he was sentenced alongside Mandela to hard labour in the limestone quarry there. His recollections of his time there and the hardships they endured was particularly moving.The guide around the prison itself had also been a prisoner there and again reminded us of the struggle these guys went through .....
A humbling experience. Grim,moving and emotional experience for me as a big fan of Mandela.The sense of reconciliation and forgiveness by ex prisoners was a lesson for us all

A fascinating insight. A "must do". A place to contemplate the past and set a standard for the future. A personal tour by a former inmate gave us all something to consider and added a dimension that can not be valued.

Thank you Madiba. Myrjam Suter from Switzerland invites me on this life changing experience. ...emotional trip a look into the lives minds and experiences of our groundbreakers all whom ever served our nation under leadership and guidance of our beloved late first ever black President. Need to go back ...

An experience not to be missed. An amazing experience but book in advance of trip to avoid queues and the disappointment of missing out. Guides were excellent both in the prison and on the island bus trip - it was a bonus that the bus stopped to enable us to take photos with Table Mountain as the backdrop. The walk through the prison buildings was a bit rushed and at one point I thought I had lost my group!

One of these places you just have to visit once is your life.. A must do visit when visiting Cape Town. The most interesting thing is that your your guides are actually former prisoners. During the whole visit I kept wondering how do they feel about being there again and talking about it. What strikes you is the size of the cells. So tiny. Book in advance as the wind may ground the ship. That's what happened in my case but foryunately i had time to reschedule and made it. Highly recommended.

Very interesting . Visited Robben Island on a visit to Cape Town with the family and found it a very interesting experience. Ferry ride across to the island, bus tour of the various sites and comprehensive narration by an experienced guide who had actually lived on the island for a number of years. Were shown the actual cells where the prisoners were kept and the conditions that prevailed at the time. You can book online if you don't want to queue for a ticket. Well worth the entrance fee.

Interesting . We visited the island on a lovely calm day. The tour is good value for money and if you have no knowledge of the prison it is a great insight.Don't go if it's rough seas if you are susceptible to sea sickness!

like chicken in bus .... Robben island the history of south africa , 45 minute by ferry , you come to the island bus the bus are not really confortable , small windows hard to take picture .. the funny is you cannot go out for take picture . Only the jail with guide you can take picture ... Tour 5 history 10 Recommandation not really
Robben island. This is such a moving trip. Being shown around by an ex prisoner is really special. Seeing things from their perspective. A real must do on your list of things to do.

Thought provoking. A half-day trip we had promised ourselves to make. Very well organised as there are constant ferries ploughing between Cape Town & the island. With hindsight, we should have gone earlier to look around the Nelson Mandela exhibition at the departure quayside

Great historical experience . Went there with my family - wife and two teenagers. The sailing tour across the bay was calm and took approximately 45 minutes. When we came ashore we entered a buss that drove us 5 min where we met up with our guide - a former political prisoner of Robben Island. His description of what had happened on Robben Island was very interesting and captivating. It would have been interesting if they've told more about the differences between ANC and PAC and the prisoners at Robben Island. The entire trip takes between 3,5 and 4 hours.

Very interesting. Really enjoyed the trip to Robben Island, the guide (an ex-prisoner) spoke very passionately and gave real insights into the time spent in the prison and the conditions faced. The tour was long enough to be informative but not too long either. The boat trip over is also an experience in itself with dolphins, seals and some amazing views of Cape Town and Table Mountain.Well worth a visit.

The surreal. After a very nice ferry ride to the island seeing whale, dolphin and seals plus mirad birds you are really hit with history and a painful reality. The way prisoners were treated on this island prison was hard to hear. Our guide was a political prisoner there for a time and gave a dispassionate account the was none the less sad to hear. Seeing Mr. Mandela 's cell was also a sad highlight.

Humbling experience. Great tour. Has to be done. Try and get one of the faster boats over if you can. Take lots of water although there is a bar as part of the visit.The quarry, cell and exercise yards and stories from the inmates are the highlights.

Not enough time. We were very rushed on the tour. There were panels to read in the small refreshment area and panels on the walk back to the bus, but no time to read them. The tour itself was good but felt rushed also.

A life changing experience. Not you average tourist trip! Grim reminder of the past and how people were treated some 30 years ago. A real educational visit, which can be very hot on the coach trip on the Island.
Very historical and educational. Met the author of Book Doing Life with Mandela. Met several former political prisoners who are now tour guides. A must see if your visiting Capetown.

Interesting history. This is accessible only by a 30-45 minute boat ride, so when the weather is iffy, the trip may be cancelled. Also, you might want to buy your tickets in advance either in person or online because the trips fill up quickly. That being said, it was very a worthwhile experience. The boat ride was very pleasant and when we disembarked, we were directed to buses which took us around the island with a very informative guide who pointed out points of interest and filled us in on the history. We then were dropped off at the prison where political prisoners had been held, and our guide there was a former prisoner (now in his 60's or 70's), who gave us a first hand account of his experiences.
Visited on 19th February. Enjoyed the visit to island with my wife. The only downside was that we had to stay on the bus and wasn't allowed to visit any areas except jail.

No need to print your tickets . What happens if you've bought your tickets online in advance, but you don't have access to a printer?We were in this position and received wrong advice by email from the Robben Island ticket office who told us we would have to come early to collect them, and even worse advice from the V&A Waterfront information centre where an assistant told us we would have to go to an internet café to print off the tickets ourselves.It turns out that if you save a screenshot of your ticket barcode on your smartphone, it can simply be scanned as you board the boat. What a shame the Robben Island tours website makes no mention of this useful facility for visitors who don't have printer access.Another tip: Get downstairs to the embarkation area early to give yourself time to read the interesting wall displays charting the struggle against apartheid. It will put your visit in context.Be ready to go through an airport-style metal detector before boarding your boat, and put your backpack through an x-ray machine. Inevitably this seems to catch people out, causing needless delays.We went on the last trip of the day at 3pm and would definitely recommend it for an unhurried experience, with no later groups chasing us through the prison tour. The last boat back from the island is at 6pm, setting you up for dinner on the Waterfront.

A must do Tour!!👮👏. Sooo much history! A real eye opener if you want to learn more about South Africa and the late Nelson Mandela, a bit expensive tickets cost R300 per person but for a once in a lifetime experience it's worth it
Not just history. Take advantage to learn first hand from those who served time here of their experience. Try to imagine what it was like. Where today is humankind being similarly inhumane?

A very clear reminder that good can emerge from bad.. It takes time to do this trip withe boat crossing an hour each way.
The clear impression that we were left with is the reminder that oppression can never be the right course.
The hardships suffered were very visible and whilst not a Wow factor in terms of picturesque sightseeing then it is something that should never be forgotten .

Worth seeing but could have been better. This is a must to see and is very interesting and the staff presentation was excellent. However we were all crammed in to buses with no air con and overall the facilities could have been better. However, who am I to complaint in comparison with the unfortunate inmates.

A sense of history that is still current. A visit to Robben island is one of those Places you have to visit to get an idea of the modern Sth Africa. The guides are usually ex inmates of the island and their stories make the whole experience very real.

Cattle herding on Robben Island. This bad experience already starts before you get on the ferry.The staff do not look like they want to be there at all. So unfriendly all the way from the tickett sales.On the ferry they do some sort of safety briefing which no one can hear.Getting off on the island, the cattle herding experience continues. You are told to get in a bus and they start racing around and telling you about leper colonies etc.You get finally marched past Nelson Mandela`s cell in 5 minutes and then the guide waits for a tip.Sometims the ferry is broken and they use old boats from apartheid times.Stinky and noisy.In all, bad service, unprofessional and not worth it.

Most well known prison in the world. Its an exciting day starting with you boarding the sea princess at the V&A Waterfront, and travelling through the choppy cold waters of the Atlantic.When you arrive, you are put on a bus with very knowledgeable tour guides and you actually tour most of the island. The tour route includes the graveyard of people who died from leprosy, the Lime Quarry and Robert Sobukwe’s house.You are then handed over to former political prisoners, and you get the full insight about the island's history, they actually bring their prison experience to life for you culminating in the viewing of Nelson Mandela’s cell.

A must see. The boat ride to Robbens island was like a mill pond on the way out and very choppy on the way back. The tour starts on a bus which drives you around the island with a very good guide. You then are given a tour of the prison by a former inmate. It's a must do when visiting Cape Town. We also had an added bonus of seeing several whales on the way back.

2 hours of a droning bus based tour, and not enough time in the place that really mattered...... This was my second visit to Robben Island. The last over 10 years ago.We were subjected to a two hour bus tour with a droning guide that loved the sound of his own voice. We were only permitted off the bus for 5 minutes, to take photos of table mountain and use the facilities. Other buses stopped in various places, and allowed passengers depart, take pictures and experience the surroundings. Mr Mohammed had a captive audience, and let's just say, he really made the most of it.On arrival at the place we all really came to see, we were now on a tight timetable that didn't give the opportunity to really get the best from the visit alongside our fantastic guide in the prison.I was saddened that 2hours in a cramped bus with a droning guide ruined what was to be a highlight of my partners first trip to the Western Cape of Africa.Genuine thanks to our guide in the Maximum Security Prison. His humility, strength of character and dignity were in stark contrast to our time on the bus.To our bus guide..... Mr Mohammed, you need to recognize how to read your audience. When they are on the phone because you are boring them..... take notice!

A "must do" experience if staying in Cape Town. An emotional and fascinating place to visit. My partner and I stayed in Cape Town January 2016 for a 10 day holiday. We took a 30 minute boat tour to Robben Island to find out more about the place where Nelson Mandela was incarcerated for 17 years. With the Rand at 25 per 1£ it was a very reasonable price for the ticket and we were lucky to see dolphins and whales along the way.The communication when we arrived on the island was poor and we nervously took a bus that was waiting as we disembarked from the boat. During a 40 minute journey around this tiny island we were treated to a captivating narration from a guide about the history of the island and how countries from around the world had helped to achieve the end of Apartheid. While were there we saw native penguins and beautiful birds with fantastic views of Table Mountain.The most impactful experience was visiting the jail where Nelson Mandela spent 17 years in a very small cell with nothing but a bucket, mat and three blankets to sleep on. The tour guide Sparks was a previous convict and elaborated about the experience of being locked away, only released to work in the Lime quarry for no apparent purpose. This was a very though provoking tour, it helped to explain an incomplete history for me and I feel was an important part of a fabulous holiday experience.

An experience, not to be missed if you are into the history of SA and the fight for freedom from apartheid.. A quick journey by boat to visit the island which housed those who were locked up in the prison for fighting for freedom, including Nelson Mandela. You are shown around the prison by a former prisoner who can tell you what it was really like. On a nature note, there are penguins on the island.

A Must. Going to Robben Island was a must.
It is sad, it is poignant. Seeing the place that held Mandela for so many years and getting just a glimpse of what they went through was very eye opening

a must. those who are interested in the recent history of South Africa must see this " monument".History at its best. You do a guided bus tour which takes you to all important sites, than you walk to the prison, the querry and the prison. Mandela must have been a very special man, how else can one survive such torture without thinking of revange. ..... Madiba preached peace an forgiveness.

Interesting point. It's a place that you should visit but if you dont visit it's ok.the best thing of the visit is that some of the prisoners are guide and you have some good comments during the visit.

A must do when visiting Cape Town. Visiting Robben Island is a humbling experience and step back into a time that was much more recent than it ever should ever have been.The boat over to the island can be a little rocky so be prepared. If you can get on one of the smaller boats do so as these are quicker and a seat upstairs will ensure you cope easier with any sea sickness.When on the island you'll be put on buses on start the tour. You'll then stay in this group for the rest of the tour and this is the only reason I've dropped this to four stars. It is not easy to take any decent photos on the first part as you tour the island as you don't get off the bus so probably best to sit on the left rather than right side. Once you get off the bus you'll take a tour round the cell areas with an ex prisoner guiding you. Amazing earring and seeing some of the stories and conditions these humans were submitted to just because they wanted equality but stay close to him so you can hear what he says. The size of the group again doesn't help and e missed the cell that Mandela was put in as we were at the back (it's the one with the bucket in on the right by the way!!).Overall a great history lesson and one that is all very humbling.
A Day with Mandela. Simple, easy tour lead by a former inmate. If English speaking do suggest avoiding duel translation tours as they do tend to be extremely long.

worthwhile, could be better. I think if you visit the area it's one of the places that you need to visit. I feel that the exhibitions could be much better presented and that lessons could be learned from the apartheid museum in Joburg with regards how to lay out thought provoking multimedia and artifacts.

A tale of 2 guides.... The Robben Island tour is split in 2;Firstly the bus tour around points of interest on the island, secondly the prison where Mandella was housed.Our bus tour guide made things very uncomfortable. As an ex political prisoner I can't begin to imagine what he has been through - but when working and reciting his experiences to tourists he wasn't very good. I felt he was far to emotionally charged, put lots of emphasis on the brutality of events and I felt it wasn't so factual but more opinionated plus he took lots of time explaining everything which made things worse.In the cell block our new guide was superb. Also an ex prisoner - he was very factual, his tone and expression was great, despite reciting horrible times he kept it light and even had a few funny stories which made the whole experience a lot better.I am certainly glad I went on the tour but on the bus I felt terrible, almost guilty.The view of Table Mt on the boat journey back in spectacular.

Important if not enjoyable. This is an important activity and thought-provoking, but it is not fun. It is a long boat ride which can be enjoyable followed by a bus ride around the island which is not. It is inspiring that when converting the prison into a museum, the organizers have made a concerted effort to turn a place of bad memories into a location for warm ones. Weddings are conducted on the island and former prisoners live next door to former prison guards. The tour of the maximum security prison is led by a former prisoner who is grateful for the job since he was unable to get one anywhere else. His speech was truly touching and made the visit worthwhile. At 300 rand (about $18) it is reasonably-priced.
For Nelson Mandela/recent history lovers. Gives perspective on Nelson Mandela's captivity conditions and was narrated to our group by an ex-prisoner of Robben Island.
As must. The trip out and a walk round the island would be worth it, but to have a former inmate share their experience with you as they show you around is a real privilege. Thank you Peter.

Robben Island.... Taking the ferry over to the island was a smooth ride, beautiful weather with wildlife on view. On arrival at the island we were introduced to our guide who had spent time on the island as a prisoner with Nelson Mandela - it was very informative receiving first hand information from somebody who had actually lived it.

Great trip but worst customer care ever. I am pleased I did the trip but we turned up at 12.45 for a 13.00 trip. We stood in the sun waiting to get in the reception building for an hour, got no information and eventually got on a boat at 14.30 (for the 13.00) crossing. I am surprised there wasn't a riot

An emotional visit. Highly recommend this tour. I've been to various old jails around the world and always feel emotional. This was even more so as so many inmates were not criminals.Our tour of the high security unit was taken by a former inmate. We were deeply affected by his stories.Added bonus was the wildlife on the island, a good deal of history learned. A whale, some dolphins and penguins were also spotted.

The courage of man. The tour of the Island was first -rate. We were shown around by one of Nelson Mandela's fellow inmates. It is unbelievable to see how they lived and what they endured. All very well organised.

A prison visit by a former political prisoner !. To visit this prison with a former political prisoner who was there at the same time as Nelson Mandela is exceptional and it is a real testimony. You cannot beat that even at Alcatraz ! The travel by sea also offers a lot of mammals sightings : seals, otaries, humpback whale, penguins as well as a beautiful vew of Table Mountain and Cape Town.

Too long. We took the boat at 11am. The boat getting there was quite fast and we arrived at 11.30am. Once on Robben Island we were put in the bus which seems to be the only way to explore the island. After having driven 200 meters the bus stopped and our guide started much too long and boring explanations. This repeated itself several times. After the bus tour we were dropped of at the prison. In itself it is very impressive to see the prison we however now had a different guide who also took far too much time telling uninteresting stories (some were the same as the previous guide). We finally were able to get the boat back at 2.10pm. The boat was slower and arrived just before 3pm back at the Waterfront. It all just took too long.

Very moving. Read Long Walk to Freedom first.. Everything we expected having read Mandela's biography. Still so emotional. Boat over was the Diaz, an old, old ferry! We had the smarter catamaran back. Saw whales. Tip the two guides! They are excellent. Took 11.00 a.m. out. Be at the sick at 10.30. We were back at 3.30 p.m.
Sombering. There are two histories here the long history of the Island and man and the Mandela story. Both are brought to like during a visit to this fascinating island.

A boat trip to an historic Island. The boat trip was a little longer than expected, and was also running a bit behind, but hey this is Africa! The first guided tour was somewhat difficult to understand, but the 2nd one on the bus was probably the most interesting I've heard. A really worthwhile trip.

Outstanding. We booked the tickets a couple of days before and arrived early and joined the queue. Staff were helpful and got us onboard the larger boat. This could have done with more seats or fewer people. My only gripe of the trip. We had Tom Moses as a guide who was inspirational and told his own story as well as that of others. Tom answered all questions even the difficult personal questions. Mandela was a hero, but we need to remember all the other political prisoners. No photos can do justice to the injustice of the place. A good trip around the rest of the island made for a perfect day. This is a must do, but plan ahead and get on the first tour. Whilst in Cape Town also visit the district 6 museum.

A chance to learn & understand. Starting with a 35 min crossing by boat which was very enjoyable we were met by the first of our two guides who took us to the entrance to the prison where our 2nd guide, a former inmate showed us into the first 'cell' which held up to 50 prisoners. He explained so much about the conditions & the various categories of prisoners & their entitlements according to their status ie colour/creed it was fascinating & gave such an insight into the history of apartheid it made me want to learn more

I'd say that this place makes one to reflect over the values of life and freedom.. There are no enough words to express what emotions and feelings I experienced as I went through the island and the divisions of the former prison. Such beautiful island, it's a shame the purposes it was used for before it became a tourist site.

Somewhat disappointing.. Took the boat form the waterfront to the island .We were loaded onto buses for a tour of the island whilst having a commentary from a previous inmate.Then we were taken to the prison itself for another inmate to tell us more tales of lifr in the cells. Unfortunately the stories went on for some time and seemed to be repeated several times. I and several other visitors felt that the visit could have been shorter whilst still conveying the horrors .

A MUST VISIGT. We booked at the last minute through our concierge at the Westin Hotel and the tour was heaps cheaper than organised tours through our cruise ship the Queen Elizabeth, It cost just £15 each. For that we got a boat trip to the island, a tour by coach around the island with a wonderful tour guide who knew Nelson Mandela and had shown Hillary Clinton and Obama around. The second part of the tour was with an ex prisoner and the highltight of the tour was Nelson Mandela's cell. Clean toilets and an enjoyable sea trip back to the Victoria and AlfredThere are 183 species of birds, so bird lovers will love this..
Essential visit. A real eye- opener, and well worth the effort. A short ferry ride gets you there, the guide was superb. In the prison, and ex inmate takes over the talk. A shame to miss this one!

Next please! Give me the money!!. This is a money making machine and tourists are not allowed to slow the process up. The most disappointing organised tour we have ever been on. When enquiring about the time of the crossing (1.00pm on our pre-booked ticket) we were told our boat would be leaving at 12.30 so entered the queue and waited "motionless" until 1.05pm. More or less herded onto the boat (the crossing there and back was probably the highlight) arrived about half our later marched to buses (see other reviews on quality) and because we had the temerity to read a few of the interesting posters on the wall relating to the imprisonment were left on the last half full bus. We then were told we would have to wait until the next boat came in before we could leave on our "tour" another 30mins. From that moment on all the guides we came into contact with were "clock watching" obviously concerned with getting us through the system. Our ex-prisoner guide must have glanced at his watch about 30 times in a thirty minute tour of the prison. No time to take in the atmosphere....to stand and contemplate.......move on next please!!!!

A well organised and interesting tour. We arrived quite early at the V&A for our 9am trip so we ended up on the slower of two boats. Not that it mattered, it left first but they both got there at the same time.When we arrived, they directed us to our bus. It was well organised and never felt chaotic or crowded. The prison tour was first, then a bus trip around the island.Our ex-prisoner guide was passionate and good humoured. Although his aggressive questioning might be too much for some, I found him amusing. He had an exceptionally strong accent which meant we really had to concentrate. We understood about half of what he said which was enough to get by.Robben Island isn't exactly something I enjoyed, but I wanted to see it and I'm glad I did. I was surprised how small this prison was. It was a somber experience but we found this two part tour interesting and informative.Near the end of the bus tour, there's a shop that sells drinks and snacks. My girlfriend also bought a couple of books for R20 each which she was happy about. There is also a toilet here if needed. And as a bonus; we saw Dolphins, Penguins, Seals and Whales on the boat across. So keep your eyes peeled.Iain, London

One off my bucket list.. I suppose you have to go if you have the chance, very moving and humbling, not an "entertainment" obviously. Plus points would be the trip out on the boat if you like boat trips, the museum back in CT, the African penguins, the chance to stand were the "guests" broke rocks for 20 years.

Essential when in Cape Town. Finally we got to see Robben Island. We felt humbled to walk in the foot steps of such a great icon of the world. The tour was fantastic and the maintenance of this place is very good.We highly recommend that you visit this historic site.

Though but a must seen activity!. We all know the stories and the bad things the apartheid brought to south africa. Being on Robben island takes you back to a time were history has been written although this did no Go down easily. It's though for the mind but an absolute must if you have the chance!
Powerful and moving and informative visit. Well organised and informative . Very moving to have a previous inmate as our guide. Reasonably priced. Enjoyed the ferry ride there and back.

Not too exciting. the boat ride was miserably cold and windy and not enough seats so some people had to stand the entire 45 minutes to and from. Once you are there, they might not have room on the bus that takes to the prison so u'd have to walk. I could not understand the tour guide's English or even hear him.

Very impressive. We booked the robben island tour well in advance and found it a very moving experience. First we had a bus tour around the island with the guide explaining the different houses etc. and afterwards we got a tour from one of the former inmates of Robben Island. He was so informative and it was moving hearing his story and expierience.
What a great experience. The place is kept clean, the tour guides are friendly and well trained. The tour was well planned. It's a must see for everyone who visits Cape Town

Very disappointing. We went on this half day to Robben Island full of hope and expectation for a special and meaningful learning experience.It was not to be.Firstly we were herded into buses and had to endure a tour guide who had an extremely annoying intonation to his voice, and whose wordy approach contained very little solid information. We basically spent an hour on the bus learning nothing. This was a hugely missed opportunity for us tourists to be educated!Then we were met by an ex-prisoner who gave us a prison tour for another hour or so. Myself and most of the other people in the group did not understand a SINGLE word this guy said because of his poor English pronunciation. He might as well have been talking gobbledegook. So that was another wasted opportunity, as I am sure this guys story is very interesting indeed........if only we could have understood him.The whole experience of the trip to Robbin Island for us was a complete waste of time and was frustrating too.We went ignorant, and we left having learnt nothing.

A moving experience. The boat ride over to Robben Island takes about 30-60 mins. After a short walk our group was met by our guide who was a former inmate at the prison. His tour, comments and insights were incredibly moving. After a walk around the prison we boarded a bus for a tour of the rest of the Island. It was really interesting - particularly the limestone quarry. Well worth the trip. Ordering tickets on-line guarantees a place at the time you'd like.

A Disaster of a Tour. . I realize that in Africa they run on a different time clock than in North America, however the trip is very poorly run. We started @ 3 PM and did not return until 7:30pm. Our concierge at the 12 Apostles Hotel told us we would return by 6. The trip moves too quickly over the poster section where you need time to understand what happened on the prison island. The guides are sweet but not understandable as are the prisoners. The ferry that we returned on did not have enough seating on the main deck, a perfect choice to get out of the cold and I ended up on the floor. Certainly learning about Apartheid is a needed story but poorly told and executed. Do lots of prepping before you take this and plan to spend 2-3 hours more than suggested.

Very thought provoking - don't miss. You need to book in advance during peak season but I'm so glad we did as we visited just after new year and it was one of the best things we did in Cape town. Given all the history a must see to really understand a bit more about what went on

A MUST DO. Don't miss this it is the history of South Africa and the progress it has made to get where it is today. It was a humbling experience The tours are done by ex prisoners ours served five years for just demonstrating. It is hard to put into words and hard to imagine that these prisoners would one day be giving tours and its most famous prisoner Mr Nelson Mandela or our father as the prisoner often called him would become president. That this great man served 28 years and was not bitter is in its self astounding. Go as soon as you can this is history of our time and in not too many years it will not be former inmates doing the tours.

Worth the visit but very busy. I've visited Cape Town but this was my first visit her. I'm so very glad I went. The tours are very busy but very well done. The tour guides are amazing and so interesting to talk to. We also saw penguins and even a few whales on the boat trip out.

amazing. Cape Town nr. 1 in the World
South Afrika is nice place to visit.so many differents nice people
Visit zwaziland ,krugerpark, Johanesburg
A must. We knew that we could not leave Sough Africa without visiting Robben Island, with its history of the prison of Mandela.

Herding cattle . What a disappointment ....So much to see and the tour was such a major rush....You could hardly take any time to soak in the history before you were forced to move into the next attraction....We pass so much history in the bus and very little was said.I understand that they have to keep time for the next ferry but it seemed like it was a bit of a tourist trap to me...

Great trip. Everyone has heard of Robben Island and we were keen to see where Nelson Maldela was incarcerated.The ferry ride across the bay is an event in itself. Great views of Cape Town from the water. Took about 35 minutes. The island is very well 'managed ' and we were shown around by a past resident.We were taken around the site at a leisurely rate. It was very hot but we were kept moving and indoors for a good part of the time. Quite a few groups there, quite a few people but the guides paced the tour well and explained everything very well and answered questions. Great views from the island and toilet facilities there.

Fascinating visit. Great trip right from the boat trip to the island to the tour. We had a fabulous guide on the bus and in the prison. A must trip on a visit to Cape Town to understand the history of South Africa

Moving and absolutely worth it. How can you visit South Africa without paying respect to what the people have survived - apartheid. with that, comes a trip of course to Robben Island - where many of the political activists were held prisoner.I found this a very moving experience - particularly meeting a former political prisoner.The tour is conducted on a bus - I would have preferred to walk, my only grumble - and the guide was upbeat, informative and respectful to the history of the island.You have an opportunity to walk through some of the wings - haunting but worth doing.I found this trip insightful and it has absolutely opened my eyes to wanting to discover more about the history of apartheid.

Incredibly moving. Both my husband and I were incredibly moved by the experience of visiting Robben Island. The boat trip to the island is magnificent in itself (we saw whales, dolphins, seals and penguins!) but the tour guides when we arrived really made the experience so fantastic. The guides we had were ex-inmates and their insight into their experiences on the island were as sad as they were hopeful. A really important place to visit.

A most interesting and informative visit. After a short (half an hour) boat trip through the harbour we had a most interesting and informative visit to Robben Island. The tour was conducted by two former political prisoners who told us of the life there and the aftermath of their imprisonment which was life affirming.

Bit too commercial. It was very interesting but I wished the guides did not use a script. I wanted to hear the real story but never did. I personally knew of a family who's Son was at Robben Island but never felt I could ask a real question.

nice and sad. the journey was exciting and the history was very disturbing as to how the prisoners were treated and humiliated. how they overcome the harsh treatment and punishments, isolation and loneliness. as we were coming back you can actual feel the sadness people were quite having conversation with themselves. no one talk to one another for good solid hour
Serious food for thought. A sensory, visceral way to enter the space of modern South African history, as well as a short, pleasant jaunt into the waters off of Cape Town.

Robben Island. We took our 3 kids 11, 9 and 6 out for this trip. What a day, it was a real eye opener to see the place where so much pain was endured, but also where so much strength was gained. We were guided by a former political prisoner, who told some stories of the atrocities committed on them by guards etc. I thought it was a great day, my kids really enjoyed it, and had a million questions for the guide who shared the boat trip back across to Cape Town with us and was more than happy to chat with the kids. This is a trip you must do if you are visiting the Cape.

Slightly disappointing. I don't know if I should have done my homework a bit better or that there is a lack of information at Robben Island about the South African apartheid regime. It would have been interesting to also hear a bit about who the political opponents of Mandela and the other prisoners were, to have a better understanding what exactly happened in the period they locked people up on Robben Island. On the way back on the boat I had the feeling more people shared my thoughts.Nevertheless the tour was really interesting. The absolute selling point of the tour is that it's done by former prisoners who clearly were emotional telling about what happened when they were locked up there. It makes one feel extremely sad to hear the stories and understand that a black persons' life didn't matter so much for some people.

A must see pilgrimage. Worth a visit although there is not a lot to see. The most interesting part is meeting and being guided by former political inmates who were incarcerated here during the apartheid era.

A Special Day. The journey across by ferry to the Island showed just how isolated it was. But the stories we were told could break your heart. We had 2 different guides who had both been Political prisoners. who made the account of life there seem so real. Sad how they were treated by an unsympathetic regime.

It's all a bit sanitised..... For anyone who is interested in S.African politics, apartheid or has read "Long Walk to Freedom" by Nelson Mandela this is surely a place not to avoid. The tours are frequent providing the weather is suitable for the 35-minute ferry crossing from the V and A Centre and the commentaries are provided by ex-inmates. It can be an emotional experience although it would be very interesting to hear some commentary by members of the security forces who acted as guards. In some ways the environment has been sanitised and difficult to imagine just how inmates were treated, although I doubt very much that many photographs taken during the years of incarceration and of how prisoners were treated have survived.A visit is recommended if only to satify one's curiosity.

Long lines but worth the experience. Even if you booked in advance, the lines are still long so plan for adequate time. Other travelers complained that they could not wander around the island. You cannot do that and have to get into the bus as soon as you reach the island and benefit from the narrative experience. The island itself has no "attraction" to see but is a stark reminder of political history told by living ex-political prisoners. Future generations may no longer have access to current living ex prisoners to share their story. The bus stops half-way around to give visitors a chance for bathroom break, snack or simply enjoy the view of Cape Town city from the island.

Moving and Reflective. The ride over to Robben Island helps you feel the solitude of the place. The tour was fair, but the walk through the prison was amazing. In each cell is a photo of a person incarcerated there, with a reflection from them about their time there. The tour is led by former inmates which makes it all the more moving. ASK questions of your guide. Ours was not shy at all about talking about the most intimate details when asked.

Great tours and you get to meet ex prisoners!. This was a very educational visit to Robben Island, i learnt a lot of things i didn't even know.You get a ferry across to the island and once you arrive you get greeted by a tour guide on a bus- the guide we had was great! You drive around the whole island and learn about each part of the area and once you get to the prison- you get greeted by an ex prisoner from there who was in prison with Nelson Mandela himself! Which was great!The island itself- have people who live around the island still.Unfortunately you can only buy tickets online- they have 4 tours each day. 9am,11am, 1pm and 3pm.Highly recommended :)

Make this a priority when in CT. A ferry ride, a powerful history lesson, adorable penguins--what's not to love and appreciate about this place? I was surprised to discover that there's more than a prison on the island. Be sure to listen to your guide on the bus tell all the stories, and especially listen to your guide at the prison. My guide was a former inmate there. Please show respect!

It is a must. Robben Island is a must this is where Nelson Mandella spent 18 years in a small cell not fit for a dog. We where taken around by a political prisenor who give us the background what went

Very moving. Boat trip out in thick fog. Island very bleak. Taken around island on a bus with fantastic guide pointing out all the historical spots. No longer allowed to walk around the iconic quarry. Then taken to prison blocks where Mandela and others were held. The guides here are all ex political prisoners. Ours was very moving and very frank. Amazing experience

Just had to visit. A trip to CT isn't complete without a trip over to Robben Island- pleasant boat ride through the harbour & Bay and the you see the island looming.Everyone who works on the island, lives on the island, including one if the original political prisoners Tom Moses.Fascinating insight into his life of incarceration & now he wants to tell his story to the world

Unique experience . This visit exceeded my expcatations. It was more than a prison it was orginally an island to isolate lepers. Then a garison. It's also a bird and albacore sanctuary. The most interesting part of the tour was the portion led by a former political prisoner. His description of the process leading to the sentence. The story of isolation confinement and the phycological toll was very credible. It's an oral history that will be lost as that generation slowly passes away.

A sobering but necessary trip.. I don't think you can visit Cape Town without a visit to Robben Island to pay tribute to the late, great Nelson Mandela. Our tour guide on the island was a contemporary of President Mandela and was imprisoned at the same time. His tour was emotional and heartfelt. We learned so much. I encourage anyone that knows the recent history of South Africa to visit this symbol of Apartheid and the victory of nonviolence and reconciliation in South Africa.
Insightful. The guides appear to be all ex-prisoners. Very knowledgeable. Extremely interesting. Taken around the island on a bus, so you see more than the prison itself. A must see "attraction".

It can be a variable experience. I first went to the island about 20 years ago; clearly it was less busy then and I was moved by the experience. Visiting again made me realise that your response depends both on the guides that you get and the questions that they are asked about their time spent here. We pre-booked our tickets from the UK - which is a good idea to avoid the first queue. The boat trip across was good - you get great views around the bay. When you get to the island, the tour includes a bus journey around. Whilst it seemed that we were on the bus a long time (not so great if you've got kids) the guide was really knowledgeable and also had a very dry sense of humour which I enjoyed.
Horrible. Not good for kids, I think families with kids must be separated from normal ones, the walking and people without kids want to concentrate.I would never go back there with kids.

A Great Experience- Just not what I was expecting. Robben Island is a great piece of history. It was amazing to see just how recently the history really was. The boat ride out to the Island was fine but then you are immediately shuttled onto buses where many seats don't have a view outside. There are all of these really interesting places to see along the way but you just drive by them. Once you get off of the bus, you head into the actual prison area where Nelson Mandela was held. One of the previous inmates tells his story, talks about the treatment of prisoners and shows you around the complex. It is very interesting, informative, and gives you a lot of perspective of what happened just a few decades ago. Once that was over, they released you to go back to the boats. They didn't really encourage you to walk around the Island, I felt like I was being shuffled from place to place from boat to bus, to tour, back to boat. There is a small gift shop which was very nice but I would have liked to have spent more time on the island. Overall it was a great experience but I would have liked to spend more time out of a bus.

Very good tour. Good historic tour based on Nelson Mandela's time as a political prisoner. Tour guide was also a political prisoner . Somewhat difficult to understand but still worthwhile. About 45 minute boat ride each way.

A must do. Anyone visiting Cape Town should take the chance to make a visit to Robben Island. Booking in advance is certainly advisable - it was necessary for us to book 4 days in advance. It takes about 40 minutes to get there by boat and on the way we saw several dolphins and many fur seals. Sun screen is a very good idea. The guide at the prison / museum is usually an ex-prisoner and it is interesting to hear their stories. The tour of the island is by coach, stopping at several different locations, which if like us you will see whales, seals and penguins. The only down side is that on your tour of the both the prison and island you will be part of a group of approximately 50, which makes it difficult to see and hear at times. Nevertheless, a well worthwhile visit.

Powerful. The visit to Robben Island was very interesting and informative, though I understand that it depends on the guide you have. The ferry trip was beautiful - lovely views of the city as you leave and we saw whales both ways. Depending on the ship it can take 30-50 minutes. It is quite a contrast when you arrive on the Island that is the symbol of apartheid. The visit is interesting in that it tells you about the whole history of the island and not just about Mandela. Highly recommended.

"...the triumph of freedom and humanity dignity over oppression and humiliation.". Symbol of freedom and hope. When you'll be there you won't realize how a human being could resist being privated of basics needs as Mandela and many other political prisioners had to pass trough.Great life lesson.You must take a ferry for 1/1:30 hour from the Waterfront to get to the island, then you take a bus and make a sightseen around the Island and its history and finish on prision's gate to begin the tour from the inside.

Interesting to see, but quite depressing. You can buy tickets online, which saved us a queue at the ferry departure point. The trip by boat to the island is very enjoyable, there is a great view over the city and if you are lucky, you can spot seals in the water! The first part of the tour is a bus trip on the island, with a stop at a special built place where you can take nice pictures. The second part is the prison tour, managed by a former prisoner. The prison tour is quite short, but the details given by the guide are very emotional. what I did not like is the fact that the guide kept telling some members of our group to mind their children, who were only whispering from time to time, being kids

Disappointing. The boats that take you to Robben Island are dated and we found some to be unsafe. When we arrived on masse to the island, we were herded onto to very uncomfortable,non air conditioned former city buses. It was so hot on these buses, one elderly passenger starting to hyperventilate. Fortunately, a doctor and nurse was on board to assist her. We were taken on a short drive around the area then stopped for 15 minutes at a shop/canteen. We were then dropped off at the prison and a former guard took us for a tour. Unfortunately, his English was not good and the tour was too long in the heat and far too many people in the tour. I would not recommend this tour until the organization is better. Many tour companies do not use this excursion any longer and one has to privately arrange it. The tour group we were on would not organize or recommend it. It is a shame as so much history is on this island.

You just have to go! The journey into the bay is worth the ticket price!. Get to the dock early and get your ticket. You have to go! Just getting to see Cape Town from the water is magical! On the ride both ways I saw whales breaching up close! So watch for them! You get on a bus once you get to the island. You could not walk it all. They take you to the tiny hut to buy a drink or a snack and if you did not come prepared this will be handy.A large sign stating Freedom Cannot be Manacled is stating the theme. So much history as you tour the prison and see the conditions and hear the stories. This is perfect for families and your kids will not be bored.It is a place of respect now...it is also the place where seagulls come to mate and raise their young. It is VERY worth the trip!

Fascinating. The ferry to Robben Island tales 30 minutes. You arrive and take a bus tour around the island which is mildly interesteing then stop for a break at a gift shop/snack bar. Then you are taken the prison block where Mandela was held imprisoned. The tour is conducted by a former political prisoner and is excellent.And there is at least one colony of penguins on the island.You've got to go. On the weekend be sure to book in advance.

Very moving tour. We took the last tour of the day leaving the V and A Waterfront at 3pm. The boat trip was rather rough due to the currents, despite the fine weather. Tour of the island good but only a brief stop to buy a drink/ice cream ( no restaurant). Mostly this was in a bus without air conditioning with an informative guide. The last stop was at the prison itself with a moving explanation of the history and first hand experience from a firmer political prisoner. The only downside was that there was not enough free time to wander round and take in the deeply thought provoking nature of the surroundings.

A must do. Trip over by boat takes 50 mins by bigger boat and half by fast newer boat so holding back in the queue each way pays off.Tour there is around an hour, going through prison with an actual prisoner who was there and it's great to ask questions about his experiences.Very thought provoking and educational.You are then taken around the island by bus and guide tells you who else lived there etc.Refreshments available so you don't need anything.You must go.
historic place. just had to take this trip, to see the cell Mandela spent so many year in, he must have been amazing to get through the ordeal. plus side great views of Cape Town.

Meaningful historical attraction, but needs improvement. The historical importance of Robben island makes the visit worth it, but the entire experience needs improvement. I appreciate that previous prisoners served as tour guides! But there needs to be more structure to the tour (so the different groups don't keep running into each other in the tight hallways), some audio/speaker assistance so the big group can hear the tour guide better, and more historical information can be incorporated into the overall experience. I didn't think I learned much from the tour, other than what I already knew... that Mandela was a prisoner there, did hard labor, kept isolated with other leaders... and that might be it.

An amazing slap in the face of history.. The boat will leave the port in cape town, Nice to watch the waves and big cruise and cargo shipd come in. But then you get to the island. If you can try to put your place in the prisoners place, you will feel the heavy of here. Do it

Interesting historic area but don't expect Alcatraz. If you haven't seen Alcatraz you will probably be quite impressed however I have seen it and it left me a little underwhelmed. The guide on the bus ( I think his name was Tambo) was fantastic, very well read and knowledgable. Definitely good thing to do in order to understand the struggles of South African black activists for equal rights...

Very sobering but disappointing overall . The boat trip over was very crowded and basic on an old tub. Little shelter from the elements - lucky to go on a sunny day. Old hot and dirty buses take you around but you are closely shepherded and see most of it from the bus. Very limited tour on the bus. Saved by the walking tour around the main buildings including NM's cell. The guide - and ex-prisoner was amazing and brought it to life. Long wait for the return boat

Historic place ruined. What a dissapointment...From the moment you step into the queue for the boat its a matter of following and rushing through the prison. The bus ride is fairly boring and the guide tells you a story like a dialtone. The prison itself is quite big but you cant really see anything cause you are rushed through. The worst part was where everybody had to line up to take a photo of Mandela's cell.The fact that an old prison inmate does the tour is unique. However its a bit unpersonal as he only tells you about Mandela. I think weve been in the prison for about 30 mins before we had to rush back to the boat.Its a shame how a beautifull and historic place like Robben Island is ruined by such a bad tour.

Robben Island tourist company has botched a great opportunity. We visited Robben island with our reluctant older teens and early 20's children who we were very keen to educate on the history of apartheid and why and how Nelson Mandela and others spent years imprisoned here. At the end of it they said (and we agreed) that it was a monumental bore, and a missed opportunity to educate people properly. We were driven around on a 33 degree day on a bus used for prisoners back in the day, with no airconditioning, and seats that you couldn't see over unless you were by the window. With 5 seats across (with very high backs) most people couldn't see a thing. There was one stop on the long tour at a nondescript place to buy drinks etc (with many things - all icecreams for instance - sold out). Our guide could have been good but had such a thick Xhosa accent (and I grew up in South Africa and could barely understand her) that all the international visitors could not follow. We had to ask her at the rest stop to please give more of a background on apartheid and who the people were that she was referring to, as she just spewed out names without any context or explanation as to who they were for those that wouldn't have known. Could not wait to get off the bus and actually walk around a bit.The cell block was the only part that was really good, with a brief tour of the cells and exercise yard by an ex prisoner who was very informative and a great guide. It was only then that I saw my kids, and all others on the tour, become engaged and get anything out of it.We then just missed a ferry pulling out to go back, and had to wait in the boiling sun for another one for 45 minutes. No shade, no seating at all for the approximately 150 people waiting, and no indication of when the next boat would appear. We have done the Alcatraz tour in San Francisco - with headphones for everyone with any language you like, the sounds and anecdotes from prisoners, etc etc. While I didn't expect Robben island to be at the same level, the management of this tourist attraction really need to lift their game and make this tour far more engaging and informative so that visitors leave knowing so much more than when they came - because we certainly didn't. And my kids hated it.
Lived the history. I have read the book about Nelson Mandela Long Walk to Freedom. When i visited this place i got the feeling of how he was isolated in this Island and life he lived there.

Humbling . It's takes about 30 minutes to get here by boat and it's a real roller coaster journey. The tour of the prison is undertaken by a former inmate and is superb. It's an odd thing to visit Nelson Mandela's cell, where he spent so many years, 18 I think, of the 27 he was captive. It makes you appreciate how extraordinary he was to come out seeking peace and not revenge. Unmissable.

Interesting and educational. Very well organised tour of the island and the prison. The trip over is by ferry, on the day we were there they were running a fast ferry and a regular ferry. Note that the fast ferry overtakes to regular ferry even when it leaves later. From the ferry everyone is herded onto a bus where you get you first tour guide for a tour of the island, short stop for food/toilets and then taken to the Jail. They fill the buses up completely so groups/families would need to be early'ish on the bus to be sitting together. (Each bus load of people are taken to the jail at different times to space out the tours). At the jail say goodbye to the tour guide and bus driver and meet your next tour guide. The tour guides for the jail are former political prisoners and at the end of the prison tour he told us his personal story.
