After this you walk a short walk down the hill to the wharf to the gift shop and ferry. Time: We were in the queue for the ferry about 8.45am and back by 1pm. For us this trip was very worthwhile and assisted in our understanding this part of the history of South Africa.

What a way to start the NewYear. We visited January 1st. first boat out at 9am. Had a very long wait to board the ferry. The boat was jam packed a good tip is to sit as far back as possible on lower level as to be able to stand out on the back of the boat. It was a humbling first half of tour on a bus with a great guide. Then second half walk through prison with a past inmate. Can be very warm/hot. Not for everyone. Have to be very patient. but worth it.

A great day out. A most interesting and well worth tour. Our guide was one of the prisoners on the island and when released he decided to stay and live on there, and show visitors where he held for over 20 years. What a guy!!!!

Inspiring but difficult to visit. The history and experience of being on Robben Island is unforgettable. While i recommend the visit, I found the presentation and guided tour to be a big disappointment. You get off a 30 minute ferry ride and are immediately forced onto the most cramp, uncomfortable tour busses i have ever been subjected to. You get a miserable bus tour of the island with one potty stop in the middle. Two hours into the excursion you finally reach the prison. Our guided tour was cut short so we could make it back to the ferry in time. We had no time to explore.

The 'poor me' attitude won't help move South Africa forward. Robben Island was actually an excellent example as to how all prisons should be run throughout the world: Inmates used to work hard through the day with physical labour which was a punishment but which resulted in very fit prisoners. Additionally, there was scope for prisoners to attend night study and complete degrees. In all it is clear the Apartheid Government did more for its prisoner's personal development than the ANC can do for its free people. The tour itself has turned into a money spinner with the sincerity and good stories of the early tour days now gone it seems. Mandela's cell layout constantly changes too, which you can read into that as you may.
Not to be missed. A trip which brings home the horrors of apartheid. Taken round by a former political prisoner who spent years there ( as they all seemto have done)

An Experience. This was my second trip to Robben Island. If you are visiting Cape Town, this has to be on your list.The island has a lengthy history dating back to the 16th century, but its the 20th century history and Nelson Mandela, that this place is now known for. When you se the celll where he spent 16 years of his life, it gives you an appreciation of the penalty he paid for his beliefs.

moved by experience. Robin island is full of history. The guides were excellent.The prison guide had been a prisoner and was so goodness the tour.i think this must be difficult to re-live the experience.

It makes you feel very humble. 50 minute ferry crossing to a bleak island that really must have seemed the end of the world for the inmates. A former prisoner takes you around the prison to give you fits hand experience of the conditions they lived and worked in. The island was a prison since the 16th century so more history is attached to it than just Nelson Mandela's time there. Only criticism would be that the walls inside the cells and corridors should never have been painted to retain its authenticity. You should go though as it's a must do

Must do when in Cape Town. Very impressing tour by one of the former prisoners. Plenty of opportunities to ask questions and very inspiring due to the personal story of our guide. You might even be able to spot some dolphins on the ferry!
Island History. We were very Blessed to visit Robben Island. Apart from the obvious incredible history, the natural beauty and wildlife on the island is breathtakingly beautiful. Not to be missed.

Cloud, Crisp Breeze on Robben Island. Monday 24th Jan 2016, online tickets and arrival to the dock by 835am, placed us on the second boat for departure. It was a grey day and the ocean had a pleasant roll, to which passengers voiced their approval. We didn't take a chance and had pre gravelled, just in case.Thirty plus minutes later we waited and jocked to berth a number of times, disembarking to direction and bus #3. Our knowledgeable tour guide in sync with driver stopped at various locations, cemeteries for prisoners and leapers, island batteries and the rock quarries. He extolled in reverence the painful history. The belief that one man can make a difference and forgive his captures. A former prisoner, now guide showed the cell block of Mandela's 18 yr detention. His words showed grace and we felt his personal recovery from hate. He lives in peace along side a former guard to tell his storey to tourists from far off places. It is quite and empty now, awaiting the attention of another group of visitors.

POOR PRESENTATION & ORGANISATION & BADLY OVERCROWDED. This was a disappointing experience. The Robben Island management could learn a lot from Alcatraz.The coach tour guide was informative but the tour was rushed and there was only one opportunity to get off the coach, which meant that visitors saw little of the built fabric or life on the island.The visit to the prison gave little insight into life for the prisoners. The group was too large and on several occasions conflicted with other groups. Some groups travel in the same direction as other groups whilst others are moving in the opposite direction. The acoustics are very poor in some areas and because of the size of our group it was impossible to hear the guide clearly. No provision was made for non English speaking visitors which must have a long term detrimental effect on international tourism.The displays are second rate and already suffering from the impact of the climate. A few basic display boards with no time to read them does not make a visit an informative experience.Robben Island needs to step up its game. Free movement of visitors and the provision of individual audio guides, in languages other than English, would dramatically improve the experience. Professionally produced displays, including audio visual presentations, as at many world class visitor venues, would make a visit to Robben Island worthwhile. As it stands I cannot recommend making the journey unless you just want to say that you have been there.

Tour guided by former political prisoner. Very informative tour given by former political prisoner inmate. We went across on the ferry Susan Kruger which is the same vessel that was used to transport the prisoners. It is about a 50 minute trip each way on the ferry and the whole thing will take about 3 hours 30 minutes.

So happy we were able to see this historic place.. We felt very honored to visit Robben Island and take the tour of the prison guided by a charming former political prisoner. Very sobering sights and information about the treatment of the prisoners, the work they did, and the food they ate for so many years. Nelson Mandela's cell has been lovingly restored and presented. The swells were 10-15 feet high on our way back to the harbor on the ferry, so wear a patch or take your dramamine!

Opens ones mind. Amazing walk through mans inhumanity to man. Challenging and confronting in multiple levels. So worthwhile. Forgiveness the legacy of Mandela. Astounded that some see it as a selfie opp sitting on Roberts bed etc.

Don't Miss This. It's Just Extraordinary.. The boat to the Island departs from a jetty alongside the Nelson Mandela Museum, and it takes 40 minutes to get across to the Island - north west of Cape Town.Once on the Island you are confronted with large images depicting life as it was lived by inmates. Then you are directed to a fleet of tour coaches that take you around the sites and buildings. My wife and I were gobsmacked by the fact that our coach tour guide was an ex-political prisoner and, boy oh boy, was he an excellent orator - first-hand knowledge combined with a remarkable passionate story: captivating does't seem like the right word to describe the experience, but that's what it was.Then, when we got to the part where he described the life of the political prisoners, including Mandela and other senior members of the ANC that formed the first post-apartheid government, working in the limestone quarry, well, the emotion lifted to a significantly higher level. What a story he told.It all notched up a few more gears when we visited the prison block and yard where Mandela was incarcerated. Our guide here was also an ex-political prisoner (14 years in prison and 7 years as a guide) and he told great stories, but in a totally different style to our first guide.The whole trip lasted nearly 5 hours, and we couldn't have spent that time any better.My only comment on the experience is that I think Mandela's legacy is gradually being squandered (but that is absolutely a personal opinion).

Outstanding your life will be poorer for not doing this trip . The boat ride out to this venue is excellent. We came back at around 5/6pm and the boat was followed by dolphins and they were frolicking in the water near the boat. Very beautiful just getting to and from. It's a long excursion. Very worth it though. But it is a long day. The island is utterly spectacular. The history that mounded SA that started from that island is just incredible. Your life will be poorer for not going on this trip.

A must to visit. Having read about the time Mandela spent on the Island, it was a great shock to see what he and the other prisoners were subjected to. To be guided through the cells by a previous inmate, made the visit even more memorable. Well worth the 40 minute boat ride to get there.

Must Go. The boat journey is very scenic with a great view of the mountain as usual. The tour of the prison is interesting but only because of the tour guide. It will be interesting to see how the the museum will manage in the long term.The museum does balance the conflicting factors of respect, interest, education, etc. well.

Moving and educational. This is a must do trip if on cape town. Ex political prisoners are tour guide so you can get any questions you may have answered first hand. The penguins are a lovely extra touch. The boat trip can be a bit choppy and it takes a while to get in due to security concerns. The tour was fascinating, the guide was great and the price was good for what was a half day entertainment.

Very moving and very interesting. Just wanted to add to those who have said how worthwhile the trip to Robben Island is. Not only the 'centrepiece' of the prison tour, but also the bus trip around the island, which gives a whole other dimension of the island's history, but also the other groups who were isolated here - the native chiefs, the lepers and even the homeless. Enjoyed the photo opportunities back across the bay, and just the little things like seeing a tortoise cross the road to a bus stop!However, would advise parents to think twice about bringing small children with them, as the bus can be hot and the ex-prisoner's talk is quite long - and at times, explicit - for children. Realise that there is often no option if you want to come as an adult though.

A must whilst in Cape Town.. We hadn't booked booked before arriving in Cape Town, and when we tried, we were told that it was all fully booked until after we were due to leave. However, we decided to head down to where the ferries depart by V&A Waterfront and try our luck, and as luck would have it we found a couple trying to sell 3 spare tickets they had, there were 3 of us, it was fate.We got on the ferry and away we went, it's an enjoyable ferry ride with some stunning views of Cape Town and Table Mountain.On arrival on the island, you get onto some old busses and you do a guided tour of the island, our tour guide was knowledgable and funny, he really engaged all us passengers. You stop half way on this leg of the tour at a shop with toilets, stunning views of Cape Town and Table Mountain and loads of penguins hanging out. Then you complete the bus tour.After the bus tour, you go on a walking tour of the prison itself, and all the guides are ex political prisoners, who did their time on Robben Island. So you get a very informative (straight from the horses mouth so to speak) and passionate tour.Before heading back afterwards on the ferries, there's time to visit the souvenir shop and buy some souvenirs.I would say this less than half day tour is a must if you're in Cape Town.

Very Educational. Robben Island is one of the landmarks of Cape Town and a huge part of our history. The tour guides are very knowledgeable and have been at the front of the struggle. The island is kept clean and they have tried to reserve most places as they are. Worth visiting

Nelson's home for quite a few years.. Your guide is either an ex-inmate or ex-guard. Each individually sharing their very own experience, so each group have a slightly different experience. Amazing, but closed if the wind is strong.

New Year 15_16. Long queues at ferry point at Waterfont, recommend buying tickets in advance. Ferry crossing OK with a few seals sighted. However, transfer to tour coaches manhandled into buses which have steep steps and little legroom! Short trip to prison where the guide (=ex prisoner) very informative, open to questions and friendly. Another trip on bus to short visit to a shop and then back to ferry point. Here there is a shop and bar.

A sober and thought provoking experience. Leaving the V & A dock for a short 20 minute boat ride to Robben Island on a bright sunny morning is the perfect start to any experience.It only gets better boarding the bus on arrival and being introduced to the 1st tour guide who explains the history of the Island pre-prison days thought to existing times, during a brief tour of the Island. Won't go into details but very informative.Then enter to the prison to be met by 2nd tour guide ( An Ex Prisoner) who goes on to explain how the prison worked.My wife and I were accompanied by our 12 year old daughter and we were concerned she may not have found it interesting , how wrong can you be.A GREAT tour, had read a fair amount before going but you can't beat the inside information available from the guides.Would go again.
Very Informative tour. A very interesting tour of the former prison and the Island. The Guides are former political prisoners so you get a true insight into the treatment they received.

A must do in Cape Town. We really enjoyed our trip to Robben Island. It was so informative and our tour guide was imprisoned there so he had some amazing stories to share with us. He had met with Nelson Mandela and could speak of the time he shared with him and of the hardships that they faced while impassioned.

A Must-See. Don't even think about not visiting Robben Island if you're planning to go to Cape Town. It's filled with incredible history that will help you understand our country so much better. The ferry across to the island is an amazing experience not be missed! Go - you won't be sorry!

Sadly a waste of time!. I had been 10 years ago for a tour and went again on a visit to Cape Town. 10 years ago the tour was amazing with an incredibly interesting guide who was filled with interesting stories and information. Sadly this time the tours seem to have gone hugely downhill with a guide that was intimidating and felt that he was preaching to everyone about how we should sell the country back home and get more tourists sharing very little information about the history and his experience of Robben Island. He was also very hard to understand and hear. The trip was poorly organised and the boat back a total joke - the crew seemed to think it was a party boat despite them being the only ones singing and dancing to some seriously terrible music! We left feeling like we had totally wasted half a day which was sad when compared to previous tour! It seems a real gamble depending on your tour guide!

Well Worth the Ferry Ride. Go on this tour.. not only do you meet a former political prisoner who explains what it was like to be on the island; we also had a very good, informative and emotive bus guide.. her story of the quarry cairn brought a tear to my eye (honestly).View the cairn, not Mr Mandela's cell - the cairn means more!

Puts things in perspective. I would say this is a must visit when in South Africa - does give you a good insight into the trials & tribulations of Nelson Mandela and other black South Africans and their struggle against apartheid .A very emotional experience . A comfortable boat ride from the docks of Cape Town .

Visit to Roben Island. Book in advance on internet to save long queues.
When you are on the boat, look for whales!
On the Island, the tour is organized and commented by
previous prisoners.

Well worth a visit but book in advance!. Our hotel arranged the tour for us in advance of our stay.We took the 9am tour and found it well worth the time & 300 rand each. The 40 minute boat ride offered great views of the City and Table Mountain and the 45 minute bus ride around the Island was relaxed and informative. Our guide Kent was really knowledgeable, passionate and interesting. Surprisingly the most disappointing part of the tour was the ex prisoner part and we were probably unlucky. Our guide looked at his watch so often, sometimes at 2 minute intervals and it felt rushed. Worth the trip but I guess luck of the draw on the guides!

Well-presented prison.. Once you see the mats people were given to sleep on (before the radical introduction of bunk beds), you can well imagine the hard going that being sent here entailed. Then you visit the lime quarry and imagine going snow blind. This was truly hard time.

beautiful journey. such a nice place best to visit day time nice view 300 rand ticket for boat best idea to purchase in advance take your food and sandwich with you two hour time for guided tour all included in your ticket

Not to be missed when in Cape Town. Fortunately, I had booked this excursion in advance (in the last week of December). This meant that I was not disappointed by the notices indicating that there was over a week before there was any availability.The walls of the Gateway give a good background to the apartheid struggle which can be read whilst waiting for boarding the ferry.The catamaran ride was smooth and speedy and offered good views of the city and mountains and the island.The coach tour of the island was interesting with several stops where the guide pointed out specific features. My only regret at the time was that we were not allowed to get out of the tour bus at the lime quarry, but on reflection I understand that if over one thousand visitors every day did so then 'tourist damage' would occur.At the prison itself a former detainee escorted us round, ably explaining the relevance of the different blocks and showing us the various cell blocks. It looked a harsh environment and one can only imagine how bleak life must have been for those incarcerated.Inevitably, everyone wanted to see Nelson Mandela's cell. The fact that it was just like the others served to emphasise how his reputation in the outside world counted for nothing with the prison authorities.This is a key site in the struggle against apartheid and should not be missed when in Cape Town.

Sobering. This is a long trip and we wer shown around by former detainees who had been political prisoners. The conditions were quite shocking particuarly when you consider we are talking about recent history. The boat takes about 30 minutes and then the tour another 2/3 hours
Very good. Very interesting tour,learnt a lot about South African history.Visiting Nelsinho made las cell and finding out about his life in prison

Do not leave Cape Town without visiting Robben Island. The island with a prison where many political prisoners, including Nelson Mandela, spent years of their lives, is a required visit. The tour guides are all former prisoners and give first-hand accounts of the prisoners' treatment, required work, clothing allocation and general living conditions. It is a powerfully moving experience to visit. (A 30' ferry ride provides transportation from the Mandela Gateway to the Island, and runs frequently as long as the water isn't too rough.)

Excellent for both History and how Humans survive. What a super trip.Started on the first boat of the day after easy boarding etc with friendly staff.Whilst waiting the story on the walls was good and a taster of what was to come.The boat journey was a little lumpy but well worth it for the magnificent views of Cape Town and Table Mountain and we were very lucky and also saw a whale not to far way in the bay.Arrival at Robben Island was well managed and we were immediately shown to a bus which when full started on the tour.The young guide was very informative and it was really interesting to learn not only about when Nelson Mandela and other political Prisoners where held there but also about the Islands previous and current use and history.The bus tour ended with a tour of the Block and cell where Nelson Mandela was held and the tour was guided by an ex prisoner which was both very informative and moving.Ther were many picture opportunities and a short time to check out the souvenir shop before back on the boat with further magnificent views of Cape Town.The boat sets of from The V&A at The Waterfront so could not be more accessable.This trip is a must for any visit to Cape Town and well worth the time,about 4 hrs in total..

A must visit in Cape Town. Firstly I'd say you should read up on some of the history before you go here, I'm glad I read the books and saw the movie because it gave me a much deeper understanding of the island.They have inmates running the tours which is quite cool, given you real life up close experience of live in the prison. Also makes you understand just how recent it was that these events took place. Everyone should visit here to be reminded of how we should not treat other human beings.

Special place. The tour on Robben Island is one of the best in the World. With real users of the jail as a tourguide gives it a extra dimension! It feels priveliged to visit this important place in the world! Remember our Freedom

Fascinating insight. We booked well in advance via internet (before we left home) as these tours book up quickly and may not be available by the time you get there (this was the case on our previous visit the year before).Firstly, the tour was nearly an hour late leaving and the queues were ridiculously long and hot. We were not impressed when we saw a couple with a very tiny baby turned away at the gate because they hadn't bought the baby a separate ticket - bloody silly.However, once we got there it was very interesting and the guide obviously most knowledgeable. The tour actually is designed to take 3 - 4 hours (I had thought it was only two hours, so had arranged something else back in Cape Town) - we discussed my dilemma with the guide and he kindly agreed to take us independently to the Mandela cell and give us a quick look around and then get back on the next ferry to the mainland. Actually this was good as I think the 'long version' of the tour would have been too long for me. We enjoyed what we had time to do and would recommend a visit to this unique island.

A "Must see place" ...but. We were really looking forward to this trip.....but it was a total let down. In my opinion this attraction has been over played.and now just a money spinner for the people who work there. A total waste of our day...
Tour. Knowledgable tour guides and wonderful experience! Highly recommend the tour on Robben Island. Arrive early and buy tickets in advance.

A must see. Robben Island is a very sobering journey back in time - not so very far back either! Ferry ride is enjoyable with great views back to Table Mountain. There is more than just Nelson Mandela's incarceration to the story of the island. Well worthwhile!

Reminiscing the Nelson Mandela moment. Detailed tour. See everything and hear everything through tour guide an ex prisoner of robben island. Visit Nelson Mandela's cell and other political prisoners and read their thoughts written on the paper (which they pasted on the wall). Its a good historical day tour and souvenir shops available to buy keep sakes and Nelson Mandela's quotes on post cards.
Thought Provoking. What can you say Nelson Mandela's (home) for all those yearsmakes you realise how 1 person can treat another and its unforgiving

History lesson. It was a brilliant trip,we were took around the prison by an ex inmate that was friends with Nelson Mandela he was very knowledgeable about the prison and inmates ,I was so intrigued by it all ,well worth the money ,excellent trip

Why I went to Cape Town. Before I went I read a couple of reviews here that were just dumb. Folks complaining the guide talked about racism! That's what its about; learning from the black mark on the history of humanity to ensure we never let it happen again.We lucked out in that one of our group turned to to have been a prisoner himself, He described life undder the pass card laws & would have been a better guide than the one we had. But our dude was cool and did a nice job of engaging some kids visiting.

Very rich in South African history. Very informative and the Kramat is a must see for a Muslim traveller . Beautiful ,wonderful, safe city. Where the sun shines and the wind blows day in day out. Top place to visit. There's a lot of food for the eyes
A must if you want to understand South Africa. Started our time in SA by visiting Robben Island. Wonderful tour guides. Very knowledgeable and willing to share so much with us.

Obligatory . You have to do this tour, though it could have been better.
Best part is that there is a guide who actually was imprisoned there, giving the tour an extra dimension.
I was left with a feeling of being shown more than involved

A place for reflection. Nelson Mandela's name will forever be associated with this grim Island. There were many others who suffered as he did under the Apartheid system. Our wonderful Guide Mr Tom Moses spent many years there. During our tour he explained how the prison worked and what happened to the detainees as they lived their daily grind there,under a severe,harsh and brutal regime. He spoke without rancour, he challenged us gently and you would not have heard a pin drop when he spoke. A most remarkable man whom I will never forget. As I understand it most of the guides are ex prisoners and so give a dimension to this experience which you should not miss.

Robben Island is a Must See. If you have any interest in history, you must visit Robben Island. This is the prison where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for 18 years. Your tour will be conducted by a former political prisoner, which is very moving. The island itself is also very interesting in terms of its geography. The boat ride ou/back to the island provides beautiful views of Cape Town and Table Mountain if the weather cooperates!

Skip this at all costs. Awful...wasted an entire day and waste of money.. I do not like sharing negative reviews. But if I spare one person the awful experience of going to robben island I've done my job. This whole thing is very poorly organized. I felt as if we were the first tour to ever occur there. No one was able to tell us where to go, or how long our tour would last. Last loading was at 10 minutes till the hour. At the hour, we were still standing in line doing nothing. After we loaded We took a nice boat over with a nice safety demonstration and life jackets under our seats. When we exited the boat, there was zero direction. Imagine 300 people on a random island and not a soul saying "go this way". Nothing at all. Some busses came up behind us and started driving through the crowds but there was no one to say hey go here go there etc. it was so confusing. There was clearly a high priority party who had special treatment but who knew what they were up to? They seemed to get whisked away with their special bus driving right through the crowds. Anyway. Finally a random bunch of people loaded on a bus but we did not know why. Then another couple people with official looking badges came up and stopped us with no directions and waited for about 10 minutes to let the loaded busses pass. We were so confused. Finally a guy said hey we are starting the tour now. His accent was awful. I'm very well travelled and can decipher just about anyone's speech. 2/3 of what he said was unintelligible. One and a half hour later we had completed an absolutely horrible tour of the prison. Then they told us we need to get on the bus. The tour guide called the bus drivers by yelling at them. They did not want to come. They were only 100 yards away. 10 minutes later the bus arrived. We loaded on the bus but were too many and there was standing room only. That's when they informed us that we can not stand. So they called a 2nd bus. We offloaded the first bus and then we loaded on the 2nd bus. Then began another hour long tour of the island with a new guide. He was better but at this point- I just wanted to go home. Little did I know it was 2 more hours before we were done. Finally we make it back to the boat to go home and they put us on a very different boat. This time there was no safety demonstration.this time it was an open air boat with no life jackets. And people kept pouring on this boat. If that boat had trouble we were screwed. It took over an hour to travel back on this very slow overloaded boat. And the exhaust stack was belching diesel fumes down on the crowd on the deck. I was not enjoying this at all. If they had simply done a self guided tour with plaques and signs it would have been fine. No need at all for guides. The guides sucked anyway. A hop on hop off boat that came and left every hour would have been great. We could have turned our 5 hour+ experience into a nice 2 hour enjoyable excursion.

Historical Significance for Apartheid. Upon arriving in Cape Town, this was our first activity. You reach Robben Island (located about 4 miles out in Table Bay) via a 40 minute ferry/boat ride to the island from the V&A Waterfront (all part of the purchased ticket). The name is Dutch for "Seal Island". Robben Island is both a South African National Heritage Site as well as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.From the dock, a bus will take you around part of the island and then come to the prison buildings, including viewing of the cell that housed Nelson Mandela for 18 of his 27 years in prison. The tour guides are prior prisoners of the prison during Apartheid. Three former inmates of Robben Island have gone on to become President of South Africa: Nelson Mandela, Kgalema Motlanthe, and current President Jacob Zuma. Following the tour, you have the opportunity to walk through the grounds on your own. This is a half day activity.

Must see because of the historic value. It is a place full of history that was reflected to the whole world and has it's importance in that way. Nevertheless it has become a propaganda machine and the communication is rather one-sided.

reflection. A very important part of history for South Africa and for everyone. Our guide was a former prisoner and his testimonials to what he and so many others endured including Nelson Mandela were incredible. You could hear a pin drop. Important life lessons for our children and ourselves.

a walk through history. the boat ride is an experience on its own. I found that on arrival there was a little confusion and not clear instruction on where to go. quite a bit of walking so wear conmfy shoes. the kids became bored easily and that's never a good thing. depending on the time of year, it can get very hot so come prepared. All in all i would not recommend for very young kids. and pack some snacks and something to drink, the tour is very long and the kids got hungry and thirsty and there's only one shop if i remember correctly.

A look at the past. Emotional trip to the heart of the Apartheid Movement and home of Nelson Mandela for more than 18 years. Half hour trip by ferry from the mainland. Very informative guides. Worthwhile.

A crucial part of SA history. For many years political prisoner Nelson Mandela was held on Robben Island during South Africa's apartheid regime. Thi strip offers an incredible insight into the conditions on the island during the racist regime.
An ex-prisoner takes you around the prison. We were lucky enough to have the fantastic Tom Moses offer us his part in the prison's history. What a

A must do in Cape Town . Fantastic experience and definitely worth the money! I recommend going early to ensure you have a good seat on the boat to the island. Once you arrive, you are split into groups of about 30 and shown around the island. Our guide was absolutely amazing and provided a lot of information. He was also very open to answering all of our questions. A must when visiting Cape Town!

Book in Advance. Usually we like to go with the flow but it is ESSENTIAL to book this tour in advance. Even booking in advance is not a guarantee as our boat was cancelled on the day due to windy conditions - not uncommon- and the next available tour was ten days later (we were visiting during the Xmas period)The boat ride was wonderful with whales, seals and dolphins in the water. As soon as we disembarked, we were herded on buses and driven around the island. The guide on our bus was informative and humourous - especially about the most famous toilet in the world in the lime quarry where the prisoners held clandestine meetings.Then we were handed over to a different guide- another former inmate - who showed us around the prison buildings at a breakneck pace and managed to lose at least half the original group. He was very difficult to understand even though I managed to keep up with him. We kept running into other guides with other groups and backtracking. He did say that there was more people than usual on the island that day. I'm not even certain that we saw Mandela's cell as our guide pointed vaguely to a cell and just kept walking, saying that there were many, many prisoners! Interesting comment.It is worth a visit but would have liked a less 'herded' frantic approach.

Good, but more time consuming than I foresaw. I had it in my mind that Robben Island was something you "had" to do when you come to Cape Town. But after having done it, I am not sure the investment in time was justified. It takes an hour and a half to go there, and an hour and a half back (and the sea was rough). The tour once you are there is ok, you kind of troupe through an empty prison and you do feel the historical significance of it, but . . . I felt like I had run out of time in Cape Town, and I could have spent that day more wisely and pleasantly, like going on Chapman's Peak Drive and Hout Bay.

Must do but need better tour guides. This is a once in a life time experience to see where Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners were kept. The island is still very untouched. Only problems were the bus had no air conditioning and on a 32 degree day this was very uncomfortable and our second tour guide was very hard to understand (even for our south african friends). As this is a truly international tourist attraction i would say they need to have tour guides who can speak slower so you can understand them. However i would recommend doing this as it is a big part of the worlds history. Make sure you book in advance as this can book out

Inspiring experience but a little rushed. A truly moving experience, made all the more personal with a tour by former inmate. Starts with a boat trip which provides a different perspective on views of Cape Table. The bus tour that precedes the visit to the prison provides an insight into the long history of the Island as a place of imprisonment and exclusion. Finally the prison tour itself, unfortunately this way very rushed and it was impossible to take your time to appreciate the significance of the place. There appears to be information boards around but again we did not have time to read as we were ushered back onto the boat which was disappointing.

Important visit to Robben Island. The visit to Robben Island was very interesting and moving. What an impressive tour - makes Nelson Mandela's (and other political prisioners') story even more moving, bringing it to life in a concrete way. Seeing his garden, where he spent time writing was incredibly inspiring. The only challenge was that we had a very hard time understanding our guide as he spoke. That didn't diminish the overall experience though - Robben Island speaks for itself.

Exceptionally Moving Visit. I think the best part of the visit was our tour guide - an ex-prisoner of Robben Island who had the most amazing baritone voice. He was very knowledgable and very forthright with details. He would frequent use that baritone voice while we toured the prison, which created a very eerie feeling as you walked through such an historical place. It took us three days to see Robben Island, but it was well worth the wait!

Important to do but unimpressed . I was really looking forward to this visit but found it disappointing. First we had a huge group of 50. The guides are former inmates which should make it very interesting and personal, however I found my guide to be fairly impersonal and failed to really tell the story of he prison. Beyond the guide, they don't do a great job of displaying information. There are posters of long quotes from prisoners but they fail to set up the story or background for the quote. After the prison tour you like on the bus again for another 45 min driving around the island. I would have skipped it if I could.

Robben island is the best place to be,ever last memories. I have visited the place last year December for my first time.I have enjoyed the historical even though i feel very emotional.We will never regret what you have paid for the ferry was very comfortable.I would recommend to everyone who is visiting capetown to experience robben island.

Fascinating and moving. A fascinating and moving experience to hear a former Robben Island prisoner describe what life was like for him, for Nelson Mandela, and for countless other political prisoners of the apartheid regime. I was concerned that my nine-year old son would not have the historical background to appreciate the experience, but he came away having absorbed some crucial messages about politics, democracy, and intolerance. I would recommend it for anyone visiting Cape Town. Keep in mind that there is no place on the island to get lunch, so it might be wise to go early in the morning or early in the afternoon (before or after lunchtime).

Historical visit. Educational and emotional tour all in one there is a lot we never knew about the island from the limestone quarry to the cells and the prisoners. Very entertaining bus tour from ex prisoner a real treat for all historical enthusiasts....

Eye-opening experience - must do!. The tour was one of the most educational and moving experiences I had in Cape Town, if not out of all the traveling I've ever done, and highly recommended. I knew very little about South African history going into this, but the humanity displayed transcends race or age or nationality.  Visitors can visit Robben Island by catching a boat from the V&A Waterfront. The fee for the boat includes a bus tour around the island, and a tour inside the prison complex where Nelson Mandela was kept, both guided by ex-political prisoners. The whole trip lasts about 3-4 hours, and there are 3-4 boats out per day. It's best to book tickets in advance, for the simple fact that it is a very popular destination for visitors to Cape Town.

A Must if you are visiting Cape Town. A long and emotional tour. Boat ride about 1 hour each way. Bus ride with amusing but very informative guide. Got to see Nelson Mandela's cell along. Learned a lot. Great for teenagers.

Very interesting, but no flexibility to the tour. It's really interesting to see Robben Island and to learn about conditions endured by the prisoners here, including the food rations which depended on whether you were coloured or black. Beware if you go on a hot day as there is no shade and you are moved around the island on very old coaches with no aircon. Also, expect to queue for quite a while while you wait for the ferry across.

Inspiring. Robben Island is South Africa's Alcatraz. It is a place where political prisoners and criminals were held under austere conditions. It is a reminder of Apartheid and what it allowed the government to do to the citizenry of South Africa. Guided tours are given by former prisoners who make the experience far more meaningful. This is where Nelson Mandela was held and his cell is part of the tour. The 1/2 hour ferry ride from downtown Capetown makes you appreciate the isolation of the place. A short bus tour provides an orientation of the island and the quarry worked by the prisoners: The prison itself is then visited. It is frightening and inspiring at the same time.

Worth the money . The price charged to visit the island is worth what you get. The tour of the island and prison itself is informative and well constructed. Weather was very windy when I visited and therefore the ferry trip wasn't too pleasant with the choppy seas but none the less it's a good visit and definitely something to do when visiting the mother city!

A piece of history. Book ahead because everyone else wants to see this in peak season. It's a thought provoking and sobering experience that will stay with you. Especially as you are taken around by guides who were actually held in the prison during apartheid. This added extra emotion and credibility to the experience. One word of advice, don't trust them if they say that 'today is my birthday'. Three of our guides said that in the hopes of getting extra tips. But they didn't need to because their harrowing stories are enough to see most visitors give generously.

Powerful, sobering and extremely interesting. What an experience! Our tour guide for the duration of the trip was a former political prisoner of Robben island and a mine of information. I would highly recommend this trip if you're in town for just a couple of days - especially if you're not from South Africa and you want to learn more about the Apartheid years and what life was like for the men in prison who opposed it.Ferry leaves from the Victoria wharf.

Don't bother. Do yourself a favour and give this a miss. Nothing to really see or hear.
Long hot boring coach ride around unremarkable island then
An insignificant and rushed photo opportunity outside the cell. That is it

Must do. Be it just for the sake of getting to understand RSA a little better.. We didn't have too high expectations but were surprised about how well the whole trip was organized. Make sure you book the ticket ahead of time, it's very busy during peak-season. Trip can be shaky, hence take the bigger boat if you get sea-sick quickly. A great bus-tour to start with including great guidance. There will be a turtle on the road and the bus will stop, trust this to be a "wowww-try" by the organizers. :) Then there will be an ex-prisoner guiding you through the prisons. This is excellent since this is very inter-active and one can ask questions of interest.

A must if you are in Cape Town.... This place isn't just about Nelson Mandela it's about history. I visited Robben island 3 years ago and loved it. We went back in December with friends and family and they equally enjoyed it. You get a boat from the waterfront across to the island. If you stand at the back you get amazing views of table mountain and Cape Town. When you get to the island there are about 4 buses waiting to take you on your tour - each bus goes a different way to avoid congestion. We are told about the history of the island about Nelson Mandela and abut other inmates who served there. At the end of the tour an ex-inmate gives a speech about their time in the prison which is very interesting. If you like that kind of thing then I would recommend it ;-)

History Preserved. I really do not understand the negative comments about this site. Having visited the prisons and cells in Johannesburg and Mandela's house in the townships this completed for me the story. The trip over by boat is about half an hour and you stay on the island for two hours. The tour includes a bus trip around the island with stops at the quarry prisoners worked in and the penguin colony where you can get refreshments etc. The prison tour itself is conducted by ex prisoners and it is fascinating to hear their stories. Well worth the money and a part of history that changed the world.

A Historical Journey. The trip totals about 3 hours. You start with a ferry from the Waterfront. The tour around the island was very informative wish a guide the whole way. The last bit of the tour is where you find Nelson Mandela's cell.

A place to be known. Actually when traveling I like beautiful and joyful places but my husband likes history (even if they are sad), so, I was not that happy to go there.But truly, even though I was walking around with tears in my eyes, it is a place full of history and you can actually feel all the pain people went through. It is very necessary to keep places like that to make the next generations to never make the same mistake.Worth visiting

A little underwhelming. It is definitely worth visiting as an educational exercise to understand what went on and how things were organised. I particularly liked the way explanations by former inmates were given in a very factual and objective way, with great dignity and no obvious rancour or bitterness. I also enjoyed the boat trip out there because Cape Town and Table Mountain look glorious from the sea and the island itself. However, as others have said there are missed opportunities to make the island more of a tourist experience. It is a bit like visiting a shrine to the Great man and all who suffered there and perhaps that is what it is to locals and should remain that way.

Wonderful trip. The entire tour took us around 3 hours. With a 20 minute ferry ride each way. The ferries are large and have comfortable seating. The tour was informative and extremely interesting. Viewing the colony of penguins that live on the island was a bonus. Tours sell out fast during the holiday period, so it is best to book them in advance. A definite must see for anyone visiting Cape Town.

Boring. Not worth the trip....you get bored of listening to the tour guide go on and on...and you restricted on the bus...once you get off at the prison site you venture to the cells.. etc.they should have developed the place by now to include a hotel and restaurant. ....its really not worth the money. ...so much more can be done with that site....its history!!

Very enlightened visit. Extremely educational if you are interested in one is interested in South Africa Apartheid & Political & Social progress. The tour also discusses about other famous political prisoner besides Nelson. The morning boat ride is usually booked 2 days in advanced. I found the 11am clock ride is good. Afternoon boat ride sometimes got canceled due to high waves

A key place in world history. Very moving to see the conditions under which the prisoners lived.
Fascinating to hear from someone who was a prisoner about what happened and his own experiences.
A memorial, we will never forget, and a testament that the human spirit wins through and that right triumphs.
And that people can forgive and move forward together.

Excellent visit. An excellent visit with superb guides throughout, the trip is well worth the money but you need to book several months beforehand if travelling at high season. The former prisoner who was our guide around the prison was outstanding and really brought the visit to life.

A Must when in Cape Town . So glad I purchased tickets previously on line as this trip was sold out all week during our stay.A lovely ferry takes you across the bay to the island where a bus tour begins , I was surprised at the size of the Island and that role still inhabited it . Having an ex prisoner talk to you about his experience I found both haunting, enlightening and shocking as to how these prisoners were treated. Seeing the cell where Nelson Mandela was incarcerated gave me goosebumps . I would highly recommend This tour and it's one off my bucket list .

Very educational. I always associated Robben Island with Dr Nelson Mandela. When I got to the island I realised that is it rich with history from the muslim slaves to lepers disease sufferers and supply station. The ferry to the island will cost you R300.00 and the whole tour lasts 4 hour two hrs sailing back and forth and two hours touring the island in a tour bus.

Well worth the trip to Robben Island. The tour by political ex-prisoners truly gives you an insight into life on Robben Island. A bus ride tour of the island and tour of the cell blocks, especially cell block B where Nelson Mandella was in incarcerated is a great way to spend a morning. Very well organised and a great tour!

Fascinating. Before going we heard from various sources that a Robben Island visit "was not worth the time nor the money", and that it did "not give you much that you did not already know". Well, we are very glad that we went despite those discouraging comments!!! Both our guides (prison and bus tour) were fantastic and gave us a lot to think about and new insights. And that is although we are generally politically interested and had read a number of guidebooks, introduction-to-South-Africa articles etc before going.

What a disappointment. What is supposed to be an iconic visit turns out to be an embarrassment. For such a high profile venue, the island is in bad shape, the amenities for visitors are sorely lacking. The tour on the island was a total disappointment .The island has so much history and there is such an amazing view of Cape Town bay area .The island tour is hurried, the history told completely biased and condensed into a 30 year period, you rush around te island and then hop on the ferry on the way back to the city.One can spend a whole day on this island and not have seen enough, but the tours are nothing more than a cattle drive.Very, very disappointing , especially as this is such a" must -do" visit for overseas visitors. You would be none the poorer for giving this a complete miss.

Robben Island a true Long Walk to Freedom!. We boarded the Thembekile boat to the Island. There is so much history and a very heartbreaking one! All the prisoners who were there they truly went through hardships! We saw the graves of those Cape Town citizens black, white, coloureds and Indians who died because of leprosy. During those days all people in Cape Town who suffered from that disease were all brought to the Island when they died. We also saw the prison cell of our South African hero Mr. Mandela the man who fought tirelessly for all people to be liberated. What also fascinated me was to see a painting of Jesus Christ on the walls in the prison cells, that shows that prisoners had faith even in their hardships, they still believed that one day they will be liberated!!

Need to be a Mandela enthusiast. It wasn't a bad tour, but unless you are really in to Mandela and the whole apartheid scene, most people would find it a bit long and boring. The boat ride was a change of scenery and it was nice to have a former inmate conduct the tour to get a real feel for what really went on.

Sad history. Firstly, you must book. During the holiday period this 'excursion' fills up every trip. It is very interesting for all tourists to visit the island for, obviously, Mandela's cell and the tour around half the island... it's unfortunate that the other half of Robben Island is not visited as there are seals off the northern coast. I'm a local and have been out four or five times; it's always fulfilling. I remove one star for the poor guides (ok, they're ex prisoners and all) but their language skills, especially for foreign language speakers, are quite poor. They are sometimes hard to understand. Kids get tired of trying. The jokes on the bus are tired and unnecessary. Altogether a valuable and informative few hours.

It brought tears to my eyes!!!. I booked the visit to Robben island as part of a day tour, that included a city tour in the afternoon. If you are going the summer time, and if possible, make sure you book it ahead of time, I waited 4 weeks before going to book and only got a 7:30 am ferry, which was hard on my kid, but so worth it. it was so touching to see the prison, after watching the movie "Long Walk to Freedom", it brought it all together. The icing on the cake was that the tour guides are all ex-political prisoners, our guide, Tom, was incarcerated for 9 years, while Nelson Mandela was there. Such a touching story and helps you understand the struggles that SA has had for so many years.

Beware of Horrible lines - educational. I m not one to take waiting in lines. It was a lot of that. Wait to get on the boat - off the boat - on the bus - off the bus - in the prison - back on the boat (which that one was very unorganized / almost dangerous. It was interesting and sad to see where Mandela had spent so many years. To see his garden and the cell that he lived in for so many years. He was such an inspirational man.

Evocative. Buy tickets on-line in advance. Get the ferry from the V&A waterfront. Once on the island you board a bus and tour the sights on the island with some very informative commentary. A chance to get some photos of Table Top. We had a former inmate showing us the cells and yards where they had been incarcerated. It was well worth the visit. Highly recommended to all.

The evil of the apartheid system: Robben Island. To really understand what the freedom fighters went through, the inhuman conditions they were subjected to,then a visit to Robben Island is a absolute must.It is only accessible to tourists via a ferry that sails at different times of the day. This excursion will take about 3 hours of your time but is worth every minute. As you sail to Robben Island, you can look back at a spectacular Table Mountain, but as you near the island you feel some sense of premonition as you are now almost in the middle of nowhere. Once on the island a well informed guide ( I came to know later that he was also imprisoned at the very same prison) will take you through all the stages of the intake, the courtyard, the holding cells to the open workplace where prisoners like the late Nelson Mandela,had to chip away at solid rock almost every single day of their imprisonment.The cell where he was held captive is still in it's original state and it is really mind boggling to comprehend how a man of his stature and built had to sleep in a cell that he could not even stretch out!That is just one of the atrocities and I won't do justice to prepare you should you go and visit this island. The Island is now renowned for the multiple Valentine's marriages.For more shocking revelations I suggest you experience it personally.

It generates lots of emotions.. The life of Nelson Mandella is why you visit Robben Island, although the island itself long predates Mandella's incarceration, serving as a provisioning stop for mariners and also as a leper colony, long before becoming an isolation place for political prisoners as well as ordinary convicts.The ferry to the island is quite enjoyable with good views of Cape Town, but it could be a challenge if there are rough seas in the bay! The island divides into a prison, and a village for the guards and their families. Today visitors are required to take a tour guided by former political prisoners, who tend to become quite emotional about their experiences. How Mandella survived 28 years, mostly in solitary confinement with hard labor (breaking stones) is amazing.

Great historical visit and a bit sad!!. We book our tickets before an advance as it is not easy to get it , they fully book everyday. Such a nice visit it was , all the smell of history . Would definitely recommended to all who comes to S.A

Informative Tour. Kind of worth seeing if you are into the history of apartheid. Not recommended for young kids and babies as they tend to get to restless. Wear comfortable shoes which you don't mind getting dusty. Overall not bad. Book in advance to avoid disappointment.

There's better ways to spend your day... We visited Robben Island during one of our first days in Cape Town. We pre booked our tickets as they get booked up so far in advance. We took the first ferry over in the morning, there were queues when we arrived half an hour early! The ferry takes around 25-30 minutes and there's enough seating for everyone, it's also a great photo opportunity if you are near the back as its open. Once you arrive at the island you are put on buses and given a tour which shows you where the school, hospital etc are located. There is a guide on the bus at all times. After around 15 mins you stop off at the cafe to get a drink, snacks (crisps etc) and there's toilets available too. After ten minutes you are back on the bus (which can be very hot and stuffy) to complete the rest of the tour. The bus drops you off a the prison / cells where one of the inmates gives you a short talk on life inside. Once the talk is completed you are shown Nelson Mandela's cell. The tour is then completed and you make your way to the shop / boat ready for departure. The whole event including the ferry lasts for around 3 hours. This tour isn't a must do in my eyes, there's lots of more interesting things to do with your time, I think this is just a money making exercise.
Wonderful afternoon outing. Enjoyable afternoon outing for the whole family! The ferry ride gives you some of the best views of Cape Town. The island tour is interesting. Well worth it. Recommended!

The personal stories are the key. It is not a standard 'Tourist Site' There are few photo ops and nothing grand to seeIt is a long boat ride to and fro (with SPECTACULAR views of Cape Town) and you do have to take a bus around the island with a group. And more money could be invested in the site and the interpretation.But open your heart and mind to feel the stories of the people who were here and whose struggle freed South Africa. You will be rewarded with a deeper insight and appreciation.

Interesting . Had a very interesting time. Tour guide on the coach was very knowledgeable. Tour guide of the prison (ex inmate) was good. Interesting tour full of information. The boat trip was good we saw whales which was lucky at this time of the year.

Powerful experience, but could be improved.. It's hard not to recommend a trip to Robben Island, as it's historical and cultural significance, to SA and the world at large, is unquestioned. However, if you only have three or four days in Cape Town, I would not put it at the top of your list. Plan for it to take a full five hours - starting with the queue for the boat and the ferry (if you get the fast one, it's about 25 minutes. The slow one, closer to an hour). Once you get to the island, you are shepherded onto tour buses that drive around the island, with a few stops and led by a tour guide. We found this part disappointing - it would have been much better to be able to walk around the island and check out the prison and other buildings at our own pace. The last third of the tour is by foot, where former inmates guide you into the cells. This is the highlight and still a moving experience. If you have a week or more in town, you should definitely go. But Table Mountain, Kirstenbosch, Cape Point, Boulder's Beach and Lion's Head should all take precedence. Also to note: the V&A Waterfront, though impressive in scope, is primarily a large outdoor mall. If you've been to many parts of America, it will be familiar.

The good and the bad. We were in Capetown over Christmas holiday and were interested in seeing Robben Island. I would recommend doing the trip but "know before you go"...1. It is a process to get to the actual prison. First there is a que in Capetown where you are placed on one of three boats. We arrived very promptly and originally were thrilled to be placed on the first large boat "The Jester". As the Jester chugged along slightly choppy water, we began to see the boats that had loaded later pass us-- a 25 minute ride took almost one hour due to our decreased speed and the fact that there is only one dock to unload on2. Once you arrive you are placed on a bus for about an hour tour. This was surprisingly interesting. There is no official line for the buses and it is a total free for all when the buses arrive-- Once we finally managed to push our way onto the bus we enjoyed the tour and our guide.3. The prison is very interesting but our guide was incredibly difficult to understand due to his heavy African accent. I'm sure he was telling an interesting story but I understood about 40% -- I'm sure if the tour had been longer my ear would have grown accustomed to his accent and understood more. However, the actual time inside the prison is not long. I would recommend the following to improve this site--1. consider improving the boat situation-- a slow and choppy ride is not ideal2. Set up stanchions to organize the cue for buses. 3. provide written material about the prison experience and perhaps bios of the guides--

Interesting but harsh. An interesting place with important historical significance. The ferry ride out can be a bit choppy, but you might be lucky enough to see dolphins on the way. The tour of the island is very informative. Meeting and listening to one of the previous inmates was a humbling experience.

The price of freedom. As I set my foot on the ferry at nelson Mandela Gateway at The Clock Tower, I knew that an exciting journey was awaiting me. The cool breeze caressed my face all through the journey as I watched the Mother City and Table Mountain drift away into the distance. Upon disembarking, we were taken on a tour by bus around the island as one of the former inmates at the island. We were shown around the island and finally we came to see the cell where the late Nelson Mandela spent 27 years of his life. Yes my history teacher in school had taught me about it all, but coming face to face with this historical sight left me more appreciative the price some had to pay for freedom. This sight is for those who appreciate the history of Southern Africa. Highly recommended historical site.

Point of interest. The whole trip takes a half day, it is a moving experience. However, if you have only two days at Cape Town and we not very interested in moder history, I suggest it is safe to skip this trip. I personally found the guides talking too much and it felt that they were obliged to fill the time.

Don't miss a trip to the island. The Scene: 4 days in Cape Town, wanted to learn more about the history of Apartheid and the significance of Robben Island in it. We booked it in advance online and went for the 9am tour. Positives: all of our guides on the island were previous political prisoners and were therefore very knowledgable and passionate about the subject. This was particularly eye opening during the jail tour. Boat was in good condition and very comfortable despite it being very choppy and windy.Negatives: despite getting their early as stated on the tickets, the boat left late and we received no communication or updates as to why or when we would be departing. During the bus tour, if you were sitting towards the back of the bus, it was often quite difficult to hear even with the microphone. Try sitting towards the front and by the window for best view. During the prison tour, there were 30-40 of us with a single guide which made it very cramped, difficult to hear, and slow at times.Top Tip: even though ticket recommends arriving 10 mins before departure, try getting there 30 mins early to get outdoor or window seat on the boat - great views during a clear day!

Amazing and a must-see to understand the history of SA. Grabbed the first ferry. Told that if weather is windy ferries to the island can be cancelled but first one always runs (so be early).Guides are former inmates. Tour is a bit rushed, would have preferred more time but still amazing.You go into cells and can read a short blurb by an inmate about their time there. Things like "My worst time was when they made me dig a grave, lie down, and then started to shovel dirt on me and said they were going to bury me alive. I choked a lot on the dirt. I made many friends there etc." Unreal experience and I can't understand how the inmates didn't go insane with the brutality of it.A few days later we talked one of my wife's relatives who was at Robben for 18 years (her father missed getting picked up by 5 minutes) and he talked about Mandela talking to him, getting him to forget about getting tortured and focus on the future of the country.

A must see while in Cape Town, a great tour to Robben Island.. A world heritage site and rightly so, the ferry itself can be a little choppysometimes, but it was a bonus to see whales and seals during the crossing and watching the superb views thrown in. Once you get to the Island you are herded on to buses and taken off in different directions, in my case four buses going one direction and four the other Imagine a giant bun-fight at the start to get a good seat.... The tour conducted by a former inmate was intriguing, informative and provides the visitors with an insight into life in prison on the island. The only thing on my bus was no PA, he apologized It the start but found it sometimes to hear what he was saying. We saw the lime rock quarry, that brought this fairly bleak site to life only did work under harsh conditions, Large part of the first half the tour spent on a bus listening to a highly entertaining talk then you could hear him.The second half was the prison visit itself, well we left the buses for good. we got out and toured inside the main prison buildings and courtyards, involves a fair bit of walking and then sitting on benches inside the former prison where Mandela, amongst others, was held. The guide another former prisoner, who told us about daily life in the prison. then it was time to see the actual cell where Nelson Mandela served some of is time.My only criticism of the trip was that it could be a bit rushed at the end depending as to how long your ex convict spoke during the prison visitwhich meant no time a visit the shop and no time as well of souvenirs.I would strongly recommend it to anybody who visits Cape Town to make the trip. I would recommend the whole morning or afternoon to do trip, take some comfortable footwear and hat for the sun.

Poorly Organised . The trip over to the island was good for the history and to say you've been. However the transport via ferry is chaos! Every man for themselves getting on the return ferry from the island. People pushing and shoving with no form of organising from the staff. You're very restricted and must be in a group tour which is also disappointing.If you didn't have time to visit the island I wouldn't be worried you won't miss much.

First time on the island. In all my life, I'd never made it to the island despite its easy accessibility. We booked ahead, which I recommend, as I am told that they often fill up all the available ferry spots.When you get there - you are filtered into buses with your guides who take you around the island. The tours are clever, the guides are witty, and if you're lucky - you may see a whale. When you get to the cells, you're spoken to by a political prisoner.It's a must do to understand South Africa's history - strongly recommend.
Understand Hate. The boat trip, the tour, and the personal guide by previous prisoner give you the opportunity to reflect on one of most horrible times of humanity. Stop being afraid.

Brilliant tour. I came here in January 2014 with my two children and my dad, his wife, my two brothers and sister who already live in South Africa. This trip was an eye opener as I had only been to places like Spain!Robbed island is a lovely day out , getting there by boat, learning something new . Would love to go backDefinitely go!

Could be a lot better, feels run down. The history of the island is very interesting but the island and buildings there feel very run down. Not just in that the buildings are old but it's that they don't seem to be maintained properly. It's worth going to but read up on the history before as I think you'd get more out of it. The exhibits/museum are good but not great. You have to wonder where all the money goes as it doesn't seem to be going into the maintenance of the island. The main negative of the island is that it could be so much better, but it's just not. Getting the boat out/back can have delays depending on weather so check before you go.

An important, poignant reminder of South Africa’s past. Robben Island is the place in which the late Nelson Mandela was incarcerated from 1964, spending approximately two-thirds of his prison time there. Mandela was just one of many individuals forced to labour at this location.I booked my ticket online before touching down in Cape Town. This is essential during the peak tourist season. A useful tip is to arrive well in advance of your tour time, enabling you to get to the front of the queue and pick your spot on the boat that departs from the Nelson Mandela Gateway. I stood at the back, affording me excellent views of the beautiful waterfront but the boat was so fast that I ended up kneeling, fearing I might topple over the edge!The tour began with a highly informative bus ride around the island. The place is much bigger than it looks from the summit of Table Mountain! Sights included the Leper Graveyard (leper colonies were admitted to the island during the second half of the nineteenth century) and the Lime Quarry. Personally, I found it particularly discomforting to learn that prisoners’ eyes were damaged by the reflection of the sun from the latter. Prisoners were deprived of the rights other humans would expect and eye protection was not provided.The island is an important wildlife habitat and although I missed the understandably reclusive penguin colony, I did spot a tortoise. This, along with the picturesque scene of waves crashing against rocks with Cape Town in the background provides great photo opportunities.The second part involved a guided tour of the cells by a former inmate. This was a humbling experience. It was an honour to shake the hand of someone who had survived such an ordeal. He was asked whether he bore any resentment towards the individuals responsible for his incarceration, and responded with remarkable humility. Somewhat inevitably Mandela’s former cell is a considerable draw. Most people in my large group wanted to photograph it.My time on Robben Island nicely complemented a trip to Alcatraz I made in 2014. It’s worth knowing that whilst Alcatraz was predominantly self-guided when I was there, my Robben Island tour was escorted at all times. Rather than compare the two any further, I would say that both provided remarkable, valuable experiences. Site visits today ensure that the suffering of former prisoners is not forgotten as time moves on.

Defo worth doing. Booked online. Best parking in large underground carpark well signposted at V&A - very cheap. Then walk through shopping arcade to waterfront, and keep going round to the red clock tower. Cross the swingbridge and you will see Nelson Mandela tour entrance. Make sure you are at least 15 minutes early - boat will not wait for you. Bags are searched - strangely they didn't like my 400mm camera lens and asked me not to use it. Didn't understand that but wasn't overly bothered. There are 3 or 4 different sized boats used to get to the island. We travelled out on a small one - like an overflow when busy. Fantastic flat crossing taking about 25 minutes. The island harbour stinks of seagull waste. We were marshalled to the right side of the pier and jumped aboard an old bus. The tour was lead by a young man living on the island - he was very informative and humourous. We visited a small shop for refreshments. Great photo in the frame with Table Mountain in the background. The mine was like visiting a concentration camp. Very humbling. The internal prison was orderly and informative. To be honest, it was nice to hear about all the others that fought the cause, not just the great Mandela. The talk was by an ex inmate, who did a good job of making us feel how it was. Then it was all a bit rushed. We were told to get back to the port on foot as the boat was leaving. Flew past the souvenir shop, and boarded a large catamaran. We got back to Cape Town much quicker on this fast boat. Overall - a humbling lesson in history, and I'm glad we did it. If you're really pushed for time in Cape Town, maybe this one could be a lower priority?

Interesting day out Robben Island. Very informative day out at Robben Island with commentary from locals and people who had an insider view too! Very interesting and great views from there of Cape Town.

Awe inspiring. The boat ride over was nice and then we got on busses (a bit hot but they can't help that) and given a brief tour of the island. Then a former inmate guided us through the cells - stopping at Mandela's of course. The stories in block a were heartbreaking and inspiring. There were many in the tour, but we were all (even children) so very quiet to just listen and feel the aura. It's a must do.

Moving and enriching. Our guide was a former political prisoner. His words and recollections made the experience all the more poignant because of his commitment to looking and forging ahead.I cannot say I enjoyed this excursion, but I was certainly moved and enlightened by the things I saw, heard and read. Pleased I got the opportunity to visit Robben Island.IMPORTANT NOTE: Make reservations as far in advance as you can - particularly around any holidays or school breaks. Robben Island is popular with locals and tourists and because ferry service is weather dependent spots for the tours often sell out.

The Prison on Robben Island. We took a short ferry ride from the water front to the island. We were loaded on a bus and driven around the island. The guide explained the naming of the island, various historical location. The bus dropped us off at the cell blocks. The guide described the condition at the prison before it became a museum. There were cell blocks for most of the prisoners. High valued prisoners were assigned separate cells. He pointed out the censors’ office. All the mail was read by the censors and the volume was restricted.The prisoners were assigned work projects. The food was limited to the very basic food items. Several prisoners sent to the prison were never heard from again. There is a list of missing prisoners.

No time to let it sink in ..... This place needs a rethink. It's too regimented: only 3 boats a day, herded onto buses on the island, rushed round the prison so you can be on the boat back to the mainland. Phew ! Don't get me wrong it's very interesting and poignant. But how about more boats, time to look around the prison at your own speed, perhaps offering audio tours as well as former inmate guides and better signage ? For me the visit was rushed and as a consequence the impact of the place was somewhat lost. Glad I went but won't have a lasting effect. Shame really.

Historical Robben Island. This trip can be done by purchasing a ticket from the V&A Waterfront at Nelson Mandela Gateway for R300 (£13.25) and then boarding a ferry. We left at11am and returned back at the V&A at 2pm. Departures to the island start at 9am, then 11am, 1pm and 2pm. It takes about 30mins from the V&A to cross over to the Island. Before we board the ferry a photographer takes a photo of us next to the ferry, which we will need to collect upon our return. A fee of R40 (£1.76) is imposed. Once on board the ferry and before we depart we are given a quick demonstration on safety precautions aboard the vessel and how to put on our life jackets in the event of an emergency. When we arrived at the Island we were met by our tour guide and then we boarded our tour bus to the island. The guide commenced telling us about the history of the island. The Island is famous because it is where President Nelson Mandela served 27 years Imprisonment. Other inmates included President Jacob Zuma and President Kgalema Motlanthe. Robben Island's History is linked to South Africa as a whole under colonianist and apartheid rule, the racial and class inequalities that transpired within the country and resistance to this. There were so many human rights abuses, suffering and injustice which were encountered by prisoners, including segregation and no bread for breakfast. The Island was declared a National Monument in 1996, a National Museum in 1997, a World Heritage in 1999 and a National Heritage Site in 2006. On the island there is a White Limestone Quary where Nelson and other Prisoners had to work on whilst shackled. During the day they would break the quary stone and carry it to one end of the quary and then bring it back in the next day. This process was done to keep the prisoners busy. Nelson Mandela worked with white Limestone Quary for 13years, and as a result he developed eye problems. When he was finally released people were not allowed to use flash photography when they took his picture. Mandela and his inmates used their time in the quary to educate themselves from literature, philosophy, history and various events. One of the prisoners Robert Sobukwe was kept in solitary confinement for 3 years for his part in urging blacks to repeal pass laws made during the apartheid. On the island there is a 'Leper Cemetary,' where people with leprosy were buried. There is also a Moturu Kramat Mosque where Muslim political leaders pay homage at a shrine build to commemorate Sayed Abdulrahman Moturu, Prince of Madura, Cape Town's first Imam who was exiled on the island in 1740 and later died there in 1754. You will see houses previously occupied, various prison quarters, a church which was designed by Sir Herbert Baker, a school, a lighthouse, antelope, seabirds. You can visit Nelson Mandela's cell, Prisoner's shower blocks, toilets, sinks. The tour of the Island and prison are led by guides who were formerly prisoners. They will take you along the footsteps of Mandela in the Notorious B section. Mandela's cell is left open whilst others are locked. Deep emotional encounter.

Great History. I did not know what to expect when I took this up but what a fantastic tour! The tour guides were amazing and very knowledgeable! It was such a joy to be part of such rich history and it further painted the picture of a history I was introduced to as a young child!

Must visit when you are in cape town. extraordinary experience and a must do when you are in cape town. At the prison you will be guided and who else better can tell you the story of how it really went at that time. Amazing guides who will tell you their story.
Great tour. We had a very informative tour to Robben island. The guide was great and spoke well. We got to see everything this time as last time they had to cut our trip short due to time contraints.
