bus tour around robben island (RI). The tour offered different experiences. The trip by boat(Thembekile to go to RI and Sea Princess from RI) was FUN - passengers were interacting. The RI tour was emotional and informative. I took pictures which I will keep for ever.

Historical. A must see if you are in Cape Town., especially if you are interested in history and the life of the great humanitarian and President Nelson Mandela. He was incarcerated on Robben Island for most of his life. The tour can only be done by boat out to the island and then you get to tour inside the prison. You would need to book in advance as it is always full. Be sure u have a couple days to play with. It is worth the wait. The tour is very reasonable priced. It is ran by the South African government.

Cape Town's Essential tourist attraction . Must book in advance. A definite must do if visiting Cape Town for the 1st time. Historically poignant and renders heart wrenching empathy for Mandela and other prisoners. So far from "normal " life as we know it

Christmas Day on Robben Island. We purchased tickets online months in advance - on the chance it would be busy Christmas Day - and it was!It's an hour each way and maybe 2 hours in the island. The prison tour is moving and learning about all the people that spent time there was interesting. I don't recommend this activity for families with small kids. It's a historical educational place - perfect for older kids, and those who understand the context surrounding the island.

Emotional visit. You can't come to Cape Town and not visit Robben Island. 45mn journey by ferry you might even see dolphins we sure did. The guides are old prisoners which made the visit even more special and very emotional when you hear their different stories. Make sure you bring a hat it's really hot on he island. I'm glad we went to visit it. It's part of South Africa's history..

must see!. Everyone must visit this place to appreciate the struggle of Black South Africans against apartheid. The most touching part is standing in front of Nelson Mandela's tiny cell, and imagine spending over two decades locked-up!

Depends on Your Guide. I was here ten years ago and the place was a superb experience, thanks to the fomer jailor turned tour guide. But I was disappointed the second time around as the former prisoner guide just went through the motions, instead of putting his heart and soul into the story. The group was also large and it was difficult to hear what was going on. Robben Island is popular so book well in advance. Tours can be cancelled if the seas are rough.

A site for thought. I thoroughly enjoyed the boat trip there and back. I felt the island of historical significance but very depressing, leading to thoughts of perhaps the failure of the penal system in the brutal futility of quarrying and breaking up limestone, when some of the more famous inmates had so much to offer society
I thought the overall experience was great. I learnt so much not only about Nelson Mandela but the history of the island. I thi I this is a must for everyone going to Cape Town

Humbling Experience. The visit to Robben Island impacted profoundly on me. Seeing Mandela's cell and the life he and other freedom fighters led, listening to a narrative about their suffering, was st best traumatizing but then there was a happy ending. An emotional experience
Historic. A must see for all tourists. Guided bus tour . In-mate from Mandela's time to guide you through the prison. Thoroughly enjoyable and informative.

A tour would have been nice.. I came down from abroad with my partner for a holiday to visit my family and wanted to show him all the sights, including the Robben Island museum. We booked the tickets beforehand by phone, which was quite difficult because the lady kept getting our names wrong and generally made the process complicated. Eventually we confirmed the date and time, but when we got to the desk, we were informed that we were late and that we had missed our tour. The lady we spoke to on the phone had given us the wrong information. In trying to remedy the situation, the lady at the desk was very unhelpful. The only thing she did was shove a complaint form at us and said that if the offices think the reason for appealing is justified, they will reimburse us. Naturally we never went on a tour or ever heard from them again.The only reason I have rated this museum a "3" is because I have been to the museum on previous occasions and the museum itself is interesting and everyone should see it. However, the service is terrible and attitudes in general are disgusting. I feel embarrassed to bring foreigners to my home country knowing that, despite it being quite pricey, it's a gamble on whether or not the people running these establishments actually know what they're doing.
Not great. It's a mission , boats break down , hassle getting tickets , everywhere you turn the X cons are looking to get a tip. Suggest you skip this one as its not what it's supposed to be about .

Impressive. We took the 5 o'clock tour, it was full booked so reservation is needed.First a ferry from Capetown to Robben island, took about 20minutes.Once we arrived on the island the big group is being split in three busses whowere already waiting for us. The tour with the bus took about 1.5 hour. A lot of information with year details and names about the (politcial) prisoners of Robben island. At the end a small tour, block F from Nelson Mandela where he stayed such a long time.At the end you can visit shops where u can buy souvenirs. Obvious it was the end of the day for the staff from the gift shop unfortanly they were not friendly or helpful. But overal a very interesting tour, definitely one I recommend if your in Capetown. A must see. We booked online 2 tickets for 600Rand.
Nelson Mandles Prison. Very insghtfull place for prisoners during Apartheid regime and the cuertly of these who ruled and oppressed the people of South Africa then ....Thankfully it has changed now .
So touching!. The lady who conducted our tour was a brilliant and captivating storyteller. Took my mother here and out of all the tours we did this was our favourite. Such powerful history.

Terrible. For an attraction with so much history and such a story to tell, the experience was brutal. This could be a truly great tour where visitors could learn about apartheid and Mandela etc, but instead it's an overhyped boat trip followed by a mindless shuttling around an island...It starts when you line up to get on the ferry. Even though you have pre-purchased your ticket, don't be surprised if you're in line for 45 minutes - the ferry does not depart on time. The ferry ride itself is OK although there are only 20 spots on the "viewing deck", after which you get to sit in the bottom of the ferry like cattle. Once you get to the island, you get on a bus which drives around the island with a host whose English and knowledge of the history is limited to the script he follows. The bus stops at 5 places along the way which have no real significance to Mandela or Apartheid. You are then let out at a "rest stop" which is basically an excuse for them to put up a shop where you have to buy drinks/food. After this, you get the prison tour by an ex-political prisoner. Our guide spent 20 minutes asking everyone where they were from and making some lame joke about each country. We then walked into the prison yard and into a large cell where multiple prisoners were kept. The only thing our guide told us was how much they talked about politics. NOTHING about the history, nothing about apartheid, nothing about what happened every day. We then walked down a hallway and he pointed out Mandela's cell. To be fair, it could have been any cell since there are no distinguishing marks or numbers on the cell. The worst part of all was at the end, the tour guide stood at the gate to the prison with his hand stretched out looking for money. For anyone visiting Cape Town, I would highly recommend you skip this. There are FAR better things you could do with your time.

Fascinating day tour to Robben Island. Our entire group really enjoyed the trip to Robben Island. A sobering tour with a former inmate guiding the group. The tour itself contained a great amount of detail and personal insight from the guide which made it much more engaging. The logistics of the tour were well organized. The ferry was very choppy and several members of the group were getting sea sick but once we reached land everything was fun very efficiently and professionally.

Hearded around in a big group...... It's a 'must do' in Cape Town because of the history but it could have been so much better. Getting on the buses for the island tour was shambolic but the tour itself was very informative and the guide was excellent. The prison tour was rushed and the group was far too big. The guide was good but I think It would have been better as an audio tour. Nowhere nearly enough time either. I guess nothing will change because the tour operator has the monopoly. Such a shame because given the opportunity, one could get much more out of the experience.

Great experience. I visited with my 8 year old daughter and she thoroughly enjoyed our tour. Granted, she didn't pay as much attention to the history aspect, but I did. I learned a lot and enjoyed the scenery.

Disappointing . I've been to Robben Island a number of times since the late 90's and unfortunately it gets worse with each visit. I was showing friends for the first time and apart from the guide at the prison and the guide on the bus it was very disappointing. They missed the house Madiba was in and his relationship with his guard, they skipped glad the island and the prison tour was a mess. You used to walk from the harbour and enter the same way as prisoners and get a feel for the place. We were driven 200yards in a ratty bus for no reason other than to have more people ambling around. All cells have been painted and stopped of any authenticity where before each one told a story and had mementoes. We were left to wander about with no real input from anyone. We didn't get to the shop until the boat was leaving so missed out. The boat out was late leaving (9:40 not 9am), so we were rushed. The boat back was an old one and so slow the next boat beat us back. The lack of scheduled times threw out afternoon plans into disarray. The gift shop half way round is a waste of time and it advertised books it didn't have. The information about the quarry was scarce to say the least. I visit Cape Town frequently and will never go back to the Island. It has been a cash cow for the many and lots of staff just stood there not bothering. Very sad that somewhere so important in South Africa's history has become a petty cash box for those running it. There was little emotion. Very upset and disappointed and will not recommend to anyone.

YOU SOON WON'T FORGET. We took the ferry from the V&A, on a bit of a windy day. They cancelled the ferry the day before due to weather but on our travel day, the ferry was running. It was a bit choppy but the rolling waves were fun. Everyone was laughing as waves splashed in. It was a warm summer's day. We docked at the wharf and had to walk to our bus waiting to give us a tour of the island. Our tour guide on the bus was very extremely knowledgable, given tours of Robben Island to very prominent people. We were surprised at how many people live on the island and how many animals exist there as well, including deer and copious amount of ibis. The views back towards Cape Town and Table Mountain are spectacular. Different vantage point for sure. We toured the island itself, including the limestone quarry where prisoners, for no reason, mined the rock. We ended our tour at the prison where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned. Our tour guide was a former prisoner. His details from his time imprisoned were startling and unforgettable. He showed us specifically which prison cell was Nelson Mandela's. We would highly recommend this tour.

Above my expectations!. I truly enjoyed this place. I thought it was going to be a tourist trap but I actually enjoyed to hear the experience from former prisoners and about Mandela's life there. I think this experience can be good or bad depending on the guide that you get....it will be all about their story!

Disappointed. Had a lot of expectations. So much history. I have read Nelson's Mandela's book - Long Walk to Freedom. Boat ride over was nice. Simple video provided some background but it was limited and hard to hear and if you were outside you didnt know it was going down. Bus ride around island was OK. Guide on the bus was funny and informative but there wasn't a whole lot there. It was scenic. Tour of prison by former prisoner was OK. Hard to understand the speaker. Lot of respect for him and his colleagues but we didn't get as much out of it as we were expecting. You have to do it when visiting but don't expect too much.
Powerful and moving. We had the most brilliant guide on our bus and had an unforgettable experience on Robben Island. Well worth the time -about 4 hours. I would highly recommend this tour.

Must do when in Cape Town - great insight into history of SA. We caught the ferry across to Robben Island where we were shown onto a bus. The bus takes you around the island (stopping for one stop off point) and a guide gives you a history of the island which is really interesting. At the end you are able to walk around the prison and have a tour from an ex-prisoner and see Mandela's cell. A very interesting trip which give you a great insight into the history of SA and its people.

Amazing but emotional. Tour guide was amazing. He gave you a really good insight into life on robben island although there were some very rude people who talked over him and were on their phones throughout. It was an amazing experience. But very emtional.

Interesting tour by former prisoners. After a rocky ferry ride (and the weather was calm) we went on this fascinating tour of the island and prison. The prison tour by a former inmate was the highlight. And as a bonus we saw whales from the boat. Pack some snacks as there is only a small shop on the island with a limited selection. Make sure you book tickets well I'm advance of your visit.

Historic. Robben Island is a good historical tour of the island itself and the famous apartheid-era political prison. I learned a lot about the island, which actually has a much richer history than I had imagined. The prison is kept in similar conditions from when it was operational, and all tour guides are former prisoners. You can get a lot out of the tour by simply speaking with them, in addition to seeing the facilities. Probably the biggest downside is that the boat ride takes 30-45min just to arrive and to return. Not a good tour if you are looking for something lighthearted.

Rewarding day. On our first visit to Cape Town, a couple of years ago we did not visit Robben island but have fixed that omission now. We thoroughly enjoyed it and found it very moving. Much of the day was made by our guide, Tom Moses, who was jailed here for 12 years. He brought the history and the significance alive in a most moving way. He was an excellent guide. The only let down was the poorly managed transport to and from the island. We queued for 45 minutes at V and A before we boarded and for the same length of time in the hot sun before we left the island for the mainland. There needs to be some shade provided and seats for the elderly if such delays are the norm.

Average Tour. We took the boat out to Robben island and were put on a bus which then showed us around the island. The guide on the bus was very informative. We then were shown into the prison where we met one of the old prisoners, who is now a tour guide. He spoke about life on the island, and it was really interesting. We then saw the cell that Nelson Mandela was in during his incarceration on the island. afterwards we returned to the boat and were taken back to Cape Town. Overall I felt that it was a bit of a let down. An audio tour would probably have been more informative as it was only a short meeting with the ex prisoner. Expected more for the amount of money spent.

Interteresting attraction with former prisoners giving tours. Definitely worth the visit and scenic boat ride to this attraction. Tour was a good pace and informative guides made it authentic. Book in advance since it sells out and it should be seen.

An important piece of history. I've heard people say that they weren't "impressed" by Robben Island, but I think that those people are missing the point: apartheid was not so very long ago and as of a little over 20 years ago, people in South Africa were being imprisoned for their political beliefs. Seeing the conditions they lived in, hearing first hand experiences from former prisoners, and walking through the cells will make that experience real in a way no book could. Our bus guide was excellent (they drive you around the island before going into the prison complex part) and we found this to be one of the most interesting parts of our stay in Cape Town. Book tickets in advance as they sell out!

Ran out of time. Booked on the 3pm boat returning at 7pm we were late leaving & as a consequence found ourselves being rushed to conclude what should have been an emotional & heart rending visit. Don't misunderstand, it was still a fantastic trip to see where Nelson Mandela & others were incarcerated & if you're in Cape Town then it's a must do trip ... but I'd suggest you book an earlier trip than 3pm to enable you a more leisurely opportunity to soak up all that can be available.
Boat ride to history. Inspiring visit to a diverse island with so much history. A must do trip. The island was more than a prison....

Very interesting but very rushed . I don't blame them for doing it the way they do because of sheer volume of people. You get herded onto the ferry, herded onto a bus, then shown around the island quickly before a tour of the maximum security with an old political inmate. Fascinating stories just very rushed through

There is only one Robben Island. The ferry and trip were booked on-line and you print your ticket. The organisation of the embarcation and disembarcation of the ferries was inefficient and the weakest part of the trip. We walked first with a guide who had been a prisoner there so could speak eloquently about the history and the experience. We were shown around the high security prison which is well-cared for and where the political prisoners were kept. Our guide finished with a challenge to the "born-frees" i.e. those born after 1990 ish: the prisoners have forgiven their white captors, but have the "born-frees"? Moreover, he quoted Nelson Mandela on the destructive effect of bitterness and hatred. Quite an amazing experience.Then there was a bus tour which was quite quick. We could easily have spent another three hours there and we would recommend that people leave their group afer the formal tour and just explore and read the many displays.

A must for locals and tourists. A visit to Robben Island is a must see for any local or tourist. Robben Island is accessed by a short boat ride from the most beautiful city in the world,Cape Town. Visiting the prison of Nelson Mandela who is renowned as one of the greatest statesmen the world has known is very special. The tour is well structured and very informative. Entering the prison cell of the great Nelson Mandela is spine-tingling and very poignant.

Fascinating but too many people per tour. Less people so I don't feel like a cow in a heard! the 55min ferry on way back compared to 15 catamaran on way there was annoying. Fascinating tour and still worth the trip.

the cell. This trip takes around 4 hrs and already the ferry trip with possible whale watching is pleasant. The guided tours on the island are well done. The bus drive should allow for some more stops to catch the ambiance of the island. The former prisoners are presenting their stories in a very impressive way. Not too sentimental or over emotional. All in all a perfect way to indulge into the history of SA.

A Moving Experience. It really brought home the cruelty of apartheid when we saw the conditions that political prisoners, including Nelson Mandela, were kept in. Our guide was a former prisoner himself, so gave us first-hand information. An excellent tour.

South African heritage!. This is truly a must for every South African and fantastic experience for visitors from abroad. The highlight for me was the guided tour by a man who spent 7 years of his life on the Island as a prisoner. The guides on the boat and bus need a bit more rounding to make them world class.

An evocative trip to Madiba's prison. A must do for anybody visiting Cape Town. This is the island where he and many comrades were incarcerated for years. Wiithin sight of Cape Town,but out of reach, it might have been a place where they saw out their days were it not for global pressure. The trip attracts thousands but they are efficiently processed, and everybody gets the opportunity to speak to a political prisoner imprisoned on the island. Seeing Madiba's cell with its bleak blanket was very moving. Go!

Poignant, moving insight into the life of prisoners. If you visit Cape Town, a trip to Robben Island is absolutely a must do as it shed lights on what the political prisoners went through during the apartheid years. The trip takes about 3 and a half hours, including the boat trip across Table Bay, and it's absolutely brilliant. Our bus guide - the bus tour takes about 45 mins - was informative, engaging and really funny, while the tour of the jail was conducted by a former political prisoner and was absolutely breath taking. One of the best tours I've ever done.

Good visit, but dependent on your guide. Take along a jacket if you wish to sit on the upper deck of the boat. It can get very windy and cold, but you get a nice view of the surroundings. When on bus, try to sit on the right side of the bus as most of the sights are on this end.We had a good bus guide who told about his experience with foreign heads of state whom he hosted. Lots of history and nice stories to be heard. There will be chance for a walk to visit the inside of the prisons and Mandala's cell too. Go and queue early. We had to wait for a second boat as the queue was long!

Amazing. Just to do it and get the experience. The guides are exprisoners. And I was amazed how they accepted their years being in prison. It seems they realised they reached the expectation to get equal rights for black and white. Writing this review I am still astonished.

Living history. Individuals who were imprisoned at Robben Island serve as "tour guides" in what is now a national historical site. This is an extraordinarily moving place, the cells so small and bare, Cape Town and freedom visible just across the bay. It will tell you much about the courage of those who fought apartheid.

Worthy. A "must do" perhaps, and talking to the ex prisoners was fantastic but it is a long tour (3 hours at least) and apart from the limestone quarry I was left feeling that the regimen wasn't as detestable as other prisoner experiences in other parts of the world today. I'm pretty sure this wasn't the intention!

An emotional journey. You hear such a lot about this island and although there are hundreds of visitors every day the guided manage to convey the history very well. There's a bus tour of the whole island with stops on the way. Our young guide was entertaining and informative. The tour of the actual prison was by a ex- prisoner who was fascinating. Get to the ferry early at peak times. It's a popular location.

A must see. Bought the ticket on the Internet. Remember to do that in good time because only a few tours per day and fully booked days before. The tour was on a very tight schedule. However very interesting to hear the ex-political prisoner tell us about life in incarceration. It was however too rushed and we would have loved to have more time to look at Mandela's cell before we were hurried forward to finish the tour. Another half an hour would have made all the difference as we would have had more time to ask questions. However a must see when you are in Cape Town.
A must see. This is history we forget at our peril. The logistics work smoothly. The guides, former prisoners, are knowledgable.

Interesting place. We were in Cape Town recently and while there we decided to take a boat trip to the island to learn more of the apartheid and nelson Mandela.While the island itself is not that spectacular the whole experience is a worthwhile trip,I know the tour bus guide was an added bonus as he made the whole experience even more intersting

Better than expected - by a mile. After some of the reviews here I was expecting a mass tourism horror. The queuing for the boat departure added to that. However, I understand logistically why it is run the way it is. And if you focus on the stories and information you quickly become absorbed and forget about all of the other people. Maybe it's my age ( 50 years old !!) but I was close to tears at the limestone quarry as the message of hood and spirit was so beautifully shared. Don't miss it and focus on what's important - the humanity and hope.As a bonus we were joined enroute by dolphins and three or four whales !

Very interesting but a little long. We enjoyed the tour of the island with our very knowledgeable guide. The prison tour was interesting but overlong. I understand that a restaurant might detract from the atmosphere but a couple of water fountains might help prevent visitors from dehydrating - or possibly give out some bottled water on the boat as part of the trip. On a hot day it is a very dry place.
Must see attraction. This was the highlight of my trip. So emotive & the tour is delivered in such an informative way, you feel you are back there with the prisoners.

A must visit place for those who love to know history!. A must visit place for those who love to know history! Feel little depressing during visit but you left with the inspiration from the greatest personalities who served more than 20 years in prison. This is 4 hour trip. Starts with ferry from V&A waterfront for about 30 minutes one way trip. Lucky people will get to see whales as well as seals on the way.

Moving Tour. The ferry ride over to the island is enjoyable, the tour round the island not so great as you don't get off except to buy a drink ad see the penguins, but the tour of the prison is incredibly moving and well worth doing. Couldn't go to Cape Town and not go there, almost a matter of showing respect.

Memorable. An absolute to do list in cape Town...à tribute to ALL those who fought for freedom.Excellent tour, you need to book all day for it.The guides on robben Island are ex Prisoners...Raymond & Nadine from Mauritius

A moment in history. Very enjoyable day, particularly as we had also been to Soweto and visited the home of Nelson Mandela so this was a must see for us. The cruise across to the island is most enjoyable with a magnificent view of Cape Town as you leave the waterfront. The tour is very well organised and you visit the cell where Nelson Mandela spent many long years and the guide who takes you through was once an inmate himself so that is very interesting. We were lucky to sight whales on the way back to Cape Town which was a bonus. If its hot make sure you wear a hat an apply that sunscreen! Oh and take some water with you too! This is a must see on any visit to Cape Town!

A Snapshot of Prison Life. I bought a ticket to go by ferry on one of the three tours per day to go to Robben Island as I wanted to see where Nelson Mandela had been imprisoned.The tour was on a very tight schedule and as soon as we landed we were put onto buses with an ex-political prisoner commentator and taken on a tour of the island. After a brief stop for drinks we were then driven to the prison and another ex-political prisoner told us about life in incarceration. It was interesting but far too rushed and I barely had time to look at Mandela's cell before we were hurried forward to finish the tour. Another half an hour would have made all the difference as we would have had more time to take some photos or to look at points of interest on the island eg the graveyard,
Interesting . Good to see the symbol of triumph of principles. Mush visit place while you are in Cape Town. Really friendly guidance and enjoy.

A must see. The Robben Island tour is a must see if you are interested in the history of Nelson Mandela and South Africa's dominant culture political practices. The tour is amazing and hosted by a member of the ANC who was jailed with Mandela. The resiliency of these men is akin to those revolutionary leaders Malcolm X, Marcus Garvey, Dubois and others.

Critical part of our history. Visiting Robben Island offered a somber reminder of our past as a country and the sacrifices made by our great leaders. The trip to the island is per boat and the journey in itself is a journey of whale, rob and penguin watching. Great tour and awesome reminder of our journey towards democracy!

Not to be missed - Very humbling. No visit to Cape Town would be complete without a visit to Robben Island. We were shown round the prison by Sparks who had served with Nelson Mandela. The whole experience - the prison, the quarry, the cells, the menu cards for all creeds and races were very thought provoking and humbling

Very interesting and heartbreaking. We visited Robben Island to se where Nelson Mandela among many other prisoners have been imprisoned for so many years. The visit was well organized. We were divided into buses which then started their tour from different spots to avoid a chaotic situation. We had a very good guide who told us the history of Robben Island. After we had visited some interesting places, and a penguin colony !, we went to the prison where a former prisoner, Moses, who had been imprisoned for almost 13 years told us about his experience there. It was heartbreaking! I admire him for being able to tell us about these awful years! I highly recommend a visit to Robben Island.

Interesting but too regimented. Tour of Robben Island and the prison that housed Nelson Mandela for decades is interesting but the objective seems to be to get as many through as quickly as possible. Not much chance to just wander around and explore on your own. As far as prisons go, Alcatraz was done much better.
Go. A good experience. Very informative tour. Boat ride to and from a bonus. Whale sighting on ride back.

A sobering experience. An in depth view of where Nelson Mandela was held prisoner for many years. Living conditions were more than harsh especially for political prisoners. Our guide was once a prisoner on Robben Island and provided an eye witness narration of the prison and its operation. If you are in Cape Town, do not miss this tour.

More than Mandela. This tour is definitely a good idea for anyone wanting to learn more about the impacts and death of apartheid. The tour begins with a bus tour of the island. You see the main areas of the island including the little guards village where around 200 ppl continue to reside. After the bus tour you are taken to the main jail block where Mandela spent so many years of his life. The guides around the main jail are former political prisoners so they provide a very personal account of the time. I really liked that touch because I was a little worried the jail would become a shrine to Mandela. Each cell has short stories written other prisoners and in general there is a lot of information about the others aside from Mandela.Highly recommend this tour.

Sobering experience but with optimism. Be prepared for a choppy crossing but well worth it...you might even spot a whale on the way. Tours were conducted by ex-prisoners who brought to life the isolation and hardships...all in tantalising view of the mainland. Half of the tour is by bus, including a visit to the limestone quarry, while the rest is within the prison buildings and courtyards.We learned of privations but also of fellowship and education initiatives run by the prisoners, and came away thoughtful but encouraged by what eventually came out of it.

Solemn awareness. The trip to Robben Island by the ferry can be a bit "wavy". Go early in the AM before the winds start. Stark yet beautiful island. The history is amazing. The sense of overwhelming political horror that was endured by Mandela and others is only compounded by the fact it all took place not that long after the end of Nazi Germany.

an important part of history but unaffordable for most. the visit to Robben island formed the base of our staff end of year function. having a range of staff from diverse backgrounds and ages provided a moving sketch of our history - many would not have been able to afford this if not for our organisation funding it. made me realise that this world heritage site is not available to most South African families - to pay almost R1000 for a family is unaffordable - we must do something to make it more accessible. the input from various guides is amazing but i have to give an average point given its unaffordability

Tourist trap. Visited years ago when it first opened to the public. Far cry from it once was. Just a money making tourist spot now. Much of original features gone. Some idiot official in their wisdom painted over graffiti.

Hopeless tour guide. As a South African, my family and I were looking forward to the Robben Island tour. the bus tour around the island was done exceptionally well by a very informative tour guide. unfortunately that came to a grinding halt when we embarked on the prison tour by a guide known as ZoZo. this guy was arrested as a student and was kept on Robben Island. that is about it. his English was so terrible that we as south Africans were battling to understand a word he was speaking. he kept harping about "Torecha" (torture) and the horrible food they were served which resulted in many deaths. as the only south Africans on the tour surrounded by many foreigners from all over the world, we were embarrassed. we noticed that they lost interest in this guy as eventually even stopped paid attention to him after he failed to understand a question, therefore unable to answer. he kept asking if we had any "Qeshens" (Questions) how could we possibly have questions when he could not even speak clear English. when there was a question... he did not understand it and gave a totally useless answer. considering what Mandela fought for and the state of the country now... as a south African it was depressing being on the tour. his legacy is clearly not going to live on
Excellent trip to Robben Island. Excellent value for money. Great historical content. Friendly and welcoming staff and guides. I highly recommend the tour.

History, never to be forgotten. The tour conducted by a former inmate is intriguing, informative and provides the visitor with an insight into life in prison on the island. Obviously the highlight, if it can be called that, is being able to see Nelson Mandela's cell. A great trip and also get great views of Cape Town from the large catamaran as you power your way to the island.

A must see - for many reasons. When in cape town theres no way around Robben Island and the story on Mandela and apartheid. The ferry trip it self gives you the opportunity to see whales if in season and we where lucky enough to spot whales going there and back, even though ti was december. Again with our luck we got a real good guide on the bus tour around the island before we were handed over to the last guide who was a former inmate.Much of the content of the stories you probably already know but it is still interesting to learn and hear from a former inmate.Remember to bring money for tipping. Including boatride and waiting in line for the both in cape town the trip is a total of 4 hours

A trip down memory lane . Really awesome experience and we had a fantastic time. Listen carefully to past inmates and ask as many questions as you can... they really know a lot that happened behind the scenes. A DEFINITE must see

Another Highlight of my trip thanks to Go TouchDown Tours!. What can I say about Robben Island?? It was an incredible experience that will humble you when you hear the stories from actual inmates who were also imprisoned on this island when Nelson Mandela was there...truly an incredible trip! Thanks to Go TouchDown tours, we had this also included in our package as opposed to others who had to pay for this and other excursions out of pocket!

A sombering place. You cannot go across the water from Cape Town to Robben Island without being transported back to a different and darker time in history. Visiting the gaol and hearing from forner prisoners, who are the guides there, is a sobering lesson in the struggle for human rights.

Educational & Moving. I have several good friends who are South Africans who told me all about Nelson Mandela even before I visited Cape Town. Certainly this was on my to-do list & off I went one day - little did I know what i was up for. The island, not only preserved, but the guides were informative, genuine & passionate about sharing the struggles and discrimination of Africans due to their darker skinned colour. Towards the end of the tour, it was then taken over by this guide who used to be an inmate and this was when the tour started to hit our nerves hard when he shared his own personal stories when he did his time back in prison. I was deeply moved as to how people like him could even be passionate enough to come as a guide to those from all over the world and step back onto the grounds that probably were the darkest days of his life, just to educate and inform people what he had gone through. It certainly brought a whole new level of respect to these people, Nelson Mandela included on how they had endured the tough times until the days where freedom for them was fought & achieved.

A must in cape town!. This place goes without saying. I shouldn't even need to write a review...I mean who wouldn't wnat to go to the prison where Nelson Mandela spent almost 18 yrs of his life in?? There is just so much history to catch up on as well..The tour guides are brilliant and be prepared to get a good lecture on history from an EX-prisoner of Robben Island themselves!! Get your tickets for only 300 rands directly from the Robben Island museum situated at the water front. We bought tickets at 1:45pm for the ferry that left at 3pm and we were back by around 6pm :).

Good tour not to be missed.. This is a great tour not to be missed especially if one is into African history. Our tour guide on the bus was good explained everything quite well. Our prison tour guide was fairly good- could have been better by telling jokes, being less serious etc. Otherwise great tour!

Moving.. We visited the island on our last day in South Africa and I was intrigued to learn more about the island, and particularly the history around Nelson Mandela's incarceration. It is really moving to see where he was held prisoner, where he worked and the conditions he and his fellow inmates were forced to live in. Truly moving and hard to believe it was ever considered acceptable.

Historic and moving. The ferry ride over was a bit dreary due to heavy fog. The actual tour of the island and prison was important to see because of its historic significance. We found both the guides on the bus and in the prison difficult to understand. Still it was impressive and well worth doing.

Interesting Tour of the Place. Robben Island is an interesting place and also a big one. When visiting there, you are taken around by bus. You don't get off at the stops. There is a guide on the bus that tells you about the places. I had a very interesting, knowgalable and funny guide. He also claimed to have seen Nelson Mandela personally. His stories were very fascinating and he interacted with the passengers on board, to show that every country had a part in shaping Robben Island. At the final stop on the island we got out and toured inside the main prison, where Mandela, amongst others, was held. The guide changed to a different one, who was imprisoned in Robben Island when Mandela was there too. To get to the island, you need to buy a ticket in the Robben Island Museum that is at Waterfront or online. The cruise sets off from the lower floor of the museum and lasts about 15-20 minutes.

Knowledgable History Tour - Must do Trip!!. The tour got of to great start from the port where we were greeted by Humpback Wales (what a bonus). Tour was very extensive with History from the Leper Colony to the modern day political. Thought it was very informative that the tour guides (we had) were former prisoners.This is a must do trip

Why wouldn't you go?. You must book. You must be there at least 30 minutes before the scheduled departure. You should be aware that the journey can be very rough.I really enjoyed the whole experience from the journey over - I like rough journeys - to the journey back. Even rougher.We disembarked and made our way over to the coaches. I was disappointed to get one that was almost full. But we got a window seat and so it was fine. Our guide explained that he didn't normally do the tours but they were short and so he had been pressed into service! As soon as he started talking the coach was in thrall. He had met everyone and seen everything and had a story not only about s load of supposed celebrities, but also each country the tour party came from. So stories about, Mr Mandela himself, through Hilary Clinton - please don't let her be the next President - to Mr Obama.his delivery was excellent and we all enjoyed the coach ride. We got off at the prison and were met by a former inmate who was to be our guide. Unfortunately he didn't project his voice and so most of the tour was a struggle to try and make out what he was talking about.We then had to almost run to make the boat back. We walked quickly from the prison and made it by about 10 people.So, go for the history, and the part it played, not only in the making of modern SA, but also for the previous three or four hundred years.

Incredibly emotional experience. It has a great historical significance. The staff on the island are well informed and they know their subject matter very well. It's a very emotional experience but also very inspiring. I would encourage tourist and even South African citizens to visit the island because it's truly remarkable

Very moving. We were.very interested in the recent history of the island and moved by the tour conducted by an ex political prisoner. We booked this tour through our travel company weeks before our departure and we're glad we did as we understand it is not always possible to obtain tickets close to the date.

Centrally located. We occupied 2 apartments. Couldn't have found a better location to spend four nights. Apartments well equipped & comfortable. Wish we could have spent a few more days, just taking it easy enjoying the surroundings.

The heart of African History. This is a must do on your visit to Cape Town. If you want a life changing experience, when you learn all that Nelson Mandela did to stand up for the people in this country, and you see the tiny room he lived in and maintained hope for 17 years, you will leave Robben Island a different person.
Very interesting historical site. The guide made the trip as unfortunately he had been detained there for 2 years. He shared personal stories that brought this fairly bleak site to life.

Robben Island Dec 2, 2015. Ferry to island from Cape Town. Ferry trip bonus with whales and seals seen during visit Dec 2, 2015. Riding on top deck gave the best views of wildlife and Cape Town with mountain background. Went from ferry to bus with short tour of island and very informative bus tour guide. Saw the rock quarry, some of the associated buildings and history of island. Tour of facility was done by a former prisoner who spent three years in the prison during 1970's. Walk through of the prison and viewing yards and cells with comments on life from day to day by tour guide. Should not miss this.

Easy booking and superb trip. Far better than the reviews has suggested. Booking done on a smart phone and checked boat via app booking. No confusion at allBoat trip added bonus with whale watching and superb views thrown in.Large part of tour spent on coach listening to a highly entertaining talk from guide. Basically easiest way to manage large number of people there to see a small prison cell. Very informative trip. Well worth the money

Understanding South Africa. A visit to Robben Island is necessary for an understanding of South Africa as it is today. This is were the leaders of South Africa spend much of the lives. Nelson Mandella was there for 23 years. There is a short bus tour to the former prison. There a former political prisoner gives you tour of the museum (former prison). This is gives one a incite into what forces formed the South Africa of today.My wife thinks I should have given this 5 stars

Thought provoking. This tour is very interesting. It starts with a bus tour which circles the island and stops at most points of interest. Unfortunately, we were not allowed off the bus to inspect sites freely. The whole bus trip was a little rushed for my liking. And depending what side of the bus you're seated the views can be limited. Hint: sit on the left hand side. The bus then drops you at the prison where upon disembarking you are greeted by your tour guide who happens to be an ex-prisoner. This is where the tour gets very interesting. Our guide was fantastic. Funny yet very knowledgable. We got a real sense of what the prison must have been like back in the day. Some of the stories he told were both tragic and amusing. The boat ride back to Cape Town was a bonus as we followed a whale for around 10 minutes. All in all the whole half day tour was worth it but certain aspects could be improved (or just slowed down).

Enjoyed. This was a must see attraction site. We took a ferry over, very comfortable. The history was well preserved about President Mandela. The staff was great. They really had the tours organized and timed well.

Impressive. The tours are given by ex-prisoners, so they tell from personal experience. It's impressive to see how these prisoners have been locked up for years in such bad conditions, some because they've had the wrong vision according to other people. In the B cell block you can read stories of prisoners. You get to see both group and solitary cells.

Nelson Mandela's hell. A must for anyone with a conscience. I wasn't quite prepared for for the humility I felt after visiting Robben Island. I don't think anyone can be by just reading about it. Being shown and told about Mandela's brutal incarceration by ex-political prisoners who shared some of his 18-year hell here was a mind blower that will stay with me forever. If you have a heart then half a day on Robben Island really is a must. And don't be surprised if you come away with thoughts and opinions you didn't necessarily have when you went there!

Always wanted to see and visit. It all started on a boat a great day with good weather and calm sea. The boat or ferry trip is fantastic beautiful views and pleasant the island is very interesting and the guide we had was rather informed about everything he was an ex prisoner and had marvelous stories to tell glad we could see it all

MAKE A BOOKING. VERY busy so make sure you prebook. Bus tour before prison tour excellent. Prison tour was brief - depends on individual who leads tour apparently. Gift store offers historical info as well as souvenirs

Over-rated and spoilt by the local tourists. Imagine a giant bun-fight from start to finish .... that's pretty much how it is. Everyone pushing and shoving and elbowing everyone else out of the way. Frankly I was stunned at how appalling badly behaved the local tourists were, compared with foreign tourists. Don't know why they bother to go if they cannot be courteous enough to listen to the guide and have no interest in what is being said. I was ashamed for them!

A Trip Through History. I could not imagine visiting Cape Town and not seeing the cell that held Nelson Mandela for most of his incarceration. The brutal face of Apartheid is made very plain here. It does matter who your bus guide is. Make sure you get one that you clearly understand. Also, on the ride out make sure to board the THEMBELIKE. The other boat is painfully slow. Even if the slow boat is leaving first, wait for the THEMBELIKE. It will catch the other boat, pass it, and disembark before it ever makes it to the other shore.

Must-see but allow plenty of time. Visiting Robben Island should be on every Cape Town traveler's to-do list. Be sure to allow ample time - it took us 5 hours total, from lining up at 12:30pm for our 1pm tour, to getting back and off the boat at 5:30pm. We must've been on the slow boat since it took nearly an hour going over. Once there, it's a moving experience that somewhat depends on the guide(s) that you get. Well worth doing and experiencing even a bit of the important history that took place there.

Eye and mind opening. . Robben Island is a must see if you're visiting CT. Go early, I took the 11:00am tour and noticed when I returned that the crowds were much larger. If you can, sit on the right side of the bus for the non-walking portion, your camera will thank you later. The prison tour was amazing to say the least, the stories that Tom Moses, a former prisoner, shared with us were hard to imagine. This tour was both somber and eye opening, but I left with good stories to tell and will forever be changed.

Could have offered more. The trip is definitely worth doing and having both a young local called Kent (very funny) and a former prisoner sharing the guided tour of the island presented the perfect balance. Enthusiasm and sobering reality.I feel that there could have been a lot more "museum" type spaces where you can walk through at your leisure with more photos of "life" on the island or in South Africa generally, placed either on the island or within the gateway museum. The highlight of the gateway are the plaques in the waiting area and the video on the top floor. This was lacking. Otherwise, very impressed.

A wonderfully magical experience.. A tour that uses ex prisoners to take you through the experiences of life on the island by the tyrannical government at the time.The tour was fascinating and always kept you wanting more information and a great look back in history.

Historic and Cultural. We enjoyed the trip to Robben Island, if you don't like cultural experiences then don't waste your time going there. But, just the fact that Nelson Mandela was imprisoned here and that an ex prisoner gives you the tour is worth it.

Sobering and educational, easily accessible from Cape Town. After taking a short ferry ride from the Waterfront, you are given a 20- to 30-minute bus tour of the island then a walking tour of some of the prison where Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners were held during the Apartheid era (the island also shows signs of earlier uses, including a leper colony). The tours are led by former prisoners, lending an extra air of authenticity and urgency. Highly recommended.

Interesting. Soul moving. The ferry ride over went smoothly and you are able to get some great shots looking back to Capetown and Table Mountain. On arrival we got on a bus which took us for a short ride and our guide explained about Robben Island.Afterwards we went on a tour of the prison by an ex prisoner. This was great to hear what they were subjected to and how they were treated which was poorly. The guard dogs were treated better than the prisoners. However it was on the walk from the prison to the ferry - the prisoners 'long walk to freedom' that really got me emotional. Taking the same walk the men did to their freedom, gave me goose bumps and I felt like I had a few souls walking along side me.

Insight into the political prisoners' experience. While it does take at least 30 minutes to and back from island via ferry, it is not only a sight to see but the tour guides speak from a personal experience so truly moving. The lime quarry where there was a "cave" is where not only did they work under harsh conditions, but it was their bathroom and their dining room. It was amazing how they all chose to work together, and teach each other and SURVIVED!

A Must Do. I agree with the last review posted on here, it is great, but needs better organisation.The boat takes about 40 minutes, get there early as it will be busy and the journey can be quite rough. Once you get to the Island you are herded on to small buses and taken off. Its an amazing slice of history but the actual tour could have been slicker. It annoyed me that people paid to go on this trip but then happily spoke over the tour guide, which was a shame, as he had so much to say of all of which was first hand and interesting.But definitely worth a trip.

Interesting but the guide's presentation was difficult to follow. We toured Robben Island on November 4, 2015. It was unseasonably hot; the ferry to the isalnd was nearly full; coming back, the tour operator had to add a ferry boat to accommodate everyone leaving the island. We were glad we toured this historic venue, but the tour involves a fair bit of walking and then sitting on benches inside the former prison. The island has few amenities for tourists. However, it is possible to buy a soft drink and some kind of snack while you are waiting for the bus that will take you around the island before your group tours the historic prison facilities.

Not enough time. You are ferried from the V&A Waterfront. When you arrive you board buses for your tour of the island. You are stopped in front of several locations and the guide gives you the history of the location and its significance. After visiting several places you are stopped and allowed to exit the bus once during the tour. In this location there are restrooms, a light house and a beautiful view of Table Mountain. This is a great location for a picture with Table Mountain. It would have been nice to have more time, on your own even, to explore these other areas more. I think it is not allowed as a way of preservation. You are then taken to the maximum security prison. The tour guide is a former prisoner. He had a lot to share. His insight was invaluable. The only down side is that our tour guides accent made it difficult to understand everything that was said. I think this is and should be expected. Well worth the educational experience.

Needs better organisation. The boat trip over takes about 40 mins and can be a bit rough, go on the smaller catamaran if you can as it's quicker and smoother. When we disembarked on the Island things were a bit chaotic as the guides tried to assemble people into small groups. The tour itself was o.k. but I think this Island could be a fantastic tour if the authorities got some one professional to set it up as a proper operation. It seems they want as many people as possible on the 4 tours a day and not really bothered what they take home with them as an impression.
History must do!. History, panoramic views, reality checj, its all in this tour. If its windy, the boat will be a challenge...

I hesitated over excellent because I can't tell if the discomfort of the subject matter put me off a little.. The ferry was exhilarating - we saw a whale and a family group entertained with acapella singing. The bus tour guide was great, funny and brightened the potentially grim mood with pointing out springbok and penguins. The prison itself was interesting - perhaps it depends upon your particular guide and their relationship with the place. I didn't feel able to ask the questions I had - which cell was his? Why did he come back and not stay away? Has he made peace with the place now? Incredible experience, though.

you have to!. to be in capetown and not going would be an absolutely shame informative, up and personal because of the fact that ex political prisoners are openly sharing their personal experiences and ready to take any questions you may have. i was and still am deeply impressed. thank you, it again opened my eyes and hopefully take the experience with me.

Glad I Went. Going to visit a former prison is always an emotional experience for me. I can feel the pain of incarceration still in the air. Robben Island was used to imprison political prisoners, some of whom set off bombs. Like Alcatraz in the United States, Robben Island is now history.
Amazing experience. Guided tour by actual prisoner was heartfelt and authentic. He shared his heart and was extremely truthful about his thoughts, doubts and convictions.

A must see when in Cape Town. Really interesting bus tour round the island with a very knowledgeable guide followed by a talk from an ex- prisoner. A real insight into life under apartheid. Difficult to believe it is such recent history and a lesson to us all in tolerance and forgiveness.

Pleasure and History!. Robben Island trip is both relaxing and educative. The tour guides are knowledgeable with great sense of humour. Meeting one of the former prisoners who works there gives you a feel of how life was during the struggle for freedom. You also get a chance to see the Penguins. Ensure you book your tickets early and arrive at least 30 minutes before the scheduled departure as there are long queues.

An must see part of South Africa's history. I initially chose to go to Robben Island without knowing too much about its' history and just because "its one of the things you do in Cape Town" but got from it so much more than I expected. The tour provides a bus ride around the island as well as the tour of the prison. Very interesting to hear from an ex-prisoner as well as see what prisoners were subjected to. Don't overlook this attraction, a must see.

Very interesting - another must do!. Initially we were not going to take this tour and decided to.. thank goodness; as it was well worth it. Very educational and interesting to see, feel and learn first hand one great man's plight and fight for freedom. The actual prison portion is narrated by a real prisoner of this prison and people could ask questions. The ferry ride over and back was enjoyable and we were so glad to take this tour instead of bypassing it. Whew!!!

Very nice . Nice visit and lot of knowledge from the guides. The first was at the bus, no that comfortable, hot and can't see every. The second was a very big group inside the prison, couldn't hear that well the guide.. Was nice.

World Heritage site needs upgrading. This was my second visit. The boat trip to and from Robben island is spectacular on a clear day - there is something quite haunting about seeing Table Mountain standing out in stark splendour against a blue sky. It must have been a terrible reminder for those incarcerated there, whether prisoners, or leprosy victims to be so near, but yet so far. My biggest disappointment with both trips is that you are only allowed limited access on the island. There is so much of historical interest, but you are not allowed to get off the bus - even to take photos - until you get to the prison where you can walk around with a guide and take photos and see Mandela's cell and the yard, with its interesting history of the political prisoners. (Photos are from first trip in 2011)

Left a bit to be desired. I know this is an incredibly important piece of history, but the tour and the island was pretty lacking. I thought too much time was devoted to the fact that people were treated badly at the prison than to the history and interesting stories to come out of it. A nice video would have also been good. The prisoner story is a good idea, but it could have been so well done.
Historical visit. Informative and historical trip. Guides have interesting stories. Bus tour of the island provides a view point of more then just the prison.

Nice tour.. Interresting tour. A lot of information is given by ex political prisonners. There is a tour arround the island by bus. You can see de celblocks as wel. Check the weather before you wanna go because sometimes the ferry's won't go if the weather is too bad. Easy to find in the Waterfront.

Definitely worth a visit. Best time to go over is on the first ferry. You're met by a guide and escorted onto a bus where you are taken around the island. The guides are usually ex inmates that will inform you of the events that went on, especially when Nelson Mandela was imprisoned. It was so informative. Tip: we pre-booked tickets 3 weeks prior to arriving in Cape Town.

Heritage Site. Although this is a world heritage site, the visit is not well organized and you visit with a mix of other language groups which do not aid in getting to see as much of the island as you would like. The prison visit occupies much of your time and the bus around the island is not as good as we would have liked.

Very moving experience. We really enjoyed our trip to Robben Island. We booked in at 9.00am as we knew it lasted for about 4 hours and the boat left on time. The boat staff were great and the boat trip over was pretty quickly. The tour of the island was very interesting and we found we knew very little about the history of the island - we thought it was like Alcatraz but the island houses more than just the prison. The tour of the prison itself was the highlight. It was incredibly moving to be shown around by a former prisoner. They're the only people who can explain what it was really like and I found myself moved to tears on several occasions. A really wonderful trip and I would strongly recommend it to anybody who visits Cape Town. We also saw whales just off the coast of the island and on our boat trip back which was great.

Ex-Prisoner Guide around a historic landmark. We booked online and it worked well. There were huge queues for tickets. So well worth it. The trip via boat is 20minutes. If u sit up top in the open be prepared to get wet. On arrival you are either placed on buses or start with a prison tour. We started with the prison tour. The guide was super informative and an ex-prisoner. He was to the point providing context in an honest way. He encouraged questions and was easy to understand. The bus tour was also good. The guide pointed out animals, buildings and plants. Frequent stops for photo opportunities. However, it was difficult to follow what she was saying at all times. We recommend you pay particular attention to follow all of the English. All-in-all a good trip and worth going. It takes 4 hours and costs approx R300 pp. Leaving from the V&A waterfront.

Interesting - but slightly unusual. Fascinating afternoon visit - Long wait for the boats - First bit where were are jammed into small old fashioned coaches was not great - and then we had to keep jumping on and off - but the second bit where we were shown Nelson Mandela's cell by an ex political prisoner who actually spent time imprisoned on Robben Island was very moving and informative.

Experience way much more than what u paid for.. U need to take the ferry from V&A Waterfront ferry terminal.Arrival earlier by 1 hours. 30mins is not enough if u like to have a concise understand in a well-organised summary of Sth Africa's history.Both ways to and fro the island, we saw whales activity. Great deal huh!!!Once u arrived on the island, u would be directed to the bus which takes u ard the island with a tour guide who was the ex-inmate there. Nothing beats hearing from the person who experience it all.Saw some reptile or turtle-like in action. Quite many of them around, all moving fast. haha.Prison tour is the climax where u would visit Mendela's cell of 18 yrs.A great trip which I will hold close to my heart for a long time.Great job done in conserving this island and its history.Cape Town tour isn't complete without this visit to the island.

ROBBEN ISLAND IS A MUST. This was a very moving experience. We were taken round the island by bus with a guide who was very passionate about Robben Island. It was very interesting and informative. After going round the island we were then taken round the cells by a man who was a prisoner there for 3 years. The whole experience was very moving. Book your tickets before you go there is always a queue to buy tickets.

Dissapointing. Unfortunately this tour did not live up to expectations Our bus guide made comments that were uninformed and plainly incorrect and really appeared to have very little understanding or knowledge of the political history of South Africa. For example, she did not provide any context as to Robert Sobukwe's segregation from other political prisoners on the island.Our ex-political prisoner, who led the prison tour itself, was barely understandable to me as an ex-South African. Members of our group who were from other countries could not follow him at all. Much more information should have been provided through static displays as a minimum. A minimal effort to provide information in other languages other than English would be appropriate given the fact that more than half the visitors were European.If you are going to Robben Island do your homework beforehand.

An intensely moving experience.. I was moved to tears on our visit here. I could not believe that a man could survive this inhumanity and still retain his own humanity and sense of forgiveness. If you visit Cape Town then you must visit Robben Island. It is hot and dusty, many of the guides are former prisoners and a few are former guards.This is a unique and cathartic experience and should not be missed.

A must see but could be a better experience.. They tell you to queue up 45 minutes in advance and then the boat was 35 minutes late! It's all a bit disorganised, no communication (they made announcements but it was unintelligible). In the end you wander down to a bus which takes you around the island with a humorous narrative from a guide. A visit to the jail and Nelson Mandela's cell is moving and the tour with a political prisoner was the highlight. The views of Cape Town are fantastic.

Worth the Boat Ride. I booked my tour of Robben Island several months before I left the United States since I had heard it can be difficult to obtain tickets. This is a site not to be missed. The guides are former detainees of the prison. They provide first-hand accounts of what it was like to be imprisoned on the island. Mandela's cell is a humbling site. You also see remnants of other uses of the island, such as the "Lepers' Graveyard" and you have great views of Table Mountain from Robben Island. The boat ride can be a bit rough, but do not let that deter you. Robben Island is worth the ride.

Well worth a visit. Very interesting visit. You go there by boat, and as it was November we saw a couple of whales on the way, literally hundreds of seals on the way back and another couple of whales.You get taken round the island on a tour bus with a guide, the second part of the tour you are shown round by an ex-political prisoner. You'll see the tiny cell occupied by Nelson Mandela for 18 long years and you'll find out what life was like for prisoners.It was three hours well spent.

Museum with a message. Due to a lack of time to invest (probably 4/5 hs needed)and Marilyn not having her sea legs with her ,we followed our hotel managers suggestion that the museum on the waterfront , from where the ferries depart to the island, would be an ample substitute-it ticks most boxes other than actually being there.. She was right-the museum is modern but goes back in time to remind us of darker times in SA.. It tells the story of Apartheid,the struggles,Mandela and many other political prisoners . There was a special,and moving exhibition and film on the anniversary return visit of many of the prisoners to the island in 2005 . Educational and poignant at the same time.I should add that there is also an excellent film running continuously on the life of Mandela in the Cape Town Museum

Powerful Experience. A Must-do in Cape Town.. I truly don't think you can come to Cape Town without visiting Robben Island. It's a huge part of the history and a very important site.Book in advance as it sells out quickly. Don't just show up expecting to go out as you will likely be disappointed. The water is pretty rough normally, and if it's really rough or it's raining, apparently the tours get cancelled. People were sick on board so I don't know how bad it has to get for them to cancel.If you get a chance to choose your watercraft, avoid the Jester. It's old and slow. I took the Thandi coming back and even though it left after Jester, it passed it handily and arrived much sooner. The less time you have to spend on those rough waters the better!It's organized chaos when you arrive at the dock and board the buses that take you around the island. Don't just take the first bus they tell you to go to. They sent me to a bus that was full where there was a nearly empty one right beside it and I boarded that one instead, getting a nice window seat right up front.The guide will tell you a bit about the island and its former inhabitants, stopping at a few points of interest including the stone quarry where the prisoners worked. Then you go inside cell block B and see Nelson Mandela's quarters and get an explanation from a former prisoner how they were treated.All-in-all a very interesting and powerful visit. Not to be missed.

DO NOT MISS ROBBEN ISLAND!. Due to high winds and heavy seas, we almost missed going to Robben Island, and that would have been a pity. On the only day that the ferry was running because the channel between Robben Island and Cape Town had calmed, the ride there was beautiful and offered great views of Table Mountain, Lion's Head, Devil's Peak and Cape Town. The ride back, however, was a total E TICKET (for those of you who remember Disneyland in the 50s and 60s). The sights on the island are limited, but the tour, led by former inmates, was absolutely fascinating! Our tour guide had been imprisoned on the island for 6 years immediately following Nelson Mandella's transfer to another facility on the mainland and brought the atrocities of South Africa's former apartheid government to life. It is a story of survival, inspiration, guts and shear determination that must be kept alive! I wondered how old our guide was, but when I found out that he had been arrested and convicted when he was 20 years old, this man who appeared to be in his late 70s was only 51 years old! What a shock! This is living history. NOT TO BE MISSED!!!

Excellent recent historical attraction. A must place to visit when you visit Cape Town. The tour delivered by an ex inmate who spent five years from the age of 20 for political unrest gave an emotional and captivating insight into life in the prison and the various stages of detention. A first class visit. Booking is essential and the trip to the island could be bumpy in high winds.

More than the prison. On the tour you get to see more than just the prison and really get to see the whole island which is interesting. But seeing the prison and the cell is definitely the highlight and quite an experience.

Robben Island Visit. This is our second time to Robben Island, and although the majority of guides are ex prisoners, our latest guide, Lionel Davis (Google him) was a better quality prisoner, if that makes sense. he was there when new prisoner blocks were built, which may sound good, but they had to sleep with very thin blanket on new concrete floors which were still drying out, so pretty damp and cold.Apart from the usual sections which are covered by all the tours, we had time to explore more of the Island, which had a fair amount of wild life running about. One thing which was common to both Lionel, and our guide on previous occasion was that they did not seem to be resentful of the experience,and in some cases they ended up with an education which would normally have been denied to Black South Africans. Another comment Lionel made was with respect to the different diets for White, Coloured, and Black prisoners. Well worth the visit

A very moving tourist attraction. A word of advice be on time for your boat. I was held up getting to the boat on another tour and had to go to the office to change my trip time. I was told they did not change tickets on the day and it had to be done 48hrs in advance. The short story is they changed my ticket asking me for 50 rand to do this, and was after some discussion. They were reluctant to do this I was ready to walk away but they don't give refunds which is outrageous. The trip was informative and the nature and wild life on Robben Island is worth a look. I'm glad that I went it was informative and I was moved by the history of the island.

interesting.!. To see Robben Island one must book a ferry ride at the waterfront, there is a large complex which houses all the information about this haunting island. This tour is really a full day experience and one not to miss if staying in Cape town. The normal tour to Robben Island takes approx 4 hours , including the two half-hour ferry rides. Ferries depart at the Clock Tower precinct at the V&A Waterfront. . Ferry tickets cost R300 for adults and R160 for children under 18. Currently the ferries operate at 09h00, 11h00 and 13h00 There is a small shop on the island for buying refreshments and souvenirs. Take a jacket as the sea breezes can get chilly crossing over the harbour.

Emotionally filled day. The visit to Robben Island is enlightening as well as emotional. When you learn about the men incarcerated here for the reason of apartheid it can sadden your heart. The best part is understanding how the inmates and jailers connected on humanity. This is a must see in South Africa. 46664

A must do visit but.... This was a very worthwhile trip which really made you think about what it must have been like to be a prisoner on Robben Island. But it all seemed a bit rushed. Boats are every 2 hours but you struggle to complete the visit the visit properly in this amount of time. Our guide was still trying to explain things about the prison when the boat was due to leave in a couple of minutes. Quick walk back to the dock then off. No time to wander around a bit on your own, get a drink or look through the shop. But 4 hours would be too long. And hopefully you do not get a group who talk when the guide is talking or ask stupid questions.
Just OK. This tour is just OK, if you are pressed for time leave this one out. There are ton's of amazing things to do in Cape Town that are much more interesting and fun to do.

An important visit to make.. I had the opportunity to visit the island using the first ferry which left the Robben Island Gateway at 9:00am. The trip over was about 30 minutes and on a catamaran style boat. It is a bit of a rough ride over so if you get seasick it might be advisable to take some gravol in advance.The tour experience itself was well managed with ex political prisoners providing first accounts of the experience there. It is truly a harsh location and you can see why political prisoners were banished there. It is a tough visit because of the history but well worth it.

Interesting and thought provoking . Great half day out while in Cape Town. Missed this last visit so has to see this time. Nice 30min boat trip out to the island. Once there met by guide who shows you to a coach. Then begins a trip round the island with several places to see. Told about the history and events that shaped the island and the people and prison. Then dropped off at the prison itself. Guide was an ex political prisoner from the prison what takes about another hour explaining the workings and stories of prison life. Can get a bit of a feel for what it must have been like to be a prisoner there. Grim. Thought provoking stuff. Just the right amount of time without being boring or skimping on detail. Then boat back to main Quay in Cape Town. Great morning out. Well priced and we'll run with top guides. Well worth a visit.

A truly emotional experience. Although not a 'fun' visit we really do recommend visiting Robben Island. A former prisoner can guide you around and of course there is so much history to see and read about. The ferry takes about 50 mins each way and can be rough, we took sea sick pills. Buy tickets online to avoid the queues.

Gets you in the feels.... This was something I had wanted to do for years, and I actually felt emotional on the ferry over to the island. The bus tour was interesting, and getting some of the background info was helpful for those who don't know a lot about it all.However, by far the best part was the guided tour of the prison - led by a former political prisoner. We had Jama, and he was such an interesting person. He had several people ask him hard questions, personal questions, and he answered them as best he could. I can't imagine how much he would have to prepare himself for work everyday.Seeing Mandela's cell, and having Jama explain what life was like - from his real life experience was really overwhelming, and I think it's what sets Robben Island apart from other prison museums.This was a bucket list experience for me - and really hit home. It's a must do for anyone in Capetown.

Can't visit Cape Town and not visit Robben Island!. This place, wow! It's very atmospheric, it's full of sadness and emptiness. But to list pen to the history from an ex prisoner that was imprisioned for crimes he did not commit is just heart breaking! Please visit, it's worth it!

it was ok but not well organised. One of the boats to the island was very unsafe and it all seemed to be a little chaotic. I didn't enjoy it much. We were spoken to by the guide for some time without knowing what time the boats were leaving and there didn't seem to be any information to let you know. I wouldn't recommend the trip.

Worth the trip and interesting, but..... not much time or opportunity to see much. Easiest to book in advance and print out ticket to bring. Best to book on earliest ferry at nine as winds can get up later and the crossing will be choppier or cancelled. Get there early as Arrived at 8:20 to join the queue already boarding the boat, Jester, which left fifteen minutes ahead of schedule. Unable to sit on top of the ferry as gangway had been cordoned off and there were only just enough seats on the lower deck. I had to sit on a stool at the bar, which was not in use.On arrival everyone isherded into coaches and driven around stopping at various points of interest, but the only chance given to get out is at the tip of the island with a view of Cape Town and then only for five minutes. Then back in the coach and back to the prison propper, where a former inmate gave a talk at various stages of the tour. The group was huge as the one was joined by another, making the visit less pleasant as translations were also being made. Nelson Mandela's cell was proudly pointed out for photo opportunities. The penguin colony which apparently exists on the island was ignored, but then given the size of the groups ( transported in four coaches) this was probably better for the birds. Arriving back at the V and A waterfront on another, quicker ferry, which for a time had deafeningly loud music playing, it was just after one, and time for lunch. Glad I went, but would not count the visit as a must on my bucket list.
