Emotional and though provoking - Thank you. The Robben island trip was to explain the history of cape town more for me but also i wanted to see how Mandela had portrayed the series he had drawn from an art perspective as well. I enjoyed the trip so much due to the amazing guides who we had whom had been prisoners on the island. Our guide had struggled for freedom for what he called the melting pot of people. I cant express how much i feel this was a worthwhile trip.
Very Educational. An insight to a Man that made History. Nelson Mandela. Full of facts and information about the Island and It's History.

For a Time to Reflect. This reminds you of man's all too often inhumanity to man. To incarcerate people on the basis of political beliefs and the colour of their skin has no place anywhere in the world. An informative trip to a stark place. Known of course because on Nelson Mandela's time there you learn many of the experiences of so many others, often unknown. Unmissable.

Trip to Robben Island. An amazing and very moving experience - a must do trip if visiting Cape Town. The sea crossing can be quite choppy, so bear that in mind - although it usually takes about half an hour from the Victoria and Alfred Waterfront. The tour of the island begins with a bus trip around a number of notable sites (Robert Sobukwe's house, the limestone quarry, lighthouse), followed by a guided tour of the prison. I was shown around by a former inmate, which made the experience all the more special. It was hard to comprehend that Nelson Mandela spent 18 years there - and in such a small cell with nothing more than a flimsy mat, a couple of blankets and a bucket.

Can't escape commercialization!. The place is being well preserved and well presented. Would be great to be able to explore a bit on your own, but you must stay with the bus and not leave the prescribed route. Seems like the experience would be enough to inspire you, but if not, go by a key chain in the gift shop!

Interesting. If you are interested in the History of Mandella and the fight for freedom, then this a good experience, on the otherhand it is a place where you can say "I went there". It was a interesting place to visit but I must admit I did feel rather disappointed, not sure what I expected to see but felt that there was not enough about Mandella. Of course they had other "Political" prisoners there to and the story of Robben Island was about them all. A good place to visit though.

Joburg Museums far more interesting!. Don't waste a day doing this! Seeing the Apartheid museum, Peterson museum, and Mandela's home in Joburg was far more moving and informative. A prison tour with a former inmate that we couldn't hear or understand was not worth a one hour boat ride!

Worth the trip; wish there were more options. This is a must-do trip if you're in Cape Town, but I think it falls a bit short of its potential emotional impact. You don't quite get the feel of how bad a place it was, outside of a visit to the quarry, but even then you have to use your imagination. Best part was during the section led by the former political prisoner held on the island. You're free to ask questions, and please, have the nerve to ask whatever's really on your mind. The answers to the difficult questions are the best. Would have been nice if there were different "paths" you could have taken. Walking tours of the quarry, for example, instead of seen from a bus. Perhaps there are, but I wasn't aware of them. Seems to be a one-size-fits-all 4-hour tour.The museum within the ferry building, on the other hand, was excellent. Make sure you take the time to go through and see it. No worry about crowds; don't think people pay much attention to it.
Been here twice!. Fantastic trip in history with ex cons as guides. It is incredible how the buildings bring home the torment of this place. Do it, a must see
Interesting day. The highlight of is day was listening to the talk by a previous inmate as it put the whole thing into perspective.
boring!. no worth the trip: a prison is a prison, and being there adds nothing at understanding apartheid. The boat trip is long and boring, the compulsory bus tour with guide is even worse...

Rich History Lesson. The Robben Island Tour we took on a recent weekend getaway to Cape Town was a hard hitting lesson in South Africa's painful past. We caught the ferry from the V & A waterfront and the ride over was about 30mins long and quite smooth, something I was very thankful for as a sufferer of motion sickness. The first part of the tour was guided by a former prisoner on the island and provided a lot of first hand information. The second part was a bus ride around the island visiting various spots including the actual prison cells in which Mandela and many of his fellow political prisoners spent many years. The ride back to the V&A was possibly one of the worst experiences I've had on holiday in a long time. The waters were rough and the ferry was much smaller than the one we'd been on going to the island. People were struggling to maintain their balance and many, including myself, left the ferry with an extra package - regurgitated lunch. I would advise EVERYONE to take this trip atleast once but I'd also advise taking a motion sickness pill if you are taking this trip

Worth a visit but could be so much more. Firstly you will need to book in advance to do this tour, particularly if you want to get on the 9am trip.. Note the ferries leave before your tour time so you need to be there at least 30mins before. The visitor centre in the waterfront is nice as are the boats out to Robben island. The tour has two parts. A bus tour round the island and then a tour of the high security prison with a former inmate. Both were good and well organised but it's a lot to take in and I felt a bit rushed and would have liked a bit more time there than I got. Particularly in the prison and time to take in the information by the pier. I believe there is future plans to enable stays in houses here and there are other ways in which this could be more developed as a visitor attraction. Overall though, i do recommend it but from reading some of the reviews I feel I should point out, this is not a tour about Mandela. You will see his cell but there is so much more to take in. Finally it's also worth saying that this tour will (on good days) give you amazing views back to Cape Town so although you can do this on a rainy day I'd recommend you plan it for a good one. Also keep an eye out for whales as you cross!

A world class heritage site with so much history. So much sad memories and all the history about the birth of democracy in South Africa, a must visit when you are in Capetown. The guides are superb as they were also once prisoners on the Island so they have first hand experience and be sure to carry some tissues as you will indeed shed a tear.

Lots of history. This is well worth the visit, you get a bus ride around half of the island, make sure you sit on the RIGHT HAND SIDE of the bus, as nearly all the points of interest are on that side.We only had one stop at the turn around point for the ever present gift shop, there was no getting off the bus at the other stops, strange as there were signs for you to read, but I was told by the tour guide that you could not walk around the island by yourself? Of course the prison is the highlight of the tour and you have plenty of time to look around and take photos. Ex inmates give you a very personal slant on what it was like to be held there.

Still a must do when in Cape Town!. The journey is made by one of 2 ferries. On the way out we were on the faster catamaran, on the way back on the slower ferry and the sea was a bit choppy so they had to hand out sick bags to some!However, once on Robben Island you are greeted by the tour guides and to our surprise they were all either ex-prisoners or prison wardens!! I found this very moving that having served over 20 years in a prison on an island they are still willing to devote their lives to the place!! It is amazing though to have first hand experience from those who were there, but somewhat sad.You spend quite a bit of time on the coach and you are shown the different buildings. The highlight is at the end when you are taken to the main high security prison where Nelson Mandela was and you get to see the cell where he spent 12 out of the 27 years. They have clearly re-painted and done the place up somewhat, which kind of takes away the authentic edge from the place making it almost feel like a staged tourist attraction. But you are definitely made to feel the reality of the place whilst you are captivated and hang on to each of the words coming out of the ex-prisoner, tour guides mouth.So overall a "must do" when visiting Capetown - best to book online at least the day before to avoid disappointment as its always fully booked!!

Very inspiring g. We loved this visit, there was a lot of people but the fact that it is guided by previous prisoners made it all! In particular we had one guide that was so interesting in the bus with lively and hard true stories about the life In the prison at the time. This is strong history and we recommend doing the tour

An absolute must do. I was unsure whether to visit the Island and how wrong I was. this part of history I would encourage all to go and see and experience for themselvesThe tour is well organised and you see and feel some amazing things

A Must-See. If you're at all interested in South Africa's tragic and then hopeful history, go. Nelson Mandela, not to mention many, many others who strove for freedom, were imprisoned here (Mandela for 19 year), within sight of the beautiful city of Cape Town. The tour includes being guided by someone who was a prisoner. It is quite moving.

A must see tour while in cape town. No matter what your opinion is of the history of South Africa. Robben island is a must see place. Our tour guide who himself was a prisioner himself was fantastic clearly explained the struggle that people went through. I wouldnt plan on spending the whole day there though you only need half a day at most. The boat ride is quite long and it can be rough sea so the tours do get cancelled if the weather is bad. The whole day was value for money.

Very moving, but not one for young children. Straightforward to access, very informative and moving guide, powerful stories everywhere. Our 6 year old was a bit bored as there was not a great deal of interactivity.

Remind me how it was!. Robben Island makes it possible to imagine, albeit in limited fashion, one aspect of the ugly apartheid regime and to try and understand the hardships suffered by so many of its inmates.

Highlight of the trip. Robben Island was wonderful. an ex prisioner that was incarcerated with Nelson Mandela was our guide and what a lovely informative man he was. It was an emotional and humbling experience one im glad i have experienced

When you take a pilgrimage, you don't expect to have a comedian guiding you on the bus.....?. Robben Island is one of those places you feel you simply MUST visit if you have a sense of history - rather like Auschwitz - you go there because you should not because you want to. So having a bit of a "comic" on the initial bus tour was not appropriate in my view. So briefly I will say that the 45 minute or so boat ride across to the island can be very choppy so take something if you are apt to puke on a boat. Secondly, everyone is herded onto a bus and you are taken around the island and while it is interesting to see the tortoises and penguins, what we are here for us to visit the prison and in my view rather too much bus and not enough prison. At the prison the talk given by one of the ex prisoners was absolutely fascinating - he was sentence to 25 years at the age of 21.....fortunately with the change of politics he was released after 8 years but during this time he had to sleep on a simple blanket on the floor in a room of 60 men. We were then taken to Block B, Cell 7 which was Nelson Mandela's cell for every day of the 18 years that he spent there. It was very moving to see this place which could have driven him mad but, instead, helped in focus on what he had to do when he was eventually released.So in brief, a must see but we prefer less time on the bus and more time in the prison !

This is a Must-See Tourist Attraction. Make sure you take out about 4 hours and buy your tickets ahead of time. There is a ferry ride which is about 40 minutes each way. You ride a bus on the island for the tour and walk a bit as well. The tour was incredible! You have the chance to see where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for 18 years of his life. We also got to hear first-hand from one of the prisoners who was at the prison with Mandela about his experience. There is much pain in the history there as black people were imprisoned unjustly for standing up for their rights. This is an attraction that everyone who visits South Africa should see and experience. I am so glad that I went. (Take a bottle of water with you as it gets hot during the tour.) The whole experience opened my eyes...

Well, at least I went? Would be better off reading a good book about Mandela. I can't imagine not going on this tour but....I was disappointed. I really did not get much out of the bus tour portion (our tour guide seemed more interested in being theatrical) but the inside of the prison portion was interesting. However do not expect to leave with a deep understanding of anything from the information you are given here.

You really have to go...... The ferry ride took about 30 minutes and then you are met by a bus with a guide on who takes you around the Island and tells you all the stories about what went on here You then leave the bus at the Prison and are met by an ex convict who then tells you his story about his time in the prison and of course all the stories of the era of Nelson Mandela. Just so moving when you hear true stories, please go and visit..... a very good half day out.

Sobering Thoughts. Its a must visit. A caterman takes you out to the island where you get a bus trip around the island. You visit the prison and see where Nelson Mandela was held. There is also a penguin colony on a nearby beach.

Review on Robben Island. It's one of the must see in Cape Town because of its history. It takes about 3 hours - on ferry, bus tour and than walk tour around the prison but I still got feeling like being pushed and in hurry all the time. It could get quite overcrowded and you have to buy tickets in advance to be able to visit Robben Island. To be honest, I expected more from visiting this place

Part of learning of the injustice of apartheid. This tour complements a visit to the District 6 Museum if you want to appreciate the injustice of apartheid. The ferry ride offers some great views of the city cradled by the mountains. Once on the island there is a bus tour of the shore line around the island - pretty, but clearly forbidding if you were thinking of escape. The prison tour is guided by ex- prisoners who add a powerful personal note. Of course there is a stop at Mandela's cell. While sobering, this half day trip is historically important.

Tour Guide. A worthwhile trip but our guide around the prison should not be allowed to mix with tourists. We started with a trip around edge of island and the lady had very good knowledge of Robben Island. She mentioned how great the guide is who showed us around the inner maximum security prison. He was polite enough and knew the regime well. He was an ex-prisoner who was not a political prisoner but a murderer. I can not accept how great a murderer is. He should still be locked up. I fully support the release of political prisoners in South Africa but not murderers!!!!!

fantastic tour. this is a must do on the list in Cape Town - book your tour before you arrive we did the early morning one so we could have lunch at 2pm when we got back. Ex prisoners take you around the prison and give a great insight into what happened there and what life was like. You get to see the island as well as the prison.

Long tour, not very authentic.. Everybody seems to think that it is a necessary stop during a stay in Cape Town, I disagree. The tour takes approx 4h, you spend 1h on the ferry, 1h in a bus touring around the island (where you basically just see some buildings from the outside, listening to some confusing information about different periods of History), 30 min in the prison with a former prison inmate (THE only interesting part) and you can have look at Mandela's jail cell but to be honest, it is like any other cell and you have exactly one second to contemplate it. The rest of the time is wasted for organization : get in the ferry, get out of the ferry, get in the bus, etc.
Incredibly moving. We weren't sure what to expect exactly. But we left with a newfound appreciation, not only of the history and hardship, but of those that work so hard to preserve the island.
unique. when visiting Cape Town a must during your stay. Going there by boat you have a great view of Cape Town, sometimes you see also some whale.

Great well organised tour!. We had a great morning trip to Robben Island - the tour is very well organised and the tour guides are so knowledgeable and just great! We especially enjoyed the prison tour with the ex political prisoner. A great experience!

Emotional . The Robben island tour is a great experience and relatively inexpensive for what you get. You need to pre book though. Your tour guide is an ex political prisoner who is knowledgable about the prison. The tour takes about 3.5 hours so don't plan anything afterwards unless you go on the early morning trip

Unique opportunity. Visiting Robben Island offers a unique opportunity to reflect on and view evidence of the recent Apartheid regime in South Africa. The museum at the Waterfront is very well presented but hard information about the conditions and regime of the prison would be an important addition but sone of this is available from the ex-prisoner who guided the. The lengthy bus trip around the Island before arriving at the prison adds nothing to the experience.

To never forget experience. The tour of the robe island museum is worth every Rand spent on it. Going there by boat you have a great view of Cape Town especially when you take the afternoon trip of 3pm. The island is explored by bus and ends with the prison where Nelson Mandela was impropisoned for so long. Special is that the tour of the prison is done by former prisoners who with their own experience and emotion tell their stairs to you. Absolutely a must when you go to Cape Town, also for your kids!

Suck it up and do it. Yes you have to endure spending 3 hours with 100 other tourists who are not always the best behaved. However you will be blessed with spending time with a tour guide who might be a former inmate of Robben Island during Apartheid. These men bring a wealth of knowledge to our visit to the prison. Very empowering

A peak into a dark but not so long gone era of South Africa. The trip leaves from the V & A waterfront with a catamaran like boat, taking half an hour single way. When arriving on the island you will be escorted by an ex inmate of Robben Island prison. Our guide served 8 years of his live there and really took some time to explain to us what this time was like for him and his other friends who ended up here. I felt real honesty and patience in anwering all kinds of tricky questions from the crowd which made the trip for us really worth while. After these stories he will guide you to some cells including Mandela's cell, the yard where they worked and afterwards you are taken on a bus to the mines the inmates had to work on. The bus guide was a really nice one as well.A must see!

Inspiring, complicated, sad. Least we forget how cruel we as humans can be. Least we can forget the strength of the human spirit. Isolated but also strickingly...the prison where Nelson Mandela was held for most of his 27 years in jail.

a piece of history as told by those that were there.... Ok, first of all the ride there can be a bit hairy as some of the boats are old and the seas can be rough, but once there it is an experience to behold. As the title would indicate each of our tour guides were actually political prisoners who where sent there during Apartheid. A moving day in a well kept little piece of history.

You just have to go.... I'm not an Elvis fan but I went to Graceland. The Albert Memorial is impressive as are all the cenotaphs all over the UK. The Waterway Museum in Ellesmere Port can't be missed. But none of them really make you closer to the experience of a life. Robben Island fails to do that as well. One of the greatest men we have seen over centuries even millennia lived here, suffered here for a lifetime but despite the efforts of former inmates we wandered around what seemed like a film set on a dead sound stage - no life, no smell of the pain and suffering wreaked here. Maybe that's in a salute to reconciliation but this was not the experience of Auschwitz or Breendonk, not even close. I half expected people to be taking selfies of themselves next to a smiling wax Mandela.

Historical, but generally disappointing. Frustrating travel with unreliable ferries. Unenthusiastic staff and poorly maintained in general. So much potential, but not nearly as good a tourist attraction as it could be.

Impressive tour by ex political prisoners. Important part of recent SA history.. Very well organised for R300 per person.Fast boat with very good view on the Waterfront and Table mountain. Includes a bus tour for the main highlights and a tour by foot through the maximum security prison where ao. Nelson Mandela was being kept.Because the story is being told by ex prisoners (of who some and some ex guards live on the island right now) it is a very real experience.The total tour takes about 3.5 hours.

prison life at Robben Island. A trip out to Robben island if you are visiting Cape Town is almost a must. Very intressant ex prisoner as guide, he gave a detailed description of the hardships the prisoners endured, information re the prison, ANC and Mandella was more comprehensive than other history of the island. We were there on a calm day, be prepared for a rough & cold weather. we saw three whales on the way back.Book tickets in advance as availability is limited,

Well Done!. Meaningful place to visit and well organized. The ferry ride was short but provided a great sweep back towards Cape Town, especially Table Mountain which arose out of the fog covering the city. Upon arrival, the bus was waiting and the guide was delightful, sharing great information. The scene at the lime pit was especially interesting. I also learned much more about the pivotal role played by Robert Sobukwe. After a short rest break and leaving the bus, we were met by our guide for the prison tour, himself a former prisoner. He shared wonderful if wrenching information. After the tour, the ferry was waiting for the short ride back. Very well organized and a great site to visit.

A fantastic tour - learning from the past. This is a fantastic trip and a must do for anyone who is interested in South Africa's history. The ferry trip is stunning although apparently it can get a little rough sometimes and you get fantastic views of Table Mountain. Robben Island itself has a really interesting history and this gets brought to life by a guided bus trip and later a tour of a cell by a past inmate. This adds a personal touch to the facts and brings history alive. The one thing you leave with is a sense of hope that we will learn from our mistakes and learn to treat each other with consideration and care.

Must see. Apparently you have to book in advance as there are limited places, however we were lucky enough to purchase two tickets for same day travel. The bay was mirror calm although it had a roll which added to the adventure. The boat stopped twice to view whales. The prison tour was undertaken by an elderly man, who was very passionate about the prison. We found it very interesting. The short bus ride around the small town and compound was made interesting by the guide who provided stats and historical data. We went over on a slow boat and returned on a fast cat. All up the tour lasted about 3 1/2 to 4 hours. A must see. 300 rand ($30 Australian dollars) per adult. Good value.

Heart wrenching. We are glad we did not miss seeing Robben Island. It certainly gave us a heart wrenching understanding of this very dark period in SA. Unbelievable that Apartheid lasted as long as if did. The tour guide on the bus very passionate about his job. It was also interesting to find out more of the history of the island going back to the 1600's. Our only gripe was not being told at the end when exactly the boat would return. The ticket said 4 pm. As the tour was over we went directly to the boat and waited for the next half hour while tourists straggled on. If we had known this we would have spent more time at the poster displays and in the gift shop.

Ferry Trip is makes the trip enjoyable but also expensive. If they regard this place as the History of South Africa they may be need to re-visit their rates. R300 per person is very expensive if you are paying in rands. capetown is catering for tourists not South Africans
Moving. You cannot go to Cape Town and not experience this. Great informative tours. I recommend you book your tickets in advance if you have a date in mind because tickets do sell out quite quickly.

Thought Provoking. I had heard so much about this Island through the Nelson Mandela chapters. It had a stillness, and everyone treated the visit with a great deal of respect for what had gone before. The biggest surprise was that our tour of the jail area was done with a former prisoner of the Island. He was quite open to questions, which made the tour very personal. There was also a bus tour of the Island, which takes you to areas of the prisoners lives, which were explained to us. Along the way we stopped for a short comfort break, and were lucky enough to see Whales. The boat trip out to the Island - around 45m - was calm, the return was quite choppy. However, the view of Table Mountain slowly coming closer definitely took your mind off any lumps and bumps. This trip gets Very Busy. Luckily I decided to go to the Ferry Terminal the day I arrived, as I had to wait two days for a ticket. Either do that, and re-jig you agenda or, pre-book before travel. I would hate to think I had missed this trip.

Beautiful views of Cape Town and Table Mountain, and Moving. Worth the time to take the ferry ride and the guided tour n the Island. Our tour guide was so special, despite poking fun at Australians due to the gum trees. Everyone visiting Cape Town should do this

A must do. - but don't go for the jail cell. Very interesting site. The Robben Island tour is less about Mandela, more about apartheid. Most of the time is spent on a bus tour around the island. Our bus tour guide was outstanding ad he told the story of Aoarteid and the island. The jail cell is like most others. And surprisingly the jail cell guide who was in prison himself didn't personalize his story. That said, it was an excellent learning opportunity.

Brilliant - a must!. We were a little worried when we found out that the tours can only be booked through one operator and fill up quickly but were relieved when we managed to get tickets on the day. Boat ride is a little bumpy on the smaller boats so would recommend trying to get on the larger ferry if you are prone to sea sickness. Coach tour around island was very informative and interesting: very well delivered by a knowledgeable guide. Prison tour was given by an ex-prisoner so he was able to give a first hand account of what life was like there. Overall this tour was brilliant and well worth the money!

the island is nice but.... don't expect very personal things about nelson madera, his cel is like every other cell,the boat trip is very nice but the bus trip on the island is taking 45 minutes and you have to listen to the guide making his way and jokes

Family trip. The Que. For the ferry is a bit mad ( no one can que) the ferry over to the island is about 20mins then your taken by coach around the island with stop off points ,for photos .the guide was very informative and answered lots of questions .the second part of the tour is a walk round the cells and the guide is a former in mate , so the detail of prison life on the island is as good as it gets .you end the trip with a look at Mandela's cell .then back on the ferry I would get there. Early to get on the ferry with that in mind the whole trip takes 4 hours but well worth doing

a "must do" tour in Capetown. This was a well executed tour with a massive movement of people. We received excellent content from both the guide on the bus and also the former inmate who led us through the prison.I learnt so much but just wished the group had not been so large as it was sometimes hard to hear.Nevertheless, I would recommend this tour as an absolute must for anyone visiting Capetown.

Alcatraz of Africa. You need to experience this. Good tour by one of the former inmates of Robben island. Read Long Road to Freedom by Nelson Mandela before you come so it's more meaningful. You can ask questions of the inmate, making the tour more impressive. Half bus tour of the grounds, and half tour of the cells with the inmate. Not that well done, but a definite must-see. They have a huge opportunity to educate people, but don't take advantage of that opportunity.

Beautifully moving. This is a MUST if you're in Cape Town. I went with friends and we were all moved. The tour was done by an ex prisoner which made it very real and the facts were really good. You get to see different parts of the island and Mandela's cell. I was reading the Long Walk to Freedom at the time and it was amazing to see the places that are spoken about in the book. We were warned that the ferry crossing would be bad and it was very rough!! But it was worth it. We had a inspirational and emotional day there.

Good experience but a missed boat made it GREAT.. This was a highlight of our trip and a truly humbling experience. We were shown round the prison by a former political prison who told of his experience, the group was about 20 strong. On our way back to the boat returning us to the mainland 3 of us decided to take a quick detour to see the Penguins that live on the island thinking that the boat would never leave without us..... It did! We were advised by the very friendly shop attendant that we would have to wait for the next boat (3 hours time) but feel free to roam the prison. Upon returning to the prison being a smaller group the prison became much more "real" and less a tourist attraction. The silence and empty hall gave an altogether different experience to what it was earlier in the day. If you visit Cape Town you have to experience Robben Island if only to better understand how people fought for a better place for all to live.

Read up on wikipedia first.. I agree with other reviewers here that the tour is way to rushed. The guy we had to take us around the inside of the prison was difficult to understand, he was informative to a degree but relied/encouraged people to keep asking him questions. He kept saying 'come on quick, quick time is money' and shuttled us through. Again, when we got in the corridor to see Nelson Mandela's cell it was packed, to be honest it could have been anyone's cell, nothing there that made it unique, that I saw anyway. Then I noticed people were going into other cells so I followed suit, to my surprise there was a photo on the wall and a narrative from the person incarcerated there, I found this very interesting and moving but of course we were shuttled onwards. That is what I found disappointing, if you could take your time, like in a museum, to digest what you are reading and what that person was going through at the time it would make the experience so much better.If you have seen inside a prison before, you are not missing much other than to say you have been to Robben island, and get the history from wikipedia. The boat trip was good, we had calm sea and the views of Table mountain are worth it.

Moving Experience. Must visit once. Not enough time / flexibility. It is important that everyone visit this Robben Island once, if in the Cape Town area. You can “feel” the past inmates in the atmosphere. Make sure you book tickets in advance. Best bet – take the first boat over. The actual visit is a bit disappointing. The tours are led by ex-inmates which is interesting. However, they are sometimes difficult to understand. You are transported around the island with a couple of stops via large buses. At some points, the stop is very brief and you cannot exit the bus. At others, you can exit for a tour of the cells and washrooms, but a very disjointed tour. The bus groups are too large for a single speaker to be heard. Upon arrival at stops the group should be divided into smaller groups. Need to provide more time for visitors to read the signs along the way to really capture the history and importance of this site. When visitors are returned to the harbor, there is not enough time to visit the gift shop unless you want to wait an additional hour or two for the next boat. Sorry… no gift shop experience is worth waiting that long for another boat. Recommendations: Reserve a minimum of 4 hours for this visit. Take Dramamine if you experience motion sickness as the boat crossing can be quite rough. We have rough waters and many of the passengers were green or getting ill! Wear good walking shoes. Be patient with photo opportunities. You may need to wait in line to catch a photo of Nelson Mandela’s cell and other key points, but it’s worth it. Recommended improvements to the staff: Give each visitor a card with an actual inmate’s name and history. Then, at the end of the tour, visitors can check the board to see if they were released, relocated, died in prison, or whatever. Provide visitors with a bit more independence to walk in other areas. Maybe provide guided audio tours for an extra fee. Visitors can then pace their visits and the audio will be more easily understood than a single guide with a bus load of people.

A disturbing place.. The last day of our tour was dull and rainy, I suppose it fitted the place we were visiting, the poor prisoners did have a lot of hardship. Our guide was an ex prisoner he added feeling to the story.

"Great tour". The tour around Robben Island was very moving. Our tour guide on the bus was excellent, she gave us a good account of its history and life on the island. We also had a guided tour of the the cells from a former inmate and what life was like as a prisoner. A must if you are visiting Cape Town
A must-see in South Africa !. The tour was led by a former prisoner and this added a very compelling narrative to an already emotional presentation.

Understanding more about political freedom. One of the best parts of this tour is that the guides are former inmates. They are open and willing to share experiences, including the charges that landed them in the prison. An incite full way to experience what life was like for Nelson Mandela and his fellow inmates

Very moving experience but too short. The tour of the island is organised to a very tight time schedule. A former political prisoner explains life in the prison and leads the tour of the cells etc. A bus tour of the island takes in other aspects of its history. The drawback is that the time doesn't allow for stopping, being still and reflecting on what you've heard. The only time you're not being shepherded along is on a brief stop part way round the bus tour for toilet/souvenir shopping, photos and then when walking back to the ferry.The other drawback is that the ferries aren't brilliant and we caught a slow one back to the mainland, missing our lunch reservation at a local restaurant.

Overwhelming historical tour. for such a dark period in history, South Africa has done a remarkable job ensuring that all have an opportunity to experience this landmark. The moment you step on the Island, you are overwhelmed by history, I was, it was a moving experience. I highly recommend you make the effort of going over.

Must Visit. If you happen to be in Cape Town, it is a must to visit the Robben Island. It is one of the places, visiting which makes you more human than before. And the best (if this word is suitable here) is that the guides who work there are the ones, that not so long ago were prisoners of the island. That words "this is the place my bed was standing" give you shivers. And the whole history behind Apartheid cannot really and fully be understood without visiting Robben Island.

When in Cape Town a must!. Robben Island is a must visit when you are in Cape Town. Prepare to be there most part of the day. For very young children it might be a bit boring. You will be toured around in a group, by an ex (political) prisoner. Book online in advance.

Inspirational place, not well organised!. I leant towards rating this 'poor', but went for average as I think it is an extremely important attraction, and it is a fantastic thing that it is open to the public. However I don't believe the visitor experience does it justice.Unlike others we had a fairly easy time booking tickets (I think you just have to plan ahead) and the boat ride went smoothly. However once you get there, there is a not-particularly-clear loudspeaker announcement telling you to get onto some buses over in the car park. You are then driven around the island with a guide giving you info and you are able to stop for a few minutes only at a couple of locations. The guide for this section of our trip was great and really informative, although it would be nice to have seen more things in person rather than from the bus window!You are then dropped off at the political prisoner compound where you are passed onto a guide who was an ex-inmate. This was, really regrettably, not good- the pace of the tour was very erratic, at times it was very difficult/impossible to understand what the guide was saying and at other times he would repeat the same thing over and over, meaning there wasn't much content. I wouldn't know what to suggest in improvement as it is a really good unique selling point and a really valuable thing to have prior inmates who are able to testify, but I don't think it has the impact that it should. I'd also imagine the experience varies depending on who you are shown round by. It was also very crowded here with large amounts of time being taken up for people to individually get pictures of Nelson Mandela's cell, and I got the impression that there were several areas we didn't even get to see.By the time this is done, you have maybe 10 mins at the harbour and shop and then you get back on the boat.Practicalities- set aside 4 hours. Wouldn't recommend going in flip flops as I did as the terrain is a bit rough in places. It's good to bring a camera although getting good pictures will require patience as there are so many people!Really this tour would benefit from giving visitors more independence and being more information-heavy. It was difficult not to mentally compare the experience to Alcatraz where you walk around with a guided audio tour and there is a huge amount available to learn. Perhaps with the size of the island this wouldn't be possible but allowing visitors more flexibility and autonomy I think would improve it greatly.I wouldn't say that I don't recommend it at all, as it is a great thing to see, but the visitor experience pales in comparison to other museums both in Cape Town and elsewhere, and is in need of some TLC!

A must-do, but poor customer service. Obviously the Robben Island Museum Tour is a "Must Do" for any visitor to Cape Town.We booked tickets well in advance, and were excited to go. Unfortunately as we headed to the V&A Waterfront to board the ferry, our bus (MyCiti) either broke down or did not turn up, meaning we were late. We called the Robben Island Museum on 5 occasions as it looked like we were destined to be late, however nobody picked up the phone. When we arrived, we explained we had tried to call and asked if we could swap to a different trip as we had already paid. We were told we would have to get, in writing, a letter from MyCiti conforming the bus problem. I see where they are coming from, however asking this of a tourist with less than 48hrs left of their trip is something of a big ask. I implored them to call the bus company and check if they wanted, and also showed the the call log on my phone showing I had called and nobody answered. I ended up filling in a form and having to buy new tickets. I would hope one day that perhaps if this is read, they can look to issue a refund for my original tickets. The person at the "Information Desk" didn't seem to have any sympathy, nor really care about anything.On the Island itself, the tour was great on the bus. The guide was both funny and knowledgeable, and made sure everyone felt part of the experience.The tour of the prison with a former political prisoner was great too, however our guide was quite softly spoken so hard to hear at times.Needless to say, after what was a great trip, our ferry going out to the island was delayed by 15 minutes, and our return trip home delayed by almost an hour. No bad weather, just generally over running for no apparent reason. No thought taken into account that this would delay further activities planned. I would welcome hearing from management.

What an experience! . Need to ensure you book your tickets in advance as spaces are limited, you also need to be careful of the weather in winter as trips can be cancelled.Make sure you give yourself at least 30 mins in the museum before you leave, well worth taking time out to really understand the history.A memorable experience to the island, well organised, and well worth a visit, would be a real disappointment to go to Cape Town and not visit. Breathtaking at times.

Worth a visit. The tour of Robben Island gives an insight into it's history as a leper colony, labour camp and prison through the years. The prison tours are conducted by guides who were themselves prisoners on the island during the apartheid years. Very popular, book tickets in advance or you may be disappointed.

Bonus view "leper History ". Apart from the the main attraction, the history of the other group of occupants onthe island, was a real treat, the church ,grave yard for the leper persons sent becauseof their condition,it also shows there was also other prisoner's history.you can get refreshments etc at a cafe ,the boat that takes you out to the island was comfortable and a bus will tour you around points on island, but this is not away's available. a interesting and learning curve....

Freedom. We caught the ferry over to Robben Island and an ex prisoner was our guide. This is very moving tour, as all they wanted was the rite to vote!! Something that so many of us take for granted. We were shown the cells, the quarry and told many stories of what happened in the prison. A must to do if in Cape Town. The ferry trip was amazing as we had the Johanasberg Boys Choir on board and they sang for us, a bonus in deed.

Who else could hold the title of this review except NELSON MANDELA. If you suffer from motion sickness, especially on the water - rather give this trip overseas to Robben Island (as South African's who haven't traveled much are quick to joke about) to the other tourists. Ferries depart at 9am, 11am and 1pm from - you guessed it - the Nelson Mandela Gateway at the V&A Waterfront : obviously weather permitting. It is a World Heritage Site and museum and one can spend hours learning about the island's history and see the cell where Nelson Msndela was incarcerated. The guide is a former political prisoner himself.

Inspiring visit. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to Robben Island and would definitely recommend it to anybody who wants to get a better understanding of the struggle for freedom in South Africa. Our tour guide on the bus ride around the island was a real highlight as he was able to give us first hand accounts of the struggle in a humorous and charismatic way. The tour of the prison itself, conducted by a former inmate as fantastic and hearing him talk about his experiences there and life afterwards was truly inspiring.

Unmissable!. The island is about 4kms out and the journey takes about 40 minutes from the waterfront. It's a very popular attraction, which gets booked up 24 hours or more in advance ( although you might be lucky enough to get tickets on the day) so best to buy timed tickets online (R300 in October 2015). The trip is also weather dependent (full refund if cancelled) so try to leave another day spare to do it if cancelled. Make sure you arrive in good time as the queue to board starts early.On arrival you are met by a tour bus, with guide - if you are really lucky you will get Yasir Mohammed (not sure about spelling) who has the great gift of communicating facts in the most fascinating way ensuring a rapt bus load of visitors all listening intently.The island itself has an other worldly feel, and you can well imagine how bleak and silent it was during its days as a prison. The. It's most famous residents were Nelson Mandela who spent 18 years of 25 confinement here, and Robert Sobukwe who was held in solitary confinement for 9.

Robben Island is a must-see in Cape Town.. The admission charge is 300 Rand which includes a return ferry ride and guided tours of the prison and island. I was very lucky to be able to purchase a ticket at the V & A Waterfront a couple hours before the 1 pm ferry took off. You will have ample opportunity to take pictures of the mainland and Table Mountain from the ferry. Sometimes you would even see seals, dolphins and whales swimming by. The prison itself is not much different from any other prison. Depending on which guides you got, the script would be very moving. I liked the island bus tour much better than the prison tour because the island does have a number of interesting landmarks and a long history other than being the prison for important political prisoners. We also saw a group of African penguins near the island shop.
Interesting and heartbreaking. Very well organised with great guides. We also saw penguins very nearby. Heartbreaking to see how people were treated

Absolutely must visit. Every visitor to Cape Town must head out to Robben Island. You may need to book your trip on the ferry a few days in advance however, so perhaps do it online. Sometimes if the sea is too rough the ferries will be cancelled.It's definitely worth visiting to see what life was like at the prison. You will begin your trip being driven around to other parts of the island and will stop at a cafe where you can get really nice photos across the sea to Table Mountain. Sometimes there are birds nesting and penguins in the area too.Next you visit the lime mine where the prisoners worked, then you go to the prison and are guided around by a former prisoner. You see one of the cell blocks where they had lots of prisoners in one room first and hear about what life was like, then you walk through a couple of courtyards and go to the single occupancy cells, and see where Nelson Mandella was held.There's not much chance to walk around independently and see anything yourself, unless you want to miss your return ferry and chance the next one. But on the guided tour you will see everything you really want to see, so it's nothing bad to just follow the crowd.

The boat ride that shouldn't have been. I think the island tour was quite good. It was very captivating to hear the personal story about our tour guide. I was touched that after all he went through he seemed to be extremely forgiving.The reason for my rating is what happened on the way back. Although it was still sunny, it turned out that the winds had picked up quite a bit (after I got back I checked and the weather report which said 30mph). We were put on a tiny flat bottomed boat called Thandi. The ride was extremely unpleasant. The waves were around 3/4m high, which is almost the size of the boat. It did not seem like suitable sailing conditions for this boat which looked as if it was going to capsize. The captain had to repeatedly turn the engine off because of the incoming big waves and I was left fearing my life for about an hour. The worst part is that this was completely unnecessary; they have bigger ships that can easily travel under these conditions but for some reason they decided to endanger our lives by putting us on the small boat.

Informative, Eye Opening and awesome tour. 1. My guide for this tour was an ex con... You can really have heart to heart talk to know about how it was like during apartheid...2. The tour tells you about the history, how the prison operates and interesting story...3. The tour will bring you to the prison area from the common cell to the high security cell..Famous Late Nelson Mandela cell... Their yard... And bus tour round the island..4. I love the souvenir shop...

very informative. I would recommend this trip even for those who feel that they have already read a lot about this period and place. i saw whales and seals on the boat ride over. The first tour is a coach trip around the island and our guide was very informative and fun. The second part was inside the prison and the guide was an ex political prisoner held in the prison there. Listening to him was informative and moving but what surprising about this visit was that the focus was not on the past only it was about change and hope for the future. His talk was both humbling and inspiring
inspiring to visit. puts things into perspective when you see what so many hardships people were put through in their struggle for what so many of us take for granted

Great to see, but not that well organized!. We travelled to Robben Island this week and while the experience of seeing it was great, the experience of the day was at best marginal. It started with the ferry over that was announced to be 15 minutes late but ended up leaving 45 minutes past the posted time. (By the way unless you are in the first 30 who are there two hours early, just hang around outside and don't queue up in the hallway or stairs as there are lots of seats downstairs and you won't get a seat up top!). We then had an interesting bus tour, but the tour inside the jail from the ex prisoner, while his enthusiasm was fun, candidly we understood about 10% of what he said. Great experience, but could be better managed.

Fantastic tour. Well worth going. The boat ride back was little hairy, but the tour of the island was excellent - a bus tour followed by an ex-political prisoner showing the cell blocks and Nelson Mandela's cell.

Interesting trip but scary boat ride!. We set off on a beautiful sunny day to Robben Island. The trip was informative, you are guided through various areas, get to see the cells and many other important aspects of Mandela's life. The only downside was the return trip on the boat, the swell had pumped up, and it made for a terrifying ride back! Just check the weather conditions before leaving!

Iconic site but rushed tour. The ferry ride and island provide some great views back to the city and mountain. We spotted a whale off our ride also. On arrival then you are put in a bus and taken around the island with a knowledgeable and entertaining guide. Only stop off is for pictures of table mountain until you get to the actual prison. Any other pics need to be taken from the bus so was disappointed we weren't able to get off and have a look around or take photos. On arrival at the prison a former inmate takes you around and tells his story and a bit about the prison history. The guides were the most interesting part and you don't get long to wander and take snaps before you are rushed back to the ferry so the next boatload can come in and do the same. Nowhere for a drink or snack really either so if you are on the 11am trip back at 2.30 you should eat prior. Very efficient and directed process but felt like it was get you on, get a look, get you off and not great for wandering or pics. We were lucky with the weather too - day before visits got cancelled due to swell and strong winds. Book well prior as it gets full up and we would have missed out otherwise if doing when there.

A Moving Experience. We had not planned to visit Robben Island during our short stay in Cape Town, but did fit the trip in, and are very glad we did. The guides were well informed and could share personal experiences. See where Nelson Mandela lived for so many years -- his tiny cell, on an island with the skyline of Cape Town in sight -- was a lifetime highlight.

Historic place, must visit. The Robben Island itself was great, an amazing site to remind us what should never happen again. It is a must do when in Cape Town. The guides are great and very knowledgable, the site is well roeserved and visitor friendly.However the transport and the handling of visitors (by Robben Island Museum) going in and out of the site should be much better, they need to improve customer experience.We were instructed to arrive 30 mins prior departure, then the boat was delayed over 30 mins so we ended up queueing for over an hour, without any information.On the way in you are literally rushed (by loudspeakers) into the buses which are absolutely not suitable for sightseeing(old, public transport-like buses). On the way out again you are rushed by loudspeakers into the boat, even if you are the first visitor to be out you have no time to walk and look at the boards which are an exhibition, or go into their souvenir shop or even use the bathrooms.I am happy I went but I was left with some bitter feelings.

worth the wait. you need to book early as it gets fully booked early. The tour is informative and the boat ride is lovely. Adults and older children will enjoy this more than children under 10. The views are magnificent

Historic place. It is an impressive monument of the newer South African history.
And as long as there are previous inmates who can tell their story, it becomes even more exciting

Very interesting!. Very interesting tour around the island and its prisons. The boat trip from Cape Town to the island can be quite nauseating if waves are strong. The bus tour on the island is instructive and well organized. Only English though! A former prisoner of Robben Island took us through the different blocks of the prison and explained us its conditions and routines. Very touching.
A must visit. One really needs to book ahead as its difficult to get last minute tickets. A very informative tour with a former inmate.

Emotional high point of our trip to South Africa. The ferry for our tour of Robben Island departed from V&A Waterfront. Leave yourself plenty of time to find the ferry ticket office. Fortunately for us a nice local woman was able to direct us efficiently and safely through a construction site to get to the ticket office; maybe we had tried to enter from the wrong entrance. Fortunately, the sea was calm and the weather sunny, and the trip to the Island great with magnificent views of Table Mountain and Cape Town city. On Robben Island we had a great tour guide (Tabhu) and driver (Albert I think). It is quite chilling entering the jail complex and looking up at the foreboding ‘WE SERVE WITH PRIDE’ sign. Tabhu was knowledgeable and friendly and he adapted the tour to maximise our enjoyment (at one point, he bypassed one site as there was a busload of people there and instead took us to another site, which was less busy, then returning to the first after the other bus had moved on). Inside the prison we were able to listen to one of the original political ex-prisoners (Glen) who spoke in a very moving way about his time on Robben Island. We saw Nelson Mandela’s cell, which was quite an emotional experience for both myself and my wife. Those were terrible times indeed back then during the Apartheid period. I am glad South Africa has moved forward. For anyone who has read ‘Long Walk to Freedom’, this tour of Robben Island makes a very fitting epilogue.

Booking the tickets is the worst part of the trip. You have to book the tickets online. Unfortunately for me, I missed my first visit because of traffic. I then had to pay for another ticket on another day. Thank goodness I made that trip. The visit was something that I HAD to do. I could not leave Cape Town without visiting Robben Island. I felt a little rushed during the tour. Other than that the ex political prisoner was very informative. Also I got to meet an ex guard and author of the book My prisoner, My friend. I not only bought the book but also had him sign it. I overlooked some of the negative aspects of the tour and was able to leave with a deeper knowledge of Apartheid and the freedom I take for granted.

Very Knowledgeable Tour Guide. Our tour guide, a former inmate of the prison himself, really gave us insight into the workings of the prison. For instance, he helped explain how apartheid colored the prison atmosphere (no pun intended), even in such small ways as serving darker-skinned people slightly less to eat than lighter-skinned people, although everyone in the prison was a PoC. He really brought the place to life for us.

A Must visit to really understand what happend. This was where I had to go no matter what once I reached Cape Town. I had to see and pay my respects to the Men and Woman that were imprisoned here for political "differences."What happened here was wrong, so very wrong, but as in other countries including my own there is not always a place left to visit to pay respect. Robben Island is an exception to this. Your tour is conducted by a prisoner and the story they tell needs to be heard before they are gone.You will take boat ride from the V&A and it is about 30 min's from the waterfront. Take your time, wonder around, mail a postcard from there and step inside a cell and shut the door.Than you will understand.
Eye-opening. A very thought-provoking experience made more 'real' by being led by a former prisoner with first hand experience. Would highly recommend

Worth Waiting in Line. Although the lines were long to take the ferry and enter Robben Island, it was totally worth it. Since the tour was facilitated by a former inmate, it added authenticity to the tour. We purchased our tickets through the hotel concierge, so that was easy. Seeing how white prisoners were treated vs. how black prisoners were treated was surreal. A prisoner is a prisoner. The prison was much smaller than I expected, but it was still a great experience.

Definitely worth the visit but could be much better organised. The history behind Robben Island is fascinating and definitely worth the visit. Boarding the boat to the island was slightly chaotic and the boat ride over could have been better organised (but I think this depends on which vessel you travel over on as trip over in Sea Princess was crazy but it was very civilised coming back on Susan Kruger). Pack plenty of water especially if it is a hot day and there isn't much opportunity over the 3.5 hours to go to the bathroom so take the opportunity when you can. From talking to friends who did the tour but at different times, the quality of the tour is dependent on the tour guide allocated to your group. Ours was good but could have gone more in depth for the non South African tourists in our group. Some of the signs on the island are very worn and tired and these could be revamped to provide more information on the history as well. The bus allocations where disorganised and there was a a lot of unnecessary stopping and starting along the tour. I still really enjoyed the history and it is something you must do when travelling to Cape Town but the whole operation could be a lot more organised and professional.
very good tour , very interesting. good tour to do ,, they just need to change the buses ,, their out of date too noisy when the guide was explaining things around the island
The must see of South Africa. Impressive, emotional, historical, inspiring.... An absolute must see when visiting Cape town. Booking in advance is recommended.

Totally engaging. It's an experience. I knew the history behind the people and why they were incarcerated on the island. But being there is like walking in their shoes. Sitting inside a cell, seeing Nelson Mandela's cell made it all so real. The fact that people came out of there with dignity and strength is beyond belief and a credit to the human spirit. Past prisoners are the guides and that adds another touch of reality. It's a life determining experience to visit the island and you shouldn't miss the opportunity.

A lovely trip - could be improved. We visit Robben Island by booking tickets online with the help of our hotel. The ferry ride was about 45mins - hour each way. The tours are carried out by an Ex-inmate which adds a little depth to it. The prison itself isn't huge and we were surprised that there is a community living on the island which itself is very beautiful. The trip was good but it was sometimes hard to hear the guide and he moved on quickly, not waiting for others to view and catch up. Also there is an assumption to your knowledge of the history of the Apartheid law which, whilst we had some knowledge and had watched the Mandela movie, we still had to fill in gaps afterwards. They don't make the most of the cafe and shop either. A lovely trip though and worth doing.

Great historical and cultural tour. We were lucky enough to book a couple of days ahead. Make sure you leave time as if it's windy and the water is too choppy, the tours get cancelled and you have to reschedule. The day we went was fine. We caught the second boat - which is faster and beats the first boat back. Boat ride was very comfortable. When you arrive on the island they tell you to go to the busses over loudspeaker, but there is not much direction. Some of these busses are for particular tour groups, and if they run out of busses, you start the tour at the closest point and walk. We were lucky enough to get the first bus and started at the furthest point, which got us back first. The island tour was really informative and the prison tour was hosted by a wonderful man who was a political prisoner on the island. His stories are from the heart and he is so passionate about what he does. This was our favourite part of the tour. I am glad we did the tour, just out of respect for what the political prisoners endured and how much they fought for their rights.

Powerful and thought provoking. Whilst we were in Cape Town we knew we we wanted to visit the prison on Robben Island. As we were visiting out of season we were able to get tickets easily without having to queue. The journey over to the island takes about 40 minutes but is very enjoyable as you get to view Cape Town and Table Mountain from a distance. Once we arrived at the Island we got onto a bus which then gave us a short guided tour around the Island. The guide on our bus was very knowledgable and humourous and pointed out the various points of interest like the leper graveyard and the place where the prisoners were forced to work every day. The views are stunning but you get a feeling of how depressing it must have been to see the South African mainland in the distance and to know you might never step foot on it again. After the bus completed it's short tour we met our prison guide, a former prisoner, who took us around the prison over the next 90 minutes or so. The tour was very interesting, to hear the stories from someone who actually lived through it was very powerful. You have to remember that many of the men who were sent to Robben Island were political prisoners who were arrested for having an opinion - our guide was only a student when he was arrested for holding a meeting at his college - yet they were treated worse than many of the 'proper' criminals. On the tour we got to see the cell that Nelson Mandela spent 18 of his 27 years in prison. So many men lost the best years of their lives here, the least we can do is remember what they went through. If you are in Cape Town I highly recommend going on this tour, it really makes you think.

Wonderful Tour and Experience. We enjoyed the Robben Island tour very much. The bus ride offered a good overview of the Island and its history, and the guide leading that part of the tour was friendly and knowledgable. Having a former inmate show us the prison was unique and gave visitors a special insight to the experience there. Seeing Nelson Mandela's cell was an emotional experience. This is a tour well worth doing. Those who experience sea-sickness should be prepared, as the ride to and from the Island was quite choppy and made many on the ferry feel ill.

Interesting tour in the history of SA and stunning nature and views as well. Very very fascinating place! Tours are guided with ex-political prisoners, they are so friendly and interesting as they tell you their own stories. Especially Sedeeq was the best! You can see the cell of Nelson Mandela as well. Nature around is breathtaking, we saw penguines, turtle, many birds and seals. Views of table mountain and Cape town are amazing too. Book in advance in summer, as the early tours are always sold out. The downside of this trip was that the groups are way too large and there was not enough time just to stroll around the island and enjoy its beauty.

Robben Island boat trip. The trip to Robben Island was very interesting. The guides on the tour were well informed and ours on the bus trip round the island also had a great sense of humour. Our second guide had been incarcerated in the prison for being a dissident, for many years and spoke from first hand experience which was very moving. The island had imprisoned many different types of people over the years, not only the dissidents from the apartheid years. A good trip.

Again a historical must visit site. Some tour presenters were ex-political prisoners. Tipping is not mandatory unlike the US. After hearing those shared memories, and looked around faces of different colors, it was a well worthy trip.
Indeed," Freedom cannot be manacled!"

Very interesting. This takes 4 hours out of your day but is worth doing to understand the history and story of apartheid in South Africa. Guided tours from former prisoners are the highlight with some stories hard to believe. Travel to the island and transfers to buses aren't as slick as they could be, but if you can get over that, you'll have a good time.

A visit with a lot of potential, but which could be carried out much better. Visiting Robben Island should be one of the highlights of Cape Town tourism, however I found it to be quite disappointing. It's a shame that no time to left to walk around the island and enjoy the natural scenery, and the size of our group was too big for the visit of the prison. Most times we could not hear what the guide was saying. He had a strong accent, which was difficult to understand for us - that cannot be helped but if we had been fewer people it would not have been such a problem. All in all, a must-do, but there is a lot of room for improvement.

Robben Island . We took a ferry to here , we bought tickets from the water front , and the ferry was a short trip to the island , we so lots of wild birds on the way , when we got there we were put in groups and taken round with a x in mate , he gave us lots of information on the prison and on the way it was run , Nelson Mandela was here in his time so it was very interesting we went in his cell and so his work place , a good trip

A moving experience.. One must visit this place and a get a real feeling of what it was like to be imprisoned here for Mandela, Sobukwe, and other political prisoners. We had a private tour with a guide that was a former prisoner there and it was a very emotional tour to hear and walk in the same footsteps as Mandela.

Very interesting and emotive visit. We caught the ferry across from the V&A Waterfront, on a bright sunny day in October. The crossing was scheduled for 30 minutes but took nearer to 50 as the sea was fairly rough partway across. We did see a whale on the way though!Once on the island we were divided up, some people walking to the prison first while our group did the bus tour first. You will get to do both. The bus tour took us past Robert Subokwe's house, the leper cemetery and the hospital, all the while with a commentary from a guide. He, like the the other guides, were all original prisoners from the prison. The only problem was that the microphone was not very loud so it was hard to hear him while the bus engine was running.After the bus tour we were dropped at the prison building and given a walking tour of the cells and dormitories, including of course Nelson Mandela's cell. Many of the cells contain details of their occupant, sometimes with the option to hear their voices or see some of their letters or belongings. Our guide for this section was a gentleman called Nindisi Siswana (apologies for the spelling if wrong), who was excellent, really bringing it to life with exactly the right mix of pathos and uplifting endeavour.

An important visit. To see how people have been treated during the apartheid was to me a sad experience, but still one I think everybody should do to make sure history doesn't repeat itself. The visit to robben island was a bit to rushed by the guides, which brings it down to a 3/5.

VERY MOVING EXPERIENCE. My wife and I found the experience very moving and instructional, seeing the conditions under which Nelson Mandela lived in prison. Our guide's situation was very sad - he had been an inmate but was released when the policy changed. Unfortunately he was unable to find work after release but was taken back to Robben Island, where he now lives and acts as a guide for visitors, His delivery was very touching. At times it was difficult to comprehend how man could be so cruel to man.

Warning: You would rather do something else. This place has the potential to be the best tourist attraction in the whole of South Africa. But unfortunately the whole Robben Island experience must be reworked.

Disapointing. What a shame the Long Walk to Freedom has been over processed and commercialised. I was very disappointed. Bus loads of tourists being pushed through rapidly, lack of direction as to where we were to be picked up when arriving at the ferry terminal. There were at least three bus loads of people each bus carrying around 60, going around the island when we were there with even more arriving and many school groups. The tour lacks organisation and was totally chaotic at times. Groups too large and people often unable to see or hear what the guide was saying. Something which I had been looking forward to, it is an experience not to be repeated or recommended.

Exceptional, Moving!. Our group, and I suspect most, was led by a former political inmate who served time on Robben Island. His stories, sadly, made the island come alive, with tales of torture and other brutality at the hands of the guards, but along with an amazing bond of unity among the inmates. Show no fear, where there was fear; show no anger, where anger roiled; don't give the cards any indication of what and where any leverage may be brought to bear. All were political prisoners (yes, some committed serious crimes) who shared a common enemy and relied upon the collective strength of those incarcerated to survive under the harshest of circumstances. MOVING!

Mixed feelings. This is an amazing place that has an amazing history and story to tell about human rights. The guides who tell their stories are to be admired and appreciated for what they endured and what they achieved in the fight for freedom. A most important time in history. As a tourist experience it is lacking in organisation, infrastructure and customer service. Busses were cramped and dirty, microphones failed, you were unable to see clearly from the bus and there was no invitation to explore the island after the formal tour was completed. To me this should be a full day trip, with time to explore the full history that this island has to offer, not only as a prison for political dissidents, but its former history as a leper colony and assylum. This place has the potential to be a high impact, emotionally charged attraction but for me it fell way short of this.

A Must Do Attraction. South Africa's recent history is so obviously attached to this particular piece of geography that it is hard to imagine a trip to Cape Town with considering this opportunity to walk, feel, and absorb some of this reality. The attraction is well organized, as tasteful as such an institution can be, and generally a very pleasant way to experience and reflect on this bit of history. If you are lucky enough to enjoy good weather on the day you visit, it is a delightful experience to perhaps encounter whales in the water on the way over or back, in addition to the history while on the island.

History maketh man. Painful path down memory lane of what took place here, but worthwhile to retell the stories. Apartheid was evil and no one deserves such treatment- may the human race learn and help future generations to avoid a repeat of such evil.

Historical must see. The historical importance of this island makes it almost a must to visit this place.Ex-political prisoners are providing more background.While both the boats and busses are well arranged, it still feels like the tour is done in a rush with too large groups. Smaller groups and more walking could have improved the experience.

Lot's of history, not much touring. The island has an amazing amount of history and our guide was amazing in telling some of it to us with humor and story telling talent. However the island lacks some "extra", it could have been done a lot fancier and more planning.A clear highlight is the fact that most guides are either ex-political prisoners or people who are attached to the apartheid scenario.
Excellent!. For a walk around the history of apartheid go to Robben Island. Unforgettable and thought provoking!

Robben Island trip : A morning well spent in Cape Town. When we reached the Victoria and Alfred Waterfront, one afternoon in April, we walked up to the place where ferries take off to Robben Island. To our greatest disappoint, we found that all the tickets are sold out for that day, and we had to come next morning. So make it a point to book your tickets early to suit your itinerary. We bought out tickets for next morning trip and arrived for the 830 am trip. We made the trip, and we didn’t mind all this hassle because it was fully worth it, for two reasons. Firstly it was a long awaited moment in my life to be where this great man was incarcerated for 18 long years, and secondly, the amazingly beautiful scene of Cape town, flanked by her famous mountains slowly appearing and taking their full shape and dimensions when you approach land in your return trip was truly a sight to behold. Robben Island is both a South African National Heritage Site as well as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.The comfortable and covered ferry took about an hour to reach the island. From there, there were comfortable busses to take you to the prison. There was an English speaking guide, who was very witty, like most of the SA guides I have met, gave us a commentary briefing us about the history of the islands and s description of the important buildings and sights. We stopped by to have a cup of coffee and then went to see the prison complex where Mr. Mandela was held. The description of the prison life was given by one of former inmates. Unfortunately this gentleman who gave us the commentary had a very hoarse voice and spoke in a low volume and spoke with a heavy accent and I couldn’t follow anything he said. To date, three of the former inmates of Robben Island have gone on to become President of South Africa: Nelson Mandela, Kgalema Motlanthe, and current President Jacob Zuma.After photographs we were taken to see where Mandela was incarcerated. We were not so lucky to see penguins that day.The return trip was in an ancient ferry , Dias, and we were able to travel on the deck. We were fascinated by the sight of approaching Cape, in its all glory. The Devil’s Peak, Table Mountain, Signal Hill, Twelve Apostles, all these peaks were visible from sea and looked so beautiful.We arrived at the Jetty in time to see huge seals.It was certainly worth of every Rand we spent…

GREAT INSIGHT INTO THE LONG WALK..... Being South African, this was a must see place. It was shoking and a bit emotional to think the President who freed our country from Apartheid spent 27 years of his like living in this place. great for historical value

Visit to Robben Island. This was my 3rd visit to Robben Island, each time visiting Sout Africa with a different grandson. as a youngster I used to sail to the island before it was used as a jail. Each visit brings a different perspective to the island and I as an Israeli just wish to ourselves both a mandela and a de Kierk.Worth a visit

Great History but Renovated. Any first-time trip to Cape Town requires a trip to Robben Island. The history alone compels the visit. Always check the day of your trip, as the ferry can be cancelled sometimes because of choppy seas. The island itself is a great visit, and the tour led by former inmates can be really, really good if you get the right guide. The only sad thing is that they have renovated the cells with a new coat of paint and dressed them all up, rather than leave them as they were (like other jail monuments, such as Alcatraz in the USA), so it leaves you with the impression that the accommodation was a lot better than what it was. That was probably the only disappointing feature of the trip.

Sobering Experience. Had perfect weather on our tour of Robben Island. Was more than interesting taking the tour and learning the history of the island. We then had a guide, who had been a prisoner, walk us through the prison area. There was so much to learn about that time of South Africa's history.

Interesting and moving, but maybe not worth the hassle.. While this place REALLY is an interesting and worthwhile experience, it almost wasn't worth the time and hassle to get tickets and get out there.
Nelson Mandela's cell.. It was so emotional due to history. Listening to a guide who had experienced life at the island was the final straw for me.

Second visit but didn't disappoint. We last visited Robben Island 10 years ago. Since then it has become a much busier tourist attraction. The bus tour around the Island was good and has been made better as you can now get off the buses and explore some areas, however the buses are much bigger than they used to be and it feels like you are being herded round. The prison tour was great - really informative as it was led by a former prisoner. All in all a worthwhile visit.
Moving. The tour of Robbin Island was fantastic. The tour guides are past prisoners. It's interesting to see Mandela's cell, but the entire property and the information given is eye opening.

Mesmorizing. Sometimes in your life you realise how lucky you are.
