On Robben Island we heard an ex prisoner talk about his painful memories of the Robben island prison, we saw cell 5 where Nelson Mandela spent 18 years and met Christos Brando one of the guards who ended up befriending Nelson Mandela. This trip is a must for anyone visiting Capetown and very thought provoking.

Disappointing. Being a place of such historic importance visited by local and international visitors, I expected more. The place is a bit neglected, specially the gardens, and the personnel not well trained or friendly.More could be done to entice visitors and give value for money (the trip is quite pricey): a continuously running video describing the history in a visitor's room; a place to rest and eat (with a view); more and better washrooms; more variety of books in shop.

A complete must of a trip. this is a very informative trip. an important piece of world history. the place is quite bleak as you would imagine but i felt it was right to not pretty it up. you can sense the atmosphere of how it must have felt, isolated and yet being able to out toward the shore and cape town and freedom.. We were shown around by an ex prisoner who's crime was only to stand up to oppression. for that he did seven years. it was very moving hearing his story but he asked for no pity just calmly explained the basics of how he came to be imprisoned. both my 21 year old daughter and i really enjoyed this trip, so glad we did it. the boat trip to and from the island was a nice thing to experience also, bit choppy coming back but a great way to make friends. i sat on a womans lap twice.. lol my sea legs are not what they used to be.

Remarkable Future. This tour is a three hour tour from the time you leave the pier in Cape Tour. If you want to know more of how the island came to be and all its uses, this tour will answer your questions. You will find out that it was not just a prison but was used by the military plus other things. The first hour talks about all the uses of the island with bits of history about Nelson Madela. The second part of the tour you will leave the bus to go into the cell of your actual tour guide. Our guide was imprisoned for 6 1/2 yrs. before he was released in 1994. He was to serve 25 years. After viewing his cell and the area he was only allowed to visit we went to Nelson's cell where he stayed for 27 years in a one person cell. In it you will see his stool, floor mat, and metal cup. You will also view others who were in the cell by themselves. The tour is very visual. The three hours viewing all of the different sites passerby so quickly.
Very good. It was briliant. I liked the fact they didn't dwell on Nelson Mandela for the entire of the trip however I don't think there was enough time to look around properly
Interesting. The tours are "okay", but all you do is look at the attractions through the bus window, but I guess its far to walk around the island, other than that it was a quite informative tour.

Disorganised and disappointing. I hate to say it, but this was the most disappointing and disorganized tour I have ever done. We ended up in a group of about 200 to tour the prison area. The poor guide had real difficulty shepherding this number around and it was almost impossible to hear what he was saying. At the end of the prison tour we were meant to embark on a bus to enable us to see more of the island, including the quarry, other prison complexes and the village. There weren’t enough buses available to cater for the numbers so we were some of the people who waited over 40 minutes of the 2 hours we were on the island for a bus to appear and the tour had to be foreshortened in order to get us back to the wharf to board the boat on time. We didn’t see some of the places advertised and the guide had to rush everything she did.There was no need for this to happen. The tour operator would have known exactly how many people were going to arrive and it should have been possible for them to arrange a sufficient number of guides and buses accordingly. I left with the impression they were more interested in making money than in giving visitors a positive experience. If this is the case they are insulting Mandela and all the others who were held at Robben Island.

Be wary of buying a ticket online & of unhelpful staff. I booked a ticket online. The computer screen showed the time/date I wanted, and this is what I selected, but I was instead issued a ticket for the next available tour (when I couldn't attend as I was working). I emailed immediately asking them to fix this (it was the middle of the night so I couldn't phone), but they didn't reply. I phoned first thing the next morning and was passed from person to person. Ultimately a supervisor phoned me back, said it was my fault (she didn't believe me when I explained I had selected the correct time/date), and wouldn't swap the date even though tickets were available at the time I'd tried to book. She said I'd have to buy another ticket, which seemed to be a blatant attempt to milk tourists of their money. So it was 300 Rand (around US$25) down the drain! I don't really know what happened, but I am certain i chose the correct time/date and I suspect the computer 'timed out' while my overseas credit card verification was happening, thus issuing a different ticket to what I could see on the screen. In any event, the staff were unnecessarily unhelpful, and insisted that I'd left it too late to do anything about it because it was within 48 hours of the issued date (their T&C say tickets can be changed up to 48 hrs beforehand for an admin fee, but they wouldn't change it even though I offered to pay the admin fee) -- notwithstanding that this was because the ticket that issued was for that day rather than the day I wanted!! Needless to say, I was not impressed. The staff at the Radisson Blu Hotel (where I was attending a conference) tried to assist but were also startled by how unhelpful the Robben Island people were -- a strange way to run a tourist attraction that presumably the New South Africa wants people to see so they can understand the brutality of the past. So I never made it to Robben Island, and can't tell you what the attraction itself is like.
Informative and worth the visit. It was a good visit. Got a chance to learn more on Nelson Mandela and the island. Well organized tour.

good to visit. We really enjoyed the trip to the island.The island has a rich history way before the most famous stories regarding the use as a prison during apartheid.We were glad our guide on the bus Keith was very hilarious and made the trip fun and somber at the same time.The ferry ride to the island is also very exciting

place to remember. A place where you can feel the history. A place that you are able to see where the big changes at South Africa really happened. You are able to see where there prisoners where locked and how they were feed and put to work. It is shocking to see the way the prisoners were treated. To know the African history you have to be there.

Historically amazing but rushed!. Such an amazing history packed place, would have loved to spend some real time there getting a feel for it all but instead you are packed in bus with many others and given the rush through version of a tour and then sent back on a boat smart.

Beautiful and interesting - but not a lot of information. It just does not feel right to give such an historically important site an average review, however this is my honest view of the tour. It was over crowded, rather unorganized. After arriving by boat we all just stood around not sure what to do and where to go - and only after 20 minutes did the buses for the first part of the tour show up. Additionally the information provided was in my opinion really limited. It was an honor to "meet" a man (guide on the prison part of the tour) who had suffered at the hands of apartheid and was actually imprisoned on Robben Island, however there were just too many people and we could barely hear what he had to share. That was a real shame because I would have loved to be able to hear more and perhaps even get to speak with him directly. Somehow I just felt like this tour did not give the correct weight to what really happened there. It felt to me like it was all a bit swept under the rug...which is sad because the people of tomorrow should really understand the mistakes of the people of yesterday to make sure that they are never to be repeated.

Could have been better.. Ferry went early as it was filled up. Good journey over. Very disorganised at other end. Far too many people, some went on 2 buses others to the jail. The tour was a farce, couldn't understand what the guide was saying. Other groups were trying to get out as we were trying to get in parts of the jail and vice a versa. Bus was good and saw penguins. The ferry home was great, with music.

very educational. excellent place to visit, its a must, Ferries only run when weather is good, we were fortunate that we had the first ferry over at 9 am, weather got rough, and remainder of the day, ferry did not cross

One of those things you have to do while in Cape Town. We decided to do the Robben Island tour because it's just on of those things you have to do when visiting Cape Town. However, it wasn't much of an experience for me and my husband. Wouldn't do it again but do recommend it for those going to Cape Town for the first time.

Everyone should visit this place at least once in their lifetime whether local or tourist!. Its a eerie thought provoking experience being in the place where Mandela and other political prisoners spent so many years in prison. It was really the birth place of our democratic and free country and were probably much of our current constitution was probably drafted.Its a beautiful boat trip across and we were lucky enough to see whales on the way there and back.Tips1. Its a long trip a good 5 hours and no much options or time to grab a snack so I'm glad we had lunch before we went.2. Not great on a windy rainy day as its a long trip over3. Book in advance - at least the morning of your trip as it gets very busy

Badly organised, quite disappointing (compared to other Cape Town attractions). I had heard many negative reviews about the Robben Island excursion, and the whole experience was extremely disappointing. I had many opportunities to make this trip over the last years, and kept putting it off, until I finally decided to take this trip. Sadly, I will NEVER do it again, and will NEVER recommend it to anyone else either. From the arrival and boarding like a bunch of cattle to a broken-down ferry ... it's a very very disappointing and badly run excursion. Extremely sad, since it can be so much more impressive and memorable.
Very interesting. Birth place of South Africa's freedom, where Mandela, was kept for so many years...enjoyed the boat ride across, amazing tour and really sad all at the sametime.

Very moving experience. The whole trip was a humbling and moving experience. You get a boat over to Robben Island and are then taken by coach with a guide round the island, stopping for a coffee break before reaching the prison. It's an ex political prisoner who gives you a guided tour of the prison with first hand experience of the conditions they stayed in. You see the cell Nelson Mandela stayed in. Well worth a visit but would advice you book in advance as it's very busy

Nelson Mandela . I read the book by Nelson but the island did not live up to my expectations. Tours was like being hurded as if we cattle. Self/organised tour and more time on the island to reflect the triumphs of an icon in HISTORY!!!

Eye opening . If you decide to this get to the ticket booth early as they sell out quickly. The island was smooth and relaxing. Once we landed we were loaded on to a tour bus. Our tour guide was funny and friendly. We were able to walk through the prison. It was truly heart breaking to see the size of the rooms and the menu that shows how different the races were treated. Besides the prison there a few other places to see including a WWII bomb depot. If you get the chance, take some time and walk around.

See how Mendela lived for 18 years.. Book early (on line) on the first boat out. A great expereince to learn about Nelson Mendela. Can grab a coffee or a quick bite close to the boat before you head over, then walk through the waterfront district afterwards.

Well Worth a Visit. My husband & I spent a morning visiting Robben Island & learning about it's history. The guide had been a prisoner and was able to add many personal insights which added credibility to the stories we heard. It's a great experience for those of us that lived far away during Apartheid and knew little of the experiences of so many political activists.

Must see while in Cape Town. Robben Island is a must see while in Cape Town. It's very interesting to learn about where Nelson Mandela spent so much time; you get to see the room in which he lived, and hear about his story. A place of such energy, and the views are incredible looking towards Table Mountain in Cape Town. A very special place to visit.

The experience was remarkable. Enjoyed taking a trip back in time to share some of South Africa's history.Nelson Mandela spent 18 of his 27 years in prison on Robben Island. The tour was guided by former Political Prisoner's this was very impressive.

Should be a moving experience for anyone visiting South Africa, but.... The idea of visiting the prison, where so many political prisoners fought for their freedom should be a moving and memorable experience. Unfortunately, my trip was tainted by two things - a very rough boat trip and an incomprehensible guide. After 35 minutes of rough seas (they cancelled all the rest of the trips that day) we proceeded to visit the prison - our guide a former inmate. He seemed to be a well meaning and lovely man, but his English was incomprehensible. I appreciated the fact that he wanted to give us a tour, but it doesn't help if no one could understand him. The bus trip part was great, but too short, since it was the only part we could get information. I also would have preferred being able to walk around the island. They should offer this type of tour for the interested tourist. I can't say I would recommend this.
THE "HOME" OF AN ICON. The "home" of our Icon, Nelson Mandala, for many years and well worth the visit to walk in his footsteps. And the trip by boat is amazing to get there.

Book tickets in advance. The trip to Robben Island by boat can take 15 min (large catamaran) or 45 (converted yacht), so depending on your sea legs, the catamaran is a gentler ride. You get on a bus and tour the island first- our guide was very enthusiast and knowledgeable. Then you tour the prison with an ex-inmate. There is a lot of history to take in - not just about Nelson Mandela, but how the camp and inmates were separated, who else was imprisoned there, and how they lived. The entire trip takes 3.5 hours.

Informative and important. The whole tour is well organized. The guide inside the prison is an ex political con who was locked up in there. The prison tour itself is very good, the bus ride leading up to the prison also makes very interesting stops and is very informative. However, it's a shame the bus stops for a 10 minute break at the cafeteria and restrooms (less then 15 minutes after boarding the busses from an area with a cafeteria and restrooms), yet doesn't stop and let the passengers off for the old churches or the old lepers cemetery. A bit of a miss.

Not to be missed - won't ever forget . A very emotional & informative experience We were lucky enough to be shown around by an ex inmate & it was not a busy day so we did not feel herded around.I thought I was quite well informed about apartheid & the political prisoners before our visit but we learned so much more. Very moving "Each one teach one"

A place full of history. This was a very interesting place. There is a lot of unhappy history here but I was glad we went and learned about it. My only complaint would be that we first rode around the island on a bus with 40 people and the young tour guide did not speak very loudly. Again when the pardoned political prisoner walked us through the prison, there were 40 of us and it was often hard to hear him, too. But I was still very glad we made the trip because it is such a big part of South African modern history.

Humbling experience. This trip was a wonderful and humbling experience. It is very emotional to see where Mandela lived for 18 years of his time here.Our guide was amazing sharing his stories of his time spent on Robben Island.Don't let history repeat itself. Highly recommended.

Disappointing. Given the context of what Robben Island is about it is hard to give this such a review.Poorly run, badly organised and over subscribed. We left 30 minutes late, were on an extremely slow ferry, then when we arrived were told that the people from the faster ferry had already arrived and taken all the buses. Ended up walking to the jail and had a tour by a guy we could hardly understand. The tour group was about 100 people with one guide so no way to truly get a feel for the prison.Such a waste. Feels as though they are more focused on getting people through the door and their money than actually understanding about what went on at the island.

A must visit but could have been better. A trip to Robben Island is a must if only to pay respects to those imprisoned there. I felt that whilst the Guides were informative / entertaining in their own right, as a whole experience, there was a missed opportunity to tell a much bigger story. I think some more background and information on the history behind the story would have enhanced the tour.
Very informative tour.. This was a brilliant tour and very in expensive. The staff are very knowledgeable and can answer any questions you have about the island.

Mandela's prison for 27 years. The trip to Robben Island is quite a long one and the island itself is quite bleak.It is interesting to actually see the cell that belonged to Nelson Mandela and the surrounds. But its a trip I would not do again. Once is good to say you have done it.
A Must for Everyone. Moving and educational! We were really glad to visit and really appreciative of the knowledge shared by our guide, who was a former inmate.

Robben Island Visit. Robben Island was a wonderful experience. It was very emotional and full of learning the history. Guides were fantastic and would rate this experience as being one of our highlights.Would recommend and believe it is a must for travellers to visit.
Informative, moving and sobering.. Must see historical site to understand the history of South Africa. Very well organized. The highlight was definitely the tour by a former political prisoner.

Must do. This is a must do (in my opinion) when visiting Cape Town as the island plays an important role in the history of Cape Town & South Africa. While it was incredible to see the cell where Nelson Mandela was held for so many years, we felt that the tour was not terribly well run. An ex-prisoner was the guide while going through the jail, which should have been very enlightening (and it was at times), but we had a hard time hearing him due to it being a large group, and he was often very difficult to understand, so a lot of what he said was lost. You spend part of the tour in the jail, and then part on a bus going around the island. The island itself has great views of Cape Town and Table Mountain (and you may spot some penguins). Definitely book the trip in advance as it tends to sell out. You take the ferry from the V&A waterfront to the island (about 15 minutes on the ferry). Overall, I definitely think this is something that should be done on a visit to Cape Town, but I felt the tour of the jail was a little lacking which was disappointing.

Waste of time. Told to be at ticket office for 2.30 or won't get in! Finally left at 3.30 put onto what was the slow boat nearly 40 minutes later we arrive.rushed off and then told to walk to the gate of the prison! The man talking was very hard to understand! It was not an enjoyable trip at all! We were then loaded onto a bus for a very short tour of the island which I found very cramped and smelly! Best part about the trip was that we were the lucky group who got the fast boat back..I really feel I have lost out on an experience I was so looking forward too..waste of money and time!

Too regimented. Robbed Island was a must visit place for me as soo as I went to Capetown but was disappointed by the amount of regimentation on the obligatory guided tour. Too much time was spent on the old leper e church etc. Then a reasonable amount of time at the site of the lime quarry but a very limited time was allowed for the visit to the prison which was the main reason many of us made the trip. There was no time allowed to just explore at least a little of the island with strict I junctures to keep to the paths at all times. It would have been lovely to be allowed a but more time there as it was strictly regimented. Went out on the boat and returned on the same boat after allotted time on the island. Although we met ex prisoners we had no real chance to interact with them at all

A moving and oddly uplifting experience. Do know that this is weather dependent, so go early in your trip as the tour could be cancelled at any time. The boat ride is about 35 mins. each way. The bus tour, which is quite good though the bus seats are a little on the small side, is about an hour, including a restroom and snack stop. The walking tour, which is lead by a former political prisoner, lasts about 45 mins. This part is the star of the show, where you find out about the horrific personal experiences that these men lived through. Our guide finished by thanking us for visiting this beautiful prison, and made sure that we all knew that he was now friends with the prisoners and guards who still live on the island with him and that what was fought for was achieved, so why have negative feelings, just move on. What an amazing outlook we could all learn from.

Great educational experience. We expected to be rather bored, but we found it a very exhilarating experience. Interesting & Memorable. Interesting and memorable, that was my experience on Robben Island. I didn't particularly enjoy the boat trip....

Get your ticket in advance.Long queues and often sold out. Take tour from 1100 or 1300 (no later)Just do it and go there, and you will know and remember the number 466/64 forever (Mr N. Mandela)

Informative and recommended. Informative and interesting trip to Robben Island with the biggest highlight being a former prisoner narrating his tales during the days of his struggle. A memorable visit. Book well in advance. Make sure that you book this trip well in advance once you arrive in Cape town most hotels can book it for you its best to check the weather reports as you do need a fine day. This trip cannot be booked on the day due to the limited amount of passengers the boat can take over to the island and the coaches that ware available for the tours of the island It is quite along walk from the jetty to the coaches on Robben Island hence the fine day.The tour is excellent and you do learn a lot more about the island from it being a leper colony to a prison is not what you would expect and then the tour inside the prison is really interesting.
compulsory for all. fascinating. outstanding tour guide. this trip should be a pilgrimage for everyone.well organised. need more time.

Walk to Freedom. A very memorable visit, which I will always remember. We had an ex prisoner who guided us through various cells and was very knowledgable on daily life. It was great to learn about South Africa's greatest president, learn about his daily routine and see his cell.

very interesting visit. excursion very interesting, to well understand the history of south africa. suggest to reserve on line some days you want to go. half day tour. guide very professional and kind

A very significant place in modern history.. Excellent journey through the history of the people who suffered imprisonment simply for demanding what was rightfully theirs as human beings. Short walk to freedom. I'm am very happy that I got to go there and see the history about South Africa greatest president. Very disappointing- don't bother. very disappointed in our tour to Robben Island as it was near the top of the bucket list on our first visit to Cape Town. Not to be missed. Over rated big time. Well worth a visit and not because it served as a jail during the days of Apartheid.. Avoid at all costs - worst tourist trap ever - unless you like being treated like a prisoner yourself. The trrip to Robben Island is a horrble tourist trap and was definately the worst of the Cape Twon expriences (which otherwise were all great).If you are interested on the history of this place, buy the book for 125 Rand and or visit the exhibition at Jetty 1 down at the Waterfront.That is unless you want to be treated like a prisoner yourself, than this is probably a great experience.We were put onto a boat, which in very little waves produced the most severe movements and took more than 50 minutes to get to the 7.5 km away island (the return journey miravulously only took 25 minutes).Upon arrival we were instructed via a loudspeaker system to get into a very uncomfortable bus (5 seats per row), severe safety hazards (worn-down tyres and wrongly assembled wheesl) and a guide, who must have been the most arrogant South African I came across. When we visited the toilet anyway, another boat was available after all.Everything seemed to be tailored to limit time for people on the island and especially prevent individual exploriation.I assume, they would have loged, if we just paid our entrance fee and then not go at all.If you do go to the island, don't get on a bus and be initimadated by their strange instructions, after all we are visitors and not inmates.It seeemedthere is lotsto explore on the island, if you get the opportunity.

Worth a trip for insight on apartheid and political prisoners held here. What made this trip to Robben Island so impactful, was having the tour led by a former inmate, who could talk about his experience first-hand. A must for any visit to Cape Town. Don't miss out on this trip. Excellenty guided tours by former inmates of this infamous prison, where Nelson Mandela spent decades of his life are the highlight of this trip to the island in the middle of Tale Bay. Humble experience. An amazing experience that reminds us all of how far we have come, and the courage and resilience that some people have to fight for humanity and equality.

A historic place to visit.. A nice ride to the island . An ex-prisoner was a guide. He showed the maximum security prison for political prisoners. The quarry where the the prisoners were made to work back-breaking jobs without any respite. They also showed the room where Nelson Mandela was held.

Recommended. We went in early spring and were fortunate to walk in and get tickets on the day. 3 trips a day at 9,11 and 13. Trip takes about an hour to get there and an hour back which left about 2 hours fro the visit. First half was a bus tour going round the various cell blocks. The bus stopped about half way round at a little cafe which sold snacks and drinks, this appears to be the only place to eat on the trip apart from the boat which only sold drinks and crisps. Many people had brought there own food. Our guide was very good and clearly experienced. The highlight of the tour was the walking part, led by an ex-inmate. This was really interesting and for a cynic like me strangely moving. I would recommend.

emotional yet necessary stop on a visit to cape town. We saved our visit to Robben Island until the last day of our trip. It was a gorgeous sunny day which made the 45 minute ferry ride to Robben Island bearable. The process to get tickets was messy as the online website was not working for us and our concierge tried to call for tickets but no one was picking up. Fortunately, we were able to get tickets for the same day. We spent about 1/2 hour before the ferry ride exploring the museum which had some interesting displays but probably could be more robust. The ferry ride offers a beautiful view of the ocean and city behind you. However, it can be a bumpy ride- so fair warning for those who get motion sickness. Once you get off the ferry, you're shuttled onto buses and driven around the island. This is the part of the tour that, while informative, could have been shortened a bit but there are some interesting landmarks besides the prison. Then you're let off at the prison and met by a former prisoner who guides you on a tour of the various blocks. Our guide was very open and honest about his stay there and shared a lot of information with us. Overall, I'm glad we went but I think the whole process could be a little more organized and cohesive.

Walk in the footsteps of South African freedom fighters. Experience the not so beautiful side of this gorgeous country. Robben Island demonstrates the ugly past of the new South Africa. This tour highlights the sad legacy of colonisation and South Africa's bitter history. A pleasant boat ride will take you to the prison used for many years during apartheid and before as a place for lepers, prisoners and other undesirables. A driving tour of the island is followed by a walk through the prison itself. The prison tour is conducted by prior detainees. Some of these guides are more articulate than others but all seem to bring alive the time of the struggle for equal rights. Every South African school should have this as a curriculum requirement.

Amazing recent histoy. Really interesting tour around the island and prison. Well worth the trip. Worth booking in advance online. The bus tour is quite packed, and I recommend sitting on the right hand side of the bus.The guides were excellent and knowledgable. Well worth the half-day trip. The trip to Robben Island begins with a boat trip from the Cape Town waterfront to the island. Overall, well worth it. NOTE: be sure to buy your tickets in advance -- the trips do sell out, particularly if the weather or sea conditions on preceding days is such that tours were cancelled on those days.
A must see.. The tour starts on a bus and was given by a very knowledgeable guide. The walking tour of the prison grounds was given by a past prisoner. This was a very emotional and relevant tour.

Prison. another must when visiting Cape Town, very important historical place but can also be a bit depressing. Nelson Mandela was imprisoned there and the tour guides are ex-inmates which provides an even better inside in to history.

Don’t Miss so Book In Advance. Robben Island is one of the must see sights in Cape Town and is extremely popular. Don’t expect to just turn up and get a place on a tour; there is only one way to get there and that is on one of the three daily tours operated by the official company. I was advised to book the tour before even going to Cape Town and did so online several weeks in advance. Another tip I would offer is to sit inside. I was tempted by the thought of sitting outside at the front and arrived at the Island pretty wet as the boat bounced over the waves. The tour is very well organised with a bus trip round the island, including a couple of stops, one of which offers beautiful views over the sea to Cape Town and Table Mountain, before arriving at the prison. The prison, and of course Nelson Mandela's cell, is the highlight of the tour and the guide and later one of the former political prisoners previously held there gave very descriptive accounts. There is not really a great amount to see on the island, or even in the prison itself, but I found the whole tour a very moving experience. I did brave the outside front of the boat again on the return journey and was rewarded with some great views as we headed back to Cape Town, as well as another soaking.

Powerful Place.. A visit to Robben Island is a must for visitors to Cape Town. A must see at least once.. Enjoyed the Boat ride to the Island. A must see at least once. A lot of History to be learnt. Took the tour throughout the island and the prison.

Shameful History, Shamefully Presented. Organised by our travel agent for us on our second day in Cape Town, we had high expectations given our experience on the first day with our private tour, but this was a reminder of how many things can be screwed up when presenting an iconic part of South Africa's recent history. Our tickets had been prepaid, so we headed straight for the scanners: we waited a few minutes before being allowed to pass through the scanners and board the boat. The queuing area looked like it could hold about 30-40 people at a time, and was quite modern. More on this later ...After boarding and heading upstairs on the boat, we took our seats: as we were doing so, the safety officer kept calling for volunteers to fill up the VIP section, which was a glassed area on the second floor. Why anyone would pay extra to sit there, we couldn't work out as the door was left open (upstairs is very noisy) and most of the VIP folks left anyway once we got underway. The safety officer welcomed us with what should have been a humorous talk, but the delivery was wooden and no one laughed. It appears that someone has scripted these presentations but not explained the technique of delivery. Arriving at the island, we were directed by loudspeaker to board buses at the end of the pier. These were decrepit looking vehicles with 5-wide seating (anyone in the isles was bumped by other guests) and dirty windows ... so no point trying to take photos. The "45" minute bus tour was really a 10-minute affair, with 15-20 mins spent the first stop so that our bus driver could cuddle with her partner while guests mingled, took photos of Cape Town and purchased snacks at a run down cafe. There was a presenter in the bus, but like the safety officer on the boat, the delivery of the information on Robben Island was limited to whatever the speech writer had written, and was given in a monotone (including the "jokes"). There is such a rich history to be told that it cries out for someone to make it interesting and engaging.After the first stop, the bus moved onto a quarry, with a stop of 5-10mins (no boyfriend to cuddle there) and then onto the prison where one of the political prisoners walked us through. While he was friendly, he was very hard to understand - I got about half of what we was saying. He harangued us for about 5 minutes at the entrance quoting Nelson Mandela's prisoner number until everyone in the group could repeat it before we set off: it was needlessly pedantic, and upset a few people who were embarrassed that it took 4 or 5 attempts for them to remember it. The tour ran late, and everyone headed back quickly to the wharf to catch the return boat. We need not have bothered: there had been a breakdown and it was chaos with several boatloads of people trying to board a single craft. There were no announcements as people ignored a lame attempt to ask everyone to queue up. We stayed downstairs for the return trip as it is quieter and more comfortable. When we got back to the mainland, there was an enormous queue stretching for about 100meters beyond the threshold of the building used by board the boats. Really, this should be better managed, coordinated and presented - I'd love to return and see it improved but if it is just more of the same, I'd save my time and read Wikipedia instead as I learned almost nothing from the experience.

Overrated, crowded bus tour and disorganised. I had high hopes for Robben Island because I love history so much but I was quite disappointed with the overall experience of this tour. My biggest complaint is that you get on old, crowded buses and driven around the prison grounds. They stop at historical sites, such as the quarry where Mandela and other inmates secretly taught each other different things and ideas, but you can't get out of the bus. I was on the wrong side of the bus and could barely see through other people's heads. There were a few other sites that were obstructed by small bus windows and people! The 2nd complaint is that the tour guide, although he was an actual inmate, was not a proper tour guide. He had no stories and was boring actually. It was super disorganised and my group of 40 were pushed through small doors and corridors and I had no idea where to go. I also left the island feeling like I had no idea about Mandela. I would have given it a 1 star but the view of Cape Town from the boat ride is fantastic. I would recommend going to a museum over going to Robben Island.

Sacred soil. If you are a citizen of the world, this is a must-see stop. The one-time shame of the apartheid government has been turned into a sacred shrine. Mandatory to visit this memory site.. Ticketing and boat crossing are well organized. Absolutely diabolical.. We should have gone to robben Island but got the timing wrong so missed the trip fair enough I accept it was our problem. My issue was that there must have been free spaces on the boat if people did not turn up or something happened we we were treated appallingly and diabolically weareas everybody else in Cape town has gone out of there way to be helpful.

A lot of interesting information. This place has so much South African history - ideal for locals as well as foreignors. Very interesting fully guided tour of the island, lime quarry, prison cells etc

Overrated island. There's a lot of emotion wrapped up in this little island. A great pity then that this trip seems to have devolved into a bit of a bored shuffle through South Africa's recent history.  Bored bus drivers and equally bored guides pack visitors onto buses and whisk them around the Robben island history racetrack. The climax (after a littany of barely comprehsnsible 'struggle' names have been fired at you like a gatling gun) is to be crammed into the main prison complex with a 'former political prisoner' as a guide and historical spokesperson. Perhaps its time for some investment in a public address system in order for more than a handful of the visitors to listen to the dialogue. Quite probably the talk was interesting but judging from the looks, I'd guess not. The brief 10 minute coffee/ablution stop seemed to be the most popular part of the trip judging from the conversations, and despite the island also being a reserve, we were whisked away from wildlife sighting with a, 'they're just birds, who wants to see them'? Avoid - its more exciting (and cheaper) to go and buy the book, The Long Walk to Freedom, and then go for an ice cream.

Great historical tour with real meaning!. Went by boat to Robben island, only bad thing were the tickets had to be booked online and were difficult to get. but well worth it! great trip and full of lots of history and blessed to be able to have a tour guide that was a prisioner their with Nelson Mandela! .. A must see for anyone visiting Cape Town

Learning oppression. A must see--purchase tickets online in advance--you can always reschedule if poor weather. An informative guide hands you off to a former prisoner as you are escorted into the prison. Gain a fuller understanding of Nelson Mandela and his politics.

A must do tour!. If visiting South Africa for the first time, how do you not go to Robben Island. It is a very important part of Nelson Mandela's history and of course He is South Africa history. We enjoyed the tour and learning about the place such an important historical figure spent much of his life.

Robben Island is well worth a visit. You need to prebook your excursion down by the Victoria & Albert docks, the boats go frequently weather permitting. You are guided around the former prison by an ex-inmate, and taken into the cell of Nelson Mandella. It's a well paced tour and a bus will then take you around the island pointing out areas of special interest.

Powerful, thought provoking tour. I did the tour of Robben Island a couple of weeks ago. I wanted to do this to understand more about the history of the place and the tour certainly didn't disappoint. It was thought provoking and quite challenging at times.mhearing the history of the place - and not just the apartheid era history - was great, but quite uncomfortable at times when hearing about what we are capable of doing to each other as human beings!Using former political,prisoners as the guides around the prison makes the experience very real. I guess there will come a time when this will no longer be possible so I really hope that the people who look after Robben Island so everything that they can to capture the memories and raw emotion of these guides for future generations.

Impactful. The tour guides are former inmates who add a dimension of personal experience we don't get from most historical places. This is a must see to understand one of the most horrific political events of the 1900's. Well preserved.

Nice but light weight. The tour is nicely structured, a 40 minute boat ride followed by a bus ride around the island, followed by a walking tour inside the prison. It is very meaningful that all the guides are former inmates, but the content of the tour is not very deep. Maybe it's designed for school children mostly. It is a beautiful island, and it is heartbreaking to hear about these men and women separated from their families for decades, but we didn't really get a feeling for their day-to-day lives. Nelson Mandela spent 18 years here! We did get to see his cell, and the yard where he grew his garden.

Very impressive. Very interesting place and a must see when you are in the Capetown area. The most impressive was that the tour was done by an actual former political prisoner of Robben Island. The boattrip to the island is also fabulous with great views of the city.

It's difficult to imagine that Nelson Mandela spent 18 years here. There isn't a great deal to see on Robben Island but the opportunity to hear from a former prisoner is priceless. Once you arrive from the V&A Waterfront, the crowd is divided into smaller groups with each group guided through the buildings by a former prisoner. As they recount their daily routine (and some of the indignities they suffered) the now empty buildings become more menacing.

Sit On The RHS Side Of The Tour Bus!. My family and I were very humbled to have visited Robben Island but it isn't a trip I would make again nor would have attended had I known what to expect. In summary, even in SA's winter/ low season; long queues, gosling tourists all vying for the best position to take pictures, cramped tour buses with glass windows preventing photography, a prison tour guide that was difficult to understand (accepting he was an ex-inmate and we were therefore gracious of his involvement) - basically, an over-subscribed stereotypical tourist attraction full of rude and bad mannered people. A little harsh but not my `cup of tea'. The only constructive comment I can make is a recommendation from a Cape Town tour guide who advised us to sit on the right hand side of the tour bus when leaving the ferry/ boat given the tour bus circles the island clockwise and most of the sites are on the RHS of the bus. Lighting in the prison is difficult for cameras as our flash bounces off the walls and creates excessive brightness whilst no flash leaves photos too dark - if you want to take good photos think careful about your approach (hence why some many people hung back to take photos and became a bit of a nuisance). I have scored this review 3 stars simply because of the nature of the tour, i.e. desire to want to see where Nelson Mandela was incarcerated. My personal recommendation would be to book the trip online before you visit SA but have it has an `optional cancellation' should you not be able to undertake another trip and need to re-schedule your itinerary. FYI, the trip is also subject to weather with the scheduled trip the day after we attended being cancelled yet the swell on the sea did not appear excessive so if you really want to visit Robben Island as `a must' ensure you leave contingency in your plan to re-schedule.

RACIST TOUR GUIDE. I had the displeasure of witnessing a tour guide be very rude and racist towards a fellow black tourist. Do not go to this museum if you are not a rich white European or American because you'll be treated like a second class citizen by the Uncle Toms that work there!

Nelson Mandela. e spent the morning being guided around Rooben Island by a former inmate. Fascinating to hear all their stories and to see what was home to Nelson Mandela for many years.
A tip SO NOT miss the ferry as there is no refund and one has to book for another day!

Interesting insight into the complex history of South Africa and the Apartheid era. The tours were very well organized when you got off the boat at Robben Island. We were fortunate to learn about the prison, as well as how the prison was run by a former inmate! It was incredible to hear their stories and get a first hand account of what they went through during their stay. We toured some of the different prison buildings and housing facilities, and saw Nelson Mandela's cell while he was incarcerated. This was definitely worth the trip our to learn about a deep history in South Africa.

Interesting tour, very long. The tour itself was very interesting and we learned a lot. Our guide on the bus - Kent - was a good balance between serious and entertaining. Our prison guide was also quite interesting and it was good to hear first had experience of being a prisoner on the island. I did think the stop at the shop was a bit pointless and too long. We booked the 11 am tour under the impression that we would be back by 2pm, this ended up not being the case and it took up pretty much our whole day. So if you are to do this trip I recommend setting aside your full day for this trip.

A must do. Simply a must do for everyone visiting Cape Town due to its historical importance. On the island, you are taken along on a bus tour; subsequently you are guided inside the actual prison buildings by a former political prisoner. A touching experience.

Very interesting. I booked the tour with Cape Town tourism guys who had a counter at the conference centre- convention centre. They took extra effort to book me the trip on the day I wanted. Thanks for it.I really enjoyed the trip. Our guide eas an ex-political prisoner who did a very good job. It was very moving. The lady who took us around the village also very good.

Important for any Cape Town Visit. Very well done -- the way the tours are organized is well done. You are on a large ferry, but then a smaller bus and you keep to the tour. Extremely informative and I loved how some of the former prisoners are there to talk with you. It is an important perspective for everyone to understand more about Mandela and his colleagues.

Well worthwhile and a worthwhile introduction to those new to South Africa. We enjoyed our tour to Robben Island as an introduction to understanding more about Nelson Mandela and apartheid. Our guide, a former inmate, was very passionate and knowledgeable but very difficult to understand. We were herded into buses when we arrived at the island - but the group sizes were too big to be able to easily hear and see all that was there to see. Tours seemed a bit disorganised and we had to queue for more than 45 minutes before we could even get on the ferry. By the time we left the island, we were apparently running late - so they closed the shop and information centre before we had a chance to get a look which was very disappointing Would still recommend the trip. For those who get seasick - be prepared!! The sea is deceptively rough and the swell certainly played up for several on our boat who spent the trip over and back hanging close to the edge!
Very humbling and informative. Loved sharing the history of the Island with an ex- inmate to give us 1st had accounts of what it was like

Pros and Cons, but Go!. The Pros: Historic significance, your former inmate tour guide who will share his personal story and show you where he bunked, played soccer, ate, etc., physically seeing the prison and environs. Hearing about the notable inmates and of course about Nelson Mandela.The Cons: You are herded in large numbers onto the ferries, onto buses, into the prison and given not nearly enough time to experience the site and even read a small portion of the descriptive captions accompanying the displays/sites.My two cents: You are given a time to board the ferry on the way out. It did not seem to me that there was much order to boarding the ferries to return. So if I were to go again, I would stay longer and read the stories of the inmates posted about, take more pictures and shop at the gift shop - then catch the next ferry out. As it was, for some reason we did not fit on the ferry that brought us out and we had to wait 5 minutes for another ferry.

Amazing experience. This was an incredible experience! Our guide was informative and very interesting. Of course the highlight was Nelson Mandela's prison cell, but I found the rest of the tour just as interesting! At each stop on the tour before you get to the prison, a tour guide tells interesting stories and facts about the place. The island is also beautiful and on a clear day you can get pictures of Cape Town and Table Mountain from the ferry that you can't get anywhere else!

Disappointed with Guides & History. For 300 ZAR/person I was pretty disappointed with the quality of the guides and history on this tour. It really didn't get into the magnitude of the history of the island offering small tidbits here and there. While I thought it was really unique and interesting to have an ex-political prisoner giving the tour of the actual prison, I found him exceptionally hard to understand (maybe 35 percent). Seems sad to say you could miss (since it is such a historical spot), but I don't know that I could recommend.

Cancelled all tours due bad weather. We were in Cape town in August.....winter. So we're expecting mixed weather, but we didn't realise Robben Island was weather dependant. We had booked to go thursday, but when we got there all trips were cancelled that day, we immediately rebooked for the Saturday, but again all trips that day cancelled. We left Sunday. Real shame we didn't get to go, and I just wish we'd known it was weather dependant as we might have planned our week differently.

Great to see and very educational. If you have time in Cape Town - definitely get over to see Robben Island - you get to hear about the islands history and of course about Mandela and the other prisoners time whilst they were there. We also got to see some seals and penguins whilst on the island

An experience you should experience!. This place was easy to get to, the tour was really insightful and did not use it as a place to force political views on the visitors. The views were great but also humbling. So much history and emotion to be experienced.

Historical lessons. Even though it might not have luxurious boats, nor much option on food, or whatever... this is a great opportunity to get to know some of the most important aspects of recent history of south Africa. Once a prison for political prisoners, this is now an important museum to help everyone learn from their past.The tour, at one point guided by one of the political prisoners, is interesting as it could be. Everyone who comes to South Africa should take a tour there.

Robben Island. Emotional and poignant experience. Interesting that the guides are former political prisoners and hearing their stories really makes the experience real. Only downside is the 45 minute boat ride there and back and not very clear directions of what to do when you get off the boat. All the buses filled up and a bunch of us were left and had to wait a bit for an employee to tell us where to go.

Must do but could have been better. Of course, RI is a must do for when you are in Cape Town. However, i found the groups were way too big (about 30pax) and our second guide within the prison (although he is a former prisoner himself) didn't seem to be very motivated and also didn't want to tell us much about his personal experience (i understand that ex prisoners might be traumatised etc. but what's the point of being guided by a former prisoner then?) which I thought was a pity.
Humbling. Really impressed with the guides. They gave me a first hand history lesson. Sometimes struggled to understand because of accent but a real education.

ROBBEN ISLAND CRUISE AND TOUR. This was a fascinating insight into the recent history of South Africa and its political prisoners held on Robben Island. Saw Nelson Mandela's cell, and more importantly, our guide to the gaol was an ex political prison who was just 17 when incarcerated. He now lives on the island, and gives talks to visitors, telling of the hardships endured by prisoners, especially during the winter months. We were humbled by his lack of bitterness, and his desire for peace and improvements for his people in South Africa. An important lesson for anyone visiting South Africa, and I feel gave us a better understanding of what has been achieved so far.

Living history. This is a must do! Coming from Western Australia the parallels with Rottnest island are obvious: both "discovered" by the Dutch, both named after animals (penguin and quokka); both home to the brutal incarceration of Indigenous peoples. Robben island though has a much more significant impact on the history of its mainland. You get there by boat from the V&A waterfront. Finding the right dock is confusing as there is a Robben island museum and Nelson Mandela Gateway to Robben island. It's the latter dock near the clock tower centre where you embark (33°54'22.6"S 18°25'21.2"E). Buy your tickets online a few days before departure as the tours can get fully booked. The trip takes about 45 minutes with possible whale sightings along the way. On reaching the island you take a 45 min bus tour and 60 min guided tour of jail. Both have informative and passionate guides to take you through the history. Our jail guide spent 6 years incarcerated for so called terrorist activities. It would be good if the SA tourist authorities would allow some eco friendly accommodation on the island to allow for those interested to stay longer to investigate this living history.

A disappointment of note. I have been to Robben Island quite a few times in the past
The boat trip out was slow on the Jester. Never moved above a wallow.
The guides only spoke about the struggle and nothing about the rich history of the island itself.
The island structures and buildings are run down. Sad lack of maintenance.

Harrowing and important.. One of my top things to do on my trip in Cape Town was Robben Island. My mum was fascinated by President Mandela so I had grown up knowing he was important. When we arrived after getting the ferry I instantly felt uneasy. The place is grim. As we were shown around the max security by an ex prisoner I just got more uneasy. I cannot believe that this happened. I cannot believe people were treated like this. The things they tell you that went one and the things that you see there are just awful. It is so important that you go there to see it with your own eyes. People were taking selfies and it was inappropriate. Although it is now open as a message of freedom and forgiveness I just feel so embarrassed that us Whites treated the black community like that. It was an incredible experience and I don't want to go into too much detail as I want everyone to hear about it whilst they are there. The ferry is a forty minute journey and it's an enjoyable ride, we even saw a whale on the way. The have refreshments and toilets on board. There are toilets and a little cafe on the island and a little shop where you can buy books about the apartheid and the prisoners etc. make this number one on your Cape Town list.

Robben Ilsland visit.. We were fortunate on our trip to see whales on the return trip from the island. Whilst the history is humbling to say the least our guide's English was marginal and it was very difficult to understand all the explanations and history outlined. The visit however provides and amazing insite into the Mana of Mandella and his forgiveness of all who were involved in the various atrocities they all suffered.

A must. There is much more to this island than you think, there is a lot of history surrounding the island, this is a must when visiting cape town.Tours done by ex prisoners, helps to bring things to life.

History Before Your Eyes. To be on the island and in the facility where Nelson Mandela, Sibukwe, and other political prisons were held and treated in such a demeaning and inhumane manner is just moving.
Beautiful . This tour is really for anyone who wants to learn more about South African history. Really beautiful island with amazing views of Table Mountain:)

Informative, educational tour. Very informative tour but could be organised better. The bus system gets you around the island but all the majority of busses stopping at the same place is not a good idea. The Prison visit was quite an eyeopener

Essential to understanding South Africa's recent history. Friends and I visited Robben Island recently. We booked the boat trip ahead of time -- that's advised, because it was sold out by the time we arrived. A former prisoner welcomed us and took us on a walking tour of the prison that lasted nearly an hour. He showed us the room where he himself had been incarcerated and talked about the prisoners' daily routines, limited food rations, etc. Another guide took us around the island by bus before dropping us off at the pier for the ride back to Cape Town. South African politics have changed a lot since the days when Robben Island was used as a prison, and visiting here helped me understand the attitudes that prevailed in the not-so-distant past. It's an important part of South African history.

Fantastic. This is a don't miss outing. Our guide through Robben Island had spent 13 years as a prisoner. He provided an incredible historical perspective. The tour includes a bus trip around the island and a walking tour through one of the prison blocks. You see where Nelson Mandela stayed along with examples of the daily lives of the political prisoners. We were lucky to have good weather for the trip. The tours are frequently canceled due to weather. Get tickets in advance.

Sadly underachieving historic site. This is an important location with an valuable moral and emotional story to tell yet so little is communicated to the visitor - it feels like the tour and visit achieves only a fraction of the story and history. If the operators visited Alcatraz in the United States they might get some ideas on how to engage and inform visitors in an interactive exciting way.
Dream come true. Historical place which I wanted to see from my childhood. I have studied in books about the robben island. but never thought that I will see it on live.

Mandela's prison. Awesome. Must visit. Take a boat from the waterfront. 20 minutes. Bus tour of the island and guided by an ex political prisoner. Mandelas cell and exercise area plus the lime quarry.

An Is. A comprehensive historical narrative is given by guides who were incarcerated on the Island. A great Visio -audio presentation assists visitors understand a poignant part of South Africa 's sociopolitical history

Remembrance of Things Past. Visiting Robben Island was the first attraction of a nearly two-week visit to four African countries. The former prison reminded me of a visit to Auschwitz, but only more uplifting. Our guide, a former political prisoner, showed us the dormitory, courtyard where Mandela and other prisoners once trod. Another guide showed the quarry where they once worked. Mandela's cell was especially inspirational.
Must visit attraction. As per the title. A must visit especially for the history side of things if you are interested. Not that many good photo opportunities before the ride back arrives.

Sad, but awesome. It's sad, because most people just mock about not showing any interest until we get to Mandela's cell where they can take a photo to post on Facebook. It's an EXTREMELY rich please, with tour guides that know the history inside out (literally, some of them were ex-prisoners) and that can give you a incredible insight into the history of the country.

Robben Island: The Price of Political Activism in South Africa. One must experience a trip to Robben Island, South Africa where Nelson Mandela and others paid the price for their political activism. Our knowledgeable and well-spoken guide Glen, was a prisoner at the same time as Mandela and shared moving and, at times. humorous tales of their experiences at the prison. Highlights included seeing Mandela's prison cell and here he hid the manuscript of his book, Long Walk to Freedom..

Impressive but limited. The boat trip to the island was great. We also loved the bus ride and the bus guide was very knowledgeable. Too bad we did not stop in all the places we were supposed to go (Alpha One for example). The guide for the walk through the prison was an ex-prisoner and we found that this had a real impact; it made everything so much more real.The only reason we did not give 5 stars was that the whole experience was so limited. We did not get the opportunity to stroll around the island, we could not move away from the bus even at the stops, and we had to rush back to make it to our ferry in time. We would have loved to spend a lot more time on the island.

African history to remember and never forget. The trip to Robben Island is something I always will remember. Its dark history and cruelty must never be forgotten. To honor and respect the men who was being kept there will always be in my heart.

Great Tour....must do when in Cape Town. We had a great day on Robben Island, the island itself is beautiful and largely untouched in recent years. Unfortunately you only get a bus ride around the island so cannot get out and venture. You the. Get dropped of at the max security prison where an ex inmate will give you a tour. This was very interesting and really enjoyed by ourselves.If you have plenty of time in Capetown it's a must do, if you have limited time it's maybe something that you could sacrifice.

Not spectacular, but nice. Our tour guide at the prison was great. He was a former political prisoner and we even visited the cell he was housed in. The main highlight was seeing Mandela’s cell. Of course, it was like most of the others. Our guide had some interesting stories about other cell mates and his personal experiences, but the tour was not as moving as I had hoped. Maybe it was hard to relate to, as I am not a native South African. I would consider doing something else if back in the area. However, I’m glad we did it. While researching things to do in Cape Town, we thought Robben Island was a “must-do.” After leaving, it was not one of our most memorable activities. You may want to reconsider.

The Most Interesting Experience in the hiistory of Mankind. Luckily we booked in Advance as there were so many tourists booked as well.WE boarded a lovely boat and met so many friendly people as well.Once we got there we received such a warm welcome.Our tour guides were fantastic.They showed us every nook and cranny and gave us a detailed explanation of everything.From prison cells to sad stories,the fight for freedom.The trials and tribulations and the end result where everyone made peace and became friends.A trip to Robben Island is not to be missed!

Important Place. If you visit Capetown, you have to go to Robben Island. Book the tickets in advance! On peak times, the number of boats is higher than scheduled. We could enter our boat much earlier. The visit of the prison was impressive and the view back to Capetown is very nice.

Robben Island Cape Town. Well worth a half day trip by boat. We had no expectations at all. The tour was very good, given by one of the local guides. The things he pointed out we would have never known had we not gone. Conditions were very bad as expected. Mandela survived the ordeal and is to be praised. We have a new respect for him as a man.

History and much more. High expectations of this most ominous prison, so much history, so much pain, so many lives, so many human mistakes! The guides were excellent, clear precise, knowledgable, especial the ex-prisoners who showed the group efficiently around the prison and the bus guide around the island. Robben Island could offer much more, it has many stories, many life experiences that everyone wants to see and hear. The tour was very well organised, possibly too regimental giving little time to read, absorb, take in the gravity of the experience.

A shame. what a disgrace to the New South Africa. The staff are nonchalant as if they are doing you a huge favour. The guide was extremely negative and painted a very bleak picture of South Africa. I would give this trip a miss. A pity though because of its iconic position in the fight against apartheid

Thought provoking. This is an amazing tour and the experience and information our guide had to offer was beyond our knowledge and expectations. BUT there was a busload of us, the guide did his absolute best to talk to us and walk us through the site but it was like herding sheep. Sheep who were taking photos and although obliging were fascinated with the buildings and surroundings. The tours should be broken down to 10 people maximum and let the visitors be enthralled with what is on offer. The guides do an amazing job and we are very grateful for the experience. However as noted the experience would have been far better if it was not rushed and so many of us.

Well worth a half day. The whole Robben Island experience is a bit slow moving, and communication by the organizers is to flawless. (No one tells you before you depart the ferry that half of you will go first on a bus tour and half will go first on a walking tour; you learn this only after the buses leave you behind and you blindly follow others on the short walk to the prison). Nevertheless, I still found the visit worthwhile. I know a great deal about South African history, but I learned a great deal more from this visit. The guide through the prison is a former inmate. Though his voice was low and often monotone, his personal anecdotes added texture and richness to the experience. The guide for the bus tour was younger and more energetic. In short, Robben Island is a must-see for those--like me--who see Nelson Mandela as an extraordinary man, an international hero. Budget 3-4+ hours, including travel time because it is impossible to know just how long the tours (walking and on bus) will be, and you do not how quickly a ferry will depart once you have finished the tour.
Robben Island. Robben Island is a must visit place. Once a prison, now a historic museum. Nelson Mandela spent 18 years of his life in this place.

Very poignant! . We were lucky enough to get to visit Robben Island during our 3 day stay in Cape Town, the day before was canceled as was the day after. If you really really want to go hedge your bets and book for 2 days in advance as it is hard to buy tickets closer to the time. As previous reviews have stated there is a bus tour of the island before visiting the prison blocks. Our guide was very relaxed and you never felt hurried giving you time to reflect on what life was like for its inmates. The tour guide was very informative and the only reason that it didn't receive 5 stars is we'd have liked to have read the information boards at sites such as the quarry where you couldn't disembark so photo ops were limited. However, thoroughly worthwhile!

A must visit place. A good boat ride out to the Island. Bus tour (included in the price) of the island and of course seeing the prison. Good guide was a "guest", really interesting and somewhere where one can get an idea of the recent history of South Africa

Historical, Educational, and Emotional Tour. Robben Island was part of our full day tour. Our ferry on the way there was one of the original boats that took prisoners to the island so it was not set up for comfort. If you get sea sick, you should take medicine because the seas were rough. Once on the island, people are put into groups. We had a family of 13 so we had our own tour guide. All tour guides on the island are former prisoners there so it's very moving to hear first hand accounts of what they did that put them in prison (all political prisoners not criminals) and then what they experienced once they were there. Our guide said it was hard to be a tour guide at first, but now it's helping him be able to talk about it. The boat on the way back was a high speed catamaran which was much better than the boat on the way out. It appeared which boat you get just depends on the time of the tour and where you were in line.

A historical place, but a little disappointing. We had great expectations for our trip to Robben Islands. This is for certain a very important place in History. But perhaps it has become a bit too touristy? We were taken out in big groups on two boats. At arrival we were hurried and put in different groups. Some took a walk and the other took a bus ride. Later on we changed. Our guide in the prison area was a former inmate. He had of course a lot of knowledge and he was a good speaker - but we had big problems with understanding his English. When the guided tours ended we had to rush into the boats again. So we didn't have time to study all the posters and information which was exhibited.

Not given enough time to appreciate it. Second visit to Robben Island - first was back in 2001 and we wanted to repeat it with our kids as it was such a rich experience first time round.While still very interesting and informative it has changed for the worse. The island is still beautiful, the history still tragic and emotive the operation is now very much run as an exercise into getting as many people on and then off the island in the shortest time possible.I found staff on the boat trip efficient to the point of being rude and the passage through the detention blocks is very speedy, leaving the guide (a former inmate) little time to talk and take questions. There's little time to take in the information on boards throughout the quayside on the island before being herded onto a returning boat (you'll be packed on to the first one whether it is a slow boat or not). A real shame as it is an incredible place but the time for contemplation is in short supply.

An overrated attraction. My husband and I went there full of enthusiasm. What we found was very dissapointing, a very politicised place. For the price we paid, the island should have been in much better condition, it is in fact not well maintained at all. It was good however to experience the cell where Mandela spent his life, but that was about it. I will not go again, and not recommend others to go.

An amazing trip for an amazing story!. The long boat ride to and back from Robben Island (about 40 minutes) provides one with some time for personal reflection. I visited Mandela's prison with some anxiety and not knowing what to expect. However I returned convinced that it was a very good idea and I think that it is a must visit when visiting Cape Town. The extra bonus for our trip was that the guide we had was an ex prisoner with Mandela and that made the visit even more emotional and authentic. It open my mind to understand the legacy of apartheid and the greatness of Mandela's character.

A very authentic view from a former political prisoner. The crossings were smooth and quick with lovely wildlife around us. The tour of the prison was very special with Derrick's account of the "system" being particularly moving. He showed no bitterness but instead demonstrated that reconciliation is a better approach as he works alongside former prison guards. It was very un-commercialised which gave it a stronger sense of where we were, in comparison with Alcatraz. The island tour was also well covered, even the use of old buses helped you get a better feel for the how people were treated.

Extremely moving. hard to explain the emotions involved as they range from anger towards the apartheid regime, to sympathy when you hear the stories of men who served on the island. The guides there were former prisoners and their resolve and strength to remain on the island and give visitors a genuine perspective is both highly honourable and humbling

A must do when visiting Cape Town. If you are in Cape Town for more than a day or two I would strongly suggest paying a visit to Robben Island, but you should budget most of the day to do this. My tour departed at 11:00 am and I did not return to port until close to 3:30 as they were in no real hurry to depart the island at the appointed 2:00 time. South African time is always on time.Go with an open mind, I have read some reviews of people who have not liked the visit but I think it is good to just take it as it comes. The visit was broken into two parts, first a bus tour of the island and various points. We could get out of the bus for some of it but not others. That part was not as good and I would have liked to be able to get out of the bus more at some of the points. The second half is the actual prison tour. Most or all of the time the tour is lead by former prisoners who actually live on the island to this day. I found it very informative on what life was like for prisoners during South Africa's Apartide past. They show you the cells, our guide talked about what life was like and they take you to the B Group area where Mandela was housed. You will see the courtyard where he spent time and get a chance to see his cell.The ride out takes 35-45 minutes by boat and it is open ocean so you will bounce some. If you get sea sick easily take some medication before going. Also they make a big deal about the boats departing on time, ours actually left 10 minutes early, so get there 30 minutes before you go. The return trip, they are not so worried about the boats leaving on a strict schedule so build in a buffer time on the back end.Wear comfortable shoes and once you get back walk around the V&A Waterfront. The island is exposed to the elements so pay attention to the weather before you go and bring something warm for the boat and island. Also book your ticket online, I only paid 300 Rand this way but had to pick my ticket up before boarding which took 15 minutes. Also pay close attention to the date on your ticket. I initially went a day early and on the right day for my ticket, there were other people who were there the wrong day. Also Americans so watch the date, especially if you are used to how Americans run the month first then the day.

Humbling visit. Well thought out place to visit with a boat ride to the island and then a tour round the prison led by an ex prisoner who gave a excellent tour around. Then you are taken onto a bus and another tour guide talks about the other things to see on the island. Thoroughly recommend a visit it highlight the long walk to freedom and the hopes for the future.

Robben Island on Mandela Day. Deemed a must-see sight in South Africa, I had fairly high expectations especially as my tour was booked for Mandela Day. The ferry trip was a rough 1hr 30mins (45 mins each way). I was fine for the first 15 mins but felt quite ill for the rest of the way. Therefore, I would suggest taking motion sickness medication if you suffer from this. On the plus side, the ferry ride is picturesque.Upon arrival to the island, we were ushered onto minibuses, where we were driven round the island. The tour guide was an ex-prisoner who was softly spoken and not entirely versed in English, so unfortunately, I did struggle to grasp the odd few sentences. The prison cells tour was also given by an ex-prisoner, it was informative but I felt that it lacked substance. We all know that Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for 18 of his 27 prison years on Robben Island, but I believe a bit of if recognition should be given to other key former prisoners such as;Autshumato - one of the first activists against colonialism Nceba Faku - former Metro Mayor of Port Elizabeth Jacob Zuma - current president of South Africa etc I wouldn't say the tour was a disappointment, but I believe the experience could have been better. Perhaps an auditorium with audio/visual narration as a part of the tour would be beneficial to visitors, smaller bookings at any one time and South African freedom singers at the dock to welcome visitors and set the tone.

Boat ride and tour. My friend and I had the opportunity to visit Robben Island as part of a tour to Capetown. The boat ride to the island and the tour was quite good. The prison facilities although no longer in use are very well maintained. The tour through the prison itself was very eye opening. The fact that the guide through the prison was actually a past detainee gave very good insight into what happened there. The only issue, was that his accent was very heavy so you had to pay very close attention to what he was explaining but all in all it was a good tour.

Very important to go, could be much better. Read Mandela's autobiography before you go, the physical sites will mean a lot. Otherwise, it's get on the ferry, get on a bus to tour around the island (no walking permitted), a short tour through Mandela's prison block, back on the ferry. No chance to really experience what 17 years of 8 hours in the quarry (among other things) might be like. The museum at the ferry launch site is quite good, however -- spend some time there. Absolutely go -- but the touring part is such a skeleton of what it could be. Spend a few moments by the concession stand to get a sense of the island's isolation and inescapability.

Great to visit on a clear day. It is worth booking a ferry in advance. There is an interesting informed tour by coach followed by a tour of the prison itself by an ex prisoner - there is more to Robben Island than the prison. However since one is expected to return by the ferry bringing the next group of passengers there is little or no time to browse and purchase in the excellent looking shop - I was disappointed with this and would have liked more time here.

Powerful. This is a must see for anyone interested in southern African history and Nelson Mandela and the others who lived their lives in pursuit of racial equality (still a project in process) there. The guides are ex-political prisoners, and ours was superb. We knew about Mandela, as most people do, but there were many others whose stories are also powerful, all of whose lives intersected at that place. Not a "normal" prison in that regular but a training ground (they called it the university) for black anti-apartheid activists. Not to be missed! Between the boat rides there and back and the tour on the island, it takes about half a day - wish it could have been longer.

Robbins Island, Cape Town. Robbins Island is an amazing place in contemporary world history. I would not go to Cape Town without taking the boat to the island. When you see Mandela's tiny cell, South African/Apartheid history becomes very real. This is a must see if you visit Cape Town.
