Visit as part of South Africa tour. We visited Robben Island and had a very informative morning. Our tour guide was an ex-prisoner. Well worth the visit to see where political prisoners were kept and the conditions in which they had to endure.
Excellent Tour!. Excellent tour, worth a visit.The ferry ride of 30 minutes to and from the Robben Island is also a good experience.

Rushed Tour. I'm sad not to give this place 5 stars. I am torn between 3 and 4 starts. It is such an amazing place with so much cultural relevance. I loved that a former prisoner was our tour guide. However, we went on the last ferry over. The whole tour felt rusehd. We were literally given "2 mintues" to look through the cells and see where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned. At exactly 2 mintues, it was time to move on. I personally feel that to truly apprecaite what occured at Robben Island, the tour needs to take a step back and people need time to reflect on their own.

Great experience. I enjoyed the trip in the boat even it was really cold. The tour on the island was very detailed .. The tour guides gave a lot of unnecessary details. But they were funny . As visiting any attraction you have to collide with irritating tourists that have no sense of giving you a decent space

Great experience but delivery not great. Overall the experience of visiting the island was fantastic. The boat trip out was great. However when we landed on the island it was a bit shambolic getting on the buses and we were crammed on the bus like sardines and useless for seeing anything or taking pictures. The tour round the prison was superb and led by an ex political prisoner which made it so informative and so emotional and insightful. With a little more thought and planning this would be a truly excellent experience.

Powerful Visit. Our guide was a former prisoner. What a powerful experience. We learned so much while touring Robben Island. One main takeaway was forgiveness. We saw Nelson Mandela's cell. We learned first hand from our guide what it feels like to be imprisoned. A must see while in the CapeTown area.

Relive the history of Robben Island with former political prisoners.. A 15 minute boat ride led us to Robben Island for a life changing experience. All of the guides our former political prisoners. Ours told an in-depth story about his time at Robin Island and the events leading up to Nelson Mandela's imprisonment and then the eventual closing of the prison and all political prisoners being released. View the cell where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned. A very emotional experience.

Thought provoking day. This was my second visit to the Island and I again found it quite a moving experience, appreciating what Nelson Mandela and his colleagues endured for so many years. Our tour guide was a former political prisoner - a man who was jailed at age 19 for seven years for organising a boycott of his school.

Reliving History & Hearing Firsthand the Other Side of the Story. Wow what a powerful tour this was. You need to come here with an open mind. We walked five minutes from our V & A waterfront hotel to the Robben Island ferry building. We lined up about half an hour before our boarding time. I recommend you purchase your tickets online ahead of time and secure yourself a spot and the time you prefer. Once we boarded the ferry be sure to go to the upper deck and sit in the back row so that you can take some great photos of the waterfront, Table Mountain, Lion's Head, Signal Hill and the soccer stadium. The fellow on the ferry monitoring the top deck was a character with an good sense of humour. The 20 or so minute ferry ride was comfortable and was great for checking out the surrounding area. Once we arrived at Robben Island we boarded a bus and went on a tour of the island. The young fellow who led our bus tour had a dry sense of humour, was passionate about the info on the tour and encouraged questions and was overall fantastic. On the tour you do stop at a building with restrooms, food and refreshment snacks and it is a place to take photos of the mainland. The tour was informative and the perfect length of time. We then visited the prison that Mandela stayed in and that portion of the tour was led by a fellow prisoner of Mandela's. He too was amazing and shared his story. Even though there were a few tour members who were a little disrespectful he took charge and led the tour as a leader should (in stride). This tour ranks with some of the best I have been on in my world travels. After visiting the Apartheid Museum and Soweto in Johannesburg this completed the picture for me and gave me a better understanding about why Nelson Mandela has the respect that he has from South Africans and the world. South Africa well done on sharing Robben Island with us!

Robben Island. The ferry ride from the V&A Waterfront to Robben Island is quick and picturesque. Robben Island has played a significant role in the new South Africa. The tour is very well structured. Once inside the prison, your tour guide is a former political prisoner. The former prisoners are passionate about the role they have played in helping to bring an end to Apartheid, as well they should be. Their experiences on this island bring to life the struggles that is helping to from a new South African way of life for many. This tour has political undertones, but it is one of pride and courage that helped formed the men and women who have fought so hard for freedom. Very insightful. Well worth the trip.

A "must see". Robben Island is a MUST SEE if you have a day or more in Cape Town. Receiving a tour of this infamous prison by a former political prisoner is an extraordinary opportunity to receive insight into one of the darkest periods in South Africa, if not the whole African continent. I've done this tour three times now--doesn't get old. And, each time we've seen interesting wild-life: penguins, sea turtles, and whales.

Overall good but could be so much more. Be sure the people at he ticket counter print off he right tickets. The person we purchased tickets from did not print off our tickets correctly so we were stuck. Then when we tried the change manager was so pathetic she refused to even face us. When we arrived on the island we were not directed where to go or what to do. The overall tour could be so much better and so much more information rich. It's lacking a lot of the important history that was made there. I was glad to have learned what I did but feel I could have learned so much more.

Intresting historical frome not that long ago. This place was very nice and interesting. Sometimes it is difficult to realize what has append not that long ago. The explanations on the tour are good. The only thing is that I would have liked some time top walk around on my own. except fore that it was a god day.

Our tour was given by a former political prisoner who was there with Mandela. A shor ferry ride but a bit rough takes you to the barren Robben Island. A short bus ride around the Island begins the day. It is a guided trip and gives some political and physical history of the Island. You are dropped off by the barracks where the prisoners were housed. We were met be the guide who shared thee barracks with Mandela as he was also a political prisoner. He shared his personal experience and showed us Mandel'a small austere cell where he spent so many years. You need to see it to believe it. It was a highlight of our trip to South Africa.

Pleasant yet Sad. It is a good reminder of the horrors of apartheid and what the black South Africans went through to gain recognition as equal citizens. It is well preserved and it was a both exciting and and to see where Nelson Mandela used to sleep. The boat ride to Robben Island is very bumpy. Good memorabilia available

Historic visit. The tour to robben island included a nice ferry ride, narrated bus tour and walk of the prison area. Our guide was very informative. The view of table mountain was beautiful. A must do in Cape Town.

Nelson Mandela's Prison. Robben Island is a must see.It is extremely humbling and sad to see the condition in which Mandela and all the other political prisoners were imprisoned for all those years and to hear their story and to go back in time.If you are not interested in history,politics and humanity,then the ferry ride to the island,the bus tour,and the cafe etc can keep you entertained.A definite must see.I have done this trip more than once.

A truly emotional experience. Such an emotional roller coaster of an experience. It never ceases to amaze me that the tour guides are all previous inmates. Each time we have been it still has the same sobering effect

Robben Island. I was really looking forward to my visit to Robben Island to learn more about what happened to the political prisoners there. However I was extremely disappointed with my experience, especially since the ticket cost R300. There were around 40 people or more to one tour guide and if you were at the back you couldn't hear what he was saying. The tour was extremely rushed and I didn't actually get a chance to read any of the exhibitions that were there (I don't know why they are there if you aren't given a chance to actually look at them). I felt like we were rushed from place to place with very little information given due to the time pressure. It was wonderful idea to have ex prisoners as tour guides but he only had 5 minutes at the end to quickly tell his story. I felt I did not learn anything from my trip and most of the time was spent on the boat. Far too rushed. You should be allowed to walk around at your own pace and chose which time of boat you would like to take back. Very disappointed with this, especially for the price.

I was expecting a bit more. Robben island is definitely something everyone will visit when going to Cape Town. For historical reason is very good to visit it! However, make sure you book your tickets months before you go and be prepared to wait n long queues. The tour of the island was not anything special! I found very interesting the tour of the prison and the condition people had to live in. Probably the fact that an ex-convict (the was sentenced to Robben island) was the thing that made the most difference!
Nightmare!!!!. Making a booking over the phone is such a hassle.im 45min on the line being transfered back and forth!!!!!!

Historical site, not to be missed. Nelson Mandela was incarcerated on Robben Island for nineteen years during the Apartheid regime in SA; though it’s not a pretty venue the historical connection to one of the worlds great men makes a visit a must. The ferry trip from Cape Town Harbour also adds to significance of a visit as it provides stunning views of Cape Town, Table Mountain and the Cape of Good Hope as well. Visitors are escorted on a conducted tour by ex-prisoners, men who were deemed terrorists at that time. Our guide Mr Thulani Mbazo was exceptional, telling us about his own experiences, being a freedom fighter, the reason for his imprisonment and much else about the “Madiba” in a non-judgemental and modest manner. We also saw the cell that Mr Mandela occupied for years. Robben Island is living history and should be on your to do in Cape Town list.

Weather permitting - worth the boat trip. We had originally booked in advance, but on the morning we had scheduled the trip it was cancelled due to bad weather. We were offered a refund or a booking for another day. Luckily we opted for another day when we returned to Cape Town. It was a fine sunny afternoon and we boarded the boat for the 30 minute boat ride for the island. While waiting to board, there is an inspirational museum of sorts which gives a good outline of Mandela's life set amongst the struggles that led to the overthrow of apartheid. Arriving at the island, we were given a 45 minute bus trip around the island with a commentary describing the various buildings and the history of this island. Then a former inmate of the notorious prison gave a walking tour of the prison describing the conditions, providing anecdotes and also describing Mandela's life in the prison - his book written while in prison - and his cell. A moving experience. It was then a 30 minute boat ride back to Cape Town.

A humbling experience and an important reminder. . I spent a remarkably interesting couple of hours on Robben Island. There day consisted of two tours: a bus yournof the island and then a tour of the maximum security unit. The bus tour was very informative, and taught me a lot that I didn't know about the island, including its earlier lives as a refreshment station and a leper colony. I was very interested to see the lime quarry in wchich Mandela worked, the "University of Life" cave and the famous stone pile. I was equally interested to see the village and learn that the current staff (former prisoners and guards) still live there, side by side. The scenery of the island is stunning, and the view across the ocean back to the main land is beyond description. The tour of the maximum security unit is particularly poignant, and was conducted by a for.er prisoner who spoke with passion and conviction about his time as an inmate. The stark reality of the overcrowded group cells and the miniscule individual cells (including Mandela's cell) is particularly harrowing. This is something everyone should do at least once.

a humbling experience. i know that robben island was a prison, but hadnt realised how much more there was to the place until we visited. we did a tour of the prison first, our guide being an ex political prisoner, he sawed us around the prison, telling us what happened where, and the which part of the prison he was housed in, and the conditions they endured. the tour inside the prison lasts a good hour. after that there is a bus tour of the island which was unexpected, lasting another hour. the guide here explains the history off the island, the wildlife that lives on the island and also the people that still live on the island which l wasnt expecting. the tour ends near the light house offering you supreme views of cape town . the only let down is that the little shop near the light house had ran out of sandwiches by the time our bus and another had arrived, so all that was available food wise was chocolate and crisps and pop. so would advise you to take your own food if you have an afternoon or lunchtime ferry crossing

Rich history with a former political prisoner. I took a guided tour to Robben Island and our tour guide through the prison area was a former political prisoner and acquaintance of Nelson Mandela. The island itself is filled with greenery, exotic animals, and gorgeous greenery. The tour staff was very friendly and knowledgable. I left the island with a deeper understanding of the apartheid era and was very moved by the whole experience.

Inspirational. From the moment you board the boat leaving behind an incredible view of Cape Town,you begin to feel Mandela's spirit.The boat is in fact the very one he was taken as a prisoner to Robbyn Is.Once there you take a tour by bus,first going to the prison itself.There a guide,who was once a political prosoner himself,gives you a tour.It is very inspirational and moving.You see Mandela's own cell,hear heroic stories and then see the yard and other cells.The tour of the rest of the island is good as well.Do not miss the opportunity to learn more about the man that could not be silenced and led South Africa out of apartheid.

An education of what not to do. The apartheid government that held Mandela and others for long jail terms is explained by a previous inmate. This makes the tour very personal. Well worth the trip. We took the boat over. Some saw whales.
an interesting history. It is a great experince to get the history of the island and the prison of Mandela. It is a bit crowdy so be sure to buy ticket in advance.

A must see!!!!!. I really enjoyed this trip. From leaving the harbour by boat, going across to Robben island. Taking the bus tour with a wonderful tour guide who couldn't be more helpful!It was a truly humbling experience, a definite must see!!!!!

Humbling. A must for a visit to Cape Town. Our guide was an ex prisoner who had his own fascinating story although he of course spoke mostly about Mandela. His stories about this giant of humanity only enhanced what we already knew of him - what an amazing man. My only suggestion would be that the guide could have had something to give/sell us about his own story which in itself was remarkable and whilst not something we will forget, would be nice to have with all the details in his own words to take away and re-read/share.

Disappointing Trip. We had high expectations - this is one of the must-see sights in South Africa, but what a disappointment. We could hardly understand our tour guide, though I understand that he was a prisoner there, he spoke so badly and so softly - it would have been great to have heard more of what he was saying.

Memorable Trip. Firstly the trip to Robben Island is amazing as you see the land drifting further and further away from you. Learning about the history of the Island and seeing Madiba's cell is a moment to treasure forever. Whats more amazing is the out tour guide was an ex-prisoner. Beautiful spots to take pictures especially of Table Mountain from the island so make sure you take a camera. Not much walking to do as your are taken around the island by bus. A once in a life time trip to the island is a must!!!!!!

Could have used a little more organization. There were moments that definitely could have used a little more organization - often it felt like entire busloads of people were trying to figure out where to go. It was a very interesting tour for the most part, though it did feel a little bit rushed, and I do wish we could have had more time to explore on our own and learn a little bit more about the island and prison. It was very interesting hearing from a former prisoner, though the one we had seemed to be preaching a little bit, and giving a somewhat non-biased opinion of the island and prison. Overall, though, it's a must-see while you're in Cape Town,and a good way to spend a could of hours learning about a piece of history.

Historically Significant. Robben Island is a historically significant place to visit because it is where Nelson Mandela was incarcerated for 18 years.We were able to book tickets for our group of 16, via our hotel's concierge, on the morning of the day that we went on the 1 pm tour. However we noted that the tour was sold out by the time that we got to the Waterfront, so it was just as well that we had gotten our concierge to book it online for us.When we arrived at Robben Island, it was initially unclear where we were supposed to go, particularly as we saw some groups getting onto buses while others walked towards the prison. After making enquiries, we were told that the first part of the tour consisted of a walk through the prison. It would be helpful if the people on the boat gave explicit instructions about the format of the tour (walk through prison then bus ride around the island) before disembarkation.Our guide, a former prisoner, was candid in his descriptions of prison life.Robben Island is well worth the visit.

Interesting from both an historical and scenic viewpoint. Historically interesting. Enjoyable boat trip. Very good guide avoiding overt political bias. Excellent views of Table Mountain and Cape Town from the boat.

Must see. Lovely ride getting to the island. So full of history and so humbling. taken around by a former inmate so that made it even more poignant. Mandela's cell is a must see.You do get a good feel of how prisoners were treated. Ride around the island was telling as you understand how prisoners spent their time and where they learnt how to read and write in secret. Found the souvenir shop a bit unsettling -commercialism after such an awe inspiring part of recent history.

Overcrowded tours and over rushed and uncomprehensible such a pity as could be great. We were looking forward to this tour so much, after watching the documentary and I even started reading the book before our vacation, we thought this was going to be such a great tour, we were so so dissapointed although the tour guides themselves have passion, the tour was ridicuously overcrowded and rushed1) we met at the designeted nelson mandela gates at the designated 12:30 time, there was over 4 boats and an estimated 500 people just for the 1 pm tour alone!!! each boat can hold 150 people and we saw 3 other boats leave before us, so we were thinking like wow this is gonna be a packed tour but hoped that they would subdevided us into groups when we got there alas not the case!!!2) our boat of 150 passengers arrived after an hour onto the island by which time both my partner and I were sea sick we thoght the ferry was 20 minutes not an hour and we should have taken our pills this was our fault, - we were ushered very quickly to board two busses, all 150 of us!!! on two busses, the other bus was not there so we waited for a good 15 minutes inside one bus while the other 70 or so people waited outside for their bus to arrive3) after everyone was on we had a supper supper 30 minute -40 rushed tour around the island, not a walkng tour, not a tour where you get to get off and get on, there were 2 stops we could get off one at the lime/cave place a total of 90 seconds!!!! so under a minute and a half was given to get off take 1 picture and run back to the bus that is it, and at the second stop which was last stop 10 minutes was given to go to bathroom and photograph water with view, the guide although enthouthiastic had no time to explain anything to us he just quickly pointed said ok this is a church, oh this was a school, i mean we were just astounded, i don't understand why they packed so many of us onto a bus and why it has to be so rushed, it was such an abysmal experience after such anticipation i felt like i was on train in china, we thought we were going to get on and off at serveral points during the tour, be able to take pictures alas we got but two pictures the whole 40 minute bus ride, the rest of the time the bus was moving and can;t take good pics through the windos of the glass, 4) we then arrived at the prison and we said ok finally we will get to walk around we got off and noticed the other 70 or so people on the other bus standing outside, we thought for sure there would be like two guides for both our groups but amazigly this was not the case!!! all about 150 of us were ushered into the tiny prison, by the time we reached one cell our guide had moved onto the next place inside the prison, so we missed almost every explanation ( only once did he wait for all the 150 people to be assembled) also while he was giving an explanation the tour from before us which was another 100 or so people was walking out so with them talking and their footsteps immposible to hear anything!!! 5) our guide although very enthouthiastic I could not understand anything when he was not facing us, this is not his fault ofcourse, but it was so frustrating to miss 75 percent of what he was saying, we were ushered into a room where the 40 prisoners slept, ( i will post pics of how crowded it was when we get back home you cans ee theres about 100 people sitting to my left in the picture) and another 50 on my right, the guide tried to walk around but because his accent was supper thick and there was so many people could not hear anything, when asked if he likes this job he said that this job is very depressing for him and he thought when he was released he would never have to come back here, so its hearbreaking to know he has to give tours there even though he really does not want tothen we were ushered back onto boat and another faster jetty ride back, what a horrific day for usI don't know what the tour company is thinking organizing tours so big 1 tour guide for 150 people or so is insane!!!! there should be a ratio of 1:20 maximum i think at the worst 1:40 not 1:150, they basically have 3 departure times and i am assuming its as crowded on other departures so 500 people visiting on each tour, i reccomend 1) making the tour longer, and allowing people to walk around the island and take pictures with a guide or on their own after the tour at least!!! how dissapointed it was to have only 2 pics after the whole tour of the island, and now overcrowding their ferries and bussed 2) have more guides or have option of audio guides,! it was so frustrating to come out of this tour not having learned anything because you could not hear the guide or could not understand him a lot of the time due to the chear number of group sizei have no idea if you can book a tour thats private or semi private where they don't pack people in so much, i would say do that otherwise give this attraction a miss,
Trip full of history. The trip was very enjoyable and I learnt a lot from the history of Robben Island. I like it a lot that ex prisoners take you through the prison.

A Must Whilst in Cape Town. The ferry ride and couple of hours on the island cost only £45 for us 4. The whole experience was excellent. Of particular interest was the prison facility tour by the ex inmate who was excellent and open to any searching question by those that were in his party. Brilliant.

Humbling and should be a "Must Visit" in Cape Town. Was this comfortable? No. Was this up there with Disneyworld, Florida as a sexy place to visit? No. Was this fun? No.Should it have been? No.Nelson Mandela spent 18 years of his life here as a victim of a morbid and racist regime, so let's not think that this should be anything other than thought-provoking and challenging.We had a superb guide on our bus. She brought the island to life and spoke movingly about the island and its (admittedly dilapidated) buildings. We met the driver's young grandson who came out to wave at his grandpas's bus (number 6!) as it passed by.We met one of the ex-political prisoners who showed us around the prison. Please forgive me - but I think his name was Zozo (sic). He showed us Mandela's cell; he showed us the dormitories and he showed us the toilets. He banged the doors and hit the metal warning bells. He brought it all to life.Comfortable? No. Inspiring? Yes.Five Stars? Without question.

Feels obligatory but not worth the time. We had four days in Cape Town and our only regret was wasting a good part a day going to and getting back from Robben Island. The boat was crowded, there were too many people on the required guided tour and most people had trouble understanding the English of the guide (and we are native English speakers!). If you are short on time, skip it. I know it feels like an obligatory pilgrimage when you are in Cape Town but RESIST.

Well Worth a Visit. A very insightful look into what life was like for the prisoners held on Robben Island. Booking tickets is mandatory as the ferry only has so much capacity. Once the ticket is booked, passengers are advised to arrive up to an hour before the departure time. I recommend you do get there early as our boat left forty minutes ahead of schedule! The disappointing part of this tour was that for much of the time spent on the island you are in a bus with a number of other visitors. It was difficult to hear exactly what the guide was saying at all times. Of course, for preservation and protection of the island, tourists can't be wandering around freely. However, it would have been a better experience if there were certain areas that could be roamed freely.When walking around the prison itself, the guide had been held captive himself so he gave an honest and heartfelt account of his time on the island.

Its ok (ish). Our ex president Nelson Mandela was incarcerated there so it holds a special place in my heart. I wish the island looked less tired and delapidated though, however, seeing the cell he stayed in for all those years is humbling. This is not my top attraction in CT, i did find it a bit disappointing

Informative but rushed. The entire visit was impeccably managed from beginning to end. Staff members all along the way ensured that every step happened on schedule and without delay. The guides were incredibly knowledgeable and were able to bring the space to life. I especially appreciated the fact that the guides showing groups around the facilities were actually once detainees there and that we were able to hear a bit of their personal story. I do wish, however, that I didn't feel as rushed when touring the different cell blocks. There is so much history inside each cell but we did not have nearly enough time to visit before being ushered (with much urgency) to the next stop on our tour.

Tourism. Went to Robben Island twice in June with different sets of friends. This is somewhere to go to really understand what South Africa is all about. The island itself is pretty ho-hum but to hear the stories and see the prison conditions in which people like Nelson Mandela were incarcerated for decades is worth the half day journey. Generally you get a bus tour of the island and then an ex-prisoner will show you the prison. They are fascinating and once. You start talking to them, you realize the miracle of South Africa and how it is trying to pull itself out of a cycle of revenge by truth, love and reconciliation.

Island where Nelson Mandala was imprisoned. A must see in South Africa. The prison where Nelson Mandala spent 20+ years for his fight against the apartheid. What a great man. You take a bus around the island and see where he spent all those years. Guide was mediocre but what a lesson in history. A very good gift shop where we saw the warden while Mandala was there. It made us all cry.

Humbling experience. The journey is on one of the original boats and so you are given a realistic experience from the outset. The guide on the bus taking us around the island, including to the quarries where the prisoners worked, was very informative. Once we entered the prison, our guide had been a political prisoner along with Mandela and so we had a first hand account of how harrowing it was. A challenging but essential trip. Book in advance.

Complete waste of time. Unfortunately, the incredible history and former residents of this fascinating prison island are not at all given the credit they deserve during this disorganised, slow and uninspiring tour. You are crammed onto a boat with hundreds of others, then squeezed around the prison in groups of 100+ with one guide. Our guide had an extremely unclear voice and I couldn't make out more than 20% of what he was saying. The bus tour was more interesting than the prison tour but rushed and hosted by an unenthusiastic guide. To improve this tour, I would suggest they look into doing something like Alcatraz in San Francisco whereby you are provided with an audio guide and you can walk yourself. I am a huge Mandela fan and I regret going to this tour, a waste of time. If it improves I would be more than interested to go again though.

Superb history lesson. What a privilege to visit such an iconic place and important part of our history. The guides were very good and their knowledge was impressive. Well worth a visit and hopefully the seas won't be too choppy on your way back.

Educational. Had a very nice day at Robben Island, after two failed attempts to go there due to bad weather. Saw whales, penguins and seals on the way over. Good your of the island and very interesting to meet a former prisoner, it's fantastic what they are doing to help other people understand the horrors of apartheid. The sea can be pretty rough so if you know you'll easily get seasick make sure you get something for it prior to departure.

Interesting for historical reasons and the stunning view of Table Mountain. The trip is very well organized. I feel they should have a video o some sort of information on the boat ride to the island, it is quite long and could be rather boring. So buy a book about the island and Mandela´s life and use that time to learn something. Once on the island you can get a good tour guide or a bad one on the bus tour, so good luck with that. And while walking the prison you´ll get to talk to a former prisoner, that for me was the most interesting part. You get to ask questions as long as you are respectful about people’s feelings.

Must do. To hear the views of a former inmate as he takes around the cells where so much history was made is unmissable. The rest of the tour is fairly standard but is worth it for that piece of history

Lengthy Tour. Plan for the tour to go long. It is an interesting tour led by a former political prisoner, but it goes long. The boat ride is about 45 min. and was on choppy water. Be prepared for sea sickness, if applicable. Otherwise, it is a moving tour to see how the political prisoners lived and how it impacted the future of South Africa.

What Island? Poor organization of tour.. The tour was quite fast, and the guides were terrible to understand. We were surprised of the severely unorganized routes of the island. I know that hundreds to thousands of people tour this place per day, but the boat ride to and from location were bland and boring. The Island was impressive, but encouraged disinterest due to the bus-system, pop-stops, and quick photos to be taken of Mandela's cage. Overall highly disappointing and not worth the time or money.

Guided by a former prisoner. I'm glad we went to Robben Island, but I probably wouldn't go again. My favorite part of the tour was when we were taken through the cells by a former prisoner. Hearing the first hand account of his resistance efforts and imprisonment left a large impression on my. The bus portion of the tour was ok, the guide was well informed and interesting, but I wish we'd been able to walk around the island more.The normal ferries were out of commission, so we had to take smaller, slower boats. I heard that this is not an uncommon experience, so you may not want to plan anything else for the day.

Fascinating and important. An important view of history and of the fighters determined to end racial injustice. Starting with a lovely boat ride to the island, the most significant part of the tour was that it was led by a former inmate of the prison. It brought the story of those who endured the treatment within the prison to life as well as their story of their fight against apartheid. One is able to see the small cell that was Nelson Mandela's home for 18 years. It is a must see if you are in Cape Town.

Be part of a legend!. I know that the old apartheid system was in full swing back in the day when Nelson Mandela was arrested for wanting to blow up people and all the rest of it; but there is no denying the sense of being a part of greatness when you go to Robben Island. To stand where Mandela stood, to see how he and others lived... the quarry, the rabbits - even the trip out to the island brings with it a solemn silence as the enormity of what people of colour had to endure under the apartheid regime.I have no words for the sadness and pensiveness that will strike you; nor anything to say about being lost in your own thoughts for days after the experience.Don't miss this!

This location deserves a better tour system. We bought tickets for the morning crossing. The trip to and from the island is about 40 minutes. The "Gateway to Robben Island" operates two boats. One is very old and guides claim it is the boat that was used to ferry many of the political prisoners to the island. The other boat is quite a bit newer and is designed for sightseeing. Which boat you end up on is a function of where you are in line. On the day we sailed, they loaded the older boat first. Even on a clear, sunny day, the wind is stiff and chilly, so dress warmly. Problems began when we arrived on the island. Theoretically, we should have boarded a bus, but all of the buses were full. So about 50 people were assigned to walk to the prison with the one remaining guide. The walk was pleasant, but it was impossible to hear his comments because of the size of the group. And the large number of people slowed the whole process considerably. Everyone wanted a photo of Mandela's cell, but the corridor was narrow and it took forever. So parts of the tour were rushed. Our guide was a former political prisoner. His narrative was full of anecdotes and detailed information. So it was frustrating to be unable to see or hear him for parts of the tour. Also, the nature of what took place on the island, the reason for the tour, deserves more reflection and contemplation than this tour structure provides. We noticed very small groups working with their own guides. If we were to go again, we would pay more to book a private tour.Having said all of that, I am very glad I visited, and I learned a great deal about the history of political oppression and the struggle against that oppression.

Waste of time.. Sadly, a site that could and should be a great experience was properly the worst time spend in a long time for me. First the Ferry did not run and no reason was given by a person who is obviously overworked and has adopted a terrible mood as standard. Eventually when we went the day after, we found the tourist guide also un professional.

A walk down recent history!. This place is a subtle reminder of how much pain we as humans can inflict on one another, how strong Mr. Mandela and his team mates are (and were) and most importantly, how FREEDOM is NOT always FREE.. it comes at a cost and should never be taken for granted!The tours start at the Nelson Mandela Gateway, which is close to Cape Town Downtown and from there it is a 1 hour boat ride to the Island. The tours are preferably done by political prisoners - as soon as u get off the boat, you are ushered into buses and then the buses take u to the different parts of the prison and around the island. Book your tours before hand as there are not too many tours happening through the day..

A very humbling experience and a 'must do'. Took the same boat out the prisoners used, a rickety old thing which was hugely enjoyable. Thought it would be like Alcatraz, and it wasn't. We didn't know what to expect, but found we were emotional almost from the start. Had only a high level understanding of apartheid and was shocked by what we learned. Almost hung my head in shame when I discovered the British started apartheid. An ex prisoner showed us around the cells Nelson Mandela and others were kept in. Mind blowing. Some lightness and humour brought to the visit by our South African tour guide - when he found out 2 of us were from Newcastle he said 'Bet you were relieved that The Magpies managed to stay up this season!' Took the speed boat back, another fab experience. An unforgettable day.

Something you have to do when you visit Cape town. Vividly brings to life the struggles during the apartheid era but in a way that avoids blame and maintains the dignity of all involved. The island tour also enabled us to see some of the wildlife that has made robbed island its home but the main event is the tour of the prison by an inmate. Be prepared for some very thick accents and if English is not your first language you may struggle with some of the guides but persevere- it is an uplifting experience.

A touching visit. I was doubtful about spending half day to the island. I Thought it was more liKe a museum. A former prisoner showed us building, Rooms and told us about his and Nelson Mandela story.Very touching. I left with heavy Heart and more awareness of apartheid time. Not for toddlers or young children.
Nelson Mandela. Nelson Mandela's prison cell. Good to see once, but not a tourist attraction as such. Just a sad reminder of human cruelty.

Well worth taking the time to visit.. If you visit Cape Town it would be remiss of you not to visit Robben Island. The trip out on the boat was cramped and crowded but I think this was because it was a beautiful calm day and everyone wanted to sit outside. However when you arrive on the island you soon come to realise that this place has history that you can see and experience. Having a past inmate take us around the jail was a moving experience. So many stories and even though it would have been a terrible experience the guide highlighted many of the good stories as well as the bad. To see it make you realise how bad the apartheid regime was in that era and I am this period of terrible history is behind them all. I am glad we were able to see the Robben Island. Take time to see it yourself.

Poignant and awe-inspiring. For history lovers and current affairs buffs, the island-museum is a must-go. Although the only way to visit Robben Island now is with a large scheduled group on ferry and bus, the sense of haste is more than compensated by the poignant and informative narration by the two guides: on the bus and at the prison cells - the second guide is an ex-political prisoner of apartheid.Do not forget to visit spend some time before or after the ferry ride at the boarding centre to look at the exhibits. There is also Jetty 1 - the original boarding point for visitors and prisoners heading for the island. Jetty 1 is a small white building separately located near Victoria Wharf Shopping Mall. Admission is free and you can see the waiting room and letters written by family members applying to visit the prisoners.Remember to book or buy your ferry tickets (which include the guided tour) in advance to get the slot you want. Be early - avoid delaying the ferry's departure or the entire group will be delayed and rushed. There are four tours per day.

Goree meets Alcatraz..... Robben Island its something unique to experience while you are in Cape Town. The fact that you can visit a place with such amount of history its a privilege, specially since most of the tour guides were prisoners of the place himself. After a short ferry ride, out of the shore of Cape Town, you will have the chance of experiencing the old prison where Mandela spent a big part of his life. The tour is not easy to book and you will need at least one day in advance through the web page (recommend it) to book it. Same day bookings are almost impossible to find since most of the places run out quite fast. The tickets costs around 300 ZAR (around 25 USD) and in my opinion they are worth it. As I mentioned before, for me, the trip was a mixture of Goree Island with Alcatraz, having the chance of seeing such an important place in terms of history of the human rights battle and equality. You will be reminded about slavery, unfairness and hate, but the main message I took from here was peace.

An extremely interesting and educating tour. Well worth doing!!!!. This was a tour we were really looking forward to and it did not disappoint! The ferry ride to the island was smooth, although I understand that it can be quite choppy. There is a wonderful view of cable mountain from the back of the ferry. We saw a whale on the return trip.We were guided to buses once we got off the ferry. We driven around the island and were accompanied by a guide.p (I can't remember his name, other then that it means Joy) His knowledge was excellent and he was extremely personable. I felt that I learnt more from him than I would have learnt from an audio tour. He fully explained the history of the island and its uses over the centuries. He explained the story of Robert Sobukwe, which was so interesting I bought a book about him from the store. The actual tour around the prison was carried out by a former prisoner and again he was informative. He provided insight that is exclusive to former prisoners. I found the tour to be an emotional and humbling experience. Highly recommended!

Emotional and moving. The boat trip out was amazing, beautiful weather, calm seas and the scenery looking back towards table Mountain and Cape Town. The island itself was very barren, the tour guides were informative and the fact that they were former prisoners there was an added bonus. But,to listen to the stories and the horror that was placed upon these people, the cell where Nelson Mandela slept made me feel very emotional, teary and touched and I could not wait to get off the island

Worthwhile Visit. So glad we went, Well organized. Boat left early. Beautiful day and views back to Cape Town. Informative bus tour guide before walk around prison with another guide. Good explanations given and shown of life on the island.. Can't understand some of the previous negative comments

Expected more for the actual history. Loved the fact 2 in-mates were our guides on the island BUT the actual location itself had nothing deeper than the building itself - thought it would have had a history section or video/photo footage so it would be more of an experience to remember. And there is NO water for sale at the 1 mini shop by the boat which I found very odd.....but lots of sodas..
The most amazing trip of my life!!!. The most moving experence in my life. Extremely emotional and yet a slice of history that people should never forget!

Robben island. All i can say goo see this place,you will definitely learn alot,i was very sceptical before i went,but I decided for it anyways,I returned with a whole new picture of robben island and nelson mandela!!! Lower your pride cut the crap just go,its worth it!

Robbed Island: A Devastating Slice of History. The voyage to Robben Island conjures up the sense of hopelessness that Nelson Mandela and countless others must have experienced. The island is largely devoid of any topographic features. It's prison blocks are featureless....just basic housing for the inmates. I believe it is a place that must be visited to help fully realize the history of South Africa's struggles.

Robben Island. A visit to Robben Island starts with a ferry ride when the water is calm enough. Once across you board a bus for a tour of the various buildings and the seal colony. A former inmate gives a first hand account of the conditions in the prison and the tour ends with a look into Nelson mandella`s cell all 4 x 6` of it.

Good to visit. You can visit this island, if you love history and want to know how SA got independence. Best leaders came from there. Its a town in itself with very small population. Please beware of snakes.

An island with great history and nature.. It was an insightful tour to a place which holds great historical significance to South Africa. The island itself was a haven for many creatures. As I was on the guided tour, I wish that we have more time to explore the island outside of the tour.

Excellent Tour. Robben island was great experience , My elder daughter was so engrossed in what the tour guide had to say and was mouth and eyed wide opened for most of the tour. A trip that parents should take their kids on. It was an eye opener. The speed boat ride to the island was sheer excitement for these teenagers. Thrilling to say the least.

Memorable experience. Firstly an amazing boat trip with the sea and sun on your face. Once on the island had a wonderful guide who stayed with us the whole time. It is not a place to eat, it is a small island. You just go there to see the Prison. It shows you what a plain island it is. Rather eat when you get back to V & A. Saw Mandela's jail which was a very moving and emotional experience. Will never forget it. 27yrs in that small space. Then another amazing boat trip back to the wonderful V & A waterfront.

Great Day. A great way to spend the day. The boat ride out to the island is relaxing and you have a chance to see lots of wild life. Once you get to the island you are greeted and shown the island. We got to see the prison cells and take lots of pictures. Definitely a must see in South Africa. Bring Sun Cream and a hat. ( The sun is unforgiving)

Disappointing anti climax. A recent visit to this well known prison of Nelson Mandela for 27 years has been nothing but disappointing. Of all the tourist destinations this has to feature as one of the top attractions visitors would want to see. Except, that the quality of service and tourist guides are at such a low, it's hard to imagine how this place will sustain itself over time. Starting with the boat to get there leaving an hour late, with no communication as to the reason why. Then inhabitants of the island, getting into the same boat as tourists as part of their normal daily ferry routine, and jumping on and off before visitors. We had to wait for them????. The guide had No interest in the main attraction of Nelson Mandela cell. He explained in detail all other prisoners history, but made noreference to the one cell all came for. He was also visibly irritated with all questions being posed at him. Finally, when we got to the cell, not a single name plate that reference this to who the most famous prisoner was. Wow.There are minimal facilities on the island for refreshments. Sorry but a huge disappointment

A really good visit.. I went to Robben Island soon after the tours started and was very disappointed by the tour guides who all seemed bitter and very arrogant. I went again with a visitor from America and was pleasantly surprised at the attitude of the guides now. The guide at the prison was a gentleman who was imprisoned on the island when he was 19. He was there for 7 years. He was an excellent guide who was quite funny and told us he, like the great Nelson Mandela, bore no ill feelings and had forgiven all the bad things that happened to him. The trip across the bay was about 40 minutes and was quite comfortable. You are able to order cold drinks or a beer etc on the way. On arrival at the island you are taken by bus around the island with commentary all the time.After that is the tour of the prison and, of course, where Mr Mandela spent all those years. I would recommend this tour, not only for visitors, but for South Africans as well.

Listen to the tour guides, their stories make it real.. When you've seen one prison, you have seen them all. What is significant for this particular attraction is the history behind it - the story behind the people who take you around the prison, talk about what happened to them when they were locked up at Robben Island, they turn a prison into history, living and real. Make sure you catch an early ferry as the winds in the afternoon tend to mean the journey back is like hanging out on a surfboard for 30 minutes.

A Historical Journey. Robben Island is a glimpse into history that is both informative and sobering. The guided tour we had was conducted by a former Robben Island prisoner. His intimate knowledge of the prison and how it functioned when opened offered an unparalleled perspective. The tour was factually based and well presented. The tour pace easily allowed time for questions. The boat ride over was about 40 minutes in length. The ride back was much quicker as a different boat was used. When we left for the island it was lightly raining and there were white caps on the ocean. We were pleased we decided to go. No one seemed to get sea-sick. When we arrived on the island the sun was out. On the way over, I would suggest sitting in the back of the boat but not along the sides. As the exhaust fumes are strong in this area. The book / memorabilia store offers a number of items that may be of interest. Make sure you leave enough time to spend at least 10 minutes at the dock store.

Moving. I'd expected more time to walk around but it didn't detract from an amazing and humbling and moving experience. The first half is by small bus with witty but informative commentary. The second half is on foot with a survivor of the prison who takes you into the grounds. Our survivor was fascinating and I could have listened to him and talked to him all day. My only minor complaint was being hurried past Mandela's cell and running out of time to spend longer before the boat back. Definitely worth a visit though. Take a hanky.
Mandela's cell. It was stunning to see the place where Nelson Mandela was held in prison for so many years simply because he thought that his people should have the right to vote.

Beautiful, sad but slightly over-simplified. The views are beautiful and the space itself is very moving. If you know about the history of South Africa, you really feel it here. Also tour guides are former prisoners, making this experience even more powerful. At the end, our guide in particular (although I believe most guides did this), basically summed up by saying things are great now in the "Rainbow Nation". This was a very inspiring message and one that shows the power of forgiveness, but I felt they missed an opportunity to talk about how the impact of apartheid still exist today and how the effects will be felt for a long time to come. Changing a law doesn't cure social inequalities and I felt that was a bit oversimplified.

Incredible. I visited Robben Island at the end of my six month stay in Cape Town. It was an amazing and moving experience to see where the apartheid political prisoners were held until not so long ago - I cannot even begin to imagine what it was like to be held there. My favorite part, by far, was the guided tour by a former prisoner. He provided us insight with what it was like to live his day-to-day life there, including showing us the small room and bathroom he shared with 40 other men. Such strength and forgiveness to be able to return to the prison and tell the story to visitors. This is a must-see if you are visiting Cape Town!

EMOTIONAL! A MUST DO IN CT.. A well organized tour starting with a brief history of the Apartheid Era in South Africa while waiting for the boat. Freezing cold boat transfer in June but it was well worth the freeze! On the island, the first part of the tour was by bus, the guide was an ex prisoner so a first hand account was given. People expecting 'gruesome' conditions to be visible will be disappointed. The cells are bare and 'nothing to write home about' but the commentary by the man who'd "been there. done that" was worth it all.....he spoke without the slightest trace of anger or hatred and just talked about what the place stood for. I walked away with 'a lump in my throat'....I think several others did too! This is a must-do when in CT.

Extremely important history - GO!. I highly recommend going to Robben Island - very important part of your South African experience. Make sure to pencil in some time as it takes a while to get to and from the Island. Schedule in advance as it sometimes fills up early. I Went there on an amazingly sunny day oin Oct´14 and it was such a moving, interesting and important experience. Would recommend it to anybody.

Inspiring, challenging, and a great experience. This was an important experience for our family to be a part of. It was one of those things that I think everyone visiting Cape Town should do to understand the reality of the lives of those who were imprisoned at Robben Island and to learn about how Mandela and others overcame that to come out changed on the other side. Definitely worth the time and cost.

A Cape Town Must. Visiting Robben Island is a must when visiting Cape Town. To learn from our mistakes is the only way we can move forward so sharing these with younger generations is key. Robben Island does a good job of these and employees former political prisoners to guide you through what life was like for them while there. Book well in advance as tickets sell out.For full review see here - http://www.thislifeintrips.com/visiting-robben-island-more-than-cape-towns-alcatraz/

Unbelievable experience to see the power of hate and the strength of forgiveness.. Visited with my family in January 2015. After a rocky charter ride (the normal large vessel was not operating at the time) to the island, we received a fabulous tour of the island by bus, followed by an actual tour of the prison facility by a former prisoner. My boys cried, I cried, my wife cried. The historical significance of Robben Island and its demonstration of the power of forgiveness in the face of extreme prejudice is a lesson we can all learn from. Don't miss it.

Historical and Emotional. Because I love and respect the memory of Nelson Mandela I felt I had to visit Robben Island while I had the chance. This was a day trip of just a few hours but enough to get a taste of what Mr. Mandela lived through for 18 of his 27 years' confinement. The guides were extremely well informed because they were previous inmates themselves. Wear comfortable shoes and bring your camera. You will have many photo ops. Walking in Mr. Mandela's footsteps was what I enjoyed the most; however, I did not enjoy the large crowds.

Very Moving. Beautiful Island with some great nature, but a dark history. It was interesting talking to former prisoners, and being driven around the Island. There's a lepers cemetery, a couple of churches, a school, and of course the cells that Political Prisoners were kept, including the great Nelson Mandela.

Totally Disappointed. I was so looking forward to seeing this attraction, and was so disappointed. We were lucky to get on the catamaran and not the old boat. It was a foggy day so there was no view of the island or coming back of CapeTown. When you get to the island you get loaded onto old buses that drive around the island with a tour guide who you could barely understand, to look at not much, then stopping at a concession stand , for ??, long line up and washrooms, and a few poster boards. Then loaded back on the same old bus to the prison, where we got out and joined our tour guide who was a former prisoner. He was passionate about love thy neigbour, I actually thought I was being lectured too. We did see Mandela's cell, the courtyard, and the gravel pit. There was no organization in the tour groups to go one way, so you were constantly waiting for the tour group behind or in front of you to pass. Such an important part of history and so much to tell, it was not done here. When the tour finished there was an announcement saying the boat was leaving in 5 minutes. Not sure if there was a gift store or not? Had to get to the boat. I was with 2 other people and they both felt them same as me, buy a book and skip the tour.

one of the main attractions in Cape Town. You should book it before you go.40 min to go by boat, and 40 to come back.First part of the visit is in a bus, having a tour around the island, to check out the main buildings and areas.Second part (the most interesting) is a visit of the secure area with a former prisonier.

Tour has gone downhill significantly. I visited Robben Island when it first opened back in the mid/late 90s. It was magical. Very professionally run and with tour guides brought the place to life. Sadly, this is not what I observed upon my return visit in June 2015. Instead of the beautiful Robben Island catamaran, we were shepherded onto a very old tugboat and were subjected to 45 minutes of smoke blowing into our faces. Perhaps the other boat was under renovation but there was no explanation. There was also no explanation at any point of what to expect from the tour (ie bus ride, prison tour, boat ride back) nor was there any information provided on apartheid generally. For someone that didnt have a good background on South African history, the tour would not have been in context. When we got to the island, there was little direction as some folks in plain clothes told us to get on some old buses. What you couldn't tell was that these plain clothes people were in fact Robben Island staff and also our tour guides (PS - note to Robben Island management - please give your staff a standardized outfit saying Robben Island so people know who is in charge and also to just increase general professionalism). We then proceeded to drive around an area where Robert Sibukwe was kept and also the wardens' living quarters. Practically nothing that the tour guide said was comprehensible. People were asking each other "Can you understand what she is saying?" The answer was "no" or "barely" for everyone. Aside from her not speaking clear English, she was lethargic and uninspiring. We then went to the prison where we were greeted by a cheerful and extremely loud former inmate. This part of the tour was definitely much better. At the end of the tour, luckily my wife and I saw that a smaller more nimble boat was leaving so we caught that one back (saved 15 minutes and no smoke!) but the people just behind us were stuck waiting probably another 30 minutes for the tugboat to arrive and take them back. What is so disappointing is that Robben Island is such an important landmark in the history of South Africa and for many visitors this is the one history-related tour they will get. The tour used to be fantastic and frankly wouldn't take much to fix because the island and history speak for themselves. My opinion is that if there are financial shortfalls, they could increase the cost of the tour (for foreigners) to bridge the gap since overall it's not all that expensive.All in all, you probably still want to do the tour just to see Robben Island, just don't have too high expectations until management can address the current shortcomings.

Surreal Experience. When I stepped off the boat onto Robben Island, I was instantly transported back to the time when Nelson Mandela was imprisoned there. It was a surreal experience and one I will never forget. Nelson Mandela was a brave and strong man.
Most unfriendly staff on planet earth . Arrived at the information kiosk. Was assisted by the most unfriendly person ever. Turned around and walked out. Thanks for nothing.

Piece of South African History. Visiting Robben Island is an incredible insight into South Africa history. You will get a first-hand look at the prison cells that housed political prisoners including Nelson Mandela and a tour lead by a former prisoner. To get to the island you have to take a ferry boat which takes about 1 hour. Depending on the season and weather (winter is worse) the water becomes so rough that boats often don't run past the morning. The ride can get quite rough, and though the boat is very safe, it is not for those who are easily sea sick or fearful of water travel. Once on the island, the tour is a combination of a bus ride and walking tour. For those interested in Apartheid history and the life of political prisoners, Robben Island is a must-see.

absolutely impressive. After waiting quite some time in a enormous group of people at the quay at the V&A Waterfront, you are taken by boat to Robben Island. From the boat you get a beautiful view of Table Mountain and Cape Town. Once on Robben Island, you board a bus and and are taken around the island. You get to see the quarry, the village and get the chance to get off the bus at a certain point which is an excellent picture spot. Careful, the tour is done only in English, by a real person, not a audio guide, so there is no chance to change languages.. The main thing is for sure the prison prescint, there the tour is led by a former inmate. You get shown around the differnt cell types, get a lot of information about daily life and the conditions the prisoners lived in. After seeing Nelson Mandela's cell and hearing about everything he went through for such a long time, it's unbelievable that he walked out of prison and was ready to reconcile...

Thought Inspiring. Don't miss this, I think at busy time bookings are needed.Just incredible from a History point of view to give and insight into how people suffered to get what so many of us take for granted.Brilliantly preserved and protrayed and made even more poignant by the eye witness account from the survivor.As a relief from the horror, the views back to Cape Town and Table Mountain are worth the trip as is the boatride itself and the viewings of the African Penguins.

In The Presence of History. It felt like we were living right in the middle of the events that took place in this very historic place. We had a fortune to get a tour guide who used to be jailed in this very prison. When we entered Nelson Mandela's jail cell I got goosebumps. a must visit when in South Africa.

Amazing history. Historically speaking it is great! But with a lot of potential to be even better! The tour is still very informative! But there are so many history that it's impossible to include everything in one tour. The boat tour is amazing specially during the sunset and the views of table mountain are the best!

Long walk to Freedom. If you have read the book Long Walk to Freedom by Nelson Mandela and you visit Robben Island, it feels as if you are walking with Nelson Mandela. This is a beautiful place. You imagine yourself back in those years when prisoners were banished to this island and it makes your hair stand up. This is an experience in a life time. It is a must when visiting Cape Town however during the peak season which is December you have to prebook on line. During off peak season you can just go and buy a ticket and take a life time trip. It is amazing and it is also very sad to think what prisoner had to endure as well as our great icon Madiba. Love this place.

So much potential...still a must see. One must visit Robben Island for its historical value, but they herd you in so fast and you see so little, it is hard to reflect and have an emotional experience. For instance, the boat ride to the island was a wasted 30 minutes. We should have had headsets explaining what it was like for prisoners who were on the historical boats. What were conditions like? Maybe audiotape those still living describing the feelings and surroundings. Reinact others so that 30 minutes was like a seminar to prepare you for getting on the island. They have so many markers around the island, but they put you in groups and shoot you through a 15 minutes or so walking tour so fast, you don't get to let anything sink in or don't have time to read any of the posters and markers. Then the bus tour is 40 minutes where they give some information, but not enough. If we were allowed to get off the bus and have an audio or guided tour where you get more depth, that would be better. If you are in a wheelchair, it is tough for a manual one because they have to lift you on and off the boat and a worker will push you around to keep up with the tours. There are appropriate toilets for those with disabilities. As the political prisoners age and pass away, the management will have to find a way to capture their voices and lessons andmake sure what they bring to the experience outlast them and their lives. After the bus tour, you barely have time to go in the toilet and gift shop before they are herding you back on the boat back to Cape Town. I am still glad I went. I just wish I got more out of the experience.

Enlightening and worthwhile. The tour is extremely worthwhile and informative. The guide on the bus was excellent and very engaging. A tour of the prison is given by an ex-prisoner. There was a lot of duplication on the information given on the tour and what the prison tour guide does at the end of the tour made me feel like a prisoner. Could be perform in a much less intimidating manner. That aside, I would recommend the tour. It would be an excellent opportunity for a bike tour option. Would have enjoyed a lot more if there was.

So Much Potential, Lacking Info. The tour fails to put in to context what life was like for prisoners. Your tour guide is a former political prisoner which is very cool but he fails to explain why he was there and what conditions were really like that made it so horrible. The tour fails to answer the following questions: Why were political prisoners held here? What were conditions like in Cape Town that made it worth risking imprisonment? They assume you know details about the history and therefore don't share it. The tour made one stop on the island where you can buy food and coffee and they were out of coffee - this was huge service and revenue driver miss for them! I would still recommend going on the tour; I just think it's a missed opportunity for South Africans to convey the importance of their history.

Historical and heartbreaking - a must see!. Just like Alcatraz, Robben Island is both ominously calling and lugubriously revealing. One is drawn to the sad and twisted history surrounding it while wanting to learn more about the human rights atrocities associated with it. There is so much social and historical significance of Robben Island to pass up. Every serious tourist should not just go and see but more importantly also learn what deeper message and lessons Robben Island can teach.All in all the tour guides are fluent and well read. They are a treasure of information and can recount poignant details with so much clarity one almost feels like an inmate. The museum administration has done well in the upkeep of Robben Island as well as maintaining the two other associated museums in the Waterfront.This is a history lesson one should not take for granted.

A good learning experience. We took the 9am ferry, and returned to the mainland just before 1pm. The ferry ride is a bit choppy, but just about 25 minutes. We had an excellent bus ride around the island - and learned a ton! One tip would be to sit on the RIGHT side of the bus - most sites we stopped at were on the right. Then a former prisoner took us around the prison. The group was a little to large for my liking, but it got the job done. Certainly worth your time.

Not as much information as I would have liked. The ferry ride out to the island was fun. On the island, there isn't too much to see and there is no information on what happened/when/how/etc. There are a couple guides that walk you through the prison, but they have their own agendas to get across. I would have liked to learn more about the prison and the prisoners.

Significant historical site, average tour. Robben Island is most famous for housing political prisoners during the apartheid era; including Nelson Mandela. It is a significant historical site in SA and interesting to see and learn about the conditions. Being such an important and popular site (heaps of tourists) I felt the tour could have been better. You spend most of your time on the ferry, followed by a bus drive with some commentary before doing a walk through the max security section. More time to look around with written info or videos would have been good. The boat ride was horrible. The whether is beyond the control of the operators but the ferry itself was old with limited good seating, and lots of diesel fumes. Many people feeling sea sick. Overall fairly expensive and takes up a pretty big chunk of the day. If prone to sea-sickness give it a miss.

A must see on a visit to Cape Town. Booked this trip online in advance before we arrived in Cape Town. Was really easy to do and really reasonably priced. We booked the morning tour so we arrived a little before our departure time for the boat. It was really busy and the boat left exactly on time so I would suggest to anybody to get there in plenty of time. Had a lovely boat ride over to the island which in itself was worth the money. When we arrived on the island we had to catch one of the buses waiting for us. Again I would suggest being quick as seats fill up fast and we ended up standing up on the tour. We were the only ones without a seat despite booking which was dissapointing but I think just a mistake on their part for which they apologized. The rest of the tour made up for this start to the day. It was really interesting driving round the island with the guide providing lots of infomation in a fun way. We stopped off a few times to take photos and ended up at the prison where we met with a former inmate of the prison. He was amazing and this truly was the best part of the tour. To hear first hand his experience was truly moving and is something neither me or my friend will ever forget. I would definitely recommend to anyone visiting Cape Town to do this tour as it only takes half a day but you get to see a part of South African history and hear first hand what went on. He even allowed us to ask him questions, some personal and made everybody feel so welcome. Definitely worth a visit, its excellent I just feel a little more organisation would be an improvement on what was the highlight of our trip. Having said that it did not take away from this fantastic experience you would get no where else in the world.

A little too much like tourists being processed.. Boat trip itself no problem whatsoever.When we arrived at the island there was a small café on the quayside, but, though a very warm day and we didn't have a drink with us, we couldn't stop or buy anything as buses were waiting to depart and you're not allowed to go alone without a guide. The bus trip was very frustrating as the view is naturally limited and stops very frequent and very short. In fact for the first part of the journey there isn't all that much to see which relates to Nelson Mandela. The bus then stops inland whilst people buy a drink, but as there are a few buses the queue is long and, once more, the time is too short....... long queues too for the toilets, but then on the way back to the bus, we came across another toilet hidden away with no-one in and no queue!The second part was much more interesting, seeing the quarry where the prisoners worked before visiting the prison proper on foot. This part of the visit was led by an ex-prisoner who was excellent at explaining life as an inmate. His powerful voice compelled attention to his harrowing story. Without doubt this was the highlight of the visit.Once more though, no time to muse alone on what life must have been like for them nor to wander around or read the large posters about life there, as there was only time to walk back to the dock for the boat, where once more the pressure was on, this time to board the boat back.This should be an occasion where one can reflect upon life in South Africa, both then and now, for the indigenous peoples, and the lives of the men who made those changes happen, but because of the sheer number of visitors and the consequent organisation, there is simply not the time, nor occasion, to fully appreciate the importance of what happened there and how it heralded the end of apartheid.But on the way back people on the boat were thrilled by the unexpected sight of a whale surfacing and quite blowing close to the boat!

Hey Mr Jaielr. As one of the most historic places of the new South Africa I enjoyed the tour of this place. The history on this island is out of this world. The main attraction obviously is the prison. It would be quiet nice also to just have a drive around the Island to see other parts of it. The ferry to the island is also an enjoyable ride with alot of scenic beauty for photos.

Disappointment at the cancellation of the trip, but informative displays. The choppy waves meant the trip was a cancelled at the last minute, which was a major disappointment for me as I was looking forward to seeing Robben Island more than anything else during my short time in Cape Town. However, I did enjoy the very informative display around the walls of the queuing area for the ferry, especially when I saw the poster for Mandela's Freedom at 70 birthday vigil outside of South Africa House, in London, which I took part in. I also enjoyed the museum upstairs in the same building with exhibits tracing the history of the island, with many artefacts from when it was used as a leper colony. Very moving. I managed to have my picture taken on a road overlooking the Cape Town coast, with Robben Island in the distance.

Disappointing. I went to Robben Island ready to be moved. I had previously toured places like Ellis Island in New York and Alcatraz in San Francisco, and I thought the experience would be similar: a self-guided audio tour that gave me plenty of time to learn and go through the emotions of apartheid at my own pace. Instead, they have this tour set up in groups led by ex-political prisoners. While that sounds amazing, it is in fact frustrating, because our guide's accent was so thickly Namibian that none of the U.S. or Canadian tourists (or even one native South African tourist) could understand what he was saying. I left knowing nothing, and had no time to even read the placards on the walls because I had to stay with him as the tour guide. I'm sure he has a great story to tell, as does Robben Island, but I did not learn it on this tour because the way the whole thing is set up just isn't conducive to learning. It's nearly a total language barrier for North American English-speakers.

LIFE ALTERING VISIT. I have never been to a place that has touched me like my visit to Robben Island. I was humbled by our guide who was an ex prisoner on the island and would suggest everyone who visits Cape Town must go to the island.

Moving and sombre experience. If you like history this is a must do. Bit chaotic in the organisation of trying to get everyone on board the ferry for the ride across to the island. The ex-inmates take you around the prison telling you all about it but I found them very difficult to understand which meant I did miss a lot. Others had trouble as well. I think smaller group numbers would also be better. All in all though I think people should go and see what it was like back then and hear their stories.
The tour guide are ex inmates.. Extremely moving tour and extremely humbling. Certainly worth a visit. Whilst not a joyous place to go to, it helps put life into perspective.

A must see to know the truth. It's a bumpy boat ride out to the island and there isn't a great deal to see. But once you see inside the cell that was home to Nelson Mandella for 19 long years, it put a lot of things into perspective. Well worth the visit

End Prejudice. Everyone should experience this. Prejudice would disappear if everyone could spend a day on this island. It is wonderful the guides are former prisoners - and they tell it like it was - no sugarcoating

Too Long Delays. On 2 May 2015 my wife and I purchased tickets for the 10:30 am boat trip to Robben Island, but the lady who scans the tickets only arrived at 11:00 am. Boarding could not commence immediately as the ferry "Dias" had been delayed due to refuelling.Although there was a ferry "Sea Princess" docked we had to still wait for the "Diaz"which only departed at 11:25 am. When we arrived at Robben island the other ferry "Sea Princess" was already docked and ofloading tourists that could not be accomodated on the Dias. It took the "Diaz" about an hour to reach Robben Island.When we reached Maximum security cell block B we had to wait approx 30 minutes for the tour guide. Due to all delays we arrived at V&A Waterfront aboard Sea Princess at almost 4 pm. At this point the last blue route tour bus departed and we could not be accomodated as this was this was the last day of our 2 day ticket. Please allow for delays without explaiation.

Nelson Mandela's prison. The hero of South Africa was kept prisoner in this small island just in front of Cape Town. The quality of the guides is perhaps not the best in the world, they don't look very interested, but the place is an incredible memorial to the sufference of a great man.

Important history, though experience a little underwhelming. Robben Island is an important piece within apartheid history making the preservation of the island vital, however the tour itself feels a little too formulaic as if they're passing the visitors through a queue. Having a past prisoner talk through some of their experiences in the jail is a nice touch, however the size of the groups make it somewhat impersonal.
