While visiting Robben Island feels somewhat mandatory to learn about apartheid, don't get your hopes up of having some kind of an enlightenment.

Inspiring. Didn't quite know what to expect from this trip albeit that Nelson Mandela spent time imprisoned here. The trip was exceptional with inspirational coverage of all that happened on this island. We got to meet and talk with one of the inmates who was imprisoned with Nelson Mandela who gave us a great insight into the conditions. Thoroughly recommend this trip.

Magnificent, history and emotion combined with a lesson to all. It starts with a great boat ride, a fantastic tour, and a strong view of life, history and commitment of a great man able to see and forgive beyond the immediate events, the island itself is cold and lonely and grey, a really tough place, but a totally wow visit

Great Experience. My boyfriend and I visited in June 2014 and found this trip to be very informative, interesting, a bit sad in some ways, but a beautiful experience. I got a bit sea sick from the boat ride towards the island but the rest of the trip trumped it all, the bus ride was educational and the island is a beautiful and almost deserted one. We felt great being able to stand inside Mandela's Cell and being part of his history. An ex-prisoner who was imprisoned with Mandela shared some history with us and it felt just amazing being able to hear first hand some of the harsh things that was experienced by them. We highly recommend this tour but be sure to make your booking months ahead if you can to confirm this once in a lifetime experience.

"Robbing" Island. Robben Island could be a good experience. It has wildlife, a historical significance and, if you get a fast boat, a nice cruise in the bay surrounding Cape Town. But wait, it is not a good experience. In fact, I felt "robbed" by going to Robben Island. I went for a total experience. Sure, the Historical significance is important but they advertised a chance to see the African Penguins and the option to take a walk instead of the bus tour. No, that did not happen. We were marshaled onto buses immediately. No choice!! Ok, I could get into that but the bus tour was a waste of time. We saw some run down buildings and then stopped at a gift shop for 20 minutes. We then saw a limestone quarry but we could go in because the officials were afraid we would steal some rocks. We had to view from a distance.Finally we reached the prison. I figured time was running out so I asked if I could take the Penguin walk as advertised. No.......was the answer. You have to be dismissed by the person giving you the tour of the prison. Ok....I could live with that since we told we would have an half hour left to either do the penguin walk or go to the main gift shop.Well the prison tour was brutal. Hordes of people clamoring to hear a well meaning but ineffective former prisoner talk about the jail. I couldn't figure out what he was saying. When we got to Mandela's cell [right at the very end of the tour], I saw nothing.......just tons of tourists snapping picture with their cell phones. I figured I would let the group I was in pass and then I could go back and see the cell. No such luck, another group of people descended like bees to honey [ the polite description] and that opportunity evaporated quicker than water in the desert!!But wait, that was the end and there still was 20 minutes left to see the Penguins!! NO...more talk in a big room. I understood nothing and I was not alone. Others in the group were clearly frustrated. Now all the time is gone........we are dismissed. But wait!!!! time has run out and some people are running to catch the good boat to go back.I asked tour how much time I had to do the walk. He said 5 minutes as the old broken down boat was returning and we had to be on that. I asked about taking the next boat. He said no as all the boats were full and if I stayed I would be left on the island.Cool......love that customer service. I felt like a prisoner the whole time. Maybe that was part of the experience. I had a great time in South Africa and Cape Town. I thoroughly loved the place but at Robben Island........I was "robbed'!!

Robben Island boat trip!. This is a "must see" experience whilst in Cape Town. I have lived here 28 years and this was my first trip. The boat ride was lovely as you get one of the best views of Table Mountain from the Table Bay Harbour. Very historic and realistic as the tour guide is always and ex-prisoner or guard. So much history of the Apartheid era and of Nelson Mandela's incarceration as well as other infamous political prisoners of the time.This is history that should never be repeated! Passengers are dropped at the prison harbour and then shuttled to a bus that transports you around the island to various sights. Upon returning to the dock you are given an opportunity to purchase items at the gift shop before the 1-hour return boat trip to the Nelson Mandela Gateway at the V&A Waterfront.Good value for money as well. Other things to remember: take a hat, sunscreen and a light jacket or track top. Weather in Cape Town is forever changing.

A Joyride to Historical monument. Robben Island is serious history. The superfast cruise trip from the V&A waterfront is adventurous and exciting. However the excitement in cruising is changed to some serious view of the island which demonstrates the struggle and life of Nelson Mandela and his fellow fighters during the apartheid regime. The trip within the island is done on a tour bus with a guide who nicely explains the geography of the island, The various work and stay places of the arrested fighters, Their struggles and strategy planning areas, along with the segregated prison cell types for various kinds of inmates. One ex-prisoner will also share his experience and knowledge of the prison which can sometimes get very serious for the visitors. Well the is real history and it is good to know what happened during that time. The thought of swimming from Robben Island to Cape town with Table Mountain as an inspiration is an eye opener and with freezing water temperatures, It is still hard to believe that such a thought existed among the fighters. This place sums up the struggles of Nelson Mandela and his fellow fighters. Must see.

It was okay. The boat was incredibly sloooooooow! It takes an hour on boat just to get there and it's not that far! The MC on our bus was very funny and made the bus part of the tour very enjoyable. The prison tour itself is a bit disappointing... Pretty much you walk though to the courtyard, have a peak in Mandela's little empty cell and walk out. It was still an enjoyable experience overall though.

Educational and Interesting. I'm glad to have had the opportunity to visit the site of incarceration for Nelson Mandela and other anti-apartheid figures. The tour itself is moving and educational. The boat ride from Cape Town to Robben Island is another thing! Beware if you get sea sick at all - this one will rock your world.

Interesting . I enjoyed the experience and was definitely interesting to learn the history and get a tour from a former inmate plus the bus tour was hosted by an informed and fun guide. My only complaint was in the logistics as I pre-booked tickets for 1pm ferry and got there at 12:45 as advised however we had to wait until around 1:45 to get on ferry and with only a brief time in Cape Town this was frustrating. The weather seemed fine and no explanation was given for delay.

Educational. A Great place to visit. 30 mins ferry crossing giving fantastic views of Cape Town and Table Mountain. The Island is a fascinating insight in to Apartheid and the struggle to bring about change. You have a trip around by bus taking you to all the historic sights including Nelson Mandela's cell. A good half day out.

One of the most moving and memorable experiences of my life. I travelled to South Africa with the Bar Association of DC in 2012 and the visit to Robben Island was something I will never forget. Our tour guide was a gentleman who had been imprisoned with Nelson Mandela. His description of the group of political prisoners and their preparations for governing the nation was absolutely riveting. I already admired Mandela but after seeing his cell and hearing about his temperament and fortitude, my gratitude for his contribution to mankind increased dramatically. When he died about a year later, I was glued to the television and watched the entire funeral. What an amazing man -- one of the giants of the 20th and 21st centuries.

A Must Visit Tour. This was my 2nd visit to Robben Island, an I enjoyed it as much as the first time. I learned more information because your guides are previous prisoners; so they are able to tell you general inform along with their personal stories. This is an emotional but great experience.

Museum store rips customers off. I recently visited the Robben Island Museum and purchased one t-shirt at the souvenir shop. I was charged more than triple the cost of the item and didn’t notice until I returned home. Two of my travel companions and another man purchasing at the same time were also overcharged which I wasn’t aware of until after I had boarded the ferry back to Cape Town. Be very weary of that store. Double check your purchases and receipts before you sign and try to get souvenirs from the mainland (where the same types of items are sold more cheaply) rather than the Robben Island Museum store as the likelihood of getting ripped off is high. The fact that several people had the same experience demonstrates that this is standard practice for the store.Good luck.

Critical insight into South African history. To appreciate the history of Apartheid in South Africa and to gain greater insight into the legend of Nelson Mandela, Robben Island is not to be missed. Our guide was a former prisoner, and to say we got a first hand perspective of life at the prison would be an understatement. The boat trip from Cape Town was interesting and easy. Key: Book in advance or you may be disappointed.

Amazing experience!. The minute you get your ticket, the ferry ride, the bus tour, the light walking, you know you are in for a emotional journey. Being a young person in this beautiful country, it was truly an experience to have visited the Island and get to see the calmness of the place where a lot of activities used to take place. The stories behind it all will leave you with teary eyes, no matter how tough you think you are. Just wish they could not focus on Mandela so much :)

Wonderful, educational experience. Wife and I left V&A Waterfront in a very run down boat called the Diaz. That however was the only negative aspect of the whole trip. Wendy, our guide on the bus was very informative. Our bus driver Hennie was also very friendly and patient. Our guide who took us through the prison was a former inmate. He had many interesting stories to tell. The highlight for me was a visit to the cell of the late great Nelson Mandela. Robben Island is definitely a must see not only for tourist but anyone who is interested in a part of our history

Mandella Expedition - Must see the place. It's worth visiting the Robben Island wherein Nelson Mandella was been prison for 18-27 yrs? Knowing what he went through and the rest of the prisoners. What's so interesting about the Robben Island at present is that few of the ex prisoners are amongst the Tour Guides and actually now live and have their family in that Island. One of the Tour Guide Prisoner said to us " he feels more safer living at the Robben Island than living at the city. If you ever visit Cape Town please do not leave this place without visiting Robben Island. Glad I did with my colleagues. Chaio!

EMOTIONAL. Many people still don't know exactly what happened in South Africa during apartheid and Robben Island offers an opportunity to experience what the prisoners experienced during this demonic era. You will have benefit of hearing about some of the horrific things Apartheid did to Black South Africans from former prisoners and get to visit the room where Nelson Mandela spent all those years in prison. The package offered depends on how much you pay and who your tour guide will be, make sure that your guide offers the opportunity to visit the Mandela Room because not all of them do.

From the depths to World Leader. Be prepared for a long boat ride by ferry. Be sure and check the weather because the waters can get choppy for those who get seasick ( ME!). The island is a former prison for political prisoners. It reminded me of Alcatraz in that you can still see Cape Town on the horizon when you arrive. Must have drove the prisoners madIts stark and desolate and the tour emphasizes the punishment the late Nelson Mandela endured for 27 years. It's definitely worth seeing

Made a huge impression . This is definetly something to do when you are in Cape town. Once you are there a guide will take you around the Island in a bus and make sure everybody are comfortable. After that you have a guider Tour in the prison by an ex prisoner which is amazing!! They are so kind and can tell you how it really was to live there from personal experience. And they dont mind at all telling you there story. Something you have to do

A must see. The boat ride is a little rough but Robben Island is a must see in order to understand South Africa.The prison, the cells, the depressing aspect to the entire incarceration makes you wonder how Mandela emerged from prison a healer and not man seeking revenge. Forget everything else, absorb the moment.
Great tour, but takes whole day. The experience can be a memorable one, but try to get the new fast ferry to the island. Phone ahead to find out which tour it is booked on and/or time it runs.

Informative tour. Well run tour by prior political prisoners of the prison where Nelson Mandela spent 27 years of his life. Beautiful views of Cape Town and Table Mountain. Escorted by a huge group of dolphins on the way out!!

Emotional Historical Tour. Although I know the story about Apartheid, what I have learnt has been from the news at the time so my husband and I decided to go on the Robben Island tour.Firstly we boarded the ferry for a fabulous 50 minute journey across Cape Town harbour. We were lucky enough to have excellent weather, superb vis and outside seating so there were photo opportunities galore. This really is THE way of seeing Cape Town at it's stunning best.Upon arrival at Robben Island, we boarded coaches and were given a tour showing us the school, church and camps from an informative and interesting guide who also managed to keep the gravity of the situation on the island during the time of emprisonment whilst not being intimidating about it.We were then taken to the prison cells where Mandela, Sobukwe and many others were kept. With something written on many walls of the cells and some personal artifacts, this is an emotional and heartwrenching tour. The guides are ex-prisoners - ours was excellent and told a humbling story about his 6 year incarceration. Whilst listening to his time, we were all seated on benches, beds and floors that held the prisoners in a huge cell.Upon exiting the prison, where you can feel the atrocities of such recent history, the brilliant sunshine seems almost incongruous. Whilst Robben Island without doubt harbours harrowing history, the story is one that all visitors to Cape Town should experience and when you exit the prison, you feel like you're walking the long road to freedom too.

MANDELA'S Place of incarceration deserves better respect.. Disinterested staff at ticket office did not improve on the island. Lots of litter, guide obviously bored and what could be a memorable and moving visit was an insult to the memory of Nelson Mandela and his imprisonment. It has everything a 'Need to see' iconic sight needs but the lack lustre attitude of the staff spoiled the visit. Insufficient restaurant and toilet facilities added to the lost opportunity of making this destination one to be treasured in the mind forever. Which is how it should have been.

Good but a little rushed tour. We enjoyed out trip to Robben Island but the tour felt a little rushed and we really didn't get much time to view and tour the prison where Mandela was held. This might be due to the ferry trip being lengthened to avoid the wake of some large ships passing in front of the boat or just that the bus tour ran to long. Guides were knowledgeable and passionate about the place and its long and dark history. But in the end it did feel like we were being rushed off the island to allow the other tours to come from the mainland.

Interesting visit. Have read some bad reviews of the Robben island trip on trip advisor so was dubious about going but am pleased we did. Although not much to look at (it was a prison so this is to be expected) the tour of the prison given by a previous inmate was extremely informative and definitely made the experience worthwhile. Make sure you take warm clothes as the boat crossing can be chilly!

Madiba is worth all the tears. Our X convict guide was Sipho Msomi. He was full of energy and very clean in terms of self presentation. He was very out spoken. Hearing how Madiba and Robert Sobuku struggled was so emotional.

Robbin Island. . Beware of ferry trip. Make sure it is clear, sunny day. 45 minute trip took us 2.5 hours due to poor skills of staff. Docent's accent was hard to understand. Place is definitely worthwhile, but read about it before you go.

Overrated waste of time that eats up entire day. I was excited about the prospect of visiting Robben Island. My originally scheduled tour was cancelled due to weather. The rescheduled boat ended up leaving 1hr late for reasons unknown to me. The boat used was awful!! Terribly old boat that was way too small with awful seating and gross exhaust fumes for the solid 1hour ride. Upon arriving to the Island we were whisked onto old run down busses with awful windows. No explanation of timing for next activity, or as to what time return boat would leave. Awful bus tour. Beyond pointless "rest stop" at a snack bar for the pure purpose of making more money off tourists buying overpriced snacks. Waste of time. Eventually made it to the prison tour which was conducted in way too big a group. Barely could hear/understand tour guide. Completely too rushed. No time to explore gift shop or native penguin colony on island. Return boat trip awful on same boat. Cold, slow, smelly, got seasick. Save your time and money and just read about the island instead. Not worth the 5.5 hours out of your day to visit (waiting in line, delays, plus boat rides and tour)

Disappointing. The whole thing was very disappointing. The boat to the island did not have seats for everyone and clearly carried way more than its capacity. Hopefully no accidents happen...  Arriving at the island we were picked up by a bus which took us in a totally dispensable tour we could easily do walking. Not to mention it was late but still made a stop for snacks what cut the prison trip short. We were told we would not have time to see it all or read all the signs and there was one guide for a very very large group. Packaged tour that does not deliver what the island's history deserves. I do not recommend it to anyone.

Saturday . The trip was nice and took up my whole saturday afternoon. So if your thinking of going to go quickly and come back within two hours you mistaken! The boat trip was fun, everyone just sat or stood where ever they got a spot, and the bus trip after was more peaceful where we got to listen to the story behind Robben Island.. At the prison theres someone to give u the story behind each cell and the prisoners who spent time there.

Goosebumps. It was humbling to see where Nelson Mandela lived imprisoned for decades, taking rocks and breaking them into smaller rocks. Thank goodness this site has been preserved. We must never forget the past that has forged humanity into what it is today. I was very impressed while on safari to find our tracker and game guide were born after apartheid and they expressed they couldn't imagine a time when things hadn't been the way they are now. One was descended from a local tribe and the other Caucasian of Dutch descent whose grandfather or great-grandfather led Hemmingway on safari back in the day.

Boat trip. We had heard some negative reviews about this trip and then heard from friends from Canada who recently completed it that it was so worth seeing. Our boat trips there and back were fantastic. We went there on the tug and managed to score by being on the faster smaller boat on return. The gentleman who was our bus guide was informative and so passionate constantly filling the morning with humor. The tour of the prison was lead by a former in mate. He was so incredible never embellishing his story and clearly loving his job. An unbiased, non political and excellent tour. We highly recommend this to visitors and locals alike. The views are incredible and we saw so many penguins swimming next to the boat as well as a whale.

Very disappointing. A visit to Robben Island was extremely disappointing. The boat's used are not very safe /very old and take a very long time to travel to the island. The island buildings are in disrepair and you wonder where all the money for the tickets is being spent. The guides are very bad and sound like they have learnt everything parrot fashion. A lot of incorrect information and extremely boring. Hardly any mentioned is made of Nelson Mandela and that is why most people visit. There is no time to visit the Penguin colony or even go to the gift shop. Definitely not a must see visit in Cape Town

An Afternoon on Robben Island. Robben Island is historically important to visit. Not only is it the prison where Nelson Mandela was held, but many other key players in the battle to end Apartheid. All tours are led by former Prisoners, which is very powerful - when they speak, you can really feel the passion of their experience.However, the ferry ride to the island is long and challenging. The boat has limited seating. In Fall & Winter, with the wind, it is very cold so you need to really bundle up. Also, on the island, things are a little chaotic. There is very little organization/coordination between the two activities (walking tour of the prison & bus tour of the island). Nevertheless, we are very glad we went!
Authentic and true. Boat ride to famous island followed by bus tour to get an overview of the island. Lastly meeting a real inmat and talking about life in prison is a must.

A Harrowing but Inspiring Afternoon. We took the ferry to Robben Island as part of a day on which we first visited the District Six Museum and the one of the Townships close to Cape Town.It is a harrowing experience seeing the prison and working areas and hearing about the hardships that were endured by Nelson Mandela and all the others involved in struggling against apartheid. But it's also inspirational that he could lead the nation in a spirit of equality and forgiveness after his release.The tour is led by ex prisoners who are able to throw a spotlight on the day to day workings of the prison and reflect on the strength and determination of the ANC leaders.

Very moving, great boat trip and views of Cape Town. When I came here I was offered the tour of the Cape Peninsula or this. In my opinion, you can't go to Cape Town and not see Robben Island. The history, horrible as it is, is wild to think it happened not that long ago. The guides are all former prisoners so see it while you can because they won't be around years from now which makes it very intimate. Very cool to see Mandela's cell, makes you honour and appreciate the man that much more. That aside, this is the best place to get great shots of Cape Town with Table Mountain in the background. Plus the boat ride out is very cool. It's an amazing day out, you get views, seals jumping by the boats, a very huge appreciation of one of the greatest Men in history (and all the other men who were there with him). If you want to view Cape Town's beauty and you appreciate South Africa's history - this is a must do. Just know, due to weather, only like 2 boats run a day, book it well in advance and for the 1st day you are in Cape Town. That way, if it is bad weather, hopefully you get priority the next day.

Ok, you have to go. I have mixed emotions. SA history is not my thing, and prisons tend to bore me. But they made it really interesting with a former political prisoner as a tour guide. And Robben Island is interesting apart from the prisons. Some downsides. They use a really old boat as a ferry that probably predates the prison - it has been breaking down. Nearly every seat is below (sea sick city). Get there really early to grab one of the seats above if you want one - topsides is either quite cold, or brutally hot in strong sun. On the good side, the boat trip is very pretty on a clear day and the boat is quite large and heavy with good stability. The tour has you very crowded into poor quality bus with dirty windows, and there is only one stop. So you don't see anything well except at the three locations - dock, end of the island and political prison. I am told there is a good gift shop, but they did not leave us time to go. At the docks we felt like they were recreating the prison years for us - could all of those young women running the place have been guards or prisoners? You have to go.

Over Rated. A very important place in South African history but sadly over rated and a tourist trap ! The Mandela name used and abused. Staff unfriendly and bored out of their wits. Pity staff not motivated.

Robben Island Tour accessibility. My name is Nick Westermeyer. I am a quadriplegic from a gymnastics injury sustained at Michigan State University in April 1991 who is interested in global travel and participating in activities not normally associated with disabled people. I’m currently on an adventure that will explore worldwide handicapped accessibility. Many people have travel blogs, but there are none that I know of that come from the vantage point of a wheelchair user going off the accessible path.The boat for Robben Island leaves from Mandela Gateway. There’s an elevator to the staging area and a ramp from the staging area to the dock that is too steep that I need help up. The boarding platform to the boat is about 6” high that the crew helps me up and carries me onto the boat.The 5 mile ferry ride on board the Dias to the island is about 1hr 10min. The Dias was used to transport staff and political prisoners between the mainland and Robben Island, including Nelson Mandela. The other ferry that is used, Sikhululekile, would only take about 20 minutes but is being serviced. With the bad weather coming in the seas are picking up. The ferry ride is rough and wet. We arrive at Murray’s Bay Harbour and disembarking is not very easy or safe. There’s a five step latter that 3 crew members carry me up in my chair. The width of the hand railings is barely wider than my chair. I can’t see many people in a wheelchair being able to get on or off this boat. From the photo on the website, the Sikhululekile ferry would be much easier to board and disembark. Robben Island was first used as a political prison in the mid 1600’s. This island was turned into leper colony in 1846. From 1961 to 1991, enemies of the apartheid were held in the maximum security prison. After arriving on the island, we board a large bus for a 40 minute tour of the island. The bus has a lift that’s not much wider or longer than my chair with no safety belt.The tour starts with a stop at the leper graveyard then Robert Sobukwe House. In 1960, Sobukwe was sentenced to three years in prison for leading a nationwide protest of the Pass Laws. He was kept in solitary confinement in his own living quarters and had no contact with any other prisoners. Our next stop is the Garrison Church, constructed in 1841.Next, we take break at the gift shop for a few photos. The gift shop is accessible with ramps. The next stop is the lighthouse commissioned in 1865. The tour continues to the limestone quarry where Mandela, with other prisoners, worked digging up rock for 13 years. Our last stop, before a visit to the maximum security prison is Moturu Kramat. A sacred site for Muslim pilgrimage, built in 1969 to commemorate Sayed Adurohman Moturu, the Prince of Madura.The ramp to the maximum security prison is accessible. Our guide is former prisoner, Zozo, who arrived on Robben Island as a political prisoner in 1977 before his release in 1982. We start at the entrance where the prisoners were processed upon arrival. Political prisoners were kept in the maximum security prison while murderers and rapists were kept in the minimum security prison. We made our way through the jail to the prison yard. The ramp down to the prison yard is too steep. Prisoners would work hammering stones in the prison yard.The ramp from the prison yard to cell block B is too steep that I need help up. Zozo pulls me aside for a spot in front of cell #5. Cell #5 is Nelson Mandela’s cell and has been left in the same condition since his release on Feb 11, 1990. The cell is 7 feet by 9 feet where Mandela spent 18 of his 27 years in prison on Robben Island. The lights in the maximum security prison were on 24 hours a day.Zozo next takes us to cell block F, one of the cell blocks he stayed in his time on Robben Island. I am able to make it down the ramp from cell block B to the prison yard but need help up the ramp to the jail. Zozo was also housed in cell block E and G. There is a step to cell block F that I need help up. Zozo talks of life in prison. During his time he went through beatings, hunger and solitary confinement. Some prisoners were only given hard padding to sleep on. Zozo closes the tour by saying: “Our leader, Nelson Mandela, taught us not to take revenge on our enemies and because of this today we are free, free, free.”On May 10, 1994 Nelson Mandela was inaugurated as the country’s first black president. In 1997 the prison was turned into the Robben Island Museum. I get helped down the ladder the same as before and to the interior of the boat. I meet Christo Brand, who was Nelson Mandel’s prison guard, on the ferry ride back. I have the privilege to get a photo with Mr. Brand when we return to the Mandela Gateway. He has a book that came out Nov. 18, 2014 on his years being Mandela’s prison guard, Mandela: My Prisoner, My Friend. The tour was great. Hearing from a former prisoner was exceptional. Zozo gave an amazing tour. The Dias ferry is not accessible. The bus has a lift but any wide or longer wheelchair will not fit. The ramps to the prison yard are too steep but with help they are manageable. The bus tour was about 40 minutes long. I could have spent 2-3 hours seeing more of the island. Check on which boat is being used. Check on the dimensions of your wheelchair to make sure it will fit on the lift. There is only one bus with a lift. The Robben Island tour is a must see if you visit Cape Town.Photos of the Robben Island Tour can be viewed at http://offtheaccessiblepath.smugmug.com/Africa/South-Africa/Robben-Island/Robben-Island/Accessibility wise this tour would receive a 2.5/5 rating.

Worth the trip. A very pleasant boat trip to the island. When we landed we were escorted to a bus, one of several, for the conducted island tour. Bus access was not easy for less mobile people. I had to help one lady up and down. Very interesting and informative. A good three hours overall.

Just to feel the place. Its is very hard to get information from itIf you look for and informative please, this is not it.Its very important to feel the place and understand the roughness of life there but as your guide is a former prisoner, its very hard to understand what they say because of the strong accent and the terrible acousticSave 4 hours (1 hour boat + 2 hours tour + 1 hours boat), so in order not to lose your day, try to get the 1st ones.And GO PREPARED, learn something about Apartheid and the country to be able to absorb as much as you can!

Unmissable but could be better. You can't not visit Robben Island given the history of the place. One of the legends of South Africa, Nelson Mandela, having been incarcerated there. But, I felt that the trip was getting a bit stale and they knew visitors would come, whatever.The boat trip over provides a nice view back to Cape Town. On arrival, it's a ramshackle old bus that takes you round the island and things are pointed out at random with little chance to take photographs.The high points are- meeting an ex prisoner from the island and hearing his first hand account of being there (and everyone wants to know - why were you jailed?) and- seeing Mandela's cell and pondering what a cruel time it must have been.But it's all a bit disjointed. Modern technologies could have been used with maybe some contemporary news footage from that era and a brief historical documentary to put everything in perspective. Instead, it seemed too much like a production line of visitors being herded through to maximise income on the basis that they'll come, whatever we show them. "Bus them round the island and get them back on the boat before the next lot arrive."

A Must See In Cape Town. There were long queues for the boat ride and it was a relatively packed boat. When we got to the island we had to pack ourselves into buses where a tour operator gave us his commentary on the drive around the island. I loved the fact that the tour of the prison itself are given by a former political prisoner and we get the first hand account of what happened all those years ago. However, it was a bit rushed and you don't get time to really stop and explore the site you are in. Also, the staff were very accommodating to an elderly gentleman with a walker, they brought over a wheelchair so that he could keep up with the walking part of the tour. This is definitely a must for South Africans and tourists alike.

A life changing experience.. There was a huge queue waiting in small area for departure, then we headed to the boat and staff demonstrated life-jackets. The boat was packed. The sea was calm that day but I had been warned that it is not always so. We landed at floating pier and were directed towards two coaches and taken to the tour of the prison. The presentation by a former political prisoner was exceptionally good. Choking back tears and dealing with complex emotions, I joined my coach and we were given a tour of the island by an excellent guide. Back to the Boat heading for the Nelson Mandela Plaza to disembark and hurry to the nearest place for a strong coffee to reflect and record a unique and valuable experience. Thank you to all those involved.

A must stop but very sobering given the history. Our group of four visited and all were moved by the history contained on the island. Our guide, himself a former political prisoner, was very insightful. Our group was large and so it was hard to hear all he was saying. They could use personal sound systems now used by river cruises and the Big Red Bus tours.Fast 20 minute boat ride from the Cape Town harbor but reservations are a necessity. This is one of those must see places regardless of your race.

Must see In Cape Town. This is a must see in Cape Town. To walk in the footsteps of one of SA's darkest hours is very moving. We learned that there were many men who fought hard to end the evils of Apartheid. Some lost their lives here. To see the location where the prisoners use to break rocks is heart breaking. One of the former prisoners gave us a brief lesson on life as a prisoner. He was very sad and hard to listen to given his story. We were able to talk to him afterwards and walk a bit with him. He had even better stories in private. The irony is that the captain of the boat that brought us out to the prison used to be a jailor. Such irony. Please bear witness.

Making History. The Robben Island experience is about how the conscience of an entire country can be changed. The story told by the guides about conditions at the prison and interaction of prisoners and guards state a great deal about us as humans. Times change, ideas change and prior antagonists now work together as guides telling the story of Robben Island and its history as a prison. This experience can certainly move people emotionally and should not be missed. A great bonus is the boat trip to the island that gives outstanding views of Cape Town and the Table Mountain backdrop.

Gut-wrenching history; disappointing tour. I am glad we went to Robben Island. But the experience was a disappointment. They simply push too many people through. Two very crowded boatloads of visitors make the approx 45-minute crossing to the island. Then we are parcelled out into four or six full-size buses for a drive around the island with audio commentary and a few VERY brief stops. The best part was last, when a former political prisoner serves as docent for the tour on foot of the area where Mandela was held. But he's herding the same busload of people. Too many people: too hard to hear, inhibits questions and conversation, limits time spent at any one station.
Robben island. a very moving experience. The guide was a former prisioner and very knowledgeable of history and South Africa

Touching Experience. . A visit to this Island is a must. The tour guides are well educated and the history of the island is amazing to hear. For the tour around the actual prison an ex prisoner will do this guide with you.......this is quite an emotional tour as you cannot physically begin to imagine what these poor men went through.

Very Touching. Booked the tour online even though my card got declined twice. Later learnt that that both attempts had been successful so I had 2 tickets instead of the one that I needed. The staff at the office were very helpful with facilitating the cancellation and refund of one ticket. The tour was good but the heavy accents of some of the tour guides needed an extra keen listener to understand what they were saying. Asked the tour guide how many cells there were in the block housing Mandela's room and he said he's never counted them. Good for the historical experience but be prepared for the tour guides accents. Shocking what the political prisoners went though on this island. A must see tour.
Historical place. When you're in Cape Town and have the time to visit this historical place I'd really recommend you to do so. This place represent an important part of the history of South Africa

You HAVE to do this!. This is a MUST for anyone coming to Cape Town for the first time. This experience will show you the amazing spirit of reconciliation that Nelson Mandela brought to South Africa as it teetered on the verge of paradigm shift at the ending of apartheid. This deeply moving experience is important for all of us and we all have been affected by what happened here and in the wake of the ending of the apartheid regime. The tour of the prison is actually led by former inmates and compatriots of Nelson Mandela. Our tour guide was amazing and shared stories of how the prisoners communicated with Mandela and other leaders in the prison as well as insider details of what it was like to be imprisoned here. You get to see Mandela's actual cell during the visit and the quarry where he worked during his inprisionment here. This was an amazing experience. Take sun screen and sun covering--45 minute boat ride out and about 40 minutes back.

An eye opening experience. Don't be put off from this trip - it is not a 'fun park' or glamorous excursion - certainly the ferry over is not luxurious - but it is how prisoners were taken to Robben Island, and most people managed to find a spot to settle if the seats ran out on the 45 minute trip. We found the morning to be a very moving experience - the events and conditions on the island were all explained by one of the ex political prisoners as we toured the site in a bus and walked through the buildings. You could not help being moved by what he, and many others, had endured over so many years.  If you can't manage without purchasing food for a few hours a small shop sold snacks and there were adequate toilet facilities there.

Nelson Mandela!. Visiting Robben Island is a must if you are in Cape Town. Enjoying the city without knowing the history of the man who made it such a wonderful place would be a sin. It takes about 20 minutes for the boat to get to the island. You might want to sit on the back so you can have a stunning view of Table Mountain and Downtown Cape Town when you leave the harbor. Once you arrive, the regular tour is divided in two parts. The first half of the group will go on the bus which will drive you around the main highlights of the island (leper church, leper cimetery, limestone quarry, etc.) Unfortunately, you can't ever get out of the bus for pictures. The other half will visit the maximum security prison. The tour guide will be an ex political prisoner and will guide you in the prison. Then, you can see Mandela's cell among many other things. Historical and cultural visit. Was worth it.

Nelson Mandala jail location. The visit by ferry is worth the experience to understand first hand location and liftoff Nelson Mandala during his imprisonment. The tour is conducted by ex political prisoners, which gives authenticity. It is drive thru, walking tour.

Poor Robben Island tour. Boat trip over in a tub that should have been retired years ago - many had to stand for the whole trip.Bus trip around the island ok. Cell tour needed articulate guides.Very poor facilities for refreshments. Whole place dilapidated, and not worthy of world-class attraction status.

Shocking and dissapointing!. What should be a highlight to any person visiting this attraction has now been turned into a mockery of what it should stand for. It started with the ferry boat being totally disorganized, you scramble into it, and if you don't get a sit straight away you will spend the 45 minute trip to Robben Island standing. there are no safety instructions given and no mention of where life jackets could possibly be hiding!!!Considering that last year a similar ferry sunk whist doing this same trip- shocking. Not only does nothing get offered, there is no sign of any staff the whole of the 45 minutes and certainly no announcements or dialogue /narration is made. Not too sure if there were any toilets as I didn't dare get up from my seat!!!Arriving there was the same scramble to get out without any communication as to what one needed to do. The first impression you get is one of filth and serious neglect. You then get taken on a bus tour past the ghost town- there are supposedly 200 inhabitants still living on Robben Island but it looks abandoned and in some serious need of paint and love and care!!!! You get taken to the quarry where Nelson Mandela toiled away but its just for a look and take a photo as you don't get out of the bus. You then get a pit stop, in theory to go to the bathroom and get a snack, this is probably 2 hours after you've gotten onto the ferry!!!You get get to types of plastic wrapped sandwhiches and a cooldrink/coffee or water. Surely as a tourist attraction, and when that sees many a tourist, one have a better facility here and provide not only income for the island but also job creation for a couple of its 200 inhabitants!!! But the best was yet to come!!!!!, we then were rushed off to the prison where our tour guide was an ex- prisoner who not only barely spoke English but who singled handedly managed to waffle through the 15 minute tour through the prisoner. Very little factual and historical information was given . Trully a disgusting tribute to the memory of those that fought for liberation and especially Mr Mandela. On returning back on the ferry, a Bristish tourist commented on how disappointed he was as he had booked months in advance to come to Robben Island for the purpose of seeing Mr Mandela.s cell and his guide- an ex- prisoner as well, didn't even bother to stop and point it out!!!!DO NOT bother to waste money on this attraction, get a virtual tour app on your phone and read the book-you will learn more.
Great History. We went there with my parents during our world tour, it was amazing, how they preserved the history from the prison where Nelson Mandela spent a big part of his life.

Life long Nelson Mandela. Visited once in 2010, this island serve as memory for Nelson Mandela where he probes for the future use of the country. His stride for democracy spreads widely to different parts of the world. He also created many world leaders to spread his democracy term. I felt it was good to visit his place where he was kept prisoner during the colonial rule. It is charged with a fees to enter the island via a boat with many other attractions on the islands to explore.

Robbed by Robben. Despite the enormous historical significance of Robben Island, this is easily one of the saddest and most disappointing sites in South Africa. Any historian, preservationist or even the average person would be appalled by the total lack of maintenance and repair, and the shabby, disorganized and uniformed nature of the tour. If you still want to go,there are but two redeeming features; 1. hearing an explanation from a tour guide who was a former inmate there, and 2. being on the ocean for the views back towards Cape Town. The story of Robben Island is amazing. But it is not told here. Save your money and time (this takes nearly four hours) and either see the recreation of Mandela's cell at the Apartheid Museum in Johannesburg or watch "Long Walk to Freedom." Either will give you a far richer experience. Shame on the government of RSA for letting such a prime historical treasure be such a terrible experience, and for not having the vision to invest in this site to help tell his story to the world.

Our inspirational. We were very impressed by our visit to Robben Island,especially being shown round and addressed by a former prisoner,who explained in great detail the severe conditions prevailing at the time of Nelson Mandela,s incarceration.A very inspiring and interesting place to visit.
Not even worth the trip. Poor management.......rushed guide.....sad to see that something that means so much to South Africa is being lost

An Absolute Must-See. Any visit to Cape Town must involve a trip to Robben Island. A former prison for anti-apartied activists, it was the jail where Nelson Mandela spent 28 years. The South African government has wisely kept the place very much like it had been- there's no tourist shops, street vendors or tacky bars on the island. You should treat your visit as a chance to learn and pay your respects to the men who gave a portion of their lives so all South Africans could live in freedom and peace. Make sure you take the organized trip from the Nelson Mandela Gateway museum. The regular ferry does NOT give you the full tour. A camera is a must as well, as the island has a stark beauty about it, and it's the best place to get panoramic shots of Cape Town proper. Be forewarned, however- the island is several kilometers past the harbor breakwater. The ride can get pretty rough. If you're prone to seasickness, make sure you take anti-nausea tablet before you embark. Overall, one of the most moving and inspiring tours you'll encounter anywhere.

The time FLEW BY.. When we were told it would take 45 minutes each way to get there and that the tour would be 2 hours I thought REALLY??? I would have been so dissapointed had I not gone. It was so interesting that the time flew by. I learned so much about the history of the men who were sent there not just Nelson Mandela, but the thousands like him that were imprisoned there. Most Interesting.

A unique place in history. We visited during our 4 day stay in March. We opted for the early morning tour, and were able to book via our hotel. There were a number of boats going at the same time, and we were lucky enough to get on the bigger one !As others have mentioned, on arrival you get onto a bus, which then takes you around part of the island. Our guide for this part was both informative and at times funny - but he had a unique ability to bring everyone back to the stark realities of what life on Robben Island was like. Once we arrived at the prison, the ex prisoner took over the tour and he spoke of his times there and what they did during the years of imprisonment. It was a moving and humbling experience.Like others, we would have liked a bit more time to explore the island and visit the gift shop - but we were being encouraged to get back to the boat. I didn't mind too much as the wind had increased since our morning crossing and we were about to have a bumpy 45 minute boat trip back to Cape Town. Luckily we sat on the top deck so didn't get as wet as some.I can't imagine a trip to Cape Town and not going to Robben Island.

Historical. Robben Island is a quiet boat ride away from the water front. The tour consists of a bus tour of the island, and then a walking tour led by a former political prisoner. It was sobering to see the conditions that the prisoners endured for demonstrating their beliefs. The tour is extremely well done, and the guides enthusiasm for his freedom is uplifting.

appropriately desolate?. my fiance and I visited Robben island on a slightly overcast slightly rainy day. the boat trip out is LONG - like 45 mins... and once you get there you realise how bleak and desolate this prison was. apparently it was first a leper colony before it became a prison. a lot of the focus is on its most famous prisoner, Nelson Mandela, which is good, but one has to wonder about all the other many people who were imprisoned there whose stories have received less attention.

Robben Island. We always try to visit diverse parts of a country and felt we must visit Robben Island given its very prominent place in history regarding Nelson Mandela and apartheid. Although I would not have missed seeing it, the tour itself leaves very much to be desired. The bus trip around the island was "fine", however, understanding the tour guide was a little difficult; but, nothing compared to the long speech of the former prisoner. After he gave a very monotonous recital, he asked for questions. Since no one, about 20 people, could understand almost nothing he said, there were no questions asked of him. It is sad that there aren't headphones, or at the very least, a pamphlet or brochure with the basic speech the ex-prisoner was presenting. Something to follow while he was speaking. I'm sure he was very informative and passionate, it is such a shame we couldn't participate in his historical views. The island is not to be missed, however, since you get a different view of the city, some information from the bus trip and the many large photos with info along the walk. A very sad part of human history for sure.

A history lesson. Robben Island is obviously an essential visit when you are in Cape Town and it is advised to book in advance as it's so popular. I learnt so much of the history of apartheid and the fight for equality here. I had never heard of Robert Sobukwe before my visit. The highlight of the trip is the guided tour of the prison by a political prisoner. After the visit I realised what a great man Nelson Mandela truly was to forgive and move on after being treated in such an inhuman way.

great experience - educating and uplifting!. It is definitely something to do when in Cape Town - the island has some beautiful views and flora/fauna on offer, you can admire the Table mountain from there as well. But most importantly you can learn about the history of the island and South Africa, see the prison where Mandela and other political prisoners were kept. The prison itself is shown to each group by... an ex-prisoner. Therefore it is an immense experience in itself. In addition we were all absolutely amazed by the fact that the people now living on the island are both ex-prisoners and ex-guards, as neighbours!!! The power of forgiveness in its purest form...

Very sobering visit.. This museum made for a very sobering, but incredibly worth while tourist activity. To learn of the terrible wrongdoings within your own lifetime is quite an emotional experience. We were shown around by an ex prisoner who was an incredible man who appeared to bare no resentment to his mistreatment. We also met Nelson Mandela's prison guard who was very influential in the great mans life. I do wish it was possible to have a little bit more freedom to walk around and explore the island yourself rather than being confined to the organised tour bus and a glimpse of the hidden penguin colony would have been nice. Understandably though, it is very busy so controlling movement of visitors is a must. If you plan on visiting, book your tickets well in advance as it is very popular. We were lucky to obtain the only 2 available tickets for the duration of our 4 day visit to Cape town. You get a fantastic view of Cape town and table mountain from the island. The boat trip across the hangour is an hour long and is like an activity in itself. We were fortunate enough to see a pod of humpback whales which really made the day incredible.Every young person should visit here to learn and ensure the race problems of the end of last century remain a memory.

Disappointing. We felt we should visit for obvious reasons and were advised to book from the UK as it has become very busy. We have been to both Alcatraz and Freetown (Perth) prisons which were very informative and well done.The boat trip out is worth it for the great views of Table Mountain and one of the boats is the original prison ship. The initial tour involves a bus trip round the island visiting the solitary bungalow of Robert Sobukwe with some good information. The second part of the trip was a great disappointment. Nelson Mandela's cell appears to have been modernised, painted and glazed so little evidence of the hardship he must have suffered and the whole establishment was very sanitised. Nothing like other prisons I have visited. The veteran prisoner guide tried to paint a picture of life there but he was difficult to understand and I came away none the wiser.The references to Nelson Mandela were little more than he was a prisoner there and a list of other prisoners. I feel that this could have been much more interesting with perhaps some commentary on mobile headphones (such as Alcatraz) as you walk round and returning the cells to as they were.I wouldn't bother if I were you; a total waste of time and money.

an interesting visit, if you are interested in SA's recent history. Having seen documentaries and read about that recent period of South Africa, it is very interesting to go and visit Robben Island.The boat starts from the Waterfront area, next to the harbor. The entire tour - boat rides and visit of the island - takes about 3 hours.

Such a historical place, yet tours can improve. The first time I did the Robben Island tour was in 1992 - there were still prisoners on the island and we could not walk around freely. I was looking forward to having access the whole island and we went again.The boat trip is an hour each way. We were lucky and blessed with great weather which made this a very nice outing. Arriving at the island, you are directed to buses and then you have a drive around the island with a guide telling you some history. There is one stop where you can get off, get a coffee or somethign at the shop and take some photos of Table Mountain. Back on the bus and then the next stop is at the prison where the second part of the tour starts. Here an ex-political prisoner is your guide and the tour ends with Nelson Mandela's cell and a walk back to the harbour.I was disappointed in the fact that we could not get off and experience the other places on the island - cemetary, chruches, lime quarry, etc. Travel for me is to experience a place and to get a sense of it. The drive around did not provide any of that - you might as well watch that part in the cinema.It seems that if you want to experience more of it you must take some kind of private tour as we did see other people stoppign off and visiting the sites. Robben Island is known the world over and it is not utilised to its full potential.

Good history... need better execution.... We had heard so much about this place that it was a "must see" while we were in Capetown. The history and the cell block tour by a former prisoner were excellent. Several things really should be improved in my opinion: Need better communication to the visitors. We were just kinda waved at to go to whatever was next and we really didn't know what that was. Just a simple map and rough schedule of what you will be doing while visiting Robben Island would have made this visit excellent.

A real time-waster. We were all very excited before the tour and were expecting big things from it since after all, Nelson Mandela had been imprisoned there. The boat ride there and back took ages and they basically ride you around in an ancient bus and give poor information. Also, we could barely hear what our tour-guide was saying and not because of his accent!! We really were all completely bored out of our minds, I advise them to make a half an hour video with live footage and proper information. I just want to tell the truth to save others from this! If you are thinking of going please ask someone who has already gone! Not only a waste of money but a real waste of time as well

Missed opportunities. I'm a local who enjoys visiting attractions in my own city. It took me a long time to finally visit Robben Island due to the endless negative publicity associated with the running of this attraction - mismanagement, issues with ferries etc. etc. Having finally done so, I can't say that I was blown away by the experience.We were lucky enough to be able to select great weather conditions - some cloud kept the hot sun at bay and the sea was really calm. Our boat, the 'Sea Princess', was one of the newer ones but a few of the others looked like old fishing trawlers.There are 2 parts to the tour - a guided walk through the prison (conducted by an ex convict) and a bus drive through part of the island. The walk through the prison was informative but very rushed - I would have much preferred to walk through at my own pace perhaps using pre-recorded info. We were a big group and often the guide had started talking before everyone had gathered so people missed some bits of information. In addition, the African English accent can be hard to follow - especially for foreign guests. The involvement of the political prisoners is an interesting one, but of course this will have a time limit in the long run as they get older. I hope that the company who runs this attraction has a plan to collect their stories and for running the tours after they have retired.I never really got a feel for the whole place at the pace we were marched through and I could have done with having a map of the prison and the island. It is astonishing that after all this time that this simple tool isn't available.The bus tour is ok - made better by the informative guide. The buses are not great for viewing. Even if you get a window seat, it is possible that a sight will appear on the opposite side of the bus. Each place the bus stops has informative plaques, but they don't allow you off the bus until you get to the view point/ coffee kiosk. The stop is short and the queues are long, so avoid the sad sandwiches, take your own snacks and rather enjoy the view.There are some great displays in the gateway where the boats leave from, but you can't read them while you are queuing for the boats.Would I recommend this attraction? Compared to the other attractions Cape Town has to offer, this one is the least well executed in it's approach. It takes most of a day and has a high risk of being unpleasant if the weather isn't good. If you don't have the time to spare, but appreciate the history, rather visit the District Six Museum or the Apartheid Museum if you are going to Johannesburg. Only visit if the history is very important to you and the weather is good. It's a pity - this attraction has a lot of potential and could be a lot better.
historical place. a must visit to learn all about the Nelson Mandela heritage, impressive and important in the history of South Africa, the boat trip is really nice when weather permits

Robben Island-Could have been better. We did the Robben Island tour this week and felt like it was just a bit disappointing. The ferry experience was not up to par. Old boats with inadequate seating. The 8 mile journey took over an hour each way. On the return trip it was quite choppy and several passengers looked very uncomfortable.As others have noted, once you arrive you are given a bus "tour" of the island. This is really nothing more than driving around the island in a very old and cramped bus while a guide narrates. Aside from the gravel pit and the actual prison, there is little to see on the island so the bus portion is a poor use of time. Once this concluded, you are provided an ex-prisoner for the tour of the prison. This was interesting, but it was difficult to hear and understand the prisoner and it felt like he was speaking from a memorized script. We were then led out through a gift shop which really cheapened the whole experience.All in all, it was meaningful to see Mandela's cell, but it was a big use of time for little in return.

Once in a lifetime!. The island is reasonably close to the docks of Capetown, our ferry left first thing in the morning, upon arrival we were greeted by a tour guide, an ex prisoner, in and around the time of Mandela's release. He stayed with us through a large portion of the day, even guiding us to Mandela's cell is the most pictured location on the island, a tiny room with a desk, a chair and a mattress!

A good trip. I would recommend you go on an early boat, we were told if weather is due to change in the afternoon boats are cancelled. They apparently watch the clouds on Table Mpountain which show if the wind will get up, this tends to happen in the afternoon. We had a lovely calm trip out and the return was more bumpy and you would get wet if you didn't go inside. You get off boat get onto a bus which takes you around the island including a guide who was an inmate, he will show you Nelson M cell. Then quickly back to the boat. We sadly didn't have time to look at the wall display or go into the shop. (Not sure if that was the norm or that was due to weather turning). Well worth doing though. You get great view of Capetown from the sea. Boats leave from near Clock tower on V A waterfront.

Memorable but could be better. The Dias boat, which ferried us to the island and back is a let down for what is otherwise a memorable and significant tour. We had two excellent guides who shared some great insights about the islands history and the experience of having been a prisoner in the island for seven years. The first half of the tour highlighted the limestone quarry, leper cemetery and and Table Mountain view sight. The second half covered the prison and obviously Nelson Mandela's prison cell. All in an amazing reminder of the country's tumultuous past. Our teenage boys were not bored and found the tour interesting as well

Interesting, but still very political...inexpensive, but not very interesting. There are 3 boats that bring you to Robben Island from the mainland...all part of the same company. The slowest is the Nautical...like a barge. The water can be rough and it's a 45 minutes to an hour each way. When you get there you go through the maximum security prison and you can see Mandella's jail cell. It's just a plain cement room about 5 feet by 7 feet. You also get a bus tour of the island which is about 7 miles long. It's all fairly old and not very well kept. The whole tour is about 4 or 5 hours long and costs only about $15 US. The boat leaves from a waterfront area that is quite interesting...lots of shopping and restaurants. If I had it to do over I wouldn't waste my time on the tour, but spend the time going through the wharf shopping areas.

Fantastic island with loads of history. The trip was very rushed with little time to take in the spectacular history and geography of this island. It was disappointing to find the buses are not designed for sightseeing from the bus. I'm a little person and the only seat left was in the middle of the bus, hence I missed seeing any of the places we stopped at (cemetery, limestone quarry, etc). The stop at the cafe was for 10 minutes and once everyone had decanted the bus, lined up for the toilet, tried to buy a drink and take some photos, I missed out on the photo opportunity and a drink. The tour around the jail was great but once again it was rushed. The volunteers that take you around have some amazing stories and was the only reason I gave this trip some points. The seals on the boat trip out we're racing us, so this was pretty special.

Really disappointed with what I had expected to be a highlight of my trip. I was left completely underwhelmed by my trip to Robben Island and I regret opting to go here instead of to the Cape Point during my brief stay in Cape Town. It amazes me that I had to book the tickets in advance because the other slots over that weekend were completely booked out.The ferry service was too slow and meant that our time on the island was rushed and not very informative. We were advised by the staff that the whole experience would last about 4hrs, but instead it was closer to 5 and a half hours.Despite being towards the top of the queue (after queuing for almost an hour) before we were allowed to board the ferries we were almost herded onto the older and slower of the two boats (the Dias - avoid, avoid, avoid) and that effectively ruined our day. We took so long to get to the island that it felt as though we were constantly being pushed onto the next stage of the tour and never got a chance to stop and take a look around or read some of the exhibits that were on show.The tour of the prison was most unsatisfactory. We were hurried past Mandela's cell, with barely a chance to take a photo and no narrative, there was no explanation of the significance of the football pitch within the jail and our guide had to cut short his talk about his own experiences as an inmate because he wanted to make sure he caught the last ferry home (as it transpired, he had nothing to worry about because we were left sitting on the pier for a good 30 minutes before it arrived).The one good feature of the tour was the brief bus ride around the island where a different guide gave us some really interesting insights into the island, it's significance and the current difficulties facing SA. However, there was probably no need for a 10 minute break mid-way through what was probably a 30 minute tour overall - particularly since we had all been sitting on that blasted boat for so long just before that!We read in the local press the next day that there are efforts being made to improve the experience and to upgrade the ferries but until this happens I won't be recommending this tour to anyone.

Great historical site. Its a great historical site and a must for anyone interested in South Africa's history. I enjoyed the ferry trip. I did however not enjoy the staffs soldier like safety drill specially since i could not spot any life jackets. The prison tour was quite informative. The bus tour around the island was really rushed. We had an opportunity to take pictures of Table mountain from the island. The island is in need of some serious maintenance seeing so many tourists visit funding it should not be to difficult.There are plenty building ruins on the island which there was no time for. I would have liked to know more.

Could be much more , but it isn't. Had high hopes for an interesting, historical and educational experience, but not so. Had afternoon tickets and found unorganized lines without directions awaiting to board the ferry. We were lucky to get the newer ferry which only took 20 mins for the trip. Nice easy ride, with beautiful view. On arrival, the large group is assigned to buses that drive you through some areas. The tour guide was actually the best of the tour and explained the significance of the sites we were shown. Eventually we were lead to the old high security prison and were guided thru by an ex-inmate who unfortunately rambled thru the history without engaging the listeners, making it a surprisingly very boring activity. Even when you are shown Mandela's cell, there is no attention to the history.I believe they could do much more with what they have and should have at Robben Island. Clearly they could make it a more interesting, educational and maybe interactive site to appeal to younger and international crowds. I would have been happy in staying longer at the island if I could had the opportunity to read, watch and learn more about the area and it's history. The Robben Island Museum should probably be moved to the site and add an additional interesting element. Upgrade the experience with imaging and add a better café site, improve the store, etc Could be much more, but it isn't....

Stunning South Africa and Zimbabwe!!!. Tour Director - Linda Liebenberg. A Globus Tour Guide extraordinaire!!! Very Efficient, Professional and a great sense of humour, I would definetly book with Globus again.Cape Town Driver - Kobus Williams. This guy had talent! We went all over in his very safe hands!The weather wasn't great. Kind of rainy and cool but it was worth it.We stayed in beautiful hotels and lodges. Southern Sun The Cullinan, Cape Town. Kapama River Lodge/ Game Reserve. Here you could have a bath and the Impala's, Kudu, etc would be eating a touch away. 54 on Bath, Johannesburg. Ilala Lodge, Zimbabwe. This was a very quaint lodge and it gave me a feeling of being at home.Went to Robben's Island. The first jail that Nelson Mandela spent his first 18 years. Table Mountain. Be sure to wear closed shoes, Sandals didn't work that well on the sharp stones. I left some skin and blood there.We did a Malay cooking class with the famous Chef Faldela.Off to safari. Rangers Rassie & John. Trackers Collen & Lot. Wow......we saw The Big Five and The Ugly Five. It was totally amazing!!!Now on to Joburg. Some very poor areas here. Did the Aparthied Museum and I found that rather disturbing.Then Zimbabwe and Victoria Falls. What a sight. You will get very wet! I took the helicopter over the falls. It's a must do. Then I went on the Flying Fox over the gorge twice! This gets the heart rate thumping!After all of this I went walking with the lions. They were cubs 11 and 14 months old. We got to walk beside them and pet their backs. I was in heaven!!!It was a 43 hr journey home and I still had a smile on my face.A must trip for the adventureous!!!

Waste of money and time. Ferries always run late so do not plan for anything else on the day. Poor quality guiding. Very old boats and vehicles make for an uncomfortable journey. Staff attitude is disgusting and rude. Arrogant security guards who strut up and down on the Island at the arrivals quay - need to be told that this is no longer a prison and to change their attitudes - was told off for standing too close to the edge of the harbour! No communication when things go wrong. Avoid and rather save R300 and go to the exhibit outside the V & A hotel. Not my first visit and had a problem on every single visit.

Must do attraction. Our trip was cancelled due to stormy seas but, having booked in advance, we were able to re-schedule without hassle. The trip across is spectacular and the island itself is fascinating. Both our bus guide and prison guide were excellent.

A chilling reminder of South Africa's darkest moments. A trip out to the notorious Robben Island gives essential understanding of the Apartheid years. Our guide was a co-detainee of Nelson Mandela and his first hand experience and stories provided a personal insight into the island-prison's conditions. A rare opportunity to be in touch with recent history.We went in the morning. The mist over the ocean added a chilling touch to the atmosphere. One advantage of going early in the day seems to be the fewer visitors. The queue waiting for the midday crossing seemed much longer.

Rather watch it on Discovery. Do not expect a venue with many facilities. Run down buildings, irregular ferry, guides who are not always very well-informed, long queues and waits on smoky prehistoric buses . Apparently run by former inmates. It is begging to become a first world museum with modern facilities to meet the expectations of the thousands who want to visit.

Impressive. It is worthwhile to go and visit Robben Island as this is part of history for South Africa. Tour guide shared his experience as a convict at the island; this was great! Note that there is some food (sandwiches) sold on the island. Only disappointment: They asked us to take another boat on the return then the one we had going to the island. It was an old boat and took a full hour to do the return (compared to 20 minutes on the way out). So do not accept to change boat if they ask you to.

Disappointing. An important heritage site so poorly managed. To start the trip you are herded onto an overcrowded ex fishing boat (advertised as passenger ferry). The trip takes 1 hour, with no seating,or indoor area for wet weather and rough seas, if your on the upper deck you are informed that if you need a life jacket they are downstairs at the back. On the return journey we arrived back to cape town completely drenched and shivering as there was no inside facilities. You arrive on Robben Island to then be crammed in like sardines into a once again overcrowded bus where you cant even see out the windows. There are lots of info boards as the bus drives around the island, but you are told you won't get time to read them or even stop! We finally got to a stop.... it was a tourist shop...disappointing. We drove past cells and previous building, unable to stop. The tours 2nd and final stop was a the high security prison. A previous political inmate speech was good, however it was only 30 minutes of the 4 hour trip and there was no opportunity to wander or read any of the info signs around the prison and island, take photos or take in the history of the place. Don't waste your time until they rectifiy how they run these tours!

Extraordinary atmosphere. You have to visit Robben Island if you visit Cape Town. It's almost a humanitarian obligation. I have seen other reviewers compare it to other sites which are painful to visit but each one is unique. It's not developed and there are no 'facilities' as such but that's not the point. It's not a day out. What the site has is atmosphere which is like no other we have experienced. The descriptions from guides who were prisoners are moving and honest. There is no evident residual hate. They tell the story is a dignified way. Do visit.

A stunning experience - need to book in advance. Have been twice, and both times this place floored me. The personal tours from former inmates are moving and not at all scripted. The driving tour of the island is alright, but the hour long tour of the prison is really moving. A must do in Cape Town.

A Must See. Having just visited Alcatraz in San Francisco a few weeks before I was very interested in comparing the two experiences where countries chose to lock up their prisoners in islands in sight of large cities. It really struck me that while in the USA, the prisoners were really bad guys--bank robbers and murderers--at Robben Island the prisoners where people fighting for their civil rights--the ability to move about freely and to vote in their own country. And for that they were locked up for decades, and in the case of Nelson Mandela and others, forced to chip limestone in the blazing heat and sun 8 hours a day, 5 days a week. The trip is long--but it's because they really want visitors to understand the story and the fight for freedom--so there is a bus tour and walking tour. The walking tour of the prison is led by former prisoners and is very moving. I came away truly in awe of what Mandela and others did to earn the right to vote---which didn't happen until the mid 1990's. It's a story that can never be forgotten--and a place that helps you learn more about how recent it is in the countries history that 80% of the population was give their right to vote.

Very disappointed. I was really looking forward to going to Robben Island and it was on my must do in Cape Town, we booked via the web before travelling, which is advisable as it gets sold out. The ticket we booked was for 9am, we got there early 8.15am, had a wander around the museum then joined the queue as a coach load of people had turned up, we were on the boat at 8.30am and it left! So not sure what would have happened if we had turned up later? The ferry ride was lovely, saw dolphins and seals on the ride. There is really poor organisation of the experience, obviously there were lots of people there as we expected but the tour people did not seem organised in what they are doing, firstly we was going to walk, then we were stopped and told to get on the bus. The guide on the bus was excellent - sorry, can't remember your name :-( . On the way back there was a confusion with the boats, lots of people got on one boat, then as it was full there travelling companions where left and originally told the next boat would leave in an hour, fortunately it was only 15 minutes later. But as the whole tour is organised, they didn't seem to organise the coach and boats to match up with the tour.

Revitalizing Apartheid. We visited Robben Island on a sunny Sunday afternoon. We booked the tickets beforehand. The weather was windy but not so irritating while on the ferry. The Table Mountain scenery from the boat was marvellous. When you arrive on the island you start to think what happened 25 years ago. Of course it is frustrating to visit the prison cells of the apartheid victims. It is a memorable experience to visit cell # 4, Mr. Mandela's room for so many years.I spent some time to enter couple cells and read the stories of various inmates. It was also interesting to hear the stories from a real inmate, our guide, who really spent time there. Apart from the prisons we also visited the other side of the island to see penguins on the shore. The return at 18:00 hrs was more disturbing since the winds grew stronger. Overall it is a once in a lifetime experience.

Robben Island. We took a car out to visit Robben Island because many people suggested it. I enjoyed it but would not recommend it if you have a limited amount of time to spend in Cape Town. It was very touristy and the small town did not have much to offer. While we did see the penguins, it was in a "park" area that you had to pay to get into. I though it would be a much more natural environment so was slightly disappointed. We probably stayed for 30 to 45 minutes and then took the car back toward Cape Town with a stop for lunch in the surfing town close by.

Very powerful and touching.. The tour to Robben island was very well run. The boat ride was very nice. A funny but professional crew. Once on the island you witness a sad and powerful part of history. The tour is run by former wrongfully imprisoned inmates of the island. Highly recommended!
