An historical island. We pre-booked and if the weather is too windy you will get a full refund. However, we were lucky enough to have good weather, a good ferry crossing and a very interesting tour of an island, which was a leper colony before it was a prison for the World Statesman, Nelson Mandela. Our guide had knowledge of the prison history having been an inmate in the time of Apartheid.

Great historical visit that one should make time for. This is the second time I am visiting Robben Island. The first time was in 2009 and a lot has changed here. Then the queues were long and getting a ticket was impossible. Well, this time, we were better organised. A word of advice: please buy your tickets early, it will save you unnecessary stress. The workers are almost friendly and the ferry is clean and efficient. From the boat, you get the most stunning view of Table Mountain and this is truly worth it. At the Island, the washrooms are clean in spite of the high volumes of people.You cannot leave this place indifferent. The resilience of the human spirit strikes you even as you look at the quarry where the prisoners spent their lives during the day....

History telling it's story.. It was very interesting to go to Robben Island!One thing that wasn't so nice was the boat ride, but that's just me.The tour was very interesting! We started with the bus tour, was really nice. A lot of information and nice and fun interaction with the visitors.The walking tour was also interesting!It was so good that an actual ex-prisoner was there to tell his story.The only problem we had was that we couldn't always understand what he was saying. And it went quit slow. So sometimes you lost the focus on his story.We saw Mandela's cell, which was very hard to see. But also just really interesting to know that he actually stayed there.I really liked going here, just to have a better picture of what happened and how the people lived.It was very nice!

Very good but could be improved. The whole experience is very good but the tour groups are too big and sometimes it is difficult to hear the guide who is a genuine ex prisoner. It feels like the whole tour revolves around getting you to Nelson Mandela's cell which is a bit of an anti climax tbh, but this is just a personal opinion.I would still recommend someone visiting Cape Town to go to Robben Island, i just feel the experience could be delivered much better.

HUMBLING. This was a very moving experience for me. We went in in April and it wasn't very hectic. We were well taken care of and learned much from the experience. It is difficult to believe . Once again truth is so much bigger then fiction.

A little piece of history....... Disorganised chaos waiting to get on the boat from the Clock Tower over to the Island. There were so many people that we had to wait a further 20 minutes for another boat to take us over. The anticipation in terms of what you're going to see is immense. On arrival at Robben Island we were herded onto 2 buses. This was the frustratiang part as we spent too much time on the bus looking at various different areas without being able to get off & really absorb the atmosphere.Our final bus stop was at the prison where we were met by one of the prisoners.Shame these groups are so big as you just want to ask a million questions about their lives & time spent on the island. Our guide around the prison was very interesting & informative. The suspense starts to build as all you really want to see is where the great man himself spent all those years. What strength of character this wonderful & amazing man Nelson Mandela had to get through his time on Robben Island in such a confined & desolate space in the way that he did.It is a shame you can't walk around many of these areas freely & before you know it, it's time to head back.........so very glad we took the time out to go and see.

Interesting but improvements would make the experience so much better. We booked the trip a few days before. No information is given in terms of what boats can or can't be used, we ended up taking 'Dias' boat across which is slow and reduces your time to properly explore the island. Buses meet you at the port, but no one to coordinate filling these buses. Our tour guide was also the bus driver. At each stop he left his seat to talk us through each point of interest, which delayed our trip around the island. He we very knowledgable of the island and history but limited on the bird life, flora and forna and animal life on the island. When we go to the max security prison there was no guide to meet us off the bus, so our group literally joined another guided group only to miss the main exhibit. Although very interesting and certainly a 'must do' l found the trip generally chaotic and rushed. Small attention to detail such as someone to coordinate filling boats and busses and staggering the dispatch of busses, and a guide with a sign indicating what group he is taking around would certainly help. Alternately lay out the museum with more information, heads sets and allow visitors the option of a self guided tour. Would also be nice to open up to the public some of the other buildings such as the churches, schools and guest house.

A MUST SEE--EYE OPENING. We were fortunate to have a very beautiful day to visit, smooth boat ride and great views inckluding sea lions and whales. The bus trip around Robben Island and the walking tour were both very informative and touching. No, doubt the spirit of Nelson Mandela is alive and well.
very worthwhile. A really great trip... thanks partly to our tour bus guide. He was very informative but funny too. It was thought provoking.

Badly managed and no organisation!. Pre booked tickets when we got there for a Thursday due to high demand at the time. Booked the 9am sailing. Arrived at 8.30am to a huge crowd standing from the jetty area all the way into the main square outside only to find out then out boat wouldn't be leaving for another hour due to a problem with it. The boat then took over an hour to get to the island. Rushed onto buses when we arrived at the docks and driven quite fast around the island. Couldn't even get out to take photos of places like the lime quarry. The ex prisoner guide on the bus sounded like he had given the same speech one too many times. No interest. Arrived at the actual prison then are again felt like we were being rushed around by the ex prisoner again telling us we had two minutes to look here and three to look there. Not a very enjoyable experience. Couldn't get a feel for the island or life there. Didn't mind having to walk to the jetty again to catch the bus because we wanted to look in the gift shop and read the visual aids along the dock too but then we were told we needed to get straight back on the boat for the mainland again. No time to soak in the islands atmosphere and history. Arrived back two and a half hours later than expected due to all the problems which threw off our plans for the rest of the day. No consideration at all for the paying customers. Would not recommend it.

A Must-Do!. Being so important to modern history this island is a Must-Do during your visit to South Africa. It´s easy to order and take the ferry from Waterfront. A bus awaits you at the island and your guide is normally an former prisoner. You will se the prison itself and of course Mr. Mandela´s cell. It is so small.. My guide did a great job explaining the whole process with their former prisoners, and not to hide, Mr. Mandela is the most famous of them. The tour also drives you by the guards home, other important union representatives and some necessities of this island. It´s now a museum but still some of the guards lives here. This tour will make you think! And while you are in the "box of thinking" you can watch Cape Town and Table Mountain from the shore side. An powerful experience!

A must visit. Visited this today as part of a holiday to Cape Town. The island was great. The ferry however leaves a lot to be desired. All 160 passengers were seated on the sea cat, only to be off loaded onto another boat (much older) with little explanation!! Organised chaos!!! Don't let this put you off going to the Island. Its a must visit location for all the right reasons!!

Must see. Try to get the fast boat over as that only takes 20 minutes. The bus tour is good but the tour by the ex prisoner could be better - just because it was hard to hear and understand him sometimes due to large numbers of visitors. This was a shame because he was really interesting - maybe a simple pamphlet would help?

Part of History. This is a trip that you must make! It is part of history. Remember however that you are merely seeing a prison so don't expect to be stunned by scenery (although there are some great views back to Table Mountain). You are visiting part of history and if you get a good guide (often past inmates) it is riveting. Don't be afraid to ask the guide questions as they are much more interesting when they leave their script. Some people feel this trip is dull but this reflects in my opinion on their limited horizons.

Educational and enjoyable. We went on the afternoon trip which included a boat trip, island your and prison tour and talk. Held by ex inmates which was such a good interactive tool as they were so friendly and willing to talk about their experience. Only hiccup would be that we booked the1pm trip however just managed to get on this one being the last2 in the queue even though we arrived 20 mins early! Very popular so be sure to arrive in good time

awesome tour. Its very easy getting the ferry over to Robben Island. most of the tour guides are former prisoners...so you get a first hand account of life as it was then. And of course Nelson Mandela"s cell is humbling. there is also a bus tour of the island and you see where the guards live.. highly recommend.

Something you don't have to do. They say Go there its lovely. They say You have to see where they were all locked up.It looks soo beautiful. Calm. Peaceful. You feel sad, angry. Don't let it ruin your trip

this Tour takes a full day to complete. The start from Capetown was hot and frustrating. No boat arrived for our scheduled departure time and the waiting room was full of frustrated people.We finally got on our way and then enjoyed seeing where Nelson Mandella had been kept, and the drive around the island was good, but a bit rushed at the end. We had to catch a boat back to Capetown and could have used more time to visit shops and other areas, but ran out of time.
Nelson Mandela was in prison there for about 20 years.. I think the thing that I enjoyed most was the tour guide who at one time was also a political prisoner at this camp.

Robben Island. for me a Tour with a lot of meaning. I was living in Nigeria Wien Mandela was released in 1990. a very important day for Africa. The collaps of Arpadheid should remind us how inhumane racism is in generally. The Trip with the Shop was very enjoyable and they views especially of Table Mountain were great.

A must do in Cape Town. I suppose this is a must do when in Cape Town. we arrived off the boat to be herded on to buses and shown briefly around the island before being dropped at the doors to the prison. The tours of the prison itself are undertaken by ex-inmates who were fascinating to talk to. There wasn't a whole lot of substance to the tour, which I felt could have been a lot more informative than it was, for instance there was a lot of the prison that we did not see nevertheless it was interesting to see somewhere that one has heard so much about. We had a fast boat take us over but a slow boat on the way back, sea legs are needed if it is in anyway choppy!

Must do for a Cape town visit. Visited the island in 1997 and did not get a chance to visit again on trips in 2012 and 2015. This is a must do if you have never visited Cape Town. The history and stories are remarkable and will re-enforce all that we know of the legendary man Madiba. Short boat trip from CT and well worth the visit for young and old. From my recollection it was not commercialised in any way so get a bite at the waterfront before heading out.

Blegh... Nice to see, nice to walk around. Not all facts given is the exact truth. Wanted to learn more about Mandela and the infra structure of the island. Everything just went about politics once again. Glad i went, but wont visit again

Glad we went. We visited Robben Island because it was a "must" for those of us who have studied the Mandela days. The ferry across from the V and A harbour was very nice and comfortable. The return ferry was less nice, slower, and dirtier but still adequate. When we arrived, we got onto a bus (in the heat) and a former prisoner talked to us. Unfortunately, we sat near the back of the crowded bus and really couldn't understand him. It was very frustrating. It was much better when we got out at the prison itself and changed guides. That was extremely interesting! Really, the rating should have been 3 stars, but because it was a must see, I gave it an extra star.

Superb if you don't mind being herded in a large group. Our tour of Robben Island was well worthy raveling in a pack on a slow and chilly boat ride to the island in thick fog because our guide was so outstanding. His name: Thulani Mabaso. His story moving and haunting, delivered candidly and with heart. I won't spoil it for you - but do go and hear it for yourself. Listening to Thulani we had a sense of life in the prison and the extraordinary working together of the prisoners to educate themselves and each other, and the struggle to improve their lot and gain a voice in the country.

Very interesting. Definitely worth a visit if you are interesting in learning more about the history and the prison. Very informative bus tour first around the island then a tour around the prison and cells by a former inmate. Saw lots of wild life on the island and on the boat back we saw whales, dolphins and seals. No opportunity to wander around yourself which would be better but understandable why they don't do this. Worth trying to get on the newer boat there and back, much faster and more comfortable than the old boat.

Not to be missed. Very informative guide on the coach followed by former inmate who showed us around the prison itself. Both were genuinely knowledgeable and gave real insights for us to absorb in an involved and factual way without getting too emotional about their thoughts and experiences. Made it even more powerful and convincing as a result. Despite the fact that they do this every day it felt fresh and real for us, and we appreciated their openness, we were very impressed.Overall a not to be missed experience, and a nice boat ride to and from the Waterfront taking photos of Table Mountain from a new angle.

Robben Island. I would not recommend this "attraction". There's nothing to see and the guide who was a former inmate is very hard to understand. You are shown two or three of the buildings, and of course, the cell where Nelson Mandela was incarcerated.

An amazing glimpse back into history - not to be missed. I wasn't really sure how I felt about this tour. Our children were with us ages 16, 10 and 23. It was very moving for all of us - having previous inmates give the tour was the icing on the cake. Don't expect an amusement park - it is very low key and it is kept well and in the spirit of what it is.

Really a must see in Cape Town?. An hour by boat from the Waterfront area in Cape Town is definitely worth this trip, but this is only a trip that I would do this one time. Once you've seen it, there is no point in going back in my opinion. It is very fascinating to learn about the life at Robben Island and of course seeing the cell that Mr. Mandela was in. But that is it. A quick trip around the island is just to kill some time, as the visit to the prison (which is the higlight) only takes 30 minutes. It was a good experience, but once is definitely enough.

Disappointing. I was really looking forward to our tour of Robben Island, but unfortunately we didn't get much out of it. Perhaps we just had bad luck with our guide. After the boat ride to the island we got on a bus for the tour around the island, but could hardly understand the guide! I am a native English speaker but could only understand about 10% of what he was saying. We would often pull to the side to look at something outside, but there were so many people in the bus that we often couldn't even get a view. Afterwards we went to the prison and had a tour from an ex-inmate. This part was okay. We could understand our guide but were still hoping for more history on apartheid, the prison and Nelson Mandela. Overall we were disappointed by the amount of information we received.

A piece of history which needs to be understood. We weren't really sure what to expect especially as we saw several houses as we approached by ferry. However the tour guide on the bus soon gave us the history and told many stories of the inmates and how they were treated so badly. The highlight was an informative and compelling guided tour of the main prison, where Nelson Rolihlalha Mandala was kept for 18 years, by a former inmate, Sparks. Sparks managed to get across emotively how poor the conditions were for the political inmates and the terrible atrocities they suffered. He took us into the main section where he spent 7 years. The fact that he and others like him have forgiven their wardens and live with them as friends on Robben Island is a commendable testament to their beliefs and values and shows their true strength of character without which they would never have survived. Definitely worth a visit.

local is lekker. i always put off this trip because i thought that this particular attraction was priced for overseas visitors. but i was pleasantly surprised. the trip to robben island was quick, at about 20 minutes. the trip back was about 1 hour but with another slower ferry. the guide on the bus was articulate, funny and very informative. information was presented in a captivating manner. The ex-inmate was also similar in terms of his presentation. This trip was rather interesting because it gave me insight into our rich history and i had zero regrets on this price paid for my whole family. i dont know what the running costs are but perhaps some consideration could be given to the pricing to make this jewel of South Africa more accessible.

Incredible. This is a moving and informative trip. We would not have missed it for the world. We were lucky enough to have our trip around the prison hosted by Sparks, who was one of the men that was imprisoned there during apartheid. The information that he gave to us sends cold shivers down your spine. The fact that he can still do this trip and has found it within himself to forgive is incredible. We consider ourselves privileged to have been able to visit the Island and to have Sparks as our guide. We would like to return and spend more time there.

History and very good guides. we enjoyed our visit to Robben Island very much, but we have to say, if this island didn't play such a poignant roll in history, it might be different.The tour is guided by an ex prisoner and it is very nice to see that they do it with so much joy and dedication.It is very interesting to see how the inmates of the apartheid regime had to survive. if you have the time to go to the island we should say go, not only because of the history but also to see how dedicated the guides are.

Memorable day out. I visited Robben Island 2 years ago. I still remember it so clearly today. The history is amazing and very touching. I felt like i went back in time to see the cells of Nelson Mandela. It was very sad. But a extremely great experience to see. A must definite place to visit when in Cape Town. 10 star!

Nelson Mandela. The ferry we left in was not in a good condition at all, I was a little shaken at first and had to adapt. When we were leaving we were in a decent one. I loved the whole experience and the history behind Robbin Island. Iv always associated the island only with Mandela but the tour guide was knowledgeable and gave a lot of insight to the place

Not What Expected. We were looking forward to exploring Robben Island. We took the ferry over and were greeted with a fleet of busses. We saw plaques along the route, so it clearly has been a walking tour/less guided before. The only time we were able to actually walk and explore was at the maximum security prison (though our tour guide was a previous political prisoner). Even Mandela's cell was partitioned off with sheet glass creating a zoo-like feel.While it was a great history lesson we were hoping for more of an experience.

Well worth the effort!. Be aware that the trip to the island crosses almost 12km of open water and that the seas can get very choppy. The boats will run anyway so if it looks bad make sure to get a seat outside where you can get lots of fresh air. Make sure to buy tickets online ahead of time as sell outs are the norm. If sailings are cancelled you will be refunded. Yes, the busses are full and yes, the ex-prisoner guides accents are heavy but come on! First world problems for sure!! Take a deep breath and appreciate your freedom and theirs.

Interesting tour. We liked our tour of Robben Island, the location where Mandela was imprisoned for many years. The tour included two parts: a tour by bus around the island and a tour of the buildings where Mandela lived. The bus guide was well spoken and informative. However, the guide for the prison section, who was a former inmate, was very difficult to understand so we got very little out fo the experience. I am sure that some of the former inmate guides are very good; possibly only ours was difficult to understand.

Disappointing. We went to Robben Island as part of a day trip with Illios travel. We had really looked forward to this visit but were left disappointed. When you get to the Island, you are herded onto a bus which takes you on a tour around the Island. We were the last to board our bus and were stuck at the very back, so we struggled to hear what our guide was saying. It was also difficult to see the buildings and quarry that the guide was talking about due to the overpopulated bus. After 45-60 minutes of the Island tour, we were dropped off at the prison for a tour around it. Again this was a big disappointment, as despite the guide being an ex-political prisoner, we got very little insight into what life was actually like within the prison. The tour also seemed very rushed and we managed to lose our guide twice as they allowed little time for photographs. The final part of the prison tour was a visit to Mandela's cell, and despite the fact that most people go on the tour because of Mandela, there was very little mention of him or his time at the prison.

A must see!. Purchase your ticket online to avoid the queue at the sales counter. I would strongly advise against sitting on the upper deck of the ferry (instinctively this is where everyone heads). The breeze gets very chilly and if you don't have a sweater you will get very cold. Thankfully, I had carried a jacket but regretted sitting at the top. The views were breathtaking (particularly that of Table Mountain). You can always go up there to take pictures. When we got to the island we were directed towards the tour buses. We had a very good guide who was knowledgable. The downside of the bus tour was that you didn't get to see everything because there were some structures on the right side and others on the left. Sit on the right side of the bus to get a view of most of the landmarks. When we got the prison block where Mandela was held, we alighted for a walking tour by a past prisoner. Our guide, unfortunately, spoke very fast and it was difficult to understand half the things he said. Luckily, I had a lot of prior knowledge on Robben Island and the history of South Africa. My advise would be to read up on the island in order to better appreciate it. It was very euphoric seeing Mandela's cell. This moment was worth the entire tour.

All the potential, disappointment reigns. So much history and potential, but run-down and mismanaged. About time this place is run by competent , client-centric staff rather than the present " bunch". This should be a first-class expierance, but at present is a third-world, second class embarrassment.

Excellent & very informative. This is a great trip to find out what it was like on Robben island. Very well organised from the boat leaving by the Clock Tower on the waterfront to the tour around the island by bus. Whilst on the boat the crew would point out anything of interest and we saw a whale with its young calf, very unexpected at that time of year. Once on the island you are taken by bus with a guide who explains each part as you drive around. This includes the guards accommodation (and their families), churches and the quarry where Nelson Mandela and other prisoners would break stones day in day out in searing hot sun. At this spot we didn't get off the bus which would have been nice to have the opportunity to take photographs. We understood that you would not be able to walk on or around the quarry but to get off the bus would have been good. The best part of the trip is that an ex-prisoner guides you around the prison on foot. He gives a very personal touch to the tour. Explanations are clear and he was very willing to answer any questions. Very well done. It's well worth visiting whilst in Cape Town, it's pot luck with the weather though for the crossing by boat!!

Very poor. Went with my wife 01.04.15 and wish we hadn't bothered. The trip out was ok but the tour was a real drag as the guides had no concept of time and droned on and on about their own views. Because of them we missed the boat back and had to wait for another. We should have been back in Cape Town at 6.00pm but didn't make it until after 8.00pm. There was no safety briefing on the way back even though the seas were rough. DON'T DO THIS TRIP ON YOUR LAST DAY OR YOU COULD MISS YOUR PLANE HOME.

Life experience. We caught the mornign ferry out to the island and the weather was magnificent. A member of our party had done it with bad weather and had mentioned how awful it was. Fortune was on our side and the sea was calm and clear and perfect.Our crossing was the best experience ever and we saw whales there and on the way back.The tour was fascinating and gives one a great perspective on the political landscape that has shaped our country.Highly recommended if the weather is great.

Very moving . This was an amazing trip after we arrived. It is a shame that the staff and South African Nationals were not so wonderful as Mr Mandella. We bought our ticket online 3 adults one child. Got in line to nearly be turned away because a South African school black had a couple of people stand in line to then let about 50 + others who had been buying take away food jump the queue. Why that amount of tickets are sold with the possibility of not getting on the boat who knows. When people protested the staff just laughed and continued to let people jump in so not great. The trip out eventually and the tour of the island by one of the inmates at the time of Mr Mandella being their was truly fascinating and moving felt privileged to walk here and hear the stories so great trip but tour operator you need to sort the issues out with your staff really poor behaviour. We did complain but never heard anything. But this is a truly amazing trip to do.

Very poor. Such a shame. You are more pushed around than herded! There are lots of info boards but you are even told you won't get time to read them & to read up on the history when you get home! Boring bus tour, overcrowded so you couldn't see out of the windows. Tour of prison by former inmate, told you have beween4 & 7 mins to look at info boards in cells, then called out! Best thing was boat trip over in choppy seas! Real shame.

inconsistent experience. Like many of the other reviews our experience was mixed, the bus tour guide was extremely good, very articulate, knowledgable and just the right balance of serious delivery with some humour. Unfortunately the Prison guide spoke in a very low voice so it was hard to hear and in a very monotone way leaving us with a pretty limited understanding of his experiences.

Visit to Cape Town.. My wife, daughter and myself visited Cape Town in March (2015) for a weeks holiday. Cape Town itself is a truly beautiful city and we enjoyed every minute of our stay.During our stay we visited so many wonderful places - our trip enhanced by the politeness and helpfulness of everyone we met.A visit to Robben Island was high on our list of places to visit. As we approached the jetty the prison appeared and as we walked up to the entrance of the prison we were reminded of the terrible conditions that the prisoners had to endure. The murals on the way to the prison depicted the struggle for freedom made by those brave men.Our tour guide was himself an ex prisoner on Robben Island and described in detail the hardships that he and his fellow prisoners had to endure. What clearly came across was the intellect of this man. He articulated his experiences to all of us with such passion which was tempered with a feeling of forgiveness for the perpetrators of such inhuman crimes.It was a very interesting and highly charged visit and one which I will never forget. The visit to Nelson Mandela's cell was very evocative. The men incarcerated on Robben Island were not criminals but men with vision, spirit and intellect.I was very moved by my visit and as I left that day I wanted to thank this brave and humble man for the tour but I just couldn't speak as I felt overwhelmed.I shook his hand and embraced him. He knew well the way I was feeling but I just couldn't utter any words. He said that it is difficult to understand how man could be so inhuman to his fellow man. It was a privilege to meet such a humble and dignified man.A visit to Robben Island cannot be more highly recommended by me and I hope that you will will have the opportunity to visit this symbol of man's struggle against the odds to achieve a better and freer society.

Tour of Robben Island. This World Heritage site is not to be missed when visiting Capetown. After a boat ride, you are transferred to a bus for a 45 minute tour. There are photo stops and one longer stop for snacks, bathroom, and views of a penguin colony. The tour is narrated by a guide and at the end of the tour there is a stop at the maximum security prison which is led by a former inmate. Our bus guide was outstanding, she made the horrors of apartheid and the treatment of the prisoners very real. Don"t miss it
Simply Amazing!. Wow, the history and the amazing people that work here make this a top attraction. Everyone should visit Robben Island to see not only the history but stunning views.

Interesting and moving.. You have a guide to show you round the island in a bus which was ok but the best bit is the local guide who shows you round the prison area who was (at least in our case) a previous political prisoner who can bring the the place to life.

"No one truly knows a nation until one has been inside its jails." N. Mandela.. There are places you visit for crazy fun and places you visit for deep relaxation. But there are also places you visit to learn and pay respect to what happened there. Robben Island off the coast of Cape Town, South Africa is such a place. Robben is the Dutch word for seal and they have long shared the island with penguins, sea birds and tortoises, things. Once man inhabited the island, it became a place that brought out the cruelest aspect of human behavior. From the late 17th century until it became a World Heritage Site less than 20 years ago, this island was used to incarcerate free thinking men. For over 300 years it was a place that robbed men of their basic human dignity, a place dedicated to breaking man’s spirit and his will to live free. The island itself is a windswept coral outcropping covered with thick brush and rocks. Everything is coated with limestone dust from the quarry that once served as a place prisoners were pushed to the breaking point. The island’s shoreline and shallow waters are littered with broken ships that stand as a reminder to the many broken spirts that haunt the island. There was one prisoner whose spirit not only could not be broken, it soared higher during his incarceration- 18 out of a total 27 years spent on Robben Island mining lime stone with his hands. Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela suffered the 100-plus degree heat and the cold damp chill of winter for the crime of standing up for the basic human rights of his people.  I walked the island. I stood and starred into the limestone pit. I listened to the recollections of our guide, a former prisoner with Mandela. Tears formed in my eyes when I looked into the closet that was his cell. Only hunger strikes led by him, and the sickness that ensued, resulted in prisoners being able to move from sleeping on the floor to sleeping on cots. He had every right to be angry at his captors. He had even more reasons to be bitter over how he had been treated. Instead he led a nation back from the brink of total isolation and united black and white to forge a new government, a new land, a new freedom and a new peace.The boat ride to the island is easy and affords great views of the harbor and Table Mountain. A visit to the island combines a bus tour with knowledgable, entertaining guides with a walking tour of the prison led by a former political prisoner. A great learning experience. For those who say there is no justice in the world, I point to Robben Island, a very interesting place worthy of your time and your respect.

Takes almost an entire day. It's a great place to visit, but don't expect to get much other Cape Town sightseeing done that day. We waited over an hour for the boat to arrive to take us back to CT. Since the water was pretty choppy, it took almost 75 minutes to get back to shore. As for the actual tour, I wish that there would have been a little more detail on daily life. Even a little more of a tour and explanation of what happened on different areas of the island would be good.I also assume that there were quite a few notable residents. It would have been nice to have heard about a few that weren't named Nelson Mandela.

Worth visiting. This is an excursion not to be missed when visiting Cape Town!Starting from the boat ride to the tour of this majestic island where heroes of the Afrikan revolution were incarcerated by the now defunct apartheid regime!The tour guides know their story, they tell it ad it is.The store on the island sells nice souvenirs to remind the tourist of his short "imprisonment".It's a definite must do.

Quite insightful!. It was one of our 'must do' items when visiting Cape Town for the first time, and we're glad we went.We just took the ferry over from the V&A Waterfront and it's a fairly long queue to get on board, we hadn't eaten and there's no food at the island so a packet of chips on board the ferry had to last us for hours!A former political prisoner was our tour guide and incredibly informative tho not always completely understandable due to accents, but we were really pleased that we'd done the tour, and learned what we did.Still amazing to think that 'apartheid' could and did happen within our lifetime and that there were those brave enough to fight for the basic freedom of equality.Well worth a visit.I even managed to leave my sunnies in the amenities before heading home but a lovely tour guide had done a quick run-around before we left and had these on the ferry on the way home for me - saved!

the trip to and from the island amazing. ok now this is important to be read for that long day you will go to the harbor first to take the boat then 50 minutes in the ocean traveling to the island to see the Mandela prison inthe Robben island take your camera and coat to be ready for the wind int he sea i twill cost you 300 rand about 29 dollar you can buy food and drinks inside the boat and on the island too
Must Do. Just for the views of Cape Town the trip is a must but once you are there the trip into the not so long past is fascinating and informative a must do when in Cape Town

Amazing! Historical! Hopeful! penguins....yes.. At first, it was difficult to smile for the photo as I embarked on the journey to Robben Island. I already knew some of the history. I met a gorgeous couple from Kimberly South Africa; their first visit to Robben Island too. I experienced their joy and hope. I also saw southern hemisphere penguins! This excursion is treated with sensitivity and honesty by the guides. Beautiful experience!!!!!!

A must see. Really enjoyed the trip to Robben Island and was glad I made it a priority. Amazing to hear first hand what it was like to be imprisoned there and see the prison itself. There is a bus tour which brings you around the main part of the island and we saw the quarry where prisoners were made to work. The tour of the prison is with an ex prisoner and we learned about the diet they had and the conditions they lived in. Our guide was happy to take questions. Good photo opportunities of Cape Town also.

This should've been brilliant but... I and my wife went on this tour as part of a South African tour which was superb. The trip out was fabulous on a lovely day and the views from the island were majestic, especially the view of Cape Town. The first part of the tour was on a bus with a local lady who fancied herself as being a comedian, which she may well have been except it was very hard to understand her really strong accent. The second part was conducted in the gaol by a former prisoner. He was difficult enough to understand but it was plain that he was not a fan of Mandela's and talked about other people more. Not a single thing did he tell us about his daily schedule etc. etc. To make matters worse, another guide was shouting so loud that he drowned out half of what he was saying.This is a totally amateurish presentation compared to Alcatraz which I've seen or Cork Prison which I've also seen.

Not so long ago.... Nice ride out, not a good bus ride out because they are trying to get the most bang for the buck. I very much enjoyed the ex prisoner talking us to us and the stories and history lesson. When you see how small that cell was and you know how long he was there, makes me nauseous.

The tour is a little disappointing. Once you get to the island, you're put on a bus for a majority of the tour. You can't really get great pics, or even see everything for that fact. You do stop to get drinks and use the restroom, where you can take pics. Our tour conductor was very knowledgeable about the island, but it would be nice if you had more freedom to move around. The prison tour was interesting.

A good excursion, but could benefit from clearer guides.... The boat ride out and back was great...as was the experience of seeing the island and learning about its history. The downsides were the unintelligible tour guides. I can't imagine what non-South Africans made of the tour as the guides' strong accents were very hard to follow.
Very Moving. What more can I say that hasn't already been said. If you are at all interested in history this trip (tour) is a must!Be sure to purchase your tickets in advance on the internet.

Worthy of an afternoon. The trip to visit the famous Apartheid prison at Robben Island is almost worth the trip just for the fantastic views of Cape Town and Table Mountain that you get on the boat trip to and from. The boats are comfortable and the 30 minute trip was pleasant. Upon arriving you board a bus for a 45 minute driving tour of the island. Our guide was very knowledgable and informative.The highlight is the walking tour of the prison. These tours are conducted by former Robben Island political prisoners who give the tour a very personal touch. People like up to photograph Mandela's cell where he was kept for 17 years, but we will most remember our conversation with our guide who was imprisoned from 1984 until the prison closed in 1991. A great way to provide income and a place in history for the unsung heroes of the battle to end Apartheid.

Our guides were great. I found this tour very humbling.At times throughout the tour of the cells, I cried.It really surprised me how moved I was by this experience.A definite must when visiting Cape Town.

Visit to Robben Island. I was sceptical until I went there but now I am glad that I did.It reflects a remarkable piece of history whatever political views you hold.The transport, guides etc are very good indeed.We found that paying ourselves at the departure point was less than half the travel agent's fee.

A Must do am or pm Trip - but not as good as Alcatraz. We had to wait nearly an hour to board our boat, despite having pre-booked a set of 4 tickets for the trip back in London.This is juts poor admin.The journey over took around 45 minutes - was uneventful - but the excitement builds.The tour of the island on the coach is fine - but dodnt expect much to see or do.Being shown around the prison itself by an ex inmate who had spent 5 years there was very thought provoking.The journey back for no announced reason was by Catamaran - which took nearly twice as long. As was pretty tedious heading into the wind and against the tide & currents.Summary: worthwhile - but they need to improve the admin

Not as much information as hoped for. The ferry ride was fun and the process of boarding is easy - you can use your phone to have tickets scanned. The ride was about 25 minutes and we did not get a seat. Arrive early if you want to sit down! After arriving on the island, the tour starts on a bus. The guide was interesting and spoke about the hard labour in the quarries and how Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners educated guards and common law prisoners. Also a lot of info about Robert Sobukwe's detention there and prohibition to speak. Very interesting but little about Nelson Mandela.Political prisoners provide tours of the prison and you can see Mandela's cell but there was not a lot of history. A little disappointed.

Interesting. Went with a friend and took the afternoon ferry. Takes roughly 1 hour to get to the island. We were taken around by coach and shown the different areas. Our tour guide had lots of information and made it very interesting. We then went to the maximum security prison where we were taken around by 1 of the ex prisoners. Must admit i struggled to understand him for the majority of the tour, but cant hold that against him or anyone. What we could make out were again some interesting stories ans the fact that they came from somebody that had lived there brought it home.Must do experience whilst in Cape Town.

A must see, but could be so much better. I have visited Robben Island before, but recently visited again as my husband wanted to see it. I would say it is a worthwhile visit, however, there is so much more that could be done to make it interesting and a proper learning experience. The tour starts with an hours ferry ride to the island (not many seats on each boat, so many people left standing), before being shown onto a bus for a 45 minute tour of the island. You then stop at the prison blocks where you get a short talk from one of the prisoners, then shown Nelson Mandela's cell. The tour guide is knowledgeable about the island, however, I did not feel there was enough said about apartheid, the politics at the time and how it was abolished. Having just visited the apartheid museum in Johannesburg, I learnt so much and wish that more people could learn about the history, rather thank just see a cell.I do think it is worth a visit while you are there, but be prepared to wait around for a long time. Our boat left at 1pm, and we didn't return to the main land until 6.30pm as we were waiting for everyone to come back to the group after visiting the shop and taking photos.

A must stop!. Well worth the half day. Reservations essential.We got cancelled on our scheduled day as weather was too rough for the 4-mile water journey. It is clear they have not invested in "modern" boats - they could up their ante and shorten the "sail" to much less than than the 45-minute+ each way. We understand we were in the "better" of 3(?) boats. One of the other boats is not as stable resulting in passenger "discomfort" if the waves come up. Further, early AM reservations are better.We had to hustle to get reservations for the next day. The embarkation is a nice facility, generally well run, but expect a crowd for your scheduled time.The tour on the island is well done - our guide was a former prisoner. It is a visit you will remember. Do get to the harbor early - lots of "busy".

reserve beforehad!. I was unfortunately unable to go on the island because it's practically impossible to get a same-day ticket. I had limited time before my official tour of southern africa started so I missed out, as the next ticket possible was 24hrs later. I would definitely reserve by internet next time so as not to be disappointed

BRINGS ALL YOU'VE READ TO LIFE..... Robben Island, where Mr Mandela was held prisoner, is a very humbling place. An hour's journey via boat over to the island, followed by a short bus journey around the island, explaining what the daily activities of the prisoners were. Unfortunately, no-one could understand our female guide, yet other buses were thrilled by stories related by their guides. The prison tour followed and a very interesting half-hour spent with a fully conversant and knowledgeable former political prisoner- a lovely man. It was a poignant visit, as it brought to life the suffering and injustice brought on people during our lifetime. Well worth a visit. Thank you!

Good. We were told that if you come to Cape Town Robben island is a must !!!We booked up as part of a package (The township) we were picked up from our hotel and taken to the VA to get on our boat it was a lovely sunny day and the waters were calm it took just over an hour to get there once there we did a tour of the prison with an x con it was very interesting after the prison tour we were taken on a island tour which is very informative there is a history there that will never be forgotten .On our way back it was getting windy and the sea was rather choppy my stomach almost came up lol !!

Fascinating. This was a very interesting visit both from the historical and also from the natural historical points of view. Clearly the main reason for visiting was the history, especially that involving Nelson Mandela. Our guides were helpful and knowledgeable - one had been a political prisoner here. An unexpected bonus fro me was the wildlife, which they are actively encouraging. We saw ibis, penguins, nesting terns, tortoises and other creatures on the island and dolphins, seals and a Bryde's whale from the boat.

Essential viewing. Robben Island is a place that everyone should visit at least once in their lifetime as it is a very important part off the history of South Africa and the whole issue of forgiveness. Once you have been, you realise just how significant the peaceful transition was to democracy and how magnanimous Nelson Mandela and his co-prisoners were. We also found it very moving that our tour guide was a previous political prisoner. However, the trip and tour is a little disorganised, too rushed and the facilities (not the prison but the support facilities) are not great, but we were, in the spirit of forgiveness, more than willing to overlook this and it was a very moving and memorable visit.

Paying customers treated with disdain and contempt. Nothing appeared to run to plan. Our boat left early which is strange considering that the tickets quote a specific boat; what would the people who turn up with ten minutes to spare do? On arrival at the harbour no one directs you to the coaches so there are scores 1/2/3 boatloads of people milling around uncertain about where to go. Specifically, the prison guide was a grave disappointment because he was so hard to understand and those who could not follow his strongly accented English [most of the group] were totally perplexed and kept asking for others in the crowd to repeat what was being said. But the worst part of the trip was to be left unaccompanied on a coach for almost an hour in the midday sun with no information about why we were going nowhere. No one came to tell our group of about 40 people why we had been left so, and only after we left the coach to find a staff member did we find out that the guide had not reported for work and that there was no replacement. Each tourist/group had to go and find out for themselves that we had been abandoned, that we could not tour the island, and that we had to make our way to the harbour on foot to get back to Cape Town on any boat that would take us. There was a Korean couple on our coach who were frantic with the various delays because they had to get back to the mainland to catch a flight home. At the harbour it was like the first day of the sales with hundreds of people trying to get onto boats as they came in - beware elderly, small children, disabled because they were all pushed out of the way. Some of our coach group were unlucky and left behind with no boat in sight. On our return a handful of us went to the Customer Service Desk and explained what had happened. I spoke to Krystal who went to speak to her manager and returned with forms to complete for a 100% refund. The manager did not have the courtesy to make an appearance. Three months later I still await my refund and my emails have been ignored.Every business has problems and mistakes will be made but the true measure of a service business is to see how it recognises and rectifies mistakes. On that score this business failed miserably. My South African friends tell me that Robben Island has been soundly criticised for the way in which it has been managed, and I had first hand experience of why that is so. What a shame; this could be the number one attraction in South Africa.

Missed time on my own at Robben Island. One of my Must Do things in CT was to visiti Robben Island.In many ways it was a disappointing experience.The ferry was nice, great weather and very calm ocean.However, when we arrived at Robben Island we are kindly guided into busses that was extremely warm. Then we drove around the Island with a guide before arriving at the prison itself. A former prisoner talked about his experienses. I tried to get into the mood, but I never felt their suffering when he talked about it. I love historical sites and love thinking about what happened at different sights, but he never got under my skin. Then we were a full group passing by the cells where among others Mandela did spend way to many years of his life. But that left us with almost no time to suck in the athmosphere. After that we were gently guided directly to the ferry.I was expecting time to walk around the area but instead I kind of felt like I had been pushed around for a couple of hours.

A truly moving experience. There is so much history and suffering in this place that one visit will never be enough. Even the short time we were there was an emotional overload and we probably saw less than 10% of the island.Being shown round the prison by an ex-inmate only added to the poignancy of the day
A must visit. A truly eye opening experience and a tour which everyone should do. It was about 3 hours in total and very informative .

Emotional. Having seen Mandel's house in Soweto, now a museum, the house where he lived and died in Houghton, the spot where he was arrested in Howick, Pollsmoor prison and his release from Victor Verster prison there was just Robben Island to complete the picture. The Island has been turned into a historical museum and done very well. The guides who drive the coaches around various parts of the island are excellent and give you a real feel of the place explaining that it once housed lepers as well as prisioners, and describing what the buildings were used for and who lives in them now. A political prisioner showed us the cells where Nelson and his fellow prisioners were held and what they had to endure. We also heard from Christo Brand who at the age of 18 was his prison officer. A very worthwhile trip.

Rushed but good. Being taken around the prison by a former inmate was brilliant but if English not your first language then due to then you might struggle to understand what they're saying. However, learning more about the ANC, the history of Apartheid and the prisoners having laid to rest any animosity was incredible. A must see. The boat trips are interesting paticularly if the sea is choppy. One of the ferry staff said that that they took people over in 6 metre swells which I find very hard to believe considering the last ferry of the day out to the island was cancelled due to the chop of about a metre. Booking is an absolute must.

A Monument to Unspeakable Shame!. To see the details of how a shameful system treated humans gives one shivers. The guides, all former inmates, bring the terrors of that prison system to life, in particular, with the understating voice and verbage they use. The monstrosity of apartheid cannot be condemned more loudly than by those, now empty, cells in their silence.A powerful reminder of pain, sufferings and injustice!

Amazing. Although previous to visiting Robben Island I had read many reviews saying that people have had a difficult time with the tours and getting to the island. I however, had none of these problems. Although it was a beautiful day but we went, the boat was nice clean and easy ride over. Our tour guide was a formal political prisoner, and was absolutely amazing. He gave us lots of good information and answer any and all of our questions. If you are in Cape Town I highly suggest you take the risk and buy tickets to visit Robben island. I learned so much about the history of South Africa as well as apartheid. My only complaint was that the group was too big and I wish it had been a smaller group of people with the tour guide. All in all a must do if in Cape Town.

Boatride better than tour. Although we were guided by an ex-inmate of the prison, his poor diction made it very difficult if not impossible to understand his story and experiences of the prison. He showed us the cell in which Madeba was held and again it lacked the detail that may have demonstrated how he lived there. A quick tour in a bus preceded this, showing a previous leper colony cemetery and a few other prison buildings. I understand from a native South African friend that there is much more on the island of interest that could have been shown. Poor value for money.

Interesting trip. Overall good trip.Although not tailored at all to Small kids- they are not allowed on deck- no special commentary which is interesting for younger children (ours are 6 & 7yrs) daughter was interested but couldn't follow what was being said- very standard trip. when you get off the boat on Robben island u are packed into buses - if u are not on the first one u have to wait for the next boat to come in - they want each bus completely full before driving the 10 mins to the prison area- the best part was the tour given by an ex- political inmate - very moving Overall interesting but could have been more child friendly and more efficient

tour too long. most interest in taking a tour is firstly learn about South Africa's struggle for equality, through Nelson Mandela. Your spend two hours getting there and back on a very slow boat, then on a very old bus, not coach, to be driven all over this desolate island to second rate shops for coffee obviously filing in time . Finally after being on the island for almost two hours you get to the prison. It's a bit of an anti climax , there is no use of av , the guide for the prison section was an ex political prisoner , commentary seemed very scripted .

Not a five star rated trip. Having booked a trip to Robben Island as part of a greater package I will rate it on its own merits. The trip across was full of happy faces on a calm blue sea with clear blue skies and took an hour and fifteen minutes. Having arrived on the island you are treated to a bus trip around the island prior to going into the prison but unfortunately a bus was missing and we had to walk to the prison to do the tour in reverse. The walk was about half a mile up a slight incline which was a problem for a group of older persons. Upon arrival at the prison you are greeted by an ex con who becomes your tour guide and you are led into a short history of events was an open statement allowing you to make an unbiased judgement on the incarceration of the past inmates. The tour concluded for us with an informative bus trip around the island showing its long standing history not only as a prison. The weather changed and the boat trip was long cold and bumpy with grim looking faces. This is a must for the cultural element alone but be prepared for the change in weather

Interesting but short tour. Overall this is a pleasant way to spend half a day.The tour of the island is interesting and the guides (all ex-inmates) tell a compelling story.I would have liked a bit more tour and a bit less ferry ride...but that shouldn't deter you. The experience is worthwhile because it makes the horrors of apartheid a little bit more concrete.

Could be so much better. This was my second visit to the island, and to be honest, there's nothing there that will tempt me back again.The experience is interesting - once - but the it depends to a very large extent on the character and approach of the guides who are ex-prisoners and friendly people, but who are not professionals either in the fields of guiding or history. That's not their fault, but when they're providing all the content, it's difficult if they're not on form.The visit comprises four parts: the ferry trip to the island; a guided tour of the island by bus and a guided tour of parts of the prison and the trip home.The ferry trip is always fun if you're into boating. There were three ferries of differing age operating the day we went and we were allocated the modern catamaran, which was fast and comfortable.The bus tour of the island is of some interest - but simply comprises a talk about some of the buildings and some information about the people who were confined there including Robert Sobukwe and others before him. During the prison tour you see Nelson Mandela's cell, the exercise yard and a few of the other buildings. I was blown away by my first visit to the island and ended up on a high - blown away by emotion and thankfulness for the person of Nelson Mandela and the people around him.This time, not so much. We felt more that we were part of a large crowd being relieved of their money as quickly as possible. The buildings and displays are dilapidated; the famous quarry abandoned to weeds.But with a little imagination, the island could be transformed into something far more worth experiencing - without turning it into a theme park.Just one example was the shop that you stop at during the bus tour. It reminded me bluntly of cafes in the poorer parts of the third world: there was a choice of about 4 items - a large fridge of bottled water, a couple of packets of chips and some rusks... Good grief! A well stocked shop would make a fortune! The ride home, into a raging southeasterly gale, was fun.

Must do site. We tried three years ago but it was booked up week in advance so this visit we ordered online in advance.At the Cape Town visitor centre signage is terrible and everyone gets a little corralled before embarking. The boat then was a little cramped and 7 miles with African pop music blasting out is a little wearing.On the island it was sunny and windy. You walk to buses for an island tour and the guide was superb - funny, knowledgeable and engaging. The lime mine was especially poignant.After an hour (including a 15 minute stop off) you go to the prison itself to be shown round by one of the former prisoners. His insight was good but a little more content would be nice above and beyond his performance. Mandela's cell is simple and unobtrusive.Then it's back to the boats to be bullied into line by the very bossy Ousie who only had smiles for island inhabitants. Thankfully it was a different boat with a little more room and no music. Some might have liked that as the seas had really picked up!!!Overall this is interesting to do and good value considering the lengthy boat transfers and the hour and a half of guided tours. I would recommend it to anyone - it's not quite the emotion sapping experience that the Ann Frank house in Amsterdam is but it is in that general style

Robben Island Tour. When in Cape Town this is a must see tour well worth the price. To see were Nelson Mandela spent one third of his life in prison there. Our tour was deeply moved by what I saw there. Having prisoner that spent time there telling you their experiences added to the tour.You leave the Island with the knowledge of what it was like there in tough times that South Africa was going thru with the politics of apartheid and all of the problems of all those of all colours who fought for their freedom.There are many books in the book store on the Island to purchase on the history and events that too place during these difficult time in South Africa.DM.WB

A must see. Robben Island is dying. Literally. The plants brought over by Westerners have wrecked havoc on the island's ecosystem. They mention that on the tour. What they don't tell you is the people who tell the story of Robben Island Prison won't be around much longer either. Mandela's generation is going grey. See Robben Island now. Hear stories from people who were imprisoned there. Ignore the tourists and the odd gift shop. Time is running out.

A Revelation. I had no idea as to what to expect when we visited Robben Island, understandably my knowledge of prisons is somewhat limited to those back in the UK, of the ancient kind found in castles etc. What I didn't expect, though, was the degree of emotional involvement that the place engendered. I and my companions and many of the other folks on our tour were deeply moved by what we saw, heard and learned. However, be assured that it is not a somber experience, quite the reverse in fact. The tour guides are knowledgeable, friendly and accommodating - and above all cheerful. They breath life into a place of dread and despondency and in doing so are able to engage you thoroughly with the lives of the men who were incarcerated there - Nelson Mandela in particular of course - and their struggle. You leave Robben Island with a far greater understanding of the politics of apartheid and the courage of those - of all colours - who fought it and prevailed. Btw look out for Christo Brand, Mandela's old prison guard, in the island's bookshop and make sure you leave with a copy of his book 'Doing Time with Mandela', - it's excellent.

a huge disappointment. Easy decision.... don't bother.You see little, are subjected to long monologues about Nelson Mandela, and get ten minutes to run to view his cell before being herded back on to the ferry taking one back and the cost is high.If it is hot and windy, which it was when I went, you risk being sea-sick and getting sunburnt. No restaurants, nothing,,,,, nothing to do. BORING!!!

A Must symbolical trip. The trip did not feel safe nor professional; the boat used to go to the island were not appropriate mainly the Tigger 2 Royale on the way back as there was 10 persons standing, no proper seating in dangerous wavy waters and the crew could not care less. Unfortunately the official boats used were under maintenance. This visit was instructive and emotional with an excellent guide.

not to be missed. We were advised by friends that we were with that we must do this and are so glad that we did. We had the most informative, and articulate guide on the bus, and he was only 25! The ex political prisoner who showed us round the prison was humbling, I was so moved by his experience and so grateful that these men can bring themselves to tell their stories. The boat trip out was fine but coming back was really rough, we got drenched! Even so, definitely a must do.

On most people's bucket list when in Cape Town. We enjoyed our day on Robben Island - and considering we arrived at 10.30 for the 11.00 boat and returned approx 3.30 - you need to alot the best part of a day.Very thorough bus ride around the island - too hot though on a hot day because you're penned in really - but it's still interesting nonetheless.The main event is the 'prisoner tour' and we had a very articulate, animated ex-con who admitted to us that this was his 'therapy', his way of dealing with the mental fall-out of his incarceration.It's a must do I suppose if you have the time. It's a political Alcatraz and a window on the 'pre ANC government' South Africa. Definitely thought provoking.Give some thought to the boat trip. It is a little choppy which is no problem if you are used to travelling on the water but obviously disconcerting (there were a few green faces) for those that aren't. If in doubt take a motion sickness tablet with you.

To long. It takes more than an hour on the boat each way - you drive around the island in a hot bus for an hour (including a useless stop) and then are 35 minutes in the prison. In my opionion to worth the time you have to "invest".

An emotional must do but strange at the same time. This feels like the least touristy attraction I've ever been to. It's a strange place which you can only understand if you visit. The tour itself is really interesting and educational and what makes it so good is that the tour guide is an ex prisoner. So not only are you hearing about how prisoners were treated you hear this persons real story too. The bus trip around the island is very quick but it's fine as to be honest you wouldn't really want to spend ages wandering around. People live on the island including some ex prisoners but it's a very run down desolate looking place. There is a tiny coffee shop but it was out of tea or coffee and was kind of odd. Definitely worth going to as it is fascinating and very humbling.

A humbling but essential day out. The trip across is worth the price alone as you get fantastic views of Cape Town. Be warned that if t is very windy the crossing can be very rough and sickness inducing. If you are prone to seasickness, it would be best to do the first trip of the day when the winds are lighter.The tour of RI is very informative and helps to give a good perspective of what Mandela and his people had to endure. It also helps when you see some of the films about his story.

Modern history. This is absolutely worth a visit if you are interested in modern history. It is a frequent visited place, so get your tickets in time, it might not be able to go the same day. Especially on weekends. Buy the tickets at the red house at the Victoria warf.The boat ride takes about an hour, and it can be waves, so be aware if you suffer from seasickness. The ours takes about 3 hours. and there are several tours per day.

Unforgettable. The bus tour and the tour with the ex-political prisoner were both amazing. It was an amazing lesson regarding the history of Robben Island and always an emotional journey. It is truly something I will never forget.

A very emotional journey. While the bus tour is rather quick and doesn't give one an opportunity to truly explore the island, the personal experiences shared by our guides at the prison were an interesting, personal look into Apartheid-era oppression and imprisonment. This is an experience not to be missed if traveling in South Africa!

Great history lesson!. It's amazing hearing the history and the stories behind the people who fought to end apartheid in South Africa. It also was a great experience to see Nelson Mandela's jail cell. The bus ride felt a little tight however. Make sure you plan this event early in your trip because it's subject to cancellation at anytime due the weather. Also, if you print your voucher online and it gets rescheduled, go to the ticket office first when you arrive so they can reissue you new tickets, as opposed to standing in line to load the ferry just to be told you have to go back and get new tickets printed.

OK, but felt too commercialized.... Having been to other sites around the world which commemorate the struggle of groups of people, I wish the Robben Island experience gave its visitors more. I felt the tour lacked depth and background, while not appealing to the emotions of its visitors. Consistently the tour guides made light of the political situation and made jokes about events that had taken place in S Africa which led to imprisonment. I wish the tour tied together the political environment in S Africa with the actual prison much better than it did.This is not a "must see" in Cape Town.

Rich History, Mediocre Presentation. Robben Island is a must when in Cape Town. The ride to Robben Island is 45 mins+ each way from mainland. Our tour was split into the typical tour boat and a speed boat. Take the speed boat if you have the choice, it'll cut the travel time down at least 15 mins each way and you'll have better seating options. Once you arrive you're bussed around the island only to stop at two prison blocks (one is where Mandela's cell was) and a focal point including a store to make food/drink purchases. The tour is given by an ex-prisoner which I thought was a great touch. Now for the bad, I thought there was sooo much more to the island than what we fit into an hour, I think the tour should've been expanded to allow more walking to sites, more questions and more commentary.

Worth a visit for the history. Boat trip out was great, magnificent views of Cape Town. We were unlucky when we went as was 41 degrees so way to hot. Coaches had no air con, but on normal day good tour I am sure. The talk by a ex political prisoner who was held there gave a good insight to the place. Two suggestions for me was would have been good to see more furniture or props was quite sparse. Just to give a more accurate idea. When tour was finished no guidance where to go and in the heat was a long walk to jetty. If elderly hard walk. Def. worth going though.

An interesting piece of history. This was our second visit to Robben Island and I found it better than the first time. The boat trip was rather choppy so be careful when you travel if you suffer with seasickness. On arrival you board a bus and are given a tour of the Island as it is now and told about what the prisoners would have to do each day. You the have a tour by an ex prisoner. The guide didn't talk much about his experience other than to be factual about how the prison is run, but it was an interesting afternoon and to be recommended. Whilst interesting it did lack something and it could be developed further to become an excellent attraction.

Ok experience, nothing special. We have great interest in history of racial suppression, having been greatly moved by the slave embarkation UNESCO sites in Ghana and in dakar, Senegal. And the Nelson Mandela story is as moving and important as any in the twentieth century. All over South Africa there are museums that brilliantly tell his story. Maybe that's why we were less impressed by this prison tour where the groups were super-large, and the guides, while uniquely qualified as former original prisoners themselves, were hard to hear and understand. The ferry service was pleasant enough going over; poor coming back, even on fairly smooth water because we happened to get put on a smaller, noisy, crowded craft in place of the quiter and faster catamaran we went over on. Could have been a little better organized on the island itself, too. So only three stars, even though the story and lesson are extremely important and valuable.

Could be a lot better attraction. This must do attraction could be a whole lot better. The boat trip from Cape Town is about 45 minutes each way and it can be choppy so if you are not a good sailor best avoided, although they do have sick bags on board. Once on the island you are taken on a tour in a bus with a commentary by an ex prisoner, quite a political talk and not a lot about what life was there. Then you get to the main prison compound and another prisoner takes you round, different political persuasion this time but still didn't learn much about life there or indeed the islands previous use as a hospital. I suppose it is a must do but you will probably learn more in the museum where the tour boats go from.Could be so much better

Refund after they cancelled ny trip. I have been waiting for my refund for over 3 months now since robben island cancelled my tour of 5 people. They keep insisting that they have transferred it but they cannot give me proper proof that I can take to my bank and enquire. I am disappointed. Just hope that your trip doesn't get cancelled or else you might not get your refund.

Educationally enlightening to the human struggle. This is a must see for those that are interested in the history of the prison with a focus on the political prisoners of the apartheid era of South Africa. Not only is Robben Island renown because of Mandela's stay but the history behind the prison on this island was very interesting. The icing on this experience was getting an eyewitness accounting of the day to day experiences from one of the political prisoners of that time. It was about an hour ferry ride from Cape Town with great views from the ferry toward the V & A Waterfront coast line. Great history lessons!

A Moving Experience. I actually went a couple of years back and have visited a number of times as used to live in Cape town this is a most moving experience and where possible you are taken round the Island by ex prisoners. You get a real insite in to the brutalaty and that saddness of what went on here it is really educational and the storys are told from the heart . So worth wile , Highly recommended!
Important historical site. Learned a lot about the political prisoners themselves as well as their lives on the island. A worthwhile experience.

Robben Island. We had a good trip and experienced a part of our own history first hand. The boat ride is good. The tour is very organized and we had a good experience overall. I would like to visit again as it is impossible to take everything in on the first visit. Our tourguide was excellent.

Thought Provoking. This was a very thought provoking visit. Buy your tickets in advance as the boats do get booked up. The trip out in the boat was good for taking phots looking back at Cape Town. The tour on the bus with a very good guide was informative and made one think as to what it would be like to spend many years breaking up stones in the quarry for no good reason. The tour of the jail with a former inmate was quite emotional as he had spent many years in the jail. He now lives on the island and seemed to bear no grudge. Perhaps the UK could learn from this?

Average. The boat ride as ok. Try not to get the really old boat. It is incredibly slow. The tour guides were very knowledgable and likeable. Unfortunately you don't get to spend much time at the prison. It also appears everything has been repainted to make it look a lot nicer. I did not get the feeling of pain and suffering you get at Alcatraz and Fremantle prison where the cells are as they left them.

See, reflect and think.. If in Cape Town, this is a place you must not miss. Go on the first boat out, and buy your tickets in advance, this will save a lot of queuing. The trip out is enjoyable, but reflect on those that were going out for 10/20 years. We were toured round the island by bus with an excellent guide and then given a walking tour through the prison itself by an ex political prisoner. The rooms were bare, and Nelson Madelas cell and garden where there to see. A good talk on the workings of the prison. There were still ex wardens and their families living in the small village, which also had a church. Regretfully, like so many attraction in SA, the lack of funds means that the sites are deteriorating. You must also remember that this Island was used by the British to imprison African Chiefs during the colonial rule. Man's inhumanity to man knows no boundaries.

A great insight into a notorious prison. This is a wonderful trip organised by the Robben Island visitor attraction centre in CapeTown. It's near the clock towers in the Victoria and Albert Dock area. The ferry takes you over to the island, here you are taken round on a bus to visit some of the most important sights when Robben Island was a maximum security prison. The commentary was excellent. A former prisoner gives a very graphic account of life in the prison, you can visit the cell where Nelson Mandela was kept. There's a lot of information about many of the former inmates. It's great value at around £17 for the 3 1/2 hour trip.

Emotional Journey. We had a good trip to the Island and experience an emotional journey of apartheid, reconciliation and forgiveness. We preferred to take the first at 09hrs. Make sure you buy your tickets in advance as they book up quickly, wear comfortable shoes to walk around the island and carry a snack. We paid 35 rand for lousy sandwiches. The boat ride is an hour one way. Beautiful dolphins on the way. Carry something warm because the boat ride can get chilly. Staff were warm and very interactive asking most tour persons their country of origin and went out of their way to make everyone comfortable.

Worth seeing but a total organisational nightmare!. Everyone going to Cape Town must visit Robben Island to fully understand the history of SA. But getting there was a bit of nightmare, especially if you are old or handicapped. You first board one of two boats (a big catamaran or a decrepit old fishing boat which looks like its about to sink!). Everyone rushes to get in and shows no respect for the elderly (we were travelling with my friend's elderly parents). There is no such thing as priority boarding..Once at the island you get shuffled around in a school bus packed with people, you visit some sights like the limestone quarry and the beach where Mandela used to collect seaweed for fertiliser. At most of these attractions you cannot get off, and its hard to see much from the window. Our bus tour guide (of Malay background) was actually very knowledgeable and we learned a lot from him, but upon arriving at the actually prison we were guided by a black African ex-prisioner and no one in our group understood more than 20-30% of what he said in his heavy accent (a real shame as I think a lot of it was quite interesting!). Our tour group was huge, at least 40-50 people (basically everyone who was in the packed school bus), which made it hard to move around and see or hear anything. This group size is way too large! After leaving the prison we had to board the boats again which was a complete nightmare, again no priority boarding and no respect for elderly passengers, everyone just rushing and pushing their way into the boat, so when that was full we were told to walk another 100meters to another boat. My friends' poor parents were about to pass out in the heat and chaos.
