I know Africans are probably not renowned for their organisational skills but come on, you have plenty of paying foreigners visiting the island, put a little 'Western' organisational skills into the operation. I'm still glad I went. It would have been even better with individual audio guides for those who struggle with African english...

Good for Broadening the Mind. We enjoyed our trip to Robben Island but felt it could have been better with a bit more structure. The Guide on the bus was very knowledgeable, as was the (former prisoner) Guide in the prison but there didn't seem to be sufficient structure to the delivery of the information. This left us feeling a bit confused. They were keen to broaden our minds away from the predictable obsession about Nelson Mandela (when so many people were imprisoned here over a long period of time) but, of course, it's Nelson Mandela who was the main attraction as far as we (and other tourists, I guess) were concerned, so they could have made more of his story to encourage visitors to spread the word. The boat trips lasted about 40 minutes in each direction and it was a bit rough on the return journey, as the wind (and tide) was picking up. However, I can only commend the crew of the boat, as they responded so well to the tourists' excitement about seeing a number of whales on our return trip by slowing down and stopping, so we could get close enough to see the beautiful creatures.A worthwhile trip but could be even better.

Organized experience, nice tour. We booked our tickets in advance, as advised, and it was an overall nice experience. The whole process is very organized though we didn't have much "down" time to explore since it's so organized. The boat rides were equally nice, on two different boats. The bus tour was great and our walking tour with a political prisoner was also great. I really loved standing in the courtyard where Nelson Mandela spent much of his time. I'd recommend going here if you have a few days or more in Cape Town (if you only have 1-2 days, you can skip it) but I wish the whole experience was a little shorter.

So mis- managed.. Such an important heritage site but so badly managed. The trip over was fine but the allocation of people to buses was a drawn out affair and the tour guide gave the impression she had been doing it far too long. She was difficult to understand as was the past prisoner tour guide, who spent far too long relaying his experiences of which little was understood. I was hoping there would be far more visual aids and accounts of life on the island. I left feeling I knew little more at the end than when I arrived!Given the importance of the place a total revamp of the presentation and introduction of an audio description would have added so much to what was a totally disappointing afternoon

Very humbling. We had pre-booked our tickets in November for a trip on 13th Feb - we should have known it was doomed! We turned up at the ticket office on spec on 12th Feb to check we could use the printed off tickets. We were told that all trips had been cancelled and was told I'd have been sent an e-mail. Furious was not the word! No apology from the staff and no effort to re-book, completely dis-interested in trying to help us. What if I didn't have access to e-mail? Legged it back to the hotel and to check e-mail - nothing was sent. Then a stressful time trying to re-book on the internet. Another couple in hotel reception faced with same problem although they had been sent an e-mail. Fortunately we managed to re-book but had to juggle our onwards plans that buggered us up to be honest but we really wanted to do the trip. Fortunately when Friday 13th arrived, the weather was awful and we were glad the trip had been cancelled!We arrived the next day to try again. Sunshine and blue skies all around. We ensured we arrived at the ferry terminal in plenty of time. We boarded the Thandi boat, which appeared new and was a quick crossing. The buses were waiting upon arrival and our tour guide was great. The prison tour and guide was fascinating although we wished we had been given time to explore ourselves. It was a very humbling experience and cannot be compared to Alcatraz in any way.The return boat was the same, luckily! The crossing over was so rough, we had to hang on for our lives! The weather was still great so we had great views of Cape Town and Table Mountain.We didn't experience the negative comments raised on here and can only praise the staff, apart from the lack of communication and assistance from the cancelled trip.The whole experience was very humbling and well worth it. A must do in Cape Town.

Go to hear the first hand prisoner stories — otherwise not a good use of your time. Recommended.There are 1,250 former prisoners from Robben Island alive today according to a former prisoner tour guide. Their personal stories are compelling. This tour is worth your time if you want to hear the personal story of the prisoner-tour guide and look forward to the boat ride to Robben Island and back. Otherwise, you're better off contributing to this memorial museum by buying a book about this place (at the tour center in the wharf area downtown) and putting your time to better use.The museum at the wharf-ferry landing presents the chronological history of the island as a leper and penal colony. But visitors not aware of some of this history over the centuries may find this approach lacking. There’s a larger story to be told here. For example, if you visit the Golden Triangle museum in northern Thailand, you’ll learn how the British Empire played the world as a checkerboard manipulating commerce, triggering the opium wars, and the consequential impacts to countries throughout the world to this day.A similar pattern of history needs to be told here about the Dutch and the British colonialists. It isn’t enough they were here and subjugated peoples of color for centuries. The Dutch needed the Cape as a waypoint and trading post to support their settlement in the Dutch East Indies (the Far East). Colored peoples from Indonesia, Bali, China and elsewhere were seized as slaves and shipped in. Surprisingly, most of the slaves over the century were not solely from the African continent. The British had multiple reasons over the centuries for their actions here. The same multi-triangular relationships of exploitation and subjugation from continent to continent evident from the opium wars can be found here. This story is not told effectively. And it should be. Beyond the larger story, and less important overall, the details of this tour don’t offer up the resounding throng of support for the overall theme. The Ferry's are overloaded. The Dias lists consistently with too many tourists aboard. Once you arrive on the island, you're shuttled around on a tour bus. This is good since it's a little too big for the lame and elderly to walk around. The island consists of many one-story, vacant buildings where terrible atrocities were inflicted on prisoners over the past four centuries. But a visit to the island does not impart a sense of value adding to the overall story all of us are aware of to some degree.

Should be better - much better. Disappointed.. When visiting Capetown I expected the Robben Island experience to be a stand out cultural and educational trip, similar to how other major national landmarks showcase particular historical tours. I would compare this expectation to my previous visits to Ellis Island New York, S21/Killing Fields Cambodia, Tower of London or Kilmainham Gaol Dublin. Sadly Robben Island doesn't even come close, which is a huge shame given the story it can tell of very recent times. Plenty already said about the boat trips, yes we queued and were delayed and it's not that short - about 40 minutes to make the crossing each way. The first half of the trip is on a standard bus, not open top. It stops at some landmarks where stories are told of their significance. After about 40 mins the bus arrives at a tuck shop/toilet area with good views across the bay to Capetown and Table Mountain. You're then brought to the prison and met by a guide who is an ex inmate. We were brought, at a decent pace, through some main areas of the prison and received broad explanations of each areas function coupled with some stories and brief history of inmates and prison life/circumstances. We queued in single file to walk past the Mandella cell, which is the only cell that contains any items to suggest what conditions were really like. This was followed by a sit down in a large communal cell for more stories before our 'walk to freedom' from the prison back to the dock, where our boat was delayed. I've no doubt that Robben Island will continue to be a major Capetown attraction and rightly so. However this trip lacks education, interaction and organisation. It could and should be an awful lot better. I hope that in years to come that Robben Island receives the funding required to transform it into the attraction that it deserves to be. It has a huge responsibility to tell an extremely important story that at the moment just isn't there.Disappointing.

Robben Island. This has been on our list of places to visit for a long time. We booked an early trip (8.00 am ferry) and set off. We were met and loaded onto a bus for our trip around the island. Our guide was excellent, very informative and very articulate. I was disappointed that we only left the bus once during the trip, i.e. we couldnt stop and explore. At the end of the trip we went to the prison itself where we were introduced to an ex prisoner who told us about his experience. He had been imprisoned for 25 years for terrorism charges - in his case he had been on a demonstration against the government. This was utterly chilling - to think you could be incacerated for so long for actually not doing very much. We then toured the prison and saw Nelson Mandela's cell, the yard where he worked with other prisoners etc. I was disappointed that I didn't feel more emotion. Everyone knows about Robben Island and its history but it all seemed too sanitised. A great shame - I feel that if it had been left more as it originally was, dirt, warts and all it would have had more impact. I am glad I visited but left feeling something was missing. We returned on a different boat in fairly stormy water - I don't think I have ever been so frightened. We were in the open on the top deck, I was too frightened to go down the steps to go inside so hung on for dear life all the way back - bruises to show for it too!!

Totally worth your time. Is a Robben Island trip worth your time? I'd say, yes. Of course, there are problems getting there and back and the inevitable waits here and there. Should you go? Absolutely! Make the time and get their early. The trip over gives you a sense of the isolation of the place. As you wander around and listen to the tour guides, take in the energy of this place with its hard life, rock piles of useless work, and visit the cells of prisoners. Regardless of the other kerfuffles of the trip, it is a life experience you don't want to pass by.
Mind boggling. A real sence of thing that happened! A short exciting ride by boat. Followed by a coach journey around the island. Fantastic tour guide that showed you the sights.

Appalling Management - avoid. A disappointment of note. Old slow boats that apparently get lost in the mist. No facilities on the island. Shockingly useless tour guides. Whoever is running this operation should be fired plus the staff. They need a private operator to lift it from a third world disaster to the decent level of all the other tourist attractions in Cape Town. A beautiful place is Cape Town. Robben Islands is a shocker though.

put this LAST on your list of things to see in CPT.. i'm so happy this was not something we originally intended to see during our visit to cape town. we happened to have a few hours to kill and happened to be at the V&A waterfront. it was a few minutes before the last tour at 3pm, so we decided to buy tickets for the tour. the tickets were sold out, but a european man approached us asking if we wanted to buy his pre-paid tix as he could no longer go on the tour. i paid him half price for the tix, and we got on the boat. the boat ride there was fine. the tour itself was ridiculously stupid. you are crammed onto buses with 50-60 people where you are lectured to and forced to fight over looking out of the windows of the buses. you cannot get off the bus to walk around until the very end, when you see mandela's prison cell for all of 3.5 minutes. the boat ride back was miserably long as the waters were choppy and the boat we took back went twice as slow as the boat we took there.all in all, i'm glad we paid half price, and if you are pressed for time during your stay in CPT, do NOT do this tour.

Grateful to have been here. I had read the Road to Freedom (Nelson Mandela's biography) and watched similar movies, before our South African trip--so to see it come to life was a very special experience. I appreciated that the bus tour guide and the prison tour guide both had been political prisoners themselves, so the tour felt more personal. I felt the explanations and amount of time spent were just right in each location. I was only disappointed not to see the prisoner-visitor location. I do wish we had more time to visit the shop or get something to drink. The boat rides were on time and enjoyable. I felt it was organized and worth the price and I'm glad we had this experience at the start of our two week trip.

Could have been so much better !. I missed the opportunity to visit Robben Island the last time in Cape Town so ensured I had sufficient time to visit this time. It's a shame that I had to title my review "could have been so much better" but that is the reality of what happened. When we arrived at the ferry dock in Cape Town it is was very crowded with long lines of people. We were concerned to see everyone making there way on to what looked like a very run down ferry boat that had definitely seen better days and were genuinely concerned to see how crowded it was becoming. It's only a short journey out to the island but it's still a wide open bit of water with a sizeable swell. We were relieved that when it came our turn to board we were re directed to a Catamaran on the right side of the dock. So, my advice immediately is to hang back and get on this boat. It was much newer, better and seemed much safer. They also played modern music on the way out which was nice. What was not in the plan was the sightings of numerous southern right whales which were still in the waters, they should have gone in December. This was excellent. On arrival at the dock on Robben Island we were directed to a bus which spent the next half an hour driving around the Island. The girl on the bus pointed out interesting sites on the tour. Again given the hoarders of people that clearly visit the island the bus could have been better. We eventually got off and were met by an ex inmate of the institution who then took us in to a room in the max security prison and gave us a talk. It was very interesting to hear his side of what happened just a few years ago and I wondered why he would ever want to spend his days here given all the terrible things he must have witnessed. Some people might have struggled with his accent but we were fine and it was all very moving and I am pleased to say no attempts were made to sanitise events. We were then shown the cell Mr. Mandela was detained in and the obligatory photos were taken as we walked past it. Then that was it, shown out the side and our " short walk to freedom" back to the dock ! I learned from my trip out on the catamaran and did the reverse, held back and waited until the hoarders got on the old boat then calmly boarded the lovely catamaran for the trip back where we were again blessed with the sites of the beautiful whales. Again the catamaran skipper manoeuvred himself into a position so we could all clearly see them with two actually passing under the boat !In summary they could definitely look to invest in better transportation to and on the Island but definitely worth the time........if you get the timing on to the boats right : )

Embarrassing!. Being what it is, this should be the most well organized tourist outing in SA - wrong! My family and I booked a trip last Friday 20th Feb to depart at 13h00 and return at 16h00. We eventually departed at 14h10 in a boat hired from a local operator as the original boats are "broken" according to an employee at the departure jetty. Our tour guides were extremely long winded with many repeat comments - it was all about them and not the history behind this most incredible place. One of our family members was in a wheelchair - this was a rather challenging situation for us as the mobility lift in the bus was "broken".Our return journey arrived back at the main jetty at 18h20.......... (2h20min late!)The system as it stands today is indeed "broken" and needs a very urgent revamp. It is not a cheap outing and was an extremely disappointing experience. The rest of our trip to Cape Town was absolutely brilliant so all you folk involved with the Robben Island experience, get your act sorted because you are not doing your fellow Capetonians any justice! Trevor Hunter UK

But needs to be improved. catamaran boat left on time, good time crossing, buses ready, guide on bus VERY good, informative, but I felt so much more could be explained and seen!Prisoner guide a waste, his accent so strong most people could not understand him and his talk (lecture) was way too long. We ended up running for the boat back, no time to explore, see shop, or bathroom. This is still a must but it could be so much better, but with sell outs the norm, I suspect they have no motive. I hate comparing places, but the Alcatraz tour 20 years ago was better, , hopefully with the historical significance of Robben island more will done.

Great idea, poorly executed. Although I am rating this as poor, there would be no man or woman in their right mind who could say based on a review I'll miss where Nelson Mandela was housed/kept for all those years.The boat ride over was fine, a little rough however added to the attraction, seeing penguins and seals on the way put in perspective just how cold the water is. The tour started on a rusty bus where an ex-prisoner introduced himself to a bus of 50-55 people without a P.A. system meaning most if not all the group didn't hear a thing. The tour then started by the ex-prisoner locking the group in a cell where-by once again speaking at the group without the use of a P.A. system. After 45minutes the group was allowed to leave the cell and the ex-prisoner continued with "his tour". One visit in enough.

very touching, a must see.... The trip will take have a day to take this into consideration if you have limited time in Cape Town Pre-booking is essential and will save a lot of your time and effort.The ferry trip was quite enjoyable and even at your arrival the rustic non totally modern buses made the experience more real. It was very emotional to have had a former inmate as our tour guide and having him showing us where he slept and was held. Also to see the former guard of Nelson Mandela was quite interesting.It is amazing that with such history South Africa today is not inside a civil war with no end and that Nelson Mandela could taught sense to everyone even tough he was inside robben island. The thought that Nelson Mandela could come out of that environment a whole and inspirational human being is a miracle. The whole South African story post apartheid is a MIRACLE.This is A MUST SEE place to visit if you are in Cape-town.

Interesting experience. Wow how they treated people was insane, was great to see it in person. I wouldnt want to have been a prisoner there, at least we were free to leave, the history is eye opening. well worth the tour about 4 hours in length, make sure you book in advance as they sell out very quickly.

Well worth it but once is enough. We have lived here for 9 years and finally made the trip with visitors who really wanted to see Robben Island. I agree with the advice that pre-booking is essential and it does take a half day. Our trip was scheduled at 0900 and as is almost usual... one ferry was out of service. Take a jacket as the ride can be windy.Once we left the ferry we were shown to large buses where we first drove around the outer part of the island. Our guide was both articulate and very funny. I wish I could remember his surname but it began with an "S". The philosophy that is conveyed is that of acceptance and tolerance and is well scripted. Seeing the living conditions is very sobering. I think it is important to remember that prisons throughout Europe in those days were equally cruel and to not make it all about race and color. Still to think that Nelson Mandela could come out of that environment a whole and inspirational human being is a miracle.The guide on the bus had a microphone but the guard in the prison did not... if you are hard of hearing stick close to him.

Disappointing. Could be so much better. This tour was 4 hours in length from the time you leave CT until you return. The old ship we took to the island (I think it was the Dias, took 50 mins, with a sleek catamaran getting there much quicker - but it was full). This meant we were late, missed the buses and did the foot tour first. Although it is great to meet an old inmate there was a little too much talking and not enough walking in a large group of about 40 people. HIs accent was very strong and my children understood nothing. This would have been much better as an audio tour, taken at your own pace. The bus tour was , I am afraid, a waste of time, and felt like an excuse to take you to the cafe where you disembark, for 15 mins , with nothing to do except buy a drink ! This tour could be so much better with such history to be told. We came away thinking it was tired, resting on its laurels (it is clearly something everyone does when they visit) and needs a complete overhaul. One of the things we were looking forward to most, but the thing we were most disappointed with on our visit of CT

A memorable experience!. The boat trip was enjoyable although the boarding experience was not the best. The views back to Cape Town were excellent. Once there we had an informative tour around the island and then visited the prison. A former prisoner took us round and related his experiences. My admiration for Nelson Mandela increased even more when I saw the conditions he had to live and work in.the groups are large and it is not always easy to hear the commentary but the place does speak for itself. I shall never forget the courtyard where the prisoners worked and the small cells they had to survive in.

Fri 13th - unlucky for us, all boats cancelled. We'd booked tickets two months in advance to go to Robben Island, saving it for our last day in Cape Town and expecting it to be the highlight of our trip.However, on arriving at the Waterfront departure centre at 8am, we found out that all boats had been cancelled that day. This was really disappointing, but even more so was the complete lack of effort by the staff to inform us of this (we only found out by overhearing the disgruntled conversations of other passengers), and at no point were we offered an apology or an explanation (beyond some mutterings about a problem with a jetty). A real shame as we would have loved to have seen the island.

Booking. Not the most pleasant experience and there are only two morning boat times 9 a.m. and 11 a.m.Unfortunately, we were unable to make the trip as the rather larger ship that we were in had to wait for a pilot to come out of the mist to guide us into Cape Town Harbour. They did not rush to do this so many of us were unable to make the 9 a.m. boat and there was no refund or transfer to the later boat. Tickets were between £12 and £13 each.Had to rate this to submit it as it would have been zero but obviously the trip was not terrible as we never made it. Heard, though that the island is larger than expected. The trip takes at least 3.5 to 4 hours, I believe.

Beautiful in a Sober Way. Tips:- Definitely book ahead of time, as there is a set number of ferries and passengers allowed per day. - There is no point following the guide step by step to be at the front of the group, as you never know where he would end up standing to talk. - the sea can be rough with wind, but the scenery on deck is worth a trip outside. You can see Robben Island on one end, Cape Town in the other direction.

Very informative. A boat trip of one hour each way. Once on the island you get a short coach trip around showing you the island followed by a very informative talk from an ex-inmate of the prison. You will need around 4.5 hours for this trip and need to be there 30 minutes before your departure time.

Wonderful Experience. What a privalige to be able to visit Robben Island and walk in the footsteps of Nelson Mandala. The boat trip out to and back to the island is really quite good with lots of opportunity to see the wonderful coast line of Cape Town. You can really get a feel for the conditions and what went on in the prison and i think it is an accolade to the government of SA to maintain this memorial.

great experience. I had a great emotional experience visiting the place where Mr. Nelson Mandela and many other "political terrorists" (as they used to call them) where imprisoned just because they were black and fighting for their freedom. I was really emotionally moved. Saw the small cells with small windows with iron bars and no view except a high wall...so, not even the view was allowed to those people imprisoned just because of the colour of their skin...and all for what? I think there's no answer to this, except for the crazyness of certain humans....I think that visiting this place is an experience everybody must go through in order to learn respect for all human beings living on this world

Jsut the name is history. To go there is easy from the harbour in Cape Town and the cost is OK.Well whn you´re there they drive You around in a bus at first and then you have to go uin to the prison where Nelson Mandela sat for 18 years. The cell was not very big and the things that were in there was dreadful. 4 Blankets a small table a cup and a small so called toilette that were changed every 3 Days- awfull.

Not sure about this experience! Disapointing.. We went because we felt we had to, but it was a little bit of a disappointment. We felt "let down". The boat over had limited seating, and some were forced to stand the whole way. On arrival we were immediately dispatched to our bus. The guide was good and had a lovely sense of humour. But we were only allowed one stop on the tour of the Island where we could get out of the bus. It would have been nice to have visited, say, one of the two churches or one of the other "sights" .We left the bus at the Maximum Security Prison, where a former political prisoner gave us a talk in one of the Community Cells. That was good. Then we were sent to B Block where Nelson M was kept. Briefly saw his cell and the exercise yard. Then out and back to the boat. We didn't have the time to breathe in the atmosphere. It was "in, round and out" before we could remember where we were and why we were here. Disappointing!

A Lesson in Humility. To see where Nelson Mandela and his associates were imprisoned was a humbling and motivating experience. The small cell he stayed in and the treatment he received would have broken my spirit and made me a bitter human being. The fact that Mr. Mandela did not allow that to happen to him, makes me admire him all the more.Go see it. It's worth it.

Robben Island - a must if visiting Cape Town. The trip to Robben Island was one of the top things on my list to do in Cape Town and it was well worth it. Tickets have to be purchased in advance and it is but I went to the ticket office and got a ticket for a visit two days later - so book early. If booking by the internet make sure you book the correct dates - two couples in the boat queue I was in had made mistakes with their bookings on-line and weren't allowed on the tour.The crossing is amazing with some lovely sights back towards Cape Town and not too far for anyone who is not a great sailor!The tour was very well organised, as is everything in Cape Town, and on arrival on the island you are met and seated on coaches for a tour of the Island before entering the prison. This meant you got to see the lime quarry where Nelson Mandela and the other political prisoners were put to work every day. The tour guides are very knowledgeable and are ex-prisoners so they are able to talk to you about their experiences and how the prison was actually run. Parts of it I found very humbling and emotional, and not the enjoyable experience you might get from other tours, but it was very educational and so worthwhile. I came away amazed at just how much people had endured, how strong they all must have been and the big part women played during apartheid. Very inspiring and a must if in Cape Town.
waste of time. Nothing to see really, a good book is better you will know more about robbin island, the boat, the staff, the guides nobody cares, just a money making attraction...
History. Its an Island and it used to be a prison. It was left as is so it looks a bit run down. But thats what its about. Noting fancy but good to see.

robben island. Personally, I think it is a waste of time. Nothing wrong with the guides or the ferry. The bus journey on the island is quite tedious and hot and you really don't get to see much or get the real feel of how the prison used to be. Do the trip if you are desperate to but there are much better ways to spend your time in cape time in my opinion. Watch a video on robben island or something instead.

Not a 'review' per se.... It's difficult to 'review', as you would a restaurant or bar, this experience, because it is not one that is necessarily meant to be enjoyable, more informative, and eye-opening. This place, I suppose like Alcatraz or any other prison, holds a wealth of history and fascination and represents so much of the repression of apartheid. It's quite overwhelming to see Nelson Mandela's cell, as it is to see the identical cells of so many of the other prisoners - so many of them forced onto the island just for having certain ideas.I knew a certain amount before I went - what I didn't know was how freely people speak of a dark time that was only a few decades ago - nor did I know that people live on Robben Island, and some of these people include ex-political prisoners, as well as guards, all living together on one island, which is a very touching fact. And how proud most people of South Africa seem to be to have overcome this time in their history. On the trip, I found myself moaning that they had packed too many people on to the boat and bus that take you there and around, I certainly stopped when I got to the island on a blazing hot day and saw the concrete yard where prisoners took their walks, saw the meal allocations which were divided by colour, and heard the reasons some of the people where thrown onto this island in the first place - and seeing the pile of rocks of which Mandela placed the first one, at a reunion in the quarry where they were forced to work, followed by others until a large pile of stones was formed, symbolizing unification for all colours and people.

Trip to Island fab. The trip by boat over to the island was fabulous .I found the Island itself and the jail and cell where Mandela lived boring.It is difficult to give an opinion that may put people off going as the trip may appeal to others .The boat over and the trip around the Island was great .The Sea was quite rough but that was fun,lots of seals and if you are lucky you may see a shark .

very interesting /well organised trip to Robben Isalnd. This was top on my list to do while in Cape Town , well organised as usual for everything in Cape town .. the boat ride was pleasant from V & A to Robben island , there were tour buses with excellent tour guide awaiting to take us through the Island . Our Tour Guide , Tama , was excellent , i have learnt alot through the tour and to gain insight of the struggle through apartheid in South Africa and all the great political (prisoners) to name a few Robert Sobuke , Mr Nelson Mandela for their belief & struggles for justice & human rights during apartheid.an truly worthwhile tour that is educational .. it cost 280R which is truly economical .one of many amazing sights that Cape Town has to offer.

It hasn't got any better. As a Capetonian I know this should be an iconic Cape Town attraction. However, the best part is the ferry ride, as long as the weather is good. That's if the ferry is operating, as it often breaks down and then ancient boats are used, including one named after the wife of the one-time apartheid government minister Jimmy Kruger, who after the murder in detention of Steve Biko infamously remarked, "It leaves me cold". The island tour is badly organised and should be so much better - ex-prisoners do not tour guides make. The place is perpetually in the local news for incompetent management. I always advise overseas visitors that the penguins at Boulders Beach are far more interesting to see.

My History is powerful. Absolutely a place to visit if you are a tourist and would like to see and understand how far our country has come. if you are a citizen you should definately go see how our Tata struggle for our country.

SAD. I am very glad that other visitors had good experiences here. We took foreign visitors & was very embarrased. No explanation of what the procedure was, no welcome on boat. No safety brief. Bus on island broke & no assistance for wheelchair visitor. This was after we had to walk, whilst other visitors were taken by bus, as they had no more buses available. Being Robben Island it was great to hear & see the history.

Takes one back 20+ years. A worth while visit if you are interested in the days of apartheid and you get more appreciation of what Nelson Mandela did. Good to get first hand info from the guides which were Ex prisoners.

Robben Island – Synecdoche for South Africa. A visit to "The Island" can be chaotic, especially in December when it's really crowded and the weather (wind) can be awful. However, it's one of Cape Town's "must dos" and worth braving the elements and the booking and ferry boarding system (it is run by former political prisoners who might not be best at organisation). If you can afford to spare the extra about R1,000 (US$100) for a private guide (all ex prisoners) and tour, otherwise you have to go with the crowds in school-type buses and get less than a real experience. This will be an incredibly moving experience, the history of the island encapsulating so much of South African history. But without your own guide you won't get much of it.The ferry takes from 40 mins to an hour each way, weather depending and also if the main high-speed boat is working or not (if it is not and it is busy season, maybe give it a miss as it could then take half the day and cause some anxiety).

A real disappointment. I visited Robben Island for the first time 10 years ago (or it may have been longer) and was extremeley impressed. There was a very informative audio in the ferry terminal prior to the departure. The ferry was clean and efficient (particularly the new one). The staff were attentive and the guides were excellent. We have since visited on numerous occasions with our clients and every trip is more disappointing than the last. The staff are abrupt and slap dash, the auditorium at the ferry terminal closed about 6 years ago because the projector broke, the ferry - well its a gamble what type of boat you will get. Our last trip we got a slow sailing catamaran and the trip took over an hour and a half longer than normal which then wrecked havoc with the rest of the days plans. They rush you through the prison, the guides have lost their finesse and are clearly tired of the job. - such a shame as it is such an important part of our history.

Historical? Don't think so!. I arrived at the island to experience the "Mandela magic", but was sadly disappointed. The tour was a one-sided political view, and the prison cell is not historical correct. If you Google "Mandela prison cell" you will see photos of Mandela in a completely different cell. The current cell shows a blanket on the floor, a bucket and a small table with a plate on. In real life, on photos where Mandela is actually on the photo, there is a bed, desk, bookcase full of books, curtains, a large framed photo of Winnie on the bookcase. The experience on Robben Island is a sad distortion of history.
Worth it. Been three times. Great experience. Go in the day time for less rough waters and a beautiful view of the city. Loved it!
Highlight of our trip. One of the best parts of Capetown. The boat ride and bus tour of the island were both pretty while the tour guide provided and intimate experience.

Historic moment. Its only a short boat ride away from the pier and we got tickets just 10 min before departure. It's not like visiting Alcatraz with the exciting stories, but a very quiet tour with alot of explanation as to what happened. The guides in the prison are ex prisoners which makes the stories even more interesting.Definitely worth the time spent.

A moving yet uplifting reminder of a dark past. My third visit to Robben Island. On each occasion I am humbled by the dignity displayed by the tour guides - all former political prisoners.It might seem strange to put a forme prison on a list of top tourist sights but by visiting Robben Island you can get a glimpse of a dark past bur also sense the real optimism that there is to transforming this wonderful country.You need to book well ahead in peak season and the trip is very orchestrated - it has to be to cope with the numbers. Boat trip, bus tour (stop at the small cafe/shop), walk round the prison (with a photo stop at Mandela's cell, then back on the boat. However it really is a great experience, made even more compelling by the fact that your guide was a prisoner here.At some time in the future the guides will not be former prisoners so go while you have the chance to hear from someone who was there.

Worth the Visit. My husband was not interested in going but he enjoyed it as much as me. It was really interesting and we are happy we went. It makes you appreciate the prisoners that fought for their rights, and the people that came to their need . How Nelson Mandala lived for so many years and came out of it kind, holding no resentment is astonishing after you see how they lived.The only thing you have to be careful of is which vessel you get on for your crossing. We got a little ferry going which took an hour but came back on a shipping boat which took about 45 minutes but you sat or stood where ever.

Very Moving.... This was a very interesting trip to the island ,they were very keen to tell the whole story, which was very interesting, told by one of the old prisoners.. the trip on the boat over was very pleasant ,providing different views of Cape Town ..

Very Rushed. I was there a few years ago and i had an amazing experience however since then because it has become so commercialised, the experience is quick and rushed now to accommodate more tours through the island, its a great place but its an expensive little trip to be rushed through.

Robben Island tour. This is a must do if in Cape Town, history and nostalgia can bring a lump to your throat. You cannot pick your ex prisoner guide but I found mine extremely difficult to understand.
Enjoyed our trip, average. it was nice trip n the fairy however I felt that the tour was far too long and lacked personalization, however still an enjoyable day trip out

Duped and swindled. Our trip came at the close of the tourist season but the boat but the government department responsible for visits to the island and overbooked the visit. The boat was crowded. The bus was overcrowded. Opportunities to take photos and savour the historical significance of the site were severed by the rush and clamour of visitors competing for an opportunitiy.What is worse, however, is the sense one gets that the government department is using the island and tourist interest in it as a propaganda opportunity. The tour guides, despite their charm were not well informed and incapable of contextualizing the site. My general sense of the visit was that tourists felt underwhelmed and as if they were being taken for fools.

A Cape Town "Top Five". Everyone's experience here will be a little bit different, in part because one of the interpreters will be one of a number of former prisoners and each has their own story to relate. Each story will have its own power and its own meaning to the visitor. But I don't think most visitors can help but be moved. If you want to learn more history and perspective on South Africa's transition, this is a must-see. Keep in mind the boat journey can be 30-60 minutes in the South Atlantic so be prepared if you suffer from motion sickness. At a minimum, sit outside the boat and focus on a horizon. There is so much to see that should not be a challenge; the views of the City Bowl and Table Mountain alone are worth the effort. Bring a windbreaker--even in summer!Purchase tickets in advance at the Robben Island web site. For 30 rand, the souvenir photo is optional but a good deal--and I don't usually go for these sorts of pictures.

Brilliant and educational. As my daughter had recently discussed Nelson Mandela and his effect on South Africa at her school, it seemed only logical to visit Robben Island while we were in Cape Town. Seeing the cell he spent so many years in while a former prisoner, who was our guide for the tour, explained the daily routine of prison life under apartheid. It was a real eye opener, as was the positive outlook the guide had on the future for South Africa. A must see if you're in Cape Town.

An emotional experience. If you are visiting Cape Town, this is a must see. Much of the country's history lies on this island. The tour starts with a 40 minute boat ride out to the island - if the weather is good it will be a pleasant one, you get to see panaromic views of table mountain. We even saw seals swimming and frolicking around in the ocean. Upon docking at Robben Islanf you board a bus that takes you up to the prison precint for the first half of the tour. There you will meet a tour guide, one of the former political prisoners on the island. He will give you a first hand account of what life was like as an inmate. You go through the living area, the recreational area and finally the cells - you will get to see the late and great Nelson Mandela's cell - a very moving experience. You then board the bus again and do a tour of the rest of the island, which is just as interesting and informative, before heading back to the mainland.

The best educational exihibition of the recent south african past. In fact not eager to see an old prison , I took the trip nontheless because my friends adhad edvised me to visit Robben Island. I'm happy that I did : it is the best educational exhibition of the recent history of South Africaunder the Apartheid regime.The guide we had , told about his own experience of the seven years that he was held there. It was a revelation to hear that he had forgiven the old regime. The whole trip was for me an important revelation of the exeptional wisdom and positive power of Mandela and all the others who had suffered here. I really hope that the black politicians of South Africa will keep Mandela's not take race as a guideline to govern this country in the way the white minority did in the past.

A mut visit. You are taken by boat to and from the island, on arrival at Robin Island you are taken on a tour of the island by bus, this is broken halfway by a visit to a small cafe and shop.After the bus tour you are taken around the prison by an ex inmate. the tour is fascinating and well worth while.On the return to the boat there is a gift shop.

A must see in Cape Town. Sometimes fabulous or amazing aren't the right words, certainly not for Robben Island. If there was one place I wanted to see on my first visit ever to Cape Town it was just Robben Island for it's history. It was very special to actually get there!Being guided by an ex political convict gives an extra dimension in itself. He was full of humor, could tell how life used to be - from his own experience.I am truly happy I had this chance. The boat trip was very nice too, calm sea and sunchine. What a day!

Long Day. Did not rate this experience very highly I think because there has been so much on TV about Nelson Mandela and also the film about his life nothing came as a surprise. I also think I was biased because we had been to the hospital where Christian Barnard did the first heart transplant. This was a very well run museum and tour and in comparison this your only had pictures around the place telling the story. It was a pity because it has taken us 10 years to actually manage to do the tour.

A must do trip but leaves you a little empty. I would highly recommend this trip to anyone who is remotely interested in South Africa's history. The boat ride itself is lovely and we saw seals and a pod of dolphins. The tour comprises of a 45 minutes bus tour of the island with a few stops along the way. A guide talks you through the areas where guards lived, the quarry etc. this is really good and gives you a good insight to what happened on the island other than Nelson Mandela being imprisoned there.After the bus tour you are dropped at the prison for a walking tour. There you are greeted by a ex inmate who talks about his story and takes you on a tour of the prison which includes Nelsons garden and cell. This was really good but very sad at this same time and I left felling I had learned so much but sad that history had been so cruel. Anyway as I said in my first line would defiantly recommend.

A must see before you leave SA. An absolute must to see, and get a feeling how prisoners have been treated during apartheid. An emotional experience, not only to see where famous men has spend so many years, but also to read the stories from other political prisoners.Very interesting and hart breaking stories told by an ex-prisoner.

A 'must do' for everyone visiting Cape Town. Go and re-live the experiences of Nelson Mandela and his colleagues. You can stand in his cell and really imagine what it would be like to be incarcerated for so many years.

emotional journey. Visit to this island where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for long years is mainly an emotional journey.Ferry from the waterfront takes about 35 minutes and then there is a guided tour of the island in bus and on foot.One sees the queries where prisoners were made to work and the cells where they were kept.The guide to the prison was a onetime prisoner.One has to go with a particular mindset to see a historical place and not really for enjoyment.

Interesting. Was really looking forward to this from a long time before I visited Cape Town. Tour guides were pleasant and knowledgable and I was really surprised to see an ex political prisoner of the island to be one of the guides, who better than someone who's been there to give tours of the jail. The only thing I could fault the tour company on is the day we were going, we left the harbour, went a few hundred meters out to sea and floated there for about 20 minutes. It transpired that there was steering troubles with the boat.While they did organise another boat to take us to the island, there was no communication to passengers on board at all as to what was going on. We were all left completely in the dark.

It is a pity. There is no doubt that Robben Island and its former inmates hold an important position in modern history, it is such a shame that the tour was not better organised and informative. There is so much to see on the island but it seems that what you see is somewhat dependant on the guide. The obvious high point is Nelson Mandela's cell, but we felt we were rushed through, with very little time to take it in. Be warned the ferry trip took an hour in each direction, and due to the weather a number of passengers were sick on the way back.

Could do a lot lot better!. Glad we did the trip but the experience could have been far better. They overbooked our ferry so we had a walk to get to the charter boat. No real information was provided. Ferry crossing out to the island was good, with stunning views of Cape Town from the ocean. Our prison tour had around 60 folk on it - far too many for one guide. We didn't get the full sense of history here. The guide on the tour was far better. For a top listed must do Cape Town experience this needs to be improved.

Unmissable. As with a lot of people this was top of my list of places I wanted to visit in cape town and it really didn't disappoint. The boat ride over was freeezing so if you're going in sept as we were then I'd recommend taking a jacket. Once we were off the boat we were greeted by a guide who took us on a driven tour of the island to see where the prisoners worked in the lime quarry, robert sobukwe's house where he was kept in isolation, the guards houses and even some penguins. Once we reached the prison we met our tour guide, Kgotso Ntsoelengoe, one of the most fascinating men I've ever had the fortune to meet. He met us in front of the famous photo of robben island prisoners the day they were released and pointed to one of the smiling faces that was quite clearly his. Kgosto shared many stories with us throughout the tour, about the very first meal they had on release (kfc) , the political debates they would have every night, the guards who helped them get information from the outside - I could have listened to this ex-political prisoner talk all day. The most important thing to remember here is that in 40 or less years those visiting robben island will not have the same experience that we were lucky enough to have as these prisoners that spent their time here, with mandela and others will not be alive to share their stories first hand.Without ruining the rest of the tour for you I'd encourage everyone visiting cape town to make this trip, it's an experience I'll never forget.

Long walk to freedom experience . A wonderful trip visiting Robben Island. The boat trip over was calm. However the trip back was very choppy. The trip round the island was interesting and informative. A real history lesson...not too much info but just enough. Walking round the prison was good & an eye opener. Our guide round the prison was an ex-inmate who was informative, but we did struggle to sometimes understand him. The only down side was by the time we got back to the harbour to catch the boat back, there was no time to visit the souvenir shop on the island. Well worth finding out about this little bit of history.

A really good experience. lovely ferry ride, educational bus ride by local person, amazing to follow in footsteps of such a great man, prison tour eerie, so interesting but sad and horrifying. Something everyone should see.

Magnificent. This trip was truly an eye opener for us all. I will never forget this visit as it showed just how cruel people can be to each other because of the colour of your skin. The prisoners in our country moan, well they want to try it Robben island style. These boys had it hard and still bares the scars and you can almost hear the echo's of the prisoners it held. very emotional trip and the guide know every inch of the prison and know its secrets.

An icon that you shouldn't miss if you are in Cape Town. It is very educational and historic tour. The ferry ride to and fro the island was easy and comfortable. But be careful sometimes you might encounter a rough sea. So for those who have motion sickness, you might want to prepare some pills. I was ok on my trips :) The guide on the bus was very informative and cracked jokes here and there to lighten this "heavy" tour as you all know what Robben Island was once used for: a prison. I did enjoyed my 45 minute bus ride with the guide explaination. The prison tour is very interesting as well, especially with the explanation and stories from a former prisoner here. Feel sad hearing how those prisoners were being treated, from their rationed food, deprived freedom to read and write etc. Highly recommended. Get your ticket online to avoid the queue and choose the time you like. Don't miss this tour!

Be patient and bask in history. I've heard some people complaining about how unorganized the experience is however, we were a group of 12 individuals from 4 different continents and shared the same view. "It was worth it". Before we boarded the Diaz, which looks like an old fishing trawler, one of the staff at the gate explained to us that it is actually the same boat that was used to take prisoners to the island. Once on the island you guided to a bus with a very informative guide. Very good! The prison tour was also brilliant and the guide was an ex-prisoner who was extremely knowledgeable.

Beautiful boat trip and island, but sad story. I have visited Robben Island several times, and have seen most of the island, of course including the guiding inside the prison area.The island is beautiful, and has a nice view back on Cape Town.The guides, who are former prisoners, are showing the visitors around while telling the awful story about how the prisoners kept there were treated.

Disappointed . Robben Island This was supposed to be one important site in SA history. The facilities were very well maintained. But the tour was such a letdown – people working in the front line are great, it's the management of the tour that was disappointing.  Getting the tickets and the ferry ride were easy and uneventful. Once we landed on the island, we were put into a bus and stayed as a group until the end of the 2-part tour. There were more than 50 members in our group, including some young children. The large size made it impossible for everyone to hear our tour guide, except on the bus with the PA. Every stop we have to wait until everyone showed up, which made the tour more about waiting than learning history. Also, it was especially disappointing that some people in the group exhibited a severe lack of manner and have the unfortunate tendency of not following instructions given by the tour guides. At the end of the tour we were notified that our scheduled ferry was canceled and the replacement would come later. 45mins passed, a fishing trawler turned into refugee boat docked at the pier, everyone behind me frantically pushed onboard. This old noisy thing was also much slower than the other regular catamaran ferries, so we arrived back in Cape Town much later than we expected.

A must see. Tickets must be purchased in advance, so some planning is required. Both boats were full but when we arrived on the island we were split up in three groups so it didn't feel that crowded. The guides (one for the bus tour of the island and one for the tour inside the actual prison) were all ex-inmates and made the whole experience very emotional. This is something you do not want to miss.
A bit hard going. The trip out and back were pretty good as was the one around the island but the prison visit was pretty hard going.

Disappointing……….. I wish we hadn't bothered to do this trip, I was advised by the lady at our hotels tour desk that it was totally disorganised, but we had already booked the tickets on the internet.We were in the queue before 10.30 for the 11am crossing, there were so many people in front of us and behind us. You have to go through security, but they only screen the bags, then you walk through a scanner the alarm was going off like mad, but no one was ever checked, so I don't think they take security very seriously.The ferry we went on was like an old trawler, there was far too many people on it, no where to sit down, and if your up on deck your told that the life jackets are down stairs! It took over an hour to get to the island, we were herded on to buses for a tour of the Island, our guide was Kent and he was the only good thing of the whole trip. Then we were to have a tour of the prison but the group was so big and the guide had such a weak voice we couldn't hear what he was saying. Then because of the worsening sea conditions we were told that there were going to be no more crossing that day and we had to be at the ferry by 2pm, all the groups were all rushing around it was chaos. I was determined not to go on the trawler again so went on the catermeran but we got soaked, again because there were too many people. Sorry Robben Island you need to get your act together and be more organised. I would say just look round the museum, I wish I had!!

Take in some history. It's one thing to watch movies about the apartheid in South Africa and what happened. But it's another to actually be on the ground and take in the sights in person. Walking in those cells and learning about it all was truly amazing. I recommend this to any traveller

Robben Island's Checkered Past. After the boat ride to the Island, you are in the hands of former in-mates who try to recreate for the tourists the sense of isolation and despair that prevailed on this barren limestone rock 14km from the port of Cape Town. It wasn't hard ! In addition, the longer history of the island is explained going back to the 1600s (leprosy colony et al ) as well as the more well known recent incarceration of Mandela. Worth pre-booking tickets and picking a calm day for the trip. Good value and a real insight into a recent pivotal moment in the history of SA

Very disappointing experience. I visited Robben Island with a family group in January. It was my third visit to the island and on previous occasions had a terrific and uplifting experience. The island was clearly overbooked and different groups arrived in the same area at the same time creating noise, making it practically impossible to hear the guide and very difficult to see some of the exhibits. It felt rushed and chaotic. There were not enough buses for the amount of visitors and we did the walking tour of the prison first and the bus tour afterwards - the tour makes much less sense in this order and I would advise anyone to refuse if asked to follow the tour in this manner. The journey back to the mainland was nothing short of horrific in a tiny catamaran and not the usual comfortable ferry. Our children were physically sick and adults were screaming in terror. The crew were not trained to deal with such conditions. It felt like a miracle to get back to dry land. We discovered afterwards that the usual ferry was out of action and that they were chartering smaller vessels to ferry visitors to the island. The best part of the day was the taxi ride back to the hotel.

Robben Island South Africa. Very disappointing how this attraction doesn't live up to expectations. First visit was 3 years ago and felt that I would not go back but had visitor from USA who wanted to see historical site. In summary, boat (old one) took 1 hour 15 minutes to get there. Prepaid ticket for 1:00PM departure left at 1:55 PM. Its a first come first to board even with a specific time. Tour very disorganized and tour guides not fluent English speakers and hard to understand. Why do you want to go there? Because of Mandela and very little is said about him. Bus tour of island not much better. Guide spoke mostly about the improvements made since end of apartheid but very little on Mandela except for the quarry. Every time guide started to speak bus stopped so he could be heard. It's a shame how something so historical and internationally know can be so disappointing. Only good thing about going there is the fantastic view of Table Mountain and Cape Town otherwise your not missing much by not going there. Read Mandela's book and you get more about Robben Island than you do from the tour.
S Africa 2015. It is an iconic trip and must be one once. However we were herded like cattle and found it very difficult to hear and understand our guide. Glad we went, but would not do it again.

Humbling. An absolute must, book early to avoid disappointment, our hotel booked our tour, high season places can go fairly quickly and the Island is effected by weather and sea states, too choppy and your trip will be cancelled, but this is what the Robben Island experience is all about, very well oiled and set up for every eventuality, the website explains all. We were fortunate to have the wonderful Tilani as our guide, who as a younger man was incarcerated on the island whilst the great man was there, he brought the whole experience to life, talking and showing our party through the prison's main area's including the cell Nelson Mandela spent a large proportion of his life, we finished the guided tour with Tilani, humbled by his experience and the experiences of all who served time on the island, what struck me about Tilani was his absolute forgiveness of the past, as he said Nelson Mandela taught us to have eyes only for the future. Once finished with Tilani, we had a guided tour by coach, seeing parts of the island the prison warders and their families lived, again our guide, a much younger gentleman, was just insightful with his knowledge of the island, he allowed us to envisage life as an islander and left my wife and I with a life long memory. It was a truly humbling experience.

Beautiful Ferry Ride and Interesting History. The Ferry takes about an hour to get to the island. There are seals and dolphins to keep you occupied. As well as the beautiful Table Mountain Cape Town Landscape. You then get a bus tour that talks about the history of the island. The prison is left to be discussed by a previous inmate. Very informative. You get to see Nelson Mandela's prison cell and the quarry where he worked for 8 hours a day.

A must. The trip to Robben Island is by boat, it is peaceful and enjoyable. Once you arrive to the island everything changes. It is a place full of history, shocking to visit but really important to "feel" waht South Africans have been through. You can also visit former prisioner and later President Mandela's prison cell.

A must if you're in Cape Town. This place is has so much history. It was worth every penny. I find our guide, Mr. Sparks, very informative and answered any questions a traveler might have. I booked the ticket in advance for the 11 am trip. Make sure you arrive about 15 minutes ahead. Bring some water and a light snack. You don't need to print out the ticket as long as you have a PDF of the barcode as they will scan it when you board. After the tour you can have a meal at one of the many restaurants at the waterfront.
A must go place. Make sure you book that's a must. A very humbling expirience the ex political prisoners chat was wonderful a triumph of the human spirit .

A great experience for 30min...but it took me 5h30 hours to have it. Yes, it's very interesting to visit the inside of the prision with an ex-prisioner. That part of the tour was amazing.But everything was badly organized: we booked early for the 15h00 tour, they requested ou presence 30min before the scheduled departed time, and we were there at 14h30 only to wait in the line for 40min an then another 10min outside in the sun. So the 15h00 tour arrived to the island at 16h30.Then our ticket back said 18h00, but our tour ended at 18h15, and we had to wait again in the sun for the boat, that arrived at 18h45, an then we waited for 15min more on the boat, for a small group that was on a private tour, so we were back in Cape Town after 20h. So, it took us almost twice the time they stated on their site, and that fact ruined some plans we had made based on the time they told us the tour would take.

Very interesting. Well worth a visit for the history, our guide was very informative, our time was cut short and we didn't get to see a lot of the island. The boat trip over was nice but coming back it was a bit rough but still enjoyable.

The place where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned.. If you visit Cape Town then you must visit Robben Island. There is a boat service to get you there and once there, then you are taken on a tour which includes visiting the quarry, cells and courtyard where Mandela and other prominent members of the ANC were imprisoned. A guide takes you around and he was an ex-inmate.These places are a monument to injustice and the perserverance of the human spirit. Nelson Mandela is a true deserving hero to the majority of fair minded South Aficans. Viva Mandiba!

Must see. Robben Island is a must-do while you are in Cape Town. Book early but don't be surprised if your trip gets delayed - ours was for 2 hours. Refunds are available if thjis turns out to be inconvenient.The trip takes the best part of half a day. The tour was fascinating and really engaging for all ages.Thoroughly enjoyable and must-do!

A little disappointing!. Visited in 2003 & was very moved & impressed. Was keen for my wife to share the experience with me on this occasion. Island well preserved. Our former prisoner spoke too fast, & did not give us a great insight on daily life in the prison. Mandela's cell not shown so no opportunity for photos. Boat needs to be upgraded as a number of visitors got wet when sea got choppy. Package needs refreshing given the Island's iconic status.

A most thought provoking and humbling visit. The boat from Cape Town takes you out to the island and you get done great views of the city and mountains from the sea. At your arrival you are loaded into a bus and transported round the using to understand its history not just as a prison but a military base and leper colony. Our guide was excellent and imparted insight into not just the island but the struggle and strength of those who were imprisoned there. We were shown round the jail by an ex-political prisoner who was a measured and informative guide with a quiet presence that both impressed and humbled me. The starkness of the confinement of the people who shaped South Africa really provokes your mind.

A life experience.. Robben Island is a historical site that is a must see for anyone with compassion and a desire to understand the past to shape the future. Ths trip on the boat is suitable and the crew are helpful. Arrival at the island is prompt and the tour is excellent, well explained , sensitive and informative. I really am pleased that I did this, it gave me an insight into the history of South africa and humanity. Nelson Mandela is an icon of truth and justice. The modern World should look to these tragic sites and learn lessons of emapthy. A truly worthwhile and well organised visit to an emotive site .

Must do. Loved this tour. Our ex prisoner guide was really interesting and brought the experience to life. Downside was it was a bit disorganised. The trawler that takes you out was the boat that took the prisoners out. Don't think they told us this. The boat seemed overloaded and the handrail near me was in poor condition. I wondered if it would fail if sufficient force was applied. Coming back we were luck to go on a Cat as the fishing boat was full. It's much faster and overtook the boat which left before us. Buses on the island are very old but again original. Tour Guide didn't seem to recognise that two buses to the prison would not fit in one. Bit of a wait and some uncertainty later we did get our island tour. All that said this is a high impact tour and should not be missed.

A must-do half-day trip when in Cape Town. If you are at all sensitive to the country's history you have to take the boat trip to see where Nelson Mandela was emprisonned for 27 years and get a feel for is greatness. The tour-guides are also former prisoners which adds to this very emmotional and moving visit. Cost is around 20€ but history is priceless :)

Moving. We booked on-line to ensure the first trip out on a Sunday morning. Even though seas were calm the swell is still quite something! The tour of the island was well run and informative but the high point is of course visiting the cell blocks and especially Nelson Mandela's cell. It inspired me to read his book and watch the movie. You would need a very thick skin not to be moved by this visit and to think deeply about that discredited regime and system.

Very Moving. the boat ride was nice as the sea was carm great views as you went. the tour its self was very informative and interesting. it was also very moving at time as you heard it from a the stories of what it was like from and ex prisoner. I felt very honoured to be hearing it. the tour as a whole was good in the prison but the bus tour felt a bit rushed and a bit on time limit so didn't get time to take it all in.I really enjoyed my time here.

Amazing place, but so, so, tour. Having actually met Nelson Mandela, and having followed his struggle over the years, I was so excited to finally see Roben Island. Sadly, the tour was rather mundane and uninspiring, even though our guide was an ex-prisoner. I think more audio/visual aids should be incorporated into the program to give more of an immersive experience.The boat ride from the V&A waterfront was beautiful and the view of Capetown from the island is spectacular - almost worth the trip, on its own.

A real must-see. I wasn't too sure what to expect from this tour but it was really interesting. Half of it is spent touring the island by bus and the other half is spent exploring the prison where Nelson Mandela was kept. This part of the tour is led by former prisoners, which is a nice touch. I particularly enjoyed the bus tour of the island - it's a lot bigger than you think and our guide, Llewelyn, was very knowledgeable about its history. I was shocked to learn about Robert Sobukwe - until the tour, I'm ashamed to say I had never heard of him but can't quite understand why his name isn't as well known as Mandela's. It deserves to be. Would recommend sea-sickness tablets for the 45min boat ride to the island though as the water is notoriously choppy!

A VICTIM OF ITS OWN SUCCESS?. I last visited Robben Island ten years ago and it was amazing. Interesting, moving and very thought-provoking.This time, a friend told me in advance that the island is now so busy that everyone is herded around the island so fast as the company tries to accommodate as many people as possible. He was right. It was really disappointing. The highlights of my first trip were totally missed out on this occasion (a visit to the dining room and kitchens, for instance). There was no time to ponder and reflect on each area you visited as you were rushed through to another room/onto the bus again.Teaching people about Apartheid is so important, but it's now run it like a business, rather than a museum (I fully appreciate they have to make money, but at the detriment of their purpose?) I was half expecting to exit through a gift shop selling cuddly toys and pencil sharpeners. That may come yet. Such a shame.

Belligerent Confrontational Disrespect Sarcastic Crew Member. We were excited to visit the world renowned and iconic Robben Island, we had travelled a great distance and were looking to an unforgettable adventure, however our experience was marred by a belligerent and aggressive crew member who addressed us in the most sarcastic and cutting manner.At one stage of the ferry trip he approached us and demanded that we leave the top deck as we had broken one of the ferry's rules, without giving us a opportunity to explain ourselves, he called us liars and children. We demanded that he give us his name as his conduct was reprehensible, malign and completely out of line. He confronted us in front of other ferry guests and proceeded to dismiss our attempts to settle the dispute amicably. It is disheartening that an experience of this nature can so easily be poisoned by the conduct of one disrespectful individual. His approach was unacceptable and will tarnish the memory of this experience for us forever. He should be held accountable for his actions!

Very, very disappointing. I can't deny the emotional impact of what we felt was a 'must do' trip, but it seems the organisers are doing their best to diminish the whole experience, not least in taking an hour longer than the advertised 3.5 hours. Ticket sale money certainly doesn't appear to be going into maintaining transport and facilities.We took advice from Trip Advisor, booked tickets in advance and arrived fairly early, and waited, and waited. Got almost to the front of the queue as they loaded the fast boat but couldn't get on. Maybe lucky - it was raining quite heavily and people clearly didn't want to sit outside on the boat, so it looked as if there were many standing inside. They must then have realised they'd need another boat, so the first one went off and we waited some more before getting the antiquated, slow and somewhat uncomfortable 'Susan Kruger' over half an hour late. At least we had seats inside.On the island we were herded into cramped and ancient buses for the first part of the tour. This was NOT led by ex-political prisoners, as advertised, though the young man did a fairly good job if you could hear him; many clearly couldn't. Seating in the bus meant it was difficult to see out properly or take photographs unless you were by a window. Then we were given a totally inadequate break for bathrooms and coffee, both with long queues. Luckily it had stopped raining by this time.The prison tour was lead by an ex-prisoner but with too large a group so, again, sometimes difficult to hear. This was, of course, the highlight of the tour and it was done fairly well.Then back onto the Susan Kruger for the slow trip back. Good views of Cape Town and Table Mountain as it was sunny by now, but no outside seating and no facilities on the boat (except pretty poor bathrooms).

A must do half day tour. At 280 Rand for about 3.5 hours this tour is excellent value. Make sure to book online before visiting Cape Town as there are a limited number of tickets available as you are restricted by the number of boats to ferry people back and forth from the island. It also saves queuing. Below are the highlights of the tour:- Checkin at the waterfront museum and then 45min ferry across to the island with great views of the waterfront and Table Mountain- Transfer to a tour bus for a short drive past the main block then to the compound and story of Robert Sobukwe. - Next to the lime quarry and finally a quick stop for 10 mins to grab a snack.The guide on the bus is very informative and conveys the sad stories with emotion but does not let the mood get too gloomy with interjections of some lighter moments. - You are then dropped at the main prison where you are guided by an ex inmate who gave a very informative tour describing the conditions and you will get to see the cell used by Nelson Mandela. You are then left to walk back to the ferry port for the journey back to the waterfront. For me it was important to understand a bit more about the apartheid era and it was quite sobering at times but I would still highly recommend it.

Thought provoking. We took the catamaran from the robben island museum jetty. It takes an hour to get to the island and on the way out we saw a mother whale with her baby along with dolphins leaping by the catamaran, quite idyllic given where we were going. The tour commences with a bus tour around the island giving information on the history of the island and a visit to the quarry where Nelson Mandela and the other inmates laboured. It is a quiet place and if places hold memories then robben island is one. The second part of the tour is in the prison itself and our guide was a former inmates who had been held there for 7 years. The tour was certainly thought provoking and heartbreaking. Very very worthwhile doing, this was a museum born out of the need to show what had happened but to demonstrate reconciliation is forgiveness is critical for the country to move on.

A must see - but heart wrenching. This is one of those experiences that I am absolutely glad that I went, but once is enough - and I would not ever return. A very emotional experience.The 20 minute ferry ride over to the island and back was quite lovely - provided you are fortunate enough to get a seat topside, in the open air. The rest of the passengers below deck are all crammed together like a herd of cattle. I know. I was one of them on the return trip! But very doable.Once you arrive on the island, the is quite a bit of walking, even though most of the tour is done by bus. So walking to where you catch the buses - again, herd of cattle, first come first serve - is quite a distance. Then the return walk back to the ferry. The bus driver (some are former prisoners) takes you on a general tour of the island, pointing out and identifying various buildings and significant places of importance. With so many people packed on each of the many buses, the only way you can interact with the driver is to get a seat as close as possible to him. Which I managed to do. Not much stopping, so photo ops must be prepared for. Have your camera ready to go at all times. They do have one stop - bathroom/Snack food/smoke break. This is also where, if one is lucky, the famous little penguins are frolicking at the waters edge. Beautiful.The walking portion is also as a large group. Again, if you really are interested, stay as close to the guide as possible - without being rude or thoughtless of others in the process :). Touring the various prison quarter areas. It is at this part of the tour that the group, rank and file, walks by Nelson Mandela's prison cell. Fortunately for me, I was able to interact with our guide. He is a former prisoner of the island and was very open and honest with the information that he responded with, in response to our questions.Very glad that I went, but for reasons not mentioned (specifics not shared, so I don't ruin it for those yet to go) - I will not be returning. Still highly recommended.

Must Do!. This is a must do for anyone visiting Cape Town. The tours are very well organized and well worth the time and cost.I would suggest purchasing tickets ahead of time. Also on the boat trip if you sit on the top deck when it is windy, you might get a little spray so be prepared. Not terrible but a little surprising.Very educational and an eye opening experience.

Very Well Organised. First tip, book online in advance, second tip, get there early! This can then secure you get a seat on the boat on the way over. Even in the warmest weathers the boat trip can be a little chilly, so take something warm!Have a camera ready for when you arrive.The trip is a couple of hours, and is very informative, you get told so much about the history of the Island, which we found very interesting.Overall the trip is very well organised and informative. Enjoy!

Very disappointed
Our trip was cancelled on the 16th of December and I am still waiting for my refund. we received an email the day before we were due on our trip to say they didn't have any boats, so we could either reschedule or cancel the booking. As we were only in Cape Town for 5 days we had to cancel as the next booking was only available in January.
