I have contacted Robben Island travel and they say they have paid the money back but it is now more than a month and the money is still not in my account . After speaking to family and friends from the Cape they all say this tour operator is not working, so I would suggest do not even bother. Go up table mountain instead take a paraglide off signal hill what an awesome experience.

What an Experience. I have been to the Robben Island before but this trip was of difference since President Mandela is no more. The feeling of hate and anger on what the oppressors deprive the country and the world 27 years of Mandela's magic. However the consolation was that maybe we had to go through this to achieve the freedom and the little success we had. Well RSA government for the upgrade and facelift you have done on the "Prison". The tour was superb, though I felt a bit constraint in the prison "lol" wondered how the prisoners survived in that communal prison....
Robben Island. The boat/ferry ride was long and sickening. It takes an hour from Cape town. A beautiful island with an interesting history and amazing views.

Not worth the time. I was looking forward to this trip however it was long and to be honest unless you are a Mandela fanatic - the entire trip was a waste of time. The money charged is not going to the upkeep of the island, the buses and the overall experience. The entire trip needs to be redesigned to make it more interesting to visitors. Everyone said budget on 3 - 4 hours as the organisers do not keep to schedule. You have to spend the majority of the experience in a very old bus and spend say 30 minutes on foot.Huge disappointment.

Such a waste. Every one knows about the story of Mandela. This was an opportunity to show the world the evil of apartheid and all that lead up to it and the eventual overthrow. Not a sausage....... I believe the people who run this prison should take a trip to Alcatraz and see how to do a story correctly. To say I was disappointed would be an understatement. We arrived and could have walked to the prison instead of going by bus for 400 meters and then get shown the entrance hall,a cell block and Mandela cell. No pictures no real explanation of the harshness of what happened to the black south African . No time lines ,no pictures, no real commentary . In fact it had nothing. We could not explore and were herded in and herded out. Do not waste your time in paying for a ticket. Very disappointed!

A thought provoking visit everyone should make. The crossing to the island can be a little choppy, but is worth suffering to reach the island. We were struck by how close this former prison was to a well populated area.I spent more time on a coach than I expected on the island, but our guide was extremely informative and helped give some useful background.The tour of the actual prison was led by a former inmate, who provided first-hand experience of the actual activities within the rooms.Overall it is a visit which makes you think and puts you at the centre of recent history. It provides a lesson that no visitor to Cape Town should avoid.

A must, but the experiance is worse each time. We have been on the Robben Island trip a number of times with visitors from around the world. The initial visit was the best, where you were allowed to stroll up to the prison and do the guided tour before the bus ride around the island. Now days it a rush from start to finish. You will need to book ahead to guarantee a place, and that is if the boats run. We booked one day, but had to reschedule due to the boat being repaired. The trip out to the island by boat is worth the visit as you see the wonderful views of Cape Town and Table Mountain, Bloubergstrand Beach etc. Along with encountering some of the local sea creatures, we saw penguins, seals and dolphins. The visit to the Prison is interesting, with your guide generally being an ex "political prisoner". Each appears to have his or her own opinion of the island, with different accounts each time we have visited. The best account is still Mandela's book so if read this you get a better view. It was humbling to see the cell and the stone cairn at the quarry, which reminds you of hardship the prisoners endured. although it can be said that it was not the worst of it's kind in the world at that time.The bus tour is rushed and the guide appears recite a well practiced narrative as you speed along. A lot of the early history of the island is "skipped" to focus on the "prison years", which is disappointing. As most things over the years the island has been left to deteriorate and many parts are in need of some maintenance and repair.Robben Island is worth the visit, but the expense and rushed nature of the tour dose not do it justice. It appears to have become just another commercial tourist attraction, rather than to preserve a part of South Africa's history.

Must-see site, more historical background would be appreciated. We considered a visit to Robben Island a must-do on our first trip to Cape Town. We purchased tickets in advance online as we understand they often sell out. The tours are conducted in fairly large groups on the island, first via bus and then on foot through the cells. Both of our tour guides were quite knowledgeable and did a good job of providing information to so many people. However, we would have appreciated more historical information to provide context for our visit – the guides seemed to assume everyone was well-versed in South African history. The tour of the prison cells, led by a former prisoner, was incredibly moving.
Good views. Worth a visit but you are herded around with very little time to look at everything. Views across the bay are great.

truly disappointing. I had been warned by Cape Tonians not to bother with the tour but I felt it was an important part of Cape Town's History. I truly wish I had listened to them. The boat ride over was glorious with stunning views back over to Table Mountain. Once at the island we were jammed packed onto buses. The rows were 3 across so if you were in the middle there was absolutely no way to see out the windows. Each stop was a mere minutes before we were hurtled onto the next one. There was no opportunity to take photos or to have a really good look at each site.Once at the prison, the enormous group was mustered through with no time to read the displays, or to take in the importance of what happened here. There were information boards in each cell but there was no time to stop and read. The guide himself was interesting.When the tour of the prison was finished we were told to rush back to the boat and ushered up to make sure we didn't daudle. There is a musem and gift shop, with masses amount of informaiton, books and video footage but we were not even able to enter inside.This is a symbol for the fight against apartheid and I felt that the way we were herded like cattle was an insult to that symbol. I would recommend reading Long Walk to Freedom and give the tour a miss.

Great experience, learned south from my guide. Humbling experience, a must see when coming to Cape Town. Our guide did a great job explaining the history of the prison and the experiences of all types of prisoners

Could be good.... The island itself is worth a visit, it is interesting to see (think Alcatraz). However, the expedited boat to a bus to a guided walk through does not do it justice; and I felt more like cattle than a tourist. I could have skipped the bus tour and just read more (the 1 minute allocation was not enough) in the cell areas. They also seem to not be able to keep up with the demand. They had 3 boats (one normal and two charter), of very different levels of quality. They shoved more people on the big boat I was on than could sit, and diesel smell and loud noise made me nauseous. I was sitting on a piece of equipment, and ripped my shorts on a bolt. I am glad I went, but it is overpriced and not pleasant.

Memorable. I had been to Cape Town on business a few times but had never made the trip to Robben Island. This time I went with my family. The sea was calm and the weather was good. This was a fantastic tour. We were fortunate in that we had two political prisoners as our guides. It really brought to mind the horror of apartheid and how brave the people were to fight it. It seems unbelievable that the apartheid system could have lasted so long. I was left with a number of feelings. I realised how lucky I am and I wondered whether we do enough to fight injustice in this world.

Must see experience. If you want to do this tour book before you arrive as it can get fully booked. Unfortunately they don't really seem geared up for the demand; they were using 2 boats for each booking slot when we went which meant a 45 minute delay and the boat we were on should really be retired!I agree with many of the other comments about how the trip could be improved, but at the end of the day it is still a "must do" experience in my view. It is not often you get the chance to see history from your own lifetime and having an ex prisoner as your guide brings it to life.

Dreadful trip. I would not recommend this trip. The company is still unbelievably disorganised and badly run. Besides the boat trip (if the boats are running) which is worth the view. The island is desolate, wind-swept and boasts the prison (the same as any other prison for that matter) and a quarry. Nothing interesting really. The tales of the prisoners are well, meek and mild compared to some other prisons around the world and certainly the prisoners there were treated extremely well, compared to prisoners in Communist jails. I mention communist as most of the prisoners at the time were and still are communists.
A memorable visit. Read what to expect before boarding ferry.Still had a wow factor thanks to the guides.Return crossing was interesting as the wind had increased!

Lack of Freedom - Ironic for a Prison Tour. Visited last week with a party of 34 friends. We waited for the 2pm ferry which was running late, so we're left packed in a waiting hall with no air-con in 30 degree heat.The boat trip over was pleasant enough although they boat was overcrowded so left nowhere to sit.Once on the island we were told we had to board coach (overcrowded & standing room only) to go round the island. We decided we weren't up for that and made our way on foot to the prison. (Which I don't think amused the guide) At the prison we had a former prisoner as a guide who toured us round & his account of what went on have an authentic feeling to the tour.Downsides of prison:- dormitories & cells are stripped of any furniture- no access to sports area, reception area- no access to solitary block- felt a little hurriedBoat back was hilarious as we sat at the front of the catamaran & got well & truly soaked.

left feeling disappointed.... Having been advised to purchase tickets for the Robben Island tour well in advance (months), I expected this to be a highlight of our CT visit, but unfortunately I was left feeling quite disappointed. Once we arrived on the island, we were herded onto buses for the tour around the island. Try to be one of the first onto a bus as these are filled to the max, therefore if you are not sitting at the window, it can be challenging to take good pics. The bus tour lasts approx 1hr, with 2 stops. These are quite brief (10 mins) and visitors herded back on the buses again. Following the bus tour, visitors are taken on a walking tour of one of the buildings. Former prisoners make this for an authentic experience, however the tour can lack professionalism. If not at the front (of the bus/walking tour) it can be challenging to hear. Again, the walking tour is quite timed. The guide's parting words are not to straggle and watch penguins on the way out, as many visitors miss boat back to CT. On the way back to the boat, there are quite a few display boards and gift shop, but given the guide's words and the tanoid call of waiting boats, I felt quite hurried to depart. I had no time for either and left feeling that I had not truly gleaned insight into this important element of SA history. However, I am also left wondering...if one arrives early enough in the day on the island, is it possible to take one's time at the end of the tour and take a later boat back to CT?

Historically interesting but a little rushed. The ferry trip took about 30mins and was very pretty and quite calm when we went.There seemed to be a little disorganization with the different bus tours but the tour itself had a knowledgable guide and was quite comfortable.The tour of the maximum security section was run by a former inmate which is a big plus, but it seems like there were too many people per tour group and unless you stay up with the guide you may miss some of the information. It felt a little too touristy and some of the emotional depths of the trip were lost because of it.The guide did have lots of useful information, was easy to understand and gave the tour an added edge since they were former inmates.It's worth doing for the historical perspective, but perhaps it can be skipped if you don't have much time in Cape Town.

An exciting and a bit touching attraction. The trip takes between 25-30 minutes from cape town waterfront to robben island, when we arrived at robben island we went on a guided tour and we were taught about the history of robben island. The history was a bit touching more specially when we were taught about how the prisoners were treated. From the guided tour around robben island we were taken straight to the prison cells or rooms and we were delighted to see late Mandela's prison room. The place is a must visit place more specially if you like history.

An absolute must if you can. I can't say that I totally enjoyed the entire experience. There were some moments when our guide (an ex-political prisoner himself) was explaining what had happened at the prison on Robben Island that were humbling and others that were just plain uncomfortable. However, the tour was informative and moving from start to finish - something you just have to be there to fully appreciate. The guide on the bus that took us round the island was excellent as well. And the journeys to and from the island on the Susan Kruger went quickly and easily. A faultless experience from start to finish and one that I am so glad I have been lucky enough to have.

A moving experience. From the moment you step off the boat on Robben Island you get a sense of the history and hardship of the place. It's still eerily barren and although 200 people reside on the island, it doesn't seem like somewhere you would want to live. The trip to the quarry with the pile of stones, started by Mandela himself, was incredibly moving and visiting his cell makes you realise even more, what an incredibly forgiving and amazing man he was. We had a former political prisoner giving us a very animated and interesting talk. I have family living all their lives in Cape Town and they'd never been on this trip so they also thoroughly enjoyed it. A must visit if you get the opportunity.

A visit won't do more than a good read.. The island has more history than the island itself currently boasts so one would do better finding information online rather than the pricey trip to the island. But it does have some breathtaking views of Cape Town. Don't expect anyone on the island to know more than the past fifty years of robben island. And don't expect insight into anything. As far as an important part of sa goes the island is under utilized and under showcased. I believe it's more of a tourist trap - there's better, more informative, things to do. D6 and Jewish musuem in the east of the city is well worth it.

A dreadfully unprofessional tour. What a waste. They could make so much more of the place and its history. The tour guide could not speak English well, was very slow, and was repetitive. No decent facilities at all. Old buses. No organization. Just a very poor very badly run operation. Even the boats used are decrepit slow and even get lost getting there. A pathetic impression of incompetence for our Australian visitors.

Smaller groups and guided walking tours around the island would be nice. Worth the trip (if you're South African I'd even say it's required), but I was disappointed by the way the tours are conducted though not by the overall experience or the importance and significance of the museum. Book in advance! Ferry rides to and from the island are pleasant on fine summer days though the ride took much longer than I expected (over an hour). On arrival, you're immediately ushered to the buses, leaving no time to study the info boards. If you think you can do that on the way back, think again. Tours are rushed and even then ours was 45-60 minutes behind schedule. The buses aren't designed for sight-seeing and photographic opportunities are awkward if not altogether non-existent. The tour guide, however, was concise and engaging. The information on conservation and the fauna and flora was good and I was surprised to see what look like reindeer on the island (they're actually fallow deer). While most people come to view the prison and Nelson Mandela's cell, the museum might consider hosting guided walks for small groups around the rest of the island which has a surprisingly interesting history apart from the Apartheid years. Breaking the tours up into smaller groups in general is a good idea, though given the budget woes of the museum and its poor management I can see how this is currently impractical. Our prison tour guide, a former political prisoner on the island between 1977 and 1982, was awesome and inspiring. He was passionate about sharing his experiences during incarceration despite the unjust circumstances and also eager to share with everyone the wisdom he and others gained. Although unclear at times, his enthusiasm was undeniable and I appreciated this aspect of the tour most.

WOW. we were lucky to get the tickets because it fully booked until the 16 of JAnuary 2015.We were through to check in system and to the boat,kids were offered life jackets and off we go.Its was a liitle misty so we didnt have a clear view but when we approached Robben Island it was clearing up.When we got there we were separated in groups and each group had a tour guide.During the tour of the prison one could help it but tears rolled down thinking of what the old man and his fellow comrades had to go through during their stay in prison.Once the prison tour was finished we taken in a bus to show us around the robben island and we were off to cape town again.One thing i didnt like about our ferry is that the boat was leaking oil and smoking heavily and when we ask the captain he said he doesnt know.

Madiba History. Book in advance - you won't be able to arrive and go one the day most days be ause this is a popular attraction. The boat trip across to the island is pleasant offering stunning views of Cape Town and Table mountain from the ocean. The tour of the island is informative, busses are comfy, theres a stop and get off point half way so you can buy drinks, eats and use the loo. The tour of the prison has improved since I was last there 11 years ago. They include a bit of humour to make it more interesting and stop the exasperated cries of 'OMG thats awful' from the tourists. I mean, lets face it....it was a prison for what the then government deemed to be the most dangerous criminals, of course it was awful, its prison. The prison tour felt rushed, I could have spend a little more time taking it all in. All in all very informative. Great family outing.

Very moving. Firstly I must say, be prepared for a bad crossing - our way there was smooth, but coming back felt like a filmset with very rough seas and high winds. Saying that, and from someone who gets rather bad motion sickness, the journey was totally worth it. A well-organised operation from start to finish. Our bus ride around the island was with the most knowledgeable guide ever - I've no idea how he keeps so many dates in his head! He knew everything, and even bantered with the irritating kids at the front! Then being shown around the prison by a former inmate is one of the most humbling experiences I have ever had. Seeing and hearing what so many went through, to fight for the rights of so many more. Just incredible. You couldn't make it up. Spine-tinglingly good for those who want to learn and experience true African and political history.

Touristic must in Cape Town. Site of Nelson Mandela's incarceration. Tour begins & ends with a very pleasant 1/2 boat ride from the clocktower area on the Victoria & Albert waterfront. Tickets are best bought in advance. Last 4 hours, which includes 3 hours on the island. Begins with a very well narrated bus tour around the island & includes a snack/rest room stop. Bus tour is followed by a tour of the prison itself. Prison tour is conducted by an ex-prisoner & includes visit to Mandel's actual cell. Makes Mandela's leadership after release all the more impressive. There is of course gift store at the harbor in case you need a souvenir T-shirt or base-ball type hat with Mandela's prison number, 466/64, emblazoned on the front.

Book ahead but definitely go. Make sure you book ahead as it was very busy although this was January. Fantastic experience - great boat trip across the bay - look out for dolphins, seals, penguins and sunfish (we saw all four) and then a really interesting and, at times, moving tour of the island, led by two wonderful guides, one of whom had been a prisoner on the island for seven years. Great value for money and a very well-organised operation. Everyone who visits Cape Town should go.

Must do but the tour could be better. Obviously a critical part of South Africa's history and important for the first time toorist to do but I felt the tour was very rushed with too much time spent moving with a large group. They need a better way to tell the full story to large groups The museum aspect was not up to par. Don't get me wrong, the portion with the former prisoner is strong story telling but even that lacked some of the emotion that this place can conjur up. In my opinion.I also would have enjoyed going out to the lighthouse.Again, must do but it could be better.

A unique perspective on Cape Town and South Africa. The prisoners who lead the tours make it a unique experience. Ours told his story and our group was enthralled. Purchase your tickets well in advance and early in your trip; some days are cancelled due to high winds. Your trip to Cape Town is incomplete without a visit to the island.

Only if you have time. I am glad that we spent a good amount of time in Cape Town and did not spend a whole day doing this above other things. The boat trip is slow to get out there and then you're shuttled around on a bus around the island. A random stop at a place for bathrooms and to get drinks/food which is not necessary and just makes them more money. The tour of the prison by the ex-prisoner is interesting, but did not last very long for the amount of time spent on the island. Then getting off is a fiasco. There is NO organization and eople just pushing trying to get out of the brutal sun and back on the boat. The ride back was late and took over 1 hour which meant we spend from 10:30 - 3 for only a 30 minute tour from the ex-prisoner. Not worth it in my opinion.

Very Moving Tour. Our guide for the prison tour really brought this visit to life with his personal description of life as a prisoner on the island during the aparteid years. Very moving and really made you think about the power of forgiveness as a politcal tool.Very worthwhile - remember to book ahead.

A step into history. Our guide on the island was a political prisoner held here for 7 years. He was able to share his personal experiences along with the facts about the history of the island and prison. It was very informative. I wish they had post cards with some of the highlights as we couldn't get many pictures. The amount of time required getting there depended on which boat across you caught. Going to the island was about 30 minutes on the fast boat and returning was almost an hour on the slow historical boat.

insightful visit to this historic prison. a trip to Robben Island is a trip back in time and a trip to witness the courage of the people who were imprisoned there....Very informative and having a former political prisoner be the guide was incredible.

Warning about getting to Robben Island. I consider it a shame that I must submit this review, but I feel my fellow travelers must be made aware of a situation they may encounter: The only way to get to Robben Island is by boat, which is owned by the "Nelson Mandela Foundation". The boat is the "Susan Kruger", and it is a very old boat. As a matter of fact, I am told that it was this boat that transported prison personal and prisoners to Robben Island in the old, bad days. They have refitted the interior of the boat to make it somewhat habitable by tourists - minimally habitable at best. The waters between Cape Town and Robben Island can get very, very rough, and the boat itself is by no means built for rough water. On the day we sailed in her, January 5, 2015, the water was quite rough, causing the boat to pitch and roll excessively, with the result that over half the passengers got seasick. There was also a sea fog, which is also common to this area. After about 30 minutes, the ship's radar went out, and, for some unknown reason, the boat seemed to "wander around", apparently looking for Robben Island. We were later told that, because of reefs in the area, the captain was unable or unwilling to proceed, and could not get the radar to function. He finally came across a boat that was heading to the Island, and followed the boat in. So, a 40 minute trip that started at 9 AM arrived at the Island at 11:15 AM, with most of the passengers seasick. We were then told they would have to send for an expert from the mainland to try to fix the radar, as the boat could not return without it! The company finally had to charter two other boats to bring people back and forth to the Island. The boats chartered were modern, state of the art Catamarans, which got us back to Cape Town, in luxury, in 30 minutes! Speaking to our local tour guide, we learned that what happened to us, and the "Susan Kruger" that day, appears to be the rule, rather than the exception, and the charter companies that operate the Catamarans are very often chartered by the Foundation, to fulfill their tourist commitments. The tour of Robben Island, is one of the main tourist attractions of Cape Town, for good reason. Daily, hundreds and hundreds of people visit the island, producing significant income to the Nelson Mandela Foundation - very significant income. Why they continue to operate an old vessel, which has definitely long ago seen its best days, is a serious question that should be investigated by the proper authorities. So, here is my warning to my fellow travelers: if the weather forecast calls for heavy sea swells, AND the Foundation is using the "Susan Kruger", you might want to think twice, or be prepared for an "E Ticket experience".

This place must be number 1 in Capetown!!. If you are in Capetown or surroundings, you cannot miss a visit to Robben Island. In high season be sure to book tickets in advance.The voyage with ferry takes ab. 30 minutes but the ocean is never quiet so it is quite a tough time till you get to the island.You get off the ferry (be careful of the time of your return ferry!) and go to one of the buses that are waiting, and you will go on a quick tour of the island, that is astonishingly beautiful. The stop at the limestone quarry is impressive, if you think that lots of political prisoners were there every day for hours, under the rain and under the sun...But the highlight is the visit of the former maximum security prison, your guide will be a former political prisoner that will tell you about the time he spent there, when Nelson Mandela was there as well.This experience will touch your heart and soul.

spoilt by the small things...... Ferry trip out good. As was most of the tour. Disappointment as a national monument. Toilets filthy and smelly. Had to wait 45 minutes for a ferry to take us back to Cape town.

The authenticity of the guides alone makes this worth your time.. So much important history and emotion! The tour feels like any other until the guide explains how many years he served as apolitical prisoner, And then it is a tour like no other.The 45 minute boat ride can be tough in difficult weather.

Essential, powerful Cape Town experience. You can't come to Cape Town and miss this opportunity to learn first hand about the globally significant Robben Island prison, and the other vents surrounding it's occupants. It about Mandela, yes, but also about the whole Apartheid resistance movement, the men in particular, as the only women here were the visitors who braved violence themselves for that privilege - who people were, where they came from, what they did. You will travel to the island in a boat that was used to transport prisoners. You will tour the island with a knowledgeable and thoughtful guide, then tour the prison, guided by a former political prisoner. It is moving, thought provoking, and professionally and sensitively put together. The history is recent, and there will most probably be people with you on your tour who experienced the oppression of apartheid. This visit itself is reason to go to Cape Town.

Excellent . I have visited robben island on two occasions, the most recent with my family.It is a must see if you are near cape town. The boat trip takes about 45 minutes and yes it can be a little 'bumpy' in choppy seas but weather permitting sit out on deck.The tour is divided into two parts. One part is the Prison Tour led by ex inmates is excellent and it is a privilege to be able to hear their stories.The second part is a bus tour of the island, the quarry being a particular highlight. I would recommend sitting on the left hand side of the bus.At times it could be organised a little better and with more creativity the story of prisoners leaving the dock for robben island could form an intrinsic part of the tour. But overall the tour is highly recommended.

A sobering experience. It is a truly humbling and sobering experience to take this tour narrated by an ex-inmate and see what prisoners had to endure. It makes one wonder how it is possible that apartheid was kept in place into the nineties! Although I find the groups rather large, and that perhaps not enough time is spent on the cell blocks, you can choose to take the next boat back and roam around the island to explore more in depth.

Could do better. Were our expectations to high ? Was it because we were running late, and last group of the day ? We will never know for sure. Never less we left with a feeling that it could have been better. That they could make more of it. For example with open top busses, so you can see more and make pictures of what you see more easely. The former prisoner that functioned as guide did not feel as he would like to tell us more then answering the questions asked. Also an audio guide would have been interesting.

Disappointing . I have been to Robin Island a few times now and every time it seems to get worse. The last time it looked really run down compared to earlier visits & you weren't even allowed into Mandela's cell or the mine anymore. I had a 3 month old baby with me. There were no facilities for him, nor anyone who would require wheelchair access. The information given on the tour was vague & almost appeared to be more for foreign tourists. On arrival, I watched in horror as staff lifted my baby strapped into his pram over the side of the boat and about a meter and a half of water to dry land because there was no buggy or wheelchair access. Where is there health and safety? The boat was old, over crowed and the staff were rude. The boat on the way back was nicer, but not buggy or wheelchair friendly. Taking into account that I had to pay half the price of an adult ticket for a 3 month old baby, it was not worth the money spent. There are documentaries that show you far more than the tour did and they were done before the place became completely run down.

Powerfull emotions!. I'd been wanting to make this trip for some time! As a teenage student growing up in apartheid South Africa, opposing a regime that was running a police state, I felt an affiliation with Robben Island's most famous prisoner, and one of the most iconic men in all of history, Nelson Mandela (Madiba and Tata to his followers).Great trip on the ferry, but take a light jacket or sweatshirt. There's a bar on the ferry too, and it's only a short 40 minutes cruise.Once you're on the island you'll be flooded with emotion! Some serious history and many sacrifices on that famous island. Take the kids, they'll love it.Ps. Book well in advance ... like a month!

A very special tour . . .. Our journeys on the ferry were quick and efficient and the bus tour of the main sites on the island set the scene for the tour of the prison itself. Our guide on the bus was Wendy, who gave a beautifully clear explanation of the main landmarks. A real bonus was that Christo Brand, author of Mandela - My Prisoner & My Friend, came on to the bus to tell us his story - very emotional! We then toured the prison with a former political prisoner who told it as it was . . . He explained that telling his story to groups like us is therapeutic for him.This is a tour not to be missed and worth booking in advance to ensure a place.

Robben Island should not be missed. Great boat ride to island. Took about 45 minutes. Saw dolphin, whales and had the most beautiful view of the Cape. Once on island you are provided a tour of the island by bus then are escorted into the prison facility by an ex prisoner who will describe in detail what conditions were like when Robben Island was a full functioning prison. Ask a lot of questions because they have a lot to tell. It is very very solemn but at the same time interesting and an important part of history. I am currently reading Nelson Mandela's "Long Walk to Freedom" and have also been inspired to read another Robben Island political prisoner of lesser fame, Robert Sobukwe's biography "How Can Man Die Better." This tour is a must do. I visited in 2012 not 2014.

Touching, but sad. This is definitely worth a visit once in your life, however, what is most sad is that nothing has been done to even notify tourists about the cell Mandela is in. It is not signed, signaled, or even maintained. Most tourists visit to see his cell that he was in for 27 years! Its truly sad. Also be careful that there is a return journey and it is on time when booking your tour. Otherwise they leave you on the island for 2 hours waiting a "free boat" to come and take you back to the waterfront. Its well worth seeing, just wish they were more professional.
Must do. Very interesting to learn more about a the shameful history of apartheid and its heroes. Included a meeting with a seven year political prisoner of the island.

Thank you Nelson Mandela. The trip to Robben Island was sobering. A must see for anyone visiting Cape Town. The ferry takes about an hour and, unless you get to the departure point early (at least 30 minutes if not an hour), you will not get seats on the deck. On arrival, there is a bus tour of the island. The guides are former prisoners who have a excellent knowledge, first hand, of the prison conditions. Visitors talking on their cell phones during the presentations were not appreciated by our group. It was highly disrespectful never mind distracting. The guide was very diplomatic. So travellers, smarten up!

History Class. It is very interesting to be able to see the cell where Mandela was imprisoned for 18 years, as well as hear all the story told by an ex con, usually that was there also for political reasons.

Emotional and enlightening experience. Went to Robben island on the 18 December 2014 with my wife and 2 children, both below 12. We had booked through the internet. Although the wait was a bit long (we arrived there early) and the lady checking us in, had to trouble typing in the booking numbers. We set out to the island on the Tigger 2 boat and although the sea was a bit choppy the 45 minutes ride was comfortable. The visit of Robben island by bus with the tour guide and of the prison with the ex-prisoner was an experience not to be missed. It was an enlightening, informative, and emotional visit for all of us. Laws like the Sobukwe law are things never to be repeated again.The only bad review that we have on the trip is on transfer back from Robben island to Cape Town. We boarded the Sea Princess and the crew were in an unwelcoming party mode. They played loud club music, passed on silly jokes, invited people to drink alcohol. The captain ensured that he made our ride as uncomfortable as possible by charging the waves, while the crew thought it was funny. They even asked the crew if they were feeling sick and could offer a sick bag. After such an emotional and touching experience on Robben island that type of behaviour on the Sea Princess was totally unacceptable. It was an insult to the memory of Robben Island.The trip is an experience recommended to all, young and old. Hope that the behaviour of the crew of the Sea Princess improves, since it could mess up the whole experience for some visitors.

Boat to Robben Island. We had booked our tickets online (webtickets) before travelling to Cape Town for 9.00 a.m on a bright Sunday morning. As we had been cautioned by some people to be timely, we were on the queue to enter the boat by 8.30 a.m. and the boat left by 8.45 a.m.! The journey across the sea was a bit rough and lasted about 45 minutes. The tour on the island itself was very interesting, especially since our guide in the prison itself was a former political prisoner who was able to narrate that time in vivid colours. The whole place was sparkling which I should think was not like that during Mandela incarceration. The original state of the cells should have been kept - at least in some parts of the prison as is being done in the former concentration camps in Germany to convey the horrors of the past.

Interesting but not well managed. We were keen to pay respect to the site of Mandela's incarceration. On the day we visited the organisation was not well managed. We had to walk from the booking office along the quayside to board a private charter and our party included an eldely lady in a wheelchair . The staff did their very best to help her but the facilty was just not suitable for a disabled person. Our guide on the bus was good and humorous and the prison experience was good but we were glad to be back on dry land.
Worth going. This is a must go place while you're in Cape Town. Always very nice to know the place you visited and understand the history behind it. I highly recommend it!

Excellent. We visited on the 11 am ferry boat on Christmas Day and it was outstanding. All visitors to Cape Town should do this tour and put into perspective the history of the African blacks and the struggle they are still facing today. Our guide , a former prisoner, was amazing and I am sure he would have preferred to be at home with family. He suggested that we do a township tour and we did and it too was outstanding

A must see!. If you're in Cape Town, make sure to take the tour or Robben Island. The history is really really interesting, and it's amazing to see Nelson Mandela's cell where he was held for 18 years of his 27 years incarcerated. One thing to note however, is that it's very hard to get tickets. So if you're planning on going to Cape Town and want to go see robben island, you Hoyle definitely book tickets ahead of time!!

Exceptional guide!!. I have to write this review today as by the end of our tour our guide did such a wonderful job I felt quite emotional. I want to write this while this emotion is still with me. It wasn't only Nelson Mandella on this horrific island but many more inspirational people. Sad but a very, very amazing transformation for this country and I feel privileged to have had the opportunity to meet people who experienced this place. Mostly when you go to a historic tour it's from a long time ago and it's from history books etc but this was something more and this came across.I would highly recommend this as one of your tourist trips!!

Must see, but could be more polished experience. You simply must go, the only reason for the 4 stars is that our experience was a bit stressful. We were travelling with a baby and when we arrived it was very hard to know where to go, or where to line up. It turns out they were running about 45 mins to an hour late, but we did not find out until we had already been waiting the hour. It was stressful for me not knowing what was going on, and when I should feed the baby. On the other hand we had great tour guides and it was a very interesting tour.

Fairly Interesting. If you understand the politics of South Africa then I would recommend visiting Robben Island. If however you are not familiar with the history then it is not particularly fun, a fairly choppy boat ride to the island. Not a cheap option either.

History. When visiting certain places, there are attractions you MUST see/do for one reason or another. Robbens Island, playing such an important role in South African history is one of those attractions. The boat ride (on an original diesel boat that ferried previous prisoners to and from the island) from Cape Town was approximately one hour in each direction because of choppy waters. Upon arrival, we took a 45 minute bus tour of the island, which was most recently used to house political prisoners. We were told about the islands history and viewed various landmarks including the kennel, lepers burial ground, church, school, medical center and others. Although the buildings are currently in a state of disrepair, we were told that restoration is forthcoming. We were then went on to the actual prison area that house Nelson Mandela among other prisoners. The thing that made this part of the trip interesting is that all of the guides in this aspect of the trip are actually previously politically imprisoned South Africans that served time on Robbens Island. I highly recommend this attraction for this is the REAL South Africa.

Interesting visit. Bookings over peak periods are hard to come by. We booked well in advance. Our boat left 30 mins late. The boat itself (Susan Kruger) was old and not really up to standard for a tour of this sort. The island has some amazing history. The story telling was emotional and uplifting. There are some picturesque photo opportunities.However, the staff were of a very poor quality and not professional for this tour. Our tour guide was good, but the bus driver absconded which resulted in our itinerary being mixed up with a somewhat shortened tour. We also found most of the other staff members not very professional.

Important and must see attraction while in Cape Town. As an important part of South Africa's history, this is a must see attraction in Cape Town. Visiting the island involves a trip on a large catamaran the island. The visit involves a tour of the island, with the focus being on the Robben Island prison which was home to famous political prisoners during Apartheid, including Nelson Mandela. It is a well run and organised attraction.

educational and more.... It is a four hour round trip which opened my eyes to that the island is more than is often told. Arriving on the island we were welcomed by buses to take us around the vast island past the limestone quarry, Robert Sobukwe's prison quarters, the lepers burial grounds and the heavy world war batterries among other interesting sights showing just how much more there is to the island. The guide whose name i have forgotten was quite engaging with witty humour breaking down various new details to us...or me at least. Nelson Mandela's former cell is the show stealer naturally as were the various photos around. The Robben Island is worth the four hours and tells a story of all the various steps of South Africa's transition.Was delighted to be taken around by a former inmate at the prison section who ran us through what life was like when he was jailed on the island.

Very interesting. The boat tour over was very interesting if a bit long the guide on the bus going around the island I thought was all for giving his own personal opinion which took a long time that spoilt it a bit,the former prisoner was great showing us around the prison but he run out of time due to us being on the bus a long time,we never had time to look in the shop because we overrun.the boat trip back was a bit choppy due to weather getting rough,would I recommend it yes worth a visit.

Meaningful experience. Helps understanding of the new South Aftrica. The boat ride allows amazing views of Cape Town and Table Mountain. The history of the island and the tour led by an ex-prisoner made the whole experience meaningful. A must do on a trip to Cape Town.

Thought provoking visit. The boat ride to the island provides some great views of Table Mountain and Cape Town. The bus tour of the island allows you to take in some of the history of the place - our bus tour guide was very knowledgeable and engaging. But it's the tour of the prison with a former prisoner that makes this such an amazing experience. Yes, it was difficult at times to understand our guide, but to hear his story and to see where Nelson Mandela was held for 18 years was thought provoking. It was incredible to see a place that is such a symbol of that terrible time in South African history. It's an easy tour to take, not a lot of walking or stairs. Lasts about 3 1/2 hours. We were able to combine it with a trip to Table Mountain in the same day and had plenty of time for lunch at the waterfront as well.

Madiba!. Definitely a must for all those visiting Cape Town and are interested in the history. It's a humbling experience to visit a place that represents oppression and segregation. It was also very cool that one of our guides was a former political prisoner and to hear his personal account was an experience that I'll never forget. Its best to purchase tickets a day or two before departure and I also recommenced picking a departure time around noon returning and hour or so before the sun sets. You have to take a ferry to Robben Island and you CAN get soaked in certain conditions. We were fine going over, in fact, we enjoyed the ride but we were on one of the last tours so we were wet and freezing on our return home.

informative, presented well. If you like history and nostalgia. this is for you, a guided tour by an ex political prisoner, well presented and informative. The ferry journey alone was worth savouring. don't forget to wear a coat as it can get windy on the top deck.

Must see. Some practical tips:*There are several tours a day, but they DO sell out, particularly during the holiday season. So either book in advance online OR go and buy your tickets at their booking office before the day.*The sea can actually get quite choppy, so try to pick your moment if possible, and be aware the journey can take an hour in rough conditions*Because of the weather conditions (in conjunction with occasional organisational chaos!) it's not unusual for your ferry to be late/cancelled/rescheduled. Be aware if catching a flight the same day (as were we and several others) and leave PLENTY of time for unforeseen delays.Tour itself - fascinating and unthinkable in equal measure, but the guides (most of whom are former prisoners) have a light touch, and overall the day is thought-provoking and uplifting. There is a one hour bus tour of the island (a bit whistle stop) followed by a detailed tour of the prison, covering things like the cells, the exercise, food rations etc.

Interesting Robben Island. The boat journey is quite long but you see a lot of things on the boat like, if you are lucky, and we were we saw the whales. We also saw seals and it is also possible to see the Penguins. The guided tour around the prison with one of the old prisoners. It is amazing the stuff you learn and how the guards live with the ex prisoners. It is a very good trip and one that you must do if you go to Cape Town.
Robben Island experience. The Robben Island experience was historical and informative, the tour was lovely. The staff were interpersonal and interactive to the tourists, it was a beautiful journey.

Very disappointing tour. This was our biggest disappointment during our month in South Africa. The boat was an hour late and took over an hour to get to the island as the regular ferry was out of service (apparently for some time). We were herded onto very run down buses and did a drive by of the main sites on the island. We were not allowed off the bus, but could stand to try to take a photo past all the others on the bus. All the sites on the other side of the bus were missed. The tour guide could not have been more disinterested. We did stop at a shop for 20 minutes to buy drinks!! The visit to the prison was the same. Our tour group had over 50 people so we were each given a few seconds to take a photo of Nelson Mandelas cell. The return ferry was 90 minutes late. Then it could not accommodate everyone so they forced a school group off the boat to wait for a later boat. Disappointing is an understatement for this tour.

Chilling history. If you want to see some of the crimes committed during the apartheid regime , then Robben island is the place to visit. I visited this island prison whee Nelson Mandela was incarcerated. Its about 13km for the V & A waterfront only accessible by boat.The tour was carefully planned as we got into a tour bus as soon as we arrived at the island. The tour guide received us and gave detailed information on the history of the island and also on unsung hero's of the struggles with apartheid. There were many things to see but the highlights included the iconic Nelson Mandela prison cell, the quarry and it's hole/cave and the courtyard were the prisoners used to play tennis. The quarry cave was used by the prisoners for both eating meals and as a toilet.This visit was so full of raw emotion one of the guides who was also imprisoned at Robben Island took us through the cells and their history.Life changing experience . A must do for anyone visiting Cape Town

Amazing History and Great Views of Cape Town. I thought this was a well organized tour and gives you a great sense of this piece of South African history. The boat ride there takes about 30 minutes and gives you a great view of Cape Town from the water. Once on the island you get a bus tour of the notable spots, including the quarry where the prisoners worked, Robert Sobukwe's house, and the town on the island (which surprised me that people still lived there).The last part is a tour of the prison where Mandela was held and a discussion with one of the former prisoners, who did an excellent job answering questions and describing what life was like,If you visit Cape Town, it is definitely worth it to do this trip. Make sure you buy tickets ahead of time as they sell out in advance.

Half the trip was OK, the other half very disappointing. An OK trip, and definitely interesting to be there, just for the sake of the history. The bus guide was very good and provided very engaging stories. The Prison guide, however, was NOT good. Everything seemed too rushed and walking around in groups of 70 people+ (approx) made it hard to ask questions and to interact with the prison guide (former inmate). Also, there were not enough time to properly look around in the prison museum (reading the info etc.)This part of the trip was very disappointing.

Another piece of South African history not to be missed. Our trip was spoilt by the bad weather. The ferry ride to and from Robben Island was very rough and we could not see much off the bus as it was raining. I would strongly recommend that if you have a choice you make sure the weather is calm and dry on the day you visit

History that will remain alive forever. Visited this most amazing place for the first time even though I must hav come to Cape Town over 50 times. Tour took about 3 and half hrs from start to finish includin the the boat trip to and from the harbout. The trip was worth every cent that was spent. Lots to learn from about life in prison from the 60's onwards. The story of prison life was horrific. You get first hand information about life on the island as it is delivered by an ex confict. The bus tour around the village is also amazing and filled with rich knowledge. I'm glad I braved the waters and went as this was really a highlight of my trip. I pay tribute to our Icon Madiba and salute him for even after enduring such pain and hardship, he was such a humble, loving and caring soul. Long live ur memories. This is a must for every person local and abroad.

Moving, informative and enjoyable.. Visited Robben Island today with my husband. We took the first trip at 9am. The tour starts with the boat trip out to the island. Advice- make sure you are wearing a jacket- it was really windy and the wind was cold! We arrived at the island and went straight on to a coach. I felt the whole tour was organised really well and ran smoothly throughout. Our tour guide Toyer was fantastic! He was so informative, amusing and kept everyone intrigued. He added the personal touch with his little anecdotes. The coach takes you around the whole island which is really eerie and sets the scene for going into the prison.When you go into the prison you are taken round by a former prisoner. Listening to his story was so moving and many of us were in tears. It was a truly amazing experience. We also got to see Nelson Mandela's cell. I enjoyed the trip so much and felt moved to learn more about the apartheid. In the gift shop I bought nelson Mandela's autobiography which I look forward to reading and remembering the amazing experience that was Robben Island.

Essential tour...but there’s plenty of room for improvement. For such an essential part of South African history, the Robben Island tour is something of a mixed bag of highs and lows. At the same time, you would be at a loss if you didn’t take the R 150 tour since it really does retrace a time in that country’s history that cannot be forgotten. Nelson Mandela spent twenty years on the island where the government imprisoned whom they deemed the most dangerous anti-apartheid agitators even when their crimes were minor. The prison was built in 1961, and Mandela started his sentence just two years later. Prisoners were allowed to write only two letters a year to the outside world and subject to brutal conditions including starvation, solitary and back-breaking labor in a quarry.You see all this once you get to the island 12 km from the V&A Waterfront in Cape Town, but there is, of course, the boat ride there, which takes a little over half an hour. It’s a bumpy ride on some fairly choppy waters on an aged ferry where you will likely get drenched at certain points. If you are subject to seasickness, I strongly suggest you take some dramamine at least a day in advance. Once you arrive, you follow the hordes all of whom are targeting to get on one of the waiting buses. The buses are packed quite tightly, and you are stuck on it for about 45 minutes of narrative around the island. In reality, there is very little to see of interest with perhaps a long shot of Table Mountain the only real photo opportunity. Even the quarry is at a distance when the driver stops, and we could see little of it from our seats.The tour improves immeasurably once we arrived at the prison where we were met by an ex-political prisoner who spoke passionately about his time as an inmate. Even though our group was large, he spoke loudly and eloquently about what life was like as you go through the prison, the exercise yard and most movingly, walk past the small cell where Mandela was incarcerated where all you see is some blankets and a stool. When the tour is over, we basically had to hike back to the dock at a quick pace to make sure we weren’t left behind. There was no time for the museum shop, and in hindsight, I wish the organizers provided more guidance to help manage our expectations. An introductory film would also have been helpful or at least something to provide greater context for what we were about to see.

What kind of tour are you looking for?. One can have one of two experiences of Robben Island. The typical tourist gets on a boat, travels to the island, takes a short bus ride with a guide, walks around on foot and gets the boat back.The more serious tourist spends time before the start, at the departure point, reading some of the prisoner comments and histories.They ask the guide questions. Usually guides are ex prisoners. Ask about their motivation and you will be taken into a new world reserved for the few.My family were prison guards, what we did to some residents was terrible. The day prisoners arrived, they received a number and for the rest of their stay they were never again referred to by their names, only their numbers.Read the individual stories on the cell doors. Again, ask questions.I find any return to the island to be a very special time. special because it reminds me of our inhumanity towards each other. Ours is not the only country that is inhumane, but perhaps one of the few who has come clean, and allowed others to see a face that is shocking.So, whether you want a light tour, see Nelson Mandela's cell, go and have fun. And if you want to understand how special he was as a person, ask questions and see how much he had to overcome.

A must See!. Robben Island is a must see. Even though most of the tour is by bus, we had a tour guide who was very interesting and knowledgeable. The guided tour by a former political prisoner of the cell block that Mandela was held in is sobering. The ride over on the ferry took 45 minutes. When it came time to leave they had brought in a catamaran to take people back to Cape Town. We knew that the ferry had not left Cape Town yet to pick people up from Robben Island so we thought we we would get back faster. That was not the case! It took 1 1/2 hours for the catamaran to get us back to the waterfront. In the meantime, the ferry passed us on the way to Robben Island, picked up the passengers and then passed us again to get back to the waterfront ahead of us. Be forewarned- unless you WANT a sailboat ride, wait for the ferry! I would have given this venue an excellent if not for that.

Huge disappointment. Possibly the worst tour, for such an important venue, I have ever encountered. When we got off the boat, nobody told us where to go. Some walked aimlessly, others squeezed into a nearby bus. After sitting in the bus for 15 minutes, the bus left, went 50 metres around the corner and told us to disembark. Then the tour guide arrived. He was an ex Soweto internee, but even allowing for this, I was very disappointed: I only understood perhaps 5% of what he said. What he did say was obvious and not informative at all. Further, the group following him must have been about 60 people. The 2nd guide a few hours later was better. But overall, considering that we had travelled 6,000 miles and expected this to be one of the highlights of our trip, was terrible. I suggest that they organise people better, perhaps have an audio guide also.

Shocking service. Tour cancelled twice!!. We wasted two days of our four precious four days in Cape Town trying to get on the tour. The 1pm tour on Monday was cancelled then our 3pm tour on Tuesday was cancelled with no explanation! We were emailed on Sunday about the Monday tour. So no email on Tuesday and went to queue for almost an hour to be told the 3pm tour was cancelled. It all seemed to be pretty disorganized and no communication to the numerous people waiting to board. The ticket sales queue was horrendous with people trying to rebook or get their refunds. We went back on Wednesday to request our refund to be to be told that is had already be refunded to our card as we had booked on line. As of today, still no refund! I can just imagine what a battle it is going to be to get our refund as we are now back in Durban!!

forgotten island. the experience of going in Mandelas footsteps is for tourists disappointing, as everything is neglected. Could be our main tourist destination, but the ferries are old, service bad and not reliable. The buildings on the island need renovation, waiting rooms are neglected -pity. Certainly not worth a visit under those circumstances.

Excellent Experience. Visiting the prison made me really understand exactly the life led by all those who were incarcerated there. The guide was an ex-prisoner who answered our questions with honesty and humility, which get me close to tears. A very humbling and insightful visit

Thought provoking trip. We went on the Sea Princess ferry yesterday which is supposed to be one of the better ferries. Even though i took a motion sickness pill, the trip back was very choppy and left me queasy for the rest of the day.The actual tour on the island was amazing and emotional to hear the apartheid stories ... makes me appreciate my roots. Visiting Nelson Mandela's cell was truely amazing and then going to his garden where he buried the 'Long Road to Freedom' manuscript. Our tour guide was Sipho Nkosi who was an ex political prisoner. He was an avid narrator of his experiences in the prison.Definitely worth the cost of R280 per adult and R150 per kid.Something i would love my kids to bring their kids to see one day.

Remarkable place. Beautifull day, eventhough see was rough! 1 hour trip, by chartered boat! If you are on island you have to take guides bus. In jail there was Parks, a former political prisoner, who told everything about who everybody survived here.Because I read the book long walk of freedom and the book from mr brand, I was impressed! A lot of sick people in the boat when we returned! Great to see, but a little to touristic. Cannot go for a walk yourself. Only little 3 minutes

Long walk to freedom. It was my 4th or 5th time!But it always different and emotional.The guides are ex-political prisoners and they share theirs experiences with the visitors.The visit takes 3 hours approximately

An historic and humbling experience. This was my second trip to Robben Island. I was there in 1997. everything from the booking of the tickets online to the ferry was awesome and very professional. The bus tour was really enlightening and the prison tour left me speechless. The tour guide was an ex political prisoner, his passion, humility and care inspired me to be a better person. The tour was professional and I would rate it amongst one of the things you need to do in your lifetime.

Informative, but also a missed change. The prison-part of the tour, with a former imprisoned as guide, is very informative. However, you are rushed alongside the cell of Nelson Mandela without having a good chance to think about what happened there. The bus tour is informative as well, but short. All in all, this is an experience you don't want to miss, but on the other hand, there is a lot more possible with the island. Cape Town, take that chance and surprise me next time.

Historical Site. We did a bus tour of the island, which included a great commentary . Robben Island is probably best known as the site where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned. However, it has a very chequered and interesting history. The visit to the prison was informative and very moving as the guide had actually been imprisoned with Nelson Mandela. He gave a very graphic commentary.

hit or miss. This was a 2 part trip which was annoying. There were 3 different boats that take you. 2 are nice, one is old & dingy. We got the bad one on our 50 minute boat ride to Robben Island. Once we got there, we found out there weren't enough buses for everyone, so they split us into 2 groups. Group A went on the buses & did an island tour first, Group B would do the prison tour first then do the island tour later.We were in the group to do the prison tour first. We got put in a group with about 30 Belgium travelers who had a private translator. This was awful. Everything our guide said, we had to wait for the private group's translator to translate to Dutch. As a result, we only got to see half as much as others since everything had to be said twice. We (the 10 or so non-Dutch people on the tour) that it wasn't fair. The tour specified it would be done in only English, and we were denied half of the tour because of the time it took to translate to Dutch. Then, at one point, the private Dutch translator actually yelled at our guide that we "need to move on" because his people didn't want to wait for the English version of the tour. Hello! The tour was said to be in English, not our problem the Dutch booked it and cannot understand it! The Dutch tourists would yell back and forth to each other while the English was being said, so even when English was being spoken, we couldn't hear it due to the private tour people. When we complained about this and said we wanted to tour again, they said that'd be a private tour & cost extra. Well, why did the Dutch essentially get a private tour with their translator they brought, which infringed upon our time there?So after this half-assed tour, we decided we didn't want to get on the bus and have another half-trip, so we jumped in with another group and did the prison tour again, this time in English. We literally saw twice as much & were told twice as much. This guide was excellent.So all in all, we were annoyed. We only did 1/2 of the tour, and did it twice. The first time was awful because of awful guests & because the tour operators allowed for this private translator to take up half of the time. At least on the ride back to Cape Town we got on the good boat, and saw whales & dolphins.

Missed opportunity. We were really looking forward to this experience and learning more about the history of the area. However, it's just not executed well... Book in advance to make sure you get the trip you want (and save 10%) as sometimes tickets not available at the time. The boat is like a Garage party boat-I think these guys have lost their way!!! Especially given the role the island played in the countries history. You then take a bus-bit naff and are then given a tour of the prison itself by an ex inmate-this part has the potential to be incredibly interesting but it's just so rushed you don't have enough time to read or take in the information. Missed opportunity for what could be an incredible experience.

Impressive. You can not visit Capetown without going to Robben Island!South Africa is Nelson Mandela, and Nelson Mandela is South Africa! So you must take a tour here, to get a closer look how the political prisenors were kept and treated. What the faced, and how the lived. trying to get equal rights.The tour was guided by a former prisinor, who can speak from his own experience.Also the boat trip towards the Island was was nice! enjoying the seals and even a visiting whale!Great excursion!

A must to visit. Book in advance online to be sure of a spot, also book the earlier tour in the morning, it gets very crowded later in the day. A wonderful tour with an ex inmate gives you a true feeling for the prison.take sunscreen and a jacket if you want to sit out on the deck for the 35 mins crossing
Walk to freedom. It was a eye opener to see how people were treated in prison just because they were fighting for their freedom.

INTERESTING BUT CUMBERSOME. We had an Online Ticket booked. First we checked in at the Nelson Mandela Gateway building at 1pm. After we our Tickets were authenticated we or any one did not know where to go next.The Boat was parked at a completely different location and there was no one to guide or inform or escort.The crowd went into a tizzy and started walking in all directions looking for the Boat to board.After much confusion some one knew and every one started flocking like sheet behind that someone for quite a long distance.Final we arrived at the boarding point at a completely different location and felt like a prisoner myself.The boat ride was ok. On disembarking again the flock started walking where every one went.There was a bus ride around the Island, which was not very informative.The brief talk by one of the former Prisoner a Freedom Fighter was interesting.A look at the Cell in which Nelson Mandela was kept for 17 years, and our return trip was same as before.Good for once. Could have been more interesting if we were not hauled and handled like a flock of sheep.

Wasted opportunity. Robben Island is a symbol of the end of apartheid and the imprisoning there of Mandela and numerous other political prisoners was an important part of the road to change. There is a lot of history to be told here and much to be learnt to better understand what apartheid meant and how it was overthrown.Unfortunately the tour does not tell that story very well. Sure it was nice, indeed it was a privilege to have a former inmate talk to us about some of his experiences there, but it didn't tell us the whole story or anything like. Arriving on the Island we were herded onto buses and then each bus load became a single tour group taken round a very limited number of locations. Then we were herded back onto the buses for the boat trip back.There is a real opportunity here to use the prison buildings as a museum where people are free to browse exhibits and read documents at their own pace. I felt the film "Long Walk to Freedom" gave some fascinating insights about how Mandela and others used their time on the Island to nibble away at the oppressive regime and maintain their struggle and their dignity. There were only hints at this on the trip. The overall impression was that I was glad to have seen where the political prisoners were incarcerated but I really didn't learn anything new.

A real education. We were blessed with good weather so the ferry trips across Table Bay to/fro Robben Island were very smooth. Our previous visit to Cape Town in the winter of 1996 went without visiting Robben Island given adverse weather conditions at the time.Having read the late Nelson Mandela's autobiography shortly after it was published, and with the benefit of excellent guides including a former political prisoner to relive history and show us around the island and the prison facilities, the entire experience was exhilarating. To view the solitary prison cells, the common prison cells and washroom facilities, the limestone quarry where the prisoners endured hard labour, the accommodation and leisure facilities available for the prison warders and their families, etc. was a real eye opener.This was definitely the highlight of our visit to the Western Cape.

Bus portion of the tour sucks. The robben island 'experience' is made of three parts: boat trip out to the island, bus tour on the island, and guided tour of the prison. The boat trip out was incredibly long, around 1h 15min in a very slow boat. The bus trip was completely worthless. You get driven around and can't really see what you're supposed to be looking at. Our guide was also very hard to understand. The guided tour of the prison makes up for it though, and it's worth going for that part alone simply because the guides are former political prisoners that were jailed there, which gives the tour added significance.

An informative and moving trip. We booked 2 days ahead and had our choice of trip times, so, bearing in mind the problems we'd had in getting up Table Mountain because the wind speed closed it, we went for an 11.00 trip. Transfer by boat could have been more comfortable but no real complaints and the organisation on the island was excellent, with a great guide on the bus which takes you round the important spots on the island (including the line quarry where the prisoners had to work. There was a break for snacks and drinks on sale at a point looking back at Cape Town and Table Mountain (one you'll recognise from many postcards) and then to the actual prison where one of the previous inmates took us around and told stories of his time there. Very moving. Lucky that we hadn't booked a later trip because we were then hurried back to the boat - the wind had got up again, the remaining trips had been cancelled and our boat left rapidly to get us back to Cape Town. A "must do" trip if you're in Cape Town, but check the weather and if in doubt, go for an earlier boat.

Happy to have visited, but experience could have been much better. Of course, this is a must visit location. A symbol for the fight against apartheid. Seeing mr Mandela's tiny cell is really impressive. The organization is certainly not bad, but the experience could IMHO be much better. On arriving on the isle, one has to join a bus tour. As a consequence, key sights such as the quarry can only be seen from the bus. And if you happen to be seated on the wrong side ... Bad luck. Same goes for the actual prison. You have to join a tour with an ex-prisoner. Our guide was pretty entertaining and even the clear expectation of getting tipped did not bother me too much. Yet: I would have enjoyed it much more to have spent a couple of hours on the island by myself. Walking, seeing, thinking. A must see, but also once more proof that monopolies tend to destroy customer value.

Unmissable. This was the last stage of our South Africa tour which interalia had taken in the Apartheid and Hector Peitersen Museums, Constitutional Court and Soweto in Jo'burg, Voortekker Museum and Union Building with its huge Mandela statue in Pretoria and the Zulu Battlefields and Rorkes Drift in Kwa Zulu Natal. Robben Island helped fill in this part of the picture for us of the history of South Africa from settlement by the Boers and then the British and their respective impact on the indigenous population and the descent into the horrors of the apartheid system. It was shocking to learn that the system was applied in prison with black prisoners given a smaller food allowance than coloured and white prisoners. It was very moving to see Nelson Mandela's cell and more generally to be guided by an ex inmate who served 5 years for his political views. There is some truth in some of the earlier reviews posted on this site's criticism of the organisation of the trip. Loading the buses was a bit of a scrum and the groups were quite large for the tour and not helped by inattention and chattering by some tourists when the guide was explaining things. However, the number of people wanting to do this tour is so big that it is inevitable that to allow everyone a chance to go the groups have to be larger than desirable. The criticism of the boat trip is unfair as on a nice sunny day it was pleasant to motor across with lovely views back into Cape Town and Table Mountain with seabirds and the occasional dolphin. One boat was faster than the other so we did speed back but that was just luck. The organisers could look at how they embark and disembark people on the boats and buses and ensuring visitors get the best out of the trip whilst on the island and catching a returning boat. We pre-booked our tour before leaving the UK and I would recommend this to avoid disappointment. An early morning departure does enable a return to Cape Town for lunch and or afternoon exploring.

Learn the history. One can take a nice boat ride over from the V&A Waterfront, and take a guided tour there. It was sad to learn what the prisoners went trough there. Nelson Mandela was imprisoned here, the true father of the South African Nation. Breathtaking views of the city from the island.

Very angry right now. Arrived in South Africa and booked tickets to Robben Island well in advance. Got a message the day before the tour to say it has been cancelled. As tickets sell out days in advance we have no opportunity to purchase anymore before we leave. Now faced with trying to find a private tour company or individual who will charge us five times as much for tickets or not seeing the island at all. Unbelievable that a major tourist attraction seems to be unable to cater for demand.

A must visit. If you only do one trip when in Cape Town it is probably this one, the tourS are very well put together and for those of us old enough to remember the 60's and 70's it really brings home what was being protested against. The tour of the prison is led by ex inmates and their personal stories are deeply moving.

Excellent experience. We rarified on time make sure you do for booked trip if late you miss ferry and no refund. We went on one of the older ships Susan Kruger , this original boat took prisoners, staff and guards back and forth for many years. not the fastest crossing and if see sea is a bit rough you might also suffer . Wee had no problem, met other side by staff who were pleasant and informative, over 250 people and children still live on the island. Went around by coach part of the trip stopped for Tea / coffee break then went to prison ,where one of the previous detainees gave a talk of what life was about both inside and outside, social time , hard times , good times . Most most informative and brought tears to your eyes. Time out was on ferry at 13.00 hours 45 minutes on boat. / return was at 16.00 hours from island arrived back at dock at about 17.00 hours .Note this is all timed departure and return not a lot of time on your own. They are very strict and careful for those going on and off trip .. If hot you may need to take a bottle of water.

Disappointing. I've lived in SA all my life but never went to The Island.I'm not sure what I was expecting but felt that it was 'n real waste of time.There is nothing there, not much to see, nothing to do.It's an island with a prison.Not worth the time, the money or the effort.

Worth a visit. Certainly worth a visit - the tour of maximum security prison was particularly moving, though the rest of the tour was a little here nor there. Might be nice to have a bit more of a museum much like Jobergs apartheid museum where people can move at their own pace too...

a little disorganised. A visit to this Island is historically interesting to see where Mandela and fellow prisoners spent long years of their life. Be aware that the trip to the island takes almost an hour in a very small, slow and quite crowded ferry. Arrival is quite disorganised and people are herded to waiting buses only to find there were too many people resulting in a large group waiting around until one of the tour guides decided what was to be done next (which was a walk through the prison cells). If you intend to visit take the 9.00am departure so that you can at least have the afternoon in Cape Town. While the ferry ride was long we did see two whales breaching, several seals and a penguin!

Unmissable but disappointing. I am pleased I went on this visit as I have wanted to see where Nelson Mandeal was imprisoned for so long. However I was disappointed with the experience which was very commercialised. Three ships went across to the island at the same time and we were herded into coaches and shown around the island before going into the prison itself. This was more poignant.

so confronting. This was the highlight of my trip!
