I was so humbled by the people who had gone through this experience and then standing up before me retelling the story their life in Robben Island prison for 7 years!! Horrid but the forgivness and the ability to get on with their lives.... amazing

Disappointing. Having looked forward to this trip for months I was very disappointed by my trip here. It took and hour to get there by boat and you were ushered to a bus where 2 buses set off immediately, our bus had to wait for people to come and fill it up before we could leave, about 15 minutes wait. The chap on the bus was very good and knowledgeable, we were then told to get off the bus at the prison where a former inmate would meet us and take us around the prison. This he did but I felt the we were not given enough time to see around the prison and read about the people who were incarcerated there. The cell of Mandela was shown to us and we were told to leave by the front exit. I would like to have gone back to see what I had missed in the first part of the prison but I was not offered the opportunity. We were not informed of the time of the boats and there were no facilities to queue up for the next boat. We were grouped en masse at the quay and when the next boat arrived everyone rushed forward to get on it almost knocking elderly and disabled people flying! The boat could only take so many so we had to wait for the next boat, if I knew I would have to wait so long I could have spent more time at the prison. Someone was telling arrivals where to go but it would have been helpful if someone was explaining to the people waiting to leave what was going on. I felt it was very badly planned and it spoiled my whole experience.

Emotional visit. After a short boat ride, you can see how Mandela lived for all those years while in prison. Pre book you ticket because it always sell out over the holiday season. Just an amazing experience to see this. January 2013

place of reflection.. this island held an old guy who apparently was a visionary, his name... Nelson Mandela... I hadn't heard of him but he was said to have help black people get freedom in south Africa.... you can see his cell and all of the prison as well. that's a bit boring the prison bit but the best bit is the bus tour round where you see hundreds and hundreds of tortoises. they are wild there I would say if you like tortoises and frankly what's there not to like? also the snack bar is great too w=ith loads to eat....

Re-Living History!. The tour was great! Our island tour guide was very helpful, giving us all the information with a fun twist to it. The Prison guide was an ex-prisoner who shared his actual experience at Robben Island! Great!

Average experience. We only realized after we have already booked the tickets that our tour was on the one year annivery of Madiba's death. I am therefore not sure if it is always as crowded and busy - possibly. It was good to see the history and hear more about the experiences of the polictical prisoners, even going back hundreds of years. Our guide inside the prison was very good. Sadly I am almost of the impression that the "air" of slight negligence of the facilities and grounds are intentional to "enhance" the "suffering" of the prisoners in a way? Also, we were supposed to return at 2 pm on the "nauticat" - which seems to have been booked on short notice (?) for a private function resulting in a delay of over half an hour. The "Susan "Kruger" seems to be managed by the government and whereas the "nauticat" is privately owned. Big difference. I'm glad I saw it, although I will probably not return.

Good value but takes half a day. I had booked this trip online a month prior to arriving in Cape Town and was glad we choose the first boat out at 9:00am. We arrived to the dock at 8:30 and the boarding started promptly with no announcements from the crew or staff. We were on the Nauticat which didn't seem as old as some of the other boats reviewed but it still took 40+ minutes to get to the island. I agree with other reviewers that there was little organization/direction - we arrived and you just wandered to either the store, restrooms and eventually to the waiting buses at the end of the dock and had to ask which one to get on. I was happy that we did the walking tour of the prison first and then drove around the island. I felt we had more time to hear the guide (an ex-prisoner "Sparks") and to tour the area on foot which was better than the bus ride portion. Afterwards there were two boats to take us back and ours filled up so we took the catamaran which was even slower than the boat over. The ride back was entertaining as we had a large group of local women on our tour and they started an impromptu sing along (in Africaans?) and dance among themselves that lasted almost the entire ride back. A lot of it featured Mandela's name and it made the ride back quite enjoyable.

Allow 4 hours. My husband and I did this tour and were very glad we didn't have our kids (aged 9 and under) with us. Boat very slow and toilets smell invading into seating area (We were on the Susan Kruger). Would have thought for the amount of tourists it must get they could upgrade this boat from the 1970's! The tour was informative and good if you are very interested in the history of the struggles. But I wouldn't recommend it if you only have a few days in Cape Town due to the amount of time it takes to get there and back. The ferry is the weak link!

SA's History. Well, I kinda feel guilty rating this visit as 'very good.' Because how does such brutality be deemed as 'very good?' That being said, I liked the way they had preserved the prisons. And the way they told the stories of the prisoners and the challenges therewith.Our guide was awesome, made jokes and has a wealth of knowledge regarding many countries and how they helped SA during apartheid.As expected, HUGE crowds gather at Mandela's prison.My only critic is the boat they use to ferry visitors to the island. An old, rickety boat!!! They certainly can do better than that!

It could have been so good...but failed!. I had really been looking forward to visiting Robben Island, and learn a lot more about the important part of SA history - but sadly it was a very disappointing - a waste of time.The place has all the opportunities to tell the terrible apartheid story, while showing the historic site for a lot of Mandelas many years in prison (and the other political prisoners as well).But after an alright boat trip, it just goes downhill. I felt like were treated as a big herd of buffalo's that just had to be moved around until we could be sent back.Everything was rushed through - we didn't have time to read all the small stories in the cells, and it felt very crowded all the time. Our guide, a former inmate, had good intentions in speaking loud and clear, but it came out so slow and awkward that I almost felt asleep.I had hoped it would be like visiting Alcatraz - maybe even better due to the possibility to teach us all more about the apartheid.I would have loved to have walked around the prison at my own pace - with headphones explaining the things our guide tried to tell us. And if busses for the short island tour were just cruising around all the time, I could have decided if I wanted to do that part as well - or just spent more time inside the prison (where I imagine a museum-kind of style with apartheid stuff), and then just take a boat back whenever I were ready for that (if they sailed on a regular schedule).Maybe my expectations were just way off - I had really hoped for some more - instead I now think of the visit like this"walk around...watch out not to step on other people in the small space....go into a cell, have a look...get out again....here is Mandelas cell....hurry...move on to the outside....get in the bus....get out again....go back to the ferry"It wasn't worth the money or time - the best part was the view of Cape Town from the ferry.

So emotional. The boat trip to Robben Island was lovely as it was a good day despite being warned that the sea might be choppy - it wasn't. This trip was full of emotion as we were given a talk by a guide who was actually an ex political prisoner and some of his tales were heartbreaking. We were able to wander around all the exhibits and take photographs of the cell where Nelson Mandela spent a long time, this was all very moving but a must when in Cape Town.

This was my third visit and it always gives me pause for thought. on the last two occasions I arranged a private tour via my travel agent. This gives you time to see each of the areas and spend time there absorbing the history. Since my last visit a lot of work has been done to restore the buildings and ensure that those visiting are able to experience what Robben Island is and was.My niece felt that it was an experience that she is keen to share with her students when she returned to the UK. It gave her insight into the birth of a new nation that post apartheid Afrcia has become.What interested me wa that she commented the this was the first place she had been(Africa) where everyone had been nice to her.A visit to Robben Island should be on everyone's itinerary.

A must see in Cape Town!. This was an incredible experience and possibly my favourite experience in Cape Town. The ferry ride out to Robben Island is incredible and we even saw dolphins swimming alongside the boat! The tour includes a half hour bus tour of the island which was incredibly interesting. Our guide was an ex political prisoner who provided great insight into the history of apartheid and his own story, it was an honour to listen to what he had to say. Also included is a tour of the prison including Mandela's cell. All in all, a must-do for anyone with an interest in apartheid history! Very moving.

Broke my heart.... I've read a lot of reviews that said the tour was poorly organized. It was nothing like that. We were completely satisfied with how the day progressed.Hint: Buy your tickets online ($28 CAD) then head down to the V&A Harborfront about 30 minutes before the ferry leaves. Try not to go on a weekend when it's busy.The tour guide was a political prisoner and he told us stories about what it would have been like to serve there. Mandela and the other inmates worked hard to change conditions there. it was very hard to hear about what these men endured. You cannot go to South Africa without going to Robben Island.

A little too rushed. This was a very moving and interesting trip. The guide was an ex political prisoner which was a great insight. Sadly, there just wasn't enough time to wander around the exhibits as we were rushed back to the boat

Refurbish Robben Isalnd. Well, it's quite expensive to start with. The ferry ride is average. The guide in the island was quite informative, however, the facilities are quite run down. It was a good experience to actually stand in the cell of Nelson Mandela, but we were underwhelmed with the whole experience.

Good day out but wish they included more. The trip to Robben Island is a rare treat. The boat trip is beautiful on a sunny calm day. There is a lot of history on Robben a island and this is touched upon, but the overall tour is about the struggle against apartheid. Now I fully understand this but when you are on the Island, there are whale bones and WW2 structures, and artillery pieces. These are hardly mentioned. Nelson Mandela was hardly talked about and the visit to his cell was literally oh this is Nelson Mandelas cell, this way please. Still, it is a very worthwhile trip and has got to be done.

Visit the place of Mandela's Captivity - if YOU'VE got time to kill!. I visited Robben Island on the last day of my two week stay in South Africa in August (2014) and have to say I regretted the loss of 5 hours from my holiday. This was a guided tour that to me was so haphazardly organised and rushed it was laughable. We (myself and my newly found German friend Alex) actually did crack up laughing at the shambolic nature of the trip - it was either that or be annoyed but the former seemed more appropriate.  The outside of the Nelson Mandela Gateway departure building is modern and quite impressive.Having got our tickets a couple of days earlier - highly recommended if you do decide to go as bookings do fill up in advance - we waited the stipulated 45 minutes in the departure area (1 bench available for 170-odd passengers) thinking the boat would be on the quay outside. Not a bit of it. After going through the security check points we were ushered outside and then on a 10 minute walk back through the Waterfront part of town to the waiting boat. Although the boat had historical interest and relevance - it carried the original convicts of Mandela's era over to the Island it just wasn't up to modern tourist standards. I believe it took 169 passengers. Well there couldn't have been seating for a third of that number which I think raises a serious question of safety. Added to that there was an awful lot of mooring rope and chains lying about and the boat being in very rusty condition it left a lot to be desired. Once arrived at the Island there was no time to stop and look round the shop. We were directed straight onto two large multi-doored buses for an around the Island bus tour. This probably for us was the most interesting part of the trip as the on board tour guide was a former prisoner of the prison in Mandela's time and gave a good resume of the uprising that resulted in the prison being built used for Mandela and his co-captives. But even this seemed rushed. The bus didn't actually stop at any of the places of interest until we got to Mandela's cell block. We did stop halfway round at a cafe for TEN MINUTES barely enough time to queue for take out snacks and go to the toilet let alone soak up the amazing view of Table Mountain. By the time we got to Mandela's cell block incredibly our 2nd tour guide said we were running considerably behind schedule!! Where we lost that time I don't know! Before entering the block he pointed out the direction for the quay and the boat back to Cape Town. Then the new guide proceeded to spend 15-20 minutes repeating most of what the previous guide had said! With huddles of the party blocking the doorway view of Mandela's cell we didn't even get to stop, look and ponder (well we COULD of but we would have missed the boat back - more on that).So I just raised my camera over the heads of those hogging the cell doorway and clicked - luckily it came out quite well. On leaving the block we understood why the guide told us before where to walk to the Island's quaint harbour because there was no sign of any guides! When we got to the quay there was no sign of the boat that brought us either!  A large sailed and motored catamaran was there and we were directed to board this. After passing a sign that arrowed shop this way that actually pointed into the harbour, we boarded our boat back. What the boat over lacked in comfort, this boat lacked in capacity! It seated probably 30-35 people with others sitting on the webbing between the hulls and left us wondering if the other 100 or so people who came over had realised there was so little time or even how they were getting back. Anyway, we made our way onto the webbing on the front of the boat and soaked up the sun and view back to Table Mountain which we agreed was the best part of the trip! Part of my angst was knowing that my hired package holiday's driver was waiting for us at Cape Town from 2pm when we were told the boat would return. In fact it left Robben Island at about then so we didn't get back until gone three (where my driver loyally waited) - the catamaran didn't go as fast as it could of (safety reasons no doubt). What was most disappointing about the trip was we didn't really get the time even to pause and soak in that moment/event in history. There was definitely a massive shortage of time over the whole tour - you really felt it was a conveyor belt style attraction. Had we had the time and KNOW we could get a later boat back it would have been a lot better. As far as value for money goes it wasn't too expensive - under £20 for the whole tour including return boat trip but then how do you weigh up value against dissatisfaction? Had the Island not had such great historical significance I would have begrudgingly given this attraction ONE star but given that famous part of 20th Century history and the icon that Mandela is I would still say visit - just be prepared for the above.

Historic Landmark in South African History. Robben Island was a look at the historic past of a country that had massive racial problems and has since come to grips with many of them. The brutal captivity of the men imprisoned here showed the inhumanity of mankind. A look at the past, not to be repeated.

Deff worth the visit . After being to robben island I got a glimpse of what Nelson Mandela was. What an amazing man he must have been.The guides are amazing. Political prisoners and volunteers. They explain things with such zeal and warmth that it is amazingDo make this trip.

Makes you reflect. Our ferry trips over and back again were a little rough but we did want to visit the island. Once over the bus takes you around the island and then a former prisoner guides the group around the prison. It was very moving hearing him explain the conditions they endured. Well worth a visit but pre booking is advisable.

Robben Island. I have been there more than 4 times already and with different tour guides and the rich history is mind blowing. Each tour guide I have met had personal experiences of Robben Island and shared their experience of being held captive on the Island. The tour is very interesting and one can learn alot of the Island it self and how the prisoners worked, stayed and studied. A must for any person visiting Cape Town

An extraordinary way to do a triathlon on an extraordinary island.. I ran my first ever triathlon this year on the 1st November 2014. What made it even more memorable and poignant was that I did it on Robben Island. I've lived here for over 20 years, but I've never taken the 45 minute ferry over to see this extraordinary place. This is my year of being a tourist in my own city,( I am extending that to next year too) and so when I heard that there was a race being held on the island I jumped at the chance to go. We took the ferry out at 6am in the morning - they run all day and are fast and efficient. Saw plenty of dolohins and seals en route as well which was really cool. The closer we got the the island the more magnificent Cape Town looked as the backdrop. Honestly, we live in the most beautiful city. I often imagine what the first explorers must have thought when they arrived in Table Bay. It must have been an astounding feeling. It still is today for me. For the triathlon - a mini sprint- I swam in the harbour, cycled around half of the island and ran through the prison and the staff quarters. When you are moving through a place like this- be it running or cycling, the experience takes on a different perception: I felt the beauty of the island, yet also was acutely aware of the solitariness of it all and that many people have spent years incarcarated there. Yet there is a strong feeling of freedom as well. As a local, I felt sadness as well as joy for all that we have gone though as a country. You have to go and feel it for yourself.

A page of History. Although tickets are bought well in advance- in my case 1 month ago- you still have to queue up for quite some time before embarking on the ferry- may be tiresome for elderly people.The ride on the ferry is a good experience- good views of the table mountain and CT.A more modern ferry -like the one taking you to Langkawi, Malaysia, would have been more comfortable and probabaly would have taken less time to reach the island- 45 mins app., depending on the sea.Once you disembark on the island, buses are very far and the walk in the sun can again be very tiring for elderly people.The buses should have been closer to the ferries.The bus takes you around, with halts at important places; the guide was very useful and informative, with a good sense of humour.It stops to allow you buy something to eat/use the washroom for abt 15 mins, but a very unpleasant surprise when you get on it again- other tourists have taken your seat and you are forced to go at the back of the bus- all the elderly people were at the back of the bus- this is a shame! The authorities should consider assigning a number when you buy your tickets on-line, according to which you are provided a seat no. in the bus as well, so that younger tourists do not behave shamelessly !!There is no stop at the quarry where prisoners, including Nelson Mandela, used to break the rocks; this would have been most welcome.Inside the prison, I would have preferred entrance into the cell of Nelson Mandela itself, and more time in this cell, rather than spending more time inside the main jail with an ex-prisoner.But overall, a good experience- once in a lifetime is o.k. P.S I would have loved to see the penguins as well, but it was not allowed.

More time required. A must do but prebooking is essential. Our crossing was a bit rough and takes about an hour each way. Buses take you to different areas on the island but I felt the only place you get any time is at the cafe at the first stop. I would have preferred more time to read the signs, wander in the prison and soak up the atmosphere but you get moved on quickly but this is probably due to its popularity.

Disappointing.... Was really looking forward to this day trip. The weather was fantastic. Calm seas. But left me very disappointed.The whole experience is well organised. Maybe a bit too organised.The trip over and back was a good chance to relax and enjoy the ferry ride.Once on the Island buses transported us around the island and the guide did a great job of explaining it's history and answering questions etc etc. SO far so good.Next the prison. There we were met by a very lovely man who was himself a former inmate. He was also very informative and you really did feel as though you were getting the real story. Of course we got to see al the important bits (Nelson Mandellas cell etc etc). But then it was... 'thanks for coming, there's the front door and your ferry leaves at... (whatever time it was)'. So before you know it you're out the door standing in front of the prison with no chance to wander around and explore because the next group was behind you.I know there are probably thousands of visitors each day, but I couldn't help feeling that if I had actually not gone and did something else that day... ah well, been there, done that, bought the t-shirt!My advice... just done expect too much.

Slightly disappointing. Perhaps we had too high expectations of this trip. We felt we were rather rushed through the prison and there wasn't really any opportunity to ask questions. I suppose they just want to get as many visitors as possible through each day. Our guide, like all them, was an ex prisoner and although his story was interesting he didn't present it very well. Then again, he's not an actor so may be we wanted too much. 2 hours of the 4 are spent on the boat and another 1 hour at least on a bus driving around the island.Go but don't expect too much

Worth the journey if nothing more than the ferry ride. I would rate higher if they gave the option for walking the island but it is with buses and you are limited to where you can go. Interesting to see the actual cell of Nelson Mandela and have an ex-prisoner be the tour guide. Ferry ride is about 45 minutes one way. You spend about 2 hours on the island. Need to give yourself a half day.

An eerie piece of history. We did Robben Island on the last day of a 3 week South African adventure. It drove home the things we saw at the Apartheid Museum and history of South Africa's struggles. Walking through the prison was eerie. It can only compare to Alcatraz in the feeling you get walking through the cell blocks and grounds. You can only imagine what it must have been like to be imprisoned here. The most intriguing part was that the tour guide was ex political prisoner that had spent 6 years there with Nelson Mandela!

Too rushed. Overall we were disappointed with our experience. We felt it was too rushed, we wanted to spend more time speaking to the ex prisoner and finding out about his experiences in the prison. Instead we felt like we were being ushered on the whole time. At the start of the tour we were shown around the island, this to me was a waste of time. People visit this island to find out about life in the prison!

It could be better. I went with three colleagues to Robben Island. I felt that a place that special deserved a much more comprehensive and professional level of interpretation. Except for the final stop at the gaol, we were bussed around everywhere - how about a set of headphones so people can walk the short distances from site to site themselves to get the real feel of the place. It was great to have a former inmate as a tour guide in the gaol itself, although there were far too many people in our group, jammed into a narrow dark corridor, and very few could hear him. He also probably needed some basic presentation skills to help hold the attention of the audience. Final thought - could there be a better, faster ferry? The trip across the rough water was pretty awful with some sick people on the return journey. Final final thought - because we were given no deadline to climb back aboard the boat, some people took forever wandering back from the gaol and idling around in the shop while everyone else was waiting. The whole tour took five hours - including the boat ride - it felt too long - lots of hanging around.

Interesting. The boat ride out was fine but the return wasn't. The sea was choppy and the boat made 50% of people sick - although not to blame on the organiser I feel it's important to mention.The actual visit was well managed - once on the island one is greeted by a guide, in our case an ex-convict. He shows around and explains briefly about the prison, the prisoners and life in the prison. I guess it took 1 hour and of course a few references to Nelson Mandela - but don't expect it to be centred around him (which we had expected).The 2nd part of the experience is a bus tour of the east and south side, incl. the village and a number of noteworthy locations. Not too long neither, just right.If you have 3-4 days make Robben a part of your visit to Cape Town. If you only have a weekend don't. In total the visit lasts 4 hours (it took as 45 min to get through security and board the vessels) and the sailing time is 30-45 min each way.

A classic piece of history of political repression in the 1960's - maybe not for everyone. At first glance this barren piece of scrubby island with small buildings one would not expect to be a major attraction. Add in its political historical context as the incarceration site of South African black activists in the 1960's , particularly Nelson Mandela , and this has become something of a pilgrimage site. It is not as spectacular to see as Alcatraz or the Chateau d'If but has strong historical interest.Since ca 1994 it has been a heritage site museum for the politicos held under the Apartheid regime.We had booked our tour from the UK and the morning was taken up with a visit to the District 6 museum and the Langa township.You can just book a Robben island trip directly at the waterfront area.Suggest you book ahead as demand is high and there is limited space on these old ferries..For the afternoon our guide handed us our tickets for the ferry ( an old convict ship the Suzy Kruger) and we travelled over ( ca 45minutes) to the island and straight onto buses which took us round the island with guided commentary of the islands history , comments on the Prison buildings , the limestone quarries ( hard labour) and a village where ex prisoners and some ex guardes live together now , and some wildlife can be noted on this tour. There are some spectacular views back to Cape Town during the tripOnto a pedestrian tour round the individual prisons , with an ex political prisoner (Ntando Mbatha) as a guide describing his experiences and those of other prisoners.I found this guy very knowledgable and sympathetic .Most political prisoners were imprisoned on a generic charge of "Sabotage" - usually being a member of the ANC or other banned organisations , breaches of the "Dompass " laws , or simply being in the wrong place at the wrong time. Certainly travelling outside of SA without approval attracted prison incarceration.Whilst some may think that the Nelson Mandela cell was bleak and featureless - that is the nature of prisons.There is also an area where penguins can be seen but the timing of the tour ( to get back on the return ship to CapeTown) does put one under some pressure. No sign of the seasls which gave the island its name Robben , from the Afrikaans.So , not for everyone , my wife and I enjoyed it as " an experience" .Would however recommendit to anyone who wanted a historical context to the Apartheid regime and its passing.

Too much time for so little. Our experience was very affected by the fact that our "guide" was impossible to understand. We all felt we got about 20% of what he said. Had that not been an issue it would have been a whole different experience. Riding around the island with someone pointing out the names of places is fine, but not very interesting. The rest of the time we followed this gentleman around and tried to understand what he was saying. With so much to do in Cape Town, our time would have been better spent elsewhere .

Expensive, rushed, disorganised,. Your time on the island is very limited so didn't like the fact we spent 20 minutes on the dock side while they decided how to spilt up the boat load of people that had arrived - it was like to didn't know we were coming. We eventually got on our bus, drove 50 metres to the prison. Meet our guide who started his talk before everyone had got of the bus. Rushed around the prison, back on a bus then a quick drive around the island. No opportunity to get off.

disappointing. Although I do not regret visiting this attraction, I found it very expensive for what it offered. The guide on the bus very very knowledgable but the freed prisoner who showed us around the prison itself was very disagreeable. I would not recommend this to anyone

Long bus ride to freedom. I hope I will be forgiven for tweaking the title of Nelson Mandela's famous book, but the visit to Robben Island is a bit more of a bus trip round the island than the long walk that Mandela described. After a short boat trip from Cape Town (great views if you are not clinging on to avoid being blown over the side) you arrive at the harbour and then the bus trip starts. Make sure you sit on the left hand side of the bus as that is where you will be able to see the quarry and the cave. I would have preferred being allowed out of the bus to see some of the Mandela related sites rather than only being allowed out on the beach to look at the view of Table Mountain across the bay. The prison itself is very moving especially as the guides are former prisoners so are able to give a real first hand account of life in the prison. Be sure to read the accounts printed on the walls of the cells, some real insights into what the prisoners experienced.

A must see. We went on a beautiful day with pre booked tickets, the sky was blue and the sea flat calm. The first guide who took us around the island in the bus was softly spoken and a little hard to understand but we got used to him. The island itself is bigger than we expected. The second guide brought us around the cells and gave us a good insight into prison life, he also explained how he was kidnapped and ended up there.Well worth a visiting.

Very interesting. After a bit of a rough boat trip to island, we were met by a very friendly informative guide who took us round island by bus. We then alighted at prison to be escorted round prison by ex prisoner. Quite awe inspiring experience. Beautiful views of Table Mountain during return to main land.

Worth the trip if you can get past the inefficiency at the visitor's center. The island tour was very good and worth the effort but be prepared for possible hassle at the Visitor's Center. We had tickets for the 3:00 boat. After going thru a security scan and metal detector we are moved into a holding pen where we think we are waiting for the ferry boat. For some unknown reason they then herd us all across the waterfront area and split the group between two private tour boats. No explaination was offered if this was normal or not. After a 45 min ride in fairly rough seas we arrive at the island. It’s much bigger than expected. A bus tour takes you around the island – to the farthest point where there’s a lighthouse and beautiful view of Cape Town. The bus tour ends at the maximum security prison for a walking tour of this section. Our tour guide is an ex-inmate. He explains life in the prison, we see his cell and the cell of Nelson Mandela. Also visit other locations within the prison. The boat ride back to Cape Town is in VERY rough seas. Rough seas are common so be prepared. The boat seems overcrowed and I'm uneasy it can accommodate this many people and the high waves. (In the US boats would not sail in these conditions.) We make it back safe but it was a scary boat ride for many people that day.

Guide let us down badly. Book ahead if you want to take the trip to this iconic island prison. The boat ride and trip around the island were great with some beautiful views of the mountain and Table Bay. On the way back the sun was just right to show us the optical illusion of the Lions Head with his body and paws. The prison was an anti climax, we were brought around by an ex political prisoner who no one in the big group could understand. Other people on the boat had a better experience but we felt very let down. It's a trip you probably should do but you will coming back wondering if it was really worth it.

Robben Island Prisoner number 46664. We had a weekend in Cape Town and on the Saturday, managed to see Cape Point and the Cape of Good Hope (using Baz bus Tours...excellent) and then going up Table Mountain to watch the sunset in the evening. This left a morning where we decided to go to Robben Island. We arrived at the ferry terminal to be told the trip was completely full which was very disappointing. We were asked if we wanted to wait and see if there were cancellations, which we did and there were and we were really pleased. The trip to the Island was cold, so try and take a jacket. We found the trip well organised and interesting and worth going once in a life time, as it gives you a small insight into the historical aspect and the harsh conditions and sentences that Nelson Mandela and all the political prisoners (and other prisoners) had to endure.

Waste of money. Heading on a dodgy boat over to Robben Island I had great expectations of Robben Island ... I was left disappointed. You were not allowed to get out of the bus to look or take photos of anything. The two stops you were allowed to get out of, 1) cafe: They had no coffee! 2) Mandela's jail just seemed so staged. The guide (apparently a former prisoner) was hard to understand (even as a south african!) and he didn't wait for everybody to arrive, he just talked regardless of wether the whole party was there or not, and when asked to repeat what he had said, he said that there wasn't time.... probably because he couldn't be bothered as this was the last of the day. He clearly couldn't be bothered. Views were bias not balanced. The boat trip on the dodgy boat was fun in the high winds - if you are one that likes a bit of fun that is.

Harsh treatment of political prisoners brought to life. The boat trip takes about 45 mins each way and so if, like me, you suffer from motion sickness you might want to take precautions - even on the still waters the day we went I ended up feeling a little queasy. But it was all worthwhile as the tour of about 2 hours was fascinating. When you get off the boat they direct you to a bus tour where they show you various sites including the lime quarry where they were made to work. There's a stop at a shop for a quick drink or ice cream then on to the prison where an ex-political prisoner shows you round and tells you about the harsh treatment and brutality they had to endure. An amazing afternoon topped off by seeing seals on the journey back.

Robben Island. 3 vessels now take trippers out to the island. If you book on line and the trip is cancelled you get refunds ar rhe ticket office beside the yellow clock tower on the V & A. The ticket office tends to be busy and the provider advises 30 min attendance before departure.
The Robben Island website is helpful...

A historical island. A place worth visiting to get a feel of human endurance and willpower. Nelson Mandela and his colleagues and before that leaders from the 1800s and lepers were housed in cells of various sizes. The history of Robben Island is aptly displayed at the ferry start point at Cape Town harbor through images and descriptions.The ferry ride although only takes one hour but depending upon the waves can cause nausea to some. The tour guides on the island are ex-convicts and the information provided by them are of first-hand experiences. The trip is not complete without visiting Cell No. 4 in which Nelson Mandela was housed.

This is a "must"when visiting Cape Town. We took this tour on our second visit to Cape Town. The first time the weather did not permit the boat trip. The boat trip is great and the tour is well done, both fascinating and disturbing. There is a bus trip around the island with a former political prisoner giving an actual tour of the prison where Nelson Mandela was held. We appreciated his intimate knowledge. It is a piece of horrible history we all need to experience, so it is not repeated.

Slow start but picked up. first of all, dont go if its windy or rainy as it gets VERY choppy on the crossing!started slowly on a coach and then at a rest stop but the tour of the prison by an actual ex-convict was brilliant and informative. highlights include tortoises wandering around and the prison tour

Nice to have seen. To be honest, the trip was a bit boring. It takes quite some time to get there and to get back and the procedure to board is not exactly pleasant. It's a good experience to have seen it, but it's not awesome...

ABSOLUTELY RECOMMENDED. Robben Island is a must see when visiting South Africa. The tour guides are former political prisoners who were imprisoned with Nelson Mandela. They recounted their horrific experiences and gave us a history lesson you could never learn in a book. This is definitely one of the highlights of the trip. Beware: Depending on the weather the ferry may be postponed by a few hours or for the day. Fortunately it was a beautiful day when I went but people warned us about this before hand. Don't let this discourage you, definitely worth the trip anyway.

So much history...so badly organised!. The museum on Robben Island is such an important part of South African history and provides a great opportunity to learn about the wrongs of Apartheid. We were extremely disappointed as the tour was rushed and controlled. You are shuffled around from the ferry, onto a bus, into the prison and back onto the ferry, leaving you frustrated as there are many stories to read and things to see but very little time to take in the experience. This tour is very badly organised, delayed ferries and we felt like we were on a conveyor belt! I do not recommend this tour until the organisers improve the time for visitors to soak in the experience. Stick to seeing the museum at the VA Waterfront, you will save yourself time and disappointment.

Humbling experience!. The two of us went to Robben Island on October 14th and it was a humbling experience. It's best to go as early as possible and book well in advance, as it gets very busy. We both felt that the tour round Robben Island was good and to see where prisoners were kept, especially to see Nelson Mandela's prison cell was incredibly moving. The people who do the tour around the prison cells were in prison the same time as Mandela. To hear the way in which the people were treated was mortifying and incredibly sad, especially the gentleman who took us around and told us of his experiences. Overall it wasn't the highlight of our trip to Cape Town, but it was something that has to be done when visiting Cape Town, as learning the history of what had happened will stick with you forever. This is a must when visiting Cape Town and we both feel privileged to have learnt so much from Robben Island, RIP Mandela.

A Testament to the Human Spirit. I walked where Nelson Mandela walked and through his peers was given a glimpse into his and their lives during their years of confinement. For me, it was an uplifting and humbling experience. An amazing example of someone who was unwavering in their beliefs and went from being imprisoned to becoming President of a Nation. Now, that's impressive! This tour had a huge impact on me - There's a lesson for living and mankind here.On the more practical side, you can book your tickets on line to save time before going and if the tour is cancelled due to inclement weather, they will refund the tickets. We went in the late afternoon so we had beautiful views (+ photo ops) of Cape Town/Table Mountain in the daylight going out and at night (with the lights of the city) coming back on the boat. It can get very chilly and the swells can get quite big so dress accordingly and Gravol might be in order for some.

Visit to Robben Island. Although I had been there before, I felt it important for our son to experience this part of South African history. We had booked tickets beforehand, but the visit got postponed twice in two days due to bad weather or other. Communication and customer service not always very efficient.

Day on the water and in a bus. I went over in the early afternoon and enjoyed my trip but it did have it's pros and cons. First, you get in line at a museum to get your ticket and walk through security and then they take you outside of the building and on a long walk to the loading dock out in the open. What was the point of security? The boat trip afforded great views but can get a little wet.The island was very pretty and full of wildlife but unfortunately you are on a bus almost the entire time and can't wander around to take photos or look at anything up close. I suppose this is because people still live on the island but it was a disappointment. The tour with the guide was interesting, he was student protestor who got 5 years in prison for his political activity. Yes, his accent was a little hard to understand but it was a unique experience. Go if you want a day on the ocean and to learn more about Nelson Mandela and the uprisings.

Only if you are deeply interested in Nelson Mandela and apartheid. As per subject line, but even still it was an average tour at best. RI is a fairly low tech prison, and when you think about it you're basically taking a long ferry ride to take pictures of an empty 4x6 cell of Nelson Mandela. The tour guides generally have extremely thick accent and was difficult to comprehend even for a local person. Some of the guides are actually ex-political prisoners who are now shaking down tourists for tip money.

Let down - expected more . We visited Robben Island with friends and our kids. I was disappointed with the logistics of the trip as well as the actual Prison tour. Our guide made it clear to the group that he did not want to be a guide but had to swallow his pride to put bread on the table. The trip per boat there was not well organised. Although we had bought tickets online. We arrived and were taken through security control bout bags were scanned. We were then escorted to another small room. We were then told that we would need to take a boat from the other side of the harbour. They let us out of the secure section and we walked back to the waterfront to another dock. So much for putting our bags through a scanner. The island is full of litter and everything looks old and shabby. The bus tour of the island was the only part of the tour we enjoyed. Definitely not a trip to take with younger Children. From boarding to coming back from the island took 4.5 hours

Tried to visit unsuccessfully. Turned up expecting to be able to buy a ticket, to be told that no spaces available till 2 days time (when I'll be on a plane to Europe). The guidebooks did indicate that booking was advised at busy times, however as I did not think that this was a busy period I did not book.The museum about Robben Island beside the ferry stage was very interesting and then I went up Table Mountain which was worth doing.

Day trip,. We bought tickets in advance, thankfully. Arrived in good time and left late. The tickets said leaving at 1.00pm and return at 4.00pm. Hmmm. We left 20 mins late, and arrived back at 6.00pm, an hour late. We had a brilliant guide called Kent on the bus and he was so informative, didn't um or err the whole time he was talking. He even got the bus to stop so we could see a snake on the road. The only reason I haven't rated this higher is because we could have done with so much more time on the island and the ex prisoner who spoke to us in the prison had a really difficult accent to understand even my SA son in law said he was quite incomprehensible at times. However glad I went.

Expected more.. this is one of those things tourist want to see, however, just like the castle of good hope it is an eyesore as nothing is properly maintained. Staff are not neat and are unfriendly. Information shared by guides are basic.

Tour fantastic transport terrible. First thing to say is that the actual tour of Robben island is terrific. Ken took us through the prison and talked in a very personal and emotional way about life in the prison. This was amazing as Ken had been a prisoner but felt that he had to return to help guide these tours to make sure the true story was told. On the negative side the ferry trip on the sea princess was horrible. More tickets than seats sold so at least 10 of us had to stand on the way there or back or both. We gave up seats for two elderly ladies to make sure they were safe no assistance seemed to be offered.If you have a mobility problem this trip could be challenging. The final straw was that the passenger gate was not fastened when we left to travel back. We closed it ourselves to make sure there were no accidents.Long and short the island is somewhere you definitely should visit. Try not to let the transport to and from spoil the visit sadly even the guides on the island start the tour with an apology about the ferries so it was not a one off situation.

Social History, how not to treat people.. It was a step back in time to a much darker place. Very important that every one takes 'this type of tour' in order to ensure that society keeps our darker side under control.The fact that the tour is by former prisoners makes it more interesting. The prison displays and explains how life was, and the cruelest part was the Island was within sight of Cape Town.This visit is not about Mandela but about a period of social history in SA. Well worth the cost and time.

what a let down. Went on trip to robben island during stay in cape town before driving garden route. We found the whole trip to be disorganized and chaotic. Didn't get of to good start after being herded into a crowded terminal building awaiting departure to be told ferry had broken down and we would go over on a glass bottom boat they had borrowed. Crossing was rough and took 30 minutes longer than normal. On arrival chaos resumed as nobody was around to tell us where to go and it was generally follow someone else that led us to board some overcrowded coaches. Coach journey round island was uncomfortable and tedious to say the least. The visit to the prison was the only part with any interest . Had been told this is one of the things you must do in south Africa but were very disappointed as were other people we spoke to. Give it a miss.

That is the history.... We got so much for so little price! A boat trip there and back, a trip around the Island with a guide in a bus, a foot trip around and through the prison area also with a guide who was sooo enthusiastic and it was great to listen to him. We realized a lot of things and facts. We also saw the seals and penguings in the wild! WOW!

You will gain insight. I feel that if you want to understand as much of the South African historical picture, this is a must see. You can read about Robben Island all you want, but being there to see the facilities and the quarry and to listen to the primary testimony of a political prisoner will shed a whole new light on your knowledge of the situation. I would warn you to get these tickets weeks in advance. Also be prepared to have your trip canceled due to wind or weather conditions. They will give a full refund.Another caution is the trip. We were in an old boat, the Susan Kruger, and half the people looked sick going and coming due to the huge waves. Take some Bonine before you go.When you arrive, you board a bus with a local resident who explains the town and what the buildings are used for now as he also explains some of the history of the prisoners. You will then meet with a former political prisoner in an area of the prison who describes the untenable conditions and treatment, Many people, including myself, did not know that people suffering from mental illness and leprosy were also imprisoned here. Made me think of the Nazis.Will history ever stop repeating itself?

Really enjoyed the trip. Firstly make sure you get to the ferry terminal on time. We were booked on the 11am and luckily checked what time we had to be there (10.20am) as had we been later we would have missed the boat as it left at around 10.40am.The ferry over was nice and comfortable and on the way we were lucky enough to see a Southern Right whale, a dolphin and a seal! On arrival you get loaded onto a coach and drive round the island for a while being told about the history. You also make a quick stop at a shop if you want some food or need the toilet. Our guide was Kent and he was really knowledgeable and entertaining. If you enjoy this then make sure you give them a small tip.We then went into the prison and were taken round by an ex-prisoner. We were able to spend enough time looking round before then walking back to the dock. We thought this was a really interesting trip with the right amount of time to cover everything you needed and I would definitely recommend it.

historic and very interesting. The historical importance made it very interesting as you toured the actual prison and viewed Nelson Mandela's cell. The tour was guided by a former political prisoner who gave personal, first hand information, and also could answer people's questions from his own experience. The island itself is interesting as it is now a small town with residents who work and live there.

impressive historic site. To see by ourself the prison in which Mr. Mandela suffert so many years and to get backround information through a guide, who was once a prisoner at this place, is very impressive and may change your thinking. Book in advance, othervise you won't get your ticket for the right day!!

So Badly Organised. I bought tickets online two months in advance for this trip and it was very straightforward. However that's where it stopped. We arrived half an hour in advance of departure time as requested and then stood on a stairs in a very poorly organised waiting area. No seats. No crowd barriers. No information. At the scheduled departure time, we were told that the ferry was running ten minutes late and that the return ferry would be extended to take account of this. Half an hour after the scheduled departure time, the ferry docked and everybody disembarked. It was then announced that the ferry had been cancelled. The skipper had just decided. Mayhem then ensued as people asked about refunds and rescheduling. There was one person at the cash desk to refund the entire boatload of people. Very disappointing service. We can understand that bad weather happens but letting customers sit there for a precious hour knowing that the sailing won't happen is just cheap service and unforgivable. We never got to Robben Island and still await our refund (one week later)
Robben Island. It was inspiring to see where an Icon spent much of his life then to run the country. I would recommend it.

Deeply Moving. Like most people of my age group we were well versed on the history of S.Africa and the apartheid regime that governed the island, but this was only something that happened halfway round the world. Despite seeing all the documentarys and films that have aired since the end of that terrible time it still remained distant. That was until I visited Robben Island, the ferry ride is on a bit of an outdated vessel thank goodness the weather was kind on arrival you take a bus tour of the island. which is reasonably interesting but not why most people come to the island the buses are old and they pack you in. Once in the Max security prison you get what you came for, the guide is an ex political prisoner and he will tell you his story and the story of the facility. Yes it is political but propaganda I don't think so or perhaps I had a moderate ex prisoner, I come from a country which also suffered years of violence and had it "troubles" and in Northern Ireland there are politicians who today compare themselves to those that suffered in Robben Island Max Security Prison well all I can say is they should hang their heads in shame no matter what they believed their cause was or how unjust their convictions they did not suffer anything remotely like that island. It was a great experience a crabe to see first hand and hear the stories.

Thought Provoking. This is one of the most thought provoking experiences that I have had. It is an organised tour which means you have a guide that provides all the information. Part of the tour is with an ex-political prisoner which makes the experience all he more personal. I highly recommend this, but pick a day were the weather is good so that the boat crossing is not too choppy and so that you can see Cape Town from the island.

Thoughtful Tour. We made sure to reserve some time in our Capetown stay for a Robben Island tour.It's an hour ferry ride out to the island. Once there you embark on buses for a tour of the island hearing about some of the island's history along the way.It was a leper colony and insane asylum prior to its use as a prison. Also heavily fortified during WW 2 against German attack.The tour of the actual prison building where Nelson Mandela was held is the high emotional point. Especially because it is guided by a former prisoner from the apartheid era. He has detail from that time that is incredibly engrossing.Time goes by quickly and the last part of the tour is the walk to the pier, which is in fact the same walk to freedom that prisoners lucky enough to be released endured.The whole tour from start to finish runs about four and a half hours.A bit of a mixup on ferries on the way back with a lack of coordination for passengers knowing which boat to attend.All in all if you are a student of history a must do.

A once-off outing. I had guests from USA in my B & B and decided to do this outing with them. Everything went smooth with the booking and all the procedures going with that. The boat was not completelyup to standard and the seating were limited. The tour around the Island was quite interesting, though I thought they could do a bit better. We did not really enjoyed it but thought it was ok seeing to get to know the whole history behind it. Unlikely going up Table Mountain, this is definitely an outing to do once only and there should be no reason to repeat it.

Disappointing........ I think Robben Island is a "must see", when you go to Cape Town, especially so soon after Mandela's death. I am sure if we had to do it over, we would again.The ferry ride over is pretty boring. Our boat was packed and so we ended up sitting inside, where the there was lots of room. Outside standing room only and it was a very hot day. Little problem with organization when we got to the Island. They were short of guides and so we were divided into very large groups and we visited the prison first. This part of the tour is quite short. At first a description of the prison by a former inmate, who is still very angry about the current situation in South Africa. Then we saw Mandela's cell. Then we had a bus tour of the island. The bus was quite full. Couples actually had to split up as there were not enough seats for them to sit together. We had a quick stop and when people asked how long before the bus would leave, the bus guide told us not to worry about the time as he would find all of us. The washrooms were limited and so most of the stop had been spent standing in line for both men and women.One couple had to chase the bus to catch it as we almost left without them. It was obvious that there were empty seats and so people that were missing. I guess the guide only was interested in finding the people standing outside, anxious to get back. There wasn't much else to see on the Island. The quarry where the prisoners worked and the Leper graveyard and that was about it.If it wasn't for the historical significance of Robben Island, we would have felt that it was a waste of a full morning of our vacation.

Far too political. The ferry to Robben Island (if it actually works - often it's out of action due to some malfunction) is fun, especially on the return trip with the summer South-Easter wind! Be aware, if you're on the bow, you WILL be soaked!But the island museum itself is a sad propaganda machine for the country's ruling party. Yes, you see Madiba's cell, but they've grossly over-politicised it to the extent that it's actually nauseating.If you know only a little or nothing about our history, you'll probably not notice this, but having grown up here I assure you it's very much a propaganda exercise to belittle and defame white people and garner support for the ANC.Terribly sad, because the island has a lot more to offer than politics. It's a natural paradise, and has a powerful history that deserves a fair commentary from the guides.

Educational, Something to See, but.... I learned a lot, but my favorite part was probably the ferry ride over and back. On the actual island, the prison tour with a man who had actually met Nelson Mandela and who had actually been a political prisoner in the prison was VERY INTERESTING, but the bus tour around the island was a little boring. In the prison, you get to see Mandela's actual cell. We had bought tickets in advance through a travel agency in the states, so we were a little confused about where to go initially and where to stand to get onto the ferry. That was a little stressful, but this is definitely something worth doing.

Depressing!. Well preserved but that kind of makes it a bit "staged". Did not remove from the sense that humans can just be so mean to their fellow humans. Luckily, unlike Cape Coast in Ghana, it did not make me feel that the Caucasians were just mean.The thought of people imprisoned just because - black, white, Indian or mixed race - just depressed and saddened me, and reminded me just how tenuous societal balance is.
Amazing tour. One of must see destinations in Cape Town. Great experience and visited Mandela 's secret garden was the highlight of the tour... Amazing experience with an awesome history ..

Worth a visit from a historical context. The boat ride to and from the Island is the bulk of the trip. The museum at the waterfront could be expanded to include so much more. Once on the Island you are given at our of the island on buses. The buses are not very viewing friendly if you are on the opposite side of the bus from the site. After the bus tour you are given a tour of the prison site by an exploits all prisoner. Obviously pretty cool and moving at the same time. Once this is complete you only have about 10 minutes to get back to the boat. Having more time to take in the history and significance of Robben Island would go a long way in my opinion.

Robben Island. The visit and the tours on the Island is well organised and the guides are well spoken and informed. However the organisation re the boat trips there and back has much room for improvement. If only they speak to people and explain their problem with a broken boat it will leave visitors with a much more positive memory. The marching of visitors through the waterfront to catch another boat with no help to the elderly was not what I would expect from the operators. Please remember all those people you shunt around are paying customers and might have waited and planned for days or even years to go to Robben Island. Please help to keep us proud South Africans and ensure we treat the visitors like Madiba would expect us to treat others. Make him proud …I know you can if you are all committed to making sure everyone have an unforgettable trip to the Island and back.

Robben Island - A Must Visit. Cape Town is a beautiful city with an amazing mountain as the centre piece. But Robben Island is a definite place to visit for the historical aspect. All tour guides are ex inmates so the stories they provide are factual, chilling, and heart wrenching. Do not miss this!

Interesting place. Worth the visit to get an insight into the lives of the prisoners here. I have to say I thought the museum at the docks was more interesting than the actual prison! My guide was a previous 'inmate' whogave quite a good idea of what life was like at the prison.
Awesome. It was full of history . The guide was an ex inmate and he described the conditions which was touching . A lot was said about Nelson Mandela which was nice

Great day out. There was a review on Carte Blanche that this was a bad experience. I thoroughly enjoyed it the trip on the boat and the tour. They do need to get a bit of technology in there. parking in the clock tower was exceptionally expensive.

Great Tour. I visited Robben Island with a group of four friends. We all purchased our tickets online for about $30 USD, this includes the ferry ride to make it over to the island and your tour. https://www.webtickets.co.za/events/big-6/robben-island-museum-tour/76219. I suggest you get your tickets as soon as you know what day you'd like to visit. We wanted to go earlier in the week during our visit, but the days we wanted were sold out.Keep in mind that the ferry leaves the port at the time listed on your ticket! Give yourself plenty of time to get there and board. I would recommend 30-45 minutes prior to the departure time on your ticket. We did not do this and ended up having to run through the terminal and to the ship! They will let you know when you need to return to the boat for the return trip. As far as security goes prior to boarding the boat, it was not a big deal. You walk through a metal detector and they check your bag. The ride over to the island was not bad at all, but it was very choppy on the way back. It is a scenic ride though and if you sit outside you get beautiful views of table mountain.When we got to the island we walked over to the prison where we met our guide. All the guides there are former political prisoners. He shared his personal experience and knowledge of the prison with us while the group was seated in one of the cells (tour groups are about 30 people). I'd have to say this was my favorite part of the tour because it really brought things to life and made it personal. We then walked through the prison with our guide. After that portion of the tour we hopped on a bus and drove around the island with a guided tour from the bus driver. There is a stop during the bus tour for pictures, bathroom and snacks. I'm not sure if you can stick around the island and walk around after the bus tour and catch another ferry, but there is definitely plenty to explore if you're interested. Our group was pretty tired at that point, so we got back on the ferry.I high recommend this tour. It will give you a great perspective of South Africa's history and culture.

Service could be better. There was a long line of ticket holders for a one o'clock boat that didn't even board till 1:45. The boat ride out to the island takes about an hour but afforded great views of Cape Town, we sat on the upper deck. Once on the island you are put on a bus and driven around the island with a guide. It was quite difficult to understand what our guide was saying. At the end you get to visit the actual prison with a former prisoner as the guide. This was the best part of the journey. You are only given a few minutes to view Mandela's cell.

Hunker down for the ride. The boat trip has been discussed by many. I was driven topside by diesel fumes. If you are from a diesel dominate area, no problem. Yes the ride is rough. That exacerbates the skill needed to escape.  See reviewers complained about being searched prior to island transport. Consider it meger taste of prisoner screening or post 911 sequela. Smuggling in prison is universal. However, I did not anticipate such prescreening. Our group was extremely honored to tour with a former inmate of President Mandela. He made it soul stirring real. Should not have been surprised apartheid ideation systematically prevailed there (food rations allocated by color and offense). Wish tour allowed a tour of the Steven Biko "cottage" and kennels. Noted an open gate to the area. Tour was quite interesting.  The snack shop is dismal and dark. Carpet smelled of beer. Wondered how fresh were the offerings. Unsure if the decor was by design or neglect.  Souvenir shop is tiny with items you will not find elsewhere. Female bathrooms are scarce on the island. More were available on the dock. A MUST SEE & SHOP.

Go now, while real people have real stories to share. This was the advice of our guest house hosts at the Villa Rosa, and they were right. There's not much to see out there (though the boat ride included being accompanied by dolphins--seriously!--and seals), except for some photo exhibits telling aspects of the story of the Island as a prison. But the story shared by our guide in part 2 of the tour (after you get off the bus and stand around in the rather boring actual prison) was the most powerful part of accessing the history of South Africa. The real deal is in the storytelling...

Terrible service at Gateway to Robben Island. Robben Island and its history is priceless and well worth visiting.Unfortunately, the Department of Arts and Culture is doing a terrible job of managing the Island and its facilities. I took a group of 10 elderly American tourists. We waited in a long quee despite having bought online tickets, not enough seats for the elderly while waiting on ferry. Eventually we went through a strict security check, metal detectors and x-ray scanners for bags. The security guards asked each and every tourist/visitor including children if they had fire-arms/guns. Very valid question, but 5 minutes later we all walked out of the main building through the V&A Waterfront (about 800 metres) to a section of the Waterfront where private boats were moored, to board one of these private boats to ferry us to Robben Island. During the 7-10 minute walk without security, I could have obtained a fire-arm or explosives and nobody would have known. So security at the Robben Island Gateway, who are you fooling. It is a big joke and time consuming. My elderly guests did not appreciate the long walk to another part of the Waterfront to get on a boat. The "new" Robben Island ferry which cost millions of rands and with a lot of question marks around its purchase was on the dry dock for repairs and has been more out of the water than ferrying visitors to Robben Island since being purchased a few years ago.The experience to my guests on the island was good, the site guides around the island and at the old prison were good.The return was a disaster. They overbooked and when the last ferry left at 18h00, we were still around 60+ people who had to wait for a ferry to come from Cape Town. By then the south-easterly wind was blowing strong and the sea became rough. When the Susan Kruger (an old ferry) eventually arrived, we took more than double the time to return back to the City due to the rough seas and strong winds. Lots of local/international visitors got sea-sick. We eventually got back to the Gateway to Robben Island at 20H00, missing our dinner booking.To the management of Robben Island, thousands of tourists both local and international, come from all over the world to visit the island and Mr. Mandela's prison cell. You make millions of rand, please put the visitors first and not money. It is a disgrace. Your staff are all complaining and saying nothing ever gets done.

Interesting. Was very interesting and a window to South Africa's modern history! Would recommend going there tho would also recommend to pre order tickets online because its hard to get tickets when you are actually there :).

Live history.. A boat trip to the island and a guided tour is of great interest. It is made all the more interesting as many of the guides are former inmates, their stories of their treatment as black activists are harrowing. Eighteen years of Nelson Mandela's 27 years of imprisonment were spent on this island. He worked in the lime quarry which is visited on the tour.

Deeply moving but poorly organised. This is as much a place of reverence as any religious site. If you go I suggest:* You arrive at least 30 minutes before the ferry departure time as the queues are long and multiple ferries leave at about the same time.* You not jostle onto the ferry or bus. Sufficient spaces are allocated on both.* You do not talk when the guides are talking.* If you take children, consider beforehand whether they can behave with sufficient respect.* Be prepared to be moved by the information being conveyed by the guides and former inmates.* Remember that this is not Disneyland but a hugely significant place of hardship.* Be prepared for little practical information to be given during the day and accept that the organisation is unnecessarily shambolic.For us it was very rewarding but it was almost ruined by the behaviour of others and the lack of organisation.

Emotional and Inspirational. I had read a lot about Robben Island but nothing compares to visiting. Our guide was a prisoner at age 17 until he was 24 just for being a member of the ANC. He brought it alive as did our bus tour guide. Seeing the place where Nelson Mandela hid his manuscript for the long walk to freedom and the inhumanity shown to these people was unbelievable. How they came out as sane as they are and not bitter astounds me. They are an inspiration to us all. It surprises me to read that some visitors found the queues and the ferry laborious, try doing it in manacles!! We enjoyed the ferry, looked at the scenery and watched dolphins. Next time I moan about something trivial I will remember Robben Island.

Cancelled by e mail an hour out- boked three months prior. We were informed by e mail, two hours before that the boat and trip was cancelled. After booking three months out the best they could do was to offer us a trip 'on Friday'- three days later and one after we had to leave SA.. Not happy. Whilst all the reviews I have read have been very positive, a second company needs to be involved with this?From what I gather they had a full boat and not all of them would have access to their e mails, so they may get a few more zero stars?At least we got two hours notice and didn't totally waste our day in Cape Town and a refund, but we wont to go there now.

A must for every civilised person in the World. Buying tickets, queuing and the boat over are a bit of a chore but after that it was all forgotten. It is much more that Madiba as it is a still inhabited island originally used as a leper colony run by Irish Nuns. Being shown round the prison by an original inmate whose only crime appeared to be he was carrying a knife. A demonstration board for one prisoner sentenced to 18 years who went in on my 22nd birthday and came out the day before my 40th birthday - my main productive years - so the damage that the system did to the country was immense.

Far too expanded - but interesting. 40 minute boat ride over and again back with good city skyline views. Two hour tour of the island with it's history - and 5 minutes looking at Nelson Mandela's cell. I guess with the 80 minutes of boat rides - they had to make the tour long enough to justify it. Most interesting part was when they had one of his fellow prisoners guide the tour through the Prison. Keep a sharp eye out for the Penguin Colony on the island.

A must see if a South Africa history buff. A short ferry ride from Cape Town wharf. You get a bus ride around the Island with a local guide and then you're let off at the entrance of the prison that Nelson Mandela spent 18 of his 27 years imprisoned. The tour was led by a past inmate that provided first hand information regarding how the prison operated during that period. You see the small room where Mr. Mandela spent the 18 years in confinement.

For Somehting That Should Be Very Powerful - Really Not Great. Late, slow and poor ferry - total waiting, journey and visit time was just short of 6 hours for a just under 90 minute experience.The tour lacks information, interaction, technique and is conducted in a rather perfunctory manner for what could and should be a much more impactful experience, given the enormity of the subject, issues and world resonance.I would however encourage people to go - it is poignant and imparts information that will be new I am sure. Feedback will hopefully lead to positive changes.

Venture to Robben Island. It was a nice boat road over and great views of Cape Town (but keep in mind it does take about 40 min to get there and 40 min back). The experience itself was good, informative, and personal as an ex-inmate is the tour guide. You get to take a bus ride around the island which is nice, but hard to see everything since you are on a bus. I did enjoy the trip and learning about the history of Robben Island, but not sure it's something I would do multiple times.

Needs more investment. We did this trip as felt is would be a moving and educational experience. We were however very disappointed as the ferry took well over an hour to get us there and the tour although good to see and hear the experiences of a real prisoner was not very educational or interactive. Then a bus tour around the island and back to the port to sit for another one hour plus wait to get back on the slowest boat ever to sit outside in the freezing cold. We booked the 3pm boat and got back to harbour around 8pm for a 1.5hr trip! I believe if more investment was made in the ferries explaining more history allowing visitors to walk around more freely, some more interaction this could be a really good trip to explain the important history of this place but also to make it a viable trip and enterprise. X

History from people who were part of it. We travelled across on the ferry from the V&A waterfront the journey takes around 50 minutes. We were lucky enough to see a whale and some dolphins on our trip. On arrival at Robben Island you are brought around the Island on a bus and the guide is an ex-prisoner of Robben Island. You then proceed to the jail and another guide takes over also an ex-prisoner. Listening to the stories of the guides is just slightly unreal they are such brave men to share their stories. My only negative on this trip was the bus tour was longer which meant the prison visit was rushed as you only stay on the island for a limited time due to the huge numbers of visitors.
very moving. we visited this and had or tour with an ex prisoner. It truly was moving seeing how people were kept for years and how they were treated, It is worth a trip and well worth the money.

Insult to Tourist and Mandela. It's incredible that such an important place for the entire humanity show us to tourist in a deplorable tour. First if you pay $26 dollars you expect a descent ferry and at least that leaves on time. The part of the prison is interesting and enough, the part to "tour" the island to make time for the next ferry to arrive is a waste. My advise is to arrive to the island tour the prison part first and try to comeback in the next ferry, so you don't have to waste 4 hours.

A must do when in Cape Town. This is a trip I can definitely advise everyone to make. The visit to the Island, prison and Nelson Mandela's cell is very impressive. The boat ride there and back is very nice with perfect views of Cape Town and Table Mountain.

An experience!. Booking this trip was the first thing I did upon our arrival in Cape Town and I was glad I did as I got the only available place that was left for the next few days so I would recommend booking prior to your arrival to ensure a place. The cost was 290R which is the equivalent to 20euro. Excellent excellent value for what was in store.We were on the first trip of the day at 9am and it was perfect timing for the day. The boat journey over is choppy and the breeze also picked up so ensure to bring a jumper! The journey took about 50minutes and overall we enjoyed it.On arrival to the island you are assigned a tour guide and we boarded a bus to begin our journey around the island. This place is steeped with history and is so well preserved, it is like having a flashback in time, nothing has changed and Robben Island is exactly how it was when Mr.Mandela served time there. I found the tour excellent, my only criticism is that we spent much of our time on the tour bus and I definitely think a few more stop offs along the way would further enhance the experience. I ended up taking a lot of photos through the bus windows!!! Stopping didn't seem to be an option. Our tour guide was good humoured also.Part of the tour was with an ex prisoner and he was amazing! He captured the attention of the audience and his story telling was very interesting. Overall I would highly recommend this trip, it is a must do and quite fairly priced. Go see where Mandela spent 18years of his life.

Ticks the box, but a total anticlimax. Though I'm glad we went, as it's one of those things you want to experience, it was just dull and unimpressive!This is such an important heritage site not just for SA but the world and it just did not do it justice. They have just not invested in this place. I'm a civil rights campaigner and I found little to see or help you in anyway connect with the issues and history.The (quick) prison tour didn't tell you anything of real interest and the 45minute bus tour stops were so stupidly quick you didn't get much chance to explore - not that there's a lot to explore anyway and often you just looked from the bus.
