I felt really sorry for the English as a second language tourists (about 50% on the bus) who could not understand anything the tour guide was saying - we struggled.You're better off just visiting the centre in the V&A harbour and doing some reading.Also as a tip if you do go opt for the faster catamaran if you can (there's no specific one you need to get on) - only 30mins and a lot smoother

Better than expected. I had read quite a lot of negative reviews so was not sure how this would go. We had booked tickets well in advance. The boat was a bit late in leaving but it was a beautiful sunny day with a calm sea. On arrival at robben Island we got straight onto the bus for th tour. Our guide was a very articulate Young man who gave us. Quite a bit of history but also a flavour of how things are now in South africa. Seeing robert sobukwe's house and the quarry etc was very moving. The tour of the prison was also good with the main feature being mandela's cell. Our trip seemed to be well organised and I was very glad I'd did it. Overall it lasted 4h 30 mins including the boat. We also saw dolphins from the boat which was an added bonus

Don't go to Cape Town and miss this site!. To see Robben Island and its prison and total isolation -- both in terms of its distance from Cape Town and the island facilities themselves, is to understand the whole history of Apartheid, Nelson Mandela's ultimately successful struggle to free his people, and much else of South Africa's history.Particularly moving is the sight of the actual cell in which Mandela was held for many years, made quite vivid by the extraordinary presence of actual former Robben Island political prisoners who served time with Mandela. They explain what life was like during this terrible years.

Slightly Disappointed. Whilst not being South African, I think much of the significance of Robben Island was lost on us. With it being such an important part of the country's history I feel that a lot more could be made of the place and the depiction of what is was like to be imprisoned there. May be its an unfair comparison but if you go to Alcatraz for example then you get a far better feeling of the place and the history and its representation through the displays.

A Must Visit--but the experience could be optimized. This was the highest priority Capetown site for me but the actual experience failed in some ways. They could learn a bit from Kilmainham prison in Dublin, Ireland or even Constitution Hill in Joburg.As others sited, definitely get tickets in advance. I visited in mid-October and needed 2 days advance purchase for a weekday visit.The round trip boat ride was surprisingly great. Both ways, I was on a catamaran with 30? people. We had spectacular views, including a number of playful jumping dolphins and sunbathing seals along the way. Not sure how I lucked out with the catamaran (the main boat is much bigger) but..if you are in a rush, please note that the catamaran takes quite a bit longer than the main ship. I think it took us 45 minutes going and over 90 minutes returning.The tour, itself, was okay. It felt a bit too structured and hurried for my taste and the information shared was superficial and made the assumption that one already had all the needed background.Upon arrival, we were shuffled on to large busses. They then drove us around the island with almost an immediate 15 minute stop at a snack shop which seemed unnecessary. With the exception of Sobukwe's house and the lime quarry, most of the bus tour seemed optional but it wasn't optional. Also, I would have preferred if we could have gotten out of the bus at both the house and the quarry.After the bus portion, they transitioned us to the main prison. There, we met a former political prisoner who led us through cell block B. His story was heartbreaking and exactly why one comes to Robben Island. Mandela's cell was locked so one just takes a picture during a brief pause outside it.After the prison tour, we were sent on our way. There was no permission to wander about or ask questions. There was no allowance for looking at the photos on the way to the boat or stop into the gift shop. It felt very rushed..too rushed!I have been in South Africa for awhile now so I have a good amount of background on apartheid but I still think it would have been nice if the museum at the V&A had a film talking about apartheid, pass books, uprisings, why people went to jail, and some bios/video footage of prior inmates from Robben island. Maybe some of the material that is in the constitution hill museum (Joburg). I still think this is something every visitor to Capetown should do but I just hope they can optimize it for greater impact in the future.
Impressive. The tourguide is a former prisoner. Very imoressive to hear himtell about life inside the prison on this island!

wastage of precious time, money and energy. the place is over hyped. there is practically nothing to see. Was greatly disappointed. all the prison rooms are empty. no memorabilia, just a few posters which do not impress. the guide was repetitive, making all the more boring

History Personified. This was my third trip to Robben Island. The beauty of having ex-political prisoners giving the tours is that the information primary source information. The only downside is that the truth is in the eye of the beholder and the danger is that some aspects get slightly skewed. A worthwhile trip none the less.

Ferry ride with a short bus tour...purposefully an injustice for a UNESCO World Heritage Site?. Oh my. Words can not express the disappointment for this excursion that was so highly sought and anticipated by our group. With tickets booked in July to ensure this tour was included, we boarded the ferry in September. A beautiful day and natural ocean goers, we enjoyed the crossing, while discussing the history and significance of this opportunity. Then we docked and this is when the disappointment set in..intentional? You decide...We were all crammed into a 60+ person bus and as mentioned if you didn't have a window you missed all the things of significance as the bus toured the island, past the guards residence and community, past the church and infirmary, past the quarry and then a 20 min. stop at a snack shop -we did not come here to eat! - and to photograph the mainland -again not why we were here. We finally arrived at a cell block, but the operator responsible for the island tours did not have a guide for us. Instead an inmate who had another group tried his best to give us a shortened briefing in 10 minutes where we then joined his group of 70 through to another cell block, were we were ushered past Mandelas cell and rushed out the other side so they could put us on the next ferry.Soooooo disappointing. Although glad we went, not sure I would recommend this tour at this time...although upon conferring with our tour company we were advised that the Robben Island tour was up for a new concessionaire. If you can hold out until someone else takes over, it may save you the absolute dissatisfaction that we experienced at this significant UNESCO World Heritage Site or if you can arrange a "private" tour do so!

Fantastic trip. We had to do this trip and it was not a disappointment. The boat ride was pretty rocky & I'm glad we took anti-sickness pills because some people looked grey!The tour was very informative & being shown round by an ex-inmate was an experience. Nice to hear about the island life now as well.A must do experience.

A Must See. Make sure you book this before you go to avoid missing out. It was very informative and though it isn't rushed, there are a lot of people wanting to see this so it is quite structured. You have a tour of the prison and the island. Our guide was fantastic but from what I have read, this can be hit and miss. This trip really does make you think. Not for those who get sea sick though, the ferry ride can be quite choppy.

Must do/must see but leaves a bit to be desired in terms of the experience. I feel bad to give an average review to such an iconic tour. Nothing I say takes away from the suffering, sacrifice and sadness of Robben Island, but I think these points are worth making.Book well in advance to avoid disappointment. We got tickets on Saturday for the following Friday. Be prepared for about 2.5 hours on a boat - we had a beautiful day, but on the crossings (especially on return) we experienced a significant swell - enough to make some passengers uncomfortable. Take sun precautions as there is no shade at all if you end up on the top level.Don't expect to have the freedom to wander anywhere on Robben Island. You will leave the boat, only to be loaded onto a number of elderly buses where you will be greeted by your tour guide. The quality of your experience will depend largely on the enthusiasm and engagement of your guide. Most of the first hour you are unable to leave your bus, with viewing and photography being limited to what can be seen from the windows. There is a brief ten minute stop at the "cafeteria" where you can take some good shots of Table Mountain and Cape Town in the distance. The sense of desolation and isolation is palpable. You will then be passed on to your prison guide, who will be a previous detainee. What you see and hear is confronting - as you would expect. You will sit in a communal cell whilst you hear about the daily life of detainees. You will file past the isolation cells - tiny square boxes where Mandela spent about 18 years of his sentence! A fair amount of time will be spent waiting for previous groups to move on!From there you will walk back to the harbour, where there is the obligatory gift shop. Whilst there you have no idea how long it will be until the boat arrives to take you home. There is no orderly queuing for service, and when the boat turns up there is a general exodus to join a disorderly throng hoping to get aboard. Everyone surges forward only to be told to move back whilst the next mob of tourists disembark - on only one solitary gangway so this takes a while. Then everyone surges forward again! Crowd contol and communication are not strong-suits on this tour!Food and drink available for purchase are very limited. Alcohol is available on board the boats. We started our tour at 8.30 am and got back to V&A at 1.30 pm so taking a sandwich might be advisable, especially if you have kids with you.We were pleased with the level of professionalism on Table Mountain. Some comparable procedures would help a lot on Robben Island.

A must do!. This is a must visit destination for everyone. The site of Mandela's long imprisonment it is important in modern history. The tour commences with a boat ride to the island. This can be through quite large swells, so if prone to being sea sick, take precautions. On the island you walk through the maximum security prisons, going to the jail of Mandela. A coach drive takes you are the island visiting conservation sites as well as the lime quarry where Mandela and other prisoners worked. The guides are very informative. There are shops on the island where you can buy snack food and souvenirs.

A definite must see!. We booked our tickets on-line from Australia before we left and would definitely recommend doing so as otherwise you may miss out. The seats fill quickly and you may not get the date/time you need. We went on the 9am ferry and did not return until 1.30pm. What an experience! The ferry ride was fine, nothing out of the ordinary. But setting foot on the island was surreal. You are first put in a bus and taken on a short tour of the island (surprisingly, there are quite a few houses on the island where some of the staff live). Then it was onto the prison. The tours are actually conducted by previous inmates of the prison - those that were held there as political prisoners. To hear and see the conditions they lived in was just heart wrenching. To hear first hand what it was like to be locked up there ... let's just say that the prisoners in our Australian jails ought not complain about their supposed "poor" conditions! To also really understand what Nelson Mandela went through, and to still come out with such a heart for peace and reconciliation, it brings tears to the eyes. It was a wonderful experience and one that should not be missed ... by anyone.

MUST BOOK IN ADVANCE. Unfortunately we showed up at the ticket office on a Tuesday morning to try and get over to the island on Wednesday or Thursday, were advised it would not be possible to get over til the Saturday (which is after we will leave). Incredibly disappointed to have missed out on this experience. Next time....

A Must do - RobbenIsland. But it is not that professional as I would have loved. They guide you within 2 hours through the island and there is no time to think about what has happend on this important place. I would have loved sometime on my own, just wondering around, hearing just the sea and thinking of how people must have suffered, for centuries in a row.They do not give you this room.

Not great. We missed Robben Island last time we visited Cape Town so it was on our must do this time around. Unfortunately, we were extremely disappointed with the tour.The tour comprises of an hour long boat ride each way, an island tour and a prison tour. The island tour takes approximately 90mins on an old bus for the majority of it. The island itself is pretty uninteresting, there are a few stops on the way to the end of the island where you have a photo opportunity of Table Mountain. Once the island tour is over the prison tour starts, led by a former inmate. There is not a lot of interpretation, so it is worth listening. Unfortunately, our inmate had lost his voice and we were in an enormous group (2 tour buses) so it was difficult to absorb what he was saying.After 30mins at the prison it is back on the boat. The whole tour takes about 4-5hours. One last thing, we were made to purchase a ticket for our two month old baby for 120 rand. We travelled all around the world with her and this was the only place where a ticket was needed.
Thought provoking. Wow....just so emotional...to be where Nelson Mandela walked and endured such hardship ...a humbling experience

Book at least 3-4 days in advance!. A tour of Robben Island is a must for anyone visiting Cape Town. Just make sure you book several days in advance! We tried to book a trip on Friday and the earliest we could get in was Monday morning!It's a fascinating trip and as others have said, the boat ride is smoother in the afternoon. Our trip over at approximately 11am was smooth but the return at 3 in the afternoon was quite rough.If you can, read 'A long walk to freedom' or at least try and watch the movie beforehand so that you can understand the gravity of where you're visiting.

Last Minute Tour Cancellation / Poor Ticketing Service. My review is based on the ticketing/customer service, NOT on the Robben island experience itself (we didn't even get that far). We planned our trip to Cape town three months out, and purchased online tickets months in advance. We would be in Cape Town for four days, and scheduled Robben Island for our last day. However, once we got to Cape Town, we received an email THE DAY BEFORE our tour, saying that it will be 'cancelled' (with no further explanation), and that we should reschedule (didn't give us much time)! After calling the given number many times, and writing serveral emails, we were disappointed to receive no reply. We never got there in the end, and were unhappy with the last minute cancellation. Due to frustration, we asked our hotel concierge to liaise with Robben Island Staff. We got a full refund (but would have rather gone on the tour as it was a highlight for us).Tips for management:- If you are going to cancel a tour, please give ample notice. A heads up the day before was inconsiderate, esp. since we travelled 20 hours by plane to get here. - You could have saved us a lot of heachache by rescheduling our tour for us on the same day- Failing that, at least provide an international toll free number for overseas visitors (we didn't have a local SIM card). - We understand that unforseen circumstances do happen, but better customer service would have been appreciated.

Moving & Informative. A tour of Robben Island is well worth the time and money.Our tour began with a ferry ride to the island, which afforded lovely views of Cape Town. Once on the island, we took a bus tour, during which our incredibly knowledgable guide shared the rich history of the island. We saw the quarry where prisoners were forced to work and had an opportunity to tour the room that housed Robert Sobukwe and read the touching letters exchanged with his family. During the second stage of the tour, a former political prisoner gave us a walking tour of the cells that housed Nelson Mandela and dozens of other activists. Each cell included a touching story or description of life on the inside. Finally, we had an opportunity to walk the road of freedom before taking the ferry back to Cape Town. Wear comfortable shoes as there is a great deal of walking and bring a jacket since the boat ride to the island can get cold.

Amazing experience. Traveling to Robben Island and having a tour by a former political prisoner was an incredible experience. Seeing what Nelson Mandela and others endured and the sacrifice they made for the freedom of their fellow countrymen was powerful and moving. Get your tickets in advance online as the number of daily visitors is limited and you do not want to miss this experience.

Must do in Cape Town. Definitely try and get there at least 30 minutes prior to your ticket time to give enough time to walk to the boat. It took us about 45 min to get to the island and about 1 hour to get back. It did feel a bit rushed because once you get to the island you immediately start the tour and when you're done with your, you immediately get back on the boat. Nonetheless, it was great listening to an ex prisoner give details about the prison. Price is about 300 rand aka $30 and its probably best to y tickets online ahead of time.

Educational visit. Very interesting hearing from ex prisoner and the bus tour round the island was good as well if not a little rushed. Pleasant boat journey there and back, saw the sun set over the ocean on the rerun trip.

More than just a island!. Wow, suddenly you put you first step on this island. You have been watching it comming closer and closer sitting in the boat from the main land while your thoughts have been messing with all the story's you have heard and read about Mandela and his time at the island. No words can describe the feeling. Passing Mandels cell, the yards, the quarry,.... I am SO glad to have been here. Visit it back in Feb 2011.

An in depth experience. I took this tour to get a visual for a paper I was right on apartheid. The tour provided a very in depth look into the lives of the prisoners. The ride on the boat to the island was a little shaky for me but it was worth the ride.

Impressive jail. I believe it is very impressive to see where Nelson Mandela has been imprisoned for such a long time. After that you understand how difficult it must have been to come out of prison and not want to kill all those people who brought you and your friends in.

Deeply Moving and Not to be Missed. It would have been unthinkable to visit Cape Town and not take the ferry out to Robben Islandas a show of respect and solidarity for the struggle that continues to this day in this extraordinarily beautiful country. Our tour guide had been imprisoned in the late 70's as a high school student because of his Anti-Apartheid activities and was released years later as a young man. Both his passion and his ability to forgive was humbling. He now resides on the island full time in order to conduct these essential tours. I was moved to tears when I saw Nelson Mandela's cell and the courtyard garden where he hid his first manuscript in the dirt. It was full of blooming four o'clock flowers when we visited in early April. Not to be missed by anyone with a conscience.

One for the bucket list. Hi have read most of the previous review and mist of the comment read together give a very good overview of the trip to and from the island and the visit to the prison. Like most visitors to the island wasnt sure what to expect. Our group was only 40 in size and we had a great trip in the boat to and from but as other advisor s have said the bost will leave without you keep i eye out for your group members. On arrival on the island you are directed to buses at the end of the quay i did think a few signs at this point would have been helpful. But a wonderful drive around the island about 1 hr in lenght with a 10 min stop for the loo and a leg stretch. Then to the prison the guide an ex inmste gives a really insight to conditions during his stay which he gives during the wall around the cell area. Then the highlight cell 4 mandella s home for 18 years. Like other advisor reported a bit of mixex feelings about this part but a little tip stay at the back of your group plenty of time for extra pictures and you get a feel of yhe place being the last and only person in that cell area . Ok this could have been a little better but the history and importance of the place and the people who were there you HAVE to visit

Mixed feelings. Given the story behind Robben Island it seemed to me to be a must visit during our week in Cape Town and I found it interesting but I'm not sure I enjoyed it.I had booked online before leaving Australia, a good idea because the tours are very popular and if we'd left it until the day we would have been disappointed I think.Boat trip - we were lucky to have a nice trip on the boat across to the island, the boat was in good order, the weather was exceptional so the trip was smooth, only issue would be that the boat was packed to the gunnels.Arrival on the island was smooth with everyone being mustered to waiting buses. Our guide on the bus was a very knowledgeable young man who spoke with a clear accent, something I welcomed as I did struggle with some of the deeper accents in Africa.Now, this is where we get to the bit where I had mixed feelings, I don't know if it's intentional but the whole tour was very regimented, you weren't allowed out of the bus much, a visit at the quarry and a leg stretch at the cafe for 15 minutes - it might be designed this way to make you feel like you are trapped and give you a feeling for how it might have been to be confined here, but that's how I felt. So many excellent photo opportunities and no way to take advantage of it because you are stuck on a bus. I would love to have been able to walk around the island to take some photos and soak up the environment and there might be a way to do this, but not on the tours.The tour of the cells was interesting with stories told by an ex inmate, but because there was a bus load of people trying to listen to his story was difficult unless you were up front.The end of the tour was very rushed as the ferry was about to leave, no time to visit the curio shop and send a postcard to yourself like it was suggested at the start of the tour.I'm glad I went on the tour, would i recommend it, I'm really not sure, as the heading says, mixed feelings!

Poorly run, would re-think Robben Island. At roughly $30 aussie dollars, you would expect better than what the island offered. I don't understand where the money is going to for this as the boat is old & rusted, plus it is overcrowded. The boat ride took us 1 hour to get there from the v&a waterfront. Once we arrived we just got an old rusted bus...We did a 45 minute bus ride around the island, which was good to see & the guide was great. We were dropped to the maximum security prison with probably 100 others, The tour guide is an ex prisoner which was cool BUT we couldn't hear him, The tour group was far too big, he would often start talking before everyone could huddle in so you would miss information. He didn't have a microphone either so lots of people didn't hear his words. We got to see Nelson Mandela's cell, for 10 seconds before people pushing & shoving past trying to get a look in. I wasn't impressed at all with this tour & thought it was a waste of time & money. In total, it took us 1 hour to get there, 1 hour to get back, 2 hours to do the tour then we had to wait in the dark for 1 hour for the boat to arrive as it was late. I wouldn't recommend anyone to do this unless they really are passionate about the history of the island. My recommendation would be to visit the Aparteid museum in Johannesburg & Nelson Mandela's home in Soweto as these were far better & more valuable than robben island. Besides, I could have spent a whole day in the Aparteid museum, it is AMAZING!! Robben Island on the other hand was a let down....The following day, we went on a different tour & were talking to others from England & America (all different ages & sexes), who all had the same opinion as me. They also said they wouldn't recommend anyone to go.

Took ages, few highlights. It took 3 hours before we got to the prison, the tour of which lasted about half an hour. The return trip was shortened only because we ran from the prison back to a boat and just managed to get on board a boat - the faces of those who missed the boat were not pretty. The bus tour of the island is ok but not really necessary and the tour guide (whose name sounds like Turbo) was very good. The guide book says the visit is a 'must' but I'd go by tripadvisor's ranking of 33 to plan a trip.

Great for us but we left some people behind. We both enjoyed the tour. The complaints about the bus ride, time constraints etc. were not an issue for us. Highlight was the walk through the prison cells and getting guided by a ex prisoner. We unfortunately did leave about 30 people on the island at 18:45 and it didn't seem there was any other boat to pick them up?

Must do!. A visit to Robben Island was on my bucket list and on a recent visit to Cape Town we went there. This is a trip that every South African must do particularly if you grew up during the apartheid years. It was an eye opener and very informative. I would have liked to spend more time with the tour guides to learn more. Best experience in a long time!

Great story, but needed more time.. This is a absolutely a required trip! The importance is this prison on the history of the world can not be overstated. The boat ride is a pleasant one with magnificent views. The tour guides are former prisoners with personal, touching, story's. However, we needed much more time. The island tour was interesting and the prison tour was very interesting and touching, but there was not enough time to even read the signs. To the people running the tours: Please add more time!!

A life changing experience. To have had the opportunity of visiting Robben Island and see the prison that held a nation captive...now that was a life changing experience. If you never felt small and humbled in your life...this is the place to start. The boat ride over to the island was already worth the price of the trip...great pics of Cape Town. But the actual tour with an actual ex-inmate of the prison...that was PRICELESS! Every time he spoke...it was like I was literally in the experience. The tour of the island was also a fitting end to the whole experience. Heading back to Cape Town, even though the ride was really slow...gave me a chance to think and ponder. As the great man said, "For to be free is not merely to cast off one's chains, but to live in a way that respects and enhances the freedom of others." Thanks Madiba!

Impressive visit to Robben Island. Very impressive visit to Robben Island. After a bumpy boat ride to the island (which we've been told could have been much worse!), we got a bustour around the island with touching stories about the landmarks as well as apartheid in general. After that, a former prisoner showed us around the prison. Do keep in mind that the tour can be a little rushed in the 3 hours it takes.

A must see. When the weather is good in Cape Town, the first thing to do is the mountain. The second is Robben Island. The ferry journey alone is entertaining (depending on the swell and wind), but the tour is unbeatable. You will still have a chance to get taken on a tour with a former inmate - this is clearly a limited deal. See Nelson Mandela's cell, learn about the atrocities of apartheid and the beginnings of the new SA, and get a sense of hope for all man-kind.Great photo opportunities of Table Mountain too. This is a winning spot!

A must do trip. The guides often have experience working or being a prisoner on Robbin Island. Just standing in the cells and seeing the profiles of the prisoners was moving. The hardship prisoners endured and the bleak conditions were jolting. The guides answered our many questions and were very helpful. The boat trip there was beautiful with the views back on table mountain.

Good insight into apartheid. This is a must see attraction when staying in Cape Town, and provides an important insight into the past.We prebooked our tickets before we arrived and were very glad we did... This tour sells out quickly. By prebooking you can make your way straight to the ferry line, skipping the ticket line up.Unfortunately, the day we went over to the island was very windy and cold which made for a rough 50 minute ferry ride on the original "Susan Kruger" boat that was used to transport prisoners.Arriving on the island you are walked up to the prison and given a tour by one of the ex inmates... Very interesting personal story from your respective guide. And of course you get to see Nelson Mandelas cell.Following the prison tour you jump on a bus for a tour around the island, seeing various points of interest including the limestone quarry where the lead prisoners would work every day of their sentence.Overall, a very good way to spend a day in Cape Tour.

This could have been so much better. During our holidays in the Cape region so far all excursions and tours have been so well organised with lovely informative guides, be it national park tours or private tours. It was really sad that this tour which is a must-do when in Cape Town was so badly organised.After entering the starting point of the ferry our bags were screened and we had to pass a metal detector, a couple of minutes later we were sent to a ferry at the other end of V&A waterfront - which nobody told us, we just followed the crowd- so why scan our bags???The ferry itself seemed to be falling apart and was completely full, however the journey itself was ok with nice views of Cape Town.Once on the island we didn't have a clue what would happen next, as we had no information at all. Apparently we were met by a guide, but no bus was available...we then walked towards the prison and the guide had absolutely no clue what was going on and when and where we would get a bus to take us around the island. In the prison an ex-prisoner showed us around and basically told us the same things as our guide. The bus tour which followed was very rushed and useless...most time was spend at a cafe/toilet stop.Wouldn't recommend the Robben Island tour @ all.

The ferry ride was the best part. Disappointing.. I was really looking forward to this tour however the highlight of the trip was actually the ferry ride there and back.After arriving on the island, we got on a coach bus, a group of about 70, and proceeded to drive around the island. It was difficult to see anything if you weren't on the window. We made 1 stop at a shop where you could take photos of Table Mountain and then another stop where a gentleman that was a prisoner explained the history.Unfortunately, the tour for me was an anti-climax. The tour groups were just too big. The buses aren't really designed for tour groups. Smaller groups, different buses and more stops along the way would be better. We weren't even allowed out at the quarry.I feel like this was more of a ferry ride, with a short bus tour around Robben Island. I hate to give negative feedback, but this is justified.

Somewhat Disappointing. We were warned that afternoon trips to the island might be rough and ours there and back lived up to expectations - still, we arrived ready to hear about the prison and its historical significance. We went on a bus to tour the island first and had an excellent guide, but were able to get out to explore only once. When we got to the prison section of the tour we were thrilled to meet our guide - a man who had once been imprisoned there. The acoustics and his manner of speaking made us miss most of what he explained and we were quite disappointed. We learned far more about Apartheid and the struggles from places like the 6th District Museum and the Crypt.

To see a prison. I saw the place where nelson mandella's prison was i dont know why a man would spend 27 years in jail in the belief for freedom,he fought for what he believed in but was he correct to do this

a must do. 3 parts to the trip, firstly the cruise to the island (and back) on the way back I was on a smaller catamaran, this afforded better views than the boat out. Secondly the 'bus' trip round the island, on a hot day this was a little uncomfortable and whilst the guide had a nice personality for me it would have been nice to be in smaller vehicles. finally the best part, a guided tour of the prison, our guide was excellent, most thoughtful and insightful, gave us a good description of what life was like in here, again my only complaint was the size of the group (50 or so), in some of the corridors those at the back struggled to hear the commentary and question.all that being said, this is something every visitor to South Africa must do!

a bit disappointed. It started off badly as one of the boats had broken down and therefore we were over 30 minutes late setting out; this was time that wasn't made up. We had to stay in coaches most of the time, only being 'let out' at the end to look around a tiny part of the prison. The guides were very enthusiastic but somewhat unintelligible, following what was being said was extremely hard. We felt this was a trip that needed to be done as part of our stay in Cape Town but it was the one we could have missed. I'm sorry for the negative comments but this could have been so much better.
deff a must in capetown. you have to visit this place if you want to learn about Nelson Mandela's life... The guides are amazing.. most of them are Ex Political Prisoners from the 80's and the 90's

Beautiful, haunting place. We visited Robben Island on the official tour. After the boat over we were taken on a bus tour and then visited the prison blocks. The tour leaders were very informative and I learnt more about the apartheid regime. The tour leaders are all ex prisoners so their testimony is incredibly moving. Go.

Important and amazing experience. This is the place to learn from the past about history,politics and hope!Altho we didn't learn almost anything about mandela himself, the stories of the island are amazing and touching!We even got lucky to get a tour by one of the former political prisoners (he came to visit for the first time since they were released!)You should booked it in advance (3-2 days ahead is ok) because the tours are always full!And, I recommended going on a day were the "sea princess" ferry is available (only 30 min ride and more space on board) + The preferred ride to be in if you have seasickness!The tour is about 4 hours(with the boat rides) so if you go in the morning you have half a day more to travle :)
Journey of Nelson Mandela. It was nice experience seeing cell where Nelson Mandela been kept for many years. Saw Penguins, ostrich.

Very interesting. I found it very interesting and not at all what others have said about it. Much bigger than I thought. Everyone must go and see and hear what happend and what Robben Island was. Not just a prison.

Could be so much better. I was really looking forward to this tour but left it feeling a bit let down...I felt it was very rushed, hardly got time to read all the information in the rooms...I felt there needs to be an interactive element to the tour...There could be a video room with videos of inmate interviews, Sound clips (I would have loved to hear the music from the bands that were created here). Afterall the tour is given by former inmates...If there was video interviews at least there would always be a copy of their experience for the future. Nelson Mandelas cell could have been anyones cell...There was nothing there to show that it was his...A bigger ferry would be better...not much indoor space for the cold days..

Food for thought !. An excellent half day trip and so interesting. The boat over to the island was rather full and goodness knows what would have happened if disaster had struck! But as all went well I can only recommend this visit. Our guide was extremely knowledgeable and made the whole experience memorable. Seeing and hearing about how the prisoners were treated was difficult and made us all think !! The trip back was blowy and a bit wet from spray! If you go, wear something warm and waterproof however warm it is when you leave. We went on the 11am trip and were back by 3pm.

Moving.. As a wheelchair user I was told there were limitations on the ferry arrangements. I was lucky, the right boat was available on the day I wanted to go.Having got to the island it was apparent that my (slightly larger than average) chair was not going to be able to access all areas, however the staff on the island fetched out two chairs of their own. Unfortunately both were broken and so part of the tour (F wing) was a no go for me. Later I went to board the bus tour as I was told the buses have ramped access - the ramp on the one I wanted to board would not come down to ground level and so that too was an opportunity missed. One of the ramps in the exercise yard is a little on the steep side too but not an entirely insurmountable problem.I reported all these problems on the mainland and was assured by a lady senior manager that they would be addressed. Indeed she told someone to order wheelchairs immediately.Even without seeing the whole, I had a sense of the nature of the place and a talk by an ex-prisoner guide was enlightening.

A memorable visit. As an American, I din't know much about the history of aparteid and Mandela's uniques approach to healing a country which was raw with human rights violations. His attitude to his incarceration, most of which was at Robben Island was very humanistic. There are a number of ferries which will take you over. Iadvise the 30 minute one instead of the 1 hour+.

Very Enlightening!. The Robben Island tour is a must do when visiting Capetown. The tour starts off with a boat ride out to the island, then boarding a bus once you arrive. We were able to learn of the various experiences and treatment of the prisoners based on race by our tour guide who was a former prisoner there. It was hard to imagine Nelson Mandela being held in the very small cell that he was in for so many years. You have to go to experience "The Long Walk to Freedom" for yourself. It was very moving and an unforgettable experience!

Historic location. The boat trip was fantastic.The experience of the old prison now an attraction was a lifetime experience.The guide who was a prisner with the world leader and nobel prize winner Nelson Mandelar explanation of their life in the prison was so touching and emotional.A must visit place to those visiting Cape town.

Moving, gut-wrenching, inspiring. You cannot come away from Robben Island without pondering anew man's inhumanity to man. That your guide will be a former political prisoner makes the experience all the more profound. The forgiveness that came later is an inspiration to all.r

A living piece of SA history. Visiting Robben island is a must for anyone that is interested in and has knowledge of contemporary South African history. It was very informative and the tour guides explained the history of Robben Island from its first use as a prison way back in early colonial times,to its use as a leper colony and finally to its more recent use as a prison for political prisoners. After a 45 minute boat ride to the island we were taken by bus around to see Robert Sobukwe's house where he was a 'guest' of the govt and then to the lime quarry where prisoners had to quarry lime. Our guide on the bus was informative but unfortunately gave a very biased narrative of South Africa's political history and never really challenged the current state of affairs in the country whch is clearly not what the prisoners here had fought for - whilst attempting to justify current discriminatory policies in South Africa. The fate of rural Transkei areas was mentioned to justify her view.Taking the tour inside the prison itself was interesting and we were toured by someone who experienced the prison personally. It was very interesting to see the cells and interact with former prisoners.One of Mandela's warders still works on the island and it was great to speak with him and ask him about his experiences and interactions with Mandela.The tour is not cheap at R250 per adult but it is worthwhile and even better if you read up on it before your journey. Go for a meal at the V&A waterfront after to top off a great day of touring.

An experience. . Must not be missed! The guides were great and we really enjoyed learning about about life for the people who still live on the island and of course the incarceration of not only of Mandela but also of our guide.

Great. It was very informative and the tour guides did a good job in telling the Robben Island history. Taking the tour inside the prison itself was amazing and even more amazing was to be toured by someone who experienced the prison personally.

Not to be missed!. This was a very interesting and moving experience. My main complaint would be that it felt rushed. They have so many visitors that you are moved along rather quickly. We had a ex-prisoner talking with us and there were more questions I would have liked to have the time to ask. But all and all a meaningful excursion.
fascinating and important. the ferry ride over is fun...the tour of the islan includes a tour of the prison given by an ex prisoner - very interesting...and a bus tour of the island itself....

An Adventure never to be forgotten...... Nelson Mandela was imprisoned there but it's GREAT FUN and Adventurous to go there.....There's a ferry or boat ride depending on availabiliy......Then a bus ride round the Island to see certain sights....A penguin colony is found there......A Stop-off too at a place to purchase refreshments and souvenirs and to use the toilet.......Then the guided tour of the Old Prison on Robben Island........Very informative and inttteresting......

A place in history one has to see. No doubt that Robben Island is important in the South African history, and it is a place one has to visit while in Cape Town. The tour around the island in the bus and as well the guided tour in the former maximum security prison by a former prisoner, were both interesting and gives you something to think about. Nelson Mandela is an important person, but I think we puts to much focus on him as a prisoner at Robben Island and thereby draws the focus from all the other prisoners.

This company needs competition. While our tickets were booked in advance and we were scheduled to leave for the island at 1pm, we queued for 1 extra hour at the museum entrance and only departed at 2:30pm after getting walked to the boat which was moored 10 mins away from the security gates. None bothered explaining the reason behind the delay or apologizing for it. Once we got to the island eventually around 3:30pm, the former prisoner who showed us around and described his personal experience of living on Robben Island was really amazing. It is painful to realize that our children may not be able to experience meeting such person themselves and his story may no longer be available for future generations. Following on from this touching experience, we were crammed onto a bus and driven around while a "guide" dreadfully gave a very quick learned off speech about the story of the island. We were then packed off to the boat within 30 minutes of getting on the bus and headed back to Cape Town. The contrast between the 2 guides was palpable. It is a disgrace to Madiba's and all the other prisoners' memories that such a poorly organised tour exists. This company needs competition ASAP.

Could be better. There was not much to see other than empty rooms in concrete buildings. Nelson Mandela's cell looked just like every other cell, with some props in it. I think it would be better if it was more like a museum with exhibits displaying items or some signs with explanations/prisoners' stories. On the plus side, our tour guide was a former prisoner from the Soweto uprising.The best part of the tour was the ship ride back to Cape Town, which offers an amazing view.

What an Experience. This was my 4th time being at Robben Island. Every time is worth the visit. Those men were life changers! Mandela and all of the political prisoners showed the world what it takes to forgive others and to bring peace to a land. It was a great way to start my trip. To top it off, the penguins appeared as well!

Don't expect much!. Although Robben Island is one of the "must visit" places in Cape Town, don't expect too much from the tour. I can't believe that they haven't done more with this place! The tour is divided into 2 parts - tour of the prison and tour around Robben Island. The tour guide was an ex-prisoner and he was very knowledgeable. However, we were extremely rushed and literally had 20 seconds to get a photo of Mandela's cell. I felt that there should be more to the tour, maybe more Mandela photos / quotes. An audio tour or some video clips would have made the tour more interesting. Overall, I was a little disappointed. However, the boat trip out to the island offers a beautiful view of Table Mountain and the waterfront.

Really good. The boat ride takes a good while (took us about 50mins) but goes quickly and the view of Cape Town by Table Mountain looks really good from the boat. When you get there you get on a bus and drive around the island first, seeing the different prison sections and having stuff explained by a guide. When you get off into the main prison building a guide comes to you and starts to talk about the prison's history. The cool thing is that all the guides are ex prisoners of the island, so they have their own stories to tell which is very interesting. We saw Nelson Mandela's cell and the prison block where all the political prisoners were kept. It was a really great experience and should not be missed when visiting Cape Town in my opinion. The guides are very informative and friendly as well as happy to answer any questions.

Terrible organization. As advised, I bought the tickets in advance, before travelling to South Africa. Unfortunately the weather was bad couple days before, and they cancelled our tickets at 7am in the morning (via email). The day turned out as forecasted - beautifully calm and sunny, however all tours have been cancelled (we had 1pm tickets). We tried rebooking for the next day however all tickets were sold out, and they do not run a waiting list. We turned up the next day only to experience more of the non-existent organization. There was quite a group of people who came to look for returned tickets. The fact that our ticket was cancelled previous day did not give us any priority, so we were at the end of the queue. However that did not matter much anyway - when returned tickets were brought in - they told that they wouldn't take anyone any way because it was already too late to take any one on to the boat that was still in the process of boarding. But they did not bother informing us at the right time... In the end we took some boat trip from the harbour, saw dolphins playing in the sea, had about 1.5 hour boat ride (with a small group of people, rather than 200+ as on Robben island boats) and feel got a better deal. Only a pity it has wasted our valuable time.
Amazing Museum. We had a wonderful experience at the Robben Island it is a must every Visitor come to cape town really top experience it.

Incredible. To be so close to where Mandela spent a vast tract of his time is humbling and awe inspiring. Been led by someone who had stayed there made it all the more interesting. Seeing the close confines and difficult conditions was hard to take for a day, let a lone 20 odd years, so in that sense it educates well on the experiences of the prisoners

Can you go to Cape Town and not go to Robben Island?. The simple answer is yes, but I don't think you should. The trip over is pleasant, although it could get a little rough if the wind got up. You get a tour of Robben Island itself in your group; we didn't see any ability to wander round on your own, but the guides are ex-prisoners who all have their own stories which are worth hearing. There's enough history to keep history buffs entertained and enough views for others. All in all, a moving experience.

Education about struggles for freedom. Gives a better perspective regarding their struggles,some of the stories that are related by the guides that were inmates there.A must for the privileged few from the west that have taken luxury and freedom for granted.I am glad they decided to leave it as is a testament to their history ,they had option to sale to builders to make money on the property ,casinos etc a choice given to the people to decide by Nelson Mandela.The ride is fairly long on the ferry.Prepare for full day.Book in advance ,daytrips are sold out.Not much food choice ,gets sold out quick at the stops with the number of tourist.

Historical. The island itself and the tour was great, learnt a lot and do avice that you visit. also had a private tour with one of the prisoners who now work as a guide and the idea of being there ad told the story first hand is second to none. Would only suffet that you take own food as the trip is long and so is the tour, their cafeteria was poorly stocked only managed to get chips, drinks (limited options) and chocolates. that was the downside.
Tribute to Nelson Mandela. Ferry trip to the island prison where Nelson Mandel was held. Tour by ex-prisoner was inspriational. A must see for your visit
Do not miss. The tour of the prison where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for 25 years was given by a former prison mate. It was a sobering once in a lifetime visit.

ROBBEN ISLAND. A very bad experience. The boats were rickety, with no life jackets on board, no proper gang-planks to get on, just old tyres to step on to, the whole experience was very badly managed. Ex prisoners gave talks, but we could not hear or understand them. Security was just a laugh on the mainland. The only good thing about the trip was that there was a first aider there to give you travel pills for the dreaded journey back.

Interesting museum but boat trip from hell !. As lots of other reviewers have commented the boat ride over is horrendous. We booked online for a named fast boat but when we arrived we were put on a rusty wreck which looked like an old fishing boat. Nobody cared how many people were put on it and I am surprised that a serious accident hasn't occurred by now. The coach ride and visit to the museum was interesting. Having read other reviews we made sure to be near the guide in order to hear. Whilst in Cape Town the group running the site had just asked for help with funding and organisation so hopefully the place will then live up to its potential and be a real memorial to times past.

Fantastic experience. After reading the reviews on the site I bought the tickets online and I booked the earliest tour - 9am. Both were great decisions! We were up so early that morning that we saw the sun rise over Table Mountain, when our taxi dropped near the Victoria and Alfred area it was as though we were the only people awake. We took our four children aged 9 - 16 and they enjoyed it thoroughly. On the short boat journey out to the island we saw dolphins. As other reviews have described, you then take a bus tour around the Island which was short and informative and helped to put the experience into perspective. When the bus stopped we looked around and took photos of the views, we didn't go to the shop. The tour of the prison given by an ex-prisoner was humbling and I felt that we were lucky to be there, very soon there will be no ex-prisoners there to bring it alive. My children still discuss the visit and I believe that it was a fantastic experience for them. Although Cape Town is a fabulous and beautiful city with loads to do, I feel that anyone who visits the area without doing the trip to Robben Island is missing out on a core aspect of the city and of South Africa. From the nine year old to the 45 year old, we all found the trip to be interesting, informative, moving and well worth doing!

Must Do. There is really no way to truly understand the history of South Africa unless you go to Robben Island. A political prisoner gave us the tour which made it feel that much more real. This is definitely a must do. Bonus: a beautiful ferry ride over to the island.

Alcatraz it ain't. Must book ahead as tickets are very limited with only two tours per day. A long boat ride over with no commentary about the island. The your was given by an ex-political prisoner who was sent to the island in 1984, for five years. It was a good experience and a very somber place to know what the conditions were, this is what happened in my life time and not that long ago. We then did a tour around the island and the bus was not big enough and people had to stand. However overall I would recommend this trip to see how things were not so long ago.

Impressive live demonstration of reconciliation. Visiting Robben Island is a moving experience. The tour guide was a former political prisoner; his story was incredibly insightful in understanding how South Africa has overcome a very deep divide, by dealing with the past quickly and moving forward together. The museum is the best proof, as former prisoners and former prison guards are now tour guides and colleagues. They even live together in the village on the island! The tour guide on the bus was also excellent, explaining in detail the background to some of the key defining moments in the Apartheid period.Check-in was smooth, the ride out was rough due to the strong winds and a rather small boat. The transfer back to Cape Town was both faster and smoother, due to the much larger size of the boat (catamaran).As this is a popular excursion it pays to pre-book tickets on-line (essentially the same site as theTable Mountain Cableway)

Second visit and just as good. As a South African Robben Island is a very important place. My second visit was just as interesting and just as emotional. There have been criticisms of the ferry, museum etc. in the press a lot. However my experience was - smooth, well organised, passionate guides, efficient booking system, beautiful island, important history and overall a very satisfying visit. We watched 'Long Walk to Freedom' for the second time when we got home, which really completed the experience.

A Salt and Pepper Experience. Travelling out to Robben Island on one of the ferry boats used to transfer prisoners was an experience in itself, Seeing Table Mountain get smaller and Robben Island slowly get bigger built anticipation. The tour of the island is managed and informative. Our guide around the prison, "Sparks" was excellent. Not often you get to meet someone who gathered arms and recruited for a "terrorist" organisation. There was an eerie similarity to the welcome above the gate to the prison. It reminded me of those found at camps across Europe... This was just one step away. This is a tour that I would make again.

Great trip. The boat trip is a nice and scenic ride and there are small snacks and drinks for sale while on board. The staff off loads the board and then you are loaded onto a bus that drives you into the complex and walk with a guide throughout. Visitors are able to ask questions and go inside cells that were used as well as take photos. There is a gift shop that can be visited after the tour is finished with souvenirs and drinks for purchase.

Interesting tour and beautiful view. The boat trip to the island is a nice relaxing experience with beautiful views of table mountain, the city and the ocean. The tour on the island is very interesting with knowledgeable guides that can provide you with many extra stories from the island and its history. On the one side of the island is a protected nature reserve, with beautiful plants and birdlife, as well as other small animals. The prison tour is very informative and well administered, and tours inside the prison are conducted by ex-political prisoners, that can provide you with an in-depth account of daily life in the prison.Overall it was a great experience. The only negative thing I can say about the tour is that it is very quick, with a lot of information and sites to be visited in a short time period. An extra half hour on the island would have made a huge difference.Also, as this is such a major attraction in the area, with so many people from all over the world who wants to visit it, the tours are always fully booked days in advance, so check the weather and plan ahead for this one!

Reflective place. I found Robben Island to be very well worth the time. Obviously most people go because of Mandela, however, there are so many more stories to be heard. The sacrifices that were made for freedom are very inspiring. I wish all the guests on tour there would treat it with the respect it deserves......

Interesting just for what this place represent.. From the ferry boat that take you to Robben Island you can have a very good view of Cape Town, but when you arrive on the Island there are not so interesting things to see. It is more important as a symbol.

A mind blowing experience . I have read many books about the African slave trade and how Europeans traveled around the world taking advantage of the cultures and peoples in which they encountered. However, this trip to the island exposed a lot of raw emotion I hadn't thought about in a very long time. I came away with mixed feelings of despair anger and complete bewilderment. How do humans justify treating others in such horrific ways. Don't miss this opportunity.

Historically significant but rushed. We made the trip out to Robben Island, for our love of history and the significance of the sight. The tour its self was disappointing, the tour guide, for a non first language English speaker so heavily accented my husband who speaks and understands English could hardly follow a word. The stop at the quarry, one of the significant spots is so quick you have to snap a picture on the fly by. The jail itself, more disappointment as we got to Mandela s cell, one of the main reason for the visits, it was like were were cans in a factory and shuffled past as soon as possible. Very disappointing. Its like there are so many people and you are lucky to get a 5 sec view and a photo before you are called on for more inaudible speeches about something less significant. Disappointing tour, but humbling experience.

A Very Moving Experience. Visiting Robben Island will make you wonder if no one has ever deserved the Nobel Peace Prize more than Nelson Mandela. You feel like you are witnessing history as the guides in the prison itself are former inmates. It's extraordinarily moving. Be sure to plan your visit for the beginning of your trip as rough weather can cause the ferry to be close.

Humbling experience. Learn all about the severe detentions imposed on non-whites during the country's apartheid era. Visiting Mandelas cell and learning of his experiences while a prisoner there brings humility even into the hardest of hearts. Take kids along, it's a great boat ride over and very educational.

Worthwhile bar the coach tour. Prison tour very informative, and has a strong sense of history. Boat ride is "tourist fun" with excellent views of the mountain, bay etc. Coach tour around the island took up a lot of time for not very much - brief drive by the quarry where Nelson Mandela and others worked. If short of time, you could just do the prison tour and ask (in advance) to catch an earlier boat perhaps - check first that they will do this.

Historic site in need of some TLC. This is a journey that I've wanted to make for many years as, apart from its recent notoriety, my father was stationed there for a short while during the second world war. The journey to the island is by boat and as the newest vessel is out of commission due to an accident some 9 months ago, tourists are taken out in the older vessels. For us it was a piece of history as we went out on a boat that was originally used to take prisoners to the island. The boat was in need of refurbishment! Once on the island you are shepherded to a fleet of waiting buses that take you on a tour of the island. They point out buildings of interest as well as the naval gun displacements, fauna and flora. Our guide was very informative and fairly easy to understand although I was told by some others that this is not always the case. I was truck be the lack of maintenance with buildings showing distinct signs of wear and tear with paintwork peeling, windows broken, fences down and gates hanging off their hinges. The second part of the tour is on foot. The guide, an ex inmate, takes you through the high security wing when Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners were housed. The commentary was good if a bit difficult to understand at times. My main comment is that in a large group you were given very little time to look into the cells and absorb the atmosphere. There is a well stocked souvenir store on the dockside which you can visit before boarding the boat back to the mainland.
In tears over seeing history come alive!. It was an amazing experience. I even met a former prisoner who knew Mandela. Tip: check the weather forecast & go on a sunny day.

Worthwhile but book early. A visit to Robben Island was on our list of things to do while visiting Cape Town. We were aware of the need to book early (on-line tickets sold out fast) but we took a chance by visiting the ticket office early and were still able to get a sailing that morning. As it is a one hour trip each way and about three hours on the island I would recommend the 10am or earlier sailing. The boat trip to the island was good, with amazing views of Table Mountain and the coastline. On arrival we were divided into groups and driven in buses around the island. The sheer volume of visitors on the island was handled well and the drive around the island organised so that groups arriving at different areas was staggered. Our guide told us a lot about the history of the island and we stopped at several places be shown around the prison, including Nelson Mandela’s cell. Our trip concluded with a very moving account from one of the ex-prisoners sharing his story. It was very worthwhile – moving and sobering, but demonstrated the power of the human spirit.

Needs to be organised better . We arrived at the ferry terminal 25 minutes early. The organisation at the terminal was shocking. We were kept waiting and no one told us what was going on. The queue began to move 40 minutes after the scheduled departure time. We were put through airport style security and held in another very small room. Several minutes later a lady said that she was taking us round to the quay side for the ferry because their own quay is under construction. We were then led outside, past the shops and restaurants to a completely different place. What was the point of the security check? The ferry could not have been sea worthy in a million years. An ancient converted fishing boat more like. The sea journey was awful. We were so late that the visit had to be rushed. I felt totally cheated. The thing I wanted to see was rushed and we were just ushered around. The guide on our bus was jovial, knowledgeable and interesting. The ex prisoner clearly wanted to talk but was fixated by the time and making sure that we were back on the quay side on time. He was great and gave a personal insight into life as a prisoner. Such a pity he had to cut it short. The journey back was the worst experience of my life, and to top it off we landed at the quay side right next to the place we had queued at for ages beforehand! No construction in sight. My advice would be to book with a tour group with a good boat not the museum. As a national treasure, the museum really should get this sorted out if the trip is going to survive as an attraction.

wasted opportunity. what a waste of time! not because of the possible interesting experience, but because the poor organisation. the prison tour was given in warpspeed so there is no chance in reading the info in the different area's. there should be an Island tour also but there was no tourguide, before one was available, the boat was already there to bring us back to Cape Town. Therefore a missed opportunity by the organisation.

A must-do!. Robben Island is a fantastic experience and something you must do while you are in Cape Town. Book early to avoid disappointment though! We had no issues with the system - everything was well organised. The trip around the island itself was fantastic and you are guided around the prison by an ex-prisoner. Our tour guide was a wealth of information, and happy to answer all of our questions. This is a must-see for anyone interested in the history of South Africa.

A must see/do whilst in Cape Town.. Visited September 2011Ferry crossing over provided amazing views of Cape Town.We had a guided tour by one of the former prisoners who enlightened us with many stories.The 'room' where Nelson Mandela stayed was a bit staged. I think you may need to pre-book tickets (we did the night before).

A must see!!. Robben Island to this day is one of the most amazing places I've been to. I was a huge admirer of Nelson Mandela, so to be able to experience the history of him on the island was quite amazing. It's a really unique place with a lot of tragic history that is brilliantly portrayed by the guides and the past prisoners.
Great. People there were willing to show us around and explaining what was happening and learning more about freedom

Huge Disappointment. The queue to board the ferry was organised chaos, no one seemed to know what was going on, then the ferries did not look sea worthy and were all running late. So on arrival at the island we were hurriedly put on a bus because we were running late. We stopped at the tea room which was not adequately stocked and the rest rooms were inadequate to cope with the amount of people - only two ladies toilettes, so therefore I did not have enough time to even visit the tea room, although my husband managed but they had already run out of sandwiches. We were then hurriedly scuttled back on to the bus and speedily went through the rest of the tour. When we got off the bus at the prison building there was another guide, an ex prisoner who took us around, but we could not hear the guide properly and he was also rushing and not very friendly, so we missed quite a bit about what he was saying. We also ran out of time to visit the gift shop as we had to get back onto the ferry, as we were told on arrival that we would be visiting the gift shop. On the trip back on the ferry speaking to other visitors we realised that there was a lot that we did not see and visa versa. As a World Heritage site the buildings and gardens are not maintained at all and if no maintenance work is carried out, there won't be a future heritage site. We personally felt it was a waste of time and money, and a huge disappointment.

Great Experience. This is a must see attraction if you visit Cape Town, S.A. The tour guide we had is a former prisoner of Robben's Island so it was - receiving 1st information from a former prisoner who had a similar experience to Mr. Nelson Mandela is PRICELESS!You must take a boat to get to the island......the water was choppy so if you get motion sickness, don't eat before you get on the boat and don't sit on the bottom of the boat.

An emotional, authentic and thoroughly enjoyable experience. Aside from horrid sea sickness on the ferry (in spite of good weather!), we all thoroughly enjoyed our visit to Robben Island. I was deeply moved by the stories related to us by a former prisoner of the island and our guide on the bus was fantastic. Whilst it might look a little grubby, in my view this only adds to the authenticity of the entire experience - I wouldn't want a crisp, freshly painted fake "Museum", commercialised vibe. The people who live and work on the island are passionate about their memories and it is conveyed in their storytelling.

Interesting place - beware the choppy journey and lack of tickets!. Tickets for Robben Island can be booked online, or in person at the centre in Cape Town at the V&A Waterfront. The tickets may be sold out on the day (as we found) so book a few days in advance. The journey to the island, which takes about an hour by boat is VERY choppy, and all passengers experienced seasickness, so take medication if you can/be warned!When you arrive on the island, you immediately board a crowded tour bus (a challenge after the aforementioned seasickness). A guide then gives about an hour's tour of the island from the bus, explaining the history of the island and about some of the prisoners. There is a toilet/refreshment stop half way through which provides a chance to get some fresh air, then back on the bus for the rest of the tour.You get off the bus at the prison building where Mandela's cell was, and receive a tour from a former prisoner, who shows you around the group cells and explains what life was like there. The tour ends with a chance to see Mandela's cell. Then there's a chance to visit the gift shop before it's back on the choppy boat to Cape Town.

Good experience but disorganized. This could be great but they are so disorganized. Some of the buses were packed with people standing for a 40 minute tour and some buses had many empty seats. The former prisoners who are now guides need microphones so that everyone can hear.

An extremely interesting tour, but longer than the guides indicate. My daughter and I loved our visit to Robben Island and were moved by the various exhibits and locations of the former prison where Nelson Mandela was held for so many years. A minor word of caution - we booked a 1:00 pm tour having been told that the tour takes 3-1/2 hours total (including the 1-hour boat rides to and from the island), yet we did not return to port until 5:15, putting us in jeopardy of missing our 7:00 pm flight. The tour was most definitely worth the extra time, though!

3rd visit to Robben Island Museum. I first visited robben Island in 2009.In 2013 I visited twice, with some special people.While the museum and the ferries certianly need some TLC, this does not detract from the visit much.I still find this an emotional and also a cathartic experience.I prefer to do it alone or with special people only.Every African, no matter your race or gender, should visit the museum.I have found each of the ex-prisoner tour guides very sincere, empathetic.I got miffed at tourist for whom this is just a box to tick and for whom the real stories have no interets to them.It was not rushed although there is not much time to really interact and learn more.I will go again this year...

expected a lot more!. With all the hype and emphasis placed on booking ages in advance.... I really expected a whole lot more from the tour. The island is wonderfully maintained, yet the trip out to the island is no where near comfortable. the boat was extremely overloaded, leaving a lot of us standing for somewhere between 45 - 60 mins. The view was off course immaculate. upon arrival you get crammed into (very uncomfortable again) buses and then begins the tour with a guide who, whilst has great first hand experience on and off the island, doesn't really put things forward in a great manner. the thing with great historical sights, it is the guide who brings it alive. this did not happen. also, being South African and having insight as to our countries history, I found myself explaining more in detail to a lovely American couple who kept asking questions but never got answers. I must admit it was a good experience to finally get out onto the island, however if you can't get tickets don't be too disappointed (like I was because this was previously). If you are on limited time, give it a skip. Cape Town has a lot more to offer!

If you do one attraction in CT then Robben island is the only one,. The 40 minute sail on the pirate ship is great the view as you leave the harbor and return is spectacular. Robben island is a history lesson that must be learned, guided by ex political prisoners and guards you get the intensity of what it was like to be there and the inspiration to do more when you hear the stories of a prison community that was restricted and yet managed to operate like a well drill leadership training ground. Not many men could face such horror and manage to come out forgiving and better for it . The island itself is interesting too for the people that still live there .

Wow!. What a most humbling and amazing place- you have no idea of the scale of the place or the many different buildings. The real life stories are amazing and the tour by an ex prisoner who was I prisoner with Nelson Mandela was unforgettable. A truly must see if in Cape Town

Treasure of Cape Town. Going out to see Robben Island is an absolute must for Cape Town visitors. The boat ride out can be a little bit tumultous for those that are prone to motion/sea sickness, but coming from someone who walked off the boat feeling a little queezy, I wouldn't let it stop you from making the trip. Upon arriving on the island you a board a bus that takes you on a tour around the entire island. There are a couple of opportunities to get out walk around, take photos etc. Afterwards, you tour the prison itself. The tour guides are interesting and inspiring, even for those who have little prior knowledge about the history of the island or even apartheid. All in all, it is a great trip worth taking for the historical signifigance of the site alone.

Robben Island. We met Christo Brand who was Nelson Mandela's guard. They became good friends and Mandela gave him the ok to write a book about their time spent together as guard and prisoner. I got a signed copy of the book which I believe will not be available in the US until Nov 2014. Our Robben Island tour was led by a former prisoner so you got the real deal on what life was like as a prisoner. It was a excellent tour and one not to be missed by anyone visiting Cape Town.

Beautiful!. The tour of Robben Island begins with the beautiful boat ride which offers a breathtaking view as you get further and further away from Cape Town. Upon arriving, we were ushered to buses and introduced to our wonderful guide, who was friendly and informative. The bus tour takes you round the island, pointing out points of interest with chances to get on and off to take pictures. However, one critique of the tour is that it did sometimes lack in relevant information. Occasionally the guide will point out largely irrelevant sights or will point out something of great interest and then fail to explain much about its history. However, that being said, once going inside the prison blocks where Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners were kept, we were given another guide who was an actual political prisoner. He was very informative and provided great detail into what life was like for prisoners - this was the real highlight of the tour. Overall, the visit is very worthwhile, but if you want to know a great deal about Robben Island, I suggest reading a fair deal about its background before embarking on the tour.

Stunning. Loved the boat ride to the Island, scenic doesn't give it justice. The tour was somber and informative. The tour of the cells we were guided by a former prisoner which added a understanding of the hardship within the walls of this facility. A must do while in Cape Town.

A step back in time. My visit to South Africa consisted of myself, my wife and eight other friends. We all agreed that a visit to South Africa would not be complete without a visit to Robben Island. We were overwhelmed with this dark period in South Africa's history. We felt rushed and would have liked to have spent more time looking around some of the exhibits. We wanted to know more of the history of Robben Island by studying the panels in the walkway. We wanted to buy some souvenirs but were too rushed that we could not even pay and left the souvenirs there in the gift shop. The fast way we were hustled around Robben Island kept this review from being a 5.

Disappointing June visit. I am a white South African and having never been to Robben Island I was excited and looking forward to the visit. My 2 grandsons from the USA were visiting and had recently done a school project on Madiba so were also keen to visit. Well apart from the boat trip it was terribly disappointing. On arrival we were loaded onto a bus. Our tour guide was Thabo (if I remember correctly). He was excellent and the bus tour not too bad although we could not really see much. We then stopped at the restrooms and were told we have 15 minutes to get refreshments and go to the restrooms. Very little time with 4 busses at the same spot with 2 loos and 4 kids. We then went to the prison. The gentleman basically repeated nearly all the bus guide had told us and we could hardly hear what he was saying (maybe a microphone would help)Cages like dog kennels??? Rock pile??? Story about the Key??? We were then quickly shown Madibas cell and the courtyard. We then had a short walk back to the curio shop (when on landing we were told we could browse a dash) only to be told the boat was leaving.THE LITTER ON THIS BEAUTIFUL ISLAND IS SHOCKING!!! AND AN EMBARRASMENT. Surely a few could be employed to clean up regularly. I am a keen birder and saw a bird I could not ID and only after asking 3 or 4 of the guides I was told it was a Chukar partridge.

Powerful. A trip to Robben Island is well worth it. The tour is fully guided and it that did feel a bit restrictive but that is because there is so much history to cover. It would be great if once a day they offered a longer/more in depth tour that allowed for a deeper experience. The ferry ride is nice and if you are lucky you will see some whales and/or dolphins. The tour begins with a bus tour of the island and then you are passed on to a former political prisoner for a tour through the prison. This is what makes the experience. It is very powerful to get a first hand account of life in prison on Robben Island and to be able to ask questions. Once back on the mainland take the time to go through the museum and the boards that are by the ferry boarding area that are really informative.
Book your ticket. What a trip, just buy a ticket and do the tour. One can say to much but for this kind of trip it is well worth it. Avoid reviews and just do it and then get back to me.
