Madiba's steps. Gut wrenching voyage through the perils of apartheid. The Ferry ride doesn't prepare you for the harshness of this time. First hand account by ex-prisoners as tour guides. Visit cages smaller than dog kennels. Make sure you see the rock pile. My soul was touched by history..

History. The boat ride to the island,the history,the presentation of the life of Mr.Nelson Mendella is captivating in various ways .His prison cell where he was imprisoned for all those years,his motivation to chage the country is what this trip is about and you leave from there taking a piece of history with you .

Island Tour. Had a group of 55 US students for a memorable experience. As we all know the Robben island ferry is out of service and being outsourced. And that's we problem starts . The staff on this ferries have staff tip boxes on counters. And also when you exit the boat they stand their shamelessly soliciting tips from guests which I think is disgusting. I think Island management owe it to sub hired companies that this is unethical to do this practise.Other than that great experience.

I was on the fence - so glad I went!. Take motion tablets if you are concerned about the ferry crossing - some days calm - other days not and other days cancelled due to weather. Book in advance if you can as the trip is often sold out. My day was a calm crossing. I would have preferred more time on the island. Seemed we were a bit rushed to do the bus tour then the walking piece with an ex prisoner. I would like to have had time to walk on my own - it is a large complex. They are talking of expanding to offer overnight accommodation - currently only day trips - weather permitting. The highlight was certainly the walking portion with the ex political prisoner who spoke of his time on the island as an inmate, his release, his healing and his return to Robben Island to lead tours. Tour gives a better sense of how Mandela spent his many years of incarceration.

Great Trip to Ropbben Island. Our tour group coming from New Zealand were not sure whether we would find Robben Island interesting, but we were very glad to have gone there. It was a beautiful days, so we enjoyed the boat trip. On the island we first had a bus tour, with a very informative guide. Then we were shown around the prison by a man who had been sent there as a 20 year old in 1984 and not released until 1991. He was excellent, giving us a lot of interesting historical information and showing no bitterness.

Well worth a visit. Nice boat trip out can be rough at times apparently but was fine when I did it some fairly big waves on way back but the boats big and handled them fine. The island itself is remarkable beautiful considering its history. Saw some of the little penguins which was great. The guides are great and really convey the reality of the island as a prison and brig the prisoners experience to life. The one who did the building a tour had actually been an inmate himself. Just fascinating if sad at times to realise how cruel man can be to his fellow man but it reminds us to be mindful of the dangers of intolerance.

A Sad Story and Place. Robben Island told a very sad story. Many men of South Africa, mainly from Capetown sufferedunnecessarily in this horrible prison. Of course, the tour director made it seem much better thanit actually was but those of us who can "hear and read between the lines" know how badly thoseprisoners lived. Yet, there were some very smart ones including the man who hooked up theT-V to the toilet system as the lights were turned off at ten p.m. but with this hook-up they could watch T-V much later into the night. One smart electrician! Many other interesting aspects of this tour which I highly recommend.

Amazing place. It is a great placem if you are going to the cape of the good hope, stop in here and enjoy of one of the most beautiful penguins reserve in the world, Is really cheap the cost of the entrance just 50 South African rands (5dls) and you can spend a good time with the nature,The souvenirs store is expensive, indeed more than expected.

South African history. I've met many travellers hesitant to make the trip to Robben island. Reasons being unreliable ferry schedules and not much to see. Not much to see? This is recent history affecting every citizen on the planet! On the island our driver doubled as a talented tour leader talking about other prisoners' significance besides from the one impersonating Robben island. Our guide talking us through the prison premises gave a straight forward description of the life out there. There were many families bringing small kids out to the island. In my mind Robben island is not a place to bring children under the age of six. People come to listen and learn not to hear children crying and parents calming them down.

A mixed bag - loved the walking tour. It may appeal to some people but I didn't enjoy riding around the island in a bus looking at buildings. I would have liked to get off the bus at the stone quarry where Mandela and other political prisoners slaved. The 5 star portion of the tour was having a former political prisoner guide my group around the prison with significant stops such as the garden when Mandela had hidden his manuscript and his prison cell. The visit and description from the guide emphasized Mandela's greatness for me. I would gladly do that part of the tour again with a different guide for a different experience of the visit. Definitely worth the trip!

Really Interesting...but bring your seasick pills!. I'm really interested in history, so I like to make sure to check out the most important historical sites anytime I visit a new city. Robben Island was on my must-see list for Cape Town. It was a very interesting museum, with a driving tour followed by a walking tour. The driving tour allowed us to see a substantial portion of the island. The walking tour was quite interesting, especially the walk through the actual prison blocks and Nelson Mandela's cell, guided by a former inmate. It was very emotional when he showed us his own cell. The boat ride was very choppy. It had rained the prior night, so there were some pretty big waves; a few passengers experienced a bit of motion sickness. It's about 40 minutes each direction, so come prepared.

Informative & Eye Opener. Guided by former political prisoners, the visit was very meaningful; the guides professionally related their experiences in very detailed accounts. It was an eye opener and a highly recommended visit.

Robben Island: few hours in prison.... A unique experience visiting Robben Island. First we make a bus tour around the island.The most exciting part is when we visited the prison. The guide was a former political prisoner. This was amazing. Because he was explaining about the prison and sharing his own experience. A lot of emotions. We were captivated by his speech. Definitely a must do in cap town if you are there. Better book I advance. An online booking is available. If you are traveling alone, you can try your luck. Sometime people don't show up and you may find a last minute available ticket.

Robben Island boat trip. This trip was a mixture of good and bad. The experience on the island lived up to expecttions; we saw for ourselves the conditions the captives including Nelson Mandela lived in and the open mines they worked under the constant hot sun. The crossing by boat was dasastrous. Rough sea caused cancellations of two trips in the morning and a knock-on to delays all day. Nobody's fault of course. But the queue was enough to fill 3 boats and we were kept waiting about 90 minutes. Nobody made any effort to tell us what was happening and rumours passed down the line that all crossings had been cancelled for the day. I spoke to the staff on behalf of everyone and asked for us all to be given an explanation. This was done but they told us so little it was pointless. Nobody took charge. Refunds should have been offered to people who had other plans later and to those who would suffer sea-sickness. All very disappointing

A humbling experience. This was just an incredible trip. The ex prisoners take you round and tell you all about it. Mandela's cell was so small.Do visit this amazing place if you are lucky enough to visit Cape Town.

Well organised guided tour. Lovely trip across the bay where you are met on Robben island and efficiently moved around the site on buses and on foot and given a very moving tour by ex political prisoners telling their experiences. Less harrowing than I thought it would be . Lots of students and boat loads of tourists ,take your sun cream.

Educational. This was a very humbling experience, but great to learn about things in the past (even though it wasn't that long ago). We had the chance to have 2 different inmates which both were amazing and made the experience much more heart felt and real. The men had stories, which they made jokes about while they took us through some of their experiences there. It was very worth it. I wish we had more time to explore the island a bit more.

Significant historical place. Robben Island was one of my must do's when I went to Cape town as I know it is steeped in history. The 30 minute or so ferry ride to Robben Island was a little rough. I am notoriously seasick but I did surprisingly well with one of those medication patches you put behind your ear. When you reach the island you are guided and separated into buses and taken around the island for about an hour before you are actually taken to the prison. From the bus they break you into further groups and are assigned guides who are ex prisoners. The hallways are narrow and we had a big group of people. It was somewhat hard to hear the guide that was assigned to us so try and be close to him as you can. He was good at explaining the circumstances that led to Mandela's imprisonment and showed us a quick look at Mandela's cell and even locked us up inside one of the bigger cells so we would feel what was like to be in prison there. What was important was the tour instead of being depressing ended up in a positive note.

A very moving experience. Robben Island was the number one place to visit for me. I have been interested in the political history of South Africa for a long time and therefore was interested in seeing where the former leaders of the anti -apartheid movement, including Nelson Mandela and Oliver Tambo, were incarcerated. I was not disappointed. A very moving experience but a great lesson in understanding human endurance and the power of hope and optimism!

Robben Island. We had to take a fast boat to get there but that was part of the fun, had not expected it to be as interesting as it was. The whole place was fantastic from start to finish. The guide we had was actually one of the prisoners who was held with Nelson Mandela and the others. He was so interesting that the whole tour went over so quickly and we learned a lot of history about the island and the prisoners and what actually went on in the prison, things that we would not hear or read about normally. Really pleased that we done this tour put everything into perspective to hear and see things which went on whilst they were serving their sentences, Tear jerking and real history!!!!

Well worth the boat trip. Make sure you take to first boat out as the second is more of a fishing trawler, the tour was very informative and very touching with guides who were in the prison. Exception staff and a great day! Make sure you take some Nausea Tablets!

Our trip to robben island. This is a very humbling place to visit. It was well worth it. The tour guides were exceptional and the whole experience presented in a respectful fashion.Yet another do not miss experience for Cape Town.

Robben Island. Most of us will remember Robben Island as the prison island of Nelson Mandela,it is that but more. The history of the island is quite interesting and I am not going to spoil it by telling you about it,the Robben Island museum is there for that. Robben island is much more than all of that,it is about "Unity","Forgiveness",Peace","Humanity" and in a strange way "Change". As soon as you get on to the island you can feel how special it is. I suggest you take the tour ,which is very one sided, but when its over take your time and explore the island by yourselves.Walk past the old runway,and yacht that has ended way up in the middle of the island....On the downside I feel that the management of the island think that the island is theirs.....almost as if the history before it being a prison is of no meaning.All of history is important the good and the bad.It is the only way we can learn and hopefully better ourselves as human beings.So that out of the way I have been to Robben Island many times and been privileged to have met many high profile celebs on the island. Go and see it for yourself .Enjoy.

An amazing, educational and humbling experience. This was a place I missed on my first trip to Cape Town, so I made sure it was one of my first excursions when I was lucky enough to visit again. And it was so worth it! After the ferry ride over (from the V&A Waterfront), you all get onto large buses and get driven around the island, and my entertaining guide pointed out various sights, including the quarry, where Nelson Mandela and others were forced to break rocks, and there was the cave that Nelson used to give secret lessons to other inmates. Then once back at the prison itself, you are put into groups, and given a guide to take you through the prison, and this guide is a former political prisoner! He was amazing! Telling first hand what the conditions of the prison were like, and what life was like at that time. A must do for anyone interested in the story of Nelson Mandela and South Africa's history.

A Sad but Important Experience. I initially did not want to do this activity. The ferry rides to and from Robben Island give you great views of Cape Town and Table Mountain. We were fortunate to tour the prison facility with a person who had been in prison there. He was part of the student riots. The theme of reconciliation was prominent and there was a message of hope. This is one activity you should book a few days ahead so that you can go when you want.

Worth a visit. We visited this after a township tour. Was great to have an ex prisoner as your tour guide. Found it very interesting although I thought it would be bigger. We saw Mandela's cell and was able to take photos the whole time.

A very humbling experience. The whole trip from beginning to end is a very humbling experience. To think that a 'modern 20th century country' could intern its own people for expressing a view is heart wrenching. The commentary on the coach trip around the island is very informative. The experience in and around the prison delivered by a former inmate is something that simply can't be put inTo words. Whilst the ferry boat was a touch old we can say that we were transported to the island in the same way that many of the prisoners were. The only difference being we could sit on the top deck. This is a must do excursion. Book early and on-line to avoid disappointment.

An Island of note...................... A trip to Robben Island is truely a worthwhile experience - even a second time - for it brings home the reality of South Africa's most unforgettable historical event - the imprisonment of our beloved Nelson Mandela. It also makes us aware of the Leper Colony of long ago which was housed on this island for obvious reasons,as well as the Mental Hospital. How sad that these people with any form of Mental Illness were separated from society and set apart as if they did not belong. Very often today they prove that they have a valuable contribution to make to society. This separation was ended in the early 1900 by my grandfather, as Mayor of Greater Cape Town. He was an early Scottish settler to the Cape.Sadly the boat trip organisation is poor right now and needs updating and better still - punctuality!!

Very interesting experience. This tour is ruled by the ferries that get you to and from the island and as such the tour itself is a little rushed, but to be fair there isn't that much to see on Robben Island anyway.It's very interesting knowing the background of Mr Mandela and the history being told by a man who was a prisoner when it was a prison and the South African people are very proud of what has happend to their country in the passed 30 years.Everyone is desperate to see Nelson Mandelas cell No4 which exactly like all the other cells 2.5m x 2.5m.Still, I will be reading more about the history of aparteid when I return to the uk.A recommended visit though. Makes you think about history.

Stirring trip!. Robben Island is a must if you have an interest in the history of South Africa. Don't expect a luxurious ferry ride over, which is why I gave it a very good. The boats are old and there is almost no sitting room. However, the tour of the island is well worth the trip. There is a bus tour of the island and then you are dropped off at the maximum security prison where Mandela was held and toured by an ex-political prisoner. That in itself was worth the visit. Their stories are most compelling and the displays in the cell blocks bring apartheid and the policies surrounding it to life. We even got to meet the man who was the warden for Mandela, he lives and works on the island to this day!!

A moving experience. Lesson learned from my last visit to Cape Town - if you want to visit Robben Island, book online well in advance! This time we booked well in advance and we were lucky that it was a fantastic day in Cape Town. We booked the first Ferry crossing in the hope that the sea was calm and we would get to go. The views from the Ferry back to Cape Town and Table Mountain were stunning. The seating was wet and hard so perhaps take sometimg to put on the seat. The sea was very cold when we went in April so make sure you dress warmly. The tour was very moving and a sobering reminder of the injustices of the past. Well worth the visit.

Rushed tour, not for an individual traveller. It was organised tour for a large group of people. As our ferry was rescheduled and delayed so much, due to the bad weather, we had to rush through. As a result, I had no time to talk to the guide, as suggested in one of the reviewers. I wish they had an option of a private tour to the Island, as I had so much to talk with the guide. (I have worked in a prison in PNG as an educational consultant.)

A must do. Not necessarily easy with little children, but still an absolute must for Cape Town visitors. The boat ride is not scenic, just a means to get you to the other side. It was my third time, and always very impressive.

A piece of history. A fantastic trip after waiting for a day with calm water! We were extremely impressed with the attentive service and wealth of information passed on during our guided trip was inspirational to see what these inmates endured.

Robben Island. We had booked our trip a few months in advance, but due to bad weather it was cancelled. However we got thee the following day and well worth it a very interesting insight in to apartheid in South Africa in the past. Part of the tour was conducted by an ex Political Prisoner and the regime was indeed very harsh a must do if in Cape Town.

Impressive. Another must see when you are visiting Cape Town, impressive history told by the surviving (ex) prisoners whit a beautiful view on Cape Town, Table Mountain, etc. So close but so far away at the same time..

Good Tour - very disorganized operation. I had booked my ticket for an 11am ferry, days before I arrived in South Africa. So that I could wander around the Nelson Mandela Museum first, I arrived there at 10am to find all doors locked, in spite of posted opening hours to be 10am. First strike against this company. Finally the museum opened at 10:15 with no apologies to the waiting crowd. 11am came and went....by 11:15am an announcement was made that the incoming ferry would be 10 minutes late - how stupid is that to make an announcement after the fact? 10 minutes later, the same announcement was made, again after the fact. We actually left the dock at 11:55am for the 50-minute ride to the island. Second strike against this company. Being herded like cattle once on the island didn't meet my expectations, however I did learn a lot regarding the island's history and Nelson Mandela's incarceration. More disorganization when we returned to the island dock for the ride back to Cape Town. We were supposed to leave at 3pm. The ferry wasn't even there at 3:30pm and it was after 4pm before we actually sailed. Third strike against this company. I would suggest a change of management - it appears the inmates rather than the management is actually running this tour company!

Poor Coordination and info. I recently went to the island on a tour and was disappointed by the general lack of coordination as well as the quality and tone of the information shared by the guide. I have been on tours previously and other than the fact that our group was close to a hundred people the guide chose to share his political views on the Western Cape instead of the island experience.

Historically significant but not well run. I am glad I went for the historical significance, I did see Nelson Mandella's former prison cell. However, the ferry ride over was the absolute worst boat ride I have been on. It was 45 mins late, and was a rickety, small boat. We were stopped on the dock before getting on the boat and heard the captain screaming, "No more, too many!" The count was 109. We were then allowed on with three others, hearing the deck hand scream 115! No more. The capacity posted on the boat was 70 adults, 15 children! We then took off into very rough waters with 15-20 foot swells. Most people seated on the open decks got completely soaked. The bus trip around the island was adequate, but very short. The tour of the prison itself was overcrowded. All three of the busses had only one guide and at times we couldn't hear anything he said. I'm told that each bus normally has a guide. The prison guide was a former prisoner and, very interesting when we could hear him.

Variable. I feel so guilty about giving Robben Island a less than glowing review but the whole attraction lives or dies by the quality of the guide in the prison.Pre-booking of tickets is essential. The boat journey over (complete with sightings of seals) is usually quick (depending on which boat you get).Once you arrive you either get a tour of the island or go straight to the prison. The tour of the prison is conducted by a former inmate. Many had been in prison at the time of Nelson Mandela but as the years go by, there are fewer of these. Some of the guides speak clearly and bring the history to life. Many don't. The tour of the island is conducted on a coach by a younger guide and is the better for it. Many would say that Robben Island is where the new South Africa was born. There is scope to make the whole experience special. Unfortunately it is all a bit hit and miss.You have to go but do so with an open mind.

A must go for the history lesson. First of all, it is recommended to purchase your tickets before hand online to avoid the disappointment of full ferries. We had planned to purchase the tickets there for the next day but the tours were already full for the next few days. Luckily for us we managed to squeeze in some time for one of the last few days of our trip.After experiencing Robben Island and taking the tour with great explanations from the guides and a personal tour from an ex inmate, we would have regretted not being able to make it there.The tour of Robben Island completes visits to all the musuems in Cape Town. Not going there if you have not is a mistake.One thing to note is to remember to keep some cash for tipping the guides at the end of the tour to show your appreciation.

Reality check. A must if visiting Cape TownJourney by ferry approx 11.5 km from cape town about 45 miniatures depending on windThe island is just so full of history obviously make famous by that amazingly forgiving Nelson MandelaThere is also amazing sadness to the island going back centuriesA story worth listening to The guides were excellent and knowledgeableBook on line is a good idea but at this time of year there are many cancellations due to weather

A moving experience. There is a 40 minute boat ride to get to Robben Island. Once there you board a bus for a guided tour of the island before visiting the maximum security area where the major political prisoners, like Mandela, were housed.We were fortunate that one of the people on our bus was one of those prisoners who was released 25 years previously. This was the first time he had returned to the island and so it was very moving for him, especially when he met some of the guides who had been imprisoned with him.His personal reminiscences added to those of the former prisoners who acted as guides to make it a truly remarkable experience.

was expecting more. 3 hours there and back - felt very unsafe on the journey over in one of the smaller boats (45 mins) then onto a coach with a tour guide giving out lots of info, very quickly whilst you try to take in the scenery or a photo thru the coach window. You are allowed off twice first at the shop/restaurant (great views of the Cape Town harbour and Table Mountain) plus you may get to see some penguins. A small journey again then off again to finally be shown around the prison by an ex inmate. English is not his first language and he "recites" his monologue with no punctuation, timbre or "feeling". I felt there would be more to be had from it to be treated like Alcatraz with buses between the further distances it feels like SA has only just woken up to this "money spinner" and got it wrong! People have suggested feeling moved by the island but I was bored and glad to get back on dry land! - sorry

Important Historically But.... This island is important to the world quite simply because of its involvement in a very significant part of world history. And that is why I think I need to leave this review.The visit was divided into two parts. There was a visit to the prison buildings with a former inmate and a bus tour to see some of the other buildings on the island. Having a former inmate to take us around was a pretty nice touch. Although I was not expecting a brilliant orator, I was definitely hoping to hear and learn much more about the prison and life in there. What was a typical day like in prison? What did the prisoners do everyday? What were some of the significant or interesting stories that happened in there? Unfortunately, I felt a little like a sheep being herded around the buildings with the rest of my flock. There was no time to properly see the prison buildings or even to get a good sense of the size and scale of the whole set up. You are brought in and before you know it you are brought out again.On the second part of the tour, we were kept on a bus the whole time except for the end when we were released onto this place to take photos of Cape Town across the sea and to use the toilet. After that it was back onto the bus to be taken back to the pier. There was no chance to visit the significant buildings and sites. We could only look at them from the bus.I am still glad that I had made the trip, just to see the buildings. But I think the tour, as presently conducted, would have benefited only the people who were already well versed in the relevant history. A pity really.

Disappointing activity. I cannot imagine a trip to Capetown without visiting such an historically significant site as Robben Island, so in that respect I'm glad I went. However, the experience was less that satisfactory for the price paid. The views of Capetown and Table Mountain as we headed toward Robben Island were certainly the best part of the experience. The condition of the boat itself made me a wee bit uncomfortable and I kept judging how long it might take a rescue to reach us as we got farther from shore. After disembarking from the boat, we were herded onto a crowded bus-hard to take pictures through the window as we drove past most sights. There were a couple of quick stops, but most of the tour was simply drive-by. The end of the tour was conducted by a former inmate of the system there. Just because you were an inmate does not make you an interesting tour guide! We could not hear most of what was being said-very disappointing part of the tour. Such a dramatic and important part of South Africa's history deserves a better presentation to visitors in my opinion.

Historical Perspective. I had heard mixed reviews about visiting Robben Island. My sister and I decided it was worth it to add to our itinerary. You take a short boat ride and then get on a bus which takes you on a driving tour of the island. An ex-political prisoner took us on a tour of the prison which was informative. Everything does seem a bit rushed and there isn't any time for self exploration. Overall it was interesting to learn more in-depth history.The views of Cape Town are spectacular.

Would recommend but with hesitation. Glad we went but definitely feel like you're cattle getting herded around. Our Tour Operator on the bus seemed very bored with her job and asked for tip as we left. Would have gladly tipped if she offered anything interesting. Part of experience of tour was with former political inmate which was quite interesting so of course he got tipped. Obviously, everyone wants to see Nelson Mandela's cell more than anything else.Keep in mind - It takes a big portion of your day - getting to and back from location at V & A and the boat ride, the tour...etc.Great views of Cape Town and Table Mountain from boat.

Robben Island. While the site itself is self explanatory and the significance of the people incarcerated is well known, the actual experience is lacking.Fantastic, historic and breathtakingly beautiful, however it is a rushed affair.There is little or no time to experience the magic of the island. No time to consider the events that happened or wonder the surrounds to absorb the extend of the tragedies that unfolded here.A more relaxed time frame would allow a more fulfilling experience in my opinion and many of those that traveled with me agreed that time is not on your side on this tour.

Visit was a little rushed. We were brought around the island bu bus to see the sights and then had a tour of the jail with a former inmate. I was impressed by the lack of bitterness and the openess with which he told his story. We made the mistake of wandering down the 'short road to freedom' to the pier instad of wandering around the island and all too soon found ourselved ushered onto a boat before we were quite ready to leave

A very emotional walk. Fantastic views of Cape Town waterfront, Occasional sightings of seals. Our guide was an ex-political prisoner so it was a very informative tour of the jail. Disappointed we dint spend more time on the island exploring, felt it was a bit rushed. Very emotional walk of freedom.

Beatiful Island with a sad history. This was my favourite trip in Cape Town. The significance of this Island should never be overlooked , especially when its history is so recent .Against the backdrop of a peaceful , tranquil island lays the brutal and unfair history of wrongful imprisonments , punishment and murder . During the tour and the story is told by ex-prisoners , and you leave the island knowing that good came from this story in the end . The main theme being one of perseverance and bravery in the face of all adversitry. To be physically in the Jails and the island when listening makes the story so more powerful.I think the trip to this island should be a must for all students in South Africa or anyone else who visits Cape town.

An Educational and Fun Trip. We went to Robben Island on a glorious sunny Winter's day. The bay was perfectly calm and we had a marvelous boat trip to the island. We caught the ferry, named Autshumato, after the first prisoner who successfully escaped the island. That was in the 17C. Five other prisoners successfully escaped, all occurring in the 17th C. Usually on small boats. A Xhosa Chief, Makano, tried to escape in the early 19th C but was recaptured.On arrival at the island we were shepherded to a bus and did the tour. The guide was a sweet chap named Johnny. He told us all about the island as we drove around. We drove through the village, past the nature reserve, past Robert Sobukwe’s house, past the criminal’s prison, past two churches. The older one, the Church of the Good Sheppard, was the lepers’ church for male lepers. (Robben Is. was once a lepers’ colony). This would have been demolished along with all other buildings pertaining to the lepers, but it was the only church that did not belong to the state and the Anglican Church, who owned it, refused to have it destroyed. It is a very pretty little church. Then to the Maximum-security prison for the political prisoners of the 20thC.There, we were met by an ex-prisoner, one Lionel Davis, who was incarcerated for seven years from 1964. He was there just before Mandela. He was jailed for committing acts of sabotage. It was quite moving listening to him although we knew the basic story already. It is well worth the visit

Mandela's Imprisonment for 18 Years. I can't believe this attraction is so far down the list when it should be in the Top Ten. The guided tour was given by a former inmate so you believe every word spoken to be the truth. You can't visit Cape Town without going to Robbens Island. If you don't learn your history...you are destined to repeat it.

Don't miss the boat. We pre-booked tickets for the 3 o'clock boat and arrived in good time but had to join long queues and were the last people allowed on our crowded boat. The boat was the newest on the service but had seen better days. Calm crossing and I managed short snooze!We walked up to the prison where the boat full was split into smaller groups for the prison tour. Interesting tour with little done to the buildings to cater for the visitors. Our group got bigger as we caught up with stragglers from the previous tour.The Island Tour takes you to the southern tip of the island were there are toilets, refreshments, penguins and views of Table Mountain. The bus is very high floor and difficult for some to board. I had to stand.We arrived back at the harbour just in time for the last boat (the souvenir shop had closed and other visitors had to run to catch the boat) - the original 65 year old transport to the island. Great sunset as we left.

An enlightening and educational experience!. My visit to Robben Island was an enlightening and educational experience. The boat experience was pleasurable - although rather windy on the deck. There was however plenty of protection indoors with good views through the large windows. It is always spectacular to see Cape Town and Table Mountain from the sea. Robben Island itself is rather barren, with sparse vegetation, which highlights the conditions which previous residents, namely Lepers and Prisoners must have endured. We were driven around the island and shown the accommodation which prior to the island becoming a prison colony, housed Lepers. We were also shown the lime quarry where Nelson Mandela spent many hours in hard labour. Another interesting fact is that the island apparently has a maze of underground tunnels. The prison itself is also a very basic building with no signs of luxury. It was certainly an eye-opener to see how hard it must have been to have spent so many years incarcerated there. One cannot help but identify strongly with the experiences of the prisoners and to admire their tenacity. I would recommend a visit to Robben Island. Suggestion: have your snacks ready to enjoy on the boat. There is no time or opporunity for snacking during the tour.

Robin Island Trip. The boat trip was very nice ( very often they are out of service) but on arrival the walkways were covered in bird poop & lots of staff standing around doing nothing. Being a local I found the information to be biased & the prison looks more like a hospital, nothing like it would have been when it was a prison. There's a small tuck shop but the service was awful. Been there, done it, won't do it again. I'd rather buy a good book about Robben Island & get the true facts.

Robben Island. For a Capetonian, seeing the island from the Cape Town harbour and not being able to go and visit pre-1994 when the island housed a prison and now being able to experience what the rest of the world is experiencing is absolutely awesome!.My first visit to Robben Island in 1994 was amazing, the boat trip from the Nelson Mandela Gateway, looking back at the harbour and especially Table Mountain made me realise how fortunate we as Capetonians are - nothing beats the view from the sea and looking at Table Mountain - gives one the feeling of being safely tucked under the wing of the mountain.Now you turn back towards the island and sailing towards it becomes almost mystical, apprehensive, not quite knowing what to expect, trying to imagine prisoners looking out of their very small prison windows waiting to see who is coming to visit them today. Then you arrive at the jetty at the Island and there is a bus waiting for you to take you on your trip. Magical all the way.......

Poignant, beautiful, a tribute..... I am not going to ruin the sanctity of Robben Island and everything Mr. Mandela stood for by saying its "an amazing attraction" and "well worth it" because it is.More than the "attraction", you should visit this to see what this special soul endured for so long, and then ask yourself, can you be as full of love and peace after all of that ?From a trip advisor pov- get your ferry/ entrance tickets early and in advance (by days or weeks) of your trip. Try to go in one of the early morning trips. Take lots of pictures. And close your eyes and experience an inspirational journey.

Reliving the past.... The tour in total was about 3.5 hours long, including the boat ride from the waterfront to the island. Spectacular views of table mountain and the waterfront while cruising to the island. It was an indescribable experience on the island, one could sense the emotions through the walls of the prison, if walls could only speak, about all the hardship that took place. It was very interesting to learn about our own South African history and also that of our late beloved president Tata Madiba (Nelson Mandela). This was a very inspirational experience, especially for me a young person, to carry on the legacy that our great president started, that of a united "rainbow nation". We were also very fortunate to listen to the experience of an ex-convict and also to hear something from one of the guards that served at the time Nelson Mandela was a prisoner on the island. Definitely a must for all visitors to Cape Town and all South Africans, to gain knowledge of what our fore fathers had to go through, in order for us to gain freedom. I am very proud to be a South African, and fortunate that what happened in the past, stays there, for good.

Robben Island, a must see when in Cape Town. For anyone with a tiny interest in modern history of the struggle against apartheid and further back in history, this is a must do trip if you are anywhere in or near Cape Town. The attraction is a short walk along the trendy V&A Waterfront to the Nelson Mandela Gateway. R250 check it out in your currency. Enlightening trip out, worth every penny. Makes one think somewhat differently after the experience. My guide was Sparks a lovely man, who told us about the prison from his own experience there.May this never happen again, One Love !

Excellent trip. We booked in advance and the trip lived up to its billing. The tour of the prison was brilliant and the trip around the island just as informative!!!Staff on both parts of the tour were great.

Robben Island and Tour. Best to book your ticket for the ferry and the tour at least the day before as it can book up quickly and there are limited seats on the ferries. They can be bought at the V&A Waterfront. But even with a ticket in your hand, you will have a bit of a wait before you actually board. There's a coach tour around a little bit of the island before the prison tour. Don't expect too much from this part. We only get to see a small part of the island although it's worth doing if only to garner how others lived on the island.The best bit by far was the visit to the prison compound itself. Seeing how and where Mandela and all the other many political prisoners lived for so many years was humbling. Our guide, as are all the guides, was an ex-political prisoner once imprisoned like Mandela. He was just brimming with information about apartheid, the anti-movement, as well as his own personal story. It was only spoiled in part by the ignorant and incessant gibbering of some of the other visitors in our tour group, while he was trying to speak.Our ferry back was 'fun'! It was the last one back around 18.00hrs, it was dark by then - and it was CHOPPY!! A lot of very sick people.... :(

Better than expected. Not many people I talked to before the visit seemed to enjoy it. We had a good day at Robben Island, the boat might be a bit to crowded though. At arrival on the island you will be put on a bus that takes you around the island. Then you will be dropped of at the prison for a walking tour around the different parts of the prison. All in all, it was an interesting day, but since you are not really allowed to walk around on your own, one visit is definitely enough.

Much better than its reputation. Many people come away disappointed by their Robben Island visit, feeling they've been shortchanged somehow. But in reality it's quite an outing. There's a the ferry ride itself, which is interesting. But on the island, you're really there for the prisoner experience, particularly because of Mandela. Well, you get that. We were led through the prison complex by a former inmate, who was passionate about his experience, but told it with a freshness and candour. We saw the cells, the workyards and we learnt about the conditions. We visited the infamous stone quarry where prisoners broke rocks. And we visited Mandela's simple cell. It was enough. I wonder if some people want butchers' hooks on the walls and blood-curdling tales. It wasn't that kind of place. It was where opponents of apartheid were sent to be removed from the public record.

Even better the second time. Very interesting outing and worth the second trip! Our guide was fantastic and his story was humbling! Went the day before the elections, made the 2 hour wait in the queue, feel like nothing!!

A must see!. I wasn't sure what to expect from going to Robben Island. It was a great experience and gave me a lot of insight into some dark decades for South Africa. Getting to see the living areas and hear the stories directly from a ex prisoner was a humbling experience. I highly suggest making this experience part of your trip.

Moral question, to go or not to go?. Before we made the trip to South Africa, we had read in a guid boo that this place is quite overrated. First you are being shoved like sardines in a can on a tourbus, that takes you around the island, you stop, take a few pictures and move on, all whilst remaining on the bus. Then there is a little break where you have a shop, toilets and a chance to take some nice panoramic pictures of Cape Town. Then you get dropped off at the high security prison, where you get a tour by an ex-inmate.Reading that, you have to make a conscientious decision. What happened there is terrible and should never be forgotten and it has to be visited, on the other hand The tour is 3 hours, will it not be a waste of time. Well, we decided to go and what we found there was exaclty as described in the guidebook. We booked tickets for the day previously, but due to bad weather (???) this was cancelled, so we managed to get on the tour the next day. For some reason we didn't go with the normal boat, but with another (slower) one. So this added another hour on our journey, one way! When we finally got to the island, the busses were already waiting for us. On the bus you get this monotonous speech by someone who seems to be wishing she was anywhere else but there. We hadn't driven for 10 minutes when we stopped for a 15 minute break. This was probably the highlight as the place has a nice view over Cape Town to make some panoramic pictures. Next, you drive another 5 minutes and then you are back at the maximum security prison where you are greeted by the ex political prisoner. unfortunately you are spending a lot of time waiting for the group to catch up, who are barely listening to what this person has to say, that you can see the annoyance on his face. People are pushing and talking through everyting and when we got to one of the final places where he had a long narrative, lots of people kept disturbing him by coming in much later than the rest of the group.All in all, it was an interesting and educative experience, but you feel like a school class, even worse, in a class the kids stick together. The ferry was slow, but offered the opportunity to make some nice pictures of Cape Town, seals and if you're lucky even dolphins.

Great day for Views and Reflection. About 10 years ago I read an article in the travel section of the newspaper about Robben Island and visiting the prison. So it immediately when on my list of things to do.I finally got there in Dec 2013 it is definitely a must see. The tour was great and really was a time for reflection on the political prisoners being held here. especially since you can meet a prisoner as one will be your tour guide. In a weird way this was a draw to take the tour as I was very interested to hearing what they may have to say. It was also very weird as our guide was just such a gentle sweet soul that I couldn't imagine that he was incarcerated. HINT: have an intelligent question prepared for them as I think people react like our group did when they ask you if you want to know anything about them. Everyone was shy or tongue tied and just the same questions came out...like ...what was it like to be in prison? Where were my questions? So have a great chance here so have something prepared.the tours are half day and you really are not permitted to stay longer. You have to go back on the ferry that brought you. This was one negative for me, I would have loved to have stayed longer and just walked around as it is a beautiful island and unbelievable view of table mountain so we would have like to have had more free time to walk around.Other tips:1. booking ahead of time is a must. Just like Alcatraz, if you don't book ahead you are not going. 2. Book your tickets early in your stay as there is a good chance the ferry will be cancelled due to weather. This way you can re-book another day or you have more options to book another visit.3. don't worry if your ferry gets cancelled, this happens often and I must say I was very worried about not easily getting a refund. Since it happens often, they are very good about rebooking or refunding. I would suggest that if your ferry gets cancelled do not leave the ferry bldg. Line up with everyone else, the line moves fast and they ask you if you want a refund or book another date. So we re-booked for the next morning. Don't think you are going to just show up the next day with your old tickets and get on it doesn't work that way. Line up and get the new tickets for your best chance.4. On the ferry you want to be on the top deck for photos and it can get very windy so bring a hat and windbreaker or warm coat5. The HOHO bus stops nearby. I believe it is stop 2 on the red route so after your visit to the Island you can continue on your sightseeing using the HOHO.We had the gorgeous day, not a cloud in the sky and the views of Cape Town were those quintessential views of table mountain I didn't realize this was where everyone is getting those shots. Also when you stop for your bathroom break on the bus part of the tour be sure to explore around as this area has the best view of Cape Town with the Robben Island rocks in the foreground.Walking around the prison cells and incarceration area is hard (mentally not physically) and very thought provoking but this a one of the gifts of travel. Of course, Mr Mandela is constantly on your mind while you are walking around. In the back of my mind I was singing "Free Nelson Mandela" by The Specials. I know Cape Town has so many things to do so plan a long visit.

Underwhelmed. I felt guilty as a South African having never been to visit Robben Island. I was however considerably underwhelmed. the trip around the island is great and informative considering the long history of the island. However the organisation of the entire tour from arriving in the harbour to the return trip is quite underwhelming. No effort has been made to make the tour interactive at all. the ferry trip is just that - a ferry ride with no additional information available about the island, the Atlantic Ocean or even Cape Town. The tour around the prison is also quite dull. It could be considerably improved with video/audio footage of Mandela's more significant speeches. as a South African I understood and was able to relate to most of what was said but I feel no effort was made for international visitors w.r.t. language issues. There should at least be an information booklet available in a variety of languages.

Amazing insight into plight of South Africa's political prisoners. On a recent trip (March 2014) to Cape Town, we visited the Robben Island on one of their more modern catamaran vessels. We were warmly welcomed from the very start and soaked up all the commentary on life, both past and present, on Robben Island. The highlight of course was a walk through the prison where so many political prisoners were detained, the most well-known being Nelson Mandela, or Madiba as he is more affectionately known. As a returning South African who was actively involved in the struggle for a free democratic South Africa back in the '80s the visit was especially poignant. Through the incredible authentic commentary of our tour guide, we captured and had an insight into prison life during his incarceration. Definitely a must do when you visit Cape Town. And a bonus... the view of Cape Town's majestic Table Mountain from the island.

Visit Robben Island, Cape Town. Always better to buy your tickets online to avoid the queues. Try http://www.webtickets.co.za/event.aspx?itemid=76219Book your trip in advance. Otherwise, the narration of the island by former political prisoners will have in you in tears and they explain in such a way that you feel like you were part of their experience. Bring your camera and dress very relaxed.

Great Experience. I don't know what these other people are complaining about. My visit was amazing! Our guild, a former prisoner and MK soldier was great and provided a lot of detail about the prison and prisoners beyond the obvious one. To see the cell where Mandela was kept, where he buried early drafts of Long Walk to Freedom, to look at the the limestone quarry where prisoners would educate other prisons in secret was breathtaking and humbling. A must do!

Great experience. The boat ride to Robben Island seemed longer than the 30mins i had read online. It was ok though. It was a great experience. The guy who took us on the tour was lively and was very good at explaining the history regarding the prison, the prisoners, the regime etc. Seeing Mandela's cell was a humbling experiencing. The only negative was that we had to wait for at least 2 hours 30 minutes for a boat to ferry us back to main land. That long wait was traumatic, it had become very cold and dark. Other than that, everyone HAS to go to Robben Island.

A Must Do History Lesson. This was a must do in our eyes and we were not disappointed. Was guided around the Island by a man who had spent time in the prison. Saw where Nelson Mandela had spent so many years from the limestone quarry to his cell. Brilliant. A great gift shop as well

Great historical place. Need i say more about Robben Island. It was a really touching experience, i had to hold back my tears and really sad life the political prisoners had to go through but worth the trip. The tour and ex prisoners guides were fantastic and fully informing. It is a must visit.

Great experience. Booked in advance ! 45 min ferry crossing. Visit well organised and high point is talk by ex prisoner. A must visit if in Cape Town. Makes you realise what a great country this is and the people are so friendly.

A poor taste of history. We had booked online, the fast ferry! Well on arrival a rust bucket was await us. Glass bottomoled too!! The trip to and back from the island was supposed to take 1/2 hour each way! Well it took a total of 2 hours 20 minutes. We were only told after boarding and had sailed!! We had lost 1.5 hours of our planned site seeing! On arrival at the island, there is no-one to tell you what is happening. Follow the others and get on a bus....then taken a few hundred meters and dropped off at the prison. We were then met by a previous prisioner, who we could not always understand. The tour was boring and very one sided. We then boarded the bus again - here we had a tour guide with a bit more information about the island. He also informed us that they cut the tours short to accommodate the extra ferry ride. There were no brochures about the island or any souveniers on sale. I have been on many tours around the world and would certainly not recommend this tour!

Great shame. I would think that if in Cape town you would want to take this tour anyway, But it is a huge mismanaged and wasted opportunity. My personal experience was buying my ticket the previous day at 1pm I was told that there was no tour at 11 am so bought for 10. I arrived and joined a queue boarding a ferry at 9.30 when I reached the head of it the lady told me that this was the 9 am sailing but if I went to the ticket office they would reissue and all would be well I did so along with many other people and was told I would now be leaving at 11am ! so I had been messed about and lied too. On the Ferry I found a printed email From a Mohamed Hassan to various employees timed at 5.21 the previous day say that they had not sold enough tickets and so would cut some of the sailings  The Island Itself was a wasted opportunity mostly on a bus when it would have been possible, and I think intended for us to walk as we drove past information boards. We were shown round the prison by an ex inmate which was a great idea but the group was to large and his talk too wooden- and yes when you leave he shakes your hand to get a tip ( I gave one as walking round somewhere you were imprisoned for a living seems harsh) they then said the ferry was delayed by 10 mins the fact it was nowhere insight gave the lie to this two it arrived after 40 mins and no further announcements!  This could be great but its not and for some stupid reason they redecorated Your man's cell

50th birthday trip!. Great musuem and the visit to island was nice and very informative. I learn alot about Mandela and other inmates to the cause struggle! I would had given it 5 stars but the need new ferry to island not too safe in my opinion!

Historically important, but overrated and badly organised.. This is a boat trip to Robben Island, where the "museum" is; total time is around 4 hours.I booked a ticket for 1pm, but there were too many people for that boat so I had to wait 45 minutes for the next one; I question what the point of booking a timed ticket is when you can not get on the boat at the time you've booked.The boat takes 45 minutes; when you arrive, you are transferred to a bus which takes you down to one end, where there is a cafe; a guide gives you commentary - you see the Leper's graveyard, a church, the village...there's not a great deal to see.After this, you meet an ex political prsioner who gives you a tour of the prison; interesting anedotes but not a lot to see. I did wonder if I'd missed something, but having spoken to other tourists who had done the trip, they all said the same thing; overrated and poor planning: one couple had to wait over an hour for a return boat.If you're short on time, there may be better ways to spend it..

Disappointing. Was expecting so much more. An international icon, yet nowhere near international standards in terms of the information provided - not even multilingual tour guides providing the information. The tour cam across as very rushed and rehearsed, with the tour guides rattling off their rehearsed lines in monotone fashion, not even pausing between sentences to breathe. We had great difficulty even understanding them as they mumbled through their words. Not even at the tuc shop stop did they provide for selling of books to further enhance one's knowledge - not even the famous Mandela's Long Walk to Freedom. I suggest if you make this trip, take it into your own hands to educate yourself before the time on all details in order to gain the most benefit of the trip. Not enough seating for all passengers on the boat - requiring some to stand for 45 minutes per leg of the journey. Broken toilets with broken off toilet seats added to the run down atmosphere of the entire tour.

Good experience. It was a educational and a good experience to see a snippet of what the prisoners had to endure. The trip will make you appreciate everything you have and and feel grateful that you do not have to go through the struggle they went through. I think the tour could have been organised better but it was overall a must be when in South Africa and good experience.

A tribute to humanity. Nobody visiting Cape Town should miss a visit to Robben Island. It is not a pretty sight. And it is tiring to spend 45 minutes in a boat and another 45 back. The bus that drives you around is not especially comfortable... It is a prison... A prison for innocent people, for men whose only sin was to dream of equality and freedom.It is a very touching experience: Guides are ex-prisoners, who else could better describe life in the island as a captive? And looking at the small cell where Mandela spent 14 years, and the limestone mine where he was forced to work everyday whose stone powder damaged his eyes making him unable to cry, makes you reflect... Because that same man joined a country broken by injustice and racial abuse to proclaim forgiveness.

I don't know...... without doubts Robben island is a thing to do if you are in Cape Town...but the way how the tour is organized is really disappointed....4 or even more hours to visit only one interested place, the prison of Mandela ...the rest of the long tour is boring and not interesting.

Hugely disappointed . We only had two days to spend in Cape Town and I was really looking forward to robben island. Unfortunately this was a huge waste of time. It took four hours to visit in total and I left feeling as if I had not learnt a thing. We were unable to hear the guide and we were whisked past the few information boards present. Robben island has huge potential but I feel this is not even touched upon. Strongly recommend to see other sights and just read up about the history of the island in guide books.
Robben Island. A place so rich with our history of the struggle Icons,of our freedom and Democracy.I was happy to finally managed to go to Robben Island.To learn the history of the place.

Good Way to Spend a Low Key Morning. When originally planning my trip to South Africa I nearly skipped taking the Robben Island tour because of some of the negative reviews on this site. I’m very glad I decided to do the tour regardless as I had a very positive experience. The ferry ride from the mainland to the island was a treat in and of itself… the views of Table Mountain and the peninsula were lovely. Our tour guide was a very engaging man and related many fascinating stories about his experience in the prison (all tours are guided by former inmates). I found seeing Nelson Mandela’s cell with my own eyes to be a very powerful experience. While we didn’t have a lot of time for thought and reflection, that’s simply the nature of taking a group tour with many people. After touring the jail there is a bus tour of the island which was very interesting. It took us past many notable sites including the Limestone quarry where Mr. Mandela toiled for years. Most intriguing to me was the residential town that still exists on the island. I had no idea there were about 200 residents living there, a mix of guards and former inmates. Overall a pleasant and educational morning.

Well thought through and powerfully delivered. I read many comments here expressing some disappointment with the tour but I can't really see how it could have been better done. Pre-ticketing was fine, the boat transfers punctual (although a bit old) and the coach tour was very well hosted - we even got a few penguins thrown in.The tour of the prison, the leaders' block and Mandela's cell was very powerful given in was an ex-inmate as the guide. He was completely open to all questions, many of them deeply uncomfortable, about what went on both on Robben Island and to cause people to be sent there and ultimately released. Recent, raw history delivered directly. If you want a gift shop probably better to stick to the V&A Waterfront.

Memories. This was a highlight for me. A place where so many suffered and were wrongfully imprisoned. Such a desolate place. The guide on the tour was wonderful and we got to visit the prison and the island. Also the boat trip was great
Lots of history. Good visit with lots of history. Our guide provided lots of stories about the history of the prison and his personal experiences and their struggles.

unique historic place. We were furtunate to have clear sunny weather so the 30 - 45 minute boat trip to and from the island were enjoyable giving some great views of Table mountain and the peninsula. The general organisation and information signage through the prison could certainly be improved but did not spoil in any way the impact of the personal accounts by each of the occupants of the cells and seeing in person the very small sparce cells they endured for 10, 20 or more years. It makes you realise even more how incredible the achievements of Nelson Mandela were to forgive such inhumanity and injustice and go on to do such good.

A little glimpse of South African history.. We watched the film, Mandela, before we travelled to SA so it seemed only right to take a trip out to Robben Island to see it for real. We booked tickets online from the UK which was a simple process. The whole trip was very sobering indeed from the island approach by boat to Mandela`s cell and the exercise yard. The guide, who had himself served time in the prison, was well informed and interesting giving a first hand insight into what life was like on Robben island. The bus tour section of the trip showed other areas of the island, such as the quarry, chapel and officers buildings. A bit more island time to reflect on what was a very moving trip would have been good. We were glad that we visited and that we were able to leave of our own free will.

Amazing....... This trip was amazing... well organised! 2 tours one around the island and 2nd of the prison itself. The guides were very well informed and more than happy to answer our questions, we had an ex political prisoner as our prison guide.An definite air of sadness about the place but yet very serene and peaceful, beautiful views back to Cape Town and of the majestic Table Mountain.Booking recommended especially during peak holiday season.

Must do in Cape Town. Not only is the tour itself informative & well organized the views to and from the island are spectacular. Book on advance as just turning up can disappoint however there are worse things than vein stranded at the waterfront as this is also spectacular!

The tours are a bit rushed tbh. We would have liked to spend more time on the island. Really educational and moving, and plenty of wildlife.if you can you may want to leave your pram on the bus for this one.

A Cape Town 'Must See'. We were initially put off visiting here due to negative reviews however we are glad we decided to come since the island is very much a part of Cape Towns history.Booking was straightforward and after a 45 minute boat trip we arrived.There are 2 parts to the tour - a 30 minute tour round the island on a bus and entrace to the prison itself.The bus tour stops at various places and a guide explains stories of some of the more famous inmates. Its humbling to see the quarry and hear of the conditions prisoners were subjected.In the prison itself we got to see shared cells and individual solitary confimement cells all by a guide who was originally a prisoner and who explains how life was in a very real and touching manner.The only drawback is that everyone want to see Mandelas cell and the camera popping crowd do tend to create bottlenecks.The island does give the impression of being slightly run down and at times it may have been nice to walk around at your leisure.We left feeling humbled to have heard some of the stories and seeing first hand where some South African history was made?

AN UNFORGETABLE EXPIERIENCE. My wife and i visited robben island and found the whole trip something we will never forget.to be in the cell where madela was kept was an eerie feeling and the whole place gave a sense of bad feelings from the past but helps understand the expierience he wemt through .

disappointing tour. Our family toured Robben Island and was very disappointed. There were so many people, many babies and toddlers making a lot of noise while we were trying to concentrate on the guides speaking. The guides (bus and ex prisoner of war) were very difficult to understand. They did not tell the story or give us the history that I was looking for. Anyone going to Cape Town, I would advise them to skip this as we did not get much from it.

Part of History. With the recent death of Neson Mandela I was particularly interested in seeing this part of his life history. This tour includes a bus trip around the island and seeing the quarry where the prisoners worked. A former prisoner guided the group through the maximum security building where Mandela's cell is and told us how life was there from the sparse food, censored letters and restricted visitors. In another building were cells we could walk through with photos of the prisoners and dated placards with words they wrote about they felt about their prison time. It was further out than I thought it would be and the ferry took about an hour each way plus another couple of hours on the island, so it took up a big part of the day. For me it was something worth seeing and reenforced the hardship that Mandela endured with such grace and dignity as he came out without hatred and went on fighting for freedom and becoming President. He truly was a great man,

Robben Island Tour. The boat trip to the island is quite long and the intial coach "tour" not very interesting, but the tour of the prison by an ex inmate was very emotional and moving and worth the trip, but only if you are interested in the social history of SA.

Could be better organised. This has always been on my bucket list and I'm glad I went.I understand the guides had to lighten the mood but ours constantly digressed into very irrelevant stories that got a bit boring. It is a long day, with very choppy waters, so take some sweets ! I personally felt it looked too modern with a lot of new paintings to spruce it up. It is emotional and worth the visit but not everyone's cup of tea.

Eye opening experience. We purchased tickets in advance, so that went smoothly; the boat rides were not quick, but pleasant. The bus tour was interesting and informative, but the walking tour lead by a former political prisoner was an absolute highlight of the entire trip to South Africa. Highly recommended if you want to understand the period, which is essential to understanding the country.

Interesting but poor organisation. We enjoyed our tour to Robben Island. The visit is very interesting and gives a good taste of the Apartheid period. Unfortunately the organisation is very poor and we had to wait an hour and half to return to Cape Town (our boat arrived at 8:15pm!).

Absolutely catastrophic waste of time. I am South African and wanted my English girlfriend to experience Robben Island and learn more about my country. This experience could not have been worse. Buying tickets took 45' because there is a chaotic system in place which collapsed when their computers froze. Then the boat ride took more than 1 hour on a rusty old tub of a boat. We were not impressed that things were going so differently to advertised so far. On arrival, we wasted 20' while the bus was prepared (I guess, nothing was happening anyway). The bus tour, slated to last 30', was an interminable 2 hour diatribe of random rubbish (e.g. 20' discussing whether or not there was a Church Street in every city of the world, and the fact that the fog horn was called the baby-maker). It was so bad that my girlfriend fell asleep. When we finally got off the bus, an ex-prisoner took us through the main prison. Again, random rubbish of no real interest. We spent 5 hours on this excursion and hated every second. I strongly discourage anyone from doing this tour. You won't get those hours back in your life. Rather do something useful and interesting.

Much South African History & Good Boat Ride. We were part of a tour group. Robben Island, where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for many years, is definitely worth visiting--if only for its historical significance. The Island, which was a leper colony before being turned into a prison, is unassuming and not developed. The guides through the prison are all former inmates, and this adds a touch to their stories.. The boat ride to and from the island can be somewhat choppy, but the views of Cape Town and, especially, Table Mountain are fabulous. One should not visit Cape Town without going to the island.

Worth doing - be aware people who suffer motion sickness. We booked the robben island tour through our hotel and we're looking forward to a seeing a bit of history. Some pros/cons highlighted belowProsRobben island intact (not commercialised)Lovely view of table mountain from the islandBus guide informativeSee the actual prison cell of Nelson MandelaConsBoat journey 1 hour each way and rough ride 15mins out - can get sick due to motion sickness several people on our boat did be awareToured to 4-5 areas by bus not allowed to get off so not many good photo opportunities Only one stop for refreshmentsTour is worth doing for anyone in Cape Town but be aware of the rough boat journey. This should've been a relaxing tour but I felt really tired afterwards.

What a day. After a 45 minute boatride on the ocean , we arrived on robbenisland , a guide who was a former politaical prissoner there ,guided us for about 90 minutes , it was a verry special day for mr and after we left robbenisland i felt not wel for a few hours , Shamed that white people did this to black people , But this is a MUST SEE !!!

Rushed Tour. Albeit that Robben Island and the Nelson Mandela legacy may seem to make it a worthwhile destination, it is lacking in many ways. Lineups are long to buy expensive tickets. Our tour was the 3:00 pm one (always seems to be the only one available) and it was 40 minutes late departing. Upon arrival we were herded into a bus and quickly driven around the island. No opportunity to get off and walk about. The tour of the cells was guided by an ex-inmate, which was of interest. By the time we returned to the mainland it was dark, and had to walk a while in the dark to hope find a taxi. The V and A area shuts down when dark. The ferry is a maritime disaster waiting to happen. The boat probably fifty years old and is in desperate need of upgrading and refitting. Little has been done since it was built to maintain it properly. On a positive note, you can see African penguins there.

When in Capetown...... I agree with many of the reviews here - this trip is a must-do when in Capetown because of its historical significance, however the tour itself could be so much better.We queued for ages to board the boat (they kept giving priority to tour groups.) The views from the boat back towards Capetown are very impressive. The island itself is remote and I admired the fact that nothing had been done to commercialise the place. You felt the isolation the prisoners would have experienced.We were herded onto buses and driven to the 'shop' which was distinctly unimpressive. Back on the bus you stop at various 'sights' such as the quarry where Mandela and other prisoners worked. You are not allowed to get off the bus to take photos, so if you are sitting on the wrong side of the bus, hard luck!!The trip through the prison was so quick, it was frustrating. Our guide was an ex political prisoner who had been incarcerated on Robben Island during Mandela's time. The guides do not use a microphone and his very strong accent made it quite difficult to understand all he was saying, which was a shame. I certainly would have liked to have spent more time just wandering around taking in the feel and history of the place.

Even to pay tribute to Nelson Mandela this is a complete waste of time.. 1 hour each way by ferry when you are told it is half an hour. 4 and1/2 hours plus when you are told it will be 3 and 1/2.You are first loaded onto a bus and taken to the end of the island where there is a single island where you spend 15 to 20 minutes buying drinks.You then get back on the bus and are driven up one street of the town. You the stop in front of the quarry. You are not allowed off the bus until you get to the prison. You then walk through a couple of buildings with your guide who due to the large group you may or may not be able to hear.They tell you what building Nelson Mandela was in but not which cell.You then walk back to the old and slow ferry.If you get a good guide at least you have that but otherwise there are better ways to enjoy the history of Cape Town.

2nd visit to Robben island - a "must see". This was our 2nd visit - our first visit was over 10 years ago. This time we took our son who is 7 years old. Pre booking is a must. The ferry ride affords good views but can be choppy on the return trip particularly if you sit on the upper level. Historically this is definitely a "must see" attraction when in Cape Town. The guides are ex prisoners and ours was well informed and kept us entertained with some of his own anecdotes and experiences. Some aspects were quite eye - opening and it's a reminder of our past. My son thoroughly enjoyed it and could not stop asking questions. He found it thoroughly fascinating, even made me buy him a book about the history of Robben Island which we have read many times since the trip and reminisced about the visit. Definitely a "must see" while in Cape Town!

it's a must see. My family visited Robben Island as part of our Cape Town tour, the Boat ride was wonderful except that we had unsolicited photos taken of us - which later we were supposed to buy back. The Island was historical our tour guide was knowledgable. It happened that our son got sick during the tour and we could not complete the cell tour together with the rest of the group as he was screaming his head off! It would be nice if they had at least a hospital/dispensary in there as we had to wait for the next boat out of the island to get some kind of medical care. Other than that - I felt the struggle and enjoyed the tour (what We saw). It's a once in a lifetime visit - I guess a 2nd time would be too much.

Inspirational. If theres one thing you do in Cape Town, make sure its Robben Island. Truely inspirational and makes you realise how hard it was for the men who lived here. Im glad to got to go a few years back as i loved the history and it made me read long walk to freedom which is the best book i read. Go and see how mandela made it his home, visit his cell and see how he lived for most of his life. And see what drove him as a person. Go and see it as its what has made Cape Town what it is today.

A disappointment. We had been looking forward to visiting Robben Island as a highlight of our South African tour. However we felt we were herded into a routine which was disappointing, and we considered the presentation of this historic site needed to be greatly improved. The coach tour of the island was very limited - poor guide, too long at some sites, no time to take photos at others, eg the quarry. No time to effectively read all the fascinating information on the various boards in the prison. We were rushed around. There were some very positive features - the conducted tour of the maximum security prison by a former political prisoner was excellent. This gave a real insight into the island. I would like to have heard more about the history of the island pre Mandella. As the experience stands, I feel that South African Heritage Authority needs to review its procedures, and the selection and training of its guides.

Historical "must see".. In my opinion it is a must see when visiting Cape Town, especially for those who enjoy history. Book ahead since the slots fill up quickly. The ferry ride was about 45 mins and the views were beautiful. My mother and I went on the 2pm tour, so on the way home we enjoyed a stunning sunset. The ride back was a bit choppy, but that is to be expected when you are on a boat and the wind picks up. The bus ride seems brief, but the tour guide was very knowledgable and the main attraction is the walking tour of the prison itself. You are lead through the prison by a former prisoner, who provides firsthand knowledge of his experience. The question and answer portion was very eye opening. There were small children on the tour when we attended, but I would think it is better suited for the older age groups. It is a solemn reminder of the country's recent past, but also sends a hopeful message for the future.

Not So Great, but Can Visit One Time. In some way this place is interesting, but overall I think I could do better than visiting this place.More than hour of sailing in ferry and in the island didnt see anything much. Fee was bit higher compared to other activities in Cape Town. Nice view of Cape Town and Table Mountain, Devils Peak and Lions Head on the way to island.Guid's narration was not very pleasing.Seemed like blaming someone for what happened in the past.
Absolutely worth doing once. Well organised, knowledgeable guides and of course the history. You MUST book ahead of time; very unlikely to get a slot if you just turn up.

A very well worthwhile visit. A short 45 minute boat ride from Cape Town Robben Island is well worth a visit. Excellent tour guides and well preserved recent historical site.You need more the the 2 hours recommended for te tour. A graphic reminder of our recent past.Well worth a visit

Robben Island, sad but interesting. On a one tour on a rather rough sea to Robben Island. It was an interesting experience, but also sad, when you think about what the prisoners had to go through here. The prison is now a museum and a former political prisoner guided us around the prison.
