We also visited the limestone quarry, where the prisoners were forced to work. At the end we also saw the Robben Island Lighthouse.

Glad I went, wouldn't go again. The ferry terminal is quite chaotic as indeed boarding the ferry. I use the word ferry loosely as it was basically a tug boat, with not enough seating so people had to stand. Luckily the sea was calm, the day before there were 6m swells. I do not think safety was taken seriously as people were not counted on and the "this is a life jacket" demo did not take place until we'd nearly arrived. The coach trip around Robben Island was both interesting and informative and the ex-political prisoner giving the tour of the cell at the end was both hard to hear and understand, a shame as I am sure he was very interesting. Was ready to leave however the scramble to get on the ferry was not much fun.

Historic location, deserves better management, unfortunately run down by the public entity (Robben Island Museum). The tour’s cultural significance in the history of SA is in no doubt; the original tired and rusting boat that prisoners rode still ferries the tourists back and forth to the island. Once on the island, ex-political prisoners provide intimate 1st hand account of how it felt during those imprisonment years.- Poor experience once ticket boughtYou book your ticket with stamped time of departure, but you’re instead stuck queuing for an hour to board cramped ship. You go through dubious security clearance, manned by too many state employees not doing much.- Old boats & insufficient capacityThe original boat (max cap. 90 passengers) broke down (engine fire). We were stranded on the island in poor wet weather for extra 3 hrs. They have a newer catamaran (cap. 70) but it took them a while to decide and send back, worst of all we were kept in the dark throughout. Frankly, they could do with more boats, newer ones, and more frequent schedule… 20 people were stuck for 5 hrs in total.- Information, in wrong place at the wrong timeThere are tons of interesting info compiled and plastered over a wall, unfortunately it’s all located at the waiting room for the boat ride back. I guess they knew we will be making use! The boat ride is 35-45mins each way, depending on the boat you get, which is completely idle time – maybe they could use this better to educate, possibly over audio guide? Instead, the occasional seals that swam by the boat entertained us.Overall, you get the impression that, despite the best efforts of the local guides, the place deserves better investement in infrastructure than it is getting now, especially as it is an important fixture in many tourists' itineraries. RIM’s website states that they are responsible for, “managing, maintaining, presenting, developing & marketing… as a national estate and World Heritage site”. None of this came across to us while we were there for half a day…a real big shame. The JHB Apartheid museum was so much better!

Robben Island. depending when you go trip can be 45mins in week on fastboat or up to 1.5 hours on a tug at weekends - interesting to say least!! the trip can be somewhat gruelling if you suffer from sea sickness so do ensure you go on a calm day - I am ok with boats but lots were quite illthe trip is not at all like Alcatraz - you are taken on a tour on a very old cramped bus and then escorted around the prison - there is no free time to wander - this does not mean it is not enjoyable as it is and well worth the visit - the guide on the bus is very informative and an ex inmate gives a very good talk on how it was to be imprisoned on the island and you do have some time to take photos but it would have been great to be able to wander around yourself however it is a must if you visit Cape Town

Prison tour was good, bus tour was a bust. First, if you can get on the smaller boat I would definitely recommend doing that! I think they first fill up a larger (and older, not well-maintained boat) and then the remaining passengers get on a smaller boat.Once we arrived at Robben Island, we all boarded buses and were driven about a minute away to the prison (literally a minute). It seemed foolish to get on the bus but I think that's how they keep the groups together. I've heard mixed reviews about the tour and some very unkind things said about the prisoners. For example, someone stated "we're being guided by an ex-con." The prisoners giving the tours are political prisoners NOT criminals. Our guide was great! You could see the pain and suffering he and the other prisoners endured. Its amazing that after such a traumatic experience he was able to come back and share his story. The tour of the prison was heartbreaking - I can't believe that so many of the prisoners were made to sleep on the hard floors of these tiny cells. Its sad to know that people were treated differently and given more or less amenities and even food based on the color of their skin (even between "colored" and "black" prisoners). The tour was moving and I would definitely recommend it. Unfortunately, the rest of the tour of the island was not necessary and it would be nice if there was a way to opt out of it. So don't expect much after the prison tour.

Excellent & very thought provoking.... What a morning. Beautiful boat ride (same boat as prisoners were transported on), followed by an informative hour on a bus seeing the island, then another hour in the cell blocks, including Mandela's cell. Excellent guide, no trace of bitterness who spoke very eloquently.

Living History. Our trip to Robben Island coincided with a good weather day, very important as the boat crossing goes across open water with substantial swell. At the Island your escorted to a coach and taken around various points of interest such as the former leper cemetery all the while listening to a commentary from the guide. After a few such sops your taken to the actual prison part itself where you are allocated a guide. The guide we had was an ex political prisoner and it was fascinating to this charming man explain all about their incarceration without a hint of malice or grievance. We were shown Mandela's cell amongst the others, communal showers and garden etc.I learnt more from this gentle man than 30 years of newspaper reports.

Must-see. This is the Alcatraz equivalent for Capetown and I rate the tours similarly and thus an essential part of a visit to the Cape. (although I can quite see how things can unravel if you are unlucky as posted by Neil F last month) The crossing is only 45 minutes not 1.5 hrs as quoted by another reviewer. Whilst the audioguide at Alcatraz is one of the best I've ever done, readers here will be aware that on Robben, you are guided around by an ex-political prisoner who can elaborate and answer questions, and the numbers of people in any one spot are much less than Alcatraz; each bus load forms a separate party, and contrary to some reviews I think it was pretty well organised, (and frankly a pretty daft idea to want to roam the island on foot without a guide). There's more to the Island than the max security prison, which adds interest, but of course the main event is Mandela's incarceration and there's plenty of information and background to all that. According to our Guide, the prison scenes and settings of the recent film biopic Long Walk to Freedom were pretty accurate. Like Alactraz you would be unlikely to manage to secure a ticket on the day as they tours are very popular and usually booked out well in advance. We booked on-line and our printed-off eTicket worked fine.

Mandela's Hell Hole. Nelson Mandela spent 18 of his 27 years here in solitary confinement. It is on an island about an hour away via ferry. Get your tickets early as they sell out quickly at least three weeks in advance, price is approximately $25 US.. Passage to the island is dependent upon the weather as the sea gets quite choppy. The tour is led by ex-political prisoners and they tell you first hand how it was.Built in 1962 the site contains several churches, schools, prison dorms, several shipwrecks, a lime quarry and a leper cemetery and church.It is extremely sad and moving experience. A must see if you go to South Africa.

A Trip down Memory Lane. A calm crossing definitely helped on a cool Summers Day! The team of staff who run this trip are excellent. From a wonderful crossing to the bus tour and into the cells this made for a life time opportunity.The entire trip was informative and well run by locals and ex Prison officers from Robben Island. One not to miss when in Cape Town.Be warned there is only one tiny food stall on the island so I would advise taking your own Food and Drinks - bathroom stops are at the port and one on the island.

Grim history. This is an absolute destination, when visiting South Africa. It is really difficult to understand, or you cannot understand how cruel the descendants of the Dutch and also British have been in apartheid policy. Visit on the island is good lessons what has happened - only answers why? are missing. Unfortunately still in the Country post apartheid can easily seen. Visit also in some township and compare that to villages where 'European' live. Othervise it is impossible to understand that there is still long way to go... too long for many... But Robben Island and museum close to clocktower are must and the you can go to Waterfront restaurant - either feel free or think what is wrong and what I can do!

Thought Provoking. A absolute must do, informative and educational, the boat trip alone is amazing with dolphin cruising alongside the boat.Once on the Island you are shown round by ex guards or ex prisoners who all tell their own story so no two visits are the same. I remain in awe of their forgiveness and lack of bitterness against their incarceration usually for many years.Its one of those places that should be essential for everyone visiting the area

Great tourist attraction let down by poor organisation. Well worth a visit, I especially liked the tour of the max security prison by an ex prisoner. I would have liked to be able to walk around the island on my own rather than be bussed around. The bus tour guide was great, funny and informative. Biggest let down was a) the 1.5 hour boat trip (each way) - this wasn't made clear on the website and I had a stroppy 11 year old with me, b) the queuing for the return trip. I know this is a very british thing to say but imagine a French or Italian ski lift queue and then quadruple it and add some octogenarians and people in wheelchairs. It really was that bad. There was a group of old ladies that got crushed in the rush to get on a boat (the only boat for another hour). It was just awful and really soured the whole experience. Surely it is not beyond the management to organise a queuing system, I refuse to believe it is cultural because the customs queue to get in the country is VERY organised.

Do not miss this tour.. The #1 attraction in this country and not to be missed. Just ignore the other reviewers that complain about the boat trip or the coach ride. This is where a giant of the world was unjustly imprisoned for a quarter of a century and returned his head held high to touch the life of this country. Take your tissues you will need them. It made me cry and I'm a sixty year old big man. Hang back in your group for better photo,s to capture the rooms and yards without people in the shot. Wonderful.

Great views of Cape Town from Robben Island!. Boat ride is organized but is a little choppy. Prison tours are given by ex-prisoners and it's pure luck which one you get. Ours wasn't too good. It was hard to understand his English. However, there is a bus tour around the island after the prison tour and for that we got an excellent tour guide. The views of Cape Town from the island and on the way back are amazing.

Chaos and no customer service. A tour of 3 elements. A crappy ferry ride across. An excellent guided tour by a former inmate at Robben Island. Then, the typical no customer service experience you get when an organisation has a monopoly and has no clue what to do when things go wrong. What a shambles and a dangerous shambles to boot. Apparently, (so the story goes, as we only got the information 2nd hand, as no one from the tour company bothered to inform us or speak to us at all for the hours whilst we waited in the cold and wet on Robben Island), a ferry broke down, and they did not have a spare......one turned up 3 hrs late, but could only take some of the people waiting. Now, rather than actually use a brain cell or two, and organise the hordes who were waiting, it was every man, woman and child for themselves. Pushing and shoving, onto a board walk, which barely looked capable of handling half the number. No message from the tour operator on board the boat and no one there to greet us when we arrived. I do say thank you to the ladies on Robben Island who run the store, as they kindly did offer a packet of crisps and a bottle,of drink to people whilst we waited. To the rest of the tour operator, I say you are a disgrace to the Sth African tourism industry and you did your country a very sad disservice with your conduct and behaviour. I hope for the sake of others you learn from the experience and consider some business continuity plans in your business model. To fellow travellers, my advice, go prepared for all contingencies when you do this trip.

Why is this 38th on TA?. One of the reasons for my trip was to find out about the recent history of SA. One of the best places to do that was to visit Robben Island. The visit includes a 45 minute boat ride , there and back. The island is much bigger than I had imagined.We were bussed to the prison and then toured the whole island.The prison itself was grim. The ex political activist/ prisoner who led our tour expertly led us around the whole site whilst informing of the day to day routines. He really did enliven the whole experienced with his knowledge and anecdotes of the time. Some humorous but others extremely harrowing. My understanding of the apartheid regime was heightened by my visit. It gave me a context of the past as I travelled throughout the Cape region.

Robben Island. Nelson Mandella was imprisoned on Robben Island 17 years. The tour guides were either ex political prisoners or ex guards – I had an ex prisoner. Fascinating bit of modern history. Take about 4 to 5 hrs (incl 45 min ferry ride each way - subject to weather).While Nelson Mandela "features" on this tour, the insights into history of the island, and other political prisoners, will leave an impression.

An eye-opening, harrowing experience. We visited Robben Island just after the death of Nelson Mandela. The timeliness simply added more intensity to an already emotional experience. The bus tour guide we had was extremely funny and had the right balance between sincerity and solemness and humour. All of the tour guides on the island are ex in-mates and have incredible insights to share with the tour groups. Their experiences just make everything so much more real. Visiting Mandela's cell with flowers thrown into it and a newspaper clipping for the day of his death was definitely the stand our moment for me, as Mandela is one of my greatest heroes. I learnt so much from my experience that I did not know about the island and the prison. We found out that many of the ex prison wardens still live on the island and many of the tour guides and their families. The population of the island is strictly monitored and small as the island is also a nature reserve for marine bird life and other species. Although the history of the island is a tough pill to swallow, the journey around the island is in a way uplifting and hopeful.

Good touch of history and culture. Absolutely loved that a former political prisoner gave the tour of the maximum security prison - made it very personal and touching. Didn't like not being able to walk around more on the island. I would have loved taking more pictures of various things on the island but being jammed packed into a bus didn't not allow for photo taking of any reasonable quality.

Must Do! But, it's a fast pace.. This tour is well worth the time and the money. It takes all day. The day is well organized. The boat ride is a hydroplane, so the swells are not too bad. Once there the boat is divided into buses that go different directions so everyone isn't waiting at every place at the same time. There was one stop for refreshments and pictures of Capetown across the bay. The final stop is the main prison where Mandela stayed. All prison tours are given by former inmates. I got lost from my group at one point and almost missed seeing Mandela's cell. I asked one of the guides and he took me where I needed to go. There is no time to stop and walk around. I was practically running to return to the boat, but then it left a little late. The souvenir shop is just before the dock and a lot of people stopped there and were late. The most impressive sight for me was the pile of rocks at the quarry placed there by all the inmates who returned after Mandela was elected President and Mandela placed the first one. The whole story is kind of immortalized in that rock pile. It stands to commemorate the victory over Apartheid, not the misery in getting there. I was very moved.

A must do! An emotional experience. Do not be out off by the poor arrangements and organisation for transport to and from the island. The coach tour on the island and the guided walking tour more than compensate. Very thought provoking. Perhaps a little more time would be useful and prepare for a full 4-5 hours

Don't miss Robben Island. It is well visiting the Nelson Mandela museum before boarding the boat. Regarding the actual trip : From arriving at Robben Island - this is a well organised trip / the island was bigger than I expected , the bus tour guide was excellent - very knowledgable and friendly. We were then shown around the prison by an ex -political prisoner who had been there for 5 years and been involved in the 1976 uprisings as a teenager.The downside was the fact that the weather was poor the day we went and I was surprised that the boat had open sides - so it was pretty chilly and we were not dressed for the weather! It took an hour to get out to the island. The weather had got even colder when we were due to return. Sadly there was a 2nd boat departing with an inside compartment which looked much more appealing. I don't know who runs runs this boat but if you can take it - I think you will have a more comfortable trip. With regards to things like eating - there is little on the island apart from coffee and chocolate bars so eat before you go, or take a snack! Overall don't miss it - it is a must! You can read about it and see it on TV but nothing replaces seeing it. The whole thing is outrageous - why did those people ever get locked up in solitary confinement - it was a human rights tragedy and quite right that this should be remembered as a world heritage site.

Eye opener. The Robben Island tour is well worth your time and money. We learned quite a bit about the history of the place as a prison/leper colony and the apartheid struggles. Tour of the prison is done by former inmates who have a unique perspective to share. The boat crossing can be a bit rough for those who are land lovers. Go on a calm day and bring some travel sickness tablets just in case.

Emotional visit. This is a tremendous place to visit, to hear the stories from actual inmates who were incarcerated for their political beliefs. I highly recommend this trip, but plan early to get your spot on the ferry.
interesting. Short journey over on the ferry, I found it very interesting, however some people thought it was a wasted morning.

A bit of history.. A very interesting and informative tour. Our guide had been imprisoned there in the 1970s and really gave some insight into what it was like. Boat ride over and back had stunning scenery...and the bus tour around the island was great as well. Bring plenty of water...it gets hot!

Average. Nice trip on the ferry. Fairly unorganised upon arrival with minimal information given by the tour guide overall. Very rushed. The experience overall was interesting though however I wouldn't return as there's not much more I would get from a second trip.

Eyes wide open.... My second visit here and some 12 years apart but still this island asks for much soul searching.An amazing experience and one just stands in awe of the people that had to endure this prison and their stories of oppression. Right or wrong this as something beyond humanity. An excellent tour conducted by one of the ex inmates/prisoners, I do wonder if it could be arranged for an ex prison guard to one day conduct a tour and give another perspective?A very good boat ride to and from the island with wonderful views of Table Mountain and the city of Cape Town.Also take a walk to see the penguins along the boardwalk, we also bumped into a small bok.History was made here, never to be forgotten...

Historic Trip. A must see attraction that you have to visit. The ferry takes approx 1 hour to get to the island. Upon arrival you driven round in a tour bus for 30 mins and given a running commentary on what you see. Then you are walked round the prison by a former political prisoner. Nelson cell was the highlight for me.

A sad and historic place. The Ferry departs from Jetty One at the Waterfront. It's advisable to book in advance! The seas were a bit choppy crossing over, but then the boat was quite sturdy. I disagree with reviewer that the boats are not seaworthy. I doubt whether South Africa will allow, in any case, for visitors to Robben Island to cross over on a rickety banana boat. It was a pleasant sunny day and most passengers sat or stood on the decks. Disappointing was the bus-tour. We could have walked! Information on various areas, as conveyed by the tour-guide on the bus, was short and bitter-sweet. Since such a small is open to visitors, walking would be eco-friendly - instead of polluting fauna and flora with diesel buses. The visit to the prison itself was guided by former prisoner Mr. S. A charming and knowledgeable person. Robben Island reminded of a modern day Concentration Camp and a sad place to visit. Mr. S spent too much time in one area and rushed at the next. There is no proper planning with regard to the splitting of tours around the prison premises - organisation and time management is what they need to improve!! At the end of the Tour it was apparent that we needed to rush back to the boat which was due to leave in 10 minutes!!!! This time the crossing was on a Catamaran- and even this was pleasant!!

A bit disappointing. You are pushed through like cattle, not given time to experience the exhibits. Loaded onto buses and given a bit of a tour of the island; however, seeing the WWII cannon isn't the purpose of people's visits and wouldn't detract from anyone's experience if it wasn't part of the tour.That being said, the tour of the prison area was given by an ex-prisoner and was excellent. It was very interesting to hear of the experience he and others had to endure.We got a little bit of the stupidity of the apartheid system from the tour guide, but more of that and the prisoners' experience and less of the village/outlying areas would make the tour a better experience.Also, figuring out a way to create the tour such that there'd be a self-guided portion with exhibits would be a plus.

Long ferry ride to view historic site. We hurried to make the 1:00 ferry to Robben Island only to have to wait over 1/2 hour for the boat to arrive. The ferry was full and we had to sit inside. Not the most comfortable place to be on a 45 minute ride. There were no drinks or other food items to purchase on the boat even though there was a snack bar. We met some great people from England and that made the trip palatable.When we arrived on the island there were bathrooms but the snack bar had no water for purchase. We were loaded onto busses and given a tour of the island. We saw the prison building, the houses of current inhabitants of the island, the abandoned school, and penguins. We had a knowledgeable guide who provided an informative commentary on our trip.We stopped at another refreshment building and there was water but no soft drinks.We were then let out at the prison and a former political prisoner continued the tour. He was able to fill in the details of life at the prison as he experienced it. We saw the cells and were able to see the cell that Nelson Mandela was in. My son recognized it from the movie INVICTUS which was filmed there. Other cells contained remembrances of the prisoners who had used them. It was moving and extremely interesting. On the ride back we were able to get outside seats which was better but the smell from the bathrooms on the boat was very strong.I was glad we made the trip but it is long ferry ride and somewhat disorganized.

Do not miss Robben Island trip. The trip begins at the V&A Waterfront. Best to get your ticket before you want to travel. Ordered mine directly from them on the internet before leaving home. The trip was so booked they had to take two boats in shifts to Robben Island. You go over by boat and imagine being a prisoner taken to an island where you have no communication with family and friends. The boat can be rocky....coming back in the evening there were very rough waters.When you arrive you are first taken by bus tour around the island. You get history of the Island, other uses besides the prison - leper colony, see the area where prison warden and guards families lived and see the general area of the prison. Of course you can only imagine how nicely it has been fixed up for tours and that the prison is not what Mandela and other political prisoners experienced for decades until it was finally closed. After a bus tour around you are dropped off for a walking tour. The guide will be one of several former prisoners of Robben Island. They tell you about the real conditions prisoners faced. You will see Mandela's cell, the rock quarry (if you've seen the film: Mandela The Long Walk to Freedom, this will all be put into perspective.) Many signs around the island put history into perspective. It was a moving experience and for those close to the experiences of apartheid and the history of S. Africa and Mandela's struggles for freedom, it may leave you breathless. This should be a Do Not Miss tour if you come to Cape Town. Note:There is a small colony of penguin being rebuilt on the island. They use to be plentiful,

So badly organised - new management badly needed. This should have been a poignant and moving tour which in part it was but it was totally ruined by appalling organisation. The boats used I did not feel were sea worthy, there were not enough seats on the coach so people had to stand and no one took any overall responsibility for managing the various bits of the tour to make it a cohesive experience.When it was time to leave there was no boat, and after 2 small vessels arrived but were full we eventually managed to get on the 3rd boat which arrived but arrived back in Cape Town 45 minutes after we had expected to return. At no point was there anyone to tell us what was going on.Sadly my overwhelming memory of the day is of frustrion and anger about the manner in which we were treated.

Nelson Mandela. We took a ferry across to Robben Island from a location called Clock Tower at the waterfront downtown area of Capetown. It's best to book your tickets online before leaving as they are sold out pretty quickly. Also, if the weather is too windy, the ferry ride gets canceled (same with Table Mountain, best to go first thing in the morning before the wind kicks up). You need to arrive at least a half hour early for ferry as it's first come, first served. Once you arrive on the island you take a tour and are shown Mandela's cell. It's a big island so much of it is toured by bus, included in your ticket price.

Ultimately disappointing. We took the advice and booked our tickets online before we set off for Cape Town. Weather and rough seas caused our initial trip to be cancelled - however, the service, information and online admin. at this stage were all excellent. We re-booked and set off full of anticipation. Unfortunately, there was a mess-up with the buses at the island harbour and we walked up to the prison, only to be told - on the tour bus - that we were going all the way back to the harbour to pick up some people from a later ferry! Our on-bus guide had a delivery and style he was determined to use to the full - despite the not inconsiderable delay - and the island tour was, frankly, unnecessary and boring, with almost nothing to see except the limestone quarry. And why we needed a 'pit-stop' after 30 minutes, only the cafe-bar owners will know! Once we finally got into the actual prison itself, things improved with a first class presentation from a former prisoner who had an awesome, inspirational style. Sadly, we had used up so much of our time that he had to rush the final part of the tour, so we were left with virtually no time to take in the 'read-only' displays and almost ran back to catch the last ferry. Overall, this was not as interactive or informative as we had hoped - by comparison check out Alcatraz! - so we were left very disappointed, and being over an hour late getting back into Cape Town did nothing to help our mood.

Fun Experience (once). This island prison is great for fans of island prisons. I don't think I need to visit again. I was soaked on the boat ride back to the mainland due to the huge swells that drenched those but the few who found shelter in the boats tiny cabin. Beware!

Disapointing visit to Robben Island. We went on a morning tour to the Island. It is important to order tickets days in advance. In summer the tours are sold out days before your planned trip. Important: The boats departs from the pier close to the Clock Tower. Many tourist maps show a wrong departure location. In rough sea the departures often are cancelled with short notice. On arrival to the Island you will line up for a one hour bus drive around at the southern part of the Island. There will be a guide on board telling the story of the Island. There is very little to see. Only a couple of queries where building materials were cut from the limestone and granite. A few historical buildings. Thats all, but the view to Cape Town and Table mountain is stunning.The final tour of the prison was in some way interesting. But the former prisoner explained about the daily life of the prisoners with a very low voice, which could only be heard by the people closest to him. You can get much more info about the subject from one of the many books about the Island and the life of Mandela.Do not bring smaller kids on the tour. There is very little for them to do.In general you will only feel a kick of history being there. Thats all. Spend instead your time visiting Stellenbosch and Cape the good hope or climb the Lions Head if you are in shape. The view to Cape Town is worth the trouble getting to the top.

Don't listen to poor reviews just go and enjoy. First tip book on line for your ticket and save the q,s - get on the boat early to get a good seat - Sit back and take pictures of the V&A as you leave Cape Town. As you arrive on the island get on the bus and look for guides with smiles, they will make everything magic with tales of the past and stories and historical facts. When the bus tour is over and you enter the prison take it for what it was and just remember. A joy for me to hear the reality and not some Bs

Thought provoking & a must see. Trips get booked up quickly, try to pre book - I felt privileged to visit it while Nelson Mandela was still alive. It was initially an isolation hospital prior to being a prison. Excellent guides, most informative & they speak from personal experience as most were prisoners here themselves. Desolate place & makes the hairs on the back on your neck stand up. Difficult for wheelchairs & buggies re rocky surface & steps.

A "Must Do" in Cape Town. Last time I was here I wasn't able to go to Robben Island due to the weather so I was determined to get there this time ....and I wasn't disappointed. The ferry over is slightly over crowded but the staff are very amusing!!! The guide that took us on the bus around the Island was charming, knowledgeable and very interesting. The ex inmate that took us around the actual prison was amazing. Such an experience... you would be remiss not to visit if you are in Cape Town

You Must go.. Trip across ok with sun and wind albeit a very long queue and wait to get onto the boat - bus trip around the island not bad but a lot of stopping - visit to the prison guided by a former prisoner excellent .Journey back sea very very rough first boat had to turn back and we had to wait for a bigger boat but still all of the passengers got soaked !We thought we wouldn't get back !

Thought provoking. We had been told not to bother with Robben Island, as it didn't have the 'wow' factor and was badly organised. We did go and are so glad we did. The organisation was fine and the afternoon went without any hitches. The tour of the island, and the facility, was firstly made for us by our tour guide, who himself had been part of the student unrest in '76, and his passion and knowledge brought to life the recent history of South Africa and the island. He had a coach load of people from numerous countries hanging on to his every word. Then came the former political prisoner who showed us round the prison, who was equally as enthralling, and detailed the history of the prison without a hint of bitterness or malice. It was all very poignant and moving, from which we got a far better understanding of the struggles, and we're even more amazed therefore that the leaders taught forgiveness, and encouraged equality and forward thinking, when vengeance might have been an easier choice. The world has a great deal to learn from the people who inhabited the island. 3 hours very well spent and an absolute must if you're in Cape Town.

Prisoner sharing experience is the best. We had a very nice boat trip across to Robben Island, with sun, no wind, and lots of seal and otter sightings. The initial bus tour around the island was OK, but the visit to the prison, guided by a former prisoner was the real treat. Absolutely fascinating, and scary, history, and it is not only about Mandela, but so many others as well. I really enjoyed it.

Robben Island finally. After trying five times spread over 5 years I finally got to visit Robben Island.Indeed we joked Nelson Mandela spent 18 years trying to get off and we spent 5 years trying to get on.I have to admit the effort and waiting to get on to the Island were well worth it.It was the most interestinfg and informative visit I have ever made to a tourist attraction.The tour guide( sometimes a previous inmate) was most pleasent and answered every question put to him. A trip that must be undertaken by anyone visiting CapeTown

An iconic place to visit. I didn't visit Robben Island on my first trip to Cape Town in 2012 so on my recent visit in February I made sure to do the trip. It is an iconic place and worth visiting for that reason alone, but I won't be going back. As per other reviews, we went on a calm day and the boat ride still wasn't great. Admittedly I don't like boats and particularly on the trip back (on an older slower boat I think) I couldn't wait to get off. It's about 45 minutes on the boat each way.The tour is too long, it would be much better if you could walk around the island rather than be shuffled on to a bus where you don't see much and then get sent in a massive group on a walk through the prison. There is a great gift shop on the island. Less time being pushed through and more time to take your own pace where you want would improve the experience.

Very poignant. . I've read a lot of reviews here regarding the trip to Robben Island and despite a lot of bad reviews I decided I had to go. Booked over the counter at the V & A Waterfront for a trip 2 days later. Got there for the 11am trip, straight onto a decent boat. Crossing was pretty quick (45 mins or so) and pretty smooth. Once there a bus trip, this is a bit rushed and you can only take pics through the windows but it was informative. Then back to the prison where we met a man who was a former prisoner Sipho Nkosi. He was excellent. Told his story and the story of the prisoners prior to his arrival (including Mr Mandela of course) very well, I found it pretty moving to be honest. You can't go into Mandela ' s cell but it gives you a glimpse and that is enough. I came away with a better understanding of what happened, and you realise things like a bus tour being a bit rushed, pale into insignificance compared to being forced to work for 8 hours a day in a lime quarry in the blazing hot sun. This is something that simply has to be done.

Fascinating and moving. While I agree with other reviewers that there are way too many people on the buses and the time spent seeing Mandela's cell rushed the trip is still very worthwhile. We had a smooth trip over and back and an excellent informative guide on the bus. Our former prison inmate who guided us through the gaol had a fascinating and moving story to tell. In contrast to others we actually waited until the end and had a bit more time to reflect over Mandela's cell. The guide waited until we were ready to leave. We did however, have to then rush to catch the return boat. Despite any issues this is something that should not be missed in Cape Town.

We didn't get to go :(. This was our first visit to SA, and we were planning on visiting Robben Island during our time in Cape Town. I had heard that trips can be cancelled due to choppy seas, so had booked it for our first day. Unfortunately, our trip got cancelled. We went to the Waterfront to try and book for the next day, but the boats were already full, so we didn't get to go. We did get a refund, but it was very disappointing, especially when we had booked over a month in advance.There is a free museum at the Waterfront which we looked around, but the AV exhibitions were out of order, and the information was quite limited. I think maybe more money/time could be invested in improving the museum, as for some visitors this is the only bit of Robben Island that we will get to experience. Also having a better system in place for people who had their trip cancelled i.e. running an extra boat the next day to ensure people do get to go if the weather improves.

Essential but with flaws. Of course you have to see it, I realise that. But having said that, there is work to be done for the museum I think. I visited Robben Island with my daughter on sunday 2 march. The following I can say:1) the boat should not have sailed, the wind was way too strong and the sea too rough.. If you doubt it, do not go, it was not a pleausre to be at sea.2) The tour group was way too big , around 80 people for one guide. That does not work.3) The bust for the tour around Robben Island was not very comfortable4) Perhaps they should find ways to cut the tour a bit shorter, 3 and 1/2 hours is not necessary.5) Perhaps improve the tour a bit, make it a bit more interactive, modern, educational for children, it really didn't work wel with so many people and just the one guide.6) The visit to the cel of Mandela is way at the end. Realise that it is now closed (used to be open) and you have about 10 seconds for it, so walk up front of the tour if you want a decent picture.7) It is essential, and I would take my daughter again, but perhaps the board of the museum could work and fix a few things, it is needed I think..

Well worth the long boat trip and bus tour. For some the 2+ hours round trip on the boat will be a treat with great view of Cape Town and Table Mountain, for others they will be endless. The too long bus tour of the island has visitors packed like sardines on the buses, but the reward, two hours after leaving the waterfront is the actual visit of the prison, led by former residents, who amazingly describe their ordeal in the first person and seem to have completely forgiven. Their testimonials make a 4 1/2 to 5 hours visit almost worthwhile.

Poignant but not polished..... Regardless of one's political leaning, a visit to Robben Island is worth considering and, surprisingly, it is not all about Nelson Mandela although he does feature strongly in the visit.The boat crossing is dependent on the state of the weather/tidal swell and the craft you are on - outwards we had a mill pond smooth crossing in a chartered cruiser whilst the return trip was more eventful in a medium swell and on board one of the older vessels (which used to take the prisoners to/from the island)!Other reviewers have hinted that the tour itself is somewhat rushed but you do get round all aspects of the visit - bus trip / comfort break / ex political prisoner's talk / prison tour / Mr Mandela's cell / etc.It all seems to work albeit not in a slick manner.....we felt this added to, as opposed to detracted from, the visit.We missed out on the trip when we had previously visited Cape Town because we were unable to purchase "over the counter / on the day" tickets so this time we pre-booked them via the internet before we left the UK....little tip here.

Excellent visit. We took the trip to Robben island today after almost being put off by the bad reviews on tripadvisor. We were really glad that we did take the trip as we found most of the things written to be untrue. The ride over wasn't pleasant but that's hardly the fault of the crews who did everything they could to keep it safe and comfy despite the high waves caused by the windy weather. Indeed, some passengers embraced the boat ride sitting on the vessel's bow as it crashed through the waves emitting hoots of joy as the sea spray rose over them. When we arrived we were told exactly how our two hour tour would be spent. First there was the tour of the high security prison with ex prisoner guide ( I think called Mr Nkosa) who spoke clearly and was charming. He showed us exactly which cell had housed Nelson Mandela for so many years as well as telling us his own story of his five years spent on Robben island. Then straight to the bus tour where a young guide did a good job showing us the quarry where the political prisoners spent weeks breaking rocks in the sun but also planning out a new national constitution in a small cave. A quick stop for ice cream and ladies room (very clean) and to take a picture with table mountain viewed over the waves (table mountain wasn't mentioned once by any of the guides) and then back to the port for the ride home. I felt so glad that we weren't put off and took the tour despite these bad reviews and really want you guys to hear the other side of the story!

Disappointing 1970s style bus tour. This is an important part of world history so I would still urge travellers to go but it is badly structured and organised so don't expect too much. The trip starts with an hour long journey on a dirty, noisy, poorly maintained boat (two ladies on the trip fell backwards when the back of their seat fell off. It had obviously been "repaired" before). On arrival at the island, visitors are guided onto buses for a 45 minute tour of the island's sights. The guide was reasonably entertaining and informative but the enforced jollity was a bit wearing. All a bit reminiscent of a 1970s package tour to Spain!The second half of the tour is a guided visit to the prison block conducted by an old inmate. Again, interesting but, for me, the presentation style had too much "entertainment" value and not enough focus on the situation that resulted in Mandela and others being there. There is no time for individual reflection, to wander around, to take in the enormity of apartheid rule etc. in fact, at the end of the tour all 80 on the trip literally had to run down the quayside to catch the boat to the mainland. Despite the fact that the boat was laid on specially for the tour, the crew wanted home, a handful of our group, including a young lady in a wheelchair, were left on the quay. In summary, a disappointing tour but still a must see

Robben Island - not for the faint hearted!. It seems that the boats taking visitors to the Island are now chartered. The whole experience was indifferent, and in parts scary. The guides were not up to scratch, the monologue unstructured, difficult to understand and put into context. The significant swell (causing further trips to be cancelled) for return journey on the so-called "Jolly Roger", a pseudo-pirate ship, which pitched and rolled for 100 minutes back to Cape Town marred the entire experience. Think twice about this excursion, the experience doesn't live up to its billing.

Robben Island Farce.. Booked to visit Robben Island at 1.00pm on Tuesday 18th February. We ascertained that the ferry had broken down and would be replaced by smaller boats-none of this information was officially announced. We waited until 2.30pm in a long queue and then abandoned the trip since the staff did not know what was happening and none of them cared. This was our only bad experience in South Africa. You urgently need to replace your casual management and staff with personnel that are efficient and caring. Patrick and Pauline O'Shea.

Very Rushed and Unstructured Tour. We pre-booked the tickets from the UK for this trip after reading the reports of being sold out for up to 5 days and opted for the 09:00 trip. Arrived around 08:30 and queued for about 45 minutes to go on the old prison boat over to Robben Island, its a slow (packed full) boat compared to the newer boat that over took within minutes and was out of sight within minutes so be prepared for a 45-60 minute trip to the island. You are no sooner off the boat and then on a bus, we as a family of 5 (including 2 children 7 & 10) were pushed onto an already full bus and split up to take up any remaining seats so not great for the children.The guide was Ok but seemed more interested in where we all cam from & telling us about the wildlife on Robben Island and giving us photo opportunities of Table Mountain rather that why 99% of people were there and to learn more about the prison in which Nelson Mandela was kept for so many years.There were so many iconic sights and information boards that you cannot get to read or see as you are never let out of the bus other than at the shop to take more photos of ......Table Mountain!!!The guide even told us that we should complain to the Tourist Board about the trip as he said the routine was out dated and needed a complete makeover including walking and cycling options around the Island.After about 30 minutes we were dropped off at the entrance to the prison to be given a guided tour by an ex prisoner. I understand that all the guides have their own story of why they were imprisoned and their time on Robben Island but again 99% of the people are there for one reason - Nelson Mandela and wanted more of an insight into his time and influence while on Robben Island. We had to ask which was his cell and then it was a mad rush for everyone to take a photo as we were ushered out of the corridor and back into the exercise yard. We were then told we had 10 minutes before the boats were leaving and to make sure we didn't miss these as we would have to wait 3 hours for the next ones to depart. The little gift shop by the boat drop off point is never going to make any money as visitors haven't got time to go in. We had our photos taken as we got onto the boat at the start of the day but never found out where these could be purchased.What should be a thought provoking trip into such an Iconic piece of South African history was let down by poor organisation and structure to the trip.

Must see but plan it!. First off I think this sight is s must see when in Cape Town. But plan shead - meaning buying the tickets online in advance and be prepared to reschedule due to bad weather. Secondly plan a full day. My trip supposedly started at 1pm and I was back 5 hours later and it felt a bit rushed. The tour on the island is actually given by a former political prisoner, followed by a bus tour. I would have lived to spent annually more time to go around myself.

Miss the boat - Lose your money.. I prebooked a trip to Robben Island prior to leaving Australia. Our flt took 14 hours and by the time we checked into our hotel we were shattered. To add to our problems the date on my watch had not changed. Therefore, when we rocked up for our trip we were a day late. I explained what had occurred but the staff at the Nelson Mandela at the V&A dock where the ferry leaves from, were unrelenting. No rescheduling, either that day or any other. They were adamant that we were not going to Robben Island unless we purchased two more tickets. As we were on a budget this was not possible. I can understand a NO REFUND policy, but surely it is not too much to expect a reschedule. Coming fromAustralia we are unable to return and this has left a very bitter taste of our visit to what is after all a lovely friendly city.
Tribute to the legends. Good insight into Robben Island, a place full of history. Enjoyed walking around with the ex prisoner and finding out about the daily lives of prisoners.

A pilgrimage as it were. Considering I am South African, Robben Island seems to be one of those places that one needs to visit in one's lifetime to consider yourself a true South African - a pilgrimage as it were. So dutifully, I booked a trip out to the island with friends. I think my expectations were far greater however, and sadly this meant I was left slightly disappointed. Having said that, I am very pleased we took the afternoon to visit the World Heritage Site and put ourselves in the shoes of prisoners.In fact, one's guide is a former inmate of the prison. Ours was passionate & informative. He had the unique ability to get you to empathise with him as he transported you back to the harsh realities of prison life. This part of the tour is the reason I have given 4 stars to the experience because I believe this is what it is about - to get visitors to understand, reflect, empathise and walk away with confidence in knowing just how far South Africa has come.And of course there is Mandela's prison cell which has its own unique ambience or 'presence' as it were. I would've liked to have spent more time there to experience the solitude, but mass tourism is unfortunate in that way - it does not afford time.I would recommend people to go. Would I go again? Probably not.TOP TIPS: the views across the bay of Cape Town and Table Mountain from the island are unrivalled. You can also send yourself a postcard from the island's post office which is franked with its own Robben Island stamp.

A pilgrimage to the heroes of South Africa. The short ferry ride from V & A waterfront provides a great postcard picture of the Cape Town waterfront. Small surprises like a sighting of whales, dolphin and seals provided extra delights.The prison visit itself was a pilgrimage to pay homage to not just Mandela but also the many who have helped end apartheid in South Africa. The ex-detainee giving a brief recount of his experience was a nice touch, though we are probably unable to fully apprehend the environment they were living under. The rest of the island also provided many good spots to take pictures of the mainland and a visit to the island is a must for its historical importabce

Slow and boring, not worth your time. This is a long excursion. You will spend at least 4 hours. And that is way too long in comparision to the useful information you get. We started at 14:15 with waiting for the 15:00 boat. That boat left at 15:30 and took 60 minutes to get to the island. The boat was small and the engine was very loud. On the island you will go on a 45 minute bus tour with a 15 minute break in the middle. The guide on the bus had little information and the bus was very full. After the bus tour you go on a tour with an ex-prisoner. Again there where way too many people and the prisoner told us only about the basic stuff. Like how many people go in a cell and how they communicated with other prisoners. And he shows you the cell of Mandela. Which looks like any other....There are two boats, a slow one and a fast one. But you have to go back on the boat you came with. But apparently they only told that to the people on the fast boat. So lots of people of the slow boat got in the fast one. Nobody was there to check their tickets... But when the captain found out he let is crew take all the slow-boat-people of this vessel. Even elderly people who had trouble walking and standing on boats. Then the slow boat people had to wait for the slow boat to come and get them. We where back on the shore after 19:00....

Very moving. I found the tour very moving and educational, both our guides were excellent and our group was not too big although we did not go over with a group, the boat ride is not great if you get a bit sea sick, the catamarans are better, but book in advance, we booked before we left the UK, and we heard lots of stories of people not being able to get tickets whilst we were there

I was expecting more. I do not know why but I was expecting more. One big problem - it is not suitable for people with mobility problems. It cannot cater for wheelchairs either. I had difficulty helping my friend and she was given a wheelchair but without the help of other visitors we would not have been able to enter many places. Also it is not suitable for young children as they are unable to listen to the explanations and because of their chatter, we could not hear. Again the host was unable to wait for us to keep up with him because of steps or steep ramps to negotiate with the wheelchair.3 hour round trip by boat.

Complicated and challenging. This was a big deal for us and a real highlight of our visit to Cape Town from KZN, especially at the point when Madiba was in hospital and very close to death. I thought the tour - boat / bus / prison - was very well organised, but we could have done with more explanation from the outset. The prison tour was good - the most moving part of it that the tour guide was a former political prisoner. And the visit to Madiba's cell was profoundly moving - like a pilgrimage to the tomb of a saint. I think - and I feel this for the whole future of SA - is that we need a vision of the future based on robust confidence rather than simple celebration of a (remarkable) hero. I'm in the UK at the moment but back in KZN in the autumn and will be fascinated to see how different things feel following Madiba's death.

A big let down. I first did the Robben Island tour many years ago, not long after it first opened in that capacity. I was keen to have a refresher and had such fond memories of that amazing trip. How times have changed. What a disappointment it was this time around, a completely different experience and one that we will never go on again. The ferries were late out and we were kept sweltering in the 'holding bay' for an extended period of time with no communication. Eventually the boat came and took well over an hour to get to the island. The tour on the bus around the island was so fleeting and rushed and cursory now and the guide very disappointing and robotic. The main focus of the trip seemed to be how many people they could get on and how quickly it could be 'done'. It is an honour meeting the gentleman that did the prison tour and he spoke very well but again the tour group numbers of far too big and the time way too rushed to get any meaningful experience out of it. Shame on the tour company.

Give it a miss. The tour was very crowded, not well organised and there is not a whole lot to see on the island. A 45 minutes bus drive on the island is the worst part of the tour. There are more worthwhile tours in Cape Town.

Wonderful. My trip to Robben Island was the cherry on the top for me. I enjoyed every moment of the trip and the tour guide was a source of information. It was so heart rending seeing Mandela's cell and all the other cells. Mandela's book"the Long walk to freedom" was made alive to me.

Slow start but worth it. Shambolic start - huge queues, waiting more than an hour and then no info before news of a 40 min delay. Total 2 hours standing in line and NO customer skills. Once underway though, a great trip and so pleased we did no bale out like so many.....

AWFUL. A wasted opportunity.. We were in South Africa for 2 amazing weeks. Our Robben Island trip was the lone awful part of our stay.The trip began with a 30 minute boat ride over the ocean and to the island. At the very worst this could have been a nice relaxing boat excursion -- and at best it could have been an opportunity to get the visitors in the somber mood of the prison they are about to visit. There could have been stories shared of what the prisoners and guards felt as they took the long boat ride to isolation. "COULD HAVE BEEN". What was it in reality?? As I type it i can't even believe it happened. There was an American rap star on our little boat. He gave the captain his CD to play over the boat's loud speakers. So we were treated to 30 minutes of loud rap of the worst kind, with profanity, and references too vulgar to repeat in this space. After passengers complained, on the return trip they played "ambiance music" -- some ridiculous background music, also with singing etc. Just dumb and ruined the experience of the cruise. The ocean is background music enough.The next part of the trip was the bus tour of the island. The guide was pathetic. Most of the bus tour was spent making lame jokes and playing off the visitor's countries of origin. There was NO information shared about life on the island that I didn't already know from reading 2 paragraphs in my guide book. We stopped to walk around near a gift shop and to take pictures of Table Mountain. LAME. And again, a wasted opportunity to actually educate the tourists. Nelson Mandela is obviously the reason why people come to Robben Island. The guide called Mandela "One of a kind" and "a great great man" and "a giant." All cliches, but I left with not one new insight into what actually made him great, or how his stay at the Island influenced him.The third part was the tour of the prison led by a former prisoner. Now the idea of former prisoners leading tours of the prison is brilliant. But just because you were arrested 40 years ago for fighting apartheid doesn't mean you're qualified to be a tour guide!!! The man was very difficult to understand, spoke in generalities, shared little of his own experience, and just looked like someone who was bored to be there. There was another tour group with a guide that sounded more interesting and professional, and we wanted to join that group instead but weren't sure if their tour was already ending or just beginning. Overall, this was just a disgrace. You have thousands of captive visitors on this tour, eager to learn about South Africa and to experience its intense history on an emotional personal level. Instead they are taken on this tacky tip-hungry tour that teaches absolutely nothing. We spoke to others and it seems that the quality of guides is highly uneven, and you might get lucky with better guides. Which is really a shame since all of us visitors have a limited time in Cape Town and wasting the afternoon with the awful guides we had is really upsetting. Train the guides who want to be there, and fire the rest...... and if you can't fire them because they are former prisoners and ANC members... well then write them a good compelling script to memorize.
History. Good place to learn part of the history of South Africa, its political past, resilience and forgiving nature of its people.

Interesting. We visited Robben Island on Valentines day 2014 - pre booked our tickets on-line.The ferry ride there was not the most fun especially if one is prone to sea sickness - I wished they could have at least sold sodas on the boat, to curb the nauseas feeling.Once on the island, we were taken on a bus tour of the island. Our guide had a thick coloured accent and it was difficult to understand him at timesI was extremely disappointed after making a pitt stop at a cafe and once on the bus again, the tour guide says that Madiba's former prison warden was in the cafe. It would have been nice to have spoken to him, and from my research, this prison warden works on the island now and I am sure he would have taken questions.Also, we did not get to view Robert Sobukwe prison cell but we had seen other tours jumping off and viewing it.The second part of the trip was interesting - our guide was an ex political prisoner - it was interesting to hear what he went through and and the people he met and about life in general at Robben Island.A highlight from the day was that 14 couples got married on the 14 of Feb at Robben Island - it was lovely seeing all the couples in their bridal garments.

Moving and informative. This was our third attempt to get to Robben Island as previous times the trip was fully booked on the days we wanted to go, we decided to pre book online and we were really happy we did, everything about the trip went well and our guide on the Island was a former inmate who was very informative and made the experience real and very moving, this trip is a must for anyone visiting Cape Town.

A fascinating look into the history of Robben Island and apartheid. Robben island is a must-see for any visitor to Cape Town. However, as the attraction is immensely popular, strongly buying your tickets on-line before depart for Cape Town. The ferry to the island leaves from a complex in the Victoria and Albert Waterfront. The departure terminal includes a small museum. Upstairs, the museum details the involvement of the Irish opposing apartheid, while downstairs in the departure terminal, there is a very interesting display on the history of Robben Island. Unfortunately, we could not look at this display as the staff kept us constrained in an area where we couldn't really read the exhibit properly. The ferry ride is a short, 30 minute, ride out to the island. There, you board busses for a guided tour around the island. Our tour guide was awesome and provided an interesting glimpse into life on the island, both today and in the past. After the tour ride, we were escorted into the prison building itself for a face-to-face tour with an ex-inmate of Robben Island. I had high hopes for this part of the program, but was disappointed. The tour group I was with numbered around fifty. They placed us in one of the large rooms where inmates lived and spoke with us for about 30 minutes. He was difficult to hear due to the size of the room. Afterwards, we walked through the high-value prisoner court yard and the wing where Nelson Mandela was kept. We were able to view his cell.I think that there was a great deal of opportunity for a more historical experience at this venue. Rather I found the displays and information, other than our tour driver, to be somewhat sparse.Of note, the tour does circle the island and at one point you can exit and take some photos of a spectacular view of Cape Town and Table Mountain.Robben Island should be on the itinerary for any visitor to Cape Town, but temper your expectations.

Enjoyed it!. Was very pleased with the tour of Robben Island and the information that was given; really learned a lot of new details regarding the island and Nelson Mandela. The boat was extremely late and no staff kept us apprised of what was going on but once we arrived it was fun and educational. This is a must do if you ever travel to Cape Town.

Overly commercial but a must see! . A trip to Robben Island was at the top if my list when visiting Cape Town, but after hearing varying reviews was unsure of what to expect. The ferry to the island was fine, but it is only transport and not part of the tour, and the return leg was incredibly unorganised. You have to take a bus tour around the island, and we were very lucky with our guide who was very informative and told us lots of history about the island, but I heard that other guides aren't that great. The tour around the main prison was moving and sent shivers down my spine, and our guide who is a surviving prisoner answered all our questions, but I felt it was slightly rushed as there was another group behind us.A trip to Robben Island should be at the top of your list if you are visiting Cape Town, but be aware, it has been turned in to something incredibly commercial. It is still a moving experience but feel this would work better if they went with the 'less is more idea' and let it just be the place it is without turning it in to a tourist circus!!

Interesting tour, lovely views!. The boat trip was fairly chaotic but we got lucky as only had half an hour delay on the way out there and scored for the fast catamaran. The people we met on the way back hadn't been able to get on their return boat as it was full and had waited 2 hours for our boat, unlucky them!(their whole trip had taken over 7 hours!). On arrival we met our tour guide and were bussed around then did the prison on foot with a former inmate who was interesting. The only problem i suppose was that the group was huge but we saw everything and weren't rushed at all. The views back to CapeTown are amazing.

Boat service not organised very well. Given there are generally 4 boat trips per day, every two hours for the whole tour, you would expect to return on the boat you arrived on, after your visit? Wrong! Somehow, the organisation managed to hack 50 people off by a) not having enough capacity to return when scheduled and b) being unable to communicate when any boats would arrive and where they would dock. This detracted from the whole experience, injecting a level of farce I've not seen for many years. Tip - do NOT schedule anything too near to when you are expected to return from your visit.

This really is a must see. In cape Town and so yes Robben Island was on the list to see, but I had no idea at all just how big an impact it would have. The first day sailings were cancelled, so booked for a week later. It wasn't a great day weather wise, there was a heavy sea fog and so we were very slow getting there. Then there was a problem with the coaches to what had been the prison. Then the group we ended up in was about 100 strong - nothing seemed to be going right until our guide spoke. he was called XhoXho (apologies if i have spelled that incorrectly). He had been a prisoner, he was a survivor of the Soweto uprisings, he was an amazing person. He told us about what it had been like being there, he showed us Mandela's cell, he showed us where he had been incarcerated.Then he thanked us, he thanked everyone who had signed a petition, boycotted goods, written letters, demonstrated against apartheid, undertaken any action, he thanked us, the International Red Cross, and governments around the world for helping to end apartheid. He spoke with honesty and passion, I don't think there was a dry eye. It was one of the most inspiring experiences ever. Don't hesitate, don't let the weather put you off - just go.

A Must Visit while in Capetown. We visited Robben Island on a very cool, overcast day which sort of set the mood for our tour. Our tour guide on the bus was great, provided lots of good information about the island itself. After her portion of the tour was over, we were dropped off at the prison where we were led through the prison by a tour guide who was a former political prisoner, some of which was during the same period in which Mandela was incarcerated there. He was wonderful, answering any and all questions about his time there, how he felt about coming back to work there as a guide. It was certainly sobering to learn of the hardships endure there. I can understand how some folks were down on this tour if their prison guide was not good. We really lucked out.

A "must do". Few tiny hiccups but overall an amazing trip and very good value. 45mins each way on very modern ferries (don't let anyone tell you it's 20mins!) but very comfortable with bar on board. Excellent, informative, guided bus tour round island and then talk from ex-prisoner, a charming gentleman. Hampered for some people by language, There should be printed handouts in different languages with approximate translations of what he said. Slightly disorganised return trip. There should be much stricter allocation of places on the ferries. The first come, first served does not work!!! but all in all.... super tour.

Disappointing. For a highly booked up tour, it was disorganised. From the ticket collection to the tour itself. Only good thing was being able to say you've been there. Tour was uninformative. Ferry trip was good but slow and very unsafe. Tour guide at the prison couldn't speak English properly and the tour guide on the bus hardly pointed out any points and didn't give much insight to the island. Do some reading before you go on the island about it and its history as you won't find out much on the tour.

Poignant, but the actual experience is poor........ A trip to Robben Island was a real "must do" for me, particularly since the death of Mr Mandela. I had to buy my ticket on Friday to travel on Sunday - it was fully booked until then. I presented myself at 10.30 (for the 11 o'clock trip), and stood in line for ages while the surly staff scanned barcodes and scanned your bag. Eventually got onto a rickety old wooden boat, and there were no seats, so had to perch on a corner in the blazing sunshine for the 45 minute boat ride. Not a great start.Got off the boat and we all had to get on a bus. After 5 minutes on the bus, we all had to get off to visit the refreshment hut! We then got back on the bus, and the interesting guide pointed things out to us through the windows. We weren't allowed to get off. so no pictures could be taken, which was a shame.After the bus, I thought the best part of the trip was to come - the ex-prisoner guide. Alas, all he did was ask everyone (all 50 people in the group) where they came from. It was such a tedious waste of a precious 5 minutes where we should have been hearing tales of the past. He also waffled on about lots of other things that had nothing to do with Robben Island, and he shouted at us like he was leading a protest march! The most poignant part should have been seeing Nelson Mandela's cell, but he spent another 5 minutes waffling on about goodness knows what, then said - "oh, here's the cell that was used by Mandela". We all then had to quickly file past the cell taking a quick snap each as there were 50 people in the group. No time to reflect, nothing.After visiting Alcatraz in the past, I expected atmosphere and time to walk around on your own to really get a feel for the place, but instead we were herded along and then had to run to catch the ferry back. No time for reflection. Very disappointed. Be aware too that the ferries never run on time - We were due back at 14.30, but actually arrived back at 15.15, and apparently the 11.00 tour is the one with the shortest delays! Don't book anything straight after this tour, as the chances are high that you will get back late.

An emotionally significant visit, but poor logistics. If I could comment only on the significance of the visit, I would score it as tops. This is after all where the late Mr Mandela and many others who wanted a democratic SA suffered for so many years and one is overwhelmed by those thoughts as a South African. However, it's about the whole experience. First, I was given false information about the running of the Sikhululekile ferry. Twice I contacted the offices, once through Cape Town Tourism at the airport and once personally. I was assured the ferry as stipulated on our tickets is running. It was not. Our 09:00 "ferry" left 50 mins. late with one unclear announcement made by staff about a 15 min. delay. No regular communication; you are just left there in the queue. Had to also wait for a boat once we wanted to leave the island. Nothing was on schedule and consequently we had to cancel other planned activities. The guide we had on the bus ride on the island was really knowledgable and a lovely warm person. It was also very special to be led through the cells by an ex-prisoner, but this was so rushed and he never made sure that his group was with him or that we could all hear what he was saying. I expected so much more. I wonder if Robben Island museum read these reviews? Do they care about us as visitors? Of course, one MUST visit Robben Island non-withstanding my complaints! It is very special.

Ferry left late, little service. Booked a tour for 1 pm. At 1.30 pm announcement was made, 1 hour delay. Nodody explained delay or found words of excuse. Boat ride takes about 35 - 40 minutes. On arrival one gets on a bus, side guide was very entertaining. Village of Robben Island I found semi interesting, lime quarry gave more inside of working condition of prisioners. 20 minutes stop at coffee shop and then heading to prison. A former prisoner undertook tour and added quiet personal touch. My thought a therapy would may be more helpful than working still at the place which was filled with bad memories. Few information about Nelson Mandela, more about Robben Island and its history. If you have little time in Cape Town I would go for other option.

Excellent Tour!!!!. I went to Robben Island in September. We booked the 9am tour and we had some crazy swells on the ferry over. A lot of reviews complain that the boat was nothing more than a ferry, well that's because it is a ferry. It's not meant to be a ride, but just transportation. When we got to the island we had great tour guides directing us into buses. The tour guide on my bus was absolutely amazing (I'm sorry I forgot his name)! We had so many great facts about the island, wildlife, and was very personable. We even Our guide for the prison was Sparks. He was a former inmate and was the kindest man. He led us thru the prison, telling his story and the story of Mandela. It was a great tour and nothing short of our expectations. Highly recommend if you are interested in history.

Very Moving. Anyone who visits Robben Island and is unmoved most be made of stone. What a poignant trip this was particularly only a few weeks after Nelson Mandela had passed away.The trip from a tourist point of view is well worth the money and from an historical point of view isjust unmissable. The sacrifices that those guys made was just incredible!!

impressive. the tour starts with a pleasant boat ride, table mountain on the background and giant ships waiting to (un)load before the harbour. On the island you start with a 45 min bus tour and find out that the Island is not only about Mandela.But the visit to the prison is the most impressive part. Especially because the guide is a former prisoner; their stories give you goosebumps and make you realize how hard they fought against the apartheid and what sacrifices they made. A must do when you visit Cape Town, it’s part of history!

It's a must. We took a boat from Nelson Mandela Gateway (Waterfront) and arrived on the island about 40 minutes later. There seemed to be many different boats leaving from the Gateway, which caused a bit of confusion. We had bought tickets online for the ferry at 11 a.m. but got there early and left with another boat (not a ferry) at maybe 10.40 a.m. instead so there seemed to be more boats leaving than what was said on the timetable.Like everybody else says, there is a bus tour with a guide, then a guided tour of the cells with an old prisoner. It feels like a tour you must have done if you have been to Cape Town.

S Africa's Alcatraz. Standing on the windswept rocks of Robben Island, looking over the bay 5 miles to Capetown, I thought of how lonely and forlorn Mandela and the political prisoners must have felt. Close enough to your friends and family that you can see their lights, but only allowed 1 letter every 6 months. And if the guards were angry at you, they would white-out most of the letter and tell you "too bad" and you have to wait another 6 months for a letter.Once you get inside the prison, your guide is an actual former political prisoner. I wish we had asked him more questions re his personal experience. We missed a unique opportunity to understand how he withstood his time there.

Robben Island trip. After reading previous reviews and feedback from others staying at our digs we made sure to get on the 11am trip and no later.I have to agree that with others that there is something lacking with the trip. I felt the boat trip was basically a ferry. Did not feel like it was part of the trip as the crew were not interested in the passengers. Loads of1990s music was played which for us was good as it was our coming of age but for the older generation (mostly fresh off the Queen Mary 2) they expected some commentary.We were very lucky with our your guides they were great!We were on the first bus and the tour of the island was very informative to get a background into what life was like for both the inmates and the staff who stayed there and the families who are living there presently. There was a 10 minute stop off which was long enough before heading back across the island to the limestone quarry before disembarking for the prison tour.Our tour guide was Glen. We feel very humbled to have met him after hearing his story of his stay in the prison.On both tours it was interesting to hear of the history of Mandela and the other inmates and what life was like for them.The walk to freedom had an eery feel about it when you knew you walking in famous footsteps and how they must have felt when they knew they were finally leaving the prison and the island.We had to giggle when Glen told us that one of the first things they did was head to KFC for a feed and when TV eventually arrived at the Prison the Bold and the Beautiful was the favourite TV Show.

Robben Island Experience. We visited Robben Island on the afternoon of 16 January. Our guide ('MP') on the 45 minute bus tour in rather dilapidated bus, was very friendly and informative. However, this section of the trip was disappointing as, besides a 15 minute 'scenic stop' at the end of the island opposite Table Mountain, it was difficult to see many of the things talked about clearly: it was no opportunity to get out of the bus and it was impossible to take photographs unless you were next to a window (tip: if you absolutely must have photos of the visit - sit next to an open window - if you go as a couple take two cameras and sit on different sides of the bus).The second 45 minute leg of the trip was a guided tour around the security wing where Mandela and the other political prisoners were held. Our guide (unfortunately I've forgotten his name) was an ex-political prisoner held there from the early 1980s. He was both entertaining and very informative, with personal anecdotes that help understand how the prisoners got round the restrictions imposed upon them. He also gave an insight into the thinking that went into planning the anti-apartheid campaign.Was the visit worth it? Yes, if only because of what the place represents. However, the visit felt very rushed and groups too large, with no time to reflect while at the location of the enormity of what incarceration meant and the courage with which the prisoners faced it.
