There is definitely a feeling of 'maximising tourist throughput', with little investment in facilities or staff that the excursion clearly generates. This risks devaluing the significance of the place as a symbol. Many visitors may be happy with the format of the tour, but why not offer a tour for smaller groups who would appreciate more time and the opportunity to walk around the site and please invest some of the money generated by the excursion into maintaining and upgrading the equipment and facilities.

Glad we went but ..... Our ferry ride over was smooth and without incident. However, when we arrived, there were not enough buses for everyone. We only had one stop on the bus tour around the island. I think the quality of the tour depends on the guide/ex prisoner - ours was not great. A lot of people in one group and when accommpanied by screaming babies, not the best! Glad we've been and seen it, but that's about it!

An Enjoyable Trip. We did the 9am trip to Robben Island, which although was sold out and we had to buy tickets in advance, we were pleasantly surprised to find that the boat was not overly crowded and there was enough room. The boat trip took about 45 minutes, giving a fantastic view of Cape Town and Table Mountain, as we got further from shore. We also saw dolphins swimming alongside the boat. The trip was well organised and coaches were waiting for us upon arrival at the Island. The guide on the coach was very good and gave us lots of useful information. After the tour around the Island, we had a guided tour of the maximum security prison, by one of the ex prisoners which was very interesting. He did however over run on time, so when we got back to the boat, the crew were in a rush to leave. Some people who didn't seen in a rush to get back to the boat, ended up missing this boat back.Overall a very enjoyable visit to Robben Island. Its worth booking in advance if you can as this trip is popular and does get sold out.

A must do for every human being. Shocked to read some of the reviews from others--it sounds like a completely different experience than what we had. Our tour left on time, the boat ride over was the low light of the trip--200 some odd school children snacking--then puking--the smell was horrific but that was where the bad ended. Once on the island we were taken on a quick 1 hour tour of the island--stopping and getting the history of each building, the graveyard, the quarry, lighthouse, etc. We were able to get out of the bus at 3 stops and take mini tours of specific areas--amazing history lesson. Finally, we were returned to the prison area where we met our guide Sparks, a prisoner who spent considerable time in the prison, along with Nelson Mandela. The guides were all prisoners or guards and so they have the first hand experiences to provide insight that some hired guide doesn't have. For what our guide went through it was moving to hear him speak in such a deep and powerful voice, telling his story, the story of the people he was imprisoned with, and Nelson Mandela.There's not much else to say--the island is a major historical site and one that shouldn't be missed. Not just for Africa, but the world. What happened here was an injustice not just for the people imprisoned, but an entire race. The major takeaway form the Sparks that I got was, sharing what happened is important so we don;t repeat those mistakes--something we still haven't learned, and that continually needs to be reinforced.

Very Moving Experience. very moving experience. Excellent tour guides that are very informative and articulate. Important to see this to understand South Africa and the trials and tribulations of the people. Highly recommend!

Amazing place. We were lucky to get a ticket on the 1 pm ferry as it was our last day, so it might be advisable to book in advance. We returned on the 4pm ferry so you need to allow 3+ hours. The whole experience was very educational , hearing first-hand information from an ex prisoner. There was also a lot of nature, lots of sacred Ibis and various sea birds. We were lucky enough to see the Penguins from the Antartic sun-bathing on the beach. You need to take the Penguin boardwalk down to the hide to view them. We also saw a couple of Springbok in the bushes as we walked to the hide.

Eish. For the price of this attraction i was quite disapointed, the guide seems to know her script and not much more. Do not try to ask questions as they do not seem to know. There is so much focus on Mandela, and not enough on gereal liviving on the island.Its something i can tick off my list, but will not be making the trip again.

Short but sweet. Let me start by saying it was nothing short of fascinating and at times moving to get a look at Robben Island and a hint of what life was like for prisoners who were held there, but it was a glimpse of this and a glimpse of that at a pace that can only be described as rushed.The guide on the bus was excellent and very humorous indeed, but the points of interest he was describing quickly became a blur.Better still was the guided tour around the main prison area by a former political prisoner - but the large number of visitors in each tour group took so much away from the intimacy of the place and the very personal nature of much of what he was telling us; it also made it hard to here what he was saying at time, too.The ticketing was problem free, the Nelson Mandela Gateway was interesting to look around, and the boat trip was a relatively short and a moderately smooth 40-minute ride. It was quite late, however, but I guess that's 'Africa time'! Recommended but don't expect to be strolling around at a leisurely pace soaking up this bit of South African history.

The Alcatraz of Africa. It was my first day in Cape Town, and I couldn't have picked a better way to spend my day then seeing the prison where Nelson Mandela was kept. Driving to the dock was hard to find, because their is not very good signage, so give yourself some time when your at the V&A Waterfront. The boat ride is about 30 minutes which includes a video of the Island Prison. Once you arrive it is about 2-3 hour tour of the entire island, to include a guided tour of the prison itself, and the person who gives you the tour is an ex-political convict, so the stories are just fantastic.

History today. An amazing place, not only because of everything that has happened here, but also for the nature and sights. But the inspiration really came from the excellent guide we had during the tour. He had spent some years there as a "convict" together with Nelson Mandela and to hear from a firsthand witness how it was during the apartheid time was truly a highlight of our South Africa trip.

A piece of History. Like it or not, this is a piece of History that isn't going to go away.Well worth booking in advance so you are not disappointed when visiting Cape Town. Think the whole tour for start to finish takes about four hours.. Well worth the visit & taking in the education lesson.

Disappointing & Disorganized. I came to Cape Town and Robben Island was at the top of my list. I thought it would be an inspiring and emotional tour that really went into the history of apartheid and the struggles the men went through there. However, what I actually discovered was a tour that was poorly organized (everything ran consistently late, then as a result needed to be rushed in terms of guides) and gave little historical narrative or message that gave much background. Much of the tour was pointing to a building saying "lepers were held here" or "this is Mandela's cell. Take a picture and then move along" without much of a story about him or what he went through. The guides need more training on building a narrative for the tours...it loses the power without it. I felt way more emotional at Alcatraz than Robben Island, which shouldn't happen!
A must. Impressive visit, our guide was himself an inmate. Must be done for remembering what happend there.The boat trip to go there is very enjoyable.Book in advance

Must do if you are in Cape Town. This is where Mandela was held for over a decade and is well worth the trip - We were taken around by an ex prisoner which was both incredibly informative and moving for all involved.

A complete waste of 4.5 hours!. I was sorely disappointed with our Robben Island experience. It started badly with the boat leaving 45 minutes late (no explanation was provided by the tour operators) Once we eventually got there we found the tour to be exceptionally slow and poorly organized. We found the content of the tour to be poorly lacking in interesting historical facts (of which I am sure there are plenty) Both my husband & I came away from the tour not having learnt anything new. The returning boat trip was particularly unpleasant due to the choppy seas which would not have been an issue if the experience had been great. Unfortunately this wasn’t the case. If someone looked into the content & organization of this tour it could be one of South Africa’s top attractions. Until then – don’t waste your time.

Very interesting but takes time. Did not know what to expect but found the visit interesting.Try to go on the catamarran as the trip over takes half the time.We were taken round as a bus party so it is difficult to take your time. We found the bus guide to be very good.However once you enter the prison the guides are all ex inmates and although they have an intereting story to tell the size of the party gave little time for questions as we had to keep moving so that the next group could be accommodated. I

missed the boat and paid full price. I booked by phone and was suppose to pick up the ticket 30 min before the actual departure . yes , that my fault that I came late and I was willing to pay half the price , but not full price !!!anyhow they could have sell my ticket 30 min before the actual departure.

Robben Island - tour is shameful. If you want to see how your 250 Rand is spent you will be sadly disappointed. Visitors are herded into dilapidated buses (after alighting from a dilapidated vessel - look at the rotten wooden decking) and driven around the island and "pointed out" sites of interest with no permission to get off unless there's something the ANC want you to buy, like a coffee or tourist tat. If you are unlucky to be on the wrong side of the bus as you pass, don't worry as you'll get your two seconds on the way back. You are shown plenty of buildings and monuments you can't explore - here's a building that only politicians are allowed tin....etc.Never mind that this island has a vast history stretching back several centuries - you are here to experience only the prison and Mandela's incarceration. Of course this is why most people come, but what about the island's heritage, the Portuguese, the Dutch, the English, the maritime heritage, the nature reserve - did anyone actually see a penguin? The last part of the tour is good - a talk but a former prisoner who gives a tour through the prison and shows you Cell no 7. But since none of the tourists' money is being used apparently to develop the 'experience' the whole adventure is tainted by a government keener to get its own political message out than to grant the island the status conferred on it by UNESCO.

You need to go there!!. When you travel to Cape Town you must spend half a day to visit Robben Island..Mandela was one of many imprisoned here because the South African govt. had the power to imprison anyone they wanted to...you already know that, but you will learn more during the tour....

First the island of gloom, now the island of hope. Being a young South African and having being told the history of our country all my life, it's a different feeling altogether to have "experienced" it myself at Robben Island.The island's history is not only a reminder of the bad that the people of this country experienced but its a reminder that with unity a common goal can be reached.

4 and a half hours minimum required. As compared to my trip to table mountain, please see my review, this trip is value for money at R250 for a return trip. The boat ride is exciting and we even saw dolphins. The boat is relatively stable. The island seems like a time capsule and the tour bus guides are quite informative. There was not much marking Nelson Mandela's cell and u don't get much time to look at it given the size of your tour group. All that said, it is a must for all young South Africans... Lest we forget...

Rough Seas but worth a visit. Let's face it most of the tourist that go to Robben Island want to know about the late Nelson Mandala's time on Robben Island. I have been to Robben Island before but this time I felt our ex prisoner guide was more interested in telling us about all the other leaders that were held on the island only very briefly mentioning Mandala. Even when people asked questions about Mandala we would always talk about other leaders. This was quite interesting to hear for me I have visited the island before but the people who were visiting for the first time I am sure like me would have wanted to learn about Mandala. We were not even told Mandala's prison number. In the courtyard where every picture has Mandala in it were told about his return to the island after his release and the end of apartheid. When we got to his cell we were not told anything about at all just told this was his cell and you can take a picture. From my understanding I believe the guide must have been a member of another political party not the AMC. The young guy who took us on the tour around the island was fantastic very informative and you got to hear about the major points like the limestone quarry and what the pile of rocks mean. We were also told why at least on part of your trip to the island you have to walk through the gates. It is worth a visit just depends what guide you get.

A disappointing repeat visit to this place of reflection.... This was my third trip to Robben Island and I am afraid it was a huge disappointment as it did an injustice to a place that is sanctified and should be treated with respect and dignity. The tour of the prison, which was conducted by an ex-prisoner, was rushed and information provided was minimal compared to my previous visits. He lacked conviction and spoke more about his personal life than providing valuable information linked to prison life. I even noted that he quoted statistics that were incorrect. At the cell of Nelson Mandela, the only item that was highlighted was the bucket used as a toilet. I felt saddened for first time for first time visitors who would have left the island with no lasting impression of the severity of the prison or the significance that it should hold today.The second part of the tour was also a little disappointing. As we left the prison we drove past the leper cemetery, which the tour guide promised to discuss at a later stage. We stopped for a photo and refreshment opportunity in the village and after a circular tour arrived at Robert Sobukwe’s prison house. On the tour, information provided was scant except for the waffling of the guide after our visit to the Sobukwe house for 15 odd minutes. We drove to the limestone quarry and again the significance of the lime quarry was not really highlighted. Here, our guide focused more on the visit by ex-prisoners in the 2000s’. I was particularly shocked by the guides’ reference to policy linked to gratuities on the way back to the harbour and the fact that these could be given, preferably in foreign currency. We, once again, drove past the leper cemetery and other important places, such as the Muslim Shrine or Moturu Kramaon the island without any mention of them whatsoever. The Robben Island tour ended and left me with a feeling of profound sorrow and disappointment. I can genuinely say that the guides provided little additional insight into this world heritage site and I felt embarrassed by their lack of genuine interest and sincerity with regards to the severity and significance of this place of deep reflection. Robben Island embodies the struggle against Apartheid and its consequences, provides proof of the suffering and somehow gives all South Africans a sense of pride for the victory that was achieved. Robben Island is the ultimate South African memorial site and should be the number one tourist destination in our country.

Must visit - emotional experience. We visited Robben Island on 29 December 2013 on the 01.00pm trip. Our boat was on schedule with the 1-hour ride to the island - we had one of the newer boats so we sat on the upper deck and enjoyed the ride while taking pictures of Table Mountain in the distance. Upon arrival at the island, we were boarded into 3 waiting buses for a ride around the island which included the lepers graveyard, the prisoners church, the guards church, the post office, the lime quarry, an Islamic shrine and Robert Sobukwe's house where he was held in solitary confimement. Our bus guide was youthful and very passionate about his work explaining the suffering faced by the freedom fighters.We were then handed over to the ex-prisoner called Itumeleng who gave us a briefing about his experiences in the prison and the predicament of the political leaders who were detained at the prison. It was quite an experience walking through the Cell Blocks including the yard and the prison cell where Nelson Mandela was held for 18 of his 27 years in prison - quite a sobering experience.We then took the short 300 metre walk back to the harbour straight into the waiting boat for our return journey back to V&A. The retrun boat was however older and the waters choppier in our return 1-hour trip but we made it back by 6.30pm.After reading the challenges faced by other reviewers, I guess we were very lucky to have had such a smooth trip to and from the island. We booked our ticket online 2 months prior to arrival in Cape Town and were lucky that the weather was perfect for the trip with clear blue sunny skies.This trip really gives you an insight into the pre-independence struggle by the freedom fighters and its an experience not to be missed while in Cape Town.

Historic highlight. One of the highlights of our trip just days after the death of Madiba...... despite a shambolic transportation issue which caused a delay - once we got to the island the tour was excellent. The bus tour gave a good overview and then the tour of the prison with an ex-political prisoner was powerful and moving. Walking past Mandelas cell where a single candle burned touched me. Good gift shop on the quay to browse in while waiting for next boat. They need to sort out the transportation issues and then it would be perfect.

Emotional - but not to be missed. The impressive terminal and good quality ferry crossing set a high standard for the trip. And apart from a slightly chaotic start to the tour with allocating the coaches, generally the whole visit lived up to or exceeded this beginning.We began with a coach tour of the island. This included seeing the area where Robert Sobukwe was kept in solitary confinement. We drove through the 'town' previously inhabited by the guards and now home to the island workers. We parked by the lime quarry to see the “University of Robben Island” where many of the illiterate prisoners became educated. As the sun glanced off the rock, I could appreciate how the brutally long days, breaking rocks, with no protection against the African sun as it reflected off the white rock, had permanently damaged Mandela’s eyesight. In the middle of the quarry is the Reunion Cairn, that symbolises South Africans diversity. The impromptu memorial was created in 1995 when Nelson Mandela laid a stone in the quarry where he had once been put to hard labour, a gesture followed by the more than 1,000 former political prisoners who were on Robben Island with him for a reunion. After this we met up with Glen Kaotso Ntsoelengoe, the political prisoner who took us into a large cell to tell us his story. He explained why and how he agreed to return to the island where he was once tortured and incarcerated. He was more than willing to answer our questions, and discuss the current political situation. It was gratifying to sense his commitment had not diminished in spite of his treatment by the previous regime. Finally he took us around the rest of the prison, enabling us to visit the cell block and courtyard where Mandela was kept. Standing outside the 2.4-by-2.1-metre cell where Madiba spent 18 of his 28 years in prison with nothing but a straw mat to sleep on was moving. But equally if not more so was the other cells where you could see pictures of the many people captured and read first hand accounts of their experiences - including instances of torture .It took a while for us to absorb the impact of our visit, to be able to speak. But I do wonder how future generations, those who'll not have the benefit of a tour guide who lived alongside Madiba and who survived their imprisonment, will experience Robben Island. I for one am glad to have visited while Mandela was still alive and to have had the honour to meet a survivor.

Humbling. ...but shambolic transport arrangements. Got to terminal 30 minutes before departure, having booked for 11am a month before, but failed to get on boat. Travelled on new boat 40 minutes later, so arrived on the island an hour late. Still delivered back to harbour at 3pm, but no ferry until 4. So tour was rushed , missing many possible attractions.Yet the truncated tour itself was inspiring and wonderful and not to be missed. Just sad that we lost an hour we'd booked for, wasted waiting for ferries.

Bad management. The ferry we were initially booked on (11:00 a.m.) was overbooked and we had to wait for an extra 45 minutes only to be taken aboard the Dias, an old ship that the prisoners used to be transferred with (the passengers on our initially confirmed transfer travelled on a new vessel). I believe that in Western Europe the ship would not have qualified as seaworthy. The experience on the island itself was quite ok - both guides were highly motivated and very knowledgeable. The return from the island also proved difficult as there was no ship ready to take us back to Cape Town after the tour. Passengers had to self-organize the return trip, as the official boat would have arrived only 1.5 hours after the end of the tour… A shame that the management of the Robben Island Museum is not up to par.

A moving experience, but needs investment. Prepare to bear the South Atlantic swells on your half hour boat ride to Robben Island, hoping that the clapped-out boats don't pack up en route. It's not perhaps the most well organised tour you'll take in the world, but it's certainy one of the most moving and most inspiring.It comes in three parts - the boat trip (yes, it's two way but treated as one here), the coach ride, and the prison tour. Of the three the prison tour, by a former inmate is the most moving. Our guy was fantastic. Of course the smells and fears of the former prison have gone, but he gave you a sense of what it must have been like to have been incarcerated there under a cruel regime. One of the most unusual prisons too as the inmates were mostly political, and what you come away with is the sense of commuity and humanity each gave to each other. You will also see the cell once occupied by one of the most famous men on the planet. Thus bus tour of the island is a little odd, or at least ours was, as the guide (a different one from the prison tour) was of lesser quality and tried much too hard to be funny. You see the lime quarry where hard labour was done, perhaps the best bit of it, but can't help feeling it's a bit of a time filler.The organisation is rather poor and indeed a little chaotic, and badly needs investment. One thing they should improve is the boat trip. The boats are old and need replacing; the silly group photos taken on boarding just annoyed people and caused large queues, and the heavy loud music on the return trip was out of keeping and unnecessary. Allow four hours in total.

a truly humbling experence. I went to robben island in the summer of 2013 with little knowledge of what it was, it was about a 40 minuet boat trip not even that and when we arrived we got on a bus and had a tour of the island seeing the prisons and the stunning situation of table mountain in the distance, it was a truly humbling experience, with informative ex inmates telling you what there experiences was and seeing where Mandela fought against the apartheid, a truly inspiring experience I enjoyed it, you just have to go and visit it if you are intrested in anything to do with history, law and justice, it was a great way to expence cape town and get a different perspective of it from the sea.

Authentic for all the wrong reasons. Certainly if you want to feel exploited, trapped and angry at the system then you're in for a treat if you catch this tour on one its lesser days - which we did. Checking-in for the 9am tour we were told every 40 minutes that there would be a 20 minute delay, an experience which continued until 11am. Local guides waiting with their tours told us this was an embarrassingly regular occurrence as the operator's ferries regularly broke down and no contingency is ever in place.While we left the 10am group up in arms following the brazen cancellation of their tour ("You can request a refund or re-book on another available tour... in two weeks time"); we shipped out.The island is interesting, the stories it holds from its history equally so, the way in which it is presented leaves a lot to be desired. The bus tour to a handful of sites could be covered in half the time, particularly if the unnecessary stop at a concession store at the end of the island is cut out. As a captive audience - you are also a captive market on this one.The bus guide, while friendly, was woefully inept in her dulled textbook delivery of jokes and sadly remained poorly understood by most tourists when she chose to present facts.At the prison buildings themselves, ex-captives thankfully take over to deliver the tour. Peppered with personal experiences and anecdotes, this part is worth the pain to get to it. Unfortunately, because you have spent so much time faffing around prior to this, there's barely time to take-in the cells you are shown and the information on display in them. We're rushed through, and then on to Mandella's block, filed past his cell and before we know it, we're walking back to the ferry port where dis-organisation resumes, ironically, quite efficiently. No one quite knows which boat they're catching and it's another frustratingly long wait under the sun for a ride back to port. Reaching there at 4pm - it's been a 7 hour trip in total. "Do please buy the photo of your group boarding the Robben Island ferry" - we would if we thought the money was being better spent and not lining pockets.

Time to reflect. We booked our tour to Robben Island well in advance of our trip and we're glad we did. Being in South Africa when Nelson Mandela passed away was something we will never forget. It was a joyous celebration of an amazing life, not a morbid sombre atmosphere as it would probably have been at home. From looking at these reviews we were very lucky to get a bright December day with a calm gentle sea on our way to the Island, although coming back was certainly a little more choppy and we were quite glad to get off. However the sea would no way have stopped us from getting over to feel for ourselves a piece of history.We were blown away by everything we learnt and it was an honour to spend some time with someone who actually lived it. You get a real feel for how bleak it must have been there and it made us think long and hard about how we would have felt about and reacted to the plight of the men imprisoned there (we were very small children at the time). It certainly enhanced our trip to South Africa as a whole. Standing outside Mandela's cell was a chance to reflect on how easily we huff and puff about our lives and blame others for the situation we are in, rather than getting on and doing something about it. It was just a shame I was forcibly shoved to the side after 20 seconds by a girl who was more interested in snapping a picture than in remembering why she was there.Yes the shop makes it all feel a bit touristy and the bus tour was a little bit military but I don't think there would be any other way to allow people to see the island without ruining it. Even in the one place we were allowed off the coach some people from the group crossed a boundary line and trod over ground with protected birds nesting, despite strict instructions from our guide. If silly people behave like that, how could the island survive an onslaught of wanderers??!!Definitely worth braving the sea sickness to go.

One of those things you just have to do. Having read a (one-star) review below, I was interested to see what I may find during this morning's visit (booked many weeks ago in the UK).We turned up - at the ticketed time - of 9am and were on a boat (smaller one than usual as big ones being serviced) a few minutes later. Despite a real pea-souper, we were on the island in about 30 minutes having passed by the odd seal, a dolphin or two and lots of penguins.We took the bus tour first which was both informative and touching. The guide had the right amount of humour and was perfectly able to manage the time well. A lady was taken poorly so a detour to the clinic was organised with care and compassions. No complaints.The walking tour with a former prisoner was something else. I felt his pain as he told his story. Yes, lots of people on the tour but I got to hear/see everything to 'get' some of the story.A short walk back to the boat and it was only inconsiderate fellow passengers who made us late. All in all, a great excursion and well worth the time and money.

Simply a Must See. This is what you would expect an island jail to be - and given its historic former inmate, Robben Island is simply a Must See when you are in Cape Town, or anywhere in South Africa. But its not just a tourist trap, the tour guides are passionate about their work and in sharing the history of the island with visitors. Plus, its an island, so the ticket to see the island includes two 45-minute boat rides across Cape Town's harbor - be mindful, the seas are rough.

Imprisoned on Robben Island. This was a deeply disappointing experience and clearly seeks to capitalize on sentiment towards the late and great Nelson Mandela. However, in doing so, the visit is a catalogue of woes, inefficiency and commercialism. The ferry service suffers from major delays and long waits, irrespective of the actual booking time on tickets - which is totally irrelevant. Worse, on arrival, one is corralled onto buses for a "tour" of the island which takes an hour but can be seen in minutes....were it not for a horrendous guide who emulates the worst of standup comedians, combined with tour guides. Only after his request for gratuities, are you finally escorted to prison buildings. The tour is hosted by a former inmate, who is moving and articulate, albeit a little long. In the process, only a few minutes are spent around the highlight of tour.....the cell of former President Mandela. At this point, desperation sets in and one is tempted to seek any mode of transportation back to shore......sadly, another wait for the ferry. In total, the entire process took FIVE hours....an unthinkable amount of time and solely the result of outright commercialism of the hallowed memory of a great man. A strong argument can be made for skipping the tour, buying the book and donating the balance of the ticket money to a worthy cause.

Must see!. Many people told me that Robben Island is worth a visit.. but really not that great.. more a must see when you're in Cape Town because of it's history. I disagree. I really think it was worth a visit and would definitely recommend it!The trip includes a 45 minute bus ride around the island with several very interesting stops and a 45 minute guided tour through parts of the former prison premises guided by someone who himself was imprisoned here.... I'm not sure how the guides deal with being confronted with their past on this island on a daily basis and I have much respect for what they do. And obviously it gives the visitors a very unique insight into the life in prison. I can only recommend visiting Robben Island when you're in Cape Town! Even the boat ride to and from the island is great as it gives you amazing views of the Mother City and Table Mountain!Book your ticket in advance!

Must visit. Boat ride was extremely rough the day we went, but it turned out to be the day Mandela passed away and I would say this trip is a must in Cape Town. Sheds light on the fascinating history of South African and the tour by a former in mate is quite powerful. Definitely make time in your trip for this though I will say it will take about 4-5 hours between two boat trips and the tour.

A Spiritual Journey. I've read the negative reviews about old boats and problems due to weather with great sadness because to me, Robben Island isn't about being a "tourist attraction" per se. Yes, I can certainly understand how disappointing it must be to have the trip cancelled (due to whatever) when you have limited time and many things to do. But Robben Island is a place that is holy to me and to many others. It is a place to reflect on man's cruelty to man, on what freedom means, and, ultimately, on the marvel of forgiveness. Each tour is led by former inmates of the Island, so I am not be surprised that there's variation between them. The times that I've been out have been very inspiring. The first time, I didn't know that much about Nelson Mandela and the visit made me delve much more deeply into South African history, including reading a number of important books ("Long Walk to Freedom", "Country of My Skull," etc) and seeing several movies (Mandela and deKlerk being perhaps the most relevant) I am certain that it has had similar impacts on others. That makes it a very important experience in my book.If you've tried to go and not been able to do so, please please please try again the next time you're in Cape Town! It took me 3 different attempts before getting the right weather- and time-window - but it is completely worth it!Given Madiba's death and the current situation in South Africa, it seems even more important to me to make this journey open-heartedly and open-mindedly. It certainly isn't an "attraction" like Disneyworld! It is a commemorative journey to a holy place where forgiveness emerged as central to the history of this great country.

Must do but not enough time on island. Firstly, it never occured to me that the ferry crossing may be bumpy and although we had a calm day, it was a bit choppy on the way back! It also took an hour each way - longer than I expected.This is one of those "must do" things for many people visiting the area. You also must book in advance - it was sold out for days while we were in Cape Town.There are drinks and snacks available on the ferry if you don't get seasick!On arrival at the island, you quickly get on a bus. Our guide was great, although his mike kept breaking. He told us lots of info about the various buildings and points on the island. There's a point with good views of mainland where you take a break (and there's a snack/gift shop). Then it's on to the prison for a talk from a previous inmate and a tour, including the obligatory stop at Nelson Mandela's cell - this took ages while everyone took photos. After that we had to dash back to the ferry, which was my only disappointment as both my guide book and the bus guide recommended seeing "Section A: cell stories" at the prison and there was no time. There is also an Islamic mini mosque and penguin walk people may like to visit...but you get no time before the ferry back.So overall: interesting visit, but really needs more time.

unprofessionalism. The trip took us 6 hours instead of 3,5 hrs .We had to forfeit out Table Moutain trip and in the process lost money of the hired coach for the day.My guest were rushed to the bus where we met an unfriendly tour guide(bus no 4) who made it clear that she was in No mood.There was no microphone ,her throat was sore .When asked to repeat herself or move to the middle of the bus ,she ignored us.At the end of bus tour she again thanked is abruptly ,left the bus in a hurry to avoid eye contact.PLEASE employ people who are professional and love what they are doing as a job so that visitors may see the true "ubuntu " spirit of South Africa.

Robben Island. Its not worth the time or the money. Vey disappointed. Boats are old, dirty and very slow. The trip to the island and back is much more longer than the tour on the island itself. You'll be wasting your time and money, if you go to the island.

Need to get their act together. My husband and I booked tickets just about a month in advance for Dec 27 and even when booking so far in advance had limited options with tickets, although we were happy to obtain tickets as we were flexible. After arriving in the country we received an email that our tour was cancelled and to contact the office. We had contacted the office who took down our information and we were told we would receive a call which we never did, which was a bad sign of customer service and received no explanation, We had followed up and were informed that the tickets were now sold out for that date but to stop by in person at the ticket office. We did that and were informed there were only tickets available from January 7 on. Unfortunately we will no longer be in the country at that point. I understand there are technical glitches, however there needs to be some process and controls in order to deal with these situations. It seems unfair to cancel a ticket and not try have a replacement ship for those people affected. We also heard that there have been issues with the vendor that the kusum was contracting out as their own boats were having issues. Many people visiting are not from the country and will not have an opportunity to see such a special sight again. Also, I noticed that in the line next to me at the ticket office was another person having an issue in regards to their tickets and the customer service representative was not nice to them, while the customer was being pleasant. I am disappointed that we will not have the opportunity to see the sight but based on other reviews we were not alone unfortunately. Fortunately when we were in Johannesburg we had the opportunity to visit the apartheid museum where I was able to take in the history . For anyone planning a trip, especially if you are out of the country, I would suggest booking well in advance and follow up with them when you are in town. It is shame such an important and popular sight is lacking customer service and procedures.

Either the ferries are breaking down or now the winds are preventing the seaworthy ones from going so I haven't been there yet. Perhaps it's unfair to grade it so low. Particularly when I haven't been able to get there yet. I had a ticket for this morning and received a text saying it was cancelled due to a technical fault. One of the ferries is in dry dock and apparently there are problems/questions about the suitability of the replacement. The text gave a phone number which is permanently busy. At the booking office yesterday a guy was taking people's name and contact details.saying someone would get back to us. Yesterday,before todays cancellations,they were saying that the next available tickets at the booking office would be Jan 6

Please be aware. I bought tickets on-line before coming on holiday to Cape town. Before leaving I had an email from the ticket company who said that they had been informed that the trip had gone technical and to ring Robben island services to rebook. I did this before leaving, got passed around to many different people, then told someone would ring back. They didn't, nor did they answer a separate email I sent. On arrival in SA, our host rang them to rebook but there are no tickets available at all and it was the over booking of the trips that were a problem. We will never have this opportunity again and am really dissapointed.

Disappointing. The trip was on time and well organised, but the actual tour was not very informational. It was merely a drive on the island, pointing out locations. The tour guide in the prison spoke about himself, which was interesting but not very educational. With such a historical site I expected more history.
Worth It. We visited Robben Island during the "ten days of mourning" for Mandela - which was very timely and a moving experience. The prison tour with a former inmate is brief but fascinating.

A morning of reflection well spent. This is a trip well worth the time. Read Mandela's autobiography beforehand and the while Robben Island period will be brought to life. You will see the places he and the others lived worked and socialised. We had as our guide an ex prisoner. We felt humbled by his humility, intelligent and insight. The whole thing was apolitical and thought provoking. Read the book and then go - esp. the parts relating to the island.

A must see!. Absolutely loved the experience. It is definitely a must see. After having immigrated out of the country I had always regretted not going to Robben Island considering I had always lived in Cape Town. When returning I made it my goal to go and I am definitely happy that I went. It is a must see regarding the history of South Africa. Although they could take some lessons from Alcatraz on how to actually run the show..

Inspirational yes. But overall, rather poorly presented and managed. First the good things. A very nice ticket building and welcome centre in Cape Town, and nice boat trip to the island. We visited by pure chance the afternoon after Mandela's death and the tour guides spoke with great passion.Now the less good. The island tour is on a crammed bus and all information is verbal. No leaflets, no maps. Many locations on the island show information boards - but you can't read them. The only time you get off is to visit a little cafe on the Southern tip. There are a lot of WW2 buildings on the island - largely ignored but this could warrant a tour in itself. The prison visit is mainly a talk from an ex-prisoner followed by a fairly cursory walk through. Back at the jetty the boat to take us back was only half the size of the one which brought us Guess what?No room. We had to wait over an hour for another boat. You get the impression it could and should be an awful lot better but maybe they feel they just don't need to try too hard. And at R200+ it's very expensive by SA standards.

A visit you must take when in Cape Town!. Nelson Mandela spent 27 years breaking rocks on this island & his resolve changed history. So soon after his death, it was a very solemn visited I made to Robben Island this time.I personally don't like the herding nature of this type of tourist attraction. Long queue, herded onto buses, herded off buses etc.Despite that, it is a must visit & really makes you feel how lucky you are!

Wasted 5 hours..... Where to start with how awful and long this tour is. We booked a 3pm boat, showed up at 2:30 as directed. There was a queue to almost out the door and this was the 2:30 boat passengers. After sitting outside until 3pm we returned to the building. Still a queue. We joined the queue and waited and waited to get on a boat. There was a lady's who seemed to be in charge making announcements about bearing with her and being patient. Eventually we were placed on a boat. A slow boat.The boat journey takes around 30-45 mins. Upon arriving to Robben Island we are ushered onto old coaches. Each coach has a tour guide, who to give credit to him, was enthusiastic and animated but sadly he did nothing to lift spirits. The bus is a little bit of a nonsense journey with not much in participial being shown. A view point, which was smelly and not that pretty, the quarry and the one single small prison. Eventually you are let off the coach only to do another guided tour of the actual prison. This was given by an ex prisoner which is a nice touch, but like some other reviews on here, he had a stony South African accent and coupled with the echoey rooms was quite hard to understand.Anyway, to the end of the trip. You must queue and wait for the return boats. More waiting. Eventually everyone is on a boat (I need to add that they are over capacity, not enough seats for everyone). Boat journey back was very rocky and rough. None was allowed out their seats (the ones who had seats!).All in all a very badly designed experience. Robben Island needs to take a visit to Alcatraz and learn how it's done properly. I would advise all to avoid this tourist attraction until it is better managed. If ever.....

ROBBEN (ROBBERS??) ISLAND. Visited the Island on 21 December 2013 with my wife and three high-school kids. The contemporary historical relevance of this island in our South Africa's make-up is irrefutable and we deemed it certainly worth visiting/experiencing. We so wanted to go but then....An expensive trip and a major disappointment. The whole Robbers Island (sic) thing is a loosely facilitated (will hate to use the word organized) mincing machine smelling of financial greed. This goes for both sides of the crossing by boat (no, not a ferry) and especially the boat trip itself - safety here seemingly NOT a primary consideration.The only bit of interest in an otherwise "yawn" was some charming anecdotes from an unfortunately (mostly) unintelligible guide in the Maximum Security Jail. Regrettably and inappropriately he intertwined his pearls of recollection with unmasked (seemingly personal and very skewed) political propaganda and vicious racist remarks bordering on slander - certainly not doing the SA history nor the Madiba legacy any favours. An afternoon - in the splendour of Cape Town - wasted and regrettably so, my family being subjected twice to 50 minute long crossings of the open sea, totally exposed to the sun and other elements (many people, including ourselves, were for instance soaked on the return trip) in relative dangerous conditions due to the type of boats and the condition these were in. A visit to Robben Island can be one of the most valuable and treasured experiences of a SOuth African tour - it has all the makings and it is already "there", it is already on the map, it is already internationally (historically) renowned. People are willing to pay for this experience - put the money to better use and shape up Robben Island! With a little organization and cleaning-up this can be a visit of a lifetime. As it is now - Again? Recommended?? No ways.

Sobering Visit. My wife, adult daughter and myself visited Robben Island just four days after Neslon Mandela passed away. The staff on the island spoke very highly of the man who had been the first president of the new South Africa and spoke proudly of the endeavours that he had achieved through his lifetime. The actual visit was very informative as was the visit to the cell block that was Mr. Mandela's home for so many years although I suspect that the block was not as warm and inviting during his detention. Altogether a good visit well worth the 215 Rand which included a 45 minute ferry journey.

A Must-See. A visit to Robben Island is a must-see for anyone visiting Cape Town for the first time. A must. It serves as a backdrop for the history of African resistance to the evils of the Aparthied system imposed upon them, and is a tribute to the decency of Nelson Mandela and other freedom fighters and members of the African National Congress. Our guide inside the prison walls was a very articulate African man who had served prison time with Mandela, and he was able to describe prison life there based on his own personal experiences. The guide didn't mention this, but Americans might recall that Ronald Reagan as well as many USA banks and corporations embraced the past Apartheid regimes. RR, himself, termed the non-violent Mandela a "communist" and a "terrorist." Definitely pre-purchase tickets, which can be done easily on-line or from your hotel. Board the boat first for access to the limited number of seas on the upper deck on a sunny day.

must see in Cape Town. First off, have patience. The lines to the ferry are incredibly long and it's very claustrophobic and disorganized. Secondly, make sure you have read up on the history of Robben Island before you go-you will enjoy the trip much more with a previous knowledge of its history. Third, make sure you purchase your tickets well in advance! We had Abraham as our tour guide and he was amazing. When we got to the prison cells, we were actually turned over to a former prisoner who gave us his perspective of the Apartheid era and being imprisoned. You get to go to Nelson Mandela's cell toward the end, but can't actually enter.

A thought provoking location. Having our tickets pre purchased, we arrived very early at the boarding place to get our bearings with the intention of heading back to the waterfront. People were already queueing to board for what we assumed was our departure time so we decided to wait for fear of not getting on board. There was little information available and no staff to ask. The crossing was fine and we transferred to waiting buses. We were a party of three and had to stick close as we were being guided onto buses without knowing how many seats, if any were available. The tour guide on the bus was very good and we kept stopping en route so he could deliver his narration.Soon we were handed over to an ex-prisoner whose passionate description of life in the jail was captivating and deeply moving. This was disrupted by two women in their late 20's who felt it was o.k. to sit giggling. It was obviously annoying and embarrassing to the rest of the attentive audience. Gratefully, they were addressed directly by the guide. The party had to move along fairly quickly and many of us lost photo opportunities as there is always someone who hogs the viewpoint! Maybe the guide should have stayed to keep people moving from the rear? This is certainly no place for disruptive adults or children. The arrangement for the boat home was a little disorganised. We were told we had to be at the port at 5 sharp or miss the boat and with a short time available did not get to look around the outside of the prison. It's quite a walk to the boat. We queued for a good half hour in the cold in a very unordered manor as the boat was late!! Summing up, the visit was well worth it but a little attention to the organisation of the transport would reap great rewards.
Irene. The guide told us of his views not of the history of the island. Also really Really Don't understand why my 5 month old grandson got charged for his visit. Where is his human rights.

Must visit, but managed so unbelievably bad. The big problem is the organization.Boat trip to the island is late, and getting back to main land is the worst I have ever seen! Have the people make a line! It's not that hard. I am so surprised about the level of organization, never seen so bad in my life! 5 year olds would have done a better job

Historically significant! Could be better though!. We visited Robben Island during the week that ex-President Nelson Mandela (Madiba) passed away. The place holds an extremely important position in South African history. It was this that made me plan specifically for a visit to Robben Island. Our ferry scheduled to leave at 3:00 p.m. ultimately left at 3:40 p.m. Of course there were regular announcements about the delay, but my 5-year old daughter soon grew quite restless. The journey by ferry was quite okay. But the ferry actually does not have sufficient seats to seat all passengers. So quite a few passengers were left standing. A tip - please use sunscreen, goggles and a good round hat as the sun could be quite punishing. Once we landed on the island, we were ushered onto waiting buses to be taken for an island tour. Fortunately there were sufficient buses to seat all travelers. The guide on the bus spoke English with a thick African accent but it was easy to understand. The bus tour lasted for about 15 to 20 minutes wherein the guide explained the significance of the various buildings including living quarters on the island. We disembarked the bus near the maximum security prison. There, another guide, an ex-prisoner himself took us inside the maximum security prison and showed us the cells where prisoners were held. Cell no.4 held the maximum attention of everyone - it was whee Mandela spent 17 years on this island. It was a sombre moment especially given the fact that he had just passed away. After the tour, it was time to board the ferry for the return journey. The return journey was more pleasant as the sun had almost set - it was very cool and windy! The island is definitely worth a visit for its historical significance.

Bad Service!!!. This week we visited Robben Island and out of a group of 28, more than 75% were not happy with it!We had tickets for 3pm. In the morning the ladies in the office called twice to confirm that all is good and that we will go out. At no point did they tell us that the one boat was broken down and that we will be delayed.When I arrived with the group at 2:45pm we took our place in the queue and waited. Just before 3pm boarding started and we heard from other passengers that it is only the 2pm group that is boarding now.I went to the information desk only to be told we will leave at 4pm.I informed the group as such and all went shopping.Just before we left I checked with info again and this time I was told that it could be earlier and it could be later. We were not told that we should keep our place in the queue nor were we told that they are using a smaller vessel.So, within 45 minutes we saw a boat come and we all rushed to get on it. The queue was too long and we did not make it on.At the end it took us two hours before we departed!!!When we got to the island I was so embarrassed when the people started to comment about the condition the place is in!When on of them asked the guide why they do not paint the place the reply was "we want to keep the old time feel of the place... the way it was when the prisoners were here!"I have seen many current prisons. It is maintained very well and I do not think it would have been dilapidated under correction services' use!!!The guides did not give much information and were sometimes contradicting each other.Overall it was just a bad experience!The shop was very EXPENSIVE!!!

Not bad but well worth visiting for its significance. I was expecting more from the tour. It is interesting but the actual tour could be better. The bus is a bit long and not that interesting. The tour of the prison by the ex-prisoner is very good but the groups are too big. Everyone obviously wants photos at Mandela's cell but then there are complaints that people are slowing the tour down too much. It is still a worthwhile experience.

A must see for the history and the stunning views. Robben Island, along with Table Mountain, is Cape Town's "Must See" attraction. I had a wonderful time. The boat ride to and from the Island is delightful: Cape Town is one of the world's most stunning cities and it is best seen from the sea! Try to get a seat up top (they fill up fast) where you can sit and enjoy the view. Once you get to the Island you will be there for about two hours. First, you explore the prison in the company of an ex-prisoner who talked about his treatment, his life as an anti-apartheid campaigner, and what life was like in the prison as he shows you around. You get a chance to see Mandela's old cell. Then a bus takes you around the island where you see various attractions, including the old village and the rock quarry where the prisoners worked. Highly recommend.

A Place Everyone Should Visit....if managed properly. This visit marked my second time over to Robben Island - the first being in 2012. The last trip was average but I decided to give it another try to allow my boyfriend a chance to visit as well.We went out of our way to be booked on the Sikhululekile since the last time I had went many had become sea sick within the Susan Kruger. Everything pointed to being on the Sikhululekile - the booking site, the receipt, the confirmation email. Low and behold when we begin boarding we are all herded onto the tiny Susan Kruger. Many people were disgruntled that we were not placed on the boat which we had chosen to be on yet there was no mention of why this had occurred. The only memorable thing about the Susan Kruger is that it was a ship once used to transport prisoners to the island which gives a unique historical view. However, it is lacking in appropriate transportation for such a large group of visitors.Upon arriving, we were yelled at constantly for being late even though the reason for being late was that the museum staff did not start the boarding process until 30 minutes past the normal boarding time. There were also not enough buses for us so we were instructed to stand around and wait. Luckily, our bus guide was there to give us some neat information while we waited. He instructed us to sit at the picnic tables to rest and wait but when the first picnic table became overcrowded and we moved over to the next table (well within ear shot) he made us move back to stand beside the other. The bus tour was somewhat nice. It was a smaller bus so we were able to be more comfortably seated and we were allowed to disembark twice - once at the Sobukwe house and once at the old pub. However, there were many spots along the way which had signage and patches (such as the quarry) which there was no mention of an option to stop. Why have the signs there if visitors cannot read them or even visit?The worst part of the trip was the prison tour - which should be considered a highlight for everyone. The bus guide had all 50+ of us follow along with one tour guide. Within the group cell, we could barely hear him because multiple families were allowing their kids to run up and down the cell stomping their feet. The tour guide would have to try to yell over them and eventually would stop talking when they did this. The whole experience was quickly ruined by the young kids. The guide would also leave behind the last of the group and begin talking when half of us were far away from hearing him so half of what he said we never heard. As other reviewers mentioned, we were herded along like cattle.Suggestions:Possibly impose an age restriction on tours where babies and young toddlers are not allowed. Many other professional tours and facilities do this. Limit the size of the tours at any given time. The tour guides certainly cannot handle 50+ groups and it is much less enjoyable when no one can hear or see anything.Run the better ferries which make the trip more of a leisurely trip rather than a sea-sickness disaster.

Disappointing. This should have been one of the two highlights of my visit to Cape Town, the other being going up Table Mountain. Sadly there were several things wrong with the tour. Firstly, the coach part of it was too long. Secondly, when the guide on the coach handed over the party to an ex-political prisoner for the jail part of the tour we were still a coach load of about 40. This is far too big a group for any guide to address properly. Twenty would be a reasonable size.One of the party had to ask the guide not to recommence speaking until the rear of the group had caught up. Surely one of the cardinal rules of showing a group around anything is to make it possible for all of them to hear you. Get in the middle of them, not at the head of the group. Together with his thick South African accent and the echo in some of the corridors and rooms he showed us, it make it almost impossible for me to hear what he was saying. Those familiar with the South African accent may have found him easier to understand. I fear that anyone whose mother tongue is not English would gain even less than I did from this tour, other than to be able to say "I have been there.'' When the party reached Mandela's cell, the place most visitors came to see, there was indecent haste to take one photo and move on.The tour would be improved considerably by issuing visitors with audio devices on which a commentary was available. There will come a time when ex-inmates will be unable to conduct tours.
Must Visit. Incredible Place with so much Rich History and the Struggles during Apartheid. A must visit for the whole Family it's was a second visit in past 10 years I'm sure we will be back.

A "Must See" on your Trip to South Africa!. A very well organized tour. After being met at the ferry by busses, we were given a tour of the island, including the limestone quarries where Nelson Mandela and his fellow prisoners labored daily for 18 years.We were then taken through the prison by a former political prisoner who served 5 years there. His presentation was amazing. It was a very emotional experience. We learned so much about the years of apartheid.Ironically, Nelson Mandela died a week after I visited Robben Island!

Well worth a visit. We couldn't stay in Cape Town without visiting robben island. I would highly recommend booing well in advance as the tours were booked 2 days I'm advance when we went. I'd also omens brining a jumper or coat for the boat trip as it can get quite cold at sea.The tour round the island on the bus highlights some of the history and the visit inside the prison itself is conducted by ex-political prisoners. It helped us to understand some of the history Mandela helped to shape.

an eyeopening experience. we went to robbin island at the last minute and after a 30 boat trip we pleasantly boarded coaches which took us around this small island, with a historic narrative in tow! when we arrived at the prison that held mandela for a number of years we were shown around by an ex prisoner and he related in detail their life there. it is hard to believe that this was going on while we were living normal lives. a must see when visiting cape town.

Popular tour. This was our first trip to South Africa and we were keen to include a trip to Robben Island while we were staying in Cape Town.This is an island off the coast of Cape Town and is most famous for being a prison for political prisoners in the apartheid era. The best known prisoner was Nelson Mandela.The ferry was due to leave at 9am from a wharf about 300m from our hotel. We got there soon after 8:30am and it's just as well that we got there early so we could get a good seat on the ferry. There was a long queue - mainly because we all had to pass through security before boarding.The ferry holds about 300 people and the trip to the island takes about 30 minutes. After getting off the ferry, they loaded us onto buses for a 45-minute drive around the island stopping at places of interest. The final destination was the former maximum security prison.Here our guide was a former prisoner who had been held for five years for plotting a demonstration against apartheid. He took us from one wing to another relating personal stories of the hardships they endured.At one stage, he stopped outside the cell where Nelson Mandela was held for 18 of the 27 years that he spent in prison. As with the other cells, it was very small and basic.We could walk from the maximum security prison to the ferry and we were back at the Cape Town waterfront at about 12:30pm.It was a worthwhile and memorable morning. Because it's such a popular tour, it was quite crowded and perhaps somewhat rushed.

This is amazing. I went to Cape Town and had booked the trip to Robben Island more or less, because I felt had to see it - been there, done that-ish.After arrival with ferry, you are guided to the busses where there is a guide for each bus.You are then being transported around half of the island and get to know the history of the island.Of course, it is mostly about ANC, but not exclusively. The guide on my bus was very qualified and interesting to listen to.After the bus trip, you get to see the maximum security prison where Mandela was incarcerated for too many years. The guide was a former ANC prisoner which made the experience extremely interesting. He too knew a lot and knew how to tell his story in a sober manner so all of us understood what he had had to go through, but without bitterness.All in all, I learned a lot about Robben Island, ANC and the apartheid regime in South Africa. Go there, you definitely should go there, you will not be disappointed.

Could be so much more. This prison/island offers many untapped possibilities. The tour was interesting in that we had an island survivor as a tour guide. His insights and recollections were priceless but without them the island had little to offer. With a little creativity it could be reimaged into a 'Peace and Preserverence Conference Center' paying tribute to the life and character of Nelson Mandela who endured on the island for 27 years. Perhaps exhibits could be devised to share the solitude of political inmates and the transformation from rebel to statesman. Right now the island is an empty suitcase (albeit scenic) but for a total experience we want to see not only the suitcase but all the contents as well.

Great way to learn about SA history. Very nice tour with nice guides. We really learned alot and appreciate all of the care that goes into keeping this Island a national landmark. There are actually people who live on the island to help care for it and give tours. Peope say book ahead, but we walked up and bought tix and made the boat. People who complain about the island being run down should understand they WANT to keep it as protected and pristine as possible. not refurbish it. Duh.

History come true!. It was my second trip to Cape Town and I definitely did not want to miss Robben Island this time, therefore I booked the tickets online nearly four weeks in advance, as they sell out pretty quickly. The whole Robben Island is an experience hard to describe: it actually needs to be lived and seen, as it is history come true. Not only Nelson Mandela, but many other political prisoners were here until the end of the apartheid regime in the early 1990's. Robben Island is both a South African National Heritage Site as well as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Worth the visit. It is a great place, interesting guide who was a prisoner himself. You are a bit rushed getting the trip done. I would rate this trip a 3,5 but that is not possible.

Disappointment. I was so excited to go on this tour. There was a film on the boat which was very interesting and really got me excited...Then we got on the island... Part 1 of the tour... We had to board a bus but unless you are sitting on the correct side (which is the right hand side when facing forward) you are unable to see ANYTHING... You are also unable to get off the bus which is equally as frustrating, especially on a hot day. My husband just so frustrated (and sick of listening to the guide talk when we could not see anything) so he just got off the bus and walked up to the sign for the quarry... It made no sense to us not to be able to get off the bus. Part 2 of the tour was much more interesting. We were dropped off at the cells and were taken through to see the cells and our second guide told us about his experiences and what life was like in the prison. I understand that it was an important part of South Africa's history but I wish I had not wasted half a day doing it.

Great Trip; Not Enough Time. If one is in Cape Town, this is a must do! There is a 45 minute ferry ride across to the island. It was very choppy on the return trip, so be prepared if you suffer from motion sickness (and perhaps even if you don't). Upon arrival we were put into buses and took on a tour around the island. We stopped off for coffee and then were taken to the prison where we were given a tour by a former inmate. It was an eye opening experience listening to the first-hand account while seeing where it all took place!When it was over, we were supposed to have a chance to do a little walking around by ourselves, but we barely had enough time to make our ferry back!

Must see, book ahead. 27 years in a tiny cell, worth half a day out of your holiday to get over there, much more than just a prison cell though, two parts to the tour, one in a bus round the island with a great stop yo get the best pictures of table mountain, and then a tour of the prison with an ex inmate! The boat ride might also be challenging, especially if it gets choppy and you are up top ....

Sobering experience. I was surprised at the size of the island - much bigger than I imagined. Our coach guide was entertaining and informative, but I do agree that the prison tour was rushed and we felt under pressure to 'move along'. Still worth going to get some understanding of the history of apartheid.

Interesting tour - a must in Cape town. The boat trip was a little bumpy. The tour around the island was very informative. You start with a bus ride over Robben island. Our first guide was very funny and his story was very moving. I even got tears in my eyes when he described his experiences during the apartheid regime. During the second part of the trip you see the cells. The second guide is a former prisoner. Unfortunately it was difficult to understand him and he told the story a little monotone. The trip is nonetheless not to be missed on any trip to South Africa as it explains an important part of its history and presence.

Disappointment. Having visited Alcatraz in February I had high expectations of the tour.The film on the boat was informative but difficult to concentrate on.The guide on the bus was good but the frustration of not being able to get off when there appeared to be information boards everywhere was considerableThe prisoner waited for 2 bus loads so had far too many people in the group. It was his 5th tour of the day and I think his enthusiasm was dwindling!A fleeting glance at Nelson's Mandela's cell - take a photo and move on was the instruction - left me unmoved in the crowd of milling people.It was good to see a penguin and dolphins while waiting for the boat back

Robben Island. If you are in Cape Town, you should really try and get the ferry over to Robben Island where Nelson Mandela was in Prison on the Island for many years. The organised trip was first class. The ferry across takes about 45 minutes and then there is an excursion around the Island by coach with an excellent guide on board to talk you through the various aspects. You are then showed around the Prison by a gentleman who was in fact a Prisoner at some point. Heart wrenching and humbling - excellent trip!

A Cape Town must do.. I have visited Robben Island twice. One in 2007 and again on on October 2013. Both tours were exactly the same....Hurried, crowded and very touristy but at the same time worth the visit. There is major history here. I mainly went back to show this place to my girlfriend who enjoyed it. Like a lot of reviews I recommend getting taking your time on the Island before returning to Cape Town. You will feel rushed to return to the boat. Don't worry, there will be another one unless it is the last boat of the day. Our ex-prisoner tour guide (Unfortunately don't remember his name) was almost impossible to understand (my fault because I don't speak his language) due to his accent so a lot of information was missed. It would have been nice for them to offer a 'higher grade tour' upon which there could be more exploration of the prison and island in general and I am betting tourists would eagerly jump at the opportunity.

Too rushed. Too many visitors.. First the boat was twenty minutes late departing, then when we got to the island there was total confusion trying to get everyone a seat on the tourist buses. On the way round I could not get a good photograph of anything as we weren't allowed off the bus until we reached the toilets/cafe (!). I was expecting a tiny island with one prison but there is a small community there.The ex-inmate guide in the prison spoke too long about Apartheid and not long enough about life in the prison etc. We had literally two seconds each to take a picture/look at Mandela's cell which is probably the highlight of the trip. Then the boat back was held up again, for twenty five minutes. Yes it's a 'must do' but I didn't really enjoy being herded around like sheep on a 'sausage machine-like' tour. It was not very well run and I think they should think of quality before quantity. Not worth 250 Rand.

Pretty Good. I'd agree largely with most other reviews. Robben Island has an exceptional history, dating back farther than that created by it's most famous inmate, and for that it should be given a visit. However it is also precisely because of that that one should put aside more than the half day designated in the official tour. A tour by bus is brilliant and the ex inmate as a guide is a real eye opener. However I really wish i had set aside more time to have a wander around afterwards. I suggest you do too.

Wonderful experience - moving and interesting. This was the most interesting thing that we did in the wonderful city of Cape Town. Would recommend it to everybody.
I really love the fact that your tour is operated by a former political prisoner - makes it all very real and brings it to life.

It could be so much better…. Visiting Robben Island appears to be must for every tourist visiting Cape Town, if the numbers of people on the ferry over to the island are any indication. Also, the trips on the ferry (back and forth) are not very pleasant even when you have taken motion sickness tablets, which I would suggest are a must, not an optional extra. Notwithstanding, the on board video is must for watching before you arrive.There is no doubting that a visit to Robben Island has become a ‘pilgrimage’ for lots of ‘middle-class’ white people (like me), which is rather ironic when you think about it. That said the tour is a must if you come to Cape Town, though the whole experience of visiting Robben Island could be so much better.Yes, you must get on the bus and see the whole island; and yes, you must do the tour with the former ‘Robben Island inmate’; but don’t jump straight back on the ferry at the end of the ‘official tour’ and go back to Cape Town (which was our mistake). Rather, if you want to see Robben Island you need to do some walking – that is, explore the island by yourself on foot. For example, the bus tour takes you to the lime quarry where Mandela and others worked but you aren’t allowed off the bus!!!! The post office is pointed out (where you can send a postcard with a special Robben Island stamp) but again, you don’t get off the bus. And there is also lots of other history beyond the apartheid years (e.g. World War II) which is only briefly touched on as you race by on the bus tour.The ‘on-foot tour’ with the former inmate brings the whole visit to the island into sharp focus, though serious thought will need to be given for the future when these icons are no longer available to give their personal first-hand account. While in places (narrow corridors and other confines) it is difficult to hear what the guide is saying, when he sits you down or you are in the open confines of a prison yard the whole sad story is brought all to vividly to life. It is remarkable that it could all be so true…

A must do but try and pick a calm sea day. I really enjoyed the boat trip over to the island as the views of Cape Town were amazing but the wind got up a bit on the way back and I felt very queasy. The bus tour guide was very droll and kept us informed and entertained but the bus was packed and it was nearly impossible to take photos unless you had a window seat. Our ex prisoner guide at the prison was lovely and did his best to put us in the history of the times bus his accent was hard to decipher and I missed a lot of it. It is still an inspiring place and a huge and important place in recent history. It was absolutely the right thing to do to turn it into a museum. Oh and the flocks of Sacred Ibis and the thousands of cormorants were impressive but didn't see any seals. :(

Disappointed. As I South African I felt the need to see Robben Island as it was a large part of our country's history. I had been before when it was first opened to the public and remembered it being a very informative and worth while tour. On the 17 Nov I went again and was very disappointed. The tour guide around the island was very good however the ex prisoner that took us into the prison was a waste of time. He gave us no information about prison life, instead he went on a diatribe about how the apartheid government is still to blame for what is happening in the country at the moment. I did not go on the tour to hear about someone's political views, I went on the tour to learn about our history.

High expectations so huge letdown. The guided tour on the coach was disappointing to say the least. Although informative there was no opportunity to get off the bus to see the landmarks let alone take photos, except at the point where there was a cafe and chance to snap Table Mountain. I understand that this is due to people lingering in the past and affecting the timetable but this doesn't make it a better experience. Our prison guide was also very hard to understand so although we got to see the prison a lot of what was said was just noise. What was supposed to be a birthday treat for my husband was a real letdown.

A Good Attraction BUT!. I visited Robben Island on the next to the last day of our month long vacation South Africa, the trip in general was quite good, in particular the guided tour on the coach which was very informative and interesting giving the whole history of the island and pointing out the landmarks, such as the leper graveyard and the church and school.The walking tour around the cell blocks was ok but I found the groups per guide ratio, were far to big and as a result if you were positioned towards the rear of the group there was little chance of hearing lots of the information been given.I also felt there could be more time given for visitors to explore by themselves rather than in a large group. The actual cell blocks themselves although very small, appeared to be in a very well kept condition and I doubt very much if this how they looked when in use?A good attraction but not as good as Alcatraz, where personal recorders were given to each and everyone to use and go at their own pace, but nevertheless a must see, because of it,s importance in South African history

A must see if you know the history. This is one of the places you have to go when you're in Cape Town. The name is Dutch for "seal island". The guide was one of the inmates. Robben Island has been used mainly for the isolation of political prisoners & was also used as a leper colony. The most famous prisoner, as you all know, was Nelson Mandela. If you love history, this is a "must see".

Pilgrimage or Casual Interest : a very educating experience.. For those of my generation who watched from afar, the horrors and injustices of Apartheid, Robben Island is one of the iconic symbols of the man, who through peace and understanding, ended the Apartheid era and avoided a civil war.
