Nelson Mandela, 466/64, was infamously imprisoned here for most of his 27 years of incarceration before his release and eventual election to President.You will need to book to get on this tour which starts from the Robben Island museum at the Cape Town Waterfront. The short crossing was very smooth despite a stiff breeze. Arriving on the island you board a coach for a tour around part of the island. Our coach guide had quite a sense of humour although her English was a little difficult to understand. It is worth listening carefully to what she has to say.Then to the maximum security prison itself. Our guide here was a former political prisoner himself, one of the last groups of political prisoners to be incarcerated here. We were shown through the various cell blocks and there was plenty of opportunity to see inside the cells and see some of the inscriptions by former detainees. Then to the enclosed area of area B which is a walled courtyard where Nelson Mandela wrote his book 'The long walk to freedom'. It was amazing that he managed to hide the script for the book there although parts were apparently discovered by the authorities. Mr Mandela's actual cell is locked mainly as it would take ages to get everyone through if it was open. but you can see clearly into the cell with its cramped conditions and rudimentary 'comforts'. Other neighbouring cells in the block are open. Nothing I could ever write could describe the complex emotions of having witnessed for a few minutes what others suffered for decades. This trip is most decidedly worth while. As a little aside, I can also recommend seeing the film 'The 16th Man' in which Springbok Rugby players describe their experience of visiting the Island.

Not to be missed. If you do anything in Cape Town, do Robben Island. Felt as if I was walking on holy ground...This happened not that long ago. Tour guide is a former inmate. Gotta remember the past and realize : repression still happens as does subsequent redemption. Let's not forget out past and our responsibility to the present.
Important place to visit. This is expensive for what it is but we learnt a lot on the tour. Hearing stories from an old prison inmate is not something you do every day.

Very average. There are far better things to do in Cape Town!. Ferry trip and bus tour on the island was good. The tour guide on the bus was very informative with historical information. The tour guide in the goal was terrible! He was very difficult to understand and gave more of a performance than a guided educational tour. Not worth a visit.

Well worth the effort. Robben Island was not on our scheduled visits, but we were so pleased that we made the effort to spend the afternoon there. On our visit to Cape Town our guide had explained what the black and coloured population had endured under apartheid, so it was fascinating to see and hear what these poor folk went through. We were introduced to the cells by a ex-prisoner from the apartheid era and this made it so real for us. As a sight seeing venue, hardly worth the effort, but as a history lesson and experience it was invaluable.

Don't Miss It!. Our tour guide, and former inmate, was completely fascinating and had the entire group hooked on his every word. Can not understand the poor or average reviews... this trip was completely brilliant and a highlight of our awesome holiday in South Africa. The views back to Cape Town and Table Mountain (on a clear sunny day) were also amazing and made for some superb photos.

if you're there you might as well. If I'd been given the choice I probably wouldn't have bothered going , if you've seen one old gaol you've seen them all, there was a good view back towards cape town and table mountain but it was a bit murky, so all in all it's just average.

Worth doing but not unmissable. Before going I had been advised that visitors found this either excellent or really boring, the latter usually coming from "younger folk". I found it neither. Having visited former gaols before (as a tourist) and knowing something of the apartheid story, it was not particularly eye-opening but the information on the bus tour was well done and having a former prisoner as a guide around the gaol felt a bit special. He was interesting, mildly entertaining and contrary to some other reviews, not too difficult to understand.The organisation is a bit haphazard, some had to stand on the bus tour, awkward for them and inhibiting photos for others. There is no real opportunity to do your own thing on the island. Having rushed to be at the return ferry on time it was frustrating to hear about a dozen "final calls", well after the ferry was due to depart.

Well worth it. Robben Island was not really on my top list of things to do in my 3 day stay in Cape Town, but my daughter persuaded me, and I was very glad in the end, even though it took up half a day. The island tour was made more meaningful by our pleasant young guide who you could tell was very emotionally attached to the history of the political prisoners on the island (I suspect he may have been related to one of the past inmates). The tour of the cells themselves by an ex-prisoner was a great idea - ours answered all our questions and really gave us a feel for how the life was for them there. Negatives: only ONE toilet available, and would have appreciated more information on the apartheid struggle and Nelson Mandela's history .

Worth the visit. The 45 minute ferry ride wasn't so great but once we arrived at Robben Island I really enjoyed the bus trip around the island. Very educational and picturesque. After the bus trip we exit the bus to tour the compound by an ex prison inmate that was very interesting. Just make sure you get your tickets early as this tour is extremely busy especially on the weekend.

Could Be Better - Quite Expensive. I was taking some American student friends around Cape Town and decided that Robben Island would be a good place to take them. I live in South Africa and would probably never have bothered going unless I had a good excuse - such as taking my friends. We booked our tickets online as we'd heard they go quite quickly and set off early in the morning with plenty of time to spare to catch the ferry. Unfortunately we were stuck in traffic for over an hour, arrived 20mins late and begged and pleaded with the ticket counter people to place us on the next tour. They said "Sorry, you forfeit your ticket and have to pay full price for another tour" which was extremely disappointing as one ticket is R250 (for 3 of us we ultimately had to pay R1500). I would recommend that you DO NOT book online unless you're staying close to the city center, rather just pitch up and see if you can get a ticket to avoid being ripped off. Also, try to go on a sunny day when there's no fog so that you can get a great photo of Table Mountain and the city from the island (which we couldn't see on our trip).A ferry ride with an introductory video on the history of the island was first. Then we hopped off onto a bus where a very good tour guide told us quite a bit about the island and history. Unfortunately they didn't really give you the option to hop off and take photos, except the once when we could have taken a shot of the mountain (which was blanketed in clouds). Next up was the ex-political prisoner talk, very interesting but also quite long winded as the gentlemen took quite a while to explain things. I think proper trained tour guides would make it a much more meaningful experience, including some more information for tourists to read on parts of the facility. Overall, it was pretty average, and definitely overpriced.

Unmissable. i was a bit iffy about whether this would be worthwhile but imho it's essential but make sure you book in advance as there's only 4 boats a day (0900. 1100. 1300. 1500) and its about 45 mins on the boat each way and a couple of hours on the island tour. Had a great bus guide for starters then a former political prisoner for the prison part who showed amazing dignity considering how he'd been treated. My only gripe was that there wasn't enough time to mooch in the shop before catching the boat

Enjoyable and enlightening. Was a little concerned by some reviews on here that this might not do the subject matter justice or be worth doing but my fears were widely misplaced no both counts. We booked tickets well in advance and indeed there was none available on the day. After getting the boat over to the island you are then put on buses for the first part of the tour, this will take you around the island showing you certain places and allowing you off on at least two occasions.There are tour guides on the bus and ours had a great knowledge and was also very funny when appropriate and we really enjoyed this. After about an hour you have looped round back to the main prison block, here you disembark and our showen around the prison on foot by an ex-inmate. This added so much more to the tour and he didn't go to fast and we could ask questions and take photos everywhere.This took about another hour and then we had to get on the ferry to go back. If you go to SA at all this should be top of your list no matter if you are yound or old.

Essential part of Capetown visit. Not perfect, although they cope pretty well, the food they offer in particular could be improved drastically, but it cannot detract form the feeling that you are visiting somewhere very special, somewhere history was recently made and somewhere where you feel the rocks vibrate with a struggle for the future of millions of lives.Nelson Mandela's name was well known to me, I was aware in general terms of his struggle, my university bar back in the UK was named after him in the 70's, and then not really thought much more about it, but to see the reality was awe inspiring.I cannot recommend it enough, to hear from former inmates is a stroke of genius.

No trip to South Africa is quite complete without a visit here. The history of South Africa is very much connected to this tiny island, from the Dutch settlers outcast here in the 1700s to Nelson Mandela's infamous 27 years here as prisoner before he rose to become president of the "Rainbow Nation". It's an emotional place that won't disappoint if you're at all interested in the South African story. I've heard normal tours are good, but can sometimes feel rushed or informative. I had the pleasure of joining a small, private tour led by one of Mandela's fellow inmates. We got to go to places on the island normal visitors aren't allowed to visit. It was a wonderfully intimate and moving experience. I would recommend booking a private tour if you're really interested in the island's history and want a more personal experience.

History, Conscience or Entertainment?. Before you decide to set off for Robben Island, you need to ask yourself the simple question, "What do I intend to get out of it?"If the answer is entertainment, don't bother. It's a tour of a former prison. That doesn't lend itself to fun and frivolity.If you are interested in the history of the place, the tour will give you plenty of atmosphere (it's not often you have the opportunity to be taken round somewhere by an ex-con) and you get to see Nelson Mandela's cell, hear about what life was like there for the inmates and understand a little better the background to the whole horrid period in South African development.And if you're going because you just feel you should, forget it. Stay on the mainland and pray it never happens again, because just going won't make the past go away.The tour itself is fine, but is not particularly professionally presented in comparison to other 'heritage' sites.One final word of warning, if it's a windy day, there's a choppy sea and you suffer from sea sickness, don't even think about going. 5k each way can seem like an eternity!

Tragic yet inspiring. I visited Robben Island to see at first hand where the remarkable and irreplacable Nelson Mandela spend 18 of his 27 years in prison behind bars before the fall of Apartheid.This visit was very well organised and our group was fascinated how an ex prisoner who was also in prison at the same time as Nelson Mandela (but but who never saw him ever), told us what it was like to be in prison at that time. It is simply hard to believe how these prisoners were treated.It is truly remarkable how Nelson Mandela survived this and became President of South Africa. This is all well captured at the Museum. At the shop on the Island I bought the Nelson Mandela's biography "Long Walk to Freedom"The only downside was the 20 minute journey to the island simply ruined by the owner or manager of the ferry (with a red hat) who had a ferocious argument with one of the staff just before the boat left and kept shouting all the way to the island. Rarely have I seen such tour organisers treat their customers with such disrespect!

If you have time do it. We had mixed advice whether it was worth it. True that the tour is in groups and a little rushed but interesting to hear from ex prisoners and to see this important if not disturbing part of recent history. I would personally recommend it if you are there for 2to 3 days for instance. If nothing else the boat ride provides an amazing view back to the city and Table Mountain that you can't get from anywhere else.

Truly memorable - Great experience. From the boat cruise out to Robben Island to the tour - All round wonderful experience even as a local in living just around the corner. Lived like a tourist for the day and learned so much.

your conscience should make you go. almost everyone knows the story of nelson mandela and his unnecessary cruel 27 years of punishment on robben island.His own fortitude and his will to survive and the strength of character must be lauded.His perserverence, his will to never give up is a lesson we must all try to emulate. If you honor what this man did with his life before, during and surely after his imprisonment, it is a duty and an obligation to go to visit Robben island. Such a pretty place with so much evil behind it and what makes this visit even more mind boglling is that part of the tour is given by a person (or persons) who were previous prisoners on Robben Island. To have suffferred so much and to still return to show us what happened and how they lived is absolutely amazing. do not miss the chance to go especially is you love and cherish your own life. a visit is good for your historical knowledge and great for your soul!

Total disappointment - save your time. I was so looking forward to this trip and was totally disappointed. Yes it's historic and yes it is moving to see where political prisoners like Mandela where held but the quality of the tour and the information provided compared to other world heritage sites and even other world historical attractions is really really low.If you have been to Alcatraz this doesn't compare in the slightest.There is no option for an audio tour, nothing is made to create the atmosphere or conditions that the prisoners lived in. Someone needs to take a trip to Alcatraz to see the quality that people are expecting and really up their game.It is such a shame that a site of such importance is so poorly presented.Guides are often difficult to understand and if English isn't your first language then you are in trouble.I really wish i was able to give a better review of this trip but seriously spend your time in the museums on the mainland.

Such a disappointment !. We rode the ferry out to what we expected to be a highlight of our South African trip. Not to be.The first guide on the bus was very good. The prisoner who was our second guide was a nice man but EXTREMELY difficult to understand, And therefore the tour of the prison was almost a waste of time, with no time to wander about at all. The boat trip back was a mini disaster. Half way back to Cape Town, we turned around and returned to the Island. We waited for a second 'faster' boat. All in all the trip took almost 5 hours, AND it was a huge letdown.Sadly, we would not recommend it. Do some reading instead and use the time for a walking tour of the harbour or downtown area.

Very nice trip. Very interesting tour. Good view on cape town from the island. Excellent (!) guide on the island who explained us the history but not in a very entertaining way.The ferry was not too crowded. Very well organised!

What a disappointment!. We went to Robben Island yesterday looking forward to learning more about South Africas history and the political prisoners. Despite warning from my cousin (who lives in Cape Town), we were astounded by how poor the trip was. The bus trip was poorly managed with passengers not allowed to get off to take pictures the majority of the time. The 2 occasions we were allowed off were for 10mins at Sobukwe's 'house' and another 10mins at the cafe to buy snacks and take photos looking back towards Cape Town. In terms of the history of the Island and the maximum security prison, again it was poor. We were taken around by an ex prisoner who, whilst being very sweet, had only been in the prison a few years when he was a teenager. His knowledge of the facts was not impressive and the whole viewpoint is very skewed. We weren't given time to wander around and take the whole place in. The signs were poor and told you very little information. I may be biased having been to Alcatraz over the summer but I was very, very disappointed. They could do so much more to make this interesting and informative. All they need to do is sort out an audio tour for you to take with you!I would suggest the managers take a trip to Alcatraz and see what can be done.......and it's not even a World Heritage site!

thoroughly recommend a visit to Robben Island, as it is such a huge part of South Africa’s history.. My husband and I visited Robben Island on the 3.30pm ferry on Tuesday 8th October. On disembarking the ferry, we were shepherded onto a bus and brought up to the prison where we took an informal tour with a past political prison. Our guide was very informative, personable and most importantly, spoke slowly and loudly so everyone could hear. He regaled us with tales of prison life, including his leader Nelson Mandela who the prison is famous for. We were shown around the cells, communal rooms, outside space etc of the prison and enjoyed hearing what a day in the life of an inmate was like. It really brought the place to life. After the walking tour, we were shepherded back onto the bus and driven around the island stopping to take photo’s in many of the islands’s most famous spots. I did feel a bit rushed and shepherded everywhere – however I expect this was because we were the last group of the day and time was tight. I thoroughly recommend a visit to Robben Island, as it is such a huge part of South Africa’s history.

Worthwhile but not outstanding. Both Mum and I took an afternoon 3pm tour to the island, with a capacity packed Ferry. The Ferry itself was more than sufficient and we felt safe and comfortable each way. I would definitely get there early as crowds are more than likely guaranteed, and book ahead of time online. On arrival we were herded onto large buses and taken around the island with a guide. Only stopping to peer out the windows at some places. If you are on the wrong side of the bus for the stop it is sort of tough luck! We got out twice and of course for the important historical part being the main cells. Another guide then took over and presented us with the all important info. that we would expect. But it probably went for just that little too long in the one room. I must say very glad they have not turned this into some fancy overdone tourist attraction and love the fact that it is left raw and relatively untouched. And left with your own presence and thoughts a moving moment. But found the organised tour part and overall experience a little disappointing.

Awesome - A Must. I had to visit the place where this world icon spent most of his prison years.Just to be there and see his cell was amazing.I would recommend getting tickets on line, so you don't get shut out.There is about a half hour boat ride to and from the island, offering spectacular views of cape town and table mountain.Once on the island there is about a forty five minute bus ride around the island. Then you get a guided tour of the prison and see Mandela's actual cell. I believe most guides are ex prisoners. (our's was).It takes a total of about three and a half hours.I can not imagine anyone going to Cape Town without visiting Robben Island.

Emotionally Compelling. Everyone should take this trip.Make sure you get tickets in advance. The trips by ferry book up quickly, particularly now as tourist season approaches. The trip takes a half an hour one way over very choppy seas. If you are prone to motion sickness, make sure you take Dramamine prior to getting on the ferry. A number of people threw up on our trip.Once on the island, you are met by a bus with a very knowledgeable tour guide who points out the sites along the way, and who will answer any questions one might have. The bus stops for refreshments and a bathroom break, before going on to the prison.At the prison, we were met by another guide, who had, at one time, been a prisoner on the island. He explained, that he was unable to fully integrate back into "normal" society once he was released. It has been therapeutic for him to stay on the island, and conduct tours of the prison, and to tell his story.One definitely gets the idea as to how cruel and inhumane daily life was for a prisoner on this island.The tour of the prison and island takes a couple of hours. It costs 230 Rand each.

Haunting. These place brings you down to earth with a massive thump, thank god for people like nelson Mandela. To listen to a survivor of this terrible place was indeed hard as you could feel his emotion and understand why he was obviously close to tears as he relived his ordeal foe us. A day I will never forget but glad I did it.

worth doing. It's best to get tickets beforehand online as there are a few boats a day. Water can be rough .It's a scenic trip. The tourbus is an uncomfortable model but our guide was good. The political prisoner guide inside the cells also was good but It all could have been better. An AV presentation would have been so helpful and brought it all alive. I read Mandela's book but was still shocked at how tiny his cell was. So it's something were happy we did but it's not five stars.

Impressive. It was very interesting but also very emotional to visit that prison, we had all heard about that place during Apartheid and while Nelson Mandela was keps prisoner there. Some of the guides were ex prisoners or ex warders. With time less and less obviously, they are all getting old, but listening to somebody who had to "live" (?) there for many years is extremely moving.

Oh yeah!!!some people went through tough times.... The tour was so informative and touching. Learning about the tough lives of those who were sent to Robben Island, from those who had leprosy to political prisoners, was so touching.

Mandela Gateway. My tour was cancelled due to the high swells on the first day and then the pouring rain on the second. Instead, I spent my time at the Mandela Gateway reading the history of Robben Island and the imprisonment of Nelson Mandela and many others. This just gives me another reason to come back to Cape Town next year. A couple of suggestions - buy your on-line tickets ahead of time and try to visit this early in your itinerary in case they cancelled it so that it can be rescheduled for the next day. This is a very popular attraction.

A trip into history with nature thrown in. Robben Island served last as the prison for political dissidents during the apartheid era, most famously of Robben Island. Visit the museum and the quarry where they worked. Get to the island on a hovercraft departing from the V and A waterfront. The tour also includes a drive around the island...special feature is the penguin colony.

A must do if you are in Cape Town.. Everything we has hoped and expected. Interesting, informative and thought provoking. A spin off is that you get to see the stunning view of Cape Town from the sea. Good value for money. Would recommend as a ' must do' if you are visiting Cape Town.

eye opener. you should visit Robben island as part of your itinerary. tickets can be bought online to avoid disappointment. includes 2 way ferry, guided tour of the island by an ex-political prisoner. Gained some general knowledge. visited the cell Nelson Mendela stayed in.took some nice scenic pix of Table Mountain as well

A must-do in Cape Town. Our visit included a coach tour of the island with a guide who in addition to being very informative was a lot of fun and tried to teach us how to make the click sound used in Xhosa. For me, the most significant part of the coach tour was the stop at Robert Sobukwe’s “house,” where he was detained for many years in solitary confinement, even after his initial sentence had been completed. The tour ended with a guided tour from a previous political prisoner of the main facility, where we saw the row of cells used for ANC leadership, the exercise courtyard and Nelson Mandela’s garden. A not-to-be-missed experience.

Sobering experience. Forget the crowded bus. Focus on the history. Boat trip was good. Bus when we arrived on the island was daunting as it felt overcrowded. But the best part was listening to our guide reliving his experience. We saw and we felt. How anyone could be incarcerated in this place because of the colour of their skin is mind boggling. It really brought us down to earth and made us realise how lucky we are. These guys were really pioneers and made the world a much better place for all of us. Our guide brought me to tears when he thanked us from the bottom of his heart for what we , as Western nations, had done to bring pressure on the SA government re apartheid. Amazing! After all they had suffered, this was very humbling & motivating to us. An experience none should miss. We can't let this happen ever again. On a practical note, make sure you book well in advance at it can be up to a 3 week waiting list.

Salutory but a must do. This is a very well organised outing popular with visitors. The half day is very well organised but bookings are essential. The experience is very graphic leveraging the memories of former prisoners who act as guides. It's not a fun outing but critical to understanding the recent history of South Africa. Apart from that the views from the island back to Table Mountain and Cape Town are to die for.

Tour is smaller and the atmospher too "clean". This is the second time I have visited Robben Island. My first visit 7 years ago was far better. The tour of the island was a full trip round the island, they now go to a refreshment stall and turn round. The information is now less as well, there appears to be a move towards "sanitising" the conditions the conditions that were experienced by the prisoners.It is still worth a visit, but the organisers need to heed the feedback and improve the experience.

Beautiful historical must go place. I loved that they let us to stay a little longer in the island to take some pictures and feel that emotional vibe of it... but they do the visits always on the run!BOOK THE FERRY IN ADVANCE

robben island. a visit to cape town is incomplete if one does not visit the robben island where nelson mandela was imprisoned for 27 years. a very interesting tour where one can learn a lot regarding nelson mandela and his fellow prisoners and how they suffered the injustices. there is also a grave on the island of a muslim saint.south Africa is today free because of the sacrifices made by nelson mandela, ahmed kathrada and a lot of other prominent freedom fighters.I strongly recommend a visit to robben island.

Must visit historical place. First, buy your tickets online in advance. They often sell out and regardless you will not have to wait in line. If you are visiting the area and not familiar with the Waterfront, the ferry location is by the yellow clock tower. We did not have anytime to go to the museum on the land, and did the entire island tour. You take a short ferry ride out to the island on a decent ferry (refreshments are available). On the island you hop into a bus that will take you for a tour. Our tour guide on the bus was a younger local who was fantastic in giving useful information but also making the tour fun. The drive is nice and you stop halfway along the tour at a spot with a great view of Cape Town and table mountain and a place to get some snacks. Then back on the bus to head towards the prison. I would have preferred to have been able to get off the bus at the various stops on the tour for pictures, and experiencing it more, but still a nice tour. Once at the prison you are given a tour by an ex-political prisoner of Robben Island and have a quick tour of the location. It was informative, but a little drier than the bus tour. There are not a lot of exhibits in the prison and you do not get to wander to explore. Afterwards you walk the short distance to the ferry and head back to the mainland. Overall, an excellent experience and glad to have gone. The whole experience is very structured, with almost no free time for one to wander around. I would love to see more exhibits on the island especially in the prison where one could walk around and read and look at things but this is a very new museum. Go early in the morning.

Very glad we did this trip!. Our visit to Robben Island was very informative and eye-opening. While the trip itself was sobering, we found it very valuable and were glad we booked the trip. I would highly recommend booking well in advance as there are limited spots on the tour; we saw many people turned away trying to book day-of tickets while in Cape Town (we booked ours about 3 weeks prior to our arrival). The trip begins with a ferry ride that sounds like it can vary from very smooth (what we experienced) to very rough depending on the weather and which actual ferry boat is operating. Note if the weather is too rough, the company will cancel the tours but they do provide a refund.The tour itself consisted of a bus ride that was very interesting but in my opinion, could have been a little shorter. The remainder of the tour consisted of visiting the actual prison quarters with an ex-political prisoner as your guide. The tour really only visited a large cell block, courtyard area, and Nelson Mandela's cell. I think it would have been more interesting to visit other parts such as the kitchen area. Still overall we would recommend this tour.

Book in advance. The reason I'm writing this review to advise everyone to book the ferry well in advance. We did not manage to visit the island as there were no place on the ferries and we are very disappointed. Also, I don't understand why they don't run down more ferries since there is a high demand especially during the holidays.

Robben Island. This visit was both humbling and informative. Having been brought up in South Africa as a child I was completely unaware of the scale of the apartied and after this visit to Robben Island so thrilled that there is a movement of change in the country.Highly recomend a visit to this site and take the time to absorb the long history of the island and it's impact on the world.

Incredible Experience - A must do in Cape Town. I am so glad I went to visit. Very interesting and sad to hear some of the stories from the ex prisoners who guide you in the prison. Really informative and good for us to hear the experiences of those who were kept there. I would highly recommend this if you have an open mind and willing to listen and learn. The boat trip can be an experience and there was a few people unwell on the 30 minute crossing. You have to book well in advance and get there early to make sure you avoid the queues. I suggest you book online. Excellent value and in my opinion, unmissable.

A Must-See in the Mother City!. This is best done on a windless, sunny day as the boat ride to/from the island can be a bit choppy if there is a lot of wind. A sunny day will give you a gorgeous backdrop for your photos of the V&A Waterfront with Table Mountain in the background as you leave the ferry dock and upon your return. The tour of the island is very interesting...it's very poignant to see the lime quarry where Nelson Mandela worked for so many years, and has haunted his eyes and lungs ever since. The story of the rock cairn at the quarry will bring tears to your own eyes. While I like the idea of former prisoners as tour guides for the prison section, I would have liked to hear more about their personal stories. This is a must-see for anyone who wants to understand the dynamic, ever-unfolding history of this fascating country!

Robben Island Tour. Is not what you expect you are going to see. The first part of the tour of the island is great with the tour guides knowledge well researched. The tour of the prison where you expect to see a lot about Nelson Mandela is very poor. It is extremely political making you feel sorry for the blacks. The apartheid is been over for 20 years now. Should of been more interactive. They should see how they do the tours of Alcatraz and pick up some pointers from there tours. It is not worth the bumpy trip by boat. Very disappointed tourist.

Robben Island an Emotional Experience. My wife and I had hear about Robben Island of course, but were unprepared for how emotional it was to visit there. First, the tour guides are all former prisoners of the island. We could hear first hand of their experiences. Second, seeing the small prison cell where Nelson Mandela was kept for so many years was a moving experience. Highly recommended to get a glimpse at South Africa's past. A bonus are the views on the boat ride back from the island.

So glad the weather improved!. It was touch and go as to whether the weather would be appropriate for us to visit and I am so glad we made it! I would have been very disappointed if we were not able to visit but worth bearing in mind it is a bi of a lottery this time of year!A very informative trip with excellent guide around the maximum security prison - himself an ex prisoner.

Interesting but have ticket in advance. I went in winter and was still sold out. Weekends are busy and if you don't have a ticket there is no standby line anymore. I waiting around and someone had an extra single ticket so I paid him for it in the future I recommend people to buy online at least 5 days in advance. Was worth seeing only if you have free time but don't skip other things in Cape Town just for this. Alcatraz was much better so if you've done this don't bother with Robben Island. Very educational. Nice day trip.

Worth the trip! Moving and great scenery. This trip takes approximately 4 hours and apparently it gets busy during peak times so book in advance. We booked the day before and even in early spring it was well booked up. It starts with a visit to the Robben Island museum which gives a brief overview of the history of the island. Go early if you want to get a chance to read the info boards because they are situated in the same hall as the queue for the boat which fills up near boarding time. The boat trip is a short 25 minutes with fabulous views back over Cape Town, but can be a little bit choppy on a windy day! On arrival on the Island a 45 minute bus tour awaits with a guide who gives lots of information about the landmarks and history. There is an opportunity or two to stop, take photos, buy a drink or visit the loo before returning to the prison itself where you are guided round the different blocks. For me, I would have preferred a bit longer to explore but you do see the cell where Mandela spent his time and get some insight into the history. It was well worth the visit and for me, a visit to Cape Town wouldn't be complete without it.

A scenic trip through history. A trip to Robben Island is a mixed bag of experiences.For the tourist - stunning views of Cape Town city and Table Mountain from an angle you cannot get on landFor the sailor - a great boat trip, through part of the harbour, a short trip open sea, then the little dock on the island.For the Historian - a sobering glimpse of prison life and the lot of the , then imprisoned political leaders of South Africa. reflect in the old quarry where the future of the country was plotted. A rather over-politicised guided tour and presentation but worth it once.

Informative tour, worth the price, but improvements are needed. We found our recent tour to robben island very informative. The bus tour is not the best way to see the sections of the island. You are not allowed off the bus and have to jockey to see the historic sites with 80 other people. You get one stop to walk around which gives you a nice view of Cape Town and the Island's curio shop. The prison tour was much better. Our guide had been a prisoner during the 70's. He was sentenced as a 19 year old for organizing a high school protest against the government. He was there for 8 years. He answered any questions asked about his life as well as life at the prison. Everyone visiting Cape Town should visit this site just as a reminder to stand up against injustice in the world not just in South Africa.

Interesting but could have been better. This was a must see on our trip but we left feeling it could have been done slightly better. The boat trip (30 mins) was fairly rough (as is often the case) and was followed by the full boat load of us being decamped into 6 or so fairly old buses for a trip around the island ending at the prison. The guid on the bus was fine: informative and amusing and was followed by an ex political prisoner who again was fine but din't offer much of his own experiences (perhaps he didn't want to relive them. I think I would still recommend it but we were slightly disappointed.

This is the place where Nelson Mandela was kept in the Prison!. This is the place from where South African Democracy movement (considered) was started. Well, still this country (South Africa) is going under very bad conditions with the Black People's Rights issue. The Black people are still fighting just to get their rights. No idea when the situation is going to be normal. In other words, Robben Island itself a nice place not very far from the Cape Town City Center.

Disappointing and overpriced - don't bother.. I had high expectations of Robben Island and was left feeling thoroughly ripped off and disappointed. The ferry trip over was fine - but then you are herded onto a cramped smelly bus with about 80 other people and have to endure a boring trip where you can't see anything if you are on the wrong side of the bus. We saw the quarry - but only with 4 people between us and the window. Then were made to get off the bus after 10 minutes at some random toilet stop. The whole purpose of that seemed to be either to take photos of Cape Town or buy a drink from the bored looking staff at the "bar" ( a counter in the corner of a room) Then herded back on a bus to another area where we got off to look at some houses and dog kennels. There were some interesting displays in the houses, but we werent given time to look at them all. Then the "Meeting" with a political prisoner. This proved to be thoroughly disappointing and not as informative as we had hoped. Again, we were not given any time to explore on our own, read signs or take in any of the information on notice boards etc. The people who run Robben Island, need to do some work on improving the visitor experience here. Alcatraz would be a good place to start - get some multi lingual self guided tours, give visitors the option to explore on their own, and don't force people to return at set times ( weather permitting obviously). There are many similar facilities in other cities around the world providing a much more informative experience. Would not recommend at all.

A poignant reminder of the apartheid years.. Pre-booked this tour via the website and would advise others to do so. Robben Island is about a 30 minute ferry ride from Cape Town. There are several ferry journeys throughout the day that leave from the V & A Waterfront. We were scheduled to catch the 9-00am ferry which ended up leaving at about 9-15am - no reason given for the late departure although it could have been due to some mechanical failure with the main larger ferry as we were all hoarded onto a smaller boat that resulted in a number of people standing. Seas were a little rough and mention was made that trips would be cancelled the following day if the seas became rougher. This did happen as a couple staying at our hotel found out when they arrived at the V & A Waterfront departure point to find their ferry had been cancelled due to rough seas. Would recommend all to phone ahead on the day of their trip to make sure ferries are operating before going to the ferry wharf.Once we docked on the island we were shepherded onto a number of quite old buses that were waiting about 200 metres away for what turned out to be approximately a 45 minute bus tour, with one short hop-off spot to stretch the legs, get a drink etc. At this stop you got a great view of Cape Town and Table Mountain - which must have been a very disheartening sight for the prison inmates - freedom so close yet so very unattainable. A guide aboard the bus gave us all a very informative talk about the history of the island and a brief description of some of the facilities that we saw from the bus including the lime quarry, rock quarry, church, leper's section and graveyard, medium security prison and former guard's quarters. Much of the latter was in a very dilapidated state and appeared to be in danger of being overrun by the seagull and bird colonies. Our last bus stop was at the maximum security prison where political prisoners were held. We were advised that at one stage the political prisoners were housed in together with criminals (murderers etc) but at some point the criminals were moved to the medium security prison.At the maximum security prison we were met by a former inmate who had spent 5 years in the maximum security prison from 1977 to 1982. He had been a high school student when he was arrested for being involved in a rally against apartheid. He showed us through some of the main prison block dormitories with showers/toilets attached. He advised that up to 30 prisoners lived in his dormitory and that for the first year of his term they all slept on blankets/mats on the concrete floor. After that they were given beds. We were then shown through a block were there were about 20 single cells including the one in which Nelson Mandela occupied for most of his time on Robben Island. They were all tiny with no beds (blankets/mat on a concrete floor), no toilets - only a bucket. The prisoners in this section were often required to carry back rocks from the quarry which they then broke into smaller pieces whilst sitting in a small, uncovered, concrete enclosed courtyard outside their cell block.After being shown through this section we then walked about 400/500 metres from the maximum security prison back to the docks for the ferry trip back.Interesting and informative but I thought quite a low-key tour.

Wow, what a history. It really makes one think about the hardships that some people had to go through for us as south africans to have teh freedom. It was a heart warming and definetlly sad but happy experience. It helps one not to take this our rainbow nation fogranted.

Affecting, informative, worth it just for the view.. This was my second trip to Robben Island and I cannot recommend it enough. The boat ride out can be rough- if you need seasickness meds, bring some- but the journey there and back offer spectacular views of Cape Town, especially on a clear day.It's a very popular trip so book well in advance and turn up early to get a decent seat on the boat.  You'll get a bus tour of the island and a walking tour of the prison by a former prisoner. The whole thing from leaving the Waterfront to getting back takes about 3.5 hours.For me, the most affecting part of the trip was block A- in here, each of the cells have a picture of a prisoner who stayed there, with a snippet about their time in the prison in their own words.So book early and be prepared for the crowds and the seas, but don't miss it.

Disappointing. What a wonderful historical location packed with lots to say about it.... yet, the tour is lacklustre and left us disappointed. We expected to walk away touched and to learn lots about the apartheid and the conditions of robben island... how mandela and his mates passed notes in the outdoor bit... where they were punished in isolation etc etc... i had to glean much of the history from mandela's book. if you go, make sure you read his book first as the tour itself isn't great.

Herded like sheep. My interest in prisons made this a top attraction to visit when planning my trip to Cape Town and when I took my place on the ferry that shipped at least 200 people to the island, the video that accompanied the journey made me even more excited. The group then got split up into 3 bus' and we begun the tour. Thanks to the guide (not sure what his name is- young and was wearing a green cap) this part of the visit was thoroughly enjoyable and was very informative however there wasn't much time to take pictures etc. The view of table mountain and Cape Town when we stopped for 10 minutes was the highlight of the trip and we were very lucky as the sky was clear. We were then shepherded through the prison in a group of about 100 people with one tour guide, with very little information to give (or I couldn't hear him) and quickly rushed past the iconic cell of Nelson Mandela. I was very keen on getting the nitty gritty information of prison life and I feel that if I hadn't had any background knowledge on apartheid era, I would of gained nothing from the trip. altogether, the trip was extremely disappointing and I ended up buying a book on Robben Island to find out what it actually was all about as the tour did not provide me with the information I was expecting for the money.

Disappointing. Having managed to get to Robben Island on the 3rd attempt we were very disappointed with the whole experience. I had a problem getting my tickets printed and went to ask for some help from the ticket counter and the help desk. Neither were very helpful just kept saying they needed the reference number which I couldn't get because I hadn't got an Internet connection, this didn't seem to matter to them and I think they would have been quite happy for us not to go, there was no willingness to help at all. The boat normally used was broken so we were put another which took over an hour to get to the island. On our arrival we were hurried on to the buses and given the tour with very little opportunity to take photographs. We were then taken to the prison to meet the ex inmate. Our guide was very passionate but a little difficult to fully understand. A the end of this we felt abandoned without any direction back to the boat or the times we could leave so we just got on the first boat we came to. Such an opportunity missed to give people a memorable visit whilst providing a valuable insight into the history. Perhaps someone needs to visit other places to see how it's done.

Currently 108 out of 242. Currently this experience is in the doldrums when it should be in the top ten! Not a lot to see although our guide was excellent having been sent there in 1978. His experiences were harrowing and, not for the first time on this holiday, we were left comparing the Apartheid regime with the Nazis in Germany - and quite a few other regimes, both current and past, if the truth be told! However, the ferry arrangements were shambolic!!! We spent longer waiting in queues for the ferry (both coming AND going), than we did visiting the sights. So if you are working to any sort of tight schedule best give this a miss.

Only if you are interested in history. I have limited time in Cape Town, the reason I went there is that I am interested in history and want to know about Nelson Mandela of course. To be honest with you, there is not that great views from the island, you can shoot the table mountain and the ocean but you don't necessarily have to come to Robben Island. Not that many people are living there anymore, pretty much the only thing you can see is the prison! After you get off the ferry, you will get on the bus and there will be a guide telling you the history of the island, then you will be taken to the prison where Nelson Mandela stayed, then there will be another guide explain the prison history to you and you can also visit Nelson Mandela's cell, which is the highlight of this trip. The island itself is pretty much deserted if not because of the museum there, a lot of people moved out already so the nothing too much infrastructure there. Also it's hardly to see seals or penguins there, according to the guide the seals have been eaten by the European when they first arrived. In case you don't know, Robben means seal in Dutch, so it actually means Seal island, but there is no seal anymore. Tip 1: try go there in a good weather, otherwise the waves will make you very comfortable and it will influence your visit. Tip 2: try to buy the ticket online, it's efficient and easy for you to plan your schedule. Tip 3: go there early so that you will have better chance to have the top seat to have better view in the ferry.

Robben Island Tour. We visited today and expected to be blown away by the experience. Sadly, it was awful and it is hard to identify any positives. What an opportunity this should be to showcase South Africa and the amazing man Nelson Mandela. We had a very disjointed tour, we were bored stiff by an ex-convict who was extremely difficult to understand and we are not sure if we actually saw Mandela's cell. It was so disappointing and is by far the worst activity we have undertaken during our generally amazing holiday here. The slow ferry journey back was a joke and the disembarkation extremely third world. Why don't the authorities invite a professional organisation in to provide an interactive multi-language tour like one experiences in most international tourist hotspots and museums?

Forget it.. This was to be a real highlight of our visit to Cape Town. It started fine and on time with a ferry crossing to the island. Then a bus tour which was fine too. When we arrived at the prison we were met by an ex inmate, who we were delighted to meet but was unable to give an interesting narrative. His talk was too long, quite dull and political. Urging us to buy books. It's fair to say that we wouldn't have been there had we not been interested but most people on the tour just wanted to see Nelson Mandela's cell, learn a little bit about the conditions etc, and take some photos. The ferry journey back took twice as long as the outward journey and the disembarking was chaos. A multi media tour would have been much better and more interesting.

Robben Island Guides Not Understandable. The tour was interesting for what you could see. It was heart rending to view the 6 X 8 cell where Nelson Mandela spent 18 years working during the day in the prison quarry. The sun and the dust at the quarry left him with eye and lung problems. The problem with the tour was the guides. You just couldn't understand them. The guide on the bus, a woman, spoke with an accent, and spoke very softly and rapidly. You could pick up about every third word. The guide on the walking part of the tour had a very gravely voice like Louis Armstrong, spoke in a conversational volume and only the people right up next to him had any chance of understanding him. There were at least 30 people in the group and to those further back, the words were lost. We asked him to speak up, but he never raised his voice to reach further back. He had spent 5 years at Robben Island during Apartheid, so he had a lot of valuable knowledge to impart. It is too bad the people on the tour could not understand what he was saying. The Tour operator needs to give their guides a lot more speaking training, or use professional guides. Other than seeing Mandela's cell and the quarry where he worked, the trip was very disappointing. The history the guides tried to tell us would have been fascinating had we been able to understand it.One possibility would be to hire your own guide for your group. It could be worth the money.Bring a warm jacket as the wind off the water is cold, particularly in the winter.

Heads up!. Plan ahead.....book ahead! If you don't book ahead you may miss out. Even in the off season the trips sell out at least 1 day ahead. Suggest using your credit card for payment. If the tour is cancelled due to weather you will have an automatic credit posted. Glad I used my card to book because all the tours were cancelled on the day I had scheduled.
Genuine Recent History. The guides are past prisoners.. It adds to the authenticity. ** BRING A JACKET.. it was colder on the island than I thought it would be.

A must. A trip to Cape Town must include a trip to robben island. The tour was so interesting and the guide was knowledgeable. The tour around the prison was by a ex inmate who was there when Mandela was there and the way people were treated differently is shocking! This was a very interesting place and the views of table mountain amd the city are breath taking. Book online as that seemed easier to us. Would recommend to everyone thinking if going.

Essential experience in Cape Town. Apparently there used to be complaints about the trip being somewhat disorganised and things have changed. It was very efficient, perhaps to the point of being a bit too quick. However, if they are to get people around and get the next boat load accommodated I guess it has to be done, after all everyone wants to see Nelson Mandela's cell!Buses meet the boat (which is fast and comfortable) and take you for a tour of the island, we didn't get off anywhere, apart from the viewpoint/shop/toilets, which was a bit of a shame, I would have liked to walk around a bit, for example in the quarry. There's quite a lot of wildlife on the island, but you don't get much chance to appreciate it.We were then delivered to our guide, an ex political prisoner, who took us into the prison itself and showed us around and talked about life in the prison and how it was organised. I felt privileged to meet him and shake his hand and to learn about his experiences first hand. I was very moved by the experience.We went out of season and managed to book a few days in advance but I would certainly recommend booking well ahead.

Robben Island Museum. It was difficult to get tickets for this venue and we went twice waiting to get last minute cancellation. We got the ticket for the boat ride about 40 minutes long each way and spend the time visiting various prison facilities. The highlight of the tour was the fact that the former prisoners serve as tour guides and he gave his individual perspective about the place.

Worth A Visit. The tour is informative and you get to visit the prison personally. The ferry can sit up to 200 passengers and ours was full. Fortunately, I heeded some advice and bought our tickets online at an earlier date. There will be a short break to get a cuppa at a mini cafeteria on the island. We were very lucky as our tour was the only tour on that day. All the other tours were cancelled due to bad weather. It was raining and the sea was rough. I saw so many people vomiting.If you are prone to seasick, it might be a good idea to pop a pill before the ride.

A must do in Cape Town - Ensure that you to book in advance. Robben Island is definitely a must do activity if you are planning to visit Cape Town. The tour itself is broken into 2 parts and it takes about 3 hours, it's a prison and a bus tour of the island. There's a lot of South African History, it's quite interesting that the tours are led by political prisoners who were incarcerated there. We got to see Nelson Mandela's prison cell and Robert Sobukhwe house. The Tour Guide, Thabo explained things well, clearly and was very knowledgeable. We were able to take as many pictures as we could and had opportunity to stop and enjoy the view of Cape Town and Table Mountain. Ensure that you to book in advance if possible online as it is cheaper especially during peak seasons as the tours to the island can be booked out for several weeks.

Good Historical Site. Much larger than we thought, although we felt rushed through it and would have liked to see more by being able to walk without a tour guide. The tour guides were interesting since they were former prisoners but we felt they wanted to say more but were pressed to get to the next group.

Excellent "Pilgrimage". If you find yourself in Cape Town, you absolutely need to go on the Robben Island tour. I would best describe it as a kind of pilgrimage for the average person. Yes, you are essentially going on a prison tour, but being on the island where Nelson Mandela spent almost 30 years of his life should hold some kind of significant meaning to you, if only because you are the kind of decent human being who believes in equality and justice regardless of gender, race or creed.Ferries leaving from the Nelson Mandela Gateway at the V&A Waterfront take guests directly from Cape Town to Robben Island. I believe there are only 3 or 4 departures a day so make sure to check ahead of time to avoid unnecessary waiting or, worse, missing out on the last ferry of the day. Each ferry trip is about 30 minutes and the whole tour is over 2 hours long, so expect to spend a good portion of your day on the tour.Personally, the highlights of the tour were seeing Nelson Mandela's cell and hearing the first-person tales from our tour guide. I believe all the guides who take you around the actual jail cells and prison grounds are former prisoners. At the beginning of the tour we did have a bus ride that took us around the island itself, but this guide wasn't a former prisoner.There are a couple of things I would suggest you keep in mind if you are considering the Robben Island tour.1. If you have small children, I would say any child that is 8 or younger, really think about whether or not you want to take them on the tour with you. It can be a grueling 4 hours for a child to follow his / her parents around an island where there is very little visual stimulus. Let's face it, looking at prison cells and prison grounds can't be all that exciting for children and I'm not so sure that they can truly appreciate the struggles of a political prisoner.2. I have never been sunburned in my life, except the one day I spent at Robben Island. There is not all that much shelter and the sun during the summer months is very unforgiving. So wear lots of sunscreen and cover up any exposed skin if you are visiting during the South African summer.Cape Town is a great city to visit, but make sure to spend some time on Robben Island. The tour is well organized and well worth the price of admission.

A piece of history. It was great to hear personal experiences directly from one of the former inmates of the prison and see where Nelson Mandela spent so many years. I warn you though: The ferry ride is brutal.

Interesting and Moving. This was a very interesting experience and a must do for anyone who is interested in South African history and learning more about Apartheid. The ferry ride from the Waterfront was not for the faint hearted on the day I did this tour as the sea was very rough and many people were sick and/or terrified. Upon arrival you have an interesting and short bus tour of the island and will learn more about its history. The main attraction is seeing the prison where you are given an excellent and fascinating tour by a former inmate who pulls no punches about life in the prison.

Don't miss this tour.. Don’t miss this tour. The guides of the prison are former inmates. They give you a perspective of Nelson Mandela, apartheid and their own struggles that is unique. The logistics are simple and the content is of course priceless.

Must See. We visited Robben Island in Aug 2013 and found the whole trip to be very interesting and a very worth while experience. To be able to see the Jail and to be guided round by one of the former inmates just added to the experience.

Brilliant!. This is such a brilliant experience, you get a real insight into the life of the prisoners, plus the tour is done by ex prisoners. You are slightly rushed as you walk around but due to the large amounts of tourists it's understandable. This is such a interesting day out, I highly recommend this if you want to learn about the history of South Africa and the importance Nelson Mandela holds in the country. Wear sensible shoes for walking around the prisons.

Very Moving. The two guides on our trip were outstanding - the first was a young bloke who spoke to us during the bus tour part of the visit. He was very funny, incredibly balanced and switched on and his story of the island as a leper colony and the children born there despite segregation had my bottom lip wobbling. As did his explanation of the limestone quarry where the later political prisoners educated each other in their breaks. The stone was blinding white. Our second guide at the prison was a former prisoner and I found him incredibly moving. I actually made my way back to the boat in tears. It is super bleak as you would expect with birds, the sea and wind taking back the island with buildings stuck in time. But the willingness of the former prisoners to return to the island and share their stories with tourists and the sheer spirit of the place is very inspiring. Unforgettable.
lifechanging experience. apart from being a little pricey, i thoroughly enjoyed this trip. must visit when in town, very historic.

Must See. We had a great visit here. The boat ride over was pleasant the day we went, although the queue for the ferry starts about 30 minutes before departure. The first part of the tour is a bus ride to see most of the island. Our guide was well- versed, and gave us a good talks we drove. We stopped for a couple of minutes at a coffee stand, but the view to Cape Town was so awesome we did not have time to get anything. Then, on to the prison. Our guide was a former prisoner who served five years before the general release occurred. We saw the cell Mandela lived in, and saw the areas where the prisoners bathed and the Common areas. Our guide talked about his ANC training, including East Germany and Russia. It was amazing to see former jailers work in the museum with the former prisoners. It gave Me great hope for South Africa. I recommend this tour to anyone.

Very Historic. It was like history becoming live to me,...i was indeed a memorable, yet emotional experience due to the fact that some of my country men have spent years at the island as political prisoners. The biodiversity of the island is very impressive,...

Important place, disappointing visit. Unfortunately we were really disapointed during and after visiting Robben Island. You are carried to the island by ferry and then put in a bus with more than fifty others. The drive around the island was supposed to be 45 minutes but lasted almost one and a half hour. The take you to the lime quarry, the isolation cell of Robert Sobukwe and the island's village. This is okay but the guide was, I am sorry to say that, horrible. Everything she explained I could have read in five minutes on wikipedia. At the quarry we stopped but were not allowed to get off the bus, at Sobukwe's cell we were given 15 minutes which is far to less time to read the displays, especially when you are more than fifity people. The worst thing was that her announcements were more like sermons. I reckon everyone who visits Robben Island already knows of the importance of the place but she reminded us every two minutes. The low point was reched when she asked every visitor which country she or he is from then thanking for this country's contributuion to abolish apartheid. Eventually we were dropped off at the high security prison where a new guide took over. The tour got slighlty better now. The guide was a former prisoner and took as through the group celles and eventually to Nelson Mandela's cell. This part of the visit was okay but again there is so much room for improvement. Why for instance, don't they let people walk freely arounf the island and the former prison. Then former inmates could be at certain points and explain to you prison life etc. The visit is very much focussed on Nelson Mandela's cell but there is so much more to Robben Island and I suppose so muc hmore to tell by the former prisoners. The are rewally giving away a good opportunity.To sum it up, as much as the visit is important to every visitor to South Africa and South Africans as well I was very dissapointed with the way they carry out the visit. This could have been a much better and memorable visit.

Thought provoking place to visit. Firstly book before you go to guarantee you get to visit this most thought provoking place I have visited. The boat journey across might be long but we saw three Orca (Killer Whales) jumping through the waves and a pod of dolphins playing in the sea. When you get to the island you are by a bus to take you around, the side of the bus says it all " The Journey's never long when freedom's the destination" you get to see the old buildings that prison officers and familes lived. You get to see the limestone quarry that Nelson Mandela prisoner 46664 worked in. Then you get to the prison it's self, your tour guide is a former prisoner who was in Prison with Mandela. They tell there stories and memories. To see what they lived in is heartbreaking. A visit to Robben Island makes me thankful for freedom of speech and thought we are allowed to have in 2013. You must visit Robben Island!!

Robben Island Tour - Cape Town, So Africa. I was in Cape Town in July of 2013 and visited Robben Island, one of my life-long dreams. I cannot tell you how disappointed I was; not with finally seeing the cell that Nelson Mandela served a 17 year prison sentence or meeting one of the actual prisoners of the island who was hired as a guide; but with the way that the government employees at the island and the museum have taken advantage of the Mandela name to turn a sacred site into a tourist trap.Upon arrival to the island we were herded into hot, over-crowded buses (from which you could hardly see out of) and driven around with a guide whose English was poor and accent was so heavy that she could not be understood. We were then taken to a kiosk on the island to take pictures and were left there for an inordinate amount of time - not what we had paid to see or do in our limited time as ictated by the government tour organizers. We finally were taken to the maximum security prison where we were allowed to get off the bus and see and hear about the prison itself.It was a great disappointment to me that this lifetime experience was ruined by lazy, self-entitled government employees. They and the government of So Africa should be ashamed of themselves.Shelly

It is almost compulsory that one visits here whilst one a Cape Town visit.. It is not a cheerful place, yet the boat ride is pleasant, as is the island tour. The prison tour is good, however a very sad experience. It brings home how amazing Mr. Mandela is.

Glad we made it!. We had tried to get tickets to Robben Island, but had no luck. Evidently lots of trips get cancelled even for just slightly bad weather. So what we ended up doing is going at 8:45am right before the first boat out and asked if there were cancellations. Luckily they had enough spots for 8 of us to hop on at the end! The tour is NOT scary. Some people warned me that my children might be afraid. That is not true. I actually think going to Alcatraz is more scary. There were lots of bus stops where you could hop on and hop off. There's even a stop at a concession stand. It's a good tour and a nice boat ride.

Top attraction - but could be better. Visited Cape Town in 2010 and missed the opportunity to get to Robben Island but made sure I didn't miss it when I returned in 2012.Almost a pilgrimage as someone who only grew to admire, understand and appreciate Mandela after his release from prison. As a visitor to SA i got the sense that South Africans I was with on the trip were indeed visiting as part of the healing process - to a place that was once despised by the black community and those who had the sense to call for the end of apartheid regardless of their creed. The prison is much as it was and only covering a tiny amount of the island. We were greeted by an old political prisoner who spoke well and told of the time spent here and the harshness of the prison regime.I left however feeling as though something was missing. Hard to put my finger on it - but I think probably the place could do with a little development. Perhaps add a museum. If the intention is to leave the island alone and present a bleak and uninteresting place then the authorities have largely succeeded.

Robben Island Prison. This is a must, not only to learn about the terrible history of apartheid but also to understand what a really GREAT man Nelson Mandela is. Trips are easy and 'all-in' and the views back to Table Mountain are spectacular. GO!!

A must visit site, could be better. If you are a bleeding heart liberal like me, or simply a person who is disgusted by injustice, a visit to Robben island is something you must do when you visit Cape Town. Having a guide who was a fellow inmate of Mandela and can explain the day to day life inside this hell hole was worth the price of admission alone. There is a lack of interpretive materials, and the tour starts with an uncomfortable bus ride. If you get seasick, take pills, the boat ride over and back is a roller coaster.

Inspirational and Powerful. Robben Island is one of those places that makes you really feel the history that occurred there, from the leper colony to the political prison that held Nelson Mandela. It is something that just simply needs to be experienced.We got lucky and reserved two tickets on a ferry for the next day, but this isn't recommended - seats on the ferry can fill up a week or two in advance. The line to get on the ferry is very long as well, so leave plenty of time before your ferry is scheduled to depart for waiting and security. We don't normally get motion sickness, but the ferry is pretty small and it was really windy, so we were glad that we had though to take motion sickness medication that morning, because it would have been a rough ride without it. Passengers are guided to comfortable buses after arrival on Robben Island and the tour begins. You are driven around the island and its history is explained; endangered bird habitat here, former leper colony there, view of Cape Town and Table Mountain, deserted village, among other very interesting things. And then you get to the political prison and you get out for a second tour. Former political prisoners actually give the tours through the prison, so it is an incredibly powerful experience. It is difficult to wrap your head around what prisoners actually went through while being held there. You will wait in line to look through the window to Mandela's cell, which is tragically sparse and cramped. You then usually have time to walk around the island a bit, but you don't want to miss the last ferry, so keep track of time. We walked over to the coast to see the penguin colony, and although you could only see them from a distance, it was worth checking out. Boulders Beach is a much better viewing spot for penguins, honestly, but the coast along Robben Island is quiet and beautiful, and the penguins just add to it. We walked past fields of beautiful wildflowers and colonies of sea birds along the rocky sea wall on our way back to the ferry as well.

Very interesting. We went here on nelson Mandela day and it really set the mood. We had to book the tickets two weeks in advance as the tickets are really had to get hold of if you fancy just going the next day. Boat journey was nice. We all got onto coaches and had a tour of the island. Once we got to the prison we had an ex prisoner taking us round. The way he told us about his story was so interesting and I was more interested in his story to be honest. I had a fantastic time and would come here again.

Wonderful experience. This was an amazing morning in Cape Town for us. We reached the terminal easily along the beautiful V&A Waterfront, and the boat ride which took us across was smooth. The tour itself started with a bus tour around the island and narrative, which was interesting and gave a good context to the second half of the tour, with a former political prisoner. The gentleman who spoke with us was held during with Mandela, and it was amazing and quite moving to listen to his experience. This helped us to better understand South Africa, and we would highly recommend this to any visitors. Not that you go to Robben Island for the shopping, but it is worth knowing that the gift shop on the island was impressive and had an array of books, posters and other items which were fantastic. We could have stayed there longer!

Bumpy boat ride, nice tour. This should definitely be on your "don't miss" list for CPT. On top of the historical significance, it is a well-run operation. There are plenty of sources for the symbolic significance, so I'll talk here about my logistical thoughts.Very important to buy your tickets ahead of time and BE ON TIME. Also, if you get seasick, take medicine beforehand as the ride can be extremely bumpy. We caught air a few times and lots of people were getting sick! Once you're on the island, your guide can stop at a clinic to get seasick medicine for the return trip, so make sure to ask if he/she doesn't offer.The bus on the island can be packed, so try to find a seat early. The tour through the prison by a former political prisoner was great, but I feel like it can be rushed for the guide since he had so much to talk about (a good thing). Ask them questions while you're walking to get the most out of them.

Interesting tour, boring island.. With an ex-prisoner as a tour guide, you get first hand tales of what it was like to live in that prison. The island tour is interesting but there is little to do on the actual island itself. They could include more sign boards with pictures so you can visualize what the prisoners looked like in the prison and explain if you miss what the guide said.There is only one shop which you stop at half way through the tour to get refreshments, but no other curio shops. they could make a lot more revenue from things like that.

An island of oppression and brutality becomes a symbol of hope and freedom. Robben Island is an informative and enlightening experience to learn about the struggles of apartheid and political imprisonment. I have enormous respect for Nelson Mandela and his ability to forgive his captors and to be a catalyst for the liberation of mankind. Logistics: Purchase tickets a few days to weeks in advance since they do sell out. Boats leave at 9AM, 11AM, 1PM (and 3PM in the summer). Cost is 230 Rand. Sold at the clock tower at the V&A waterfront or online. Arrive 30 min prior to departure. 3 hour tour including boat ride. Bus tour of the island and then a walking tour given by a former Robben Island prisoner. Visit group cells and also the individual cell of Nelson Mandela.Overall: I recommend visiting Robben Island. It's a piece of history that you won't want to miss.

Standing where a legend was. Hard to describe in words what it feels like to hear the guide explain how he was imprisoned on the island and then see the blatant racism within the prision. Seeing Mandela's cell was powerful.

Don't miss Robben Island tour - but book ahead. We had a phenomenal tour of Robben Island, the prison where Nelson Mandela and other freedom fighters were incarcerated for decades. It is a bumpy 30-minute ferry ride out to the island, but it was one of the most fascinating tours I've ever taken. The tour leaders were extremely knowledgeable and provided lots of history, and a former political prisoner led us through the prison. Recommend booking in a few months in advance; this tour tends to fill up.

Humbling, informative, unmissable. I never really understood the evils of apartheid until visiting Robben Island.You need to book in advance because it gets very booked up, and we travelled on the first ferry of the day, with many of the staff. The return ferry journey was rougher than we thought, but we all felt we were standing on history's shoulder, and those in our party who didn't go really missed out.Our guide was a previous inmate who shared prison time with Mandella, and his story and narrative was extraordinary.I've been and seen now, and don't need to go back, but the visit changed my whole perception of apartheid SA, and I understand that it was Mandella that prevented SA lapsing into civil war and anarchy.

Well worth the Time. I recently spent six days in Cape Town, and my visit to Robben Island (along with the trip to the top of Table Mountain) were the highlights of my stay. Even if I only had 2 days in Cape Town, I would take half a day to take the ferry out to Robben Island. It is the only place in the world, where you can be at one World Heritage Site and see another (Table Mountain). The trip is actually 3 tours in one. The first is the boat ride to and from the island. The ferry is large and comfortable but if you want seats outside at the top, then you will want to be at the front of the line when it comes time to board. The video displays give you information about the island or you can just hang outside and watch the beautiful views of Cape Town. Once you disembark, you will board buses for your second tour. The bus drives you around the island while a guide tells you what your looking at (island school, church, Robert Sobukwe internment site, WWII gun battery). We got out once to grab a cup of coffee and see the view of Cape Town. The tour is in English which is widely spoken in Cape Town a the other parts of South Africa where we visited.The third tour (and highlight) is the tour of the prison led by an ex-political prisoner. Our guide informed us through the use of personal stories and anecdotes. Since these men are in their 60's or older, you will not get this opportunity for very much longer. You will see Mandela's cell. You can't go inside his cell but can go inside others.Finally, you take the long (actually quite short) walk to freedom from the prison back to the dock where you can buy souvenirs from the gift shop. I highly recommend a visit to this one of a kind world heritage site. BTW, the weather in the winter often does not allow the ferry to make the trip to the island so you might want to book this tour first. We couldn't go the first time we wanted because of the weather and we couldn't go on another day because the island was closed because of President Obama's visit. We went the day after he visited and they still had the US flag in one of the conference rooms.

something you shouldn't miss. The major attraction about Robben island is the visit to Nelson Mandela's former prison where he was incarcerated for about 15 years.
