To get to Robben island there's a boat that cruises from Cape town's harbor and takes about 30 minutes one way. The best part of the tour is the visit to the prison's interior where you can take pictures inside the cell where Mandela had been incarcerated.Because of the historical and cultural value it is a trip you shouldn't miss.

Interesting Stories, but Lengthy Tour. We unfortunately got stuck with a slow boat, and it took us one hour to get to Robben Island, and another hour on the way back. The tour of the island was interesting, but getting to hear stories from the ex-political prisoner was the most interesting part. You get to walk by Nelson Mandela's cell and then walk by other cells that include personal stories and artifacts inside. Don't waste your time looking for the "3rd largest penguin colony in Africa" because we only saw two of them, and it was quite a disappointment. Our boat left at 9am and didn't return until about 1:30pm (but again, we had a slow boat), so I thought that was entirely too long. Although there are interesting stories and I would recommend one visit, I certainly wouldn't plan on returning.

Robben Island - A historical must see. Visiting Robben Island must be a top priority whilst visiting Cape Town. The tour surpassed my expectations -which were already set high to begin with. The tour is an interactive, engaging and sobering experience which will defiantly educate people of all age. The price to visit the island is relatively low considering it includes the boat ride to and from the island, a bus tour around the island and walk through the prison cells. I highlight for me was how each tour guide was an ex prisoner on the island. Perhaps that is one of the many reasons why the whole tour captured and retained my full attention. I 100% recommend everyone to witness the trials and triumphs of the infamous Robben Island.

Robben Island - sobering and special. Visiting Robben Island, we were lucky to have one of the ex-political prisoners as our guide. A dignified and measured man, he led us throughout the prison explaining how the prisoners lived and existed. Their day to day life was horrific. Nelson Mandela, and the men who were imprisoned over the time Robben Island was used and are now guides, are very special people to have come out and been able to forge a life moving forward. They could have all been very bitter and defeated. The tour around the island is also very interesting as the island itself has at times had large populations on it for varying reasons and uses.The trip out to Robben Island was delayed considerably by the breakdown of the ferry which we believe is a regular occurance. There was another ferry at the dock but it too was not working due to mechanical issues. The boats we then took were slow and the return caused us connection issues because of the extended time getting to and from. Whilst the time on the island was excellent, the trip out and back could have been better.

Robben Island. Total tour takes about 4 hrs..30 minute boat ride..45minutes on bus...45 minutes seeing the cell blocks. Our tour guide (who had been a prisoner there) did not really explain the day to day living they went through. Was hard to get him to talk about his daily life. Interesting but would not go back.

Makes you think. From water front clock tower with boat, you go to the island. Then the tour starts. It is in 2 parts. First part you're taken to the various important locations around the island with a guide. Then you arrive at the gates of maximum security prison, where you get of the bus and you meet your second guide which is one of the ex political prisoners. He tells you how things were back then. Depending on you much stuff you read here and go into detail, ask questions, it might get quite emotionally draining experience...

Essential experience. You can read all you want about Mr Mandela, but you can't understand his life without seeing the quarry where he was required to break rocks all day long, and his miniscule prison cell. Here you will get it all, a drive around the island, a visit led by a former political prisoner, and the honor with which the South African people speak his name. Of course, there were hundreds of others who shared his experiences and we don't always hear of them. So be quiet, listen and learn and ask all the questions you can think of. You won't find more tolerant guides than these. The ferry ride back to town gives you time to process all that you've seen. And do book ahead, we overheard many who were disappointed that they couldn't get the visit in when they wanted to.

A Must See in Cape Town. This was definitely a highlight of our trip to Cape Town. You take a ferry to Robben Island and you are then driven around on a bus with a tour guide who shows you the lay out of the island and the different buildings used by the prison. You then get a tour of the prison blocks from a former inmate, which is both moving and disturbing at the same time. It's interesting, as our guide had a very positive mentality, and did not seem at all upset that he was now living and working at the very place he was imprisoned. I would recommend giving yourself extra time to explore the island after the tour is over. Just be mindful of the ferry times so that you do not miss the last one!

Thought provoking. I was not sure I wanted to take this tour but it was a highlight of our trip. The 2 parts of the tour were extremely well done. The prison tour was led by a former political prisoner who told what life was like inside the prison. Make your reservations early as this trip books up.

And he forgave?. It was inspiring to see this historical place. It is amazing to think that Mandela left this experience with such forgiveness and fortitude. We went on a lovely day so that ride over and back was beautiful. Constitutional Hill and the Apartheid Museum were more informative and inspiring, but this was more than worth the time.

Robben island tour. For something that holds such significance for the Sth African people and history, it is EXTREMELY poorly presented......Sadly it proved to be one of the most I eventful and boring afternoons that we have spent in Sth Africa......It could be presented in a much more informative and relative light that what was given.......The boat ride over also took over an hour! And same return......A documentary ,prior to visit, viewed in australia, was way more informative than this .......Sadly I would AVOID, as so. Much could be learned elsewhere....and it was an afternoon sadly wasted.....

Ok tour but could be so much better. Enjoyed the trip a bit but it could have been so much better. They didn't allow us to look around the lime quarry, there are no arranged models or scenes to give extra info, vert few info boards ... in fact a big lack of useful and extra info for this attraction available on tour that could be terrific but yet is only ok.... and a lack of choice and options on the island, as if everyone has the same superficial interest...

Special place. although the regular boat was non-operable, and the boat ride took twice as long as normal, the ride was pleasant. The highlight was that a former political prisoner who was incarcerated at the same time as Nelson Mandela was our tour guide. It was a powerful yet funny tour and he was open to answer all of our questions.

A nice day out. We visited Robben Island as a combined family, with 6 adults, 2 children, and a 2 month old baby.The trip itself was very informative, and interesting, and the 2 guides we had were both friendly and willing to share their stories. The boat trip to the island was OK, although I think the engines need servicing, as there was a terrible smell from a cloud of black smoke which blew into the cabin form the back deck.The groups were also a little big in my view, especially when touring the Maximum Security Prison, they could have done with splitting the group in 2 so it isn't so crowded.Families must note the following:Everyone has to have a "ticket" to travel to the island. There is an adult price and then kids are charged at 120ZAR I think (almost 15USD) - now I understand the importance of everyone having a ticket, in case of emergencies, people can be accounted for. But to charge 15$ for a 2 month old baby who slept the whole trip, can't speak, and who wouldn't have been listening to the tour, I think is ridiculous.We booked on line to save queuing (no discount for booking online - unlike table mountain), and didn't pre-book a ticket for my 2 month old daughter, as I didn't think for one minute she would need one. The staff didn't seem bothered when I had to go and buy another ticket & complained. Unfortunately, although informative, it is a bit of a "tour factory". You are just "one of the masses" So that was a real shame and put a dampener on the whole day for us.
When you have time enough. Interesting but not a must see. Groups are 2 big. We didn't understand our guide very well.You should do it when you have time enough (takes more or less a 1/2 day)
Got to go place.. Really interesting. So glad to have had an opportunity to visit this piece of history. Book early to avoid disappointment.

Respect .... Yes i go to jail... and please respect every aspects.The pleople who guides you to the prison is one of the prisoners.Some times, is hard to belive in such things, but out there u can feel it. Very nice.Like the name says is a island you get there on a boat, depend on day try to get a nice and confortable place.

Must Visit. Your trip to Cape Town is not complete if you have never visited Robben Island. If you are seasick, then I suggest you inquire on which of the boats are the slowest because the one we rode on, was so fast that even me, not prone to seasickness, was almost at the point of needing a bag. When we got there we waited around for a bit since there was some confusion as to who our tour guide would be. Eventually we were let inside and a former prisoner announced himself as our guide and walked us through the prison. It was quite informative and we even got to see the actual cell that Mandela was in. You can tell that they did a lot to make the place look better, but you can imagine how worse it was back in those days. At the end of the tour we were loaded on the buses for a tour of the island. We were able to see the quarry that the prisoners worked in and also the huge guns that were used to protect the island if under seige. We also got to stop at some point to take the most gorgeous photos of Table Mountain and also to get snacks before continuing on. All in all we enjoyed the tour and would advise others who have never been to visit. I will say that once you have been, there really isn't a reason to visit again.I will advise that you purchase your tickets in advance, especially in peak season. Also, make sure that you get there at least half hour before the departure time, THEY WILL LEAVE YOU!

Robben Island. Everyone who visits Cape Town should do this trip. It's well organised and very informative. It is very nice to meet the guides and hear first hand what it was like to be ther. Very thought provoking.

A very sad part of Cape Town's past comes alive in this tour. The tour of the island was outstanding! The first part of it was a bus tour with a guide to show us the various parts of the island - its history and birdlife. Then we were met by a former prisoner who did a wonderful job of telling the stories of the prisoners of each cell block, and answered endless questions. It was amazing to see the tiny cell where Pres. Mandela lived for 17 years. Unfortunately, the regular ferry was being repaired so we were taken out on a fairly small ferry in very rough weather. Be sure to take your travel sickness pills along if you get motion sickness.

so much potential. there has been many improvements to the tour since i did it about 15 years ago. i found the 2 guides (one on the bus and one in the prison) to be doing a much better job, being both informative and entertaining. during the bus part we were allowed to stop, get off and do some walking around, something that was not part of my first time there. this was wonderful and more of this should be added to the tour, i.e. at the cemetary, the church, the quarry, etc. the prison part has also been changed. no more sitting in the courtyard listening to the ex inmate's experience and more walking around and being informed as you see the prison. also much better than my first time, but again more time is needed to take in the surroundings and the tales.although 3 hours sound like a long tour, once you get there this is simply not enough. an extra hour is vital, an extra 2 hours would be even better. from my experience they are doing a good job and they seem to be improving as time and/or money allows. this attraction has the potential to be truly incredible though. holding thumbs that they get there over time.

A human rights pligramage not to be missed. There are few who have not heard of the apartheid and how Robben Island became the detention centre for all the male dissidents during the political struggles in South Africa at the time. And while its infamous political prisoner Nelson Mandela of 18 years is likely the main 'attraction' for why many people visit the island, the history of its past, and what is now symbolizes for humanity and human rights globally is a must do while visiting Cape Town. Booking your ticket early is a must as I had to wait four days before to could get a spot. But, the price is very reasonable and I am glad I was able to wait and still go. The island and prison tour was very informative and the short bus tour to some of the islands' hi-lites while modest in comfort are also noteworthy. Although the prison tour itself was informative, it is/was the fact that the tour was conducted by one of the former political prisoners who shared some of his life story that made the tour more impactful and memorable. While the legacy of Robben Island will live on because it has been declared a national monument and heritage site by UNESCO, I recommend visiting while the tour is still able to include some of the living legends who were imprisoned and who are still able to share some of their story. And although the islands' significance may never be forgotten, like the Nazi concentration camps I have visited, the attraction may become sterile and its message fade.

Must see. For my tour, the queue at the terminal was orderly, the ferry left on time and it was clear we had to get on a bus on arrival. Yes they will take a photo of you on departure to try and sell to you later for $$$. The buses were uncomfortable and cramped and it was hard to see out unless you are beside a window. I can imagine it must get very uncomfortable in summer. The second half of the tour, in the prison, was quite good and made even more interesting because an ex prisoner was leading the tour. I would recommend for visitors to come here.

A visit not to be missed if in Cape Town. I'm going to qualify this review by first of all saying, that if like me you grew up in the 1970s and 80s during the apartheid era and took a keen interest in the ending of that regime, visiting Robben Island is a must. I booked my trip online a few weeks beforehand and so had a ticket already booked. I had not given any thought to the fact that the trip might be cancelled due to rough seas, so I was lucky because boat trips had not been running on previous days. The day I went the sea was beautifully calm and the view of Cape Town as we were leaving the water front and on the way back were spectacular and a great pho to opportunity.The trip to Robben Island itself was perfect. On arrival, we were put into coaches and allocated a tour guide. Ours was a young man with great personality and a great deal of enthusiasm in telling the story of the island. This portion of the trip took about 45 mins and the visit to the lime quarry where men were forced to work was particularly moving.The second portion of the trip was to the prison itself where we were shown around by a former political prisoner from the 1980s. There was plenty of time to ask him questions as a group and what we learnt in that hour-long visit to the prison will stay with me forever. We all managed to walk past and take a look into Mr Mandela's cell but there were a lot of us in our group so you couldn't stand and look in really for more than a few seconds.I would have no hesitation in recommending this trip, it was an extremely moving experience and even the teenage children who were in my group seemed genuinely engaged with the stories the prisoner told.

a historic national monument, now a pilgrimage center for all who love freedom!South Afric. Robben island, a small island 12 kilometers offshore the city of Cape Town, was a place for banishing the ' 'unwanted' ones -political prisoners, criminals,and even leprosy and mental patients! .Now recognized as a national monument,a world heritage spot by the UNESCO, it is a pilgrimage center for tourists from all over the world.- one not to be missed while in Cape Town. Ferries ply from the Victoria waterfront every 2 hours from 9 am till evening.You are advised to book your tickets a day or two in advance,preferably by the morning trips and on a clear day so as to avoid disappointment. Once you reach the island, take the bus ride through the place. Our bus guide, a passionate South African, delighted us with his knowledge and moving talk. Our first visit was to the famous yellow house where the Pan-african activist Robert Sobukwe was kept in solitary imprisonment for 6 years, and after release, brutally treated until his death- a very touching story as narrated by the guide! we drove through the island, viewing the various landmarls- such as the Irish church, the settlements, the old light house and the limestone quarry where the prisoners were put to hard labour.we got down at the beach from where the prisoners viewed the mainland , so near, yet so far!. we got down at the high security prison guided by one who had spent many years in that prison -courtyard enclosed by the high walls, the small cubicles where the political prisoners were kept, their daily life, the hardships and the brutal treatment they were subjected to .Our final stop-over was at the cell no. 7, the small cubicle, now painted and well maintained, where Nelson Mandela, was incarcerated for 18 years of his 27 years of imprisonment before his long walk back to freedom! There is a very good museum near the jetty - no entrance fees.

Robben Island - a bit of history. I am a South African who has been twice to Robben Island. The first time by myself, the second with my children, who were young teenagers at the time, and I felt they needed to see for themselves. This is an Incredible lesson in history. I was extremely moved by it. It really made the feeling of apartheid and what the prisoners went through much more real. I think it of great value for South Africans as well as visitors to South Africa.My children and I were extremely fortunate to have met Nelson Mandela and to spend a bit of time with him, and for my kids to see where he was incarcerated and the size of his cell, made an incredible impace on the. Highly recoomend. You get there by boat at the V&A waterfront. For anyone seeking a bit of history about South Africa, I highly recommend it.

Robben Island. I found this an amazing lesson in the history of apartheid and the political prisoners held on Robben Island. Our guide through the prison itself was held as a prisoner on the island for 7 years. Good value for money including the 45 minute boat trip each way.

Trip to Robben Island. Our guests booked a trip to Robben Island, they are a Family with 3 children, first of all when they got there to the appointed time the trip had been cancelled due to some problems with the boat. The guest came all the way from Yzerfontein to take this trip, could one not have sent n SMS to inform the guests. Then they changed the date of the trip and went again. Once back at home, he saw that the Trip had been booked twice of his account, that is not the kind of Service Level one would associate with a historically important place like that.

Could be so much better. This is an important site and could be so good, but it is very badly organised and run. We learned more about Robben Island from the recent film “Goodbye Bafana”, about the relationship between Mandela and one of his jailers. If you want to go, either book online or turn up early at the ticket office and be prepared to spend the morning looking round the very interesting Waterfront while you wait for your ferry slot. The sea is rougher in the afternoons, and the ferry takes 30 mins. If it is really rough, the ferry is cancelled. The guides on the island are former inmates of the prison, but their skill as guides varies. Ours liked the sound of his own voice far too much and just wasted time. We were in a far-too-large group of one hundred people, shuffling slowly about, listening to the guide drivelling on. He had some interesting things to say but they were lost in the pointless rambling. We eventually abandoned him after an hour of boredom, and looked around ourselves. But a good guide would have added so much more.They evidently did not have enough guides (or were too badly organised) to run smaller groups.  Sincethere are not enough guides to cope with the numbers, and former inmates will get older and die out, someone needs to save and use their memories. Film and record interviews with the former inmates and edit these precious nuggets of first-hand experience and oral history to use in the different rooms, and make a film for while people are queueing for the ferry. Smaller groups could be run by extra guides - and all guides should be trained, as their skill varies. There are many people who need the work and could do a good job with training. The tourist facilities on the island were very poor - a small fly-blown shop and tatty toilet such as you might expect to find at a tiny garage in the middle of nowhere. And there was quite a bit of waiting about for the next ferry. Compare this to the excellent operation of Table Mountain, run by a private company. The Robben Island operation had government bureacratic inefficiency stamped all over it like the Moscow Co-op. It is an important cultural resource and could be so much more professional – and generate more money too.

Apartheid Prison. Only reached by boat, the tour of Robben Island is a historical journey to a time when South Africa did not give freedom or equality to all its citizens. Usually, a former prisoner is the tour guide, which gives a personal feel to the horrors of what happened there. It can be very hot there in summer. So, it is best to visit during alternate seasons.

The price of equal rights-the end of Apartheid. This is a must if in Cape Town. A nice boat ride to see the unfortunate home of a South African Icon! Robben Island prison, the home of Nelson Mandela for most of the 27 years he was incarcerated. He remains, though in frail health a true inspiration for equal rights for all in South Africa! He epitomizes what freedom and equal rights for all signify! He is a true hero for all of us to recognize!

Amazing Experience. I waited too many years to visit this incredible place! The boat trip was fun, the bus ride around the island was interesting and entertaining. And the guided tour by the formed prisoner was surreal. All in all definitely something everyone should experience.

Not to be missed - but could do better. A visit to Robben Island is a "must-do" part of any Cape Town visit. I pre-booked, and arrived at the gateway in plenty of time to visit the exhibition of anti-apartheid posters upstairs; only one other visitor was making the effort to do so. The boat crossing was fine- don't forget to take sunscreen if it's a decent day - but on arrival on the island itself we were also herded onto buses for the tour. This was OK, but leave visitors with no time for reflection. You make two stops, one of which seems mainly to be to allow you to buy souvenirs at the Southern point of the island (but did at least allow me to wander slightly away from the group).The tour round the prison that follows suffered from an ex-political prisoner who seemed to be remote from the the whole thing; I guess it's not easy having to relive hard times three or four times a day for tourist groups, but he seemed unnaturally detached and we spent a long time ion the first blockhouse (so that other parties could go past Mandela's cell first). This meant that at the end we had to rush back from the prison to the harbour with no time to ourselves. Of course, ironically this might reflect one of the realities of prison life, but I boarded the boat feeling I had visited the island, but not really been there.

Ex Prisoners are the Tour Guides. How cool is that.. Get your camera ready. On the boat ride you can get some nice pictures of the city skyline as your heading to Robben Island. Ex-political prisoners are the tour guides which I found added much more interest to the tour. When the guide finished the tour he quickly stepped out of the room and was wiping tears from his eyes. His being a guide at the very place that he was imprisoned is obviously still one that he is healing from. I spoke with him after the tour and he said that him leading the tours is therapy for him. This is a must visit when in Capetown. The sad part is that this all took place not that long ago.

An Experience to Remember!. We were told by locals that this wasnt an experience to miss because we had a lot on our plate in Cape Town, and we are glad we did this. It isnt the most glamorous of experiences. In fact it is an experience that reminds you of the trials and hardships suffered by people. It reminds you how lucky you are to never have to go through such a thing. The island itself is nice and you dont feel that you are on a prison island. The prison is a very humbling experience. Give it a go especially if you dont a jam packed schedule and like a bit of history.

Touching. Depending on your own personality etc this may or may not be "your thing"- however we found it very touching seeing where Nelson Mandela and others were prisoners for so many years- Guide himself had been a political prisoner. They cold, however, do a much better job of that if they had a film when you first get there for overview (tour guides are not professional guides per se and the accent and crowds can make ti difficult to understand everything ) Boat ride there and back very scenic and nice but timnig could be better coordinated- get your tickets a few days before and go in the arly morning to get back and enjoy the afternoon in Cape town.

Couldn't stop crying. Honestly, this place is just so amazing for the historical/cultural value! No, it's not breathtaking or stunning. But you're not going for the view. You're going to understand (and since most non-South Africans know only the basics)... it's a great insight into apartheid. Our guide was great, and it was so interesting to hear his experience as he was a former political prisoner on the island. You have to go here!

Well it is interesting and worth the visit is you have the time. If you have visited Freemantle Prison in Australia & Alcatraz in USA then Robben Island fades a little... expectations are high & the results are just OK... The history is of course interesting but the visit adds very little....

Great guides and lovely weather made it a perfect trip!. We started this trop with mixed feelings, because of the different reviews on TA, but it turned out to be great. I think it's all about the expectations you have. We had tickets or 11 O clock, but had to wait for a second boat to come. The 35 minute boat trip can be a little bumpy, but we fell very save, on the top deck, with the beautiful views on a clear day. When you arrive at the island, there will be busses. Get on one of those and you'll be shown around on the island. There are several stops, where you get some explanation about what you see. Our guide was very informative, repeating some things and very easy to understand and hear. You get off the bus 3 times (which feels like a school trip, 'You have to be back in 10 minutes'). One of the stops is at a small shop where you can buy snacks and drinks and use the restrooms. The last stop is at the orison itself, where your guide will be an ex-prisoner. Ours was a member of the ANC. He had a very impressive story to tell about apartheid, his time in prison and how great it was to live in a country where he had the freedom of choice. He showed us Mandela his prison cell, which most people seem to come for. We then walked back to the boats and the boat left Robben Island a few minutes later. We were back around 3.We enjoyed our trip a lot, especially because of the fantastic guides we had. It might be a different experience when you don't have the guides that we had. Besided that, it was just a really nice day out with lovely weather and great views. The critism that most people on TA have, is the lack of information provided by the organisation. They are right about that, because no one will tell you about the boats, there is no schedule and no information provided on paper. There's no real restaurant, but you don't visit Robben Island for food, right? The tour is also not about Nelson Mandela only, it's about the island where he has been for many years. If you want to know more about him, read his book.

This is the most powerful museum experience we've ever done. What an experience. You need to book in advance. The hotel did manage to book us in for the next day but i think we were lucky. You go across on the ferry and are met by a coach and guide who take you round the island. Then you go into the prison and are shown round by a former political prisoner. Its very moving. It has to be one of the most important pieces of political history of our time and is a must visit for visitors of cape town.

Top of the list in Cape Town. I agree with previous reviewers - this is well worth adding to the itinnerary.The boat trip over took 40 minutes, on a perfect afternoon. There were great views of Cape Town from the water. Drinks and bathroom facilities are available on the fast catarmaran. The opportunity to ask questions of a former political prisoner on the island really is very special. We saw some other sights on the island. These included the quarry and midden where Mandela placed the first stone, added to by other former prisoners, when he came back in 1995. There is a well stocked gift shop on the island, as well. My only criticism, was that the PA on the bus was not working, and we were at the back of the bus. I asked the guide to please speak from the centre of the bus, which he did, and he also did his best to shout.

must see. I really enjoyed this attraction. The ferry ride to the island is pleasant. The transfer to the buses was smooth. Our bus guide was terrific as he showed us the sites of the island. Besides the buildings of the prison, there are birds to look at . An endangered bird resides there as well as some species which roost. There are also shipwreck remains. After the bus tour, our ex-prisoner guide led us inside the prison. The picture/verbal snapshots in the cells of the long gone prisoners are moving.A must do!

Very Powerful. The visit to Robben Island is very powerful. Beware that you do need to buy your tickets in advance if you're not going through a company, and you might have to wait a bit to board the boat. Our guides (both on the bus and then in the prison) were absolutely fantastic. The views of Cape Town from the island are also spectacular. I read Mandela's "Long Walk to Freedom" before going, which I'm very glad I did as it gave me a better understanding once I was there. Should be at the top of any visitor's list in Cape Town.

A must and a don't!. The tour itself with the sea ride plus guides and the sheer opportunity to see the cell where Nelson Mandela was held prisoner are all = a MUST!This said, The rest is a DON'T go there until the transports are fixed!. The arrangements, the information, the transporting systems arrangements, were all catastrophic! Misleading information made us cancel our meeting with sponsor children in the townships! BIG mistake!I don't need to write more about this. You can read a very good summary review here: “Must see historical site where you are turned into cattle being herded between poorly presented sites”Reviewed 8 April 2013

A great piece of South Africa history. It is great to be able to relate to the recent history of South Africa and see where Mandela and his fellow inmates lived in bad conditions under the apartheid regime. Start with a beautiful boat ride out of Capetown. On reaching the island board a bus for a tour of various points of interests including the residential part for the guards and security personnel. Then go on a walking tour through the main detention center and be guided by an ex inmate. really the best possible guide with first hand experience. Truly woth it.

Beautiful boat ride to Robben Island. There are so many great attractions in and around Cape Town and Robben Island is a must go see! The boat ride over is magnificent and the views are amazing. Once arriving to Robben Island you feel its serenity and calmness. President Nelson Mandela prison cell #4664 is still spiritually alive! While in a jeep touring the island when we stopped to let bunnies hop by, penguins waddle by and Springbok leap by! Wow! The view of Cape Town in the distance is beautiful. Lots of history here and you feel and see it in abundance.

It's only ok. My opinion of it was a little disappointed with it all. I expected it to be more interesting. It really only housed political leaders and albeit that it housed Nelson Mandela, not much was said about him. We were quickly rushed through the tour as some stragglers had to use the restrooms. Long queue meant the rest of us waiting and the bus. I wished we were able to walk around some of the sites that were shown. And the best part was the view of table mountain. So word of advice. Use restroom before boarding and bring snacks as there isn't anywhere to buy on the island except chips, coffee and water. And on the way back try to catch the princess... The pirate ship is too slow. I guess it's an experience but I learned more from other museums

A must see while in Cape Town. This was a great tour while in Cape Town. I found the ride over very relaxing. On the way back we were followed by a pod of whales. One of them gave us our best whale tail sighting on the trip. While on the island I found the history of the island very interesting. The tour of the prison was very well done. Having an ex-prisoner as the guide added to the emotion of the tour. Our bus driver was very kind and had a few funnies along the way.

Robben Island. we read the reviews and pleasantly surprised to find it is was much better - may be we set our expectations lower. Pre-booking is better as these tours can be sold out - also we took the tour on Dec25 and the tours after 11AM were cancelled. The bus commentary was good - the guide for the walkthrough was an person who has been in Robben Island and commentary is very informative and interesting

Terrible end to what would have been a great excursion. I'd like to start off by saying that I would've rated our experience on Robben Island as "very good" had it not been for the way things turned out. The tour was interesting and informative, and an important part of South African history that is very imporant to be preserved.We took the 3pm tour to Robben Island from Nelson Mandela Gateway. We were told that the ferry would return to collect us at 6pm after our tour was finished. By 5:50pm we were waiting on the pier with around 80 other passengers but no boat arrived. Eventually a boat arrived at around 6:30 however it was not the same boat which brought us across and therefore did not have capacity to take all the tourists remaining. The Robben Island tour staff were not helpful at all, could not offer any specific information as to whether or not another boat was coming and left their clients waiting in the freezing cold and dark. Eventually at 7:15pm a novelty pirate ship arrived (the Jolly Roger) and they transported us back to Cape Town. We only arrived on the mainland at 8:40pm. The crew were not expecting any tourists (they told us the only reason they had come was to drop off 2 Robben Island staff members) which means the Robben Island tourism department had no idea what was happening and took no responsibility for the safety of their customers. It took over an hour to get back to the mainland due to the fact that they boat was not built to travel at speed in those weather conditions, which is not the fault of the Jolly Roger or their crew, but rather of Robben Island management who did not make sufficient arrangements for their clients. I understand that your main ferry was in for a service, but surely an organisation which transports so many tourists every day should have more than one boat? And if they are going to rely on private charters, surely they should be reliable?It was a horrible experience, completely overshadowing the experience of visiting such an historical landmark of our country. This organisation represents not only Cape Town tourism but the whole of South Africa and it is an absolute shame that it is managed so poorly.

If you have the time, why miss it!. Having read many reviews our expectations for this tour were set fairly low, so perhaps that's why we felt it was very good. We thoroughly enjoyed the bus commentator, and learned many things about the history of the country and this site. The former prisoner was also most interesting. If there is any criticism it maybe the size of the groups....probably a little large for our liking, particularly for the cell tour etc. If anyone I knew was going to Cape Town I would definitely suggest a visit here.

Better than alcatraz. The cost was 230 rand per person. Pre booking is advisable. We were told to be at the departure point 30min before but I personally did not see the need as everything is on African time. The boat trip takes about 20-30 minutes and there are refreshments available for purchase. The tour is very good and very informative but you do sit on a bus for 40 min so take a bottle of water if it is warm.My one and only complaint is there is not enough time to have a wander around as it is literally boat, bus tour, inmate tour, boat, another hour would be perfect. The issue being you cannot take additional time as you are booked on a return ferry that is just 3 hours from departure. I would recommend this tour

Moving experience. This was very a worthwhile excursion. the island has a lot of history including a leper's colony. As other reviewer's note, the guides are former political prisoners and they can give you tremendous insight and are more than willing to answer your questions - like what did prisoners sleep on before they brought in bunks, how did they get news from the outside world, etc.We take our political freedoms for granted. this is a sobering remainders that we should not and that those that stand up to tyranny are brave indeed.

Modern history with an outstanding view. Everyone knows the history of Robben Island and it's association with Nelson Mandela (Madiba); irrespective it is a must for tourists to Cape Town to take the (usually choppy) ocean trip. The prison guides are usually past inmates with personal memories that make the telling of their story so much more interesting and certainly adds atmosphere to this important reminder of the miracle that is South Africa today - politically and economically. In addition to all of this, one of the best views you will ever see anywhere in the world - the view back to Cape Town with Table Mountain, Devils Peak, Lions Head, Signal hill, and many of the twelve apostles.

Gut Checking Must Visit. I must say this was one of those things I was told I should do when in Cape Town, but wasn't sure I would. However, after visiting this site it was the most memorable thing of the whole trip. To see island, lime quarry, and Nelson Mandela's cell was like seeing and understanding history for the first time. A former prisoner with Nelson gave the tour and had great insight of events. I highly recommend this attraction in Cape Town, South Africa. Also, bring sun block if you are there in their summer, you will need it.

Must do!. We've always wanted to do it and finally bit the bullet - what an amazing experience it was. It is just all over very quickly although the choppy ferry trip felt like ages for my seasick hubby. So glad we can cross it off our list - if you haven't been you simply must go!!

terrible service. We booked a trip to the island, when we arrived we were informed that the ferry service is not running due to 'technical problems' in other words the boat was broken.I believe that Robben Island is one of the most popular tourist attractions in the world. How can they run this on one ferry boat alone? And I was informed by many locals that the boat is out of action more often than in. Surely this is not acceptable in International standards? And to top it off I am yet to receive a refund for the tickets I purchased. Shamefull.

Must visit.. Our two guides really made the trip. One was a younger man with outstanding knowledge of the island and its history, the other guide was an ex political prisoner of the island and his insight and knowledge was unique.

Propaganda Island. I have visited several times. The most recent included the guide stopping the bus and giving us a heated lecture about Robert Sobukwe. Viewing the island and learning more of its very varied interest seemed a low priority. Hopefully, the standard of guide lecture has improved since then.

A must do for anyone remotely interested in history/culture!. If you do one thing in Cape Town it should be to visit Robben Island as it is so strongly linked to the history and identity of South Africa today. You must book in advance ( you can book directly with them online) and the queues are long, however they do move fairly quickly. The bus tours round the whole island, but there are clearly quite large parts you cannot go to, or walk on. The groups can be large but this is to be expected for such a important site, and I feel you can ask questions of the guides, some of whom are ex prisoners should you so wish. Numbers of visitors will vary according to the time of year, and when we went, February, they were not too large. The guides were interesting and knowledgeable but it would be nice to be able to spend the length of time of your choice at each stop off ( so should be hop on/hop off not scheduled times).There are information boards which are also helpful but at busy times you may find it difficult to get to them straight away.

Must see if you are in Cape Town. A great and very important piece of history for South Africans. You need to make reservations beforehand to get to see Robben Island, that too, weather permitting. We had a tour company buy the tickets for us but realized afterward that we should have bought it directly on the website ourselves. You need to be at V&A Waterfront at least 45 mins before your boat ride. You need to queue up and wait in line. It is very orderly planned and works like clock work. You leave the V&A and 30 mins later you are at Robben Island. As you disembark there are busses waiting for you to start the tour. The tour lasts about 3 hours covering the entire island. They show you how the prison was built, the guards residences, Robert Sobukwe cell, the limestone mines, Nelson Mandela, Ahmed Kathrada, Steve Biko and the other prisoners cells, the church, the karaamat etc. it was really interesting and for South Africans on tour it meant so much more. After visiting the cells we took a leisurely walk back to the boat waiting to take us back to Cape Town. It takes just over 4 hours to complete the tour.

Must see historical site where you are turned into cattle being herded between poorly presented sites. Before I start, I am not reviewing the significance of this site; there is no doubting that if you visit Cape Town you really must see the prison where the freedom fighters and now leaders of South Africa were imprisoned for a huge proportion of their lives. What I am reviewing is how this important site is displayed and explained to tourists. There is no choice here - you must do the one and only tour on offer. The tour groups are simply too big, there is scant information to read or look at other than the tour-guides' commentary, and you have zero free time on the island expect at a cafe where you are stuck for 20 minutes. You are herded like cattle onto a large ferry with 100s of other tourists. If you get sick-sea like me, definitely take heavily duty medication beforehand because this is a rolling ride and unless you arrive about 1 hour early for the tour, you will be on the underneath level without thought to people like us. You are shown a short video on the way over which is one of the most informative parts of the tour - a more updated TV monitor would have been appreciated. You are then herded into groups and onto a series of large buses. You wait and wait for your buses' turn to leave then are shown three sites from the bus - there is no chance to get out to look around except at a cafe where you are given too much time!!! Having an ex-inmate as the tour-guide for the actual prison is a good idea but they clearly gave him a standard talk and allowed the guy one sentence to speak of his own experiences. What a waste! Also, with the large size of the groups shown around, you can easily miss large chunks of what he says, you struggle to see the two or three faded photos that are provided, and you have to cue to take pictures of the key sites.Ways to improve this tour:- Do away with the structured tours altogether and instead allow people to visit the island at their own pace. Run the ferry constantly back and forth, and offer a hop-on-hop-off bus around the island that runs regularly.- Offer tours of the prison in small groups.- Offer tours by both ex-inmates (whose English was mostly understandable for me, but I noticed would challenging for many others to understand) and guides for whom English is their first language.- Add many, many information boards, photos and other exhibitions to explain the key sites - there were a total of two very faded picture boards with no written captions even. If for preservation reasons these cannot be added to the island, provide written material, a map and even audio commentary of the sites.- If possible expand the number of sites available - there is currently not that much to see.

If in Cape Town, you have to go, but don't expect much. It is a shame that the tour to Robben Island is not as good as it could be, because Robben Island is an important part of the history of South Africa. If you are in Cape Town, you should go, but go with low expectations. I suspect part of the limited nature of the tour is the fact that the island is heritage listed - you are not free to wander around and explore, but confined to a bus/coach for most of the tour, and there is no infrastructure for tourists except a kiosk the bus travels to. The guides on the coach do their best, but there is only so much information that can be conveyed using the PA system and asking people to look out the left or right side windows. The second part of the tour is a guided tour around the Robben Island prison itself. This is much better, and often conducted by a former political prisoner, but there are no plaques and no information boards (a few faded photos are on boards, but nothing with history or explanations - unlike the waiting room for the ferry ride to the island itself, which you don't spend time in unless you are at the head of the very long queue).

Historical site-a must see-that needs funding for maintenance and displays. The reviews for this are mixed-perhaps rightly so, but my husband and I are so glad we spent the 4 hours on this attraction. Our tickets were pre-purchased by Cape Grace and all we had to do was line up (get there EARLY if you are interested in sitting outside or having a view either front or back). I highly suggest getting tickets ahead of time. Some of the tour times sell out quickly. Some of the displays and rooms were closed in the Gateway Building. The informaton placards are a bit worn and you move so quickly to board the boat that you miss a lot and there is no way to see this when you return. Once arriving on the island you board a bus for a very structured tour. Our guide (a young woman who was smart, funny and interactive) gave us a good history and overview of the island-which on its own has a history for the poor and leprosy colonies that were housed there. You are captive on the bus until you get a short walk thru the actual prison where Mr. Mandela was held. At this point your narrative/tour is taken over by an ex-prisoner who gives you first hand anecdotes about the horrors of this place. It is a must see/experience because (from our US perspective) apertheid still exists in SA. Robben Island and political prisons is a relevant topic no matter what your background or experience. One plus for the length of the tour is that you get a great view of Cape Town from the water.

Must go. If you are part of the human race, I highly suggest making the pilgrimage to Robben Island. I found the whole process rather seemless, from buying affordable tickets to the ferry ride to the tour around the island. I thought it was incredible that some of the tour guides on part of our tour were former prisoners, and the other guides we had were extremely knowledgeable and passionate about what they were doing. One of the best parts of the tour was being able to ask questions of our guides and it seemed every tourist there had questions they needed to get off their chest. I think it was a cathartic and sobering experience for everyone who went. It was very hot the day I went but I'm sure there there are varying weather extremes. I would suggest bringing water. The gift shop had a lot of good books and other souvenirs.

If South African history is your sort of thing, but sadly the island surroundings and facilities are not well kept.. Firstly the staff behind the booths for tickets and the collection of tickets are not very friendly or understanding; I had a huge problem as my tickets were not there and not booked as I had booked them. I was told they not there and the tour I have booked is full although Robben Island had my booking and I had a piece of paper with my booking on and all my details etc. I was told they would try rectify the matter asap.While I was waiting, I overheard many tourists asking for tickets for the next available tour. The staff were not too friendly to many of the foreigners and did not explain as to how it all works, they should in fact explain to people that they could book online way in advance to prevent disappointment. They would just say no sold out.The site for anyone reading this is to book tickets way in advance is http://www.webtickets.co.za, on this site you can choose dates, times as well as what ferry you wish to take or another option is www.computicket.com.I suggest that you book well in advance as they fill up very fast to avoid been disappointed, also try see what the weather is doing for the day you want to go, we had some rain but they still went ahead with the ferry. Now back to the tourists, I felt bad as many were turned away without an explanation as to why and how they could prevent this happening again or giving options as where to go from there. Eventually a lady came and stated that I must wait for all passengers to board and they will see if there are any tickets left for that tour I was supposed to be on that i had booked for. I booked this 10 days in advance via the management of Robben Island. We waited and waited and we were shoved aside with the staff members.None the less the lady eventually gave us tickets and we boarded the ferry named Sikhululekile, as we were pretty much last to board so we had no choice of seats and had to sit separate on the lower deck. I went up a level and saw two available seats opposite each other. I called mum and we went up there. At least here we had a decent view and we could walk outside and take some photos. The view from the second deck was stunning and you did not have to contend with the wind like the higher deck above, but I went above anyway to see the surroundings. They play a video for your viewing on the history and a few other things but I opted to focus on the scenery and get some fresh air instead.After a bumpy 30-40 minute ferry trip, we docked by Robben Island, we got off and no one really tells you what to do or where to go, we followed everyone in lead and saw 4 buses a little way up, people were standing around and staff did not seem interested when I eventually asked what to do and we were told to get on the buses and to wait. The buses are very out dated and pretty old but it's a way of transport around the island.We had a friendly tour guide Ryas, he tried his best to make us feel welcome and make a few jokes along the way, since reading previous reviews, and I guess these jokes are the same but at least he is trying to lighten up the mood of all. We did the bus trip which was ok as Ryas talks fast about history and wildlife etc of the island, we had a 5-10 minutes break at the one shop that supposedly is managed by Christo Brand who was a prison guard who was one of several that were responsible for guarding Nelson Mandela.We then got back on the bus and the tour carried on, I noticed that the island is not very well kept, its worn and looking very old and run down. We eventually then were told we were heading now to the prison part of the tour and we would like the prisoners would do "the walk to freedom" as many as them had done when their time was up at Robben Island. We walked towards the prison and a Black gentleman was standing there who I later asked his name and was told by him it was Kgotso. We were shown into the prison and everyone was hustling looking for Mandela's Cell, Kgotso was nowhere to be seen. I eventually found him and asked where Mandela's cell was he smiled and said we will go to it shortly.We were taken into a courtyard and he spoke to us a bit and introduced himself to us. He then showed us Mandela's cell and everyone took their pictures and we were told to meet back in the courtyard. On the way back I grabbed Kgotso and chatted as we walked and I asked how long he had been a prisoner for here, he told me 6years. I asked him if he did not mind to tell me why, he replied he would later in the tour.We then went to Kgotso cell which was much larger and had 30 prisoners in it at one time. He told us his story and that he should have stayed in prison for 25 years but was released in 1991 when all prisoners were released and was asked to return as a tour guide.After Kgotso had told us his story he asked if there was any questions, there was one about Malema, and Kgotso stated Malema is dead, not physically but dead, I guess he meant politically. We then left and Kgotso was waiting outside and shook everyone's hand as we walked past, again my mum and I just followed people as where to head to next.We took some pictures outside the Maximum security prison and strolled back casually as we thought we had some time. We did not even get to go see the penguins as Ryas suggested we go do. We were in the shop and we were rushed and told we have 2 minutes remaining and told to hurry up the ferry is leaving soon, we opted to go to the toilet facilities before the ferry trip back, what a disaster, the toilets were in a disgusting state and looked as if they had not been cleaned for awhile so we decided to rather go at The V & A Victoria Wharf Market where we were going to have a very late lunch for the day as you do not have time to really eat and drink anything or to look around and do your own thing on the island, it's very rushed and I did not enjoy it.Maybe that's because I have been to Alcatraz in San Francisco and its very different tour from Robben Island - you use personal headphones in your own home language and you do the tour in your own time and listen to an inmate while telling you where to go and do, you also can leave on any ferry you wish. Here it felt more like a school tour and we had to listen to the teacher. It felt more like the staff had a task to do and it was a job and they did it to get through the day and their paycheck

Very informational with great sights. We did this tour on our first day in Capetown. This tour was very informational and well worth your money. The tour guides were great and were very knowledgeable. Our tour guide in Robben island prison was a real prisoner that spent 5 years in prison. This tour is highly recommended.

“A part of history which must never be forgotten”. Robben Island is etched in history as one of the most feared places from the Apartheid era of South Africa.I visited the Island not knowing what to expect. Having read some of the reviews on Trip Advisor made it all the more confusing.The Trip starts at the Nelson Mandela Gateway and Museum, which is at the jetty the Boats leave from. The History, the Relics and the Visual Displays in this building are both fascinating and frightening. They are also so interesting I returned to this centre twice more to fully explore and read everything on display. This part is free to visit without any need to take the trip to Robben Island.To the people who have commented about the Political content of this experience I have to say that it is not a theme park with Roller Coaster Rides and Splash Pools. The whole purpose of the tour and visit is about showing the world what ALL the people of South Africa were subjected to during the apartheid era, and showing without holding back any detail, the savagery of what man did to man.The Boat trip, if you travel on the older boats, you are travelling on the very boats used to transport Prisoners, though, you will have the benefit of seating and open air, you will not be shackled along with your fellow prisoners in the bowels of the Boat. The Sea can be rough and if you get seasick be under no illusion about the journey.... but at least try to imagine what it was like doing that trip shackled in the hold! Me I love the sea and thoroughly enjoyed the journey in both directions especially the sea life and the views of Cape Town and Table Mountain, things the prisoners would not have been able to even see.The bus tour of the Island I found very interesting and I tried to imagine how the prisoners must have felt, the hopelessness of their situation, no possibility of escape and surviving. The Quarry area where prisoners spent their days breaking rocks and the conditions they endured. It is easy to understand how many ex-prisoners now suffer serious Eyesight Problems and Chest/Lung Problems to this day. The dust and the blinding sun reflecting from the white rocks....easy but scary to imagine.The tour of the Prison Buildings and Cell areas, again very interesting and, very daunting. Never forget that this trip is about showing what people endured for years, in some cases lifetimes, to try to get a better life for their fellow man.It is good to note that many of the visitors to the Island are Parties of School Children. To allow these children to see and understand what their Fathers endured.... Yes it is so recent that it could be their Fathers and Grandfathers. It is a wise and courageous decision to show these children first hand what Apartheid was like.I urge you to visit if you can........... Theme Park? it is Not! Political? almost certainly, that's what Apartheid was! Uncomfortable? At times yes.... you are there for a short time, Nelson Mandela was there for 18 of his 27 years in Prison, many of the years on Robben Island spent in isolation!Visit this piece of living history, remember what went on here and the inhumanity of man to man.And if you have Children with you.... Take them.... We might just get a better world!Review resubmitted by contributor after editing a significant typo.

Just to have been there is enough!. I am not going to say this is the most riveting brilliant tour I went to while in South Africa.But to have visited the place where Nelson Mandela , an icon recognised all over the world, was enough for me.To hear about the brutality of the place, from an ex prisoner called Sipho Msomi , but also the imagination and ingenuity of the prisoners, who lets remember shaped the modern South Africa, and managed to survive what was thrown at them..Sipho, himself was a character, and it was hard to realise had actually spent time in this place himself. To be in Cape Town and not visit here would be criminal.

A must see in Cape Town. Very interesting visit. It is a plus that the still alive former prisioners do part of the tour. They are able to explain from first hand all their experiences. Unfortunately this will not last forever. TIP: if tickets are sold out wait until the last minute, normally they sell some reserved seats in the last moment or they even give them for free (as it happens to us).

Very disappointed. The tour of the Island was long and very boring, the guide on the bus tried to be entertaining and funny, but it fell very flat. The highlight was actually having a former prisoner as our guide. We were lucky other groups would not have had that advantage. It is very boring and needs to be shortened.

Reconsider this tour. This tour takes about four hours, or 240 minutes. You spend about 60 minutes waiting, 60 minutes on the ferry, 80 minutes stuck on a packed bus with a guy telling bad joke in between some history, and 40 minutes with a former inmate to see the cells and he is very interesting. You are better off to spend the money on Mandelas biography, A Long Walk to Freedom.

Fascinating!. A fascinating place to visit. To be given a tour by former inmates really adds to the experience and a unique perspective on events at the end of the 20th century. You may need to take anti-seasickness pills before setting out as the crossing of 45 minutes can be rough!

Made our visit all the more interesting..... Our visit to South Africa would not have been complete without a visit to Robben Island. Seeing Mandela's cell, the lime pit where he worked and the yard he exercised in for all those years in confinement was inspiring. How could this man have overcome bitterness and not sought vengeance against those who imprisoned him? Amazing!!Could parts be better? Probably yes- especially the bus ride at the beginning of the tour. But the time spent with a former Robben Island inmate who led our group and descrbied what it was like to be imprisoned there was one of the best things we did while in South Africa.Very Highly Recommended.

Great Experience, Must Visit!. When we arrived at The Nelson Mandela Gateway we waited to board the ferry - there was a modern looking one and an old one, and it was the old one we were taken too. I only mention this as my wife can get sick on rough seas and that's exactly what happened! Not a great start to the tour for my wife, considering we were on our honeymoon! I don't know a huge amount about boats or ferries but maybe the modern one would have given us a smoother ride to Robben Island, as it was quite choppy to say the least!Anyway, once we arrived (it took about 40 minutes) we got onto the bus for a 25 minute tour of the island which was interesting. Then we went to the main attraction, the prison where Nelson Mandela was held for so long. The tour guide was someone who was a prisoner at Robben Island and his insights were very interesting and informative, and definitely added to the experience.If you ever visit Cape Town it is definitely worth visiting!

Disappointing for such a important place in History. We were very disappointed in the tour guide for our bus. It was a lady who was rude, and hard to understand. She also was way too political in her message. The tour of the prison was done by a man who also was not easy to understand and too political for tourist. It is a place that could be so important to SA but is failing.

Interesting history but felt it was a bit lacking. A popular trip out, the boat trip across to the island takes about 30 mins and then you are split into two tours - a bus trip around the small island, and a tour of the prison with a former political prisoner. You do both.The latter is interesting, with most tourists very keen to see Nelson Mandela's cell. Our political prisoner never really gave any personal insight into his stay there, which was a lost opportunity.
Disappointing. Ferry! Trip cancelled. When we got there, commentary was poor, sometime difficult to follow and mainly political. Facilities poor

Don't have an accident on Robben Island!. Part way through my tour, I unfortunately fell down some steps. I was unable to walk. The medic was nowhere to be found, we tried the medical centre, the house the medic lives in, the beach. The cell phone was not being answered. The security man was very helpful, he did all he could, however I received no first aid at all, as a qualified first aider my self I knew ice was needed, this was not available. I am very surprised there was not anyone who knew simple first aid. Everyone tried their best but, without basic first aid it was a hopeless situation. I highly commend the very considerate young man who took me by wheelchair onto the boat, and pushed me all the way to the car park. Over 4 hours after the accident we stopped and bought ice. Consequently I am still wearing a splint and using crutches, and needing physiotherapy, which is expensive. Earlier intervention could have made the situation easier for me. My main point is should this have been a heart attack, or a wound that needed stitches, or a fall which the patient was unconscious, what would have happened ? I will have to return to complete my tour, I never did get to see Nelson Mandela's cell! It concerns me with so many tourists in and out of Robben Island every day this is a situation which needs addressing.

A must do. This is a must do when you visit South Africa. The seas are a bit rocky on the way out, what do you expect you are on your way over to a prison. It was great to have former prisoners and warden there guiding on the tour. Got to see Mandelas cell. Gives a great history.

One of the highlights of my SA vacation.. To me this was an experience of a lifetime.The trip to the Island is a little rough so be prepared. The crew is there for you. I wouldn't recommend this trip for those who are prone to sea sickness.The trip is hosted by former inmates and wardens who take questions. A lot can be learning about the history of SA and how amazing Nelson Mandella and the other inmates devoted to freedom are. As with most of the people in SA I am amazed at how forward looking everyone is and how very few hold grudgesYou see the cell Nelson Mandella spent many years of his life and get a real feel for the living conditions - well less the smell.

Disappointing,not enough time in the prison. We were so looking forward to this experience but left feeling very rushed and disappointed. The boat trip across to the island is quite spectacular but the time on the island is badly managed. Our principal reason for going was to understand what life was like in the prison but we spent most of the time travelling around the island on a coach! When we finally got to the prison our guide, a former prisoner, explained that the guides were all frustrated that they did not have enough time to explain everything and give a proper guided tour. Our guide was very knowledgeable and very fascinating giving us an idea of life in the prison when he was there. We were rushed around, a quick glimpse at Nelson Mandela's cell, the toilets and washroom and exercise yard and then we were left to walk back to the harbour. We were hurried along by staff who wanted us back on the boat so there was no time to look in the shop. As a museum it fails, as there is very little information or pictures about the past...in any areas with info you are rushed along and have no time to read or digest especially as you are with a large group of people all trying to have a look at the same time. The total time was about 4 hours.I really feel the management are keen to take your money but are not listening to their own staff and the visitors about how the experience could be considerably improved. Do not take the trip if you are not good on boats...the journey can be rough and quite a few people were sick.
wayyy tooo long. should be able to just explore the island and leave when you want. unfortunately some guides stretch it ON AND ON.

Could do MUCH better! Don't set your expectations too high.. This is meant to be one of the main tourist sights in SA however its not treated like this. On our visit we were put on an old whale watching boat which took 50mins to get there. We were then shoved on an old bus which was full to bursting and taken on a pretty un-informative tour of the village with the guide shouting our info not stopping in any decent location but at the village shop at the end to use the toilet. No chance to take any photos as on a bus. It was back to the prison where we were put in a long room and spoken to by a former inmate for an hour about his time in prison. Very interesting talk but had switched off by the end. It was out into the courtyard and a brief walk past Mandela's cell and out to the gift shop and boat home. Very little information about the actual prison given - facts etc. I was expecting much more of this place so dont be disapponted like we were!

Informative and enlightening trip. This trip MUST be pre booked as it fills up well in advance. We booked tickets from the UK and opted for the 9.00am trip. The total time is 4 hours. We went early to the dock as there is an interesting display showing the history of the island. When we arrived at Robben Island we had a coach tour of the island and shown all the various sights and a history of the inmates and the various sights are fully explained. We were taken around the prison by an ex political prisoner. He served his time with Nelson Mandela. We learnt so much from the trip to Robben Island. We were also lucky enough to meet a warden Cristo Brand. He was a warden to Nelson Mandela and is still a close friend.

Worth a visit. I enjoyed my trip to Robben island, but i do agree with other viewers that it felt a little rushed. We couldn't go and see the Penguins at the end as we were delayed on the way to the Island and ha to rush through some of the tour. It was a shame as we were really looking forward to exploring the island.Our Tour Guide was good and very knowledgable, it was really interesting to learn about the history of the island and also a sad reality at the same time.Ex Inmates also do a tour and a talk of the prisons and i must commend them for their bravery and returning to the very place where they were tortured. I really do think it is worth a visit, even just to see some wildlife and different types of birds that live on the island. However please be aware that it can be delayed and our whole tour from start to finish (including the boat trip) ended up lasting 6 hours.... and there is no signal on the island, so our friends waited 3 hours for us.

worth doing BUT set your expectations. As a guide in Africa i have taken 100's of pax on this trip and I feel that it is something that everyone SHOULD do to gain a historical, cultural and fundamental understanding of South Africa, but honestly despite saying this, don't expect too much from it. The group sizes are very big, the guides (ex prisoners) generally struggle with language and volume and at times it is very dull. BUT don't let any of this stop you from going, because it will give you the best understanding of the struggles of South Africa that you can possibly get outside of a township!!!!The boat trip out there can be VERY rough so make precautions for it and weather changes quickly. Amazing view of Cape Town at one stop and a good way to spend half a day if you are looking for culture instead of adrenaline. BOOK AHEAD OF TIME ONLINE to save getting all the way down to the V&A then having to wait 4 hours of come back another day

The history is my history. They are trying to sell the island to the world without loosing the intricacies. The fact that they are trying to use ex prisoners as guides who speak from their hearts and experiences make me connect to the reality of my own history.

Well worth a visit!. There are 4 crossings a day 9,11 1 and 3 and we didnt realise how busy it would be so it may be worth booking online beforehand. It costs just over 200 rand for an adult for 1/2 hour crossing on the boat and a guided coach tour, you also get time for a short visit round the prison to see Nelson Mandela's cell with an ex prisoner or guard. The sea crossing can be a bit rough but only lasts 30 minutes so is just about managable if you get sea-sick!

Don't Miss Robben Island!. I was here in early August, 2012. The boat ride from Cape Town to Robben Island was about a 30 minute ride. I was so glad that I had brought my gloves and hat as it was gray, cool and slightly misting outside.Once we got on the island, we were given a tour of the prison by an ex, freed political prisoner. He had an amazing story. He also showed us Nelson Mandelas prison cell. Just so amazing to be in the place where he was imprisoned for 18 years. Our guide said that he has forgiven his guards, but he can never forget. I also met the guard who was overseeing Mandela and he allowed me to take his photo, he gave me his email and also his website. Christo Brand is his name. He also had a photo album of pics of him and Mandela after he was freed that we're pretty amazing. I highly recommend visiting as it's obviously very historical and something not to be forgotten.

A waste of time and money. This could have been a powerful experience but unfortunately the trip was very prescriptive and the guide, the ex prisoner was extremely poor. There was no emotional attachment. It was a waste of time and money and I would definitely recommend that people do NOT take this trip.

See a little history. The ferry crossing was just the right length to not get bored and enjoy the view. Our tour guide was very amusing and informative. It was nice to see and get a feel of a part of history that led to some changes for the good.

A wonderful insight into life in prison on the Island. I booked this trip in advance and went by myself as my husband was doing a 7 hour hike up Table Mountain which I didn't fancy!I think it's best to book online beforehand but I only did this from our hotel so no real need to book weeks or months in advance.Everyone else appeared to have done the same and it means on arrival at the waterfront you can just join the queue.It's a big catamaran which holds a few hundred people and the journey to Robben Island takes about 40 mins. There is sandwiches and snacks and liquid refreshments on board as well as toilets.In the indoor deck there is a video showing all about Robben Island.As soon as you arrive on the island you are taken to buses and a 45 minute bus tour around the island commences with an excellent and informative tour guide. The bus stops at points of interest so you are able to take pictures.After the bus tour you are shown around the prison by an ex politcal prisoner who gives an informative account of prison life on the island. You are of course shown Nelson Mandella's cell and the courtyard where he used to hide and bury the manuscripts of the book he was writing.It's an amazing insight into what prison life must have been like here.At the end of the tour there is free time to browse in the shop or take the short walk to where the penguins are. The boat leaves at about 12.15 for the sail back to the V&A waterfront, arriving back in time for 1.00om.A wonderful way to spend a morning and soak up a bit of history.

A must visit for every traveller to Cape Town!. Booked this trip online before arriving in Cape town and thought at first it was a wee bit expensive at R230 per person. However it had been recommended by my wife who had previously visited the island on a previous business trip.I was not disappointed. We boarded the catamaran which holds 300 passengers and set off for our 25 minute journey to the island. After disembarking we had a 45 minute bus ride with excellent commentary from an extremely knowledgeable young man. We then took a tour of the infamous Maximum Security Prison guided by an ex-political prisoner, whose recollections of his time spent there gave us an in depth picture of what the conditions the prisoners must have endured during their time there. A visit to Nelson Mandela's cell was also an interesting insight to those times during the apartheid era.A word of warning, the catamaran is a fast vessel and if you are prone to sea sickness, always try to sit on the upper deck. As an ex sailor I know this is always the remedy to avoid it.

If the wind is not blowing, a great 1/2 day tour. My wife and I had booked onto the 09:00 sunday morning tour. we left from the V&A waterfront and the sea crossing took about 35 minutes and had great views back to Cape Town - and especially the football stadium! We were luck as the seas were quite calm and the boat looked quite acceptable to use with an upper deck for around 30 people or so, and seating for another 90 or so below.As you land at Robben Island you see penguins, seals and lots of birds. Then board buses to start the tour (the seats were quite small and squashed - my wife is quite small and even she said so!). The tour guide was informative, friendly and gave some good background on the struggles. The thing I liked was it was not over-promoted as a Neslon Mandela prison or visit. He was mentioned - and highlighted at the end - but put in context as one of many and of course it was a prison and lepreacy colony inthe 1800's so well before the apartheid struggles and political prisoners from the 1960's onwards.Inside the prison itself an actual inmate (from around 1989) conducted the tour and that was quite humbling. It was not a "Disney" polished presentation but that made it all the better - it is a fine line between imparting\ sharing history and putting ex prisoners "on show" and i think they did it very well. The balance was probably right on that front.Overall I think over time they can do so much more though with the tour to make it event better. More information\ displays on all the activities that have occured on the island.
