Having mentioned "Disney" you could just imagine how much better as an educational experience they would make of it - if probably a bit Over The Top as well but maybe a better balance has to be done.Our visit finished at 12:15 as we departed back to the V&A Waterfront for 1.00pm.We would put this as a top 2 or 3 experience and were so glad that we made the effort to go to Robben Island and now we are back in the UK after our holiday, it has made my wife and I dig out the Nelson Mandela autobiography again to re-read and put our real experience back into a new context.We would recommend you go - but book online in advance!

An informative, moving tour.. You will learn of life at Robben Island during Apartheid from an inmate, who with Nelson Mandela and many others, was imprisoned here. This prison was a tragic consequence of a regime that denied basic human rights to many South Africans.

To see. a must see place to understand the history of Nelson Mandela imprisonment as well the consequences after his transfer; now nearly deserted the island is nevertheless interesting to visit (by buses) ; even if it rains like in our case; stick with the guides- they are ex-cons and they will tell you a lot on their situation on the island.
A must see!. Chances of the ferry running, and a reasonably smooth crossing are iffy at best, but if you do get the opportunity to go, TAKE IT! A revealing piece of SA's history.

Disappointing. This could be great but.......Watch out for the sea crossing which can be very rough. A lot of people were sick but there had been no warnings before boarding so one could prepareThe boats are poorly maintained and would not be allowed to be used in the UK. The rows of seats are manually bolted to the floor and came away meaning a row of 3 heavy seats fell back and onto an elderly lady hurting her leg. If it had been a child sat there it could have been fatalThe island has a lot of discarded litter which spoils the feelYou get herded onto a very old bus for part of the tour. If you are left with an inside seat you can't see much at all. We couldn't hear the guide very well because of a faulty intercom

A waste of time and money. Robben Island is a waste of time and money: poor logistics, mediocre presenters and a lack of entertainment value detracts from what could be a powerful experience. Our departing ferry was late (with no explanation given), our presenters rambled off the story in a "let's get this over and done with so that I can carry on with my life" manner, and our tour had to be cut short so that we could catch our ferry back. It is a great pity that someone with some imagination has not stepped in to turn this into the meaningful experience it should be.

A must do in Cape Town. The Robben Island tour is a must do while in Cape Town. It really gives you a fascinating look into a part of South Africa's history. The fact that we wee given a tour by a former inmate was all the more special and we found his stories captivating. If you can ignore and get over all the other annoying tourists you will have a very special trip.

Good, but could be better!. Boat was an hour late & very full, on arrival on island loaded onto an old bus that stopped every few minutes while guide explained particular building etc, this was a bit tedious as I felt we could carry on moving during the talk. The best part of the trip was entering the prison but would have been really good if we could have access to all areas including the kitchen & eating area, the ex-prisoner was very interesting & he was happy for anyone to ask him any questions they wanted, after his tour it was back to the boat. So overall worth seeing but some of it was rather tedious with too much stopping & starting on the bus, guide was nice but we did struggle to understand all she was saying, oh & the only shop on site ran out of water for sale! Would I go back? No, but glad I did experience it.

Fascinating. The boat to the island leaves from V&A Waterfront daily at 9am, 11am, and 1pm . It is recommended to book well in advance as the tour doesn't operate if the sea is choppy and will be postponed until the weather is better. The boat trip takes 30 minutes and upon arrival all visitors are put onto buses which transport them around the island, stopping at important locations for photo opportunities such as Mandela's cell and the limestone quarry which was responsible for ruining his eyesight.The information given by the tour guides is fascinating and the fact that an ex-prisoner retells his experiences of his time in the prison makes it all the more credible and real. I would recommend reading Mandela's book, "Long Road to Freedom" before visiting, as one can then understand the austerity of the island and the harsh conditions encountered by prisoners. I think they may have deliberately left the island the way it was during the apartheid years, rather than develop it into a full-blown tourist attraction such as Alcatraz in the US. Everything one sees on the island falls into place and is more meaningful once the book has been read about the struggle. Although there is a souvenir shop there is little time to explore it as visitors need to be back at the boat at a certain time for the trip back to Cape Town. The trip on the way back can get rough so if you get sea-sick you may need to take a sea-sickness tablet beforehand. The boat hands opened to doors to the cabin but it wasn't enough to stop some people from getting sick. Also it can get windy and chilly both on the boat and on the island, so take a warm sweater.

A thrilling experience. As i am South African and making my first trip to this island my feeling was that political prisioners from this island overthrew the previous rulers of South Africa and the we went from a apartheid rule to full democracy. It was Mr. Nelson Mandela who was banished for life and was released after 27 years to become the first president in the new democracy .Our tour guide Patrick Matanjana, spent 20 years behind bars on the island ,his insight to the island was very descriptive as his prison cell was NO 1 and Nelsons cell was NO 5.The island was a leper colony thereafter was used for political prisioners .The Moturu Kramat, a sacred site for Muslim pilgrimage on Robben Island, was built in 1969 to commemorate Sayed Abdurahman Moturu, the Prince of Madura. Moturu, one of Cape Town's first imams, who was exiled to the island in the mid-1740s and died there in 1754.I really enjoyed this tour .

Robben Island. This trip is really worthwhile, assuming the weather is OK for the boat trip. The boats depart from near the V&A Waterfront. There is a small museum there, but this was closed when we visited. Once on the island, there is a coach tour around the main sights, including the lime quarry, lighthouse and the house where Robert Sobukwe was detained; but you are unable to get out of the bus. In the prison itself there are guided tours conducted by ex-prisoners, which is absolotely fascinating to hear their stories.There is a really good bookshop near the jetty where you get the boat back to Cape Town, where you can buy souvenirs, and also a decent selection of books about the struggle.All in all a moving and worthwhile experience, and a fabulous view of Cape Town across the bay. Highly recommended.

Nice but too short. An impressive excursion explaining the history of the island and Nelson Mandela's emprisonment. You are only allowed to stay on the island for two hours, which is way too short to properly see the expositions. The tourguide rushes you too much along the busride over the island. Still very much worth the visit though.

Robben Island and Museum - Commorants Are Us. -Although listed as a must see for Cape Town, we now believe that the Robben Island tour is more of an emotional journey, than a physical one.-If you are looking for a sense of what happened in SA during Apartheid, this is a part of it, but there is really not a lot on the island except abandoned concrete buildings, a couple tourist shops, a quick bus around the island, and some commentary by ex-prisoners.-We are not saying that the story and the history should be forgotten, but to be very honest, we did not bring away a lot of empathy or emotional attachment to the events, from this visit. It was barren, with the exception of a few hundred commorants lining the harbor/dock entrance....you did not have to see them to know they were they...it was in the air...-We would not suggest this as a family/young children type of attraction.-We actually learned more and appreciated more, talking to people in the outdoor cafe in the Company's Garden, and listening to their stories about Cape Town, their beloved South Africa, and its incredible history.-We are saying this attraction is not a bad thing, or a good thing.....it is just an "is" thing...it exists..-Mahalo

Well run and fascinating. A must if you are staying in Cape Town . At busy times you need to book in advance and the embarkation point is not well signposted so check before you go. The ferry left bang on time the tour was well organised and fascinating especially the ex- prisoner's description of life as an inmate . Worth every penny.

A Sad Place in the Midst of Beauty. Thousands of South Africans and foreign visitors visit this haunting island every year and with good reason. It is an important historical artifact, for South Africans and for mankind. It is worth the wait for tickets, the boat rides and sparse facilities. Guides,some of whom are former inmates, will show you the harsh and cramped conditions that Nelson Mandela and his contemporaries were subjected to. You will also see Cape Town and Table Mountain from a magnificent vantage point. And if you are lucky, you might see African Penguins in their nesting sites. A lady who was personally connected to one of the inmates who died in the prison, sat and wept quietly across from me on the return boat ride. That is my most poignant memory of my visit to Robben Island.

Fascinating; book ahead. We were in Cape Town during the busy holiday season, and you could not get tickets for days. Book ahead, or at least look into it the minute you get to Cape Town. Keep in mind that from the time you get to the building to check in, wait for the ferry, take the ferry over, do the tour, and take the ferry back - it is about 4 hours. You cannot leave early - so plan accordingly.Fascinating to have as a guide one of the prisoners from the late 1980's. Wonderful views of the city across the water. This is truly a very interesting experience - just don't miss it by not booking ahead.

Disappointment!. The journey over to Robben Island was very pleasant and lasted around 30 mins but once there it was a disappointment, everyone is rushed onto waiting buses to take the trip around the Island, first stop is to view the quarry in which Nelson Mandella was put to work, next stop the bungalow which housed Leon Stein, we were allowed in there and it showed some of his letters, books etc, next to that were dog kennels, back on the bus to the " point" a 15 min stop for refreshments, toilet etc, back on bus to a large room where an ex prisioner told us about the prison, the people who were kept there and after lecturing for nearly half an hour and people getting anxious as we had to be back to the boat in 10 mins we were shown the cell where Nelson Mandella was supposed to have been held, there was nothing to say it was his cell, it could have housed anyone, we had to file past, out and run down to the harbour for the departing boat back to main land, leaving very little time to visit the toilet ( men shouting come on hurry up back on the boat) and no time at all to visit the gift shop.Definately would not reccomend this trip, waste of time and money, can find out more at the Robben Island Museum at V & A waterfront.

Living History. Advanced booking is essential as the numbers visiting the island/Museum are restricted. The whole trip takes 3 hours including the boat rides there and back.If you are at the front of the queue for your assigned trip then you will have a chance of sitting on the exposed top deck of he boat - a bit windy.The boats are very comfortable and have adequate seating for all passengers. Access to the outside decks is permitted.The tour starts with a 45 minute coach ride around the Island - the guides are very knowledgeable and are ready to answer any questions. There are stops for photo sessions and all passengers are eventually delivered to the prison where an ex-prisoner will guide you through the actual premises and relate the history of the penal colony during the days of apartheid. The actual time spent in the prison is quite brief as the tours are on tight time schedules to coincide with the boat departures. This is our second visit to the island and there dose seem to be a need to shorten the coach tour in order to provide some more time in the prison in the company of the ex-prisoner. The prison cell occupied by Nelson Mandela is viewed from the adjacent corridor only but other exhibits are fascinating.

Robben Island Worth The Time!. My teenage years were in the 60's. I'm a teacher and have been an avid follower of current events for decades. Thus, deciding to visit Robben Island was an easy choice for me. All aspects of my experience with Robben Island were run professionally and on time. I had the good fortune to find the book Young Mandela by David James Smith in the Amsterdam airport, thus giving me a great refresher on the events leading to Nelson Mandela's imprisonment. The most poignant moments came when our group was lead around by a former prisoner. His remarks as we walked were very memorable. This is a very open look at a very difficult time in South Africa's history. Credit should be given to the willingness to be open about this part of the history of apartheid. This should not be missed.

Important part of South African history. After a short ferry ride from the Cape Town waterfront, we arrived at Robben Island where we boarded buses and were driven around the island. We were told to sit at the front of the bus because they are not air conditioned and they become very hot. The various sights were pointed out by the guide. When we reached the jail, we left the bus. We were given a tour by a former political prisoner. It was very interesting and moving. The bus took us back to the ferry. You cannot wander around the island on your own. I did not see public washrooms or concession stands, so come prepared. However, you can find these on the ferry.

A must do if you care about the history. A must do trip if you care about the history of modern South Africa. A pleasant 45 min boat journey followed by a coach tour with a very informative guide then a tour around the cells by a former inmate. All very sobering and a reminder of what man is capable of doing to his fellow man.

worth doing but it's hard work. It's a bit of an expedition to do the Robben Island trip and it's demanding if it's a hot day. The bus tour of the island is over long and is crowded (every seat is filled) and is hot and sweaty in the heat. There are no facilities on the ferry (again it's full to capacity). There's a fair amount of queueing and there's no free time before the ferry is ready to leave again. It's still worth it though for the prison tour, led by ex-inmates.

Neglected World Heritage Site. This was our 5th visit, our previous visits had always been memorable! Sadly not this time. Management were nowhere to be seen when there were insufficient coaches to take all the people around the island, we waited 20 minutes whilst a coach driver did his best to remedy the situation! The island tour has been severely cut back, our guide new her stuff however her delivery was difficult for English speakers, I felt sorry for the foreigners, her delivery improved when telling us to TIP!The lack of Management was obvious as some staff lazed about near the harbour when maintenance was sadly lacking on paths, stairs and toilet facilities. Vast areas needed weeding as the vegetation appeared to be taking over in much of the facility. The limestone quarry is now restricted to the visitor, on my earlier visits this was a sobering area where you could reflect on the hardship of the inmates, now it scruffy with pine weeds growing on the old road.The high point was going around the prison with Mr Sparks, once again he gave a passionate description of life and hardship mixed with a little humour,what a pity the Management haven't the same commitment and passion!My advice is if you want to see this truly historic site which is so important in the formation of a Democratic South Africa, visit it soon as on my experiance it won't be worth seeing, this is despite considerably higher visitor numbers, I wonder where all the extra revenue is being spent, it certainly isn't on the Facility!

Good but.... Robben Island was the only reason I even came to South Africa, so I had high hopes. I scored tickets hours before on the day I wanted to go, which I am told is unheard of normally. While you are waiting for your boat to leave, you can take the opportunity to walk around the V&A waterfront. During the boat ride, if you get stuck below deck (try to get in the front early enough to get above deck), there is a educational video about the island and its history played on screen. Once at the island, chaos ensues to get everyone on the buses waiting to take you on tour of the island. During the bus ride, you get commentary from a guide and stop and different locations on the island, including a bathroom and snack break, before you are returned to the prison area for your tour of it with a former political prisoner, where they so you around the prison and give you its history including its occupants, the most famous one being Mandela, of course. The whole thing felt rushed, so it was hard to process everything and I did not like everyone asking for tips. It cheapened the experience for me. I would have loved to have some along time to explore the island and the prison area more, but after the prison tour we were rushed off to the boat that was about to leave us. I'm still glad I went, but sad that I didn't have a better experience. Also, the ticket office charged my credit card twice, and I am still trying to get them to correct their mistake.

Robben Island Visit-Jan 2013-very sobering.. This was a very sobering but interesting visit for me, my mother and dad, and carer. It is very hilly, and not very wheelchair friendly, as some of the entrances in the prison are very narrow, and there are a few steps around.However, we went from Cape Town to Robben island on the scooter and wheelchair. The ferry staff were very helpful getting the scooter on and off the ferry, One has to book the tickets in advance with a credit card- take your credit card to the ticket office on the day you go to Robben Island,so that they can check the numbers. We forgot to do this, and had to pay full price again, as they wanted to see the Credit Card for security of payment reasons. We later got the money paid back into our Credit Card Account.An ex prisoner took as round the prison (inside and out). We saw Nelson Mandela's cell, the bathrooms, the football pitch, the quarry, and the offices. He also explained about the methods of education used and codes used between prisoners, He also explained how some prisoners were treated worse than others (political categories of prisoner) and showed us the diet allowances. He also told us how some prisoners went blind quarrying lime in the baking hot sun with no eye protection. he pointed out that the prison was like a university, because nearly all prisoners were extremely well-educated, including Nelson Mandela, The cells themselves consisted of one blanket on the floor, a drum for a toilet, bars on the doors, no windows, and very little room to move! I am now trying to get Nelson Mandela's autobiography as a result of this!We were also told how the prison finally became a tourist attraction in the late nineties. I do not fully understand how ex prisoners are brave enough to take tourists round the areas where they were once imprisoned. Food for thought!Gregory Chapman

Not very historical & cultural. We really wanted to hear something about the history of south africa, especially cape town and about Nelson Mandela and what he provoked.Sadly we are now not wiser than before. The first thing is, that the guide in the prison had a very special voice, like smoky and croaky. So it was very difficult for us to understand what he said. But the things he told weren't very historic. It was more about the life itself in the prison. Maybe because he was also a prisoner. The only thing I know now, is that Mandela had a number, like every prisoner there. And that the prisoners slept on the floor on mats and later in beds.. Wasn't what i expected :/

South African history. we have visited Cape Town many times but never managed to go to Robben Island. But... we did this time. After having heard all the stories about the island and its prisoners, as well as about the people who are living there (we didn't know that at all!) we were very impressed. The tour was organized and guided very well. it is a "MUST" for every visitor to go to Robben Island. A shame for us we did not do this before.

Historical insight. This is a must-do for anyone visiting Cape Town. Being guided round by an ex-prisoner who spent years there in captivity is a truly humbling experience and brings you face to face with what man can inflict on his fellow man. We gained some small insight into what it was like and some measure of the courage required by those held there. It's not a fun day out (and it's not meant to be) but it should make you think and even on holiday that's no bad thing.
Humbling experience. Incredibly worthwhile, a bit of a trip but well worth. The whole trip took about 4 hours with travel but this is a must if you visit Cape Town, it truly is a humbling experience.

An insight into South African history and a chance to meet a prisoner. This was our second visit to Robben Island with our family. My daughter is now studying criminology and really wanted to visit the island and hear the history about it, firsthand. The trip was as humbling the second time as it was the first. Sadly, there are fewer old prisoners guides but our guide was fascinating and told his story with great humility. The crossing was flat and very sunny, so a perfect time to visit. The coach tour was very hot but included comfort stops. Excellent facilities for wheelchair visitors.A must for anyone interested in the terrible recent history of South Africa.

Amazing visit, terrible staff in ticket office. Robben Island was strongly recommended to me as a 'must visit' in Cape Town, which is certainly the case. The museum itself is fascinating and the added extra of having an ex-prisoner as a tour guide makes for a very touching tour. The staff on the island itself were all excellent; polite, knowledgable and willing to help. The staff in the office in Cape Town, however, leave a lot to be desired.We were booked onto an 11am tour and arrived at 10.30, as instructed on our ticket. At 11:10 we were informed the tour was delayed by 20 minutes and we would be boarding shortly. At 11:50 we had received no further announcements and the staff simply told us to 'keep waiting'. At 12 o'clock we were told the tour had been cancelled and to go to the ticket office for a refund. This led to around 200 people queueing to speak to 4 people who were demanding either a passport or driving licence to be able to refund, despite there being no mention of this on the tickets. Luckily, we were rebooked for the next tour at 1pm and told to turn up no later than 12.30, which we did. At 1pm we were still queueing and were informed the tour was running 20 minutes late. When I asked a member of staff about this I was told the previous tour had run late, causing a backlog. Once again no announcements were made and we finally boarded at 1.40pm.

Very Informative. One of kind experience, that was well worth it. It was great to have someone who was a prt oif the history of Robben Island give us a tour of the prison, and it was a first han account of what really happened there. It is a beautiful island, and it would have been nice to have more time to just walk around and take it all in. Book in advance as tickets sell out very quickly.

It Could all happen again. Be sure to book via Robben Island Museaum - the other trips don't land on the Island. It's an experience like no other. First hand accounts of cruelty, deprivation and political lies that are unbelievable except that as always, there are two sides to the coin although that is no excuse for what happened at Robben Island.Be concerned - it could well happen again but this time the other way around!Don't miss the penguins at the end of the official tour - they put it all in perspective!

Must visit just for the latter history. Reasonably comfortable trip over. Get a bus to the prison grounds (not a long walk but suspect easier to manage the crowds & make it run a bit smoother) Our guide was informative but kept on repeating stuff which in parts was not needed. Maybe consider placing odd photos of which activists stayed where as would make it more interesting.Due to the almost rushing of the tour there is no real opportunity to have a sit down and have a drink and take in the importance of the place. But it is a must-I found the pile of stones very moving

Amazing piece of history. During my visit to South Africa I was also reading Nelson Mandela's autobiography, Long Walk to Freedom. To see where he was imprisoned, the quarry where he broke rocks, the area he gathered kelp, the different sections of the prison he mentions in the book and his cell was very moving. Our guide was a former political prisoner. The group was large and with his accent it was sometimes difficult to understand him, which was unfortunate. I would recommend it for anyone interested in social justice and children over ten with a similar interest.

A disappointing visit. This was one of the holiday sites that I had been really excited to visit, the history of the location and the importance in South African history meant it was top of our list. Unfortunately it was one of the few disappointing elements of our trip to South Africa. The guides on the tour were excellent, it was the lack of maintenance and organisation of the facilities.After ordering tickets for a individual timeslot several weeks before our visit, it was a little frustrating to still have to queue for over an hour to board the boat, it seemed the staff were selecting certain guests and take them to the front of the queue. When on the boat, it was over crowded. There were several people who were sick due to the driving of the ship and staff who may no effort to assist to make there trip more comfortable. Once we arrived, we were taken onto crowded buses. The guide took us to different areas of the Island, the two guides were past inmates and were very good guides, they provided an insight into the conditions they encountered on the island.At the end of the tour, when you had the opportunity to visit the rest rooms, there was a massive hole in the roof with rain coming in, the toilets were blocked and very dirty. Overall, I found the historical component very interesting, as a tourist I would have been happy to pay a few more dollars for the entry fee to have a better organised experience.

NOT WORTH A VISIT!. After 9 previous visits to Cape Town I gave in and visited Robben Island. What a disappointment. Everything has been stripped out so it is just an empty shell. There is no museum. A few display cabinets were showing mundane exhibits with an assortment of dead flies. The majority were empty - exhibits removed dead flies remaining! It seemed the guides were trying to portray an extreme and politically biased view of the existence of the prison, not perhaps a more reconciliationary view practiced by its past inhabitants. Unkempt and badly managed. The best aspect of the trip was the boat ride.
Amazing what a human can stand. To spend so many years in this place and to forgive your captures is incredible. You can only put Nelson Mandela on and even higher plinth .

ISLAND IN DISREPAIR, MANAGEMENT NON EXISTENT. The Boat was 30 minutes late Tourists waiting in queues with no explanation..Once arrived everybody was rushed off to the buses Couldn't help but notice on the pier the shop was closed. Little did I know it was only the beginning. Besides being whisked off like sheep in a paddock. I couldn't help but notice the extreme degradation of the flora and buildings lack of maintenance with weeds everywhere, rubble and litter in comparison the Island served no purpose other than to shock you how bad apartheid really was. The sad thing is in the New South Africa Robben Island was the only piece of history still living in post apartheid. Maybe the CEO instead of trying to elevate his political position by advertising onboard with a brief video on his success with the Island. He should actually catch the trip himself and visit the derelict Island he calls a Heritage sight. It should be shut-down! Again South Africa sends the wrong message to us as overseas visitors. Its petiful....Sur, Uk

Fascinating experience spoilt by poor guide. A visit to this iconic institution is of course a must during a visit to CT. Our bus tour was conducted by a very aggressive woman who spent most of the time interrogating and berating us for our lack of knowledge. At the end she informed us we could tip her if we wished - needless to stay noone on the bus accepted this invitation. Our second guide who had been a prisoner was much more sympathetic and indeed knowledgeable. Without going in to detail I felt that the whole experience could have been much better if a little more effort had gone into the presentation and planning of the tour. Indeed, at the end I felt as if I had been processed as quickly as possible through a factory line which needed sorting out and modernising.

Extraordinary visit. This was the highlight of our 9 year old sons trip to South Africa. You can hear, smell and sense the weight of the history in this place. The descriptions of life in the prison given by the ex prisoner guides are chilling. The most poignant place on the island is the quarry with the pile of stones at the entrance left by Nelson Mandela and the former prisoners. Yes, there are things which could be done better but so many museums around the world have been clinically cleaned up removing the sense of historic reality. The prison here looks like the prisoners have only just left and that makes it really memorable. The weather was rough and the boat journey was harrowing and although we were terrified it actually made the experience more real as we could try to imagine the utter fear of people going out there as inmates and as visitors. So glad we went. Don't think I could do the boat journey again!!!

Can feel a bit rushed.. The boat trip is great - try and get out on the top deck if there is space. The bus tour part of thr trip is a bit rushed and a bit lacking depth or feeling. The best part of it is getting of the bus for pictures of Table Mountain and Cape Town. The walking part of the tour around the Max Security prison with an ex-inmate is superb. Very interesting to hear from someone who was unfairly incarcerated there but returns voluntarily to tell people what happened there. Impressive guys! If your in CT then do this trip but get to the Max security bit asap for the real insight!

A missed opportunity but a fascinating piece of history. Robben Island really is an amazing place. Although its notoriety comes mainly from its role as a prison during apartheid it has also served as a leper colony and a ww2 base. However, the tours to Robben Island are abysmal. The ferry ride takes about 45 mins and as soon as you reach the island you are herded into a bus and driven around for an hour while a guide points out the major features. Following this there is a tour of the prison done by a prior inmate. The bus ride felt rushed, I would have preferred to have walked with an audio guide, there were several major sites that the guide didn't even mention. The prison tour was also incredibly rushed and the guide didn't really add anything which was disappointing. The place is also falling apart and it looks like any info graphics that were installed haven't been maintained or replaced since 1994. So much could be done to make it more interactive but as it is it's just empty cells and corridors. In some of the cells there are testimonies from the prisoners who inhabited them, but we didn't get enough time to read any. The island is also interesting from an ecological point of view with colonies of penguins and many pairs of oyster catchers, yet once again there was no time to look at these things and we were immediately herded back onto the ferry. There is no doubt that Robben Island represents an important piece of history, but the state of the tour was hugely disappointing. So much could be done to make it more exciting, interactive and informative- what a missed opportunity for this amazing site!

Good to see. Robben Island is not very big. You go there whith à Ferry. Make prereservations. When you are on the Island you go on à tour with à bus for 1 hour. Then you go on à walking tour to the prison and see the cellblock and the cell of Mandela. They don't tell much of the history. À missed opportunity.

Unforgettable tour to the Robben Island. Imagine an Island full of magic and histories, this is Robben Island. The guided tour with a prisoner is something I will never forget. The tour is a little bit fast, I was expecting a little more, but the view, the atmospheric, everything, is AMAZING.
If you go to Cape Town, Robben Island is a must-see place to visit.

What a disappointment!!!!!!!. As soon as we arrived, we were loaded onto a tour bus for a short drive which we could have easily walked. The tour of the prison was interesting but very brief and I had problems in understanding the guide. The whole island is really scruffy and neglected - it's a disgrace to call this a World Heritage Site. There are so many unemployed people in South Africa who you'd think would be delighted to have a job maintaining the place but it's just been left to fall part. The South African government should be ashamed of themselves.

A fascinating insight. An iconic site and a must-see if you have any interest in the history of this country. I agree with some other reviews that the island coach tour was a bit rapid. We had a calm-ish, if chilly, sea crossing and it was a shame that no-one mentioned that the boat Dias we went on was the actual boat used to take the prisoners over to the island; I only found out on a TV program after coming home.The prison tour was very interesting and we had a bit of time to explore some areas ourselves. Of course, seeing the tiny cell where Nelson Mandela spent 18 years was very humbling.Overall we found the tour very interesting, even though some of it could have been better.

Just OK. We are from the states and had watched a movie or 2 about apartheid to get a better feeling of the history of South Africa. We are big time History addicts. I have been to Alcatraz in San Fran and Dachau concentration camp in Germany. Robben Island pales in comparison. It is very simple and just OK and I would not do it with children or youth - too boring for them. It is nice to have a former inmate do the tour but he was unimpressive. He also stated that he felt that he had been left behind by the new governemnt and was resigned to do a job he hated because he could not find work anywhere else. It was very sad and you could tell he did not want to be there. We had a calm day on the ocean but I heard from others the ride can be very rough with many people getting sick. I would not pay the price to do this - read a book and save the $$.

So unfortunate.... People had warned us that the tour had gone downhill, and unfortunately that is true. We were ushered onto a bus right after arriving and got a 45 min bus tour where we just looked at buildings for a moment before moving on. Then the actual tour of the cells was a huge let down. It could be so great if they set up some cells to show you how the prisoners lived or even just showed more of the area. Our guide never even pointed out which cell was Nelson Mandela's. Plus the seas were a bit rough and the boat ride over was not pleasant. I don't think we would have missed out if we hadn't gone.

Humbling tour. The tour is very regimented but hugely informative. It starts with a ferry ride over to the Island where a video of the history is shown, on arrival you board a bus with a guide to give you a view of the island, our guide was knowledgeable and entertaining with lots of stories which give a great insight to life on the island. The highligh for me was the prison tour, which was led by an ex inmate, he was open and shared his personal story with the group. It was hugely humbling,It woud have been nice to have time to wander around the prison unguided but i did not feel this had a negative impact on my experience. Do put this tour on your must do list in South Africa

Bumpy Ride. If you suffer from motion sickness, please take something before the trip. Yikes! Very educational tour that doesn't take up the whole day, I would suggest the morining launch, but don't schedule it on your last day, winds can force cancellations.

A great tourist attraction - a "must see". Robben Island is an iconic tour, which all visitors should see. The tour is broken down into 2 sections, the first part being a bus tour of the important parts of the island and the second part a walking tour of the security jail, lead by an ex inmate. We immensely enjoyed the first part, ie the bus tour. Our guide was knowledgable and entertaining and we learned a lot. The second part was a little disappointing. Our guide seemed rushed and we felt that he was just going through the motions. he rushed through answers to the questions and didnt appear to be too interested. (I last did this tour 5 years ago and we then had a fantastic guide for this part of the tour, who even took us to the quarries and explained personal insights and feelings, which this guide did not do at all). However, it was still overall an enjoyable tour

Not the history I knew. Arrived to a stinky island where garbage was waiting as we jumped off the ferry. The stores were ridiculously expensive and the tour buses drove so fast, we could barely see or take any pictures. The prison tour was very dissappointing and one-sided with some racial comments made and not even about the apartheid regime, but against fellow freedom fighters.

Way better than anticipated. Very much enjoyed our trip to Robben Island! A well organized and highly informative afternoon. The ferry trip, bus tour and guided prison tour were all fantastic! Thank you to our guides, both on the bus and at the prison, for a highly personal and humbling tour! Would definitely recommend to fellow South Africans and foreign tourists alike as a must do when visiting Cape Town!

Interesting place, but with a “strict” tour route. Although the tour is 100% guided and you don’t really get freedom to walk around, it is still quite a good trip. You get a walking tour of the prison with someone who was a political prisoner there, then a bus tour around the island. The tour guides give an excellent history and I found it the most interesting account of the apartheid story. I think it would be an improvement if you were free to roam around a little though.

A real shame it is a rushed tour. I'm not sure why the non-prison part has to be conducted on a tour bus, the distances seem manageable by foot and this would give you far more time to take information and sights in. The maximum security prison tour is excellent, the insight of political prisoners is invaluable and what a credit to them that their experiences make this so worthwhile.Barely 2 hours on the island simply isn't enough considering the artefacts and real-stories that you WON'T have time to read on the guided tour. A must when visiting Cape Town, but hopefully the Robben Island authorities will give these reviews credence and allow people more time to really understand what happened here.

Dont miss the Boat! it 2 hours until the next one!. If you like you History you will love it here. I was a little bored.... However as soon as yoiu get off the boat there is a gift shop, if you look behind that shop you will find the most beautiful beach!

Worthwhile half day in Capetown. The experience of seeing Robben Island and hearing the story of Nelson Mandela's imprisonment there is a good and educational way to spend a half day while in Capetown. The tour is appropriate for all ages, and contrary to other reviews the boat ride was not rough at all. Highly recommend booking the tickets online in advance, they do sell out.
A Revelation of the shameful past. An eye opener of how low humanity can go. A very informative tour of Mandela's home of almost a quarter of a century.

MAKES YOU THINK?. Heard so much about Nelson Mandela, and his life locked up in prison, OR so i thought, my wife and i went to the island on a big catamaran, Fantastic trip over to the island.we all got onto buses with a guides to tell and show us about the general day to day life of the prisoners, were shown where Nelson Mandela ate and slept and worked. Very interesting, the living conditions for a prison in my own mind, were NOT to bad, and listening to a actual inmate , BORDOM was the main punishment; But , they did not, in my opinion, need to be there in the first place.When wondering around the cells and yards, it does MAKE YOU THINK of why they were there for so long. Not for very young children, they may get bored, AND the ex inmate we were with, wasn't that child understanding, he was a bit TO serious.

Real south african history. It was amazing to be guided through the prison that held Mandela for 18 years by someone that was actually a political prisoner ! The tour is very well organized and gives you a good impression of how terrible the system was.

Really Moving. If you come to Cape Town you have to visit Robben Island. We booked our tickets online in advance it saves time. I would also recommend you get the early morning crossing, it means the guides are fresher and you are back at the V&A by midday for lunch. The trip is well organised . There are two parts to it. When you get off the boat you are led to a coach. This takes you around the island and there is a guide on board who talks about various interesting facts. The second part is on foot through the prison itself. The guide here is an ex inmate. It was a very moving trip and it is unimaginable how Nelson Mandela spent 18 years in a tiny cell no bigger than an arms width. I felt very humbled being there and my husband and two teenage children all felt the same.
Historie. A prisoner showed us the sections at the prison. A really amazing person it was a pleasure to hear his story!
Rich in History, Rich in Life..... The tours was not rushed, however, we did not get to go to the Masjied. The souvenir shop was very cute.

Must visit!. This tour was very informative and educational. I learned so much while there. It is about a 30 minute ferry ride from the Capetown Waterfront. It can get very breezy so take a jacket. Once there you load on the tour bus and it takes you around while making stops throughout the island. Once off of the bus there is another tour guide who was actually once a political prisoner on the island bringing a unique perspective to the tour. You can see where Nelson Mandela was jailed and other infamous political leaders.There is also a penguin colony which is one of the largest in Africa. There is also scenic views where you can take great pictures of the mainland. You can buy tickets at the waterfront if you need to which we did about 30 minutes before the ferry was to leave.

A Must See. I experienced a very informative and at time moving experience learning about the islands past as a political prison. Tours are performed by former detainees which really adds detail and authority to the experience. Amazing to see the incredibly cramped and open cell occupied by Nelson Mandella.

Good, but a bit shuttle-y. The trip starts with a ferry-ride to Robben Island, where political prisoners such as Nelson Mandela stayed during the apartheid. Actually the trip started with a long queue into the ferry, were you could also get your picture taken entering the boat. On the ferry you got to see a movie regarding the apartheid.Once you get to the island you enter a bus and have a 45 minute long ride around the island, with a very knowledgable guide. I was very impressed with ours.After that you get to enter the prison, with another guide. This guide is a former political prisoner who stayed at Robben Island. It was very insightful how he portrayed his time, although(and I feel awful writing this) I didn't catch everything he said at the begining due to his unfamiliar accent.We then got to see the cell were Nelson Mandela sat and this was a very crowded since all of my group wanted to see it at the same time and we had limited time left before the ferry left. You then got to walk back to the ferry(a 5 min walk), and you could take a longer walk to look at the penguins. If you had time. I didn't, which was a bit sad, since I love penguins.Overall it was a well-planned and effective tour. However I did feel a bit like I was on a conveyor-belt and impersonal, since as as soon as we were leaving another huge group arrived.It cost about 230 R, and you can pre-order tickets online. I'm happy I did it, but it wasn't a wowing experience for me.
Great.. Great piece of South Africa's history that everyone has to experience while in that neck of the woods. Very informative and quite emotional. Highly Recommend

Robben Island what an emotional experience. "the journey to freedom" - I am deeply humbled and grateful to Nelson Mandela and all those political prisoners. Your captivity ensured our freedom. Definitely a heart wrenching day. This visit is a must for everyone who is free today

Historically significant but disappointing. Arrived on the Island after a choppy crossing of Table Bay, which is either fun or nauseating depending on your tolerance of open water or fear of peril in the freezing Atlantic. We were met at the harbour by tour buses and were entertained and educated by a tour guide who exhibited such enthusiasm, i almost couldnt believe he gave the same tour several times a day everday.The arid landscape of the island gives you a feeling of desolation, and the life-sized photograph of the last prisoners to leave the prison in the early 90's is emotive. Then you arrive at Robert Sobukwe House and you are jarred by the smell and brightness of a freshly painted house! This theme continues at the maximum security prison (where the highlight and de rigueur photo op' of the whole trip is Nelson Mandela's cell), and all the walls are again freshly painted and the floor varnished! You are told by the guide that the prison did not have windows (just iron bars), but there are newly minted windows everywhere! The tragedy for me was that history had been erased. I expected to see everything as it was. I understand that with so many visitors everyday, there would be some amendments to the structures; but l would have thought that walkways etc would be in place to accomodate the tourist without detracting from the integrity of the site. Yes, the tours are very informative and just being on the island is humbling, but it is SUCH a shame that this national monument has been modernised and therin, ruined..

Robben Island-Triumph of the Will. To fully undersstand the era of Apartheid one MUST visit Robben Island, the prison home to Nelson Mandela for nearly two decades and to countless others who struggled to defeat the evils of Apartheid. One is saddened and uplifted to see the strength of the human will and spirit. A trip to Cape Town without a visit to Robben Island is to miss an opportunity for great inspiration.

Missed potential. Coming with a prior knowledge of the historical importance of Robben Island is a key factor in making a visit here meaningful. The posters with quotes from prisoners in numerous cells are particularly interesting. However, the place has been "spruced up" and its shiny fresh paint contrasts with its grim history. The guides are well-meaning but limited in their ability to put this place into the broader context. The tours are rushed and one feels like one is being herded through. Really, it could be so much more, especially if we want the younger generations to grasp why the sacrifices of the militants still matter.

A moving experience. The highlight of this tour is the maximum security prison tour with a former inmate. The tuck shop stop on the bus tour is a great opportunity for that postcard photo of Table Mountain and to watch the angry ocean beat the rocks. Beware of the usual nationalities when it comes to queuing for getting on and off the boat. Be prepared to be flexible with your plans as Robben Island harbour can be closed by the swell. If this is the case go to the ticket office ASAP and reschedule.

Peaceful Respect. Robben Island stands as a testament to a peoples drive for freedom from oppression, not as another tourist trap. The prisons (because there were more then one) are run down and in disrepair....their prisons for gods sake, not 5 star hotels!!! This is a place of history, where freedom was taken from people for no other reason but their longing for equality. I am not African of any nationality, but this piece of land stands as a monument to people we should all aspire to be like. If you want tourist trap prisons to visit, then go to Alcatraz. If you want to see where people suffered for a basic human ideal and birthright, then visit Robben Island. Don't look at the disrepair or barren looking landscape, but see it for what it stands for.....a monument to a heroic few. Too many of us take our freedom for granted, unlike those who lingered in this place and yet kept fighting for what is rightfully theirs to possess.....freedom. Some of you bleat and whine about tuffs of grass or lack of 'public speaking' from the guides, what a disgrace and disrespectful attitude to the memories of these people. I say to those that think its a waste of time visiting Robben Island...."Maybe you would have been more comfortable during the apartheid era!?" Thank you to the staff, guides and anyone else who shared their knowledge with us. Much respect and admiration to you all.

What a shame. There is so much potential here, but it is lost with so little effort. The gardens are shoddy, the entrance is in desperate need of a coat of paint. The guides are interesting in that they were inmates at some stage. Unfortunately they can relate their experience, but they are not trained in public speaking - (well the guide we had). luckily I understood the enunciation so was able to translate. You are not allowed off the bus. It can be so much more! A pity

A thought provoking visit. Went over to Robben Island one afternoon (3pm ferry, return at 6pm). It's about 25 minutes on the ferry - a bit choppy coming back. You are picked up on arrival by bus and taken around some parts of the island (which is quite large) and given the history of Robben Island vis a vis apartheid etc. Then taken to prison where ex-political prisoner takes you through the regime he experienced and finally to cells where Mandela was held. Vey interesting piece of history told by people who clearly know what they are talking about and show a great amount of passion on the apartheid issue. Glad we went.

Excellent prison tour, terrible island tour. The trip to Robben Island is made up of two parts - the tour of the prison by an ex inmate and a bus tour of the island. The prison tour is excellent, the guide very informative and the museum is well done. The bus tour of the island was conducted by a very bored sounding guide who spoke to us as if to children and repeated everything at least twice. Only one stop was made - at a tuck shop, and we had to stay in the bus for the remainder of the tour. The bus tour part can definitely be improved. Robben island is such an important part of our history, i hope the tour can be improved.

A visit everyone should make. A trip to Robben Island was on our 'must do' list when we visited Cape Town because of the respect that we both have for Nelson Mandela. I am suprised with other reviews saying they did not learn anything about the history of the Island or Nelson Mandela because our guide around the island and our guide for the prison tour did give us plenty of history and insight and on the prison tour there was ample opportunity to ask questions of the guide who had been a political prisoner himself which he was happy to answer. It left us both feeling humble at the conditions that these prisoners survived for numerous years and we both want to reread 'The Long Walk to Freedom' again. The only small negative for me was due to the numbers of visitors that want to go each day the bus tour part is quite crowded and not everyone has an opportunity to see the relevant points of interest. A good tip is to get to the departure gate early so that you can sit on the top deck of the boat as the view is fantastic and we did see seals on route.

A bit chaotic but very interesting. We were late arriving at the Island due to boat problems which meant we basically had to whizz around with our guide (who was very good) on the bus and take photographs from onboard, rather than keep getting off, so that we'd have enough time in the maximum security (walking) part of the visit.The section where we were shown around the secure area by an ex-political prisoner was the highlight and the story he told was both moving and captivating.All in all, a good trip if a little curtailed.

Respect.. Every visitor to Cape Town should visir Robben Island.Not for it's beauty,not for the sight but out of respect for those who were forced to serve time there just because of their ideas. Or the colour of their skin. A reminder of evil but also of hope.

An Embarrassment. Don't come here expecting to learn anything about the political history of Robben Island or Nelson Mandela. It is shocking to learn that Robben Island is a World Heritage Site, and is an embarrassment to South Africans and the legacy of those prisoners who fought for freedom. I came here hoping to gain insight into the period of history which Robben Island has come to symbolize. In essence, I learned nothing. Shame on you South Africa for this dreadful experience.

Not as good as it deserves to be. A place like this, with all its history and ignominy should be a surefire visit of quality but it's not. First comment, there are 3 levels on the boat, the top deck is open and on a nice day (wind allowing) this is the place to see the coastline and stunning skyline of Cape Town and the trip into Robben Island... word of warning, you need to be in the first 12 people to board the boat to have any chance to get up there.. the second deck is half open (standing) and sitting and the main deck is all sitting an air conditioned.. do not sit under the air conditioning if you do not want to catch a cold.. the video they show is very interesting. Once you arrive at the island, you are herded into buses that will then show you around the village... you cannot get off or even take photos at each stop.. there is a nice stop for photos looking towards Cape Town and the guided visit with the former prisoner is very interesting (best bit of visit) however the visit is not as memorable as it should really be. A shame really for a place steeped in so much history..

Very upsetting. Have visited the island on a few occasions, and definitely not worth the money. I have seen the place deteriorate at an alarming pace, and it is actually very sad to see it in that state.

What an unfortunate tour and museum.. This tour takes you to the island where Nelson Mandela was kept for 18 years of his imprisonment. Our tour started with a bus ride of the island. It was nice to see the island but they don't let you off the bus to experience the sights. When you arrive back at the prison you are given a former prisoner as your tour guide. Our guide was just bad. I respect the torment he experienced in the prison but he didn't help tell the story about life in the prison. He just yelled and told us who was held here. The prison is lacking a theme. For example it would be nice to have the cells set like they would have been in 1980 when Nelson Mandela was there. This would have helped the tourist understand the prison life much more. Instead what you get are freshly painted empty cells. Only a few have furniture. Nelson Mandelas cell is set up sort of like when he was there. Save your money and your time and skip this tour. You'd be better off spending your money on a $70 helicopter ride.

worst sightseeing trip of the holiday. I was really looking forward to the visit to this historic island but was bitterly disappointed. firstly we were herded onto a boat with dirty windows so that we did not have a good view of the waterfront as we departed port (not much room outdoors).After the boat we were then herded onto old buses in rows of 3. We were not allowd off the bus and so when they talked about a sight on the opposite side to where I was sat I could not see and could not take photos. We then had a tour of the prison and despite the guide (ex prisoner) talking english I could not understand him very well at all.The best part and most informative was the video film shown on the boat!I think this has become a money making initiative rather than a historic learning experience.

Watt of time and money. I'm sorry to write this, but Robben Island is a turist trap, except for the sailing. The bus Tour with a joke of a guy was borring, he was more interested in him selv, thank telling the story of Robben Island. When we finaly gor to the jail after Driving around the Island in a Big bus, a former prisoner told us storkes that you allready kneb, if you have read just a little about the story.And there is nothing to see than empty cells.Very disappointing.

Moving!. What an interesting place and moving speaker who was a prisoner in the complex. I would have liked longer on the island and would have liked a good shop with books about the history of the island, about the black persons experience then and now. Books on spiritual views and books on island birds.I would have liked to have walked around the island and a good restaurant.Very worth while visit,it made me cry as I found it so overwhelming what men can do to each other!!

For a 'must do' I was most disappointed. It may have been the heat and the flies but I was not desperately impressed with our tour. But we were also in a large group so had very little time to look around. It is very well organised and the guide on the bus did a great job of giving us the history and showing us the sights. I was amazed that 200 people live on the island including former warders and prisoners. It would have much preferred to have done a self guided tour and wandered around. I was interested in the history but we seem to wander past so much with no explanation. The former political prisoner made a great guide to where Nelson Mandela was incarcerated for 18 of his 27 years behind bars. did you know he undertook daily hard labour in the quarry? The views of Table Mountain were stunning on the way back. Definitely worth a trip but it could be so much better done.

Great Excursion a must when in Cape Town. I thought this was a very organized tour starting with a comfortable boat ride across to the island, you are then met by coaches each with their individual guides who take you round the island.The best bit was the guided tour of the prison by one of the former inmates. Our guide was hugely enthusiastic and gave a great insight into life inside. The highlight obviously being 'Father Mandala's ' cell.We were fortunate enough to see seals, dolphins, penguins and springbok on this tour too :)My only word of warning is the ferry crossing. Whilst I am fine on boats, if you are someone who isn't it is worth noting that we were there is the calm summer seas and it was still very bumpy. If you get queasy on boats it may be worth taking some sea sickness tablets!!Definitely worth a visit.

Uninspiring tour of an historic place. It is all a bit tired. Terrible bus tour with a tour guide who is full of himself and think it is appropriate to vent his own political views. They should can the buses and let people do the tour by foot.

Very good, but slightly rushed and needs attention.. A very interesting place to see plus you get the bonus of seeing Cape Town from the sea. The tour of the prison is conducted by former prisoner which makes it more interesting. The down side is that the whole island is ill maintained with vegetation all over, which makes the place looks "pretty". It would be much better if they kept the bareness that used to be as it would give off the right atmosphere. Another criticism is that you are rushed around the island on a bus, with little opportunity to take it all in.

Interesting but needs attention.. It is very important to check the weather before you go on this trip.A little bit disappointed, because the Island needs some attention.The courtyards between the cells were covered with weed and long grass.Surely this historical place can look much better but I will still recommend this island for people interesting in history. Try to book a trip that allows enough free time on the Island to explore on your own as well.

Very disappointing. Very disappointing experience. All a bit long and drawn out with very little of substance to see. They haven't made any effort to bring it back to life and create an experience. They need to go and see Alcatraz to see what can be done with some imaginations and a bit of investment. Faculties poor - toilets dirty and out of action. Wouldn't waste half a day doing the when there is so much more in Cape Town

Good but rushed. When you arrive on the island you are herded onto a bus & taken round the island but only able to get off once. To be fair the commentary on the bus was very interesting but would have been nice to have a walk at various stops. After the bus you are taken on a tour through the prison with an ex-prisoner which also interesting but we both felt the tour was rushed and enough time to soak up the atmosphere. We took the 1100hr boat (catamaran Sikhululekile ) which was fine but the 1000hr boat was late so we watched that one leave (boat Dias) which was one of the original boats that took prisoners to Robben Island, which on the way back left before us but we got back first.Rushed but glad we went.

A missed opportunity to inspire us. The weather was not bad when we visited in August so the trip over was not as harrowing as some other visitors have described. Our tickets had been prebooked by our tour company and we were warned that boarding time could be quite delayed...and it was, by about 1/2 an hour. Our tour guide on the bus was very informative but the actual tour by the ex-prisoner was disappointing. It was such a missed opportunity for us to hear about his personal experience but instead he pretty much gave what sounded like a standard speech with a degree of rhetoric. I would have preferred if he had told us more about why he had been arrested in the first place, how he managed to survive those years of captivity, what Mr Mandela was like, etc. This would have been inspiring and memorable. Instead, it felt like a lecture. In fact, a group of high school students shared the tour with us and I felt badly they looked so bored and restless. As a first time visitor to South Africa, I would have felt badly NOT visiting this site but in retrospect I wish I'd taken the afternoon to see something else.

Wouldn't know haven't been there. We booked twice to visit the island and it was cancelled both times. For such a famous and historical place with hundreds of thousands of people wanting to visit the island each year it's not good enough to have a service that is not reliable or badly run. The staff had a "it's not my problem" attitude when we approached them about our dissatisfaction. We paid by visa and did not get back the full amount we were charged when purchasing. I don't know if this was visa's fault or the ticketing agents.

interesting but disappointing experience. I wasn't quite sure about doing this but once on the ferry I thought that it would be interesting to see where Nelson Mandela spent far too many years in prison. So I wasn't prepared to sit on a coach and be hearded around the island by a guide. We only had one opportunity to get out and stretch our legs at a point around the island which had toilets and not much else. We were pointed out various buildings but were not allowed out to take photos. This part of the tour took an hour with no aircon in the coach. We were finally brought to the maximum security prison where the political prisoners were held for such a long time. Here we had a guide who had been a political activist although he told us he had been arrested for sabotage we didn't know exactly what he had done. It was good to have him as our guide because he had first hand experience if the conditions etc. although as he said by the time he was there conditions were so much improved from when Nelson Mandela was first there. His accent was hard to understand at times and as the first part is sitting in one if the communal cells listening to him for 30mins it was hard not to nod off to sleep. Seeing Mandelas cell was humbling - it's like a cupboard!!!On the whole the experience was good but the island is small and I am sure they could do it differently. Although it is classed now as a world heritage site I am sure there could be more interaction and smaller groups. It was all too impersonal for me

A mixed bag. Well - what a pity that the organisers haven't sorted this out. There is NOT ENOUGH TIME on the island. We were told that at the end of the tour we could use a boardwalk to view the penguins, but we only had 10 mins for this and had to jog there, take 2 photos and get back quickly to the ferry. There is a shop on the quay but I'm surprised if it takes much money as there is NO TIME to visit it. As a boat load arrives the passengers fight for a coach - there is no-one organising a queue or indeed telling us how many coaches there will be. You think there are no more and another one appears round the corner. Visitors NEED TO KNOW. The information you get from the guides will vary depending on the guide. I suppose this is inevitable. Our bus guide was really excellent, very informative, amusing and clear in speech. One frustration is that there are big information boards at some coach stops but only on one side. There is no time to get out so only one side of the bus can see them. The prisoner guide we had was really hard to understand and also was hurrying us along because there were other groups ahead of and behind us doing the same route.The ferry (catamaran) we had was good - no problems there.The staff at the ferry terminal in Cape Town were not helpful. I asked where the S African airlines office was - 3 staff behind the desk - one reading a paper, one on computer and one who grudgingly took my request. I was not impressed.The experience only gets an average from me because of the history and stories behind the island.
Mandela Island. Gives you a very good idea what it must have been to be locked up there for so long. All guides are former prisoners!

A MISSED OPPORTUNITY. We had great expectations of this tour - a site of such international interest - but we were quite disappointed. The ferry transport had dirty seats, and was not in good condition, and when we arrived at Robben Island, the coach used to transport us had ripped seats, and was also none too clean. The P.A. system on the coach did not work properly, so whether the people sitting at the back of the coach could hear, was very doubtful. However, the guide was excellent, and both she and the driver were very friendly and helpful. The whole tour just did not give the visitor time enough to soak up the atmosphere of this historic site. It would have been good to have been given a couple of hours to wander around the prison site, having opportunity to read about the people who inhabited each cell. The trip itself lasted just under half a day, when in fact if refreshment facilities etc., were in place, a whole day would be a more realistic time frame. Truly, in our opinion, a missed opportunity, despite us being told that millions of rand have been invested in this attraction.

Reflects poorly. This important historical site reflects poorly on South Africa and Mr. Mandela. Our experience was mixed:Ferry transport to the island was overcrowded, in poor repair/maintance and there was no safety briefing. (It didn't help that it was rough and took over an hour each way). There was a beautiful catamaran parked in the harbor but it was "under repair". Additionally the exhibits in the Victoria & Albert waterfront building were you wait in line for the ferry where not functioning.The prisoner dialogue on the island could have been much more informative. Our group had great difficulty understanding the speaker, I think I caught 10% of what he said (including his name unfortunately).I would have ranked this lower except for our guide on the driving portion of the tour on the island, excellent job! Very informative and easy to understand. I've never written a review before but felt I must make a plea for improvement of this World Heritage Site, people come from all over the world and it is an embarrassment.

Very disappointing. I had booking the tour many months before going and was so much looking forward to it. The guide on the bus was very good, but the former prisoner guiding us in the prison was speaking English with so strong accent that it was practically impossible to understand more than some words here and there. Also he saw it as his mission to preach freedom and equality shouting at us as if we had another opinion. I understand the idea of having former prisoners guiding but it's really no use if you can't understand what the guide is saying. An advise: everything was rushed. Why not add an hour so you'll also have time to visit the penguin colony whilst you're there?

The worst "not-experience". Robben Island is of the most popular attractions, so you need to book at least 3 weeks prior when you do it online.I personally booked directly at the office in Cape Town. I paid upfront, had my ticket, thought I was all set and didn't need to worry. I was very much looking forward to this experience.On the day of the visit, I drove 2 hours to get to Cape Town's harbor where the tour departs from.When I arrived, the staff told me that it had been cancelled. They were extremely rude, couldn't care less about it, gave a lame explanation, and that was it. My guide told me, they were so disorganized that it happened very often. They are very contemptuous of customers. You would think that if they had an issue with a boat, they would have a back up plan, like... another boat for instance??. Imagine flying nearly 20 hours to CT, planning to visit Robben Island, having your ticket in hand, and being told "It's been cancelled, there's a technical problem." !!!

Robben island boot cruise. Since we could not visit the island, i can not rate it but like to warn other people who will have the same problem in the future. We booked a boot cruise to robben island. Due to the weather the tour was canelled twice. One the 3 day the weather was beautiful and we where happy to go on the trip. However, the tour was cancelled again due to engine problems. Since we could not re-schedule we ask for the refund. This seams to be a problem. I paid cash at the site and wanted cash back since the oversea people had to leave the next day. The person behind the counter was not very friendly and gave me some forms to fill in, he told me to go to the bank and get a statement, he can not give me cash it must be payd into my account. Since i do not carry bankstatment with me on holiday, he said , there is a bank close by where i can get the statement. He can not give me the money. Eventually, we agreed that i can have the money back if i used my foreigh passport. Many people had the same problem and some of them where quite abset about the treatment. From the tourism point of you, this behavior is not acceptable and should be investigated by the tourism board.
What a waste of time. The only nice thing about visiting Robben Island is the boat ride over there - you get to see Table Mountain and the harbour from a unique view point. Really not worth it.

Humbling experience. We felt this was was of those 'must do' activities to do while staying in Cape Town and it was a very humbling tour. The tour guides were really friendly, and very informative. We had a guide on the bus which toured the island and then a former inmate as our tour guide while viewing the maximum security prison area. The crossing to get the island can be a rough one, as many reviewers have already referred to but if you can handle the 'exhilarating' boat ride then you'll find this a very rewarding activity to help undercover the history and culture of not just Cape Town but of South Africa.

If you get seasick, STAY AWAY for the love of god!!!!. I suffer from carsickness and general motionsickness, which is pretty uncomfortable at times, but I felt like I could suffer through to see Robben Island.  I was never prepared for the nightmarish experience that was about to take place when I woke up that morning.Like a good tourist, I popped my dramamine and made my way to the ferry.First impression- WHY WAS IT SO HARD TO PERSUADE THEM TO GIVE ME MY TICKET?They kept asking me for some receipt number with a reference number. I told them I bought it over the phone and that they should have my last name. I had to persuade them to give me my ticket, even after I showed them my passport!Waiting for ferry- DISPLAYS? MOVIES? WHAT? After reading other reviews, I noticed that people were complaining that the introductory movie wasn't working and that areas were closed off. Hmmm. I guess that was the case for me too, because while I waited an hour for the ferry, all I had was a TINY gift shop to wander around (although that really isn't accurate either- it is about two steps in and two steps back.)On the ferry- PUKEFEST We all crammed on below deck. People are excited, chatting. Waves are pretty rough. After about 15 minutes, I notice the happy chatter has stopped. Including my own. I am concentrating on keeping my breakfast down when suddenly I hear it. I look up at the sea of green faces and hear people moaning and throwing up. It is like a chain reaction, one after another. The sounds and smells are triggering more and more people to give up their stomach's contents, and there is absolutely no shame. I kid you not, at least 20 people were throwing up at the same time. It was like a sick movie. People are crawling over each other in a desperate effort to get outside, above deck, but the waves are so intense that you have to ping yourself between a pole, a table, a person, anything you can grab onto or else you are going to be tossed 6 feet with the next wave. I ping myself towards the door leading to the outside deck in a frantic effort to escape the madness (and to have a bit of dignity when I do the inevitable: vomit off the side of the ferry into the ocean). I finally make it to the rail, in the knick of time. After shamelessly doing my thing into the water far below I look up, feeling slightly relieved, only to see a MASSIVE rogue wave hurtling in my direction. I stare at it dumbfounded, still wiping my mouth with a crumpled kleenex that I dug up from my pocket, as it literally washes completely over me. Over my head, it rushes in and hurtles me into the side of the ferry. I am seriously lucky it didn't wash me overboard- it was that huge. Covered in salt water, freezing cold, eyes burning, stomach seizing, and with the remnants of breakfast clinging to my soaked jacket, I see Robben Island in the distance. The tour wasn't worth the misery. I couldn't hear the tour guide, the snack shop didn't offer anything of sustainance, and quite frankly I was sort of bored- and I LIKE historical places.Now for the ferry back to the mainland.

One of the highlights of our 3 weeks in Cape Town!. I can appreciate not everyone would find this as enjoyable as I did, but personally the whole experience was amazing. We took the whole family, about 14 of us in total, and everyone enjoyed the trip, but for me it was very special. I hd previously read Mandela's book 'Long Road To Freedom' and everything I saw on the island was as described by Mandela. Very moving and powerful! I even got to have my book signed and photo taken with our guide who was one of Mandela's fellow prisoners mentioned in the book. If you are in Cape Town you have to do this!

What a place. Quite a fun trip to the Island when the sea is rough!! Island tour very interesting. Tour of the prison with a former political prisoner is very moving and enthralling. Really made the tour personal.

Robben Island. We loved the whole experience and every person should partake in this experience. The ferry was clean and comfortable and the tour guides (Thabo and Mr Motsele) were knowledgeable and spell binding. Definitely a destination I would bring my friends to.

Interesting tour but feels a little rushed. The only way to access Robben Island is by tour departing from the Victoria and Albert Waterfront and it is a fascinating place. However the time on the island felt rushed as we were herded from place to place with little time to stop and reflect, take photos or read the sign boards. Meeting the former prisoner was a real highlight and I wouldn't want to have missed it. Perhaps they should have a short and a longer tour to cater for visitors differing interests.

Robben Island. A piece of South African's history. Everyone should visit this place even if the tour is too long.I would recomend less talking and more photos and displays that visitors can view at their leasures. I have been on the island twice.The first time the tour guide was fantastic the second one not so good because there were many people and it was hard to hear and see.

OVERRATED. The significance of Robben Island in the country's history, particularly the people's struggle for freedom, is undisputed. However, one comes away with the feeling that a trip to the Island is over rated. The ferry ride itself is relaxing and enjoyable but the the tour of the island, itself, is far too long. For this reason, I do not recommend visiting the Island to overseas visitors whose time is limited. I would recommend less talking and more photos and displays that visitors can view at their leisure.

Madiba's Home for 27 Years. It brought me to tears, the man (Nelson Mandella) spent so many years locked up here. Such a small cell.
