It was a wonder he was released with his sanity, least of all with such compassion and forgiveness. Aw struck!!The trip across can be a little too much from those who don't have sea legs, my sister ended up feeding the fish... Some of the previous internees are the guides and hosts on the island now.

Staff on mainland very unfelpful and rude, far too many people on the tour. Our taxi was an hour late so we missed the boat. We ageed that it was our fault but when we asked at the "help" desk is there anything we could do they said no, it was our fault and we'd lost all of our money. Then we saw that 2 other passengers simply paid R50 extra to change the time of their tour with no problem. When we asked if we could do the same we had to wait about 15 minutes for the less enthusiastic staff to make a decision. After much persuasion and being spoken to like idiots they charged us the R50 and put us on te next boat.The staff on the island are very helpful and it was very interesting. However, there is about 35+ people per one tour guide so it was hard to see and hear things. We felt like there was far too many people on the tour and that they just pile as many people in as they can to make the maximum money. We were just another number.

Humbling. From the moment you step off the boat onto the island you feel the sense of history and importance which just increases as you take a tour with one of the guides (ex-prisoner) around the prison and listen to their own story and that of Nelson Mandela's incarceration.

Disappointing. Having read 'Walk to Freedom', expected to feel the atmosphere described in the book but found it had been 'tarted up' to look more like a hotel than a prison. Have visited Alcatraz, where the atmosphere was far more realistic. Although the guide on the bus back to the ferry was very entertaining, would not specially recommend this visit.

OK, but worth it to see the site. It is a really neat experience being on Robben Island and seeing the prison. The boat ride over was gorgeous, too. Unfortunately the tour guide (especially our tour guide on the bus) was very average and really took away from the experience. Inside the prison we were guided by an ex-prisoner, which was really interesting, but we were in a huge group - 100+ people - and that is just too large of a group to hear what is being said. Could have been so much better, especially for the price, but since doing this tour is the only way to Robben Island it is worth it. I would still definitely do it again!

A few faults, but an excellent experience. I agree with previous reports that the organisation could be improved but for us the experience was fantastic. We had a lovely sunny spring day, an outstanding tour guide on the coach who had also been a prisoner, and was now working on the island in a research capacity. He enthralled us with his knowledge, experience and wit, and really brought home the complexity of world politics and how this impacts on people. The guide for the prison had also been a prisoner and was able to tell his story in a meaningful way. After seeing other reviews we were uncertain about what to expect, but for us it was an experience not to be missed.

A must do if you love history. Booking on-line in advance was a breeze and recommended as this tour can quickly fill up. The ferry was packed but the ride over was nice and the seas were not too rough. Our tour guide on the bus was great; not so great was our guide on the ground through the prison. The guides are former convicts and it was interesting to hear about the prison from people who actually spent time there. However, our guide had a kind of monotone voice that eventually made several of us doze as we sat on benches listening to him. We were the first bus to begin the tour but the last one to return and our guide just went on and on and on about what I can't remember. Plus his English was not great so his talk was choppy and disconnected. Unfortunately, we got back to the dock so late our group did not have time to buy anything at the large and well-stocked gift shop. A shame because I planned on buying a shirt or hat. Could be better organized to allow time to shop.

touachable and unmissable. absolutely a must when around Cape Town. It takes more or less 4 hours: boat trip to the island, bus tour with guide and "the long walk of freedom" along the cells with an ex-prisoner. The only bad thing is that, at the moment, is only for english speakers because there is not even a short translation, so if you don't speak an excellent english many stories mught get lost (a real pity).

Could be better. As others have posted the ferry journey over to the island can be a bit disorganised, this was certainly my experience. We were delayed in boarding the ferry, and no explanation for this was given. The ferry appeared to be overloaded and there was no clearly identified staff in charge. There was no commentary or information provided during the trip. On arrival you have to walk a short distance to board buses. The buses are quite old and not particularly comfortable, I was unable to see the guide who was standing behind me, not at the front of the bus as is usual. No outline for the planned itinerey was provided. We were taken on a drive around the island and had one opportunity to alight, take photos, use toilets etc. Then back on the bus and off to the prison. Whilst the commentary was interesting there is much more potential in this museum and hopefully in time this will be developed, at present it is a little sparse.

Amazing experience. The only reason I gave this a four is that the ferry was late going out, and REALLY late coming back. We returned an hour and a half after we were supposed to which messed up some of the people's other tours. But that actual tour on Robben Island was awesome. We had a great tour guide who was hilarious and very knowledgeable. He took us on a bus around the island and explained different locations and events. Then you went to the prison and that portion was led by a former political prisoner who had stayed there. Each cell told a short story about someone who was held in the prison. And you visited Nelson Mandela's cell at the end. it was pretty great and I was very overwhelmed and moved by the end.

for don't forget. the ferry that brings yourself to the island from the waterfront have taken, they do them you to make the turn in bus with the guide in English and you can make some fantastic photos of city of the head next to do where a standstill there is then an ex imprisoned it suits you to see the jails. in those jails mandela has changed the course of the history it is very excited to see it owed it has happened

informative and interesting tour. my family and i booked over the internet for the robben island tour. we were unfortunately late and the ferry had left without us. after speaking to the manager in charge he gladly rescheduled our trip for the next ferry at a very low fee. we were very grateful for that or else we would have lost a large amount of money. the tour itself was highly informative and a real eye opener of what apartheid was like. a really enjoyable morning indeed.

Robben Island Museum Tour advice. Just a word of caution for those who really want to do this tour:- Book well in advance (we had to book 1 week out)- Internet bookings not always available- Our tour was cancelled ON THE DAY of the tour and noone from the company made phone or  email contact with us prior. A reimbursement was given however.Unfortunately as we planned this as a highlight of our trip the day before flying out, we didn't have the option to reschedule. So if you really want to do this trip, I suggest planning ahead!

Impressive but needs organizational Optimizing. First of all: book online, so do that 14 days in advance, otherwise you may expect some trouble (see other reports). You must queue up in a long line and pass a kind of security screening that really doesn't deserve that term. We entered a historic boat that brought us to the island in somewhat more than half an hour. Try to sit outside so you may take some good photos from CPT. On the island wie were directed to buses, and a nearly 45 min bus tour with a good guide explained the history of the island and showed some interesting corners. That was followed by a guided tour through the high security prison, this was made by a former prisoner, he was very interesting and also told his story. Everybody will visit also Nelson Mandelas jail cell, and we were impressed by these buildings and how the Apardheid dealt with the political prisoners. The transport to the mainland was also on an older boat, and that was my major complaint: nobody counted the people entering, and we had the idea of a very unsafe trip on this boat, as well as many others! To summarize: an impressive visit with lack of safety on the transport.

Compelling visit. We visited Robben Island as part of our school trip to South Africa. As a group of 32 teenage girls and 5 staff, we universally found our visit to the prison and the tour of the island to be a profoundly moving experience. Our guides had both been imprisoned on the island during the Apartheid era, and spoke with great dignity and passion about their experiences. This is a must if you're visiting Cape Town.

Historic and enthraling. I ran a race on this timeless island, where you guessed your time and took off your watch. The closest to the guess was the winner. A pure magic place to visit and stay. Penguin colonies, hare and dear all add to the ambiance.

Worth visiting but could be improved. First Tip to avoid disappointment book your tickets early online as this tour usually is sold out 1-2 weeks in advance depending on the day.The Management of the Island particularly the ferry staff seem very disorganized and not willing to assist, our ferry was delayed for over an hour for no reason, without even an apology from staff. We only discovered this when we arrived for our 10am departure. The trip over (particularly on the old boat) can be very rough so I suggest take precaution to avoid sea sickness, my advice sit outside in the fresh air. There was also no instruction provided on the location of life jackets or what to do in the event of an emergency. Upon landing on the island it was chaos, there were plenty of people standing around (locals on the island) but no assigned dedicated tour staff to provide instruction of where to go, this was further hindered by having a school group in attendance. Service can be dramatically improved here. Once we found our tour bus the information provided was interesting but lacking the historical detail I would have liked to learn & hear more about. The area although a world heritage site seemed poorly maintained and run down in places and points of particular interest & historical significance like the limestone quarry for instance you could not exit the bus to view in close detail.The tour & talk provided by an actual ex prisoner was great and overall the highlight of the trip (this was the best part). Sadly the overall island experience itself from start to finish has the potential to be fantastic if Senior Management only made the effort to pay a little more attention to guests and coordinate a more well planned, better organised, more structured informative tour of the island. Do this and you will have an awesome tour!

Appaling, bad service, lacklustre venue. I was very optimistic about the visit to Robben Island as its world heritage site (but I'm pretty sure if they continue in their current vein they will be bound to loose this status). We were shown around by an ex-cannery factory worker (not part of the struggle) and he was unable to answer basic historic questioning. The staff offer rote explanations in a very basic fashion (I felt they were "just getting the day over") . Please please train staff and employ people with a passionate outlook on their own history. Very disappointing day.

Homage to Madiba and his comrades. What an experience to walk on the same floors as many greats of modern South Africa. We managed to get on one of the few trips due to a break in the weather (in fact the 1 pm tour wascancelled due to rough seas). We took quite a rough sea crossing over followed by a coach tour of the islsnd with MP as our knowledgable guide abley driven by Jimmy. Then into the actual prison through some of the cell blocks with the final one being that which held the important political prisoners during the struggle. Show around by a forner political prisoner who was passionate in his excellent delivery of this part of the tour. To walk on the same floors as the great Madiba and his fellow political comrades. The only negative point being the MV Dias on the return trip being rather cattle class. An experience not to be missed and thanks to all who made it a memorial day, pity we could not get a full day tour as so much to see.

Worth the time. As international visitors to Cape Town, we were eager to see Robben Island. The tour is well orchestrated and conducted chiefly by bus. The boat ride over -- directed by capable, humorous staff -- provides fantastic views of Cape Town. Our bus guide on the island was excellent. During the first part of the tour (by bus), there is one stop for picture taking and restroom use. The second part of the tour is conducted by a former prisoner who walks the group through the prison yard and Mandela's cell. He was also very good. The tours are tightly timed, and there is not any free time for wandering at one's own pace, but we were very glad we went. I think the sponsor is losing potential income by not providing enough time for a stop in the gift shop, but that's a minor issue. All in all, we recommend this experience for those interested in Cape Town and South African history.

Historical more than anything else.... This is a great visit if history is your thing. You will mostly be visiting the jail and quarry where the prisoners worked. They also show you graves where they kept lepers on the island; and that's about it. The round trip is quiet "fast" and you cannot explore the island in your own time.

Better than expected. I'm a South African and wasn't overly keen on visiting, but went along for a work function. Was pleasantly surprised. Nice boat trip out and then we had a funny and informative guide. I'm not sure if this will be your experience every time though. Interesting.

Visiting Cape Town is not complete without a trip to Robben Island!. Very important that you book well in advance! In July which is winter in SA and I would have not offpeak, the tours where sold out for another 2wks! Part of the problem is that there is only one ferry boat and only 4 trips per day.

Great Tour, Poor Transport. Robben Island tour really is a "must do" if you're interested in South Africa's history. But while parts of this tour were quite informative, especially the tour of the prison, I would have liked to know a lot more. Transport on ferry and bus takes most of your time! Also, took the tour during South Africa's winter, and despite extremely cold temps and rain we used the open ferry. Book very early and online if you do want to go as trips sell out weeks in advance.

Embarrassed. embarrassing to see what local government has done to ensure the upkeep of this heritage site. The curator should be shot or even better be made to work in the quarry, could be a far better and entertaining experience with a historical significance. The apartheid thing is now over, time to work on a better experience!

Book in advance. Visiting Cape Town in the middle of the winter I assumed I could just get the tickets anytime, but once here I discovered they were sold out for the next couple of weeks (the first available ticket was for the day after I leave). This morning I went for the first ferry anyway, hoping someone would cancel, and there was already a line of people waiting. I was lucky to get a ticket, but many people went sent back.The tour was definitely worth it, but as others have said it felt too rushed. There's a part of the prison where you can go into the cells, see the picture of who was kept there, and read a brief story about their life there -- that was my favorite part of the tour. Unfortunately, you can only go into a few of many cells because they're rushing you. There's also no time at the end, so you either see the penguins or visit the gift shop (I thought they might have a book with all the stories). I chose the former and then had to rush to catch the ferry.They should definitely add a bit more time for both the prison tour and some "free time" at the end.

Robben Island. Very interesting to see Nelson Mandela former cell. Do not eat anything a hr.before the boat trip. It is a very bumpy trip both directions. Nice that the hotel gives all guest free transportation to the waterfront to take the boat,shop or dine at a restaurant there.

SUPREME SACRIFICE. When my wife and I recently took our ferry to Robben Island we had no idea what emotions the trip would evoke in us.On our previous vacation in Cape Town, our trip had been cancelled due to the rough and stormy seas. So we were quite excited that the unpredictable Cape Town weather had played along this time. An so off we went to the island that gave South Africa its first African President. The tour guide was informative and I was quite emotional at the story of Sobukwe and the lime quarry. That people went through that much for our freedom only demonstrates the extent of their supreme sacrifice for all South Africans. The Nelson Mandela cell and the 'bed' left me in tears.How could he and his colleagues come out of those cells without broken spirits?Overall, this is the trip of a lifetime and we plan to bring our children so that they can have an appreciation of the sacrifices of Nelson Mandela and all other prisoners.

A snapshot of the past. Luckily got tickets the day before our trip to Robben Island, we were waiting to see how the weather was and were happy that the autumn day was cool but clear and the view from the boat back to Capetown was spectacular. The tour of Robben Island itself was quite regimented, the guides were ex political prisoners and were really knowledgeable. The bus takes you around the island and stops at a few spots but you are on the bus quite a while and it got quite stuffy. The walking tour around the buildings and cells was informative and of course the viewing if Mandela's cell. Overall, I enjoyed it but found it was a little rushed at the end and could have had another 15 to 30 minutes of independent walking around. Maybe they were worried people would miss the boat?

Make this a priority when you visit Cape Town. Been here on numerous occasions with my ESL students and most recently in February with my husband who had never been before. A visit to Robbin Island should be a priority when in Cape Town as it will give you a good understanding of life under the apartheid regime and the struggle for freedom. Be sure to make a reservation in advance! Not only do you get to see Mandela's prison cell but he boat ride is lovely, you get lovely views of Cape Town and Table Mountain from the island and you get to see some interesting wildlife!

A must see- just not in bad weather. I was really looking forward to seeing the prison and after reading the description I couldn't wait to go! We prebooked tickets almost 2anniversary months in advance to ensure that we got the date and time we wanted. There was a sign when we arrived (July 20th) that it was booked until August 1st! We were taken thru security and onto the boat. Now for someone who has lived on an island (Long Island, NY) for my entire life I've never been sea sick. But boy did this trip change all that! It wws misty before our 9amtrip take off and with a storm approaching the sea got very choppy. Sitting indoors (because outdoor standing would result in you getting soaking wet) near the front of the boat was a bad idea! 3 out of my 4track friends got ill and needed sea sick bags. Many others around us needed the same.Arrived on the island and was allowed to use the restroom and get on large buses to the prison. Once at the prison, a former prisoner toured us around- providing great insight into the daily lives of prisoners as well as the prison system at the time and apartheid. (I would suggest reading Nelson Mandela's book Long Walk to Freedom- or atleast excerpts during his prison stay). Then we were back on the bus for a 45min tour of the island. Our guide, Wendy, I believe, was fabulous! After a bathroom,snack and curio stop we headed back to the boats.Might I recommend sitting on the lower deck on the boat near the back. A MUCH less rocky location where no one got sick. Besides that and the chilly, rainy weather, it was fabulous.

Great place - terrible tour. Everyone should get to visit Robben Island at least once.Our ferry ride was fine and turned out to be the best part of the trip.As a lot of other people have stated, you are herded like cattle from ferry onto stuffy, hot busses, off busses, through prison, back onto ferry.75% of the time we were stuck on a hot, stuffy bus. We were parked more than we were on the move. We had to wait for the bus in front of us to move before we could.Our guide was quite good but went on and on and on. The bus goes around the island - they point out various places of interest along the way. There is one stop for a photo opportunity. The bus then drops you off at the prison and an ex inmate takes over the tour. This was slightly more interesting although I felt it went on way too long. Then all of a sudden it was over and I couldn't believe the guide didn't point out Mr Mandela's cell. Afterall, I'm sure everyone who goes there wants to see that above anything else.The tour went on so long we were late for the ferry. I heard a lot of people complaining about not having time to visit the shop.Incredibly disappointing experience. I really hope they improve the tour in the future.

Haven't seen Cape Town until you visit Robben Island. Done this tour a few times but have to say it has changed a lot over the years. Believe its important for the youth to understand what apartheid was about but like they positive spin they have put on things, not remind us about why we should be segregated but why its important to work together. You will be suckered into buying a penguin, just give into the temtation. Best advice is to take a water with you, you're going to do a fair share of walking.

Good Tour - Not so good transport. This is a "must do" if you're interested in the history of the freedom movement and apartheid in South Africa. First the bad (strange).... The day we went was a bit misty and ride in the boat was chilly. The thing that struck us as strange was that, apparently Robbens Island has two boats -- one is an open air boat that we were on and the other is a nice catamaran style indoor boat that was sitting at the dock. The day we went was chilly and misty and they still loaded everyone up on the open air boat - which was fairly uncomfortable for the long ride out to the island. I'm also fairly sure that there was more people on the boat than the boat actually accomodates comfortably but I can't be totally certain. During rainy weather you would think that the enclosed vessel would be used.The good... the tour itself was interesting and the portion of the tour that was in the actual prison was conducted by one of the former political prisoners. The bus takes you around the island and stops at a few locations explaining the history of the island before stopping at the prison area (which is the last part of the tour).

Robben Island, Cape Town. Taking the ferry to Robben Island is a must...assuming they don't cancel due to weather! Seeing Mandela's cell and listening to a former prisoner sensitizes us all to human rights. I highly recommend the visit.

Robben Island, is it a scam. Last Wednesday four of my relations who are staying here for a fortnight went to the Robben Island terminal and purchased 4 tickets for the 11-00 sailing on Saturday, on arrival they were informed that the trip was cancelled due to rough weather, with which they had no argument, but when they asked for a refund they were asked to provide a bank statement with the banks stamp on it, they explained that like most tourists, they were not in the habit of carrying bank statements with them on holiday and that they had paid in cash, not credit card. An offer on another date was offered but as they were flying back that night this was on no use.  The lady in charge, Nomachina, at one stage turned her back on them and walked off disappearing through a door used by staff. My relations then approached the tourist info who were most helpful and who contacted Robben Island and explained that what they were doing was wrong, the clients paid in cash and should be refunded in same manner, they got stonewalled as well. Two other tourists in the same predicament gave up and wandered off, fed up with arguing. When I finished work I went down the see what was happening and got the same, no cash refunds, OK, so I left my bank details so I could get the refund and forward it on to the UK, on Monday morning I get a E Mail from Robben Island asking for a bank statement with the banks stamp attached, so they expect me to go to my bank, get a stamped statement, drive down to the waterfront and present them with it. What kind of scam is being operated here when cash disappears and they know full well tourists are here for a short time and most will give it up as a bad job and go away very disgruntled. My grandson said it should be renamed "Robben so and so's"  As a tour operator I get more complaints about Robben Island than any other of our tourist sites put together. I have now turned to the consumer rights panel for help.Thomas MurrayCamps Bay.

Well worth it. A comfortable ferry ride with beautiful views of the bay and Table Mountain starts the excursion on a high note. Once on the island, the bus tour guide had the most interesting stories to tell from around the world and their impact on the island and SA. Once off the bus a former prisoner takes you on a tour of the prison cells and shares some history on some of the inmates, their food, their clever ways of communication with the outside, how they studied, the guards' different treatment towards them, and even how they smuggled out Madiba's book.You will probably spot some penguins too while on the island! A must do on your list of activities when in the area!
Wow!. Very interesting, educational experience - I love that our tour guide was a former prisoner.

Our Heritage. This heritage site is a reminder of the price paid for freedom - will always be very closely connected to Madiba and should be visited for it's beauty and diversity - the wide variety of fauna and flora to be seen - and especially the beauty of the island with a spectacular view of Table Mountain

Great Birthday Treat!. My boyfriend decided to spoil me and take me out the island for the day. it was very cold but the trip was splendid. I even got a chance to stand inside Nelson Mandela's previous cell! What a historic experience! Great day!
Must Do. Every South African and Tourist must do Robben Island. Very informative part of South African History. Have time on your habds dont ruch it!

Buy your ticket on line in advance. The 50-minute ferry ride to Robben Island is included in the ticket price, and you'll have amazing views of Cape Town and the mountains. Seeing the prison is worth the visit, and looking into the cell where Nelson Mandela spent 18 years is the highlight. It helps to read his autobiography first, so that you know what he experienced during his incarceration on the island.

Disappointing. We missed visiting Robben Island on our first trip in SA six years ago, so this time we definitely planned it in as this is a must see if you want to understand this important part of history. What a disappointment! The tour is very commercialized and rushed through. After a 45 minutes bus tour on the island and a short time spent with an ex political prisoner who shared some of his own experiences and showed Nelson Mandela's cell for two seconds, there was no time left to wander around and to take in and reflect on the experience as a whole. We left the island with a bitter taste and we felt that there is very little learned during this trip. The most we liked were the breathtaking views of Cape Town and the Table Mountain during the boat trip to and back the island but this is not what you are aiming for during such a visit. Would not recommend even though Robben Island is a very important part of history. The tour needs improvement.

An important part of the worlds history to see. Hard to rank thus experience as the story and place it self is a must see and a part of the worlds history that we all need to see but.. an hour overdue leaving the port with no explanation is not a great experience for top tourism service. Remember to dress warmly for the boat . If you get put on an old it boat will will take an extra half an hour in the cold!

Not sure it is worth the trouble. To begin, the history of Robben Island is unparalleled and it was truly great to see where Mandela and other political prisoners were held during captivity. However, the trip itself could be vastly improved.We visited in the off-season and the ferry was still packed, so reservations are a must. The ride to the island was about 45 minutes and was terrible. My wife and I have never gotten sea sick before, but both of us were feeling nauseous only 10 minutes into the trip. Definitely stay out on the top deck if you can. We were not alone either. It seemed like everyone on the boat was sick. After docking we were immediately ushered to busses which is last place we wanted to be given our nausea.The tour guides were very knowledgeable and really made the trip. However, the experience is very limited and the time on the island was very short. The trip back was not nearly as bad.Overall, it was disappointing. Perhaps when they finish with walking/bike paths there may be more to do on the island and it may be a more enjoyable trip.

Could definitely be better, too commercialised. The trip to Robben Island could definitely be better. First, the 9 am ferry was fully packed, with many left with no seats. The 11 am ferry was already sold out when I pre-book the tickets 3 weeks before my trip.The sea was not too rough that day, but dangerous things could happen if a boat was over loaded coupled with bad sea conditions. (I’m a diver instructor, so trust me on this).Upon arriving on Robben Island after a 45 mins boat ride, we are ushered onto buses. There were at least 3 full bus loads that morning. The guide on my bus, named MP, is a real funny man. He brought life to the bus with his many jokes incorporated into his guide speech. Downside was the people at the back had problems hearing him as the PA system in the bus was down. After a 35 mins bus ride around the island, we are dropped off at the political prison cell for a guided tour with an ex political prisoner. This is where things were downhill. Tho the content were meaningful, the delivery could be better. There was not much of a “personal experience sharing session” but more of a bam wham fact fact fact content which can easily be found on wikipedia. We were made to sit in this long communal cell where the guide speaks in his monotone, followed by a few 5 mins walking down the cells, a few minutes over Nelson Mandela’s cell for photo taking and lastly 10 mins in the bare courtyard. Our group (6 person) came off the island feeling a little shortchanged. Too commercialized as we were allowed more time at the gift shop than the cells.

Spiritual. Touring this site and seeing Nelson Mandala's jail cell was for us the most spiritual tour ever, our guide was himself a old prisoner of Robben Island. For my family and I this will be a trip to remember for ever.

wonderful trip. a great boat ride followed by a wonderful setting. and what views of cape town. the icing on the cake must be however the penguin colony who have settled there. and of course the bit of history with a guide who has actually been imprisoned there. breathtaking views of cape town and the table mountain in particular. a wonderful experience in total

moving experience. Highlight of my trip to South Africa ,the guides are ex prisoners who walked the walk of fighting apartheid,i feel some people dont understand the significance of this place in history.it is not Disneyworld or Alton Towers.Robben Island is quite a big place with churches and a mosque from when it was a lepper colony .Views across to Cape Town are amazing a deeply moving and thought provoking experience .If youre not interested in the history of this wonderfull country please dont bother ,otherwise bring a hanky youll need it,

No space or time to reflect. This is a hard one to review as you have to separate the significance of the place with the only option tour that gets you there. I didn't like the way the tour was put together. After taking the ferry over we were herded onto buses, taken around the island and then given a tour of the maximum security part by a former political prisoner. So many people were there with their big fancy cameras jostling for position. When Ben, the former inmate, started talking to us it was like being at a press conference with all the cameras going off. There were some very thoughtful questions raised by people in our group which I was thankful for, not having any of my own. The time with Ben didn't feel rushed and I learned a lot from hearing him speak. And then the 'obligatory' photo of Mandela's cell. If it were up to me I would ban photography of the facilities on the island. You can buy a postcard just as easily. I would also allow time for people to wander through in their own good time. Maybe an audio guide could be used to help people who don't speak English but want to know what's going on. But rush, rush, rush and back to the ferry. There were some Capetonians on the ferry whose work had paid for their day out but I haven't met any other South African who's been there. This is a real shame because Robben Island should serve as a reminder of what it once was. The people who fought and suffered there deserve respect instead of being treated as show ponies by greedy business people who only want to make money.

history but not individual. I really wanted to go to Robben Island so when we got on the boat over it was really nice apart from the rough ride and every one being sick. but when on the island there were far too many people on the trip so we couldnt hear what the guide was saying at all and it felt very touristy. glad I did it but wouldnt do it again unless they did smaller trips

Very informative visit, you get to know better an important part of SA history. Nice tour in Cape Town. Very informative. Best part of the tour is the visit where tour guide is a former inmate of Robben Island prison. Our guide was very polite and knew quite some histories of that time. You also visit island installations including limestone quarry where inmates were forced to work. As a bonus you can also visit a penguin colony in the island. Our trip was well organized and facilities in the island are nice. Downside is that boat and buses are kind of old and seats are showing signs of wear.

Worth it. It was very touching and quite educative on the part of history that we didn't know. They view is great from table mountain as well. Worth going early so that you can see the penguins as well. We had a very good and interesting guide who made the experience all so awesome.

Badly organised great potential. There are some excellent guides but many visitors find the local ones hard to understand. The ferry service to the island has been very erratic with the buses used for transferring passengers and island sightseeing very old and uncomfortable.

Over-rated but it's probably down to the guide. We booked our trip to Robben Island online and this is a must if you want to visit. However this does mean that there was no flexibility which would be useful when the weather is bad. The ferry crossing was awful as the sea was very rough and I will try not to let this colour my judgement. We were frogmarched around the detention blocks by a former inmate. We weren't given the opportunity to reflect on the many stories posted on the walls of cells but were constantly chivvied and hustled along until we got to the communal area where we were subjected to a 20 minute lecture on the political situation during apartheid. I imagine that most of the visitors had a fair idea of the situation and that's why they were there. We then had a bus tour of the island which was only marginally interesting. I understand that the objective is probably to give as many people as possible the chance to visit this iconic site but the number of visitors really diminishes the value of the experience. We visited Alcatraz some years ago and found the experience rather more emotionally satisfying.

A Must-Do in Cape Town. We bought tickets through the hotel concierge,but there was no long line for tickets at the ferry departure point, so we could have just as easily bought them on site. Ferry left on time; trip over to the island was a bit rough, so take bonine or other antinausea medication if you are susceptible to sea sickness. Views from open area on top deck of ferry are fantastic, but the wind can be horrendous. Hats and even eyeglasses can be blown away. Buses were waiting on the island, and the guide was an ex-convict from the prison. The process of getting into the prison was a bit hurried, but the pace slowed once we were inside. There is quite a lot of walking and standing, so wear comfortable shoes. The groups are large, and there were several people who didn't understand English very well. Maybe they need more multilingual guides.Our guide was patient with them and repeated comments as necessary, but this slowed the whole process.Learning that political prisoners were considered more dangerous than murderers really made me think about the importance of ideas and how fortunate I am to live in a country where ideas, even unpopular ones, can be freely expressed. I came away from this place with a new appreciation for freedom of speech and thought. When the tour ends, you are invited to visit a penguin colony on the island, but we didn't have (or take) the time, as we were afraid we would miss the next ferry back to Cape Town. I suppose we could have waited for another one, but it was late afternoon and the schedule details were a bit enigmatic. A ferry came, so we boarded it. No one should come to Cape Town without making this trip. It's not "fun," but it is informative and thought provoking, perhaps more than small children could handle.

Interesting. This is worth doing while in Cape Town. The ferry ride was nice and the view of Table Mt is great. The tour itself could have been timed better as it was rushed at the end. The groups are also very large so not a very personal experience. The other downside is that you do have to commit a few hours for this as the ferry ride back from the island is timed. I am still glad I went.
Impressive. especially the tour given by an ex convict. Not as impressive as Alcatraz tough.

Humbling. The whole trip was awesome. The boat trip over to the island gave us a stunning view of Cape Town and Table Mountain. The tour, and talk was emotional. The only down side is that it is all a bit rushed and herded like cattle. I would have like more time to take it all in. That said we came away with a deeper understanding of those dark times and humbled.

Worth the Trip. We did the Robben Island tour and really enjoyed it, the ferry to/from the island is great, you can get some great views of Table mountain. The tour itself was very good in informative, would def recommend doing it while in Cape Town.
Get your facts straight. The trip to Robbin Island was just anti-Apartheid in reverse and the show was only for the overseas visitors. Get your facts straight and stop lying to people.

Must see!. Cape Town is a must visit city and Robben Island is a must see. First, book your boat tickets on line, access is limited and the boat sells out.I thought I understood the civil rights struggle in South Africa until I visited the Apartheid Museum in Johannesburg and Robben Island in Cape Town. It was an eye opening experience. Deeply moving -- I am not ashamed to admit that I wept. After seeing the conditions of Nelson Mandela's imprisonment, and his steering the country to universal sufferage, he should be Canonized. After getting off the boat, you will go on a bus tour of the island (which has a long history before it became an apartheid prison camp). You get off the bus at the prison block and go on a walking tour of the prison with a ex-inmate as a guide.By the way, the views of Cape Town and Table Mountain are magnificant, which must have made imprisonment more painful.Cape Town is a wonderful city. You can walk the streets and drink the water. The roads are paved. We walked all over and the only time I was accosted it was a drunken white guy. Excellent restaurants and hotels. Interesting architecture. Fantastic history.

Part of history,relevant. We arrived on the only forecasted sunny day of the week to tour Robben Island only to see signs of "holiday-closed." We called prior to leaving our hotel, and no answer, nor no outgoing message saying they were closed. We then did book tickets for the next day, online.Quick boat ride out, and then loaded onto buses. No time to explore the island, we didn't even have time to visit their gift shoppe. This experience is well executed in a very scheduled fashion. Lovely to know that the 300+ island residents rely on this form of tourism to sustain them. We were happy to contribute to their sustainability to this piece of SA history. Worth the R230.

Robben Island. If you have the time in Cape Town, I would recommend spending half a day learning about the history of this infamous prison island. If the weather is good you are also treated to a magnificent view of Table Mountain over the bay. Younger kids may be bored but 10yrs and up will appreciate the tour. Go early in the morning, book online and choose the newer ferry the Sikhululekile, more comfortable and stable especially when it gets windy and the trip can get rocky.

Extremely Interesting. It can't be called a fun day out but Robben Island shines a light on the harshness of the apartheid era. It can be recommended to any one but wouldn't be interesting for anyone under the age 10 as certain areas of the tour may be difficult to understand.
A must see in CPT. An eye opener and a must do when your in Cape Town. Bewarned the 30 minute crossing can be quite rough.

OK but could be better. I visited Robben Island today for the first time, having lived in Cape Town since 1994 and in South Africa all my life. The format was basically as follows:1. Ferry ride from the Waterfront to Robben Island (30 minutes),2. Guided bus trip around the Island (1 hour 30 minutes),3. Guided tour of the Political Prisoners Prison itself (1 hour),4. Ferry ride from Robben Island back to the Waterfront (30 minutes).For the most part it was an interesting tour; but there was not much time to actually explore the island apart from sitting on a bus and being shuttled from one point-of-interest to another. When at any of these points-of-interest, there is a minor "scuffle" of buses to get to see the attraction. You hardly get out the bus at all, so most photos have to be taken from inside and the windows are not very clean, so the photos have interesting lines to them. Having said that, the guide on the bus was very entertaining and she gave a lot of useful information in a witty and charming manner. The guide in the prison itself was rather long-winded and seemed to draw the tour out far longer than the other groups. All-in-all, I would recommend doing the tour - both for tourists and for fellow South Africans.Having read some of the other reviews of this past month, I am very grateful that the ferry was working today and we made it out and back safely.

Very moving experience. We turned up on the day, at 10.30am and managed to secure seats for 11am ferry. Ride over was smooth and we found the staff to be very pleasant. On arrival to the harbour, you get on a bus, which drives you to all the key places on the island, with a guide explaining everything along the way. You get to stop at one point with the view of Table Mountain and lions head - a stunning picture! Then you get escorted round the prison building by an ex political prisoner - my husband am I were moved to tears by his story, I think his name wasstando mbata (not sure of spelling). The boat ride is 30 mins each way, leaving 2 hours for the tour. We didn't get time to go and see the penguins, and in places it did feel a bit rushed - to improve this tour they could add an extra 30-60 minutes as it would enable both the guides and customers to relax a bit more! If you are in Cape town you must do this - we nearly didn't go and were appalled by this fact once the tour was over! A real highlight of our trip we learnt a lot and as I said, found it to be a very moving and thought provoking experience

Ferry never runs. We were looking forward to going and bought tickets. We waited in the queue for ages then half an hour after the ferry was due to leave it was announced that an engine had failed. We rebooked for 3 days later and after hearing reports from locals about the unreliability of the ferry we checked before leaving our villa and found that it was still not working.

Fascinating. Lots of mixed reviews from other people below but I have to say we had a fascinating visit. The ferry ride was warm and comfortable, the tour round the island on the bus was interesting and well-led by the guide - and included a stop-off for stunning views of Table Mountain across the water. The prison tour was well-conducted by the former prisoner and we had all the time we wanted to view Mandela's cell. A fascinating visit.

Important site to visit. You must buy tickets in advance from the V&A Waterfront offices. Once the maximum number of passengers of the ferry is filled - you can't attend.The guides on the island are ex-convicts, political prisoners that spent time in the prison during the apartheid period. You get to hear first-hand about the life on the Island.The cell in which Nelson Mandela was locked is the main attraction - it is a 2X2m concrete cell.There is a special view of Cape Town with the Table Mountain as the background - bring a zom camera.Although not serving as a prison any more, the claustrophobic atmosphere of a prison is well preserved. This is a must-see place for anyone who support democracy and equal rights to all people

Very Poor Service. We live in Cape Town and have been hearing some very bad reports about the Robben Island trip, things like the tour itself is not very good, the boat service is unreliable and the staff rude. All of this is very sad as this is perhaps the most important bit of recent South African history and the thing nearly every tourist to the country wants to see and further more should see in order to learn from the experience. But we have had a number of people who have stayed with us who have failed to be able to make the visit, not through their own fault but by cancellation of boats. The most recent example was our son and girlfriend who had booked and paid to visit the island on Friday and only when they were about to get onto the boat did they find out that it had been cancelled, so they swopped their tickets for the 9am ferry on Tuesday. They got up early traveled to the port only to find that that ferry had been cancelled and no one had informed them, despite having emails and various telephone numbers to contact them by. To boot the 11am ferry was fully booked and there was limited space on the 3pm ferry, then no space at all for the next 5 days. To top it all the staff were absolutely down right rude, almost arrogant. This is not the way to run a world heritage site, its not the way to treat tourists who have travelled half way around the world to see Robben Island and it certainly is not the way to delivery the historically important experience that Robben Island offers. Okay boats can break down, but there should be systems in place to make sure that all booked passengers get across to the island and others given warnings of cancellations, when people are here for a limited amount of time they cannot afford to spend days getting messed about by this poor service. Finally there is NO excuse for rude staff, this experience is one of the biggest shop fronts for modern South Africa having a lot of contact with locals and oversees visitors. On present performance the staff are giving a very sad impression of modern South Africa. If the staff don't want to work there find some that do, I imagine there would be a big queue of people waiting to work there. So if you are planning to visit Robben Island, book in advance, keep phoning to find out if the boats are running and hope you are told the truth because we were not and finally keep your fingers crossed that it will actually happen.

Absolutely appalling customer service. Well... what an experience. We arrived this morning ready for our scheduled 11am departure. We exchanged our web tickets on arrival at the customer service desk - the staff were surly with attitude for no apparent reason. Even a hello was too much trouble. We then hoped to walk around the various displays that were part of the departure point to pass away the 40 or so minutes before the ferry... EVERY feature was "out of order"; the auditorium on ground level was just turned off, the prisoners experience was roped off and the movie on the lower level also "out of order". The staff were sat on their computers on the lower levels behind a closed glass screen on facebook (for the full 40 minutes that we whiled away). No explanation about why all of these exhibitions happened to be closed. We then queued for 40 minutes to wait for our 11am ferry. At 10.55 we received our safety instructions from a member of staff and were ready to board... Lo and behold 5 minutes later an announcement was made - the ferry was cancelled. The announcement was muffled and most people stood around looking at each other asking what was happening. It turns out that a part was needed for the boat so it couldnt run. However, the boats the day before had been cancelled too. Why they had made 50 or so people wait around for a little under an hour the following day, and put them through a safety briefing, before announcing that the boat was still not working I have no idea. When I attempted to politely ask a member of the information desk team what was happening she put her hand in my face, turned round after tutting and then walked off to avoid having to answer anyone's questions. Absolutely appalling. Given what this museum represents the service and attitude of its staff is a crying shame.

Hard Labour. Attraction is hardly the word, but Robben island is definitely a place one should visit. This was where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for 18 years. The tours are conducted by former political prisoners - our coach guide was brilliant, but the internal guide lost most of us with his lecture, which almost caused us to miss the return boat. Nevertheless, the visit was a humbling experience.

Important part of South African History. For me being South African I was very excited to go to Robbin island as it is such an important part of my heritage. The tour is very well organised and informative, with a great ferry trip and great views of capetown . My biggest dissapointment is the fact that they have repainted and renovated the prison, which to me loses alot of its history, the prison cell numbers have even been painted over. I would have much preffered to see it in the condition that the actual prisoners were forced to stay in.

Not worth visiting. Despite the burdened history of this place, it’s not really worth while visiting it.When you arrive on the island, you’re driven around in busses (you can not explore the island on foot) for a boring tour across the island. At the end, we were able to visit the prison complex but our guide (an ex inmate) was clearly having an off-day. At the end of the tour he felt the need of telling us he was really disappointed in us all because he had the strong feeling we were not paying respect at all – no idea what he meant, and neither did anyone else of the other 80 or so people in the group. Maybe he was disturbed because some people asked questions, but isn’t this just showing appreciation and involvement in the place? Anyway, even despite the guide, Robben Island was probably one of the most boring excursions I ever did.

An important piece of South African history. Having last visited South African when Mandela was imprisoned on Robben Island it was good to come back and see the place first-hand. A very interesting tour. Boats departs from the pier just behind the clock tower and takes about 20 minutes to get there. You may not want to rush with the others and sit on top as the winds can be very strong and the temperature cool. The crossing can be rough if the waves are high. Sit on the second deck and then you can step out on the back for some nice views without committing to the upper deck. Tour is 2 parts. First on the bus with a local guide who explains all of the main sites. Then you get off and have a tour of the main political prison with an ex-prisoner. The island tour was too fast and we would have enjoyed some more stops along the way. The prisoner tour was interesting and you felt the emotion of having someone who had stayed in the cells show you around vs a young tour guide. A living testimony to an uglier time in the country's history.If you want to visit the penguins when the prison tour ends hurry along towards the pier and then veer to your left and at the end is a covered platform where you can see them. We were the only ones in our group to do so. Binoculars or a powerful zoom lens would help.Tip: Book online and do so early on in your visit to Cape Town as if the water is too rough to go and the tour is cancelled you can re-schedule for another time. The same rule applies to visiting Table Mountain! It is apparently also the only place in the world where one can view two UNESCO World Heritage sites at the same time.

A must see for Cape Town. No trip to Cape Town would be complete without visiting Robben Island (unless the seas are choppy). You should book in advance to be guaranteed a spot on the tour. 30 minutes by ferry from the V&A (Nelson Mandela gateway) with several tours a day. Once you arrive, you are allocated buses and a tour guide to show you around the island before being taken around the former prison by a former prisoner. You also get to see the cell where Nelson Mandela spent several years of his life.

Big disappointment. I was really looking forward to this day trip. What a disappointment! it is way too commercialized. Like cattle you are being stuffed into a boat, than on a bus that you are only allowed to exit at the coffee shop and then you are forced into a big prison cell with at least fifty others and forced to listen an hour to a guide that spoke English but was barely understandable. Therefore I missed 75% of what he was saying. Then you are pushed along Mandela's cell for just a minute because the next group is already waiting and off you go again, back on the boat again. Oh, and did I mention that they painted everything three years ago so it all looks brand new?!

unforgettable place. This is an amazing place to visit, a must for any visitor to do at least once. Our guide, a former inmate, spoke so powerfully it was very moving, and the guide on the coach was very knowledgable, able to comment on what every nationality on board our coach had contributed to the end of apartheid. for anyone old enough to remember those dark years, it is hard to imagine the mindset of the captors. Our only negative is that we felt rushed through the experience because of teh number of groups on site. we have friends who went there and were able to go into Mandela's cell, we had seconds to push our way to the front and take a picture through the bars. Speaking to a south african who was making her third visit, she said it was by far the least enjoyable experience due to being rushed around. That said, glad we made the effort. oh, and get there early if you want to be above deck on teh boat trip, quite a strong swell and not many seats up on top

Very good. Astonished by some of the negative reviews. This was one ov the highlights of our South Africa trip. Great guides - prior inmates - and excellent restoration and preservation all round. I thought a must-see..

Robbin Island. Every one should take a lesson from there. It was an eye opener. The tour was given by people that were prisoners as well and an academic that studies there. It is apiece of world history that should not be forgetten.

Well worth a visit. This is a must on your tour of Cape Town, we prebooked the ferry tickets with Cape Town Day Tours, which i would advise is a must as the queues are very long, the ferry journey was quite good on the outward part, but a bit choppy on the return, on arrival, you are taken by bus around the Island with a guide, who on our bus, relayed alot of information related to Robben Islands history, the second part is to be taken around by an ex inmate of the prision, i was amazed by his calmness when relaying information about his own experiences and those of other inmates, and reminded me of a grandfather figure, he obviously suffered greatly while imprisioned, and only for wanting the right to vote in his own country, make sure your camera is fully charged, as there are lots of photo's to take, and it is a humbling experience, but very recommended

worth doing once. Firstly let me say book in advance if you think you can just rock up and get a seat, guess again. I am a history nut so for me the place had meaning and how could you not admire a person like Nelson Mandela, but lets face it he is the reason you visit. As an attraction it could be alot better, you dont seem to have time to wander yourself around the island or the prison, just time to soak it up or reflect even, its go here and go there. dont get me wrong I am glad we visited and it was good but for the historical signifcance not really the attraction, I would recommend everyone visit, but it would not be a highlight of the trip and once is probably it.

Disappointing, rather do the wine route. When running the ferry to the island is modern, quick and comfortable. Remember to book before you go.Once arrived on the island you will be herded into a bus and taken around the various sights. Nelson Mandela's cell is a must see, but the rest is rather disappointing. The guides are supposedly ex inmates, however their facts aren't always factual, harping on the poor conditions - it was prison after all! What is particularly striking is that the cell walls have been re-painted removing the inmates graffiti. No use wondering what they wrote - it's all been whitewashed away.If you have a choice rather do something else.

A must do in Cape Town. Overall I would say the visit is a must-do if you are visiting South Africa and specifically Cape Town. The first part of the visit involves a ferry ride over to the island itself which was very confortable. The bus ride around the island was also confortable and informative if even the tour guide did seem to stray off-topic several times during the trip. For me, and the rest of our party we were more interested in knowing about the significance of the different buildings and places on the island rather than the sometimes complex histprocal relevance. The kids on the bus were really lost.The final part of the tour involved seeing the actual cell blocks with an ex-prisoner of the facility. This was quite amazing as we were given a very real look at the prison itself as well as alot of valuable and relevant information pertaining to prison life. At 220 Rand (about US$30) for an adult you could spend your money in many worse ways in SA.

Interesting historical place. Worth the trip if you have an afternoon in Cape Town, and have interest in the apartheid. I had read the 'Long walk to freedom' book by Nelson Mandela which made it even more interesting for me, however others I was with said it was still very interesting. I booked tickets online - http://www.webtickets.co.za/event.aspx?itemid=76219 - it seems you should do it at least a day ahead, or go to the ticket office.
Could be FAR better. Lots more could be done to make this far better. Did not enjoy the tour but would not miss the photo opportunity

Could and should be done a lot better. Robben Island certainly seems to split opinion on Tripadvisor. Either it's a World Heritage Site which really should not be missed because of its political significance or it's a tour in uncomfortable modes of transport which fails to fire up the imagination. I suspect it's a bit pot luck, depending on when you go and who your guides are.The sea was calm on the day we went and the buses on the island were perfectly comfortable, so we had no transport or seasickness problems. Seeing the island and visiting the prison was very interesting, thought provoking and certainly worth doing, but sadly, I came away rather disappointed. I felt that the full potential of the place had not really been exploited. Our first guide, on the coach, was rather too full of himself and eager to show everyone how important and how funny he was. As a result he failed to inspire us with a real sense of the history of the Island and all that happened there. The second guide, at the prison, rushed us through and seemed to be on autopilot and keen to get his bit done as quickly as possible. He was difficult to hear in these circumstances and he gave us too little time to contemplate the amazing resilience of Mandela and his colleagues and their appalling suffering. Obviously, it's a great idea to employ former prisoners to relate their experiences as guides, but I came away feeling that it could have been done so much better with a little more investment in training and in modern museum techniques and with a little more imagination.

Visiting Nelson Mandela's cell with a former inmate is a powerful experience.. The heart of this tour is the 45-50 minutes when a former polical prisoner here takes one through the political prisoner common cell room, explains life there, and then takes one to Nelson Mandela's solitary cell to understand his living conditions. The former prisoner was articulate and moving, projecting strongly for the 40 some visitors in our group. This part of the tour is supplemented by a 30 minute boat ride to and from the island (in nice weather go to the upper deck, with beautiful views of the city and Table Mountain). The 50 minutes touring the island is pleasant with an engaging guide but only context. The experience does not attempt to set forth the broader battle to end apartheid or even the negotiations of Mandela's eventual release - for that one goes, ideally, to the Apartheid Museum in Johannesburg. But what it does it does well. Book on-line in advance to be assured a place. The line to board is long but at the set time it moves amazingly quickly through a light security check and on board.

Not good.. Huge disappointment.Hopefully in time, they will make this into a great museum. Right now, it is terrible. The first 1.5 hours you are trapped on a bus with 50 other people while the guide talks about the history of the island (I get the irony). It was hot and miserable. We were stopped in the sun and the bus was shut off for most of the time without A/C. The remaining portion of the tour is guided by an ex inmate. This was not good - we could barely understand his memorized speech. And he kept repeating portions of his memorized speech.They should spend money on making it a self-guided tour with signage, displays, interactive kiosks, headset-driven tours - make it more of a self-guided tour. Don't trap people on a bus and force them to listen to nonsense. We didn't learn anything from this tour.Also consider that the 30-40 minute boat ride to and from the island can be pretty rough depending on the seas.

Horrible, horrible experience - did not even get to see the Island. My family and I had the most horrible experience of our Cape Town vacation attempting to tour Robben Island. I actually shudder to even hear the name. My husband and I bought tickets online because we heard it sells out in advance. They charge for every individual regardless of age, so we had to buy a ticket for our 1-yr.-old daughter, too. USD $70 total for the three of us. I did not read the fine print that the tickets are non-refundable, non-transferable, etc. and that you have to show up minimum 10 min. prior to departure; in our case 10:50 for an 11:00 a.m. departure. We found ourselves running down the boardwalk the morning-of with minutes to spare until 11:00, and the departure museum/office in sight with the huge boat readying to leave the dock. As we were almost in front of the venue, the front wheel of the three-wheel jogging stroller I was running with, pushing my daughter in, caught between two planks in the boardwalk. The stroller came to an immediate halt and flipped over forwards, and I fell over it. Diners at a cafe beside us gasped, I quickly righted the stroller and found my baby daughter screaming, with a cut on her forehead and quite shaken, but luckily not seriously injured. My husband and I tried to console her, as the tour ship began to pull away from the dock. We walked the last few yards to the building, my daughter sobbing the whole way, and explained to the ticket office that we just missed this boat, our daughter just had an accident, and could we please stand by for the next tour? The women at the ticket counter were rude and simply said no. We explained again, and said we were running here and didn't realize boarding opened prior to 11:00; was there any way to transfer our ticket to the later tour, or to stand by for another day during our vacation? They again simply said no. We asked to speak to a manager, and we were told she "was busy." We were very upset at this point, my daughter was still shocked and crying, and they refused to get the manager. They got someone on the phone, and said it was the manager, but one of the ticket ladies seemed to be in a casual conversation with her (in a local language). We waited, but they did not pass us the phone or seem to be talking to her about our situation. I was sickened by this treatment, hurt by the loss of $70 without even a "sorry, I wish there was something we could do, but those are the rules, in fine print right on your ticket", and upset about my daughter being hurt and for nothing. We didn't wait any longer and just left, feeling quite disgusted by the whole operation. I will likely never have a chance to visit Cape Town again in my life, and if I do, I still would never go on this tour, I am still offended and appalled by the treatment we received.
Worth a visit.. The best part is that the guides are former inmates. Very interesting perspective.

Politicall Significant. Extremely inportant site to see where Mandela and so many other leaders and participants in the struggle for independance and equality built their new country. Book ahead by at least one day (more during the tourist season) on their website. The journey starts from the Capetown Waterfront and proceeds by ferry to Robben Island. You transfer to buses and do not get off. At the end you have a conducted tour through the prison and back to the ferry. Outstanding moments were seeing the cave where the first government "in excile" was formed protected by the nonintrusion into lav policy under aparteid! Great moment for a political junkie. Second was the tomb of a major iman whose death lead to an increase in African muslims. The role played by rugby-soccer in developing national leadership and global attention explains the SA passion for the game. The negatives are that the control by the former prisoners and gvernment guides leads to long periods of tedium as the polemics are beaten into your head. As one who remembers Sharpesville and Bilko and other great leaders who died in the 1960s, it was depressing to be harrangued. The lack of opportunity to get off the bus for photographs and the inability to see and be guided to birds and nature was also a challenge. In all a worth the experience.
Can be a rough ride on a small boat.. Not to my liking but covered in history but be warned you are not allowed to go off on your own and must stay with the tour upon arrival.

Worth the boat trip. The tour takes about 3-4 hours and includes a 30 min boat trip which was very pleasant with views across the cape peninsula and table mountain. Once there you are put a bus and taken around the island stopping at various points of interest. Our guide was a nice enough person but tended to entertain the bus with jokes about nationalities rather than givng us the history of the place, so much so, that our tour of the actual jail had to be cut short due to a lack of time which is ashame as the jail guide was a former inmate with lots of interesting points to make. With a better bus guide we would have rated higher.

Good tour but not for kids(as you have to pay for small kids and babies and it is a long time on a bus and a boat). We found it very interesting. Boat ride was fun (if you have sea legs and great way to see cape town). However the second part of the tour was spent on a bus for over a hour circling the island with standing room only and very little air. Awful if you have kids so my advice is don't do it with them. Also don't sit near to people eating fish and chips on the boat as you'll see their stomach contents by the end of it!

Don't say you were not warned. One day, this important historical site will have the intelligent and respectful tour program it deserves. That day is not yet here. If you are imagining the informative tour of Alcatraz Island, or the deeply subdued and respectful tours of Nazi camps. think again. What we have here is more like Comedy Traffic School. Trapped on a crowded and hot bus for 45 minutes with a self-aggrandizing guide channeling a bad Shakespearean actor, I wanted to scream or possibly commit suicide. By the time we were "allowed" off the bus to tour the facility on foot with a very dignified ex-inmate, it was too late. Unless you have a compelling reason to make this trip, I urge you to make another choice. Also, the trip over is on a closed in and seemingly not very well maintained catamaran. These boats can make you seasick if it is not an exceptionally calm day.

A 'must do' experience, gritty and thought provoking.. If you're in Cape Town, Robben Island is a trip you just have to do. It's gritty and thought provoking - not for young children. You come away surprisingly uplifted by the positive message of how the human spirit triumphed over oppression.The trip consists of 3 parts - a half hour each way boat trip which can be choppy (best time to go is first thing in the morning), followed by a 45 min bus tour of the island, then a tour of the prison itself. The guides are ex political prisoners who speak with great passion about Nelson Mandela, the prison and its political significance. Robben Island isn't a theme park, so don't expect a polished tourist experience. Some of the guides have heavy accents which can be difficult to understand, the buses are overcrowded and the prison tours sometimes resemble a scrum as 40 people try to cram themselves into narrow corridors and small spaces. But don't let that put you off - it is somehow appropriate to the raw, real life experience that this place represents.

Very inspiring!. Robben Island was amazing! The tour starts off with a bus ride around the island, stopping at various buildings, where the guide discusses the history and purpose of each. There's a chance to stop at a shop/bathroom stop perched on the rocks where you have a lovely view of Cape Town & Table Mountain in the distance.The tour continues around to the quarry and then you are dropped off at the maximum security prison. There an ex-political prisoner greets you and guides you through the different sections of the prison. All the guides provide a very honest account of political struggle and everyday life of the prison. They are also willing to answer any question you pose them so don't be shy! I was impressed with the manner in which the whole tour was conducted. There was a sense of peace and reflection, not resentment or prejudice over what had occurred during apartheid. It was very inspiring to be able to talk to an ex-politcal prisoner in person and see that he was not bitter from the experience but celebrating freedom and hopeful for the future. It was also a great learning experience and the guides were very knowledgeable in how other countries had provided various support for the freedom struggle over the years. I even learnt what my own country had contributed.All in all a very inspiring experience and one I thoroughly enjoyed!

A Must See if Cape Town. It would be a mistake to not take this trip. The boat ride over and back is very pleasant and the tour was terrific. Ex prisoners and guards live on the island with their families so it is an important lesson in the potential for healing. The guides were also ex prisoners so that added another dimension to the trip.

One of the sights you must see, but once is probably enough. we pre-booked the first sailing while the day was still fresh. Fantastic views of CT and Table Bay. Having ex-inmates as tour guides both on the coaches and round the prison adds a personal feeling of what the experience must have been although some visitors may have difficulty understanding. One has a sense of being rather uncomfortable hearing what went on here and its notoriety which has been brought out by Mandela's presence. Also that it was once a leper colony is often overlooked. Certainly one of the visits one has to make when in CT.

Very disapointing. Took a group of students from overseas on numerous occassions and they all say the same thing boring. The guide waffled on and on and they could understand one word he said as his accent was very strong. All feel would be better with audio visuals in there own languages like the Huguenot museum in Franshoek. They only enjoyed the boat trip

Not what I expected. The biggest drawcard of this place of course is Nelson Mandela's prison cell. Well I have heard that this cell has been pointed out in different locations to different people before. My experience there left me with a bitter taste in my mouth. I went there to see what it was all about. Experience and see the history behind what made a great man like him what he is today. In stead I got a very one sided bitter tour from an ex inmate of the prison which constantly focused on the brutality of the time (Which I do not deny) and all the wrongdoing. In stead of it being factual, historical and informative. Maybe ex inmates are not the best choice for tour guides. Robber Island has a lot to offer in a spectacular view of Table Bay harbor and wildlife on the island, and this is the part I enjoyed most.

Terrible guides - unintelligeble and arrogant. The tour was ruined by the terrible tour guides on the Island. The one guide kept talking about himself, and droned on about about irrelevant details and name dropped all the time and didnt give us enough information about the history and Mandela. He was really arrogant and strutted around like a celebrity. When he finished off a number of other tourists sighed with relief and when he kept talking about how important he was a lot of us were rolling our eyes at each other. The other guide in the prison was hard to understand and virtually unintelligible. This was so disappointing as the tour guides in SA were pretty awesome everywhere else. We read in the papers that the tour guides based on Robben Island have been striking for more pay - but unless they smarten up their narrative they shouldnt be rewarded at all. Terrible ambassadors for SA and Robben Island !

Struggled to understand the on-site local guides!. This attraction could benefit from the investment of Audio Guides for foreign tourists as the SA locals they use as guides are sometimes difficult to understand (and as a Brit, my first language is English!). Despite this, a visit to Robben Island (where Nelson Mandela was incarcerated for 27 years) should NOT be missed.

Historically interesting. Robben Island is interesting from an historical perspective, and learning a bit about the anti-apartheid struggle. I personally did not find it a main attraction of Cape Town, but definitely worth seeing if you want a more in depth view of the history of the country.

Book ahead and go first thing in the morning. With tickets in much demand best to call and book ahead. Also best to travel on the first ferry out in the morning as the sea is at its calmest. Lovely tour of the prison premises. Very moving to see the tiny alcove at the quarry in which the prisoners swapped news and shared their education!

A piece of history worth seeing but it could be much more. We went on this tour full of expectation and whilst it was interesting (and sobering to think that this was happening in our lifetime) we felt that ther could have been much more to offer. Buses were crowded and the guide difficult to hear and understand. The walk through the prison was hurried and unless you kept pace alongside the guide you could not hear a thing. Is it worth doing -yes as it is an important time / lesson in history but do not expect too much.

You should go.. Booked tickets on a whim after passing the Nelson Mandela Gateway building on the V&A waterfront. I had been told you always had to book weeks in advance, however, I was able to get tickets on the Friday for the trip on Sunday. The boat looked pretty full on the day, though, so maybe I was just lucky.The trip starts with a coach tour round the island. You don't get much of a chance to get off until you arrive at Robert Sobukwe's house. He was placed under house arrest here under a special clause passed by the government. This I found one of the more moving parts of the tour, as the letters he wrote to his family are on display and some of the nobility and bravery of the man comes through. The other part I found very moving was seeing the lime quarry where the prisoners were made to work, in the blinding conditions which were visible even from the coach.The last part of the tour is around the maximum security prison itself. It has not been tarted up at all - you won't find any actors in prison uniforms pretending to be Nelson Mandela, or anything tacky like that. In fact, it is easy to believe that only yesterday it was still being used as a prison. Even Mandela's old cell has not been in any way glamourised. This is a good decision - the events are too recent and still too raw to be trivialised.It was hard to follow what the tour guide in the prison was saying because of the numbers on the tour and the fact he had a strong accent.
