However, he did his best and it is striking to think that you are being shown round by a former inmate. Perhaps people could be given something to read which might help them follow the tour better? I'm thinking especially of non-native English speakers and people who are hard of hearing.There is a different atmosphere on Robben Island, which my guidebook called "otherworldly". It certainly retains its memories and its ghosts. It may not be a laugh a minute, but I don't think anyone would regret coming here.
history comes alive. have read about robben island, but now really understand what happened here
This is the one trip you must do!. Book ahead online as tickets get sold out quickly. Very interesting guides who really make the trip. Sea can get a bit choppy but sick bags are provided??

The most. Memorable day we had. Visited with two young children. The organisation is very impressive. After arriving you transfer to coaches which manage to tour the island in a way that you never see other groups. The tour of the maximum security jail led by a former inmate is very moving.

Very poor experience. Roben island bus tour excellent, prison tour too rushed and tour guide was terrible. The initial tour starts on a 1 hr bus tour around the island, this was very good with a lot of history information. The tour then goes to the prison with an ex-prisoner, our tour guide was awful, he gave very little information and we were rushed around the prison. All in all if you are stuck for time in cape town then I'd do something else.
Nice but not. Visit for historical purposes only - bit like the German concentration camps. Necessary when near but not exactly nice
Historical Catchup. This place is very interesting to learn something about the South African history.

The beauty of history. The boat ride (preferably on a windless day) is great. The tour of the island is conducted by a previous prisoner. It is heartbreaking to hear the stories of what it was like, but what a relief that it is no longer a prison for people fighting for justice. I love going there because it reminds me of the wonderful transition from and apartheid state to a democracy!!

BREATHE TAKING!!. Even though this was my sixth or possibly seventh time visiting the island, I am always in awe of the silent yet aggressive life on that island. It not only demands your full and complete attention, it captures your entire being when you listen to the history of the island. A MUST FOR EVERY TOURIST!!!

Not for everyone. I believe this tour is not for everyone. I would recommend you to go, if you like history, politics, do not get bored with long speeches. The tour takes around 3 and a half hours.- You take the boat to go to the Robben Island, - get on the bus, in the bus the tour guide takes you to the jail. Meanwhile, he gives a long speech about history and politics.-In the jail, an ex inmate welcomes you and gives another long speech, shows you the cell of Nelson Mandela, you take a picture.-take the boat back to Waterfront.I hope this info helps you to decide to join
WILL NOT GO BACK AGAIN. Found the staff to be very aggressive. Dirty. Did not enjoy the 'over the top' racism
Very disappointed. The island needs a good clean or a new attarction be-sides the prison, tour is to quick

A must see. A must see for everybody who visits SA. A very well organized tour. You take a boat (a catamaran. make sure you get there early to get the best seats on the top of the boat otherwise you will sit 30 min indoors), then there is an hour bus tour with a really good and knowledgeable guide. You then arrive at the prison area where you get to visit the cell of N.Mandela. this part of the tour is done by an ex-prisoner which is quite sad to be honest. Please leave them tips as the unemployment rate in this country is 40%.

Interesting especially when an old prisoner talks about life on the island.. Go in good weather .....the sea can be rough. In suny weather wear a hat and lots of spf ......bring water. Go - its a must do for first timers in cape town!

Makes you appreciate the humanity of Nelson Mandela and others. We met a former inmate now a senior politician who was imprisoned with Mandela and having spent a few hours talking with him had a better insight than most as to what treatment they received, then seeing it for real the day after added to our experience.The fact that they won in the end gave them the humanity to if not forgive to not seek retribution when they came to power.

A thought provoking experience. we did a day trip from the V&A waterfront once you get there you get on a coach, our guide was fantastic he knew Nelson Mandela and had escorted some very famous visitors, most of the guides are ex political prisoners, he was very informed, the island is very interesting and the last place you visit is main prison and see the cell where Nelson Mandela was held.well worth a visit.
Historical heavyweight. For the more politically minded what better than Nelson Mandela's prison cell? The boat trip is worthwhile if the weather is good.
Why bother?. What a shame!! The ferry doesn't work properly, the prison is neglected and the "guide" are doubtful. Not at all the gracious world heritage site it can be.

A lost opportunity. A very moving place to visit, but as a tour, a very disappointing experience. For a place that is so significant in the history of the country, and rightly a World Heritage Site, the management are doing an extremely poor job of realising the opportunities to explain that history and to really inform, educate and engage visitors. Obviously everyone wants to see and hear about the prison and when you eventually get to it, the prison guides themselves are amazing and inspiring. But the problem is there is very little time for that. We spent about 45 mins of the hour-long visit either waiting for or sitting on a hot, crowded bus trundling round the island looking at other (not very interesting) things. The guide on the bus was terrible. Much of his commentary had nothing to do with Robben Island, or consisted of lame and irrelevant jokes and anecdotes. Cringeworthy. And unbeknownst to us (there was no explanation at all during the very disorganised and time-consuming bus loading process) half our passengers were Swiss so everything the guide said (including all the stupid jokes) was then repeated by the Swiss tour guide leader. And because neither had a microphone the bus had to stop for each doubled-up commentary otherwise the guides could not be heard above the engine. Without air-con this meant it was ridiculously hot, and that the tour took ages. All the non-Swiss speakers on the bus were cranky and many actually complained about how long it was taking, but he just brushed this off and carried on. When we made a toilet stop we actually got off and found a different bus – the guide on the second one was much better – and had a microphone...The tour of the prison itself was by a former prisoner who was great, and gave a bit of insight into what that experience was like. This was indeed very moving. But it felt quite disrespectful for this part of the tour to be so short, rushed and crowded. There was no time to look around on our own before we had to rush back to the ferry.We were also very surprised that there is no museum here, or even any small exhibition (even though it is called Robben Island museum). This is such a missed opportunity. We were imagining what a great museum could be built on this site – telling the history of Robben Island and linking to the broader anti-apartheid struggle, with pictures, explanation, videos, artefacts and so on. People could then wander around (in their own time!) and get a deeper insight. From comments we overheard from other visitors, many people are quite ignorant about the context and history and are just doing this tour because it’s a ‘must-do’. A well-designed, interactive museum would really help to educate and engage people, meaning they might get a lot more out of their visit than being able to say ‘I saw Nelson Mandela’s cell’.We came away saddened and perplexed by the massive lost opportunity here. This really is a shameful way to manage such a significant site.
Interesting and historic. Very interesting tour given by ex political prisoners who actually stayed on Robben Island, the experience will be depending on the actual guide you get on the day.
Worth the trip. So much History and something so different to do when on holiday

You have to go!. There's just no question that you have to visit while you are in town. The tours are structured really well and give a humbling insight into what life was like for the people kept here. Yet the focus is always on the positive example that they set and the triumph of the human spirit they achieved. Make sure to book tickets in advance as they can fill up early.

Must see attraction - but could be better. Robben Island is where Nelson Mandela spent much of his time in prison,along with hundreds of Black political prisoners (the White prisoners were kept elsewhere).Because of the history of apartheid, this is a must see attraction. The boat journey out can be an adventure in itself! The visit starts with a bus tour around this small island giving some of the history and then moves on to a short tour of some of the prison cell blocks, guided by a former prisoner. Our guide was a very quiet man who gave a very low key account of life at the prison, but there is no doubting that this was a life of hardship with long hours in a bunkroom with 40 plus prisoners together, initially sleeping on the concrete floor with a thin mattress, and limited and boring food, with hard labour digging lime on part of the island.The whole tour is well done, but I would like to have had a bit more time and found out a bit more. Some of the written material on view points to the hardships and instances of brutality, but I came away feeling that there was more of a story to tell.

Success is a failure. Since our last visit some years ago, we returned with our grown-up sons and their partners as part of a family holiday to the Cape. Access to and from the island is much better than the old ferry, but it means far greater numbers of visitors. Once on the island, most of the time was spent on the bus and although the live commentary was by ex-inmates much of it was nothing to do with Robben Island. Time in the prison itself was minimal and there was a crush as busload after busload arrive at Mandela's cell with only a few minutes between - so you get about 5 seconds to peer in before moving on. A disappointing visit compared to the 'old' days.

Ispirational. The boat trip over was a bit bumpy for some people, but we loved being on the water even in the light rain. The bus tour was great: we had a very informative and personable guide who gave us much information aand answered all our questions. Our guide through the prisons was not as good: too rote, memorized talk, didn't wait for the people at the end of the line before starting his talk in the next area, didn't ask if anyone had any questions, and rushed off at the end after accepting tips at the door. The bus tour guide was the best! Penguins at the end were distant and it was raining again. Still, an inspiring trip with lots of history.

If it wasnt something you 'had to do' I would strongly dissuade anyone from going. Terrible.The groups were massive, the busses unco-ordinated.The guides were unmitigatingly useless. Their English was appaling and their ability to lead a tour-group was non-existent.I think everyone hated it but were afraid to express their intense displeasure because of the 'importance' of the site. If Robben island wasnt something you 'had to do' from a cultural heritage perspective, I would strongly dissuade anyone from doing it.I cant believe it can be so pathetic given its touristic importance.The best thing about this attraction is the ferry-ride back to Cape-town
Modern History. Really good value tour. Worth it just for the views of Table Mountain from the ferry alone.

It was ok, but not really a must do in CT. I must say the boat ride was the best part, because you get beautiful views to Table Mountain. The boat was packed, so was the tour. First there is a 30 min bus tour and then a 1 hour tour through the prison. Then they let you wait for 45 min until you can get back on the boat, perfect time to buy expensive drinks or souveniers.You have the feeling you have to tip every guide all the time. Some of them make a hell lot of money. In my group were 50 people, everyone gave something.I dont know if you have seen places like dachau or auschwitz, robben island is paradise island. The history of this place is interesting but its enough information if you read it in wiki.

You feel the hurt the man endured!. If you are a Nelson Mandela fan and who is not???? then this is a must trip. The guided tour is both informative and witty. You can see the actual tiny cell where Madiba was imprisoned as well as the whole prison. It's a very moving and great experience.

Go to Alcatraz - its way better. We were told to book in advance which we did and when we arrived for the sailing, we waited 45 minutes before boarding. Once we arrived we were put on buses which went around the island and showed a couple of interesting site (quarry where Mandala worked). The we did a brisk walk through the maximum security prison lead by an old inmate. This was like walking through a old warehouse with a guy telling you what it was like.At 5:00pm as we were about to leave, the boat was loading people on board and we were told we had enough time to go to the toilet etc. We came back 5 minutes later and people were rushing to the boat and then an announcement came over saying the boat was for staff only. That left 50 people on the wharf with the shops both closed and no shelter. The 1 person at information kept saying "a boat is on its way" for 45 minutes. Finally a boat turned up and took us back but by this time the sun was setting and it was one of the older boats with little in door space. Due to the delay we had to wait in the harbour in freezing winds while a cruise ship left.When we went back the next day, the weekend manager looked shocked and gave us email addresses to contact and when we got back home we sent of the emails and didn't get any response for a couple of months despite repeated emails.If you have the choice go to Alcatraz over Robbin Island, much better tour and way better organised.

Plumbing new depths of BAD. Have you been to Robben Island? If so you will probably agree with me. If not, you are warned that it wil be very disappointing. I have been there on the standard tourist trip and also on a behind the scenes tour courtesy of a friend who tendered to be service provider. Virtually anything that can goes wrong, does go wrong, more often than not due to lousy attitude of staff and management who think they have one of the seven wonders of the world. Recently the overpaid staff of Robben Island went on strike demanding a 40% or more salary increase, and that they be allowed to ALL take a couple of weeks leave over the Christmas/New Year period, which is their busiest period of the year. Hello, it's a tourist operation.....they do half their turnover in two months of the year! There is so much that COULD be done with the Island as an important part of the history of SA, and particularly the overthrowing of apartheid. As a South African I was overjoyed at the overthrow of apartheid, I am saddened and embarrassed by what is presented to tourists as Robben Island. Everything at the Island, the gateway, and the administration of the operation is done amateurishly and badly. It really is a mess. As a sneak preview of the standards you might expect, have a look at any of the last few annual reports, available online. Its a badly run "business" and , again, just about anything that can go wrong, does, and quite seriously.

Historic. Interesting visit starts with the boat out and a bus tour then a walking tour with an ex political prisoner, how people could have treated others in such away leaves you stunned but the ability of those mistreated to forgive is simply heroic

Great impressing history but the trip was not exceptional. If you go to Cape Town you need to go to Robben Island; that is for sure. If you buy the tickets it will be around 220 rand which will take you on a 3.5 bour trip: boat to Robben Island (30 minutes); a tour in the old prison with a old prisoner as the tourguide; a tour over the island in a bus with guide as well and in the end about 30 minutes of spare time before the boat returns. Bookings are advised during peak season.Most impressive is the tourguide in the prison off course. Every guide and ex-prisoner has his own story and these stories are shocking. The tour in the prison itself is not that impressive; there is not that much to see. I would advise to do some reading in the airplane to South Africa to make your experience more intense and maybe ask the guide some interesting questions.The tour on the island is a bit boring; you will see some spots with: "here the prisoners did this and that" and you will end up at the best point to see Cape Town and take some pictures.Final tip: at the end, when you have some minutes: walk to the 'left (prison in the back, looking to the ocean); after the man-made harbour there is a small rock-beach; populated with penguins!

Wonderful insight into 'life' on the island. An excellent insight into what was unfortunately not to distant history of the political prisoners. The guide himself was a political prisoner and gave a frank account of life inside. You can't visit Cape Town without a visit to Robben Island
Bit disappointed. Great to go and read up on history, but tour could have been better and tour guide did not seem very interested in showing us around.

Over-rated. The boat was very full and noisy. Unfortunately it was a windy day, and the seas rough. Several people were seasick. The island itself was fairly interesting, especially the fact that in the 1700's Muslims were imprisoned there, and that the Cape Governor General had a mansion there.I believe that some of the tales told by the prison guides were "tall"

Always an informative tour. The Sikhululekile is relatively comfortable. The last time we went it was very stormy with biggish swells but still enjoyable on the boat. I have been on the tour a couple of times and always enjoy the bus tour round the island the most as it is very informative about the island history. The tour of the prison is fine but can be made or broken by the tour guide (who are supposedly ex prisoners). Some are quite good getting across details but some are not. Anyway it is definitely worth a visit.

Must see. I have no idea how and why "Robben Island" made is top 20. It should definitely be one of the main things people do in CT. You have to book a ticket online at least 3-4 weeks in advance to secure a place especially in December. You dont want to miss out this.

A Chilling Glimpse into History. Visitors are transported to Robbin Island by a high-speed ferry. A wonderful, thought-provoking view of an Alcatraz-like prison off of the coast of Cape Town. Learn about the cruelty and brutality of the Apartheid system, that led to the empowerment of many of the men that shaped the new South Africa we have today. One of the most famous prisoners being Nelson Mandela, the first democratically elected president of South Africa. The cell where he was imprisoned is on display. There is an eery feeling walking through the prison cells and yards; also see the limestone quarry where Mandela worked while imprisoned. A very interesting and must do attraction when in Cape Town. Very important lesson in history that must be experienced by all.
get your tickets well in advance!!. It was fully booked for 6 days before we could get a ticket.
Great History. This is a place I will visit every time I make a trip to Cape Town. So much rich history...I walked way haven learned some great life principles. It left me with a WOW! in my mind.

Robben Island Tour. Well done tour begins with a ferry ride to the island with hard to hear video narration of the island’s history (get in line early to get a seat on the upper deck!). Our bus tour around the island was interesting as our bus driver was informative and descriptive as she pointed out the sights. The tour ends with an ex prisoner guided walk through former prison cells. Interesting but lacking in depth as our tour guide was not forthcoming with details and chose to respond to questions instead. Worth doing – quality of tour will depend on your guide.

A Trip to Avoid. On arrival on the island as part of a large group (3/400 people), it became very evident that the event had been poorly organised. Insufficient buses were available to transport visitors from the harbour area to the prison site and those that couldn't find a seat had to walk. No-one seemed to be in overall control and instructions from the local reps (no uniforms or badges of identification) were conflicting and led to confusion. The tour was split into smaller groups to visit the prison; however, the numbers were still excessive and people were jammed into rooms to try and listen to the explanation from the guide - local accent and difficult to understand. Insufficient time was allowed to explore places of interest, I assume because of the sheer numbers involved and the need to move people through quickly. Refreshment facilities were very limited, as was the time available to make use of them. Altogether, a poor experience and not recommended.

A deeply historical site. "The Island" is a deeply significant part of all South African experiences, and provided the transport is working (check first) you will have a fairly rough but interesting boat trip out to the island. Once there you view Cape Town from a totally new angle. Inevitably, your tour guide will give you a highly politicized trip around the cells and environs (you can't leave the bus) but this is a MUST if you have an interest in SA history. Unless, management on the island could be greatly improved.

Book early and worth visiting. We arrived at the ticket office to find a sign saying they were booked for the next 3 days - I was leaving in 2. But, I asked at the ticket office anyway if they had some cancelled tickets and luckily they did! They are getting cancellations all the time so it is worth asking.The trip out was quite rough - I would take sea sickness tablets next time.We started on a bus tour of the island with the head guide - he was a good talker and talked about each person's countrys link to the island. We moved from site to site and he explained about the locations.We were a little late for the prison tour but the guide (an ex prisoner) was able to show and explain about the conditions and we could see Mr Mandela's cell.Another rough trip backWorth seeing - glad we had that guide although he did pick on the Australians because of our gum trees which the Brits had introduced.
Wonderful time. A fantastic experience starting with the boat trip across to the island. Then a guided tour around the island before finishing off at the jail tour.
A must!. The tour was given by someone who was in prison with Mandela. You could feel his pain! Don't miss this part of history.

Overrated. Of all the things we did in Cape Town this was the least exciting. Yes, it's a site of enormous historical significance, however you don't really learn much considering it takes about 3.5 hours (1 hour of that is on the boat to and from the island)The tour of the jail is conducted by an ex prisoner, which, if you think about it should be amazing but we didn't find that. The gentleman we had was very difficult to understand - I zoned out several times while he was talking. A script might help.The second part is a bus tour which takes you round the island (you stay on the bus the whole time) Some people seemed to love and were scrambling to take pictures of everything (the school, the post-office, the mine) However, the guide didn't explain anything about them and for us going to the island without knowing too much about it, seeing these places was fairly meaningless.The most interesting part of the tour was seeing inside the jail and imagining what life must have been like for prisoners.If you are pushed for time in Cape Town and are not already au fait with South African history I would personally say this is something you could miss.

Evocative, thought provoking - pity about the conveyor belt set-up. I had sent e-mails requesting information to the Robben Island website - no reply. We went to book tickets in advance and we were disappointed by the staff - they are working at a site that is of such importance to the country and they seemed to consider visitors as a bit of a nuisance, the person behind the information desk seemed far more interested in her newspaper than in my question. The boat to the island is packed with people, it's a pleasant ride and on arrival you board a bus which takes you around the island. You get a feel for the place - the lime stone quarry where prisoners were working with the most primitive tools in the heat. You see the cave where those unable to read and write were taught basic skills by those who could. Part of the island is inhabited today though the local school was closed a couple of years ago.The second part of the tour takes you to the maximum security prison block - the tours there are conducted by ex prisoners - ours was a gentle man with a great sense of humour who had spent 5 years as a prisoner on the island. His presentation was matter of fact, there was no drama - but the place speaks for itself. On the floor were a couple of rugs the size of bath towels. He pointed to those to explain that this was the 'bedding' until an international commission stepped in and the rugs were replaced by bunk beds. You see Mandela's cell, you can walk the long corridors, you can enter the cells, you can walk around the courtyards where prisoners were allowed to enjoy the fresh air for 30 minutes ..........It is a special place - but it could be so much better:(1) the staff at the ticket office and in the information centre could do with a bit of training - they are not selling tickets to a fun fair, this is a place of national (and international) importance and they should feel part of it(2) the drive in a bus with lots of other people - and in our case a number of young and very unruly children - made me feel that we were part of a conveyor belt tourism, smaller groups would be much better. Discouraging visitors to take small children would be even better.(3) the walk through the prison would be better if it was done in silence - large group make a lot of noise (4) a creche for small children on the island would be great - the presentation by our wonderful guide was interrupted by squealing children who were too young to understand, who were bored and whose parents seemed too inconsiderate to care I could not help feeling that with a bit of thought, care and attention to detail a visit to Robben Island could become one of those experiences that stay with you forever. I am delighted that we went but the set-up was not pleasant.

Worth the visit. If you want to learn about the activism and abolishment of apartheid lead by revered Nelson Mandela and see where he was imprisoned for 18 of his 27 years in jail. The ex-inmates conduct the tours of the jail...fascinating. And great view across the bay back to Cape Town.

Book in advance. The tour fills up far in advance, so get your tickets online and start planning a month in advance in the summer months. Ticket price includes: ferry both ways, 45 minute narrated bus tour and 30 minute narrated walking tour of the prison. Nicely done and worth the trip.
Windy Day. It was very exciting visiting Robben Island and very moving as well, it is incredible to see where Nelson Mandella was incarcerated

Good to been there and better when leaving. Robben Island is not a funny place, but it is a place to seen when in Cape Town. Thinking of all the men spending their lives there in sentences for minor "law" breaks is depressing. But with men giving birth to reconsilliation attitudes there may still be hopes.
nice boat trip. the trip from the V&A waterfront was exciting and so was the amazing history of Robben island but to be honest not much to see once you are there , very barren and boring

Great for the history. This place is a mixture of the sad and the victorious. The island is full of pain from the prisoners, the old leper colony and the cramped quarters of Mandela's cell. But it has a village where ex-cons live side by side with prison wardens and the crime rate is 0. It's bleak and it's history is sad but if you care about South African history you should definitely see this place.

interesting and informative. If you have a particular interest in South Africa's history, and the time spent by Nelson Mandela and others in prison on Robben Island, you will probably really enjoy a visit to Robben Island. If not, and you have limited time in Cape Town, rather use your time to see some of its many other beautiful sites and attractions. I found the Robben Island tour very informative and interesting, but feel that I could have learnt about that in a book or documentary. There's nothing much to actually see on the island, other than the prison itself.
Boat trip. This is well worth doing, give quite a good insight into how life was on the island. You also get an appreciation for all the islands uses, not just Apartheid
Makes the history books a reality. It was very informative, some of the tour guides are people that spent time in that prison so they tell the story first hand.

A really interesting visit. We were really glad we did this trip! The first guide, who talked us through the bus tour had a great sense of humour so managed to make us laugh while telling us all about the history. The second guide was a former prisoner and what he had to say about prison life was fascinating.A real must, however please be aware you need to book well in advance. I'd hate for anyone to miss out!

Shambolic and disappointing. For us, Robben Island was a 'must see' when we decided to go on holiday to Capetown. We were advised to book in advance, as it can be hard to get tickets, so I phoned about a month before we were going and we were booked on the 11.00am tour on Wed 26 October. When we arrived in Capetown on the Tuesday, we checked out where the ferries departed from, to make sure we could find it the next day, and all seemed well. However, when we arrived the next morning to collect our tickets, there was a crowd of people singing and dancing in front of the ferry terminal, and it seemed to be some sort of protest. We were a little concerned, but the crowd was relatively peaceful and made no attempt to stop us going in to the centre. When we got in, we were told that there was no 11.00am tour. No explanation was provided, but we were offered an alternative at 1.00pm, which we accepted. We arrived back at the centre just before 12.30pm, as instructed, but instead of leaving at 1.00pm, the ferry boarding was so disorganised that we did not even get onto the ferry until 1.30pm, and did not leave Capetown harbour until almost 2.00pm. When we arrived on the other side, we were told to board one of four buses waiting by the quay. We sat on the bus for about a further half hour before it finally started taking us on a tour of the island. While the tour was interesting enough, we really wanted to see and hear about Nelson Mandela's time on the island. However, ours was the last bus to return to the high security prison, where he was kept, and our tour had only just started when some of the other tourists asked what time the ferry was due back out. Although we still had a good 45 minutes before it was due to leave, we were practically raced around the rest of the prison with no time to ask questions or take photos, so that we didn't miss the boat! We then sat on the ferry for another 30 minutes before it actually left.It was so disappointing that what should have been such an interesting and informative day was spoiled by shambolic organisation and lack of proper time managment. We learned later that a lot of the Robben Island staff were on strike the day we visited, which may have impacted on our experience. However, we weren't told that at the time, or warned that it might affect the tour.

Do not miss going to Robben Island. The tour of Robben Island was truly inspiring. The tour was done by former political prisioners who were remarkable for not having any bitterness over their imprisonment. In fact both were at pains to say that we (the tourists) should not think of Robben Island only as a prision, but think of it as a place of reconciliation and learning. Speaking of learning one of the interesting thing I learned is that Robben Island was also a leper colony. There is a African Peguin colony on the islandThe must do thing for me was to take a photo outside Nelson Mandella's cell. Make sure you purchase your ticket in advance. Also tour the exhibit in the Nelson Mandela Gateway building where the tour departs.The ride from the Cape Town to Robben Island is about 45 minutes but the seas seemed pretty rough. I sailed in the older boat which used to transport prisioners to the island.
A must for every human being. We must never forget the evil man can do to man, and that the human spirit can and will triumph.

A "should" place to visit. A piece of history, Robben Island is one of those places one "should" visit, just because it figures so intimately in the history of South Africa. Though "sanitized" for tourists one still gets the feel of how it was for its many political prisoners of apartheid. Be sure to book online ahead of time as departures are often sold-out during holiday periods especially.

Interesting and well run. This was a great half day outing. We enjoyed listening to an ex-prisoner explain his/her experience and it was well organised overall.Tip: Ferry can be rough, so if you are prone to sea-sickness bring some tablets with you!

We were disapointed. It's like to pilger to Nelson Mandelas cell and that's it. For my opinion this place has a potential to be a very important place to inform people about the whole apartheid history. At least that's what I've expected. What you get is some facts about the prison island itself and many facts about how life was in prison. You even see how the warders lifed and other uninteresting stuff. I think there is so much more to tell to the tourist coming to SA and especially as there is no apartheid museum in C. Anyway - we've been highly disapointed. The view on CT on the way back is nice.

A must see. While the trip out to the island was a little rough due to large swells -it became part of the experience and provided an understanding of what it must have been like for prisoners. The tours were well organised - firstly a tour with an ex-prisoner which was nothing less than gut-wrenching but provided a wonderful insight into the history of the Island and particulalry Nelson Mansela's experiences. The bus tour provided even more history and a full commentary was delivered beautifully by our guide - after viewing the quarries and the town along with various other attactions we were advised that many ex-prisoners had settled on the Island and now lived in friendship with the ex-guards. This in itself provided a positive end to the tour and hope for the future of this beautiful country and it's wonderful people.
A unique experience. The trip to the island is great, but the tour of the island with the guides is a real treasure to behold.
Heritage Site. I haven't been, but from all accounts, it's worth the trip. One is shown around by former political prisoners.

Cool visit. Another must-see for Cape Town. Don't forget to bring your sunblock- it is really hot there! Boat ride can be a bit rough depending on the weather but the tour with an ex-political prisoner was worth it.
Well worth the trip. Very good experience,especially the tour conducted by the ex-prisioner. Make sure youbook ahead as this is always booked a day ahead.Ferry ride can be rough so be prepared.

A grim reminder of injustice. Walking in the footsteps of Nelson Mandela--seeing the cell where he spent so many years--touched us all. Having a guide who actually spent time incarcerated there with Nelson Mandela was equally sobering.

A pilgrimage. The journey across the bay to Robben island was exciting . The actual visit was intersting especially the guiding of the actual prison by a former prisoner. But in truth it was really a pilgrimage to a wonderful person
Trip to Robben island. Amazing, well worth the trip to this world heriate site. You must pre-book your tickets in advance though but this is easy to do.
Must do?. A little disappointing, we would have liked a few hours to wander round on our own, but it is all timed and organised.
Robben Island. Enjoyed the tour itself. Ferry service could be a bit better
no service attitude. It is really sad to see how little robben island's employees care about tourists!
A rough trip!. Very interesting to visit Robben Island, but the trip to and from the Island was very, very rough. Make sure you are outside when the weather is windy...just in case!

What an eye opener.. Until you have been to Robben Island, you cannot imagine what it must have been like for those poor buggers.
The world is a much better place since they closed it down.

Definitely worth the trip!. Learnt so much from this trip. Of course one can read about the apartheid time, but to actually see the island and the prison, and hear stories from the tour guide who had been a prisoner there himself for several years, was really an experience worth remembering. I would recommend this to anyone who wants to understand the apartheid time better.

A BIG DISAPPOINTMENT. We booked three days ahead, as it gets pretty busy. The boat trip was fine, but when we arrived we were disappointed to find that the trip is divided into two parts. Half of the party from the boat went straight onto the busses, and we and about fifty others did the walk up to the prison first. The guide was interesting, being an ex prison, and this part of the trip was fine. When we finished this, we met the buses, who disgorged the other half of the party, and we went off on the bus tour of the island. VERY DISAPPOINTING INDEED. There was no explanation of the history of the island, we were driven in silence to various points, the leprosy graveyard, the quarry etc. but no explanation of any of the history of the island. found that out later from reading the roughguide book left back in the hotel room. We were dropped off again at the jetty half an hour before the boarding time and left there. No sign of the refreshment stop, nor any indication of the penguins or other natural attractions. Maybe we just had a duff guide on the bus, but it was vey disapointing. MAKE SURE YOU GEN UP ON THE ISLAND BEFORE GOING is my main suggestion.

Tour was horrible!. Like some other reviews said, it was like we were being taken around like a herd of cattle. After we got to the island we were taken onto buses. Our bus did the prison tour first. We were shown around by a former prisoner, which was pretty cool but he was really hard to understand. Because he was hard to understand my group felt that we missed a lot of the stuff he said and didn't learn much at all. At one point everyone went in different directions and he had to go around trying to get everyone back together.The bus tour around the island was horrible as well. They would point out certain things we passed but didn't give any history behind it. They would just say we're passing the postal office. I would've preferred to skip the tour around the island and spend more time at the prison to explore on our own. In the end I didn't learn too much about the history of Robben Island except for what i already knew. Our entire group said we would have to look it up later since the tour was useless. I was hoping to leave the tour feeling moved by the history but that didn't happen. I didn't even want to buy any souvenirs because i felt like i didn't make any connection with the place at all.It was very disappointing since we were looking forward to it. Looks like this is the only way to tour the place though and you can't not go to Robben Island when you're in Cape Town. They need to make some major changes to the tour.

A site not to be missed. The boat trip over was a lovely way to see the waterfront from the sea and the island itself has such a varied history. One naturally associates it with Nelson Mandela but much mroe to the island than that. If you are lucky you may get an extraordinary guide on the bus tour of the island (all provided in the price of admission which oincludes the boat trip). THen the tour through the actual prison site is by a former inmate who can provide the details that only a person incarcerated there could divulge. Thje boat trip back to the waterfront was bumpy with a number of tourists getting quite seasick due to the rough seas of the time. The trip and tour was a highlight and must-see experience. Book in advance online as otherwise may find no tickets available.
Fascinating. Whilst the boat trip there and back was not great for the stomach, it was well worth it. Being taken round by a former prisoner made the experience more real.

Robben Island. A short catamaran trip out of the lovely V & A Waterfront took us to Robben Island. We then boarded a bus and began our guided tour. We toured through Nelson Mandelas quarters and were given an historic commentary by an ex-prisoner who now lives on the Island with his family. Loved it here, but would have liked to be able to wander around independantly. Best views of Table Mountain from here.

Excellent tour. The guide on our bus was excellent, but we got real lucky and got the guide that has done tours for Hillary Clintion, Barak Obama, and even Mandella himself. He has us in stitches, while still managing to give us a detailed education about Robben Island through the ages.The guide of the prison is always an ex-inmate and unfortunately ours wasn't a great speaker, but you tend to overlook that for obvious reasons. Interesting, educational and even entertaining (which I didn't expect), this really is a must-do tour if in Cape Town.Tip: We looked online only to be told there was no tickets available. And we called just in case, and were told the same thing. Then we just went down to the Robben Island office by the clock tower on the waterfront, and had no problem getting on the next boat. So be sure to chance your arm...
Must see if you visit Cape Town. Make sure you get up close to the guide so you can hear. There is a very quick refreshment stop, make sure you go to the loo on the boat!

A must of any visit. buy tickets in advance during the busy season. Sometimes trips get cancelled if the weather is bad so plan your visit a few days before you leave capetown just in case. The tour guides are ex prisioners from the island so you get a real insight into the lifes of the people who were there. The boat trip gives wonderful views of the city. The bus tours of the bleak island are a good for a perspective of what life was like there for inhabitants, shocking how recent it all was though.

Interesting tour. The boat trip across takes 40 mins each way. The water can be a bit choppy so if you get sea sick remember your tablets!Once you get off the ferry, you get onto a bus which drives you around the island and the tour guide gives you interesting information at each stopping point. You then go inside the prison and are taken around by an ex-political prisoner. They explain what the daily regime was like, and how the colour segregation was so extreme it even dictated what portions of food you were allowed. I took my 8 year old daughter who was really interested in this concept (and rightly outraged by it!)Great. Good value for money.

Humbling and enlightening experience. A key part to any visit to Cape Town that gives you an often painful insight into apartheid. The tour of the once prison is in part conducted by one of the previous inmates and I wish you could spend more time listening to their stories.Try and arrive for your sailing quite early if you would like to sit on the top of the boat, outside, as people start queuing early.

Outstanding, a must see. Visiting the prision was very moving and sad but I am so glad I went. The tour guides are often ex-political prisoners who were sent there for working to end Apartheid. They make the tour very real and keep it from becomeing just a touristy museum. The scenery on the boat ride over is stunning as well. You get a nice view of the entire beautiful Table Mountain range which is a stange backdrop for a place that was so evil.

Historical site. Wheater you are interested in history, nature or human rights this is a good place to go. It certainly tells us how evel we humans can be. You get a good explaination of the guides about how prisonlife was. NIce boattrip with good views on table mountain.

History Lesson. The ferry ride over is scenic, although the waters can get a bit rough. Go early in the morning and pick a day when the winds are not up.Had a fabulous guide on the bus tour around the island. Our guide was able to weave the various nationalities on board the bus and to show how the world played a part in Apartheid. Then we had a walking tour inside the prison. Our guide was a former prisoner. Very interesting, you will see Nelson Mandela's cell, as well as the cell of various other famous prisoners.
Nelson. Its a must do trip, the tour guides are ex prisoners with a great tale to tell.

has to be done!. Due to South Africas past and present political climate it would be rude to not go to Robben Island. We booked in advance online which I would recommend as tickets apparently tend to sell out quick. The day before we got to Cape Town we recieved an email to tell us that due to strikes our tour had been cancelled, however there was a contact number and the tour was easliy arranged to an earlier one.The sea was quite rough on the day we went over to Robben Island, and for the first time ever I experienced sea sickness, I had not expected this at all and so would warn people to perhaps prepare in advance if they usually suffer or have not got much experience with travelling on boats. Unfortunately for me becasue of how bad I was feeling the whole trip was overshadowed by a nervousness of travelling back to Cape Town mainland, however what I can say is the tour groups were too big, our guide who was an ex prisoner was in such a hurry that at times he left people behind whilst he stalked off to the next point of interest and for certain a lot of what he was saying would have been missed. the guide was difficult to understand, there is no way if you were foreign you would have understood what was being saidthe bus tour was very informative, we were shown around by 2 women and they answered questions knowledgably and coherentlyseeing the limestone "university" and the cells made you realise just what an inspirational man Nelson Mandela was and is to have survived and come out wanting equality and not the reverse apratheid as is evident in South Africa todayAll in all I would recommend this trip, its not something fun to do and probably not appropriate for young children either, but definitely worthwhile

Moving visit to a historic prison. Dont't miss an opportunity to visit Robben Island when in Capetown. Unique opportunity to walk the corridors of the prison where Nelson Mandela was held for 17 years.

Experience it. Visitors to Robben Island should not expect to be entertained. They boat journey to and from the island can be fun or terrible depending on your sea legs. It is important to see the island (and prison) in the context of its histoy and the impact that the history has on South Africa today. The experience is essential, but is not "fun".The island visitor management system can be improved. Visitors are herded around in groups that are far too large for all to hear the guide.

Important.Interesting.Memorable. Every visitor to Cape Town should take the tour of Robben Island. It's critical to understanding South Africa's past and understanding what Nelson Mandela went through and yet was able to make peace with his captors. The tour guides could have been somewhat better. But it was still very worthwhile.

One of our mest memorable experiences in Cape Town. Robben Island is the best place I have been to experience the history of South Africa. If you just want to do one "cultural" activity on your cape town holiday, this should be it!
A Must!. Humbling and informative experience - you will learn a lot and not all of it pleasant but a must so that apartheidt can never be repeated

Skip!. Robben Island is something I had wanted to do for years. Seems I should have skipped it and stuck with my imagination.The seats on the ferry are extremely dirty and a lot of them are broken or in bad shape. Better and more information should be provided on the ferry ride over. There is very little organization to the entire trip. You move as a huge heard from one bottleneck to the next and by the time the last person gets through you might catch a couple of words from your guide.There is little to NO information posted around the prison. Information boards are either damaged or missing. The bus ride around the island has you leaning, stretching and then guessing at what the guide is talking about. Large amounts of litter around the shoreline and other areas that they drive you right past.The cells have all been repainted and look nothing like what they use to. The tour is VERY bland and has little to no personality. How about more story boards, videos, audio tours, SOMETHING??No organization. Little information (even the museum back on land). Crowded. Not well kept. Litter. Boring.For an 'World Heritage Site' this is pretty shocking as far as an international attraction goes. Those in charge should be embarrassed. Only part I remotely found moving was being able to walk past the cell where Mr Mandela spent so much time imprisoned.
More than just where Mandela was imprisoned. This island could be considered the birthplace of the democracy that SA enjoys today. Take the tour and feel the importance of what happened here.

Historic site, but little to see. This is a place of major importance in the history of modern SA, but there is almost nothing to see other than the jail. Surely a missed opportunity. A Visitor Centre and audio guide would be a good start.
A must!. It's hard to imagine coming all the way to Cape Town and then missing the trip to Robben Island. Sobering and inspiring, the tour and whole experience was fantastic.
Not to be missed. You need sea legs but otherwise our guides were superb and had the personal experience of being held on the island. A little more time in the prison would have been good
Indispensable. Apprehend was a terrible time for this amazing country, and Nelson Mandela is such a compelling inspirational person, I think is a great cultural visit.
Don't waste your time & money. Boat not on time. Delays. Dirty bus on island. dreadful guides. Tacky waste of money
Historicplace. Interesting place to visit, to see the cell of Nelson Mandela, to hear the prisoners side of what really went on, very moving

Very interesting to understand the long walk to freedom. It may seem only a visit to an empty prison like going to Alcatraz but I believe it's more than that especially if you have been following the history of the country and of Nelson Mandela. He is now a legend but when I was a teenager he was in prison and I rembember all the battles for its liberation, the concerts and all the appeals. Well there's where he was so it is a place which needs to be seen . It's a very instructive experience .

A Must Do Trip. Learn about the place that incarcerated one of the greatest human beings of our time and wonder how he came out feeling the way he did. Shows what a great man he is. Boat trip can be a bit bumpy but well worth it when you get there.Recommend that you book in advance.

Rough seas!. Th trip to Robben Island was amazing! The crossing was very rough but luckily only took 30 minutes. The guide was an ex-prisoner which made the experience more interesting. My only problem was that the group was very large and sometimes you couldn't hear the guide. The guide didn't have the clearest English do the foreign guests among us struggled to understand him. This is a most trip if you are going to Cape Town but remember to book before you leave. The trips are very popular and when we arrived the boats were booked up to 5 days in advance!
Very solemn. Bit of history - this is a must whilst in Cape Town!
Great Experience. Truly loved this visit. Gives you some history about how prisoners were treated. Better told story when it is an ex-prisoner on the island.
Do not miss. We have read about it; now see it; take the tour and learn more about the effect of apartheid on those who opposed it.

Absolutely worth doing, if a bit disorganised. We'd booked on line well ahead (you really need to do that) and got there to be told there was a strike and our trip had been cancelled. We were, however transferred to a trip the next day and it was really worth the hassle to see the place and to hear from a man who had been imprisoned there - quite an emotional experience!

felt a little rushed but got to see plenty!. the guide with my group was an ex prisoner so he was amazing, had so much to tell everyone and could answer every question. bused around the site which is the best way as it would take a long time to walk so got to go to some great view points and hear about the island. cost me £22 which is quite good when you take into account the cost of the centre, boat over, bus petrol etc. well worth it
The Tale of a true Legend - Mr Mandela. Great storys and insight into the what had happened on Robben Island in the past. I'm South African, and found the tour to be insightful and very worthwhile.

A political brainwashing unorganized tour. I went for my second time on a tour of Robben island on the 5/10/11 as I had family with me that had never been before and was really disappointed at the way you get quickly shuffled around the prison on the tour and not really shown much of the island or told of the history that it has apart from prison. To top it off the boat broke down and we were stuck there for a few hours and when the boatbtheybsent as back up arrived there was no organization of anything it turned in to the scene of titanic for the lifeboats it was chaos ! My mum was injured in the process and then when we finally got back to the harbour at 8:30pm there was no one there to meet us and apoloigise for the delay. I emailed them regarding my mums injuries and got nothing back ! There lack of organizing the whole thing really was one of the most pathetic things I have ever seen in my travels
a piece of history. Given it's important role in the history of South Africa - this is an important place to visit and experience
Must do. An experience not to be missed. The guides are former inmates and they make the whole experience more chilling.

Must see, but ............. Robben Island is a must do trip because of all the events in South Africa's recent history. The boat trip there and back was great but the guided tour of the island was very disappointing. The tour was keen to point out that there have been prisoners on the island for hundreds of years but I felt that the most recent political prisoners were almost glossed over. All tours are conducted by ex political prisoners and to an agreed script. Whilst they tell you that they would be happy to answer any questions I felt the response would be considerably measured. Standing in the exercise yard was humbling and a stark reminder of recent events. However, I found the rest of the prison visit sanitised, as all the walls have been painted green and cream, and I had no sense that Nelson Mandela had ever been there, despite the fact that his cell is "furnished". I expected to feel overwhelming emotion during the prison part of the tour but this was not the case. Because of the greatness of the man you cannot go to Cape Town and not do this trip.

Very interesting!. We found oursleves with a free afternoon so decided to visit Robben Island - it's advisable to book in advance as tour tickets sell out quick. The Island was much more than we thought it was, so much history and so much more than just a prison on an Island! Our 2 tour guides were very knowledgeable. Views of Cape Town from the boat are beautiful. You have to get on the boat early to sit on top and be aware that's it quite cold and breezy but you'll get the best views. Worth a visit whether you're interested in Mandela or not
Facinating. Much better than I expected, so interesting and made all the more poignant by the fact that you are shown arround by an exprisioner.
A sad but very real part of S.African History. Ferry ride can be a little rough but to get an idea of what went on under Apartheid, visiting this prison is a must.

Big time disapointed. Robben Island is part of South Africa History, but the visit is a big disapointement! Out of the boat, you have to run to the bus, in the bus, onlyn those seated on the right will be able to take some pics. The busnstop will not give you enough time to walk around, only to buy beverages. The visit of the prison is more like a racebthan anything else: 50 pers, one guide, no mic and time ticking. If you're not beside the guide you wont hear much. For the pics inside the prison, imagine 50 pers having a total of 1 min to take a picture of a room of 2 meters square! And it's like that all the way. The guide also ask you to check several cells and to read their history, but you have a max of 2 min to do it and they are many cells. At the end of the tour, you have to run if you don't want to miss your boat! Sad! Very sad of not being able to take our time to discover this isle where so many things happened!

nice but saddening experience. the trip to the island via the ferry is comfortable, but its quite a long trip ! It's such a creep sad place ,when you just hear the stories and the suffering of its prisoners! the most intersting part of this trip , is that the tour guide is really one of the ex prisoners of this island....
ferry what ferry. The ferry was cancelled once again not for the first time,tried to go out a few times.Very dissapointing.
Got to go. It is definately worth the trip we had a really good guide who managed to inspire all on the trip to think about the issues
Awesome. Very interesting although try to ensure the sea is calm as we had a very very rough crossing.
Another must do!. Nice boat ride and a good tour! The guides (who have often done time there themselves) give you a good idea of what it was like back in the day.

We had to visit this historic island. A ferry ride to a place with so much history. An organised boat trip and guided tour around the island. What you take from it depends on your personal views. A long struggle for many people over the years..... a humbling experience.A good plus were the lovely views back across the water to Cape Town and Table Mountain.
You must go.. The atmosphere alone.The reality of the Limestone quarries.The touching story of forgiveness,and men who paid the paid for South Africa's freedom.
A magical place. When you are interested in the younger story of this beautiful country it is a must visit
Dont miss a trip to Robben Island. So much history here - we loved hearing about all the history.

A real eye-opening tour. I expected this to be quite emotional and informative & was not disappointed. Our tour on the bus, Yaseen, was so knowledgeable about Robben Island & it's history that we were all quite gob-smacked. He asked everyone on the bus (which was full) which country they were from and then included all of the countries and their role in the history of the island in his information - a real talent. Our prison guide was a little quieter & his story was equally harrowing. The history of Robben Island should be compulsory on the syllabus in every country & hopefully would stand as a lesson to us all about the way forward.

A must do while in Cape Town. After hearing and reading so much about Robben Island, I finally got to see it. The trip across by ferry is very nice with Cape Town in the background. Learning even more about the island and it's prisoners can be an emotional thing.
Take a hankie. Such an overwhelming and heart breaking experience. A must. I didn't like being herded onto buses and being part of a huge group but our guide was amazing.

Must See, but Disorganized. This is something you must do. It is a World Heritage Site for a reason. Seeing Mandela's cell and hearing a former prisoner talk about his experience was well worth the hassle factor. Apartheid is part of the history of the area and seeing Robben Island gives you a serious history lesson. Book ahead of time! You cannot just show up and go. It is popular. As other have mentioned, it is disorganized. Our hotel told me to get there HOURS early. Good thing I was there two hours early for a 10am departure. They said that the 10am tours were completely booked by a school - even though I was holding a 10am ticket. They eventually put me on the 8am tour since I was there when the boat was leaving. And I was not alone in this problem, others had the same ticketing problem. I shudder to think what happened to those arriving only 30 minutes prior to the 10am departure... Bottom line is you MUST go, but you might have to make adjustments and allow yourself alot of time.

Avoid this by all means!. It starts with a sullen ticket agent that insists on your telephone number. Poor signage at the departure point and on the boat. 6 cheesy monitors that have lousy sound systems. And that's all before you get to the island. The buses are cramped and no sound system. You simply are driven around the island with one stop to take a pghoto across the bay of Cape Town and Table Mountain. Photo ops are much better on the mainland, I might add. The second stop is at the prison where you are herded into an area where the acoustics are terrible and delivered a speech by a former prisoner that you cannot understand.My recommendation to the organizers is to equip the boat, buses and guides with a sound system. Until they do, save your time and money. Other people on this trip made the same comments.

A must for those interested in SA history. Even reading in advance, this place is still full of surprises and worth visiting. Everyone's heard of Nelson Mandela and probably knows a small part of what he experienced, but seeing where it was is very real and very sad, plus some of the other stories are even more moving, especially when you think this was not very long ago!

Very disappointing.. We went on the Robben Island tour, after about 10 years when we first went on it. The boat trip was great but was unfortunately the highlight of the tour. We got onto a bus with a less than enthusiastic tour guide who "encouraged us to ask questions and take pictures" but was sitting with her back to us whilst explaining, rather than the facts, a very emotional version of the history of the political side of the island. (We later realised this at the jail when an ex-prisoner took over). The tour and history given is very superficial and we were rushed so that we couldn't even read all the messages in the single cells that former prisoners left there. No mention was made about the rest of the history of the island (such as underground tunnels etc.) and when we later asked whether there are other tours or opportunities to explore the island on our own (at some other stage) we were just told no.The buildings on the island are in terrible condition, even the facilities (incl. toilets) for the tourist.I expected much more of a World Heritage Site, not even mentioning the history this site carries.Extremely disappointing trip.
History. You have to do it & you will not be let down - late trip - you need to come back on the Jet Boat if you are going to eat early - long trip back.

an insight into apartheid. Robben Island was difficult to book online because the website indicated tours were sold out well in advance. In the end, we decided to go to the waterfront office. The staff at the information desk told me the tours were sold out, but when I explained that we really wanted to go, she directed me to the ticket booth where I purchased tickets without any problem! We toured the museum at the harbour before we took our tour. THe boat ride has an interesting video running about the history of the island. The boat ride can be very wavy, but the seats are comfortable and the view is great. There are no refreshments on the boat. When you arrive on the island, you board a bus. We were so lucky to have an amazing tour guide, who had given tours to many diplomats. His knowledge of the island, apartheid, and how different countries in the world responded to apartheid was interesting. The tour of the prison was given after bus tour of the island. A former prisoner explained what life was like at Robben Island. We had ample opportunity to walk through the prison, ask questions, and take photos. The stories, the things you see there show the racism and cruelty of apatheid. Definitely worth the half day to take this trip.

understand. if you want to understand South Africas past and present this is a must the guide on the bus was EXCELLENT, the ex prisoner who spoke inside the jail was hard to flollow in English but his experiences came threw and it was a visit that will always stay in my memory.

Can't miss Robben Island. It's a great boat trip there and back plus you'll get to see Nelson Mandela's jail cell. Our tour seemed kind of rushed, but it was led by a former prisoner so you get to hear first hand accounts of what it was like being there.

Unable to get tickets. We tried to get tickets to go to Robben Island but they were sold out for the next 3 days.
It's a shame they sell advance tickets so tourists who only have a few days are unable to get out there.

A Must See For All Who Visit South Africa. I only learned about South Africa's history early 2010 when I met a South African and became very good friends. I had no idea that country had gone through so much and has come such a long way. I read half of Nelson Mandela's autobiography. Robben Island is a MUST see while in Cape Town. The ferry only runs on clear days so take advantage of the clear day. Cape Town weather is extremely unpredictable (4 seasons in one day). It was the end of winter when I went and I stayed in the mountains so it was cold, but not freezing (I live in the Northeast). It does make it a bit difficult to plan ahead, but there are other things to do see. We had two tour guides: One on the bus and the other on the prison grounds. They were both VERY knowledgable and gave detailed information on the history of the Island as well as what life was like for Mandela and other prisoners. It was amazing. I plan on going back to South Africa in 2 years and will probably end up taking another visit!!

Disappointingly organised tour of such a historic attraction. It was the main reason for my visit to Cape Town. After the boat trip, make sure you get a window seat on the huge buses on the Island. I was disappointed, I got a middle seat and my husband the isle seat, on a packed bus and could not see much at all. Unfortunately for the main tour of the island, till you get to the prison, you get driven around with a guide doing a commentary pointing out landmarks etc, you could hardly see. Would love to see smaller buses or even the option of a walking tour of the island.. and smaller groups for sure. Plenty of guides available who could do with a job to do this so they really need to revisit this as it takes away from the experience. The part where a previous political prisoner does take you on a tour of the actual prison buildings is really great, so historic and moving. This would have been so much more beneficial too if it was a smaller group.. at least not 50 people!Also there was no direction when we arrived off the boat so remember to make a bee line for the buses for the best seats

Worth the rough boat ride no question. We went over on the 1:00 boat, I would recommend going earlier as we didn't have time to walk to the Penguin Boulder area as we were catching the last boat back and had just enough time to finish the tour. Our trip wouldn't be complete without doing this and for our kids (9 and 12) was really impactful regarding the cultural learnings...... they were really touched that our tour guide for the prison tour itself, was actually a former prisoner there, bringing a "newness" to the issues SA has addressed.

Important part of history and must see when visiting Cape Town. To get a glimpse of the horrors of the apartheid era and understand the giant leap forward the South Africans have already taken since those days, you simply need to visit this place. With an ex-prisoner as a tour guide, we heard some first hand experiences and oddities of the life inside back then. Most touching and memorable. Apart from the grim history, Robben Island is also a very beautiful island per se. The view to Cape Town and the Table Mountain is simply magnificent. During the nice boat trip, keep your eyes open, and you'll probably see penquins and dolphins as well as many different species of birds. Seats are limited, so book early!

Not bad, really, but disappointing too.... Most people visiting Cape town would probably have this place on their list of 'things to do' while they're there. There's nothing wrong with that, and it's probably worth going there, but having read and heard about it before going, I really, really expected more. The tour is average and doesn't let you explore on your own. The guide that we got was also not great. He didn't do a great job of explaining, and told us quite a few things about his time in prison there, which was interesting, but didn't talk about anything else, really. We did stop at Nelson Mandela's prison room (he stayed there for 18 yrs) and its just so bare! it can't bear staying there, ever. The boat ride back is nice, if you stay on deck, not below. Overall, it could have been FAR better, but it was decent anyway.

Moving. There are no words that can accurately describe how inspiring and moving this experience was. It inspired me to read Nelson Mandela's autobiography, " A Long Walk to Freedom." While reading and after having taken a tour with a knowledgable tour guide who was also an ex-prisoner, I could really get an essence of how cruel the conditions at the prison were and how incredible that Mandela and his fellow prisoners were to continue to strive for change despite their environment and how forgiving they were.Everything from the ferry ride to the island tour was well-organized and memorable. If you visit Cape Town, Robben Island is a must see.

Heartfelt. After reading Mandela's "Long Walk to Freedom," I vowed to visit R.I. as a tribute to this amazing man. Knowing the history made every part of the experience deeply meaningful. While the boat leaped through the churning sea, I wondered what the journey had been like for the prisoners sent here. The view from the island is beautiful---did they find it inspiring ... and agonizing? The guide on the bus around the island was incredibly knowledgeable, with a long personal history here. He entertained, but his sense of humor was poignant. The prison guide had been incarcerated with Mandela. He walked with a brace, and the deprivation and torture of these prisoners hung in the air. Chilling and emotional. Each tiny cell had an inmate's photo and story posted. At Mandela's I took the guide aside to tell him I'd come to South Africa to honor Madiba; he waited till the rest of the group moved on, then left me alone at the cell for as long as I needed. (I found this very kind, as no doubt his job was to keep us together.) When I travel I want to know a place. In South Africa, I needed to come here.

Good place to visit to get an appreciation for some of the history of South Africa. The entire tour takes 3-1/2 hours including the ferry rides to and from Robben island. Once you get to the island, there is a bus tour followed by a walking tour of the prison including viewing the room where Nelson Mandela was held. The guides we had were very good making the tour enjoyable. The guide for the prison was actually an ex-prisioner. Good tour if you want to get an appreciation of what happened during the Apartheid Era.

If you are in Cape Town, you really can't miss Robben Island. On our trip to South AFrica this summer we left our itinerary completely in the hands of our hosts who are among our best friends, but we told them that we really wanted to visit Robben Island, where Mandela was held for 17 of his 24 year prison sentence. Tours are run by the Robben Island Museum, and include a 20 minute ferry ride and admission to the World Heritage site. You leave the ferry to board a bus where a tour guide will be with you as you drive around the island before arriving at the prison. All of the guides are former prisoners or people involved in the apartheid struggle, and their stories are amazing.The tour was first class. Facilities were clean, the ferry ran on schedule, and all of us came away very moved. OUr 13 year old pronounced it one of the best parts of our visit, which included surfing and camping in the Karoo.

A trip back in time. Robben Island is where Nelson Mandela was held for part of his incarsaration during apartheid. You get the ferry from the waterside in Cape Town and when you arrive you get on board a coach and begin your tour of this prison island. Your guide will be an ex inmate who will explain the buildings and the life of a prisoner. A must do attraction while you are on holiday.

The best History lesson one could have.. One of the best Educational Tours one could go on. Being from America, Apartied was not apart of our History Book when I was in school. This tour, give you first hand experience of the terrible past in South Africa.

Interesting but guide has 'chip on shoulder'. Great boat ride to get to Robben Island. Prison museum interesting and historic. But our guide seemed to have a chip on his shoulder towards us as 'white' S. Africans. Thoroughly enjoyable and educational in spite of his attitude. Compared to overseas tours of political jails and prisoner-of-war camps (e.g Kilmainham Jail, Dublin, Saschenhausen concentration camp near Berlin) this tour was entirely mediocre and could be so much more. The directors need to visit some similar attractions in Europe and get some ideas/tips.
worth the visit. a must see in CT, steeped in history and stunning views, this is a good half day trip - they have upgraded the boats too so not so nerve wrecking!

Disappointing. Expected to get some reasonable time and access to the facilities where so many were incarcerated, including Mandela, at that historic time in SA history. Boat trip was OK but slow boarding due to pictures being taken of all for later sale. 45min initial bus trip wasted 30mins pointing out local bird life, local buildings and churches etc which were periferal to the prison visit. Within 10 mins of boarding the bus, there was a 10min rest stop to purchase refreshments. Another time waster! The actual prison visit was poorly run.Lectures by the previous inmate were interesting but too long and very parrot-fashion and left very little time to view the actual facility. In all...disappointing.

NOT TO BE MISSED- Wish there were options for longer tour.. Great tour and experience. Took tour on glorious sunny day and the beauty of the boat ride was impressive to start with. The tour is quite comprehensive although a bit rushed. One could really spend a full day in the island as there is so much to see. But within the limits of what is a 3:45 hours round trip tour I have no complaints. As always - more is gotten out of the tour if you have done your own reading ahead of time. The guiding is OK, I would say barely acceptable and nothing more. But not much more can be expected from a tour that is very precise in its timing (because of boat schedules) and where tour groups are very large. Our group was about 50 people--a bus laod. I wish the Museum offered a longer (and more expensive) tour for those that are interested in a more in depth visit of the island as well as more interactions with the guides. Overall- great experience. However, to get the most out fo the tour, do your own homework ahead of it.

" Emotional". We visited Capetown in April 2011 and knew that Robben Island was a MUST to visit. the history that surrounds this island is very emotional and heart wrenching. It is a trip which reqires a lot of patience taking in account the boat trip, bus ride and a long walk around the prison with a former inmate of the prison telling you the history.As I live in a democratic society I felt very lucky to have what I have without going through the nightmares these people had to go through to get to where we are today!"Have to visit to appreciate"

Very impressing Tour. This was a very educational and impressing tour for us. It started with a bus tour round the island and continued with a tour of the prison itself by a former prisoner.It was a one of a kind experience to hear how the situation was like from someone who really was involved in the political struggles of those times!If you are in CPT, dont miss it!

A part of History you have to experience!. I used to live in South africa and had a chance to visit robben Island.It's a one hour ferri ride with no bother, you arrive and they take you straigh to the main prison. We had a tour guide who was actually imprisoned himself for 5 years during the same time as Nelsan Mandela himself! This man with first hand experience really drew a picture of how it used to be and the hardship the prisoners went throguh. In most prison cells there are pictures of which prisoner was in there and perhaps an object with a story behind it. very emotional and heartrenching stuff. On the island itself - there is a school and a church with houses and we found out that ex prisoners AND guards now live there together! after you take the tour you will realise how amazing that is that they can simply co exist with one another after everything that happened in the prisons!After the main prison and seeing Nelsan Mandelas cell, they show you were the prisoners worked everyday for years on end. At the work place there was a little cave where they would sneak in one by one and write messages on the sand.. its all very inspiring and an experience you cannot miss! i would suggest this to all ages, the fascination just grasps you!

Excellent visit, just keep an eye on the weather forecast. My husband and I made 3 attempts to get to Robben Island, and we were very lucky to be able to go on the morning of our final day in South Africa. The previous 2 days, all ferries had been cancelled due to very high winds in Table Bay, so when booking, perhaps schedule your visit for the start of your trip.
