If there's an issue because of the the weather, then you have time to re-schedule.The ferry was comfortable, and only takes 30 minutes. Once you arrive on the island, you get onto a bus for the 1st half of your tour, where you get to see the whole island in the company of a very good guide. This takes about an hour. The 2nd part of the tour is in the company of a former prisoner, who brings you into the main prison building. This can be a difficult experience,listening to the hardship endured by the men imprisoned here, but it is worth it. We were so glad that we were able to visit.

You must do this if in Capetown. This trip is well worthwhile. You get superb views of Capetown, Signal Hill and Table Mountain on the way out to the Island. The tour guides on the island are very informative. The prison itself is not particularly fascinating, but the history around the whole facility, particularly Mandela's stay here, is very much worthwhile

A bit rushed, but still worth going. The organization of the tours could be better, but I still think the island is worth going to see if you have even the slightest interest in its history. The tour consists of a boat ride to the island, a bus tour of the island and a walking tour of the prison. Our tour was actually cancelled because of bad weather, which happens a lot in winter, but we were able to rebook easily for the next morning. It's a pretty long tour, so I would recommend bringing snacks.POSITIVES: The boat ride was nice and had a good view of Cape Town. Kids, especially, will enjoy it. I thought the tour guides did a great job. The bus tour was funny and gave a bit of the island's history. The tour in the prison was given by a former inmate who was very informative and willing to answer questions and paint a picture of what it was like to be in the prison. NEGATIVES: The boat didn't leave on time, but after having our first tour cancelled, we were just happy it moved at all. Once in the prison, the tour groups are too large to hear the guide well and see Nelson Mandela's cell. On top of that, the last part of our group was still waiting to see the cell when another group crowded into the hall as well. The end of the prison tour in general was just too rushed. They have interesting little exhibits and information set up in some of the cells, but I was only able to see about three of them before they rushed us out.
Great day out. Besides the point that this was a penal colony what a place. Awesome views of Cape Town within swimmable distance if you dare.

Very Informative. Visiting Robben Island was an important sight to see. The tour guides were the best part. They were very informative and I have learned a few things from them that I did not know before. However, getting on and off the boat going to and from Robben Island was very disorganized. There should be someone on the boat to let people know that there are more seats on other parts of the boat. Also when coming from Robben Island there should be some type of structured line getting onto the boat. People were pushing and cutting in order to get on which was dangerous. There was a snack shop on Robben Island that sold sandwiches, candy, and drinks.

Interesting day out. We decided to go on the day trip to Robben Island whilst in Cape Town.Tip:book in advance as the time of year we went they were running out to the island twice daily and they got booked up fast.Also this is along trip so don't plan much else around the day. Make sure you are well fed before leaving as there are no opportunities to eat throughout,Robben island was a prison for political prisoners during the Appartheid regime. Its most famous inmates included Nelson Mandela. The boat trip is about an hour each way and offers some good scenic shots of Cape Town, and Table Mountain. We did however have a half hour wait before boarding despite getting there at the time told and this can be a bit infuriating given the standing que.On arrival at the island the boat load is then split up into several tour busses dependant upon language speaking. THe tour guides on the busses and throughout the island are aall former inmates. Ours was a very humorous english speaking guide. He tells you the story of the island from a political, historical and environmental point of view. The tour through the prison itself was giving by another guide and is very informative of life there during Mandelas imprisonment.

If you like history this is the right place to visit. If you are in Cape Town don't miss this place and Nelson Mandela's history... he spent part of his life in this island and you can feel and follow his steps while he was working there... Really strong feelings and I recommend you to try to catch the first bus (worth walk for a feel minutes from the boat) because this is the only bus that they have a guide (others only speakers) and this guide makes the difference. He is really hilarious. Worth visiting. Plus you have the beautiful view of Cape Town from this island.

Save your time, save your money, and save yourself the disappointment.. The tour of Robben Island can be and deserves to be much more memorable. Unfortunately it was poorly run when I did it in June 2011. I've been to about 35 countries and been on numerous tours. This tour was one of the biggest let-downs I can remember. For starters, getting on the boat was painfully slow due to the photographers taking pictures of everyone on the gangplank (30 rand upon return for the picture). We then sat on the main ferry in Cape Town with the engines running for about 15 minutes with no explanation. We eventually saw the captain run up to the boat and we then departed. Upon arrival we were toured around the small island in a bus to learn the history of the island from a guide named "MP". That was probably the best part. He spoke well and made himself available for questioning. Upon arrival at the prison our group of 20 combined with a group of about 50 to make a completely unmanageable group for the environment we were touring. The guide (an ex-prisoner for five years) clearly had a strong emotional tie to the area and had valuable stories to tell. But he was incapable of managing the group of 70. People pressed into cramped areas with poor acoustics trying to listen. His manner of speaking made it even more difficult to hear and understand what he was saying. His directions for the group were lacking, leaving the group of 70 wandering at times trying to figure out where they were going. At the pinnacle of the tour, Mandela's cell, he nearly left a large portion of the group until someone told him many people were still taking pictures. He regularly began speaking before the entire group was present and never organized the group for optimal presentation of his valuable stories. Since no one gave the typical "The bathroom is here" introductory speech, one woman ended up relieving herself in one of the courtyards while the rest of us wondered if we'd suffer the same fate. The guide said little of his own personal experience as a prisoner (though maybe I just couldn't hear it). I can't fault him for that and expect him to relate a painful tale. But if he isn't able for whatever reason then what's the value of him giving a sub-par tour? Upon leaving the gift shop and snack shop were already closed, much to the dismay of the large group. No one mentioned that the nearby buildings had more information that was worth looking at. Finally, we stood and waited another 15 minutes while the boat re-fueled. Why it waited to re-fuel I don't know. I was told that the tour is government run. If that's the case then the SA government is doing a dis-service to those former prisoners, despite employing some number of them as guides.

Amazing heritage sight. The place where Nelson Mandela spent his final days in prison. Getting to the island was a boat trip, not too long, so if you get sea sick, like I kinda did, then before long you'll be at your destination :-) Interesting to see where all the prisoners during apartheid lived and to hear the stories from the tour guides who were prisoners in those times.

Breathtaking and Rewarding. A bit hearded, you dont have much free time but it is worth the visit if you are passionate about history. The ferrys only operate when the sea is calm enough so make sure of the weather beforehand
Don't miss this. Going to Cape Town and not going to Robben Island is like going to Hawai'i where I live and not going to visit the USS Arizona and Pearl Harbor museum.

Despite its faults this is still a must visit location when in Cape town for me. I am in the ‘Must do’ camp when it comes to visiting Robben island.I have read the negative reviews below and in all respects I can empathize with them. Yes it is too rushed and the tour tries to do too much. Yes the trip round the island first, although interesting in parts, is too long and could be shortened. Yes, you do not get any free time to explore for yourself. And yes when you are in the prison there really isn’t a lot to see of the original conditions.But the highlight is being taken around the detention centre by a former in-mate who was incarcerated there for 12 years and having him tell you what it was like (albeit a sanitized version).And that’s why you should visit Robben Island , to get some type of feeling of what inhumanity went on here and why it must never be allowed to ever happen again.
Very interesting. Full of history, very informative and a fantastic sunny day. If you are in Cape Town you should make sure you spare the 3hours that the tour takes.

Give it a miss. Robben Island should be a poignent reminder of man's inhumanity to man. In reality there is virtually nothing to see: a comunal prison cell the 'leadership' exercise yard plus the rowof cells where Mandela was held. The whole poorly present ed and badly explained. The worst part of the experience was the 45 minute coach tour which precedes the short visit inside the prison. We had the misfortune to have a guide who had a very high opinion of himself, I think was from Sri Lanka. He took 60 minutes to do the 45 minute bus ride and provided us with the most pretentious and self indulgent diatribe I have had the misfortune to experience. He suggested he is the head guide (please don't let that be true) and spent the whole trip boring us with the dignitories he has met. This is a waste of three hours. Believe me there are more interesting things to see.

Must do while in Cape Town. This is absolutely a must do while you are in Cape Town. The prison guides are ex-political prisoners that were incarcerated with Nelson Mandela so the tour was great! He had lots of great insight into the internal workings of the prison and the island. The bus tour guide was a younger kid that gave a really thought provoking ride around the island that i really enjoyed. Completely worth the 200ZAR for the trip.

Touching. A well co-ordinated visit to a touching site. You cross over to Robben island on a ferry (operational only when weather permits). The ferry ride is choppy even in good weather. After reaching the island you board a bus and are taken to various sites. Part of the tour is conducted by ex convicts and interacting with them is a very moving experience.

Seemed a bit rushed. Good tour overall and very informative, but seemed a bit rushed. I can see the being on a schedule, but it seemed well, almost like being in prison. I suppose I thought it was going to be a bit more like Alcatraz where you can do as you please. But any how, once we had arrived on the island we were ushered onto the waiting buses where we were driven around the grounds with a guide providing us with descriptions of the buildings, etc. Afterward we entered the prison complex where we were led around by a former political prisoner. Really made me think of how awful human beings can treat each other over such petty differences. Highly recommend a visit if you are in the Cape Town area.

Very interesting, but could be better.... We booked tickets online some months in advance as we felt this was one place you "had" to visit whilst in Cape Town; and did this as part of a whole day spent at the V&A Waterfront. We went on the 1pm catamaran sailing, which was a comfortable 30min crossing each way, watching variosu relevant documentaries on the catamaran to/from Robben Island. With hindsight, because it was a hot day and the busses they ferry you around on are not air-conditioned, we wished we had either gone earlier or later in the day.The tour of the island, once we got there was a bit of a mixed bag, in that we had a lady guide on the 45 min bus section of the trip who was a little too political in her "aggressive" story-telling (you almost felt you she was holding you responsible for any persecutions she had experienced in life). Yet, the former inmate who guided us round the internal part of the prison visit, was charming, charismatic and fascinating to listen to, whilst he told his life story and shared his experiences of prison life at Robben Island. Those 45 mins with him made it all worthwhile! He even continues to live voluntarily on the island with his family, with his day job being a tour guide on the prison visits....Inside the prison itself, you can access more than a dozen cells, each containing the heart-wrenching stories of the political prisoners who were incarcerated within these cells - well worth reading.This is no short trip, as you need to allow at least 4hrs, and to be honest some parts of it were spoiled by the patronising way in which the lady bus guide presented herself, but there is so much history in this place, that we felt it was a worthwhile trip to see where history was created, and to meet and talk to people like the ex political prisoner that we had the pleasure of meeting.

If you only have two days in Cape Town, consider skipping this. These are blasphemous words, I know. I had heard the complaints but thought it would be foolish to come to Cape Town and not see this important part of its history. But there was little history to be had. The tour rushes you from site to site, and we had at best 5 minutes in the block of Mandela's cell, with 60 tourists trying to all take photos at the same time. The worst crime is that they rush you through the "C block stories" that explain the lives of other prisoners. At best, it's rushed, not very informative, and you see very little. At worst, it disrespects the other political prisoners that toiled for years on Robben Island. For three hours of your time, you may want to consider the District 6 museum and exploring other historical sites. But if you must go, book your tickets online in advance.

Empathy, Global Brotherhood, History and Nature. A visit to Robben Island is a must do experience in Cape Town. It is more than an eye opener, and can be deeply moving. Our tour guides were all past prisoners and it is amazing how they were able to weave in deep insight and humor at a place that one would think had so much of disturbing memories for them. Kids especially would love the colony of African penguins on the island. As our guide had put it, "If you are a South African and have not been abroad, here is where you can see Cape Town OVER SEAS!"

A must for all tourists!. I'm a tour operator and one of our most popular tours is the Robben Island tour. I think every South African should visit Robben Island at least once and for the tourists to SA, its the best way to learn about Madiba.

Too rushed. We visited Robben Island on the last day of our trip to South Africa. Firstly the staff at the exhibition centre were so rude that I wanted to cancel our trip on principle! I have no idea why but their attitudes stink! My other half really wanted to see the island so i calmed myself down and off we went: the tour was good with excellent guides who are ex political prisioners and who are extremly passionate about the history of the island and people. Its just a pity that the whole thing was a rush from start to finish and you felt like an animal being herded along from one point to the next. One of our guides commented that he had so much more that he wanted to tell us but he felt that the tours were rushed also. We didnt even have time to visit the gift shop! We did not have time to see the islands huge population of penguins either and felt a bit cheated by that. The trip over/back can be very bumpy if it is windy so if you dont have good sea legs be prepared. Overall it is a place that is definately worth a visit and I found it quiet emotional listening to some of the stories during the tour so i actually felt it was a bit disrespectful not to allow visitors the time to appreciate this world heritage site and its history.

My favourite in Cape Town. I really enjoyed my trip to Robben Island - the place where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned. The boat trip there gives for excellent views of Table Mountain. You can learn a lot from this tour and you can tell they are trying hard to preserve the history. There is a lot of information given on the past of South Africa and the prisoners of the jail. To be inside the prison itself and see what it was like is really interesting, especially as you also get to see Nelson Mandelas cell.

Extremely interesting. Definitly worth a trip whilst visiting Cape Town. We found it interesting and good value for money. The tour guide we had was very informative and entertaining. I would definitley book on-line as the queues were long on the day.

Par at best, but probably an 'Aparthied' essential.. I visited Robben Island with 3 friends during our trip to the World Cup. We were told that this was a necessary tourist attraction, but warned that the transport ferries were often delayed. I would say that both are true. Once on the island, the first portion of the tour is via tour bus with live audio guide. I felt this to be lacking seconday to an inability to clearly understand the guide and because there were numerous structures along the route that were not described.The last half of the tour was exceptional in that it was lead by an actual former inmate and political prisoner. His recollections of his time there were very enlightening and by far the most impactful of the attraction. He spoke of Mandela's influence and how it shaped the attitude of the whole prison.On our way back the ferry was delayed by ONE HOUR AND FORTY MINUTES!!! It's a good thing we didn't have any other plans that afternoon. Overall, it was worth it, but there is plenty of room for improvement.

A Must-Do if you are at all interested in South Africa's history. Robben Island is where Nelson Mandela was once imprisoned for 27 years. The boat trip to the Island took about 45 minutes one way, and the guided tour of the island was about two hours. A former inmate was the tour guide around the prison and showed Nelson Mandela's old prison cell. The living conditions in the prison during the 1960s to 1980s were horrific, and during the visit to the Island you'll be able to see just that. No this is not an upgraded or elaborate museum as this was not the point. I thought it was very educational to hear the real life stories from the former inmate and I love the idea that they can be there to explain to tourists their views and feelings about this place.

best attraction in cape town. great to see the cell that housed Nelson Mandela for so long. tour conducted by an ex-political prisoner, lots of wild life on island. great photos of table mountain and Cape town.

A vital educational visit, if not as emotionally engaging as expected. If you want to understand a little more of modern South Africa, you have to visit Robben Island to understand just what its former white leaders subjected its black prisoners to. It's a low, featureless island a few miles off the coast, now all clean and polished for the 100s of daily visitors. And while that has robbed it of what must have been its old horrors, the understated and informative nature of the tour by a former inmate brings home what kind of place this was to be imprisoned for so many years. We didn't come away amazed or horrified - but we did come away wanting to learn more about how South Africa has achieved its astonishing journey of transofrmation over the last two decades. A final tip - there is a short, well illustrated, children's version of Nelson Mandela's autobiography available in bookshops in Cape Town - ideal for 8-10 year olds (though our six year old has just read and enjyed it) - do look it out and use it to teach your kids a bit more about how the world goes round, and what is right and wrong.

Not one of my favourite. The facts were interesting but the content was to drawn out over to longer tour. You are transported around a very small and baron island. From arrival you are met with the ghastly smell of bird droppings from cormorant sea birds which greet the boat and our guide named them as oyster catchers. Everyone is corralled onto awaiting buses. You are then told to sit quietly for at least one and half hours of the islands history. The Prison tour is at the end of the tour when again after sitting very quietly listen to an ex convict for 30 or more minutes. He did not speak good enough english to hold the audience attention and he could not be understood much of the time. Any Questions are at the end (if you were still awake by then) for a walk through the small prison rooms which had just been painted up nicely in a lovely two tone pastel green which did not give me a real feel of how it had been used in earlier and such depressing times. The organisers could have given us head sets in different languages, made more interactive things to keep our interest (and restless children)and expanded with more facts and pictures in print about the Leprosy sufferers who were forced to live on the Island and World War 2

Emotional and Educational. Robben Island is about 20-30 minute ferry ride from Cape Town. There we were greeted by tour guides that were previously prisoners on the Island. I think what made this experience so emotional and educational is that we were able to get first hand details of what the Apartheid time was like and life as a prisoner on the Island would have been like.

Rushed. Although it is a 'must do' if you're in Cape Town, it is a shame that the experience is so rushed.Also, I would advise that people do a little of thier own research before going, as some of the guides might only give one side of the story.If you only have a short time in Cape Town I think there are better ways of spending half a day.

Be aware, we eventually visited after three cancellations due to windy conditions.... I booked our trip to Robben Island before leaving the UK but unfortunately, on what appeared to be a pleasant day, the trip was cancelled. Two more cancellations but we eventually visited the island on our very last day in Cape Town, in fact we stayed a day later than we had planned to be sure of being able to go. It was most definitely worth the effort but the boat trip wasn't for the light hearted so if you suffer from sea sickness, be sure to take a tablet before going. The island is a UNESCO World Heritage site and is inhabited by the people who run the island, the guides and their families. There is a shop which sells books, souvenirs, etc. A guide will accompany you on a bus tour of the island which includes a visit to the lime quarry where prisoners spent so much of their time working. A former prisoner will take you around the prison and answer any questions that you might have. You are able to take as many photos as you want to. It's a very humbling experience. A visit to South Africa must include a visit to Robben Island! You won't regret it..

Humbling, informative, educational. Robben Island, just off the coast of downtown Cape Town, is where Nelson Mandela served much of his prison time. In stark contrast to the beautiful scenery in Cape Town, Robben Island is desolate, desert-like, and practically deserted, as the prison, which no longer has inmates, is pretty much the only thing on the island. After an hour boat ride from Cape Town's V &A Waterfront, there is a guided bus tour around the island and then a guided walking tour throughout the prison. Most of the walking tour guides are former prisoners themselves, and they allow a question and answer session at the end of the tour. If you're traveling to Cape Town during their peak tourism season (December and January), be sure to purchase your tickets a few days in advance as they seem to sell out pretty quickly. Plan on setting aside about 4 hours for the tour to account for the rather slow boat ride to the island and back. Wear good walking shoes and bring a camera; pictures aren't allowed in all parts of the prison but there are some neat photo ops on the bus tour and at the prison entrance. There are Mandela-specific gift shops at the dock at the Waterfront as well as on the island that have a few snacks, drinks, and ice cream, but no substantial food is offered, so don't go hungry!I found that, as an American, it was pretty easy to get wrapped up in the gorgeous scenery and European feel in Cape Town. Robben Island is a humbling reminder of what tourists typically don't see, but should remember as an important part of the country's history.

definitely worth the visit. Robben Island is quite beautiful as well as an invaluable lesson in South Africa's history. While the first part of the tour is a little weak (they drive you around the island in a bus with a cutsey canned speech) the second part is wonderful. A former political prisoner from Robben Island takes you around the prison and speaks of his own experiences there. This is quite powerful and emotional.

Go with a local group. As part of conference of librarians, my husband and I were given a tour of Robben Island. On the way over, the mood on the boat was festive until we got near the island. Then the faces of the local librarians, some of whom had had parents imprisoned there, took on a look of reverence, which stayed with me as we toured the island. The tour would have been moving even if we had just been with a group of foreign tourists. As it was, I remember the feeling I got as we landed every time I see one of the photos of our trip.

Dissapointing. The trip has so much potential but unfortunately it is rushed and guided from start to finish with no time to explore. The boat ride is great and the views fantastic, but you get more satisfaction from reading a history book. I recommend it only because Nelson Mandela was incarcerated there.

Africa 101--A Must See!. Cape Town is bustling with things to do. Walking along the pier, climbing Table Mountain, and wandering the streets with its great music shops and eateries. My favorite attraction was going out to Robben Island where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned. The tour guides are actually ex-prisoners and it makes the tour that much more impressionable. All of the guides were knowledgable and knew information above and beyond the standard tour banter. Very interesting. I was deeply moved and impressed these men could come back to the island and turn the experience into something educational. To share with the rest of us must be very difficult but I am thankful for the experience. Take a few days to check out this scene--good food, good jazz, good people!

An historic experience. A visit to Robben Island is a must when staying in Cape Town. The island is now a world heritage site and you can tell they are trying to preserve it's history for future generations.The trip comes in two parts - a bus tour round the island, (there are some magical pictures of Table Mountain to be taken from the end of the island). Followed by a guided tour around the inside of the prison, by a former prisoner - which was fascinating.The trip inspired us to buy Nelson Mandela's book - a long walk to freedom, which detailed what prison life was like on the Island and the political issues surrounding it's history. The book was also very helpful in giving more info on many of the people who had been mentioned briefly on the tour.The whole trip is very moving especially when you realise the Island only stopped being a prison in 1996!

Worth a visit but don't expect a museum. Had some very mixed feelings about my trip to Robben Island. I can break it down into pros and cons for anyone that might be interested in visiting.Pros:- If you are interested in the political history of South Africa, it is a must see, if only to pay homage to the political prisoners who were there for decades.- There are complimentary tours given by former political prisoners, giving great insight into what life was like on the island.- The island itself (beyond the prison) has a quirky history and has some great views of Cape Town and the coastline.Cons:- Book early and be flexible. We were there in the middle of winter and could only get a tour 5 days away. Book as soon as you arrive in Cape Town or beforehand if possible.- The boat only runs when conditions are perfect. Call ahead on the day of your tour as it may very well be canceled (even if the weather seems perfect). Furthermore, even on a clear day, the ride to and from is very choppy and may lead to see sickness.- For all of its historical value, the prison and grounds have not been "upgraded" into a tourist museum. Most everything is about how it was left when the prison was closed. Don't expect elaborate displays or a lot of explanatory exhibits.

Excellent trip!. we went in July this year, you arrive on the Island and head for waiting buses, we got on bus 1 which had the most fantastic guide on it! he gave us all the facts in the most interesting way possible and made it funny he was the same guide that had showed around Nelson Mandela on his trips back to the island and Obama and Hilary Clinton. the prison itself was ok i just wanted to see Mandelas Cell which was right at the end of the trip.

A Must DO!. You cant come to Cape Town without visiting Robben Island. Its worth the money you can take a look at the museum whilst waiting for the ferry, then you take a lovely 30min boat ride to the island with great views of Table Mountain from the sea. Once you arrive on the Island you will be taken on a bus ride and tour of the Island finishing with a guided tour of the prison. Our guide was an ex-prisoner who had been their with Nelson Mandela. It was so good to hear everything from his point of view.

Not just a place marked by Apartheid!. From the 17th to the 20th centuries, Robben Island served as a place of banishment, isolation (leprosy sufferers) and imprisonment yet in the minds of some it is a place marked by the Apartheid Era only, forgetting about the whites who too spend their lives their. I have to say that I joined on this tour with my Irish and American friends dreading another trip marking me as a White person as a "Bad Evil Person who Hates everyone of colour" I was amazed that this World Heritage Site and museum, showed a different side, yes the there is a poignant reminder to the newly democratic South Africa of the price paid for freedom but also the history of ALL those who dwelled on the Island against their will.The ferry ride there was very nice and the bus ride itself on the island was remarkable. Our guide was wonderful especially as he gave up his lunch break to take us around as a school group made it hard to find spots on the busses. Our guide at the prison was well informed and seemed to bear no grudges and told it "as it was"! That as well was appreciated.

Definitely worth the 3 hours. My family really enjoyed this tour. 25 minutes catamaran jet foil boat each way to the island followed by an excellent guided tour, with one of the tour guides an actual ex-political prisoner held on the island. See and learn about how Nelson Mandela turned his prison experience into a victory of life and cause. Book days ahead as this tour almost always sells out in advance. You can book and buy tickets on their website.

Not worth the time. My wife and I love sightseeing. We were both history/political science majors, so generally love this kind of thing. But I promise, it's not worth it (and the locals will admit it too btw). This takes four hours out of your valuable time in Cape Town for what's ultimately maybe 30 minutes of interesting viewing at Robben Island. There is a nice museum at the V&A waterfront that tells you more about Mandela's life in 15 minutes than you get on the four-hour visit to Robben Island. Trust me on this, it's not worth it. If you want to really understand South African culture and history, read the Wikipedia entry from home, and then spend half a day in South Africa visiting a township and seeing how real people live. We did this; you won't regret it.

An absolutely essential visit when in Cape Town. Robben Island is basically the reason I travelled half-way around the world to Cape Town. Specifics:Tickets: I was luckily warned before I came that buying tickets on-line and several weeks ahead of your visit is essential. Many people have a quick stay in Cape Town and leave bitterly disappointed that they are unable to see the Island. I would strongly suggest buying ahead of time which you can easily do on their website. Nelson Mandela Gateway: You depart on the ferry from here at 3-4 times during the day. The Gateway also houses rotating galleries and a permanent museum on the Aparthied Era that you can browse before/after your tour. Please see other reviews for discussion of weather problems, I was happy that this didn't occur then I was in town.The Island Tour: This is divided into three parts. The first is a tour of the prison itself with a talk from a political prisoner. From here everyone boards a bus and you take a tour of the island and learn a little of the history of Robben Island before and during the Apartheid Era. You are also taken by Robert Sobukwe's encampment, which for me was the highlight of a tour that seemed to be filled with them. The third part of the tour is a quick stop at the storefront where you can buy the requisite momentos.Summary: A visit here should be mandatory if you want to understand the country's past, present, and future. It also shed light on a previosuly unknown figure to me, Robert Sobukwe, who seems to have functioned as "Malcolm" to Mandela's "Martin" during the trying time of the 1960's. Overall, my trip to Robben Island was an unforgettable experience.

Made our trip!. I feel i must write-as most previous comments seem negative ( to do with the organization). Our trip was late setting off from Capetown, but when we arrived at robben island, we had an informative bus tour around the island, followed by a fantastic tour of the prison, by an x prisoner. He took us around the site, informing us of interesting facts, a very moving experience.It made our trip to SA.

Refund problem. I am experiencing the same nightmare as Flammicke trying to get a refund for a trip (for 4 people) that has been cancelled due to high winds.Desperately trying to get in touch with anyone over there, FOR MORE THAN THREE MONTHS and I just get no answer at all. I managed to get in touch with someone once, but after I sent her the right details of my credit card, I never got an answer back, and no refund has been made. Just silence at the other end. Besides, the money had already been withdrawn from my visa BEFORE the actual trip should have taken place!

A must see. My partner and I were in Cape Town in the March and booked our tickets a day in advance. We went down to the Waterfront (Nelson Mandela Gateway) and got the ferry across to Robben Island. The ferry journey was pleasant and we saw lots of seals and a few dolphins and different views of Table Mountain etc. Once on the lsland we got on a coach and had a half hour tour of the island visiting the lime quarry where prisoners worked, the leper church etc. Afetr the coach ride we were dropped at the main prison gates for a prison tour. Our guide was a former prisoner on the island. He told us his horrific story as we went and showed us the cell that Nelson Mandela was placed in, solitary cells, and the court yardIt was a very informative trip and well worth a visit.

Beware of weather conditions. I booked tickets for 2 friends arriving from the US almost 2 months in advance. When they arrived at the ferry terminal this morning, they were told all boats are cancelled until Saturday due to high winds. [They leave on Friday] They have been refused a refund, as "they don't have enough cash for refunds"- what rubbish! If you can take money from people, organise yourselves to give it back if you cannot deliver!!

an important attraction in Cape Town. After a 45 minute ferry ride, you arrive at Robben Island to be taken on a bus tour, and then a guided tour of the maximum security prison. The guides are former political prisoners (Mandela was incarcerated there for 18 years). It is a moving experience, and should not be missed. But your tickets in advance! We were there in early December, ant they had already sold out for the rest of the month.

Enlightening and Educational. I consider this a 'must do' for Cape Town. The highlight for me was that the prison tour was given by a former political prisoner. His name was Phinneas. It made the experience very real. He was very serious and somber - he did not smile the entire time. All who work on these tours actually live in the housing on the island formerly used by those who worked at the prison. I asked Phinneas why he chooses to stay there on the island and he said as long as there are people willing to come learn what happened there, he will stay there and keep telling his story.On a lighter note, the boat road to and from the island is very nice and the views from the boat and the island are specacular.

Far, far more than a holiday jaunt. This trip offers so much more than a fun day trip from the waterfront although the view of capetown from the boat is worthy of a tour in its own right. On the island the tour guide captivated his audience in the coach with the story not only of the fight against apartheid but also the wider history of the island. He skillfully blended his own experiences with the island history and, for us, hit just the right note between humour and reflection and between information and story telling . Our 12 year old son enjoyed it a lot as well. He had read a children's version of Mandela's life the day before which we had got online from Amazon before we left home and this background helped him to understand the signficance of the fight against apartheid . It made me think more than any event I have ever been too but the message was left for individuals to reflect on rather than it all being spelt out for you and thrust in your face. Very subtle, very moving, very humbling.

A Happy Ending. My partner and I visited Robben Island on 1st March 2006 during a four day stay to Cape Town. The trip out to the island is by powerful, diesel powered catamarans which leave from behind the Robben Island Museum at the Victoria and Albert waterfront. The crossing can be quite choppy depending on the weather and swell. If you are up on deck (and you may not have a choice depending on space available within) take something warm and spray-proof for the crossing. The visit to the island is in two parts. Firstly, on arrival, a bus trip, secondly a tour of the prison.The bus trip around the island lasts for about an hour and is extremely interesting, stopping at all points of interest, including the Lime Quarry where political prisoners were expected to work for 6 hours daily. Near the centre of the quarry is a pile of stones which has great significance since the first stone was placed down by Nelson Mandela during a visit with other former prisoners. Since then every former prisoner who visits has added a stone to the pile. It would have been nice to have had the opportunity to get off the bus at this point to photograph it, rather than trying to take photo's through the windows. Forget trying to video as the bus is swaying around a lot on the uneven quarry base.The highlight of the visit is without doubt the tour of the prison.The guides are former political prisoners who give a real insight in to the way of life for prisoners under apartheid. Prisoners including Nelson Mandella were regularly moved from cell to cell during their incarceration, but the cell considered to be Nelson's was the one he occupied during his last few years of imprisonment there.I agree entirely with a previous reviewer - this is not a trip for young children for two reasons. Firstly you need to be of a certain age to understand and appreciate the experience. Young children can become very bored, tired and irritable. The second reason is that once bored, tired and irritable they spoil the trip for those who are trying to pay attention to what is being said. At the end of the trip I felt privileged to have shaken the hand of our guide. I explained to him that I had once served in the Royal Navy and had made four short visits to Cape Town in the mid to late 60's during apartheid, and how embarrased and sorry we all were to have seen the way his people were treated, and that I was so pleased he and brave people like him had got, not only their freedom, but their country which was rightfully theirs.This is a 'must do' during a visit to Cape Town. Everybody does Table Mountain, far fewer make the trip to Robben Island. Be one of them, it's a very memorable and moving experience.

I was initially sceptical, but I'm a convert. Before I visited Cape Town my wife mentioned she wanted to visit Robben Island. I was fairly apathetic about this as coming from northern Europe, I had little exposure to South African politics or the struggles of the anti apartheid movement.This is a great place to visit, The tour starts with a boat trip out to the island - it takes about 30-40 minutes. You land on the island and get on an old school bus for an island tour that explains its history pre-Euro-settlement, as a prison and today. You will see where the prisoners were forced to work and live and where the people on the Island live now.The next part - the prison tour is the most interesting part. You will be met by an inmate that was incarcerated in the prison during apartheid. He will explain what life was like and you will be allowed to ask any questions you want. This is genuinely interesting and moving as you can see the emotion as your guide relives his time there.I would recommend this tour for adults and maybe teens, not for youg children though.

Make the time to take this tour. This is to second the earlier review posted by the traveller from Ireland. My wife and I spent three lovely days in Capetown (about enough) in September, 2005. The half day spent on the Robben Island tour was the highlight. Much more memorable than Table Mountain.

Way more than Madiba. This trip is really worthwhile, assuming the weather is OK for the boat trip. The boats depart from near the V&A Waterfront in the centre of Cape Town, and there is a small museum which you can browse after you buy your tickets, while waiting for the boat. It has a lot of hands-on exhibits, and gets you into the frame of mind, so that the boat trip itself becomes part of the overall experienceOnce on the island, there is a coach tour around the main sights, such as the lime quarry, the lighthouse etc. You can only look out the windows of the bus at most of these sights, so if you want to take pictures, try to get a seat beside a window which opens. I think sitting on the left side of the bus is best. You can get out and look around at the lighthouse, but sadly not near the house where Robert Sobukwe was detained. Back in the prison itself, there are guided tours, and you are also free to wander around at this point.The thing that strikes you is that while to non-Africans the island is synonymous with Mandela's incarceration there, it is in fact about far more than that. It has a longer and bloodier history, and this is brought home well during the tour. The tour-guides are mostly former political prisoners themselves, and speak from their own experience. There is a really good bookshop near the jetty where you get the boat back to Cape Town, where you can buy souvenirs, and also a decent selection of books about the struggle. Catering on board is minimal, so bring a bottle of water and perhaps a snack or two, especially if travelling with kids. And take a light raincoat in case of spray on the deck.All in all a moving and worthwhile experience, and a fabulous view of Cape Town across the bay. Highly recommended.
